
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Vavasor
and
His
Daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Whether
or
no
,
she
,
whom
you
are
to
forgive
,
if
you
can
,
did
or
did
not
belong
to
the
Upper
Ten
Thousand
of
this
our
English
world
,
I
am
not
prepared
to
say
with
any
strength
of
affirmation
.
<EOS>
By
blood
she
was
connected
with
big
people
,
 
distantly
connected
with
some
very
big
people
indeed
,
people
who
belonged
to
the
Upper
Ten
Hundred
if
there
be
any
such
division
;
but
of
these
very
big
relations
she
had
known
and
seen
little
,
and
they
had
cared
as
little
for
her
.
<EOS>
Her
grandfather
,
Squire
Vavasor
of
Vavasor
Hall
,
in
Westmoreland
,
was
a
country
gentleman
,
possessing
some
thousand
a
year
at
the
outside
,
and
he
therefore
never
came
up
to
London
,
and
had
no
ambition
to
have
himself
numbered
as
one
in
any
exclusive
set
.
<EOS>
A
hot
-
headed
,
ignorant
,
honest
old
gentleman
,
he
lived
ever
at
Vavasor
Hall
,
declaring
to
any
who
would
listen
to
him
,
that
the
country
was
going
to
the
mischief
,
and
congratulating
himself
that
at
any
rate
,
in
his
county
,
parliamentary
reform
had
been
powerless
to
alter
the
old
political
arrangements
.
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
,
whose
offence
against
the
world
I
am
to
tell
you
,
and
if
possible
to
excuse
,
was
the
daughter
of
his
younger
son
;
and
as
her
father
,
John
Vavasor
,
had
done
nothing
to
raise
the
family
name
to
eminence
,
Alice
could
not
lay
claim
to
any
high
position
from
her
birth
as
a
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
had
come
up
to
London
early
in
life
as
a
barrister
,
and
had
failed
.
<EOS>
He
had
failed
at
least
in
attaining
either
much
wealth
or
much
repute
,
though
he
had
succeeded
in
earning
,
or
perhaps
I
might
better
say
,
in
obtaining
,
a
livelihood
.
<EOS>
He
had
married
a
lady
somewhat
older
than
himself
,
who
was
in
possession
of
four
hundred
a
year
,
and
who
was
related
to
those
big
people
to
whom
I
have
alluded
.
<EOS>
Who
these
were
and
the
special
nature
of
the
relationship
,
I
shall
be
called
upon
to
explain
hereafter
,
but
at
present
it
will
suffice
to
say
that
Alice
Macleod
gave
great
offence
to
all
her
friends
by
her
marriage
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
,
however
,
give
them
much
time
for
the
indulgence
of
their
anger
.
<EOS>
Having
given
birth
to
a
daughter
within
twelve
months
of
her
marriage
,
she
died
,
leaving
in
abeyance
that
question
as
to
whether
the
fault
of
her
marriage
should
or
should
not
be
pardoned
by
her
family
.
  
<EOS>
When
a
man
marries
an
heiress
for
her
money
,
if
that
money
be
within
her
own
control
,
as
was
the
case
with
Miss
Macleod
's
fortune
,
it
is
generally
well
for
the
speculating
lover
that
the
lady
's
friends
should
quarrel
with
him
and
with
her
.
<EOS>
She
is
thereby
driven
to
throw
herself
entirely
into
the
gentleman
's
arms
,
and
he
thus
becomes
possessed
of
the
wife
and
the
money
without
the
abominable
nuisance
of
stringent
settlements
.
<EOS>
But
the
Macleods
,
though
they
quarrelled
with
Alice
,
did
not
quarrel
with
her
_
<EOS>
à
l'outrance
_
.
<EOS>
They
snubbed
herself
and
her
chosen
husband
;
but
they
did
not
so
far
separate
themselves
from
her
and
her
affairs
as
to
give
up
the
charge
of
her
possessions
.
<EOS>
Her
four
hundred
a
year
was
settled
very
closely
on
herself
and
on
her
children
,
without
even
a
life
interest
having
been
given
to
Mr.
Vavasor
,
and
therefore
when
she
died
the
mother
's
fortune
became
the
property
of
the
little
baby
.
<EOS>
But
,
under
these
circumstances
,
the
big
people
did
not
refuse
to
interest
themselves
to
some
extent
on
behalf
of
the
father
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
suppose
that
any
actual
agreement
or
compact
was
made
between
Mr.
Vavasor
and
the
Macleods
;
but
it
came
to
be
understood
between
them
that
if
he
made
no
demand
upon
them
for
his
daughter
's
money
,
and
allowed
them
to
have
charge
of
her
education
,
they
would
do
something
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
practising
barrister
,
though
his
practice
had
never
amounted
to
much
;
and
a
practising
barrister
is
always
supposed
to
be
capable
of
filling
any
situation
which
may
come
his
way
.
<EOS>
Two
years
after
his
wife
's
death
Mr.
Vavasor
was
appointed
assistant
commissioner
in
some
office
which
had
to
do
with
insolvents
,
and
which
was
abolished
three
years
after
his
appointment
.
<EOS>
It
was
at
first
thought
that
he
would
keep
his
eight
hundred
a
year
for
life
and
be
required
to
do
nothing
for
it
;
but
a
wretched
cheeseparing
Whig
government
,
as
John
Vavasor
called
it
when
describing
the
circumstances
of
the
arrangement
to
his
father
,
down
in
Westmoreland
,
would
not
permit
this
;
it
gave
him
the
option
of
taking
four
hundred
a
year
for
doing
nothing
,
or
of
keeping
his
whole
income
and
attending
three
days
a
week
for
three
hours
a
day
during
term
time
,
at
a
miserable
dingy
little
office
near
Chancery
Lane
,
where
his
duty
would
consist
in
signing
his
name
to
accounts
which
he
never
read
,
and
at
which
he
was
never
supposed
even
to
look
.
<EOS>
He
had
sulkily
elected
to
keep
the
money
,
and
this
signing
had
been
now
for
nearly
twenty
years
the
business
of
his
life
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
considered
himself
to
be
a
very
hardly
-
used
man
.
<EOS>
One
Lord
Chancellor
after
another
he
petitioned
,
begging
that
he
might
be
relieved
from
the
cruelty
of
his
position
,
and
allowed
to
take
his
salary
without
doing
anything
in
return
for
it
.
<EOS>
The
amount
of
work
which
he
did
perform
was
certainly
a
minimum
of
labour
.
<EOS>
Term
time
,
as
terms
were
counted
in
Mr.
Vavasor
's
office
,
hardly
comprised
half
the
year
,
and
the
hours
of
weekly
attendance
did
not
do
more
than
make
one
day
's
work
a
week
for
a
working
man
;
but
Mr.
Vavasor
had
been
appointed
an
assistant
commissioner
,
and
with
every
Lord
Chancellor
he
argued
that
all
Westminster
Hall
,
and
Lincoln
's
Inn
to
boot
,
had
no
right
to
call
upon
him
to
degrade
himself
by
signing
his
name
to
accounts
.
<EOS>
In
answer
to
every
memorial
he
was
offered
the
alternative
of
freedom
with
half
his
income
;
and
so
the
thing
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
There
can
,
however
,
be
no
doubt
that
Mr.
Vavasor
was
better
off
and
happier
with
his
almost
nominal
employment
than
he
would
have
been
without
it
.
<EOS>
He
always
argued
that
it
kept
him
in
London
;
but
he
would
undoubtedly
have
lived
in
London
with
or
without
his
official
occupation
.
<EOS>
He
had
become
so
habituated
to
London
life
in
a
small
way
,
before
the
choice
of
leaving
London
was
open
to
him
,
that
nothing
would
have
kept
him
long
away
from
it
.
<EOS>
After
his
wife
's
death
he
dined
at
his
club
every
day
on
which
a
dinner
was
not
given
to
him
by
some
friend
elsewhere
,
and
was
rarely
happy
except
when
so
dining
.
<EOS>
They
who
have
seen
him
scanning
the
steward
's
list
of
dishes
,
and
giving
the
necessary
orders
for
his
own
and
his
friend
's
dinner
,
at
about
half
past
four
in
the
afternoon
,
have
seen
John
Vavasor
at
the
only
moment
of
the
day
at
which
he
is
ever
much
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
All
other
things
are
light
and
easy
to
him
,
 
to
be
taken
easily
and
to
be
dismissed
easily
.
<EOS>
Even
the
eating
of
the
dinner
calls
forth
from
him
no
special
sign
of
energy
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
a
frown
will
gather
on
his
brow
as
he
tastes
the
first
half
glass
from
his
bottle
of
claret
;
but
as
a
rule
that
which
he
has
prepared
for
himself
with
so
much
elaborate
care
,
is
consumed
with
only
pleasant
enjoyment
.
<EOS>
Now
and
again
it
will
happen
that
the
cook
is
treacherous
even
to
him
,
and
then
he
can
hit
hard
;
but
in
hitting
he
is
quiet
,
and
strikes
with
a
smile
on
his
face
.
  
<EOS>
Such
had
been
Mr.
Vavasor
's
pursuits
and
pleasures
in
life
up
to
the
time
at
which
my
story
commences
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
not
allow
the
reader
to
suppose
that
he
was
a
man
without
good
qualities
.
<EOS>
Had
he
when
young
possessed
the
gift
of
industry
I
think
that
he
might
have
shone
in
his
profession
,
and
have
been
well
spoken
of
and
esteemed
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
he
was
a
discontented
man
,
but
nevertheless
he
was
popular
,
and
to
some
extent
esteemed
.
<EOS>
He
was
liberal
as
far
as
his
means
would
permit
;
he
was
a
man
of
his
word
;
and
he
understood
well
that
code
of
by
-
laws
which
was
presumed
to
constitute
the
character
of
a
gentleman
in
his
circle
.
<EOS>
He
knew
how
to
carry
himself
well
among
men
,
and
understood
thoroughly
what
might
be
said
,
and
what
might
not
;
what
might
be
done
among
those
with
whom
he
lived
,
and
what
should
be
left
undone
.
<EOS>
By
nature
,
too
,
he
was
kindly
disposed
,
loving
many
persons
a
little
if
he
loved
few
or
none
passionately
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
at
the
age
of
fifty
,
he
was
a
handsome
man
,
with
a
fine
forehead
,
round
which
the
hair
and
beard
was
only
beginning
to
show
itself
to
be
grey
.
<EOS>
He
stood
well
,
with
a
large
person
,
only
now
beginning
to
become
corpulent
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
bright
and
grey
,
and
his
mouth
and
chin
were
sharply
cut
,
and
told
of
gentle
birth
.
<EOS>
Most
men
who
knew
John
Vavasor
well
,
declared
it
to
be
a
pity
that
he
should
spend
his
time
in
signing
accounts
in
Chancery
Lane
.
  
<EOS>
I
have
said
that
Alice
Vavasor
's
big
relatives
cared
but
little
for
her
in
her
early
years
;
but
I
have
also
said
that
they
were
careful
to
undertake
the
charge
of
her
education
,
and
I
must
explain
away
this
little
discrepancy
.
<EOS>
The
biggest
of
these
big
people
had
hardly
heard
of
her
;
but
there
was
a
certain
Lady
Macleod
,
not
very
big
herself
,
but
,
as
it
were
,
hanging
on
to
the
skirts
of
those
who
were
so
,
who
cared
very
much
for
Alice
.
<EOS>
She
was
the
widow
of
a
Sir
Archibald
Macleod
,
K.C.B.
,
who
had
been
a
soldier
,
she
herself
having
also
been
a
Macleod
by
birth
;
and
for
very
many
years
past
 
from
a
time
previous
to
the
birth
of
Alice
Vavasor
 
<EOS>
she
had
lived
at
Cheltenham
,
making
short
sojourns
in
London
during
the
spring
,
when
the
contents
of
her
limited
purse
would
admit
of
her
doing
so
.
<EOS>
Of
old
Lady
Macleod
I
think
I
may
say
that
she
was
a
good
woman
;
 
that
she
was
a
good
woman
,
though
subject
to
two
of
the
most
serious
drawbacks
to
goodness
which
can
afflict
a
lady
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
Calvinistic
Sabbatarian
in
religion
,
and
in
worldly
matters
she
was
a
devout
believer
in
the
high
rank
of
her
noble
relatives
.
<EOS>
She
could
almost
worship
a
youthful
marquis
,
though
he
lived
a
life
that
would
disgrace
a
heathen
among
heathens
;
and
she
could
and
did
,
in
her
own
mind
,
condemn
crowds
of
commonplace
men
and
women
to
all
eternal
torments
of
which
her
imagination
could
conceive
,
because
they
listened
to
profane
music
in
a
park
on
Sunday
.
<EOS>
Yet
she
was
a
good
woman
.
<EOS>
Out
of
her
small
means
she
gave
much
away
.
<EOS>
She
owed
no
man
anything
.
<EOS>
She
strove
to
love
her
neighbours
.
<EOS>
She
bore
much
pain
with
calm
unspeaking
endurance
,
and
she
lived
in
trust
of
a
better
world
.
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
,
who
was
after
all
only
her
cousin
,
she
loved
with
an
exceeding
love
,
and
yet
Alice
had
done
very
much
to
extinguish
such
love
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
in
the
years
of
her
childhood
,
had
been
brought
up
by
Lady
Macleod
;
at
the
age
of
twelve
she
had
been
sent
to
a
school
at
Aix
-
la
-
Chapelle
,
 
a
comitatus
of
her
relatives
having
agreed
that
such
was
to
be
her
fate
,
much
in
opposition
to
Lady
Macleod
's
judgement
;
at
nineteen
she
had
returned
to
Cheltenham
,
and
after
remaining
there
for
little
more
than
a
year
,
had
expressed
her
unwillingness
to
remain
longer
with
her
cousin
.
<EOS>
She
could
sympathize
neither
with
her
relative
's
faults
or
virtues
.
<EOS>
She
made
an
arrangement
,
therefore
,
with
her
father
,
that
they
two
would
keep
house
together
in
London
,
and
so
they
had
lived
for
the
last
five
years
;
 
for
Alice
Vavasor
when
she
will
be
introduced
to
the
reader
had
already
passed
her
twenty
-
fourth
birthday
.
  
<EOS>
Their
mode
of
life
had
been
singular
and
certainly
not
in
all
respects
satisfactory
.
<EOS>
Alice
when
she
was
twenty
-
one
had
the
full
command
of
her
own
fortune
;
and
when
she
induced
her
father
,
who
for
the
last
fifteen
years
had
lived
in
lodgings
,
to
take
a
small
house
in
Queen
Anne
Street
,
of
course
she
offered
to
incur
a
portion
of
the
expense
.
<EOS>
He
had
warned
her
that
his
habits
were
not
those
of
a
domestic
man
,
but
he
had
been
content
simply
so
to
warn
her
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
felt
it
to
be
his
duty
to
decline
the
arrangement
because
he
knew
himself
to
be
unable
to
give
to
his
child
all
that
attention
which
a
widowed
father
under
such
circumstances
should
pay
to
an
only
daughter
.
<EOS>
The
house
had
been
taken
,
and
Alice
and
he
had
lived
together
,
but
their
lives
had
been
quite
apart
.
<EOS>
For
a
short
time
,
for
a
month
or
two
,
he
had
striven
to
dine
at

and

;
but
the
work
had
been
too
hard
for
him
<EOS>
and

.
<EOS>
He

that

under

so

and
I

.
<EOS>
At

,
and
Mr.
Vavasor
now
never

.
<EOS>
Nor

.
<EOS>
Their

not

,

<EOS>
It

,
 
quite

.
<EOS>
They

,

<EOS>
They

,
and
after

day
Mr.
Vavasor
was

.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Vavasor
had

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Young

<EOS>
Nor

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
Lady

,

A

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
.
 
<EOS>
I
can
not

that
the

Queen

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
It

on

,

which
seemed

,

.
<EOS>
The

were
narrow
;
the

was

,
and
possessed
none

.
<EOS>
But

would
have
been
as

if

had

as

.
<EOS>
But
Alice
Vavasor
's

.
<EOS>
Her

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

was

,

was

.
<EOS>
In

,
the

on

,

.
<EOS>
This

"
study
"

Vavasor
,

.
  
<EOS>
Most

know

room
whether

or

;
but
how

!
<EOS>
There
has

London
in

a

so

that
I

no

.
<EOS>
Londoners
,

,

,

<EOS>
What

,

,

<EOS>
This

we

,

,

"

,

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
Then

Vavasor
had

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

;

Lady
Macleod
was

in

.
<EOS>

,

,

,
Saint

,

Alice
Vavasor
,

.

"
Well
,

,
"

,

<EOS>
Alice

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

,
 
every

.
<EOS>

"

"

"

"

"

obedience
on
any
subject
,
"
said
Alice
;
and
as
she
spoke
Aunt
Macleod
jumped
up
with
a
little
start
at
the
vehemence
of
the
words
,
and
of
the
tone
in
which
they
were
expressed
.
<EOS>
She
had
heard
that
tone
before
,
and
might
have
been
used

it
;
but
,
nevertheless
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
present
he
has
no
right
to
my
obedience
on
any
subject
,
but
least
of
all
on
that
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His

he
may
give

,
but
I
am
quite
sure
he
will
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

that
I

with
my
cousin
George
I
shall
certainly

his
advice
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
I
should
be
careful
to

know
how

was

by
any

.
<EOS>
It

on

,
and
a
suspicion
of
which
I
can
not

to
be

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
,
as

,
got

and

about

.
<EOS>
When

she
stood

one

to

.
<EOS>
There

,

Lady
Macleod
was
deeply

how

,
which
,
as

's
nearest

,

utter
.
<EOS>
At

collected

and
her

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Alice
,
I
need
hardly
say
that
if
you
had

mother

,
or

with
you

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

,
Aunt
Macleod
,

you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
think
you
are
wrong
,
 
very

,

;
and
if
you

in
this
I
am

I
must

I

.
<EOS>
Of

Mr.
Grey
can
not

to

George
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

,

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
,

,

Macleod
boldly
.
<EOS>
She

,

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why

,
Alice
?
<EOS>
Surely

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
How

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

Grey
,

.
<EOS>
Two

had
 
<EOS>
had
 
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Papa

,

"
  
<EOS>
Lady

<EOS>
She

,

.

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I
sha

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Alice

,

.
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>
"
God

,

.
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
I
'll

.
<EOS>
"
There
was

.
<EOS>
But

felt
that
words
had

which
must

past

.
  
<EOS>
When

an
hour
thinking
of
what
had
passed
between
them
,
 
thinking
rather
of
those
two
men
,
the

and

,
whose

had

.
<EOS>
John
Grey
was
a
worthy

,
a
man

,
as
far

she

.
<EOS>
She
told

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

her

George
was
wild
,
 
very

.
<EOS>
And

were
,

,
on
the

more

than

.
<EOS>
She
had

to

aunt
that
John
Grey
would
be

such

as
would

.
<EOS>
She

,
and
had

;
and
yet

over
the
position
which
her
affairs
would
take
,
if

the

.
<EOS>
She
told

over

,
that

she
would
not
give
way
an
inch
.
"
<EOS>
He
is
free
to
go
,
"
she
said

.
<EOS>
"
If
he
does
not
trust
me
he
is
quite
free
to
go
.
<EOS>
"
It
may
almost
be
said
that
she
came

to

from
her
lover
that
very
answer
to
her
own
letter
which

had
declared

to
be

.
   
<EOS>
John
Grey
,
the
Worthy
Man
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
's
answer
to
Alice
Vavasor
's
letter
,
which
was
duly
sent
by
return
of
post
and
duly
received
on
the
morning
after
Lady
Macleod
's
visit
,
may
perhaps
be
taken
as
giving
a
sample
of
his
worthiness
.
<EOS>
It
was
dated
from
Nethercoats
,
a
small
country
-
house
in
Cambridgeshire
which
belonged
to
him
,
at
which
he
already
spent
much
of
his
time
,
and
at
which
he
intended
to
live
altogether
after
his
marriage
.
  
<EOS>
Nethercoats
,
June
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
DEAREST
ALICE
,
  
<EOS>
I
am
glad
you
have
settled
your
affairs
,
 
foreign
affairs
,
I
mean
,
 
so
much
to
your
mind
.
<EOS>
As
to
your
home
affairs
they
are
not
,
to
my
thinking
,
quite
so
satisfactorily
arranged
.
<EOS>
But
as
I
am
a
party
interested
in
the
latter
<EOS>
my
opinion
may
perhaps
have
an
undue
bias
.
<EOS>
Touching
the
tour
,
I
quite
agree
with
you
that
you
and
Kate
would
have
been
uncomfortable
alone
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
very
fine
theory
,
that
of
women
being
able
to
get
along
without
men
as
well
as
with
them
;
but
,
like
other
fine
theories
,
it
will
be
found
very
troublesome
by
those
who
first
put
it
in
practice
.
<EOS>
Gloved
hands
,
petticoats
,
feminine
softness
,
and
the
general
homage
paid
to
beauty
,
all
stand
in
the
way
of
success
.
<EOS>
These
things
may
perhaps
some
day
be
got
rid
of
,
and
possibly
with
advantage
;
but
while
young
ladies
are
still
encumbered
with
them
a
male
companion
will
always
be
found
to
be
a
comfort
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
quite
know
whether
your
cousin
George
is
the
best
possible
knight
you
might
have
chosen
.
<EOS>
I
should
consider
myself
to
be
infinitely
preferable
,
had
my
going
been
upon
the
cards
.
<EOS>
Were
you
in
danger
of
meeting
Paynim
foes
,
he
,
no
doubt
,
would
kill
them
off
much
quicker
than
I
could
do
,
and
would
be
much
more
serviceable
in
liberating
you
from
the
dungeons
of
oppressors
,
or
even
from
stray
tigers
in
the
Swiss
forests
.
<EOS>
But
I
doubt
his
being
punctual
with
the
luggage
.
<EOS>
He
will
want
you
or
Kate
to
keep
the
accounts
,
if
any
are
kept
.
<EOS>
He
will
be
slow
in
getting
you
glasses
of
water
at
the
railway
stations
,
and
will
always
keep
you
waiting
at
breakfast
.
<EOS>
I
hold
that
a
man
with
two
ladies
on
a
tour
should
be
an
absolute
slave
to
them
,
or
they
will
not
fully
enjoy
themselves
.
<EOS>
He
should
simply
be
an
upper
servant
,
with
the
privilege
of
sitting
at
the
same
table
with
his
mistresses
.
<EOS>
I
have
my
doubts
as
to
whether
your
cousin
is
fit
for
the
place
;
but
,
as
to
myself
,
it
is
just
the
thing
that
I
was
made
for
.
<EOS>
Luckily
,
however
,
neither
you
nor
Kate
are
without
wills
of
your
own
,
and
perhaps
you
may
be
able
to
reduce
Mr.
Vavasor
to
obedience
.
  
<EOS>
As
to
the
home
affairs
I
have
very
little
to
say
here
,
 
in
this
letter
.
<EOS>
I
shall
of
course
run
up
and
see
you
before
you
start
,
and
shall
probably
stay
a
week
in
town
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
ought
not
to
do
so
,
as
it
will
be
a
week
of
idleness
,
and
yet
not
a
week
of
happiness
.
<EOS>
I
'd
sooner
have
an
hour
with
you
in
the
country
than
a
whole
day
in
London
.
<EOS>
And
I
always
feel
in
town
that
I
've
too
much
to
do
to
allow
of
my
doing
anything
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
sheer
idleness
I
could
enjoy
it
,
but
it
is
a
feverish
idleness
,
in
which
one
is
driven
here
and
there
,
expecting
some
gratification
which
not
only
never
comes
,
but
which
never
even
begins
to
come
.
<EOS>
I
will
,
however
,
undergo
a
week
of
it
,
 
say
the
last
seven
days
of
this
month
,
and
shall
trust
to
you
to
recompense
me
by
as
much
of
yourself
as
your
town
doings
will
permit
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
again
as
to
those
home
affairs
.
<EOS>
If
I
say
nothing
now
I
believe
you
will
understand
why
I
refrain
.
<EOS>
You
have
cunningly
just
left
me
to
imply
,
from
what
you
say
,
that
all
my
arguments
have
been
of
no
avail
;
but
you
do
not
answer
them
,
or
even
tell
me
that
you
have
decided
.
<EOS>
I
shall
therefore
imply
nothing
,
and
still
trust
to
my
personal
eloquence
for
success
.
<EOS>
Or
rather
not
trust
,
 
not
trust
,
but
hope
.
  
<EOS>
The
garden
is
going
on
very
well
.
<EOS>
We
are
rather
short
of
water
,
and
therefore
not
quite
as
bright
as
I
had
hoped
;
but
we
are
preparing
with
untiring
industry
for
future
brightness
.
<EOS>
Your
commands
have
been
obeyed
in
all
things
,
and
Morrison
always
says
"
The
mistress
did
n't
mean
this
,
"
or
"
The
mistress
did
intend
that
.
"
<EOS>
God
bless
the
mistress
is
what
I
now
say
,
and
send
her
home
,
to
her
own
home
,
to
her
flowers
,
and
her
fruit
,
and
her
house
,
and
her
husband
,
as
soon
as
may
be
,
with

<EOS>
That

.
  
<EOS>
Yours

always
,
  
J.
G.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

if
you
love
me
 
"
  
"
I
do
love
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
should
you
not
wish
to
come
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
wish

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
Alice
,
you
must

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
person

a

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Instantly
!
<EOS>
Come
;
I
have
not

hard

.
<EOS>
This
is

.
<EOS>
Will

middle

,

?
<EOS>
Is

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
but
it
is
,
love
.
<EOS>
Grant

,
and
I
will
swear
that
you
have

.
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
silent
,
having
things
to
say
but
not
knowing
in
what
words
to
put
them
.
<EOS>
Now
that
he
was
with
her
she
could
not
say
the
things
which
she
had
told
herself
that
she
would
utter
to

.
<EOS>
She
could
not
bring

to
hint

him
that
his
views

were
so
unlike
her
own
,
that

no

between

,
unless

could

to

.
<EOS>
No
man
could
be
more
gracious
in

than
John
Grey
;
no
man
more
chivalrous
in

;

as

,
without

,

.
<EOS>
When

came

,

,

?
<EOS>
This
she
had
meant
to
say
to
him
on
this

;
but
now
that
he
was
with

she
could
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
John
,
"
she

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

will
say

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not

now
;
 
indeed
,

.
<EOS>
That

I

not

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will

"
  
"
Never
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
press
her
further
then
,
but

and

.
   
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
,
the
Wild
Man
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
no
doubt
be
understood
that
George
Vavasor
did
not
roam
about
in
the
woods
unshorn
,
or
wear
leathern
trappings
and
sandals
,
like
Robinson
Crusoe
,
instead
of
coats
and
trousers
.
<EOS>
His
wildness
was
of
another
kind
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
do
n't
know
that
he
was
in
truth
at
all
wild
,
though
Lady
Macleod
had
called
him
so
,
and
Alice
had
assented
to
her
use
of
the
word
.
  
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
had
lived
in
London
since
he
was
twenty
,
and
now
,
at
the
time
of
the
beginning
of
my
story
,
he
was
a
year
or
two
over
thirty
.
<EOS>
He
was
and
ever
had
been
the
heir
to
his
grandfather
's
estate
;
but
that
estate
was
small
,
and
when
George
first
came
to
London
his
father
was
a
strong
man
of
forty
,
with
as
much
promise
of
life
in
him
as
his
son
had
.
<EOS>
A
profession
had
therefore
been
absolutely
necessary
to
him
;
and
he
had
,
at
his
uncle
<EOS>
John
's
instance
,
been
placed
in
the
office
of
a
parliamentary
land
agent
.
<EOS>
With
this
parliamentary
land
agent
he
had
quarrelled
to
the
knife
,
but
not
before
he
had
by
his
talents
made
himself
so
useful
that
he
had
before
him
the
prospects
of
a
lucrative
partnership
in
the
business
.
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
had
many
faults
,
but
idleness
 
absolute
idleness
 
was
not
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
He
would
occasionally
postpone
his
work
to
pleasure
.
<EOS>
He
would
be
at
Newmarket
when
he
should
have
been
at
Whitehall
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
usual
with
him
to
be
in
bed
when
he
should
be
at
his
desk
,
and
when
he
was
at
his
desk
he
did
not
whittle
his
ruler
,
or
pick
his
teeth
,
or
clip
his
nails
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
whole
his
friends
were
pleased
with
the
first
five
years
of
his
life
in
London
 
in
spite
of
his
having
been
found
to
be
in
debt
on
more
than
one
occasion
.
<EOS>
But
his
debts
had
been
paid
;
and
all
was
going
on
swimmingly
,
when
one
day
he
knocked
down
the
parliamentary
agent
with
a
blow
between
the
eyes
,
and
then
there
was
an
end
of
that
.
<EOS>
He
himself
was
wo
nt
to
say
that
he
had
known
very
well
what
he
was
about
,
that
it
had
behoved
him
to
knock
down
the
man
who
was

partner
,
and
that

regretted

.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
the
deed
was
looked
upon
with
approving

by
many
men
of
good
standing
,
 
or
,
at
any
rate
,
sufficient
standing
to
help
George
to
another
position
;
and
within
six
weeks
of
the
time
of
his
leaving
the
office
at
Whitehall
,
he
had
become
a
partner
in
an
established
firm

wine

.
<EOS>
A
great
-
aunt
had
just
then
left
him
a
couple
of
thousand
pounds
,
which
no
doubt
assisted
him
in
his
views
with
the
wine
merchants
.
  
<EOS>
In
this
employment
he
remained
for
another
period
of
five
years
,
and
was
supposed
by
all
his
friends
to
be
doing
very
well
.
<EOS>
And
indeed
he
did
not
do
badly
,
only
that
he
did
not
do
well
enough
to

.
<EOS>
He
was
ambitious
of
making
the
house
to
which
he
belonged
the
first
house
in
the
trade
in
London
,
and
scared
his
partners
by
the
boldness
and
extent
of
his
views
.
<EOS>
He
himself
declared
that
if
they
would
only
have
gone
along
with
him
he
would
have
made
them
princes
in
the
wine
market
.
<EOS>
But
they
were
men
either
of
more
prudence
or

than
he
,
and
they
declined
to
walk
in
his

.
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
the
five
years
Vavasor
left
the
house
,
not
having
knocked
any
one
down
on
this
occasion
,
and
taking
with
him
a
very
nice

money
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
last
of
these
five
years
had
certainly

the
best

of
his
life
,
for
he
had
really
worked
very

,
like

,
giving

took
time
from
him
,
 
and
giving

most

which
were

on

.
<EOS>
He
went
to
no
races
,
played
no

,
and
spoke
of
Cremorne
as
a
childish
thing
,
which
he
had
abandoned
now
that

was

.
<EOS>
It
was
during
these
two
years
that
he
had
had
his
love

;
and
it

that
he
had
,

rate
,

.
<EOS>
He
had
,
however
,
behaved
very
badly
to
Alice
,
and
the
match
had
been
broken
off
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
also
during
the
last
two
years
quarrelled
with
his
grandfather
.
<EOS>
He
had
wished
to
raise
a
sum
of
money
on
the
Vavasor
estate
,
which
,
as

was

,
he
could
only
do
with

grandfather
's

.
<EOS>
The
old
gentleman
would
not
hear
of
it
,
 
would
listen

no

to
the

.
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
that
George
attempted
to
make
the
squire

that
the
wine
business
was
going
on

well
,
that
he
himself
owed
no

anything
,
that

with

;
 
but
that
his
trade
might

by

.
<EOS>
Old
Mr.
Vavasor
was
furious
.
<EOS>
No
documents
and
no

could
make

lay

a

that

wine

,

,

.
<EOS>
No

would

!
<EOS>
So

had

,
and
had

.
"
<EOS>
He

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
But
I
'll
tie

up
so
that

sha

a

on

.
"
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
perhaps
thought
that
the
old
rule
of
primogeniture
might
under
such

have
been
judiciously
abandoned
 
in
this

,

.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
say

.
<EOS>
Nor
would

have
said

had

a
chance
of
his
doing

with

.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
from
whom
no
very
noble
deed
could
be
expected
;
but
he
was
also
one
who
would
do
no
ignoble
deed
.
  
<EOS>
After
that
George
Vavasor
had
become
a
stockbroker
,
and
a
stockbroker
he
was
now
.
<EOS>
In
the
first

months
after
his

,
 
the

the
first

after

Alice
,
 
he
had
gone
back
greatly
in
the

of

.
<EOS>
He
had
lived
in
open
defiance
of
decency
.
<EOS>
He
had
spent
much
money
and
had
apparently
made
none
,
and
had
been
,
as
all
his
friends
declared
,
on
the
high
road
to

.
<EOS>
Aunt
Macleod
had
taken
her

from
this

of
his

when
she
had
spoken
of
him
as
a
man
who
never
did
anything
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
come
forth
again
suddenly
as
a
working
man
;
and
now
they
who
professed
to
know
,
declared
that
he
was
by
no

.
<EOS>
He
was
in
the
City
every
day
;
and
during
the
last
two
years
had
earned
the
character
of
a
shrewd
fellow
who
knew
what
he
was
about
,
who
might

in

,
but

was

.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
he
stood
well
on
"
Change
.
  
<EOS>
And
during
these
two
years
he
had
stood
a
contest
for
a
seat
in
Parliament
,
having
striven
to
represent
the
metropolitan
borough
of
Chelsea
,
on
the

Radical
interest
.
<EOS>
It
is
true
that
he
had
failed
,
and
that
he
had
spent

sum
of
money
in

.
<EOS>
"
Where
on
earth
does
your
nephew
get
his
money
?
<EOS>
"
men

John
Vavasor
at

.
"
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
He
does
n't
get
it
from
me
,
and
I
'm

he
does
n't

it
from
my
father
.
"
<EOS>
But
George
Vavasor
,
though
he
failed
at
Chelsea
,
did
not
spend
his
money
altogether
fruitlessly
.
<EOS>
He
gained

by
the

,
and
men
came
to
speak
of
him
as

were
one
who
would

.
<EOS>
He
was
a

,
a

,
and
yet
he
was
the
heir
to
a
fine

,
which
had
come
down
from
father

son
for
four
hundred

!
<EOS>
There
was
something
captivating
about
his
history
and

,
especially
as
just
at
the
time
of
the
election
he
became
engaged
to
an
heiress
,
who
died
a

before

.
<EOS>
She
died
without
a
will
,
and
her
money
all
went
to
some
third
cousins
.
  
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
bore
this
last

like
a
man
,
and
it
was
at
this
time
that
he
again
became
fully

.
<EOS>
Previous

had
met
;
and
Alice
,

<EOS>
Kate
's

,
had
induced

to

.
<EOS>
But

had

no

.
<EOS>
Alice
had
given
her

to
her

's

with

heiress
,
Miss
Grant
,
telling
Kate
that
such

engagement
was
the
very
thing
to
put
him
thoroughly
on

feet
.
<EOS>
And
then
she
had
been
much

by
his
spirit
at
that

election
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
grand
of
him
,

?
"
said

,
her

brimming
full
of

.
<EOS>
"
It
was
very
spirited
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
knew
all
,
you
would
say

.
<EOS>
They
could
get
no
one
else
to
stand
but
that
Mr.
Travers
,
and
he
would
n't
come
forward
,
unless

.
"
<EOS>
"
I
hope

George
much
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
It
did
,
though
;
nearly
all
he
had
got
.
<EOS>
But
what
matters
?
<EOS>
Money
's
nothing
to
him
,
except
for
its
uses
.
<EOS>
My
own
little
mite
is
my
own
now
,
and
he
shall
have
every

of
it
for
the
next
election
,
even

I

go

.
<EOS>
"
There
must

great
about
George
Vavasor
,

his
sister
Kate
.
  
<EOS>
Early
in
the
present
spring
,
before
the
arrangements
for
the
Swiss
journey
were
made
,
George
Vavasor
had
spoken
to
Alice
about
that
intended
marriage
which
had
been
broken
off
by
the
lady
's
death
.
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
one
evening
with
his
cousin
in
the
drawing

room
in
Queen
Anne
Street
,
waiting
for
Kate
,
who
was
to
join

there
before

to
some

.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
Kate
had
had
a
hint
from
her
brother
to
be
late
!
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
the
two
were
together
for
an
hour
,
and
the
talk
had
been
all
about
himself
.
<EOS>
He
had
congratulated
her
on
her

Mr.
Grey
,
which
had
just

known
to
him
,
and
had
then
spoken
of
his
own
last
intended
marriage
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
grieved
for
her
,
"
he
said
,
"
greatly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
you
did
,
George
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
did
;
 
for
her
,
herself
.
<EOS>
Of
course
the
world
has
given
me

for
lamenting

loss
of
her

.
<EOS>
But
the

,
that
as

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"
  
"

;
 
even

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
why

?
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
not

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

you

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
George
!
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
As

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

better
.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
And

,
and
in

her
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
Poor

!
<EOS>
she

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Money

,

.
<EOS>
It
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

I

.
<EOS>
But

who

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Goodness

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

.
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
You

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

're

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
What

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
That
's
what
I
mean
by
tossing
up
every
day
for
every

that
I
have
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
did
not

,

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

.
<EOS>
She

,

I

.
<EOS>
And

had

:

that

.
  
<EOS>
In

of

he
had
spoken
of

as
being
ugly
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
generally

been
called
ugly
by
women
,
had
not
one

been

,
which
in

,

to

.
<EOS>
That
black
ravine
running
through

was

.
<EOS>
On

,
when
he

,

;
for

that

,

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
He

himself
 
making

,
"

.
<EOS>
But

George
's
face
was
not

,
and
might

women
.
<EOS>
His
hair
was
black
,
and
was

.
<EOS>
His

,
though
low
,
was
broad
.
<EOS>
His

were
dark
and
bright
,
and
his

were
very
full
,
and

black
.
<EOS>
At

of
his
anger
,
all
his
face
which
was

,
was
eye
and

.
<EOS>
He
wore
a
thick
black
moustache
,
which
covered
his
mouth
,
but
no

.
<EOS>
People
said
of
him
that
he
was
so

of
his
wound
that
he
would
not

to

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

that
no

could

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
story
of
that
wound
should
be
told
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
yet
hardly

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
A

,

,
 
<EOS>

,
George

flew

.
<EOS>
Two

.
<EOS>
George
's

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
George

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
was
rather
low

,
but
well

,
with

,

<EOS>
He

;

.
<EOS>
Since

had

,

Volunteers
,

had

.
  
<EOS>
Such
had
been

of
George
Vavasor
,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

;

I

Vavasors
<EOS>
Mrs.

.
<EOS>
But

's

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
That

"

,

"

.
<EOS>
When

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
George
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
she

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
what

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

.
<EOS>
Of

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

interfere
 
"
  
"
She

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

,

"
   
<EOS>
The
Balcony
at
Basle
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
not

describe
the
Vavasors
"
Swiss
tour
.
<EOS>
It
would
not

fair

.
"
<EOS>
Six
Weeks
in

Bernese
Oberland
,
by

,
"
would
have

,

I

.
<EOS>
It
is

I
have

,

course
of
writing
very

.
<EOS>
But
I
dismiss

temptation
,
strong
as
it
is
.
<EOS>
_
Retro
age
,
Satanas
.
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
No
living
man
or
woman
any
longer
wants
to
be
told
anything
of
the
Grimsell
or
of
the
Gemmi
.
<EOS>
Ludgate
Hill
is
now
-
a
-
days
more
interesting
than
the
Jungfrau
.
  
<EOS>
The
Vavasors
were
not
very
energetic
on
their
tour
.
<EOS>
As
George
had
said
,
they
had
gone
out
for
pleasure
and
not
for
work
.
<EOS>
They
went
direct
to
Interlaken
and
then
hung
about
between
that
place
and
Grindelwald
and
Lauterbrunnen
,
It
delighted
him
to
sit
still
on
some
outer

,
looking
at
the
mountains
,
with
a
cigar
in
his
mouth
,
and
it
seemed
to
delight
them
to
be
with
him
.
<EOS>
Much
that
Mr.
Grey
prophesied
had
come
true
.
<EOS>
The
two
girls
were
ministers
to

,
instead

having

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

those

club

,
"

,
"
and
how

the
sort

from
mountains
.
<EOS>
But
they
're
mistaken
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

why

need

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
they
are

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
They
rob
the

of
their

,
which

.
<EOS>
Mont
Blanc
can
have
no

for

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

;

;
 
but
that
avoids

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>

down

.
<EOS>
But

did
,
that
avoids

also
.
<EOS>
The

and

of
the
mountains
are
lost

familiar

their
details
,
not
the
less
because

.
<EOS>
In
this
world
things
are
beautiful
only
because

not

,
or
not

.
<EOS>
Poetry
is
precious
chiefly
because
it
suggests

.
<EOS>
Look
in
there
,
through
that

,
where

.
<EOS>
Are

;
 
beautiful

,

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

'm

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
During

<EOS>
Alice

,

.
<EOS>

;
and

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
And

had

,

thought

.
<EOS>
But
men
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
George

had

.
  
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
The

,

;

.
<EOS>
The

here

;
and

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

,

.

<EOS>
Alice
and
George
were
left
together

.
<EOS>
They
had
been
alone
together
before
many
times
since
their
travels
had
commenced
;
but
they
both
of
them
felt
that
there
was
something
to

in

.
<EOS>
There
was
something
that
each
felt
to
be
sweet
,
undefinable
,
and

.
<EOS>
Alice
had
known
that
it
would

better
for
her
to
go
up
-
stairs

Kate
;
but
Kate
's

been

such

that
had

gone
she
would
have
shown
that

had

for

.
<EOS>
Why
should
she
show
such
a
need
?
<EOS>
Or
why
,
indeed
,
should
she
entertain
it
?
  
<EOS>
Alice
was
seated
quite
at
the
end
of
the
gallery
,
and
Kate
's
chair
was
at
her
feet
in
the
corner
.
<EOS>
When
Alice
and
Kate
had
seated

,
the

had

a

for
the

-

,
and
George
had
placed
his

.
<EOS>
So
that
Alice
was
,
as
it
were
,
a

.
<EOS>
She
could
not
slip
away
without
some
special
preparation
for
going
,
and
Kate
had
so
placed
her
chair
in

,
that

actually

George

before

.
<EOS>
But
why
should

?
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
more
lovely
and

than
the

.
<EOS>
The
night
had
come
on
,
with
quick
but
still
unperceived
approach
,
as
it
does
in
those
parts
;
for
the
twilight
there
is
not
prolonged
as
it
is
with
us
more
northern
folk
.
<EOS>
The
night
had
come
on
,
but
there
was
a
rising
moon
,
which
just
sufficed
to
give
a
sheen
to
the
water
beneath
her
.
<EOS>
The
air
was
deliciously
soft
;
 
of
that
softness
which
produces
no
sensation
either
of
warmth
or
cold
,
but
which
just
seems
to
touch
one
with
loving
tenderness
,
as
though
the
unseen
spirits
of
the
air
kissed
one
's
forehead
as
they
passed
on

.
<EOS>
The
Rhine
was
running
at
her
feet
,
so
near
,
that
in
the
soft
half
light
it
seemed
as
though
she
might
step
into
its
ripple
.
<EOS>
The
Rhine
was
running
by
with
that
delicious
sound
of
rapidly
moving
waters
,
that
fresh
refreshing
gurgle
of
the
river
,
which
is
so
delicious
to
the
ear
at
all
times
.
<EOS>
If
you
be
talking
,
it
wraps
up
your
speech
,
keeping
it
for
yourselves
,
making
it
difficult
neither
to
her
who
listens
nor
to
him
who
speaks
.
<EOS>
If
you
would
sleep
,
it
is
of
all
lullabies
the
sweetest
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
alone
and
would
think
,
it
aids
all
your
thoughts
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
alone
,
and
,
alas
!
<EOS>
would
not
think
,
 
if
thinking
be
too
painful
,
 
it
will
dispel
your
sorrow
,
and
give
the
comfort
which
music
alone
can
give
.
<EOS>
Alice
felt
that
the
air
kissed
her
,
that
the
river
sang
for
her
its
sweetest
song
,
that
the
moon
shone
for

with
its

light
,
 
that
light
which
lends
the

of
half
-

to

that
it

.
<EOS>
Why
should
she
leave
it
?
  
<EOS>
Nothing
was

for
some

Kate

,

shake
from

that

.
<EOS>
Vavasor

,

<EOS>
Alice

;
but
<EOS>

,
 
a

,
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
When
are

to

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
George
!
"

.
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

?

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

;

.
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.

Alice

<EOS>

"

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
,

,

,

,
little

;

.
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

!
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
But

on
brandy
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,

.
<EOS>
"

"

;

.
<EOS>
"

"
Who

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

Grey
's
wife
<EOS>

,
 
could

.
<EOS>
I

,

;

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,
ay
,

.
<EOS>
It

;

.
<EOS>
Alice
,

.
<EOS>
You
would
starve

,

perish
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
spoken
with
great

,
but

,
having

,

.
<EOS>
She
was
looking
full

;
and
,

I
have

,
that
scar
and
his

and

seemed

.
<EOS>
But

scar
had
never
been

.
<EOS>
She
knew
the
story
,
and
when
he
was
her
lover
she

taken

in
the
mark

the

.
<EOS>
She
looked
at
him
,
but
though
he
paused
she
did
not

.
<EOS>
The
music
of
the
river
was
still
in
her
ears
,
and
there
came
upon
her
a

as

were

to
understand

song
.
<EOS>
Were
the
waters
also
telling
her
of
the
mistake
she
had
made
in

Mr.
Grey
as
her

?
<EOS>
What
her
cousin
was
now
telling
her
,
 
was

not
a
repetition
of
words
which
she
had
spoken

of
times
during
the
last

months
?
<EOS>
Was
she
not
telling
herself
daily
,
 
hourly
,
 
always
,
 
in
every
thought
of
her
life
,
that
in
accepting
Mr.
Grey
she
had
assumed
herself
to
be
mistress
of
virtues
which
she
did
not
possess
?
<EOS>
Had
she
not
,
in
truth
,
rioted
upon
brandy
,
till
the
innocence
of
milk
was
unfitted
for
her
?
<EOS>
This
man
now
came
and
rudely
told
her
all
this
,
 
but
did
he
not
tell
her
the
truth
?
<EOS>
She
sat
silent
and
convicted
;
only
gazing
into
his
face
when
his
speech
was
done
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
learned
this
since
we
have
been
again
together
,
Alice
;
and
finding
you
,
not
the
angel
I
had
supposed
,
finding
you
to
be
the
same
woman
I
had
once
loved
,
 
the
safety

I

has
not

to

.
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
<EOS>
Here
's
Kate
,
and
now
we
'll
go
for
our
walk
.
"
   
<EOS>
The
Bridge
over
the
Rhine
.
 
<EOS>
"
George
,
"
said
Kate
,
speaking
before
she
quite
got
up
to

,
"
will
you
tell

whether
you
have
been
preparing
all
your
things
for
an
open
sale
by
auction
?
<EOS>
"
Then
she
stole
a

at
Alice
,
and
having
learned
from
that

that
something
had

which
prevented

from

in
her

,
she
went

with

herself

,
as

to
cover

's
confusion
,
and

her
time
to
rally
before

should
all

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Would
you
believe
it
?
<EOS>
he
had
three
razors
laid
out
on
his
table
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
A
man
must
shave
,
 
even
at
Basle
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But

three

;

,

,

,

,

,
 
all

.
<EOS>
I
can
only
suppose

.
<EOS>
I
have

;

,

you

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

we

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

;

<EOS>
"

"
Come

,
"

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>

and
Kate

,

,

.
<EOS>
Kate

,

,
so

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He
followed

at

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you

,
"

Kate
,
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;
 
that

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
That

.

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

wo

,

,
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

dare

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

's

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Of

Aunt

,

;

have
n't

.
<EOS>
Fancy

with

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should

.
<EOS>
Aunt
Greenow

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She

,

's

.
<EOS>
You
've

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

.
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
And

,

?
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
Of

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I

;

.
<EOS>
And

;

<EOS>
Her

.
<EOS>
They

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Do

.
"
  
<EOS>
Then

and

.
<EOS>
"
Come

,
George
,
"

;

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Did

?
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
The
water
looks

,

so

!
<EOS>
The
sea
at
Yarmouth
wo
n't

anything
like
that
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
Neither

them
any

,
and
yet

went

about

,
and

aunt
,
and
her

.
<EOS>
Neither

them
answered
her
,
and
yet

that
they
had

say

.
<EOS>
But

stood
there

,
and
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
Kate
's
voice
was
to

,
preventing

which
might
otherwise

arisen
that

were
too
full
for
speech
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
Alice
seemed
to
shiver
.
<EOS>
There

slight

in

arms
,
which
George
felt

than

.
<EOS>
"
You
are
cold
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
are
let

in
.
<EOS>
I

shivered

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was

.
<EOS>
I
was

something
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
ever
think

things

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
do
,

;
 
so

that
I

inwardly
.
<EOS>
Otherwise
people
would
think
I
had
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Little

things
make

;
 
perhaps

that
I

and

;
 
the

ordinary

,
even
my
own
past
thoughts
to
myself
about

trifles
.
<EOS>
They
are
always
making
me

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
because

have

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
but

's

all

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
'm
not
so
good
as
you
.
<EOS>
I
doubt

's

my

.
<EOS>
When

've

,

,

it

that
I

.
<EOS>
But
,

,
I
shiver

.
<EOS>
I
've
been
in
one
long

ever
since
we
came
out
because
of
one
chance
that
I
let
go
by
.
<EOS>
Come
,
we
'll
go
in
.
<EOS>
We

,
and

's

.
<EOS>
I
'll
do

shivering
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

George

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

Sinai

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.

.

"

,

<EOS>

"

"

,

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Kate

angry
.
<EOS>
Kate
would
be
quite
in

;
but
Mrs.
Greenow
would
push

her

.
<EOS>
Kate
was
an

,
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
When

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

"
I

,
<EOS>
Kate

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
.
 
<EOS>
Yarmouth
is
not
a
happy
place
for
a
picnic
.
<EOS>
A
picnic
should
be
held
among
green
things
.
<EOS>
Green
turf
is
absolutely
an
essential
.
<EOS>
There
should
be
trees
,
broken

,
small
paths
,
thickets
,
and
hidden

.
<EOS>
There
should
,
if
possible
,
be
rocks
,
old
timber
,
moss
,
and
brambles
.
<EOS>
There
should
certainly
be
hills
and
dales
,
 
on
a
small
scale
;
and
above
all
,
there
should
be
running
water
.
<EOS>
There
should
be
no

.
<EOS>
Jones
should
not
be
able
to
see
all
Greene
's
movements
,
nor
should
Augusta
always
have
her

upon
her

Jane
.
<EOS>
But
the
spot
chosen
for
Mr.
Cheesacre
's
picnic
at
Yarmouth
had
none
of

virtues
above
described
.
<EOS>
It
was
on
the

.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
visible
from

but

and

.
<EOS>
There
were
no
trees
there
and
nothing
green
;
 
neither
was

any

water
.
<EOS>
But

was
a
long
,

;
there

half

,

was

;
and
in

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Therefore

was
called
Mr.
Cheesacre
's

.
  
<EOS>
But
it
was
to
be
a

,
and
therefore
the
essential

of
other

were

.
<EOS>
The

had

some

,
in

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

that

,

.
<EOS>
A

had

Ormesby

would

.
<EOS>
They
might
"

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

Mr.
Cheesacre
's

.
<EOS>
Mr.

was
to

<EOS>
But

had

,

_

_

<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

's

,

.

"

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
He

.

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

;

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
liked
to
have
her
own
way
in
these
little
things
,
though
her
heart
did
lie

.
  
<EOS>
On
the
morning
of
the
picnic
Mr.
Cheesacre
came
down

Montpelier
Parade
with
Captain
Bellfield
,
whose
linen
on
that

certainly
gave
no
outward
sign
of
any
quarrel
between

and
his
washerwoman
.
<EOS>
He
was
got
up
wonderfully
,
and
was
prepared
at
all
points
for
the
day
's
work
.
<EOS>
He
had
on
a
pseudo
-
sailor
's
jacket
,
very

ornamented
with
brass
buttons
,
which
displayed
with
great
judgement
the
exquisite
shapes
of
his
pseudo
-
sailor
's
duck

.
<EOS>
Beneath
them
there
was
a
pair
of
very
shiny
patent
-
leather
shoes
,
well
adapted
for
dancing
on
the
sand
,
presuming
him
to
be
anxious
of
doing
so
,
as
Venus
offered
to
do
,
without
leaving
any
footmarks
.
<EOS>
His
waistcoat
was
of
a
delicate
white
fabric
,
ornamented
with
very
many
gilt
buttons
.
<EOS>
He
had
bejewelled
studs
in
his
shirt
,
and
yellow
kid
gloves
on
his
hands
;
having
,
of
course
,
another
pair
in
his
pocket
for
the
necessities
of
the
evening
.
<EOS>
His
array
was
quite
perfect
,
and
had
stricken
dismay
into
the
heart
of
his
friend
Cheesacre
,
when
he
joined
that
gentleman
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
well
-
made
man
,
nearly
six
feet
high
,
with
dark
hair
,
dark
whiskers
,
and
dark
moustache
,
nearly
black
,
but
of
that
suspicious
hue
which
to
the
observant
beholder
seems
always
to
tell
a
tale
of
the
hairdresser
's
shop
.
<EOS>
He
was
handsome
,
too
,
with
well
-
arranged
features
,
 
but
carrying
,
perhaps
,
in
his
nose
some
first
symptoms
of
the
effects
of
midnight
amusements
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
whole
,
however
,
he
was
a
nice
man
to
look
at
 
for
those
who
like
to
look
on
nice
men
of
that
kind
.
  
<EOS>
Cheesacre
,
too
,
had
adopted
something
of
a
sailor
's
garb
.
<EOS>
He
had
on
a
jacket
of
a
rougher
sort
,
coming
down
much
lower
than
that
of
the
captain
,
being
much
looser
,
and
perhaps
somewhat
more
like
a
garment
which
a
possible
seaman
might
possibly
wear
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
disgusted
with
himself
the
moment
that
he
saw
Bellfield
.
<EOS>
His
heart
had
been
faint
,
and
he
had
not
dared
to
ornament
himself
boldly
as
his
friend
had
done
.
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
Guss
,
you
are
a
swell
,
"
he
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
explained
that
Captain
Bellfield
had
been
christened
Gustavus
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
much
about
that
,
"
said
the
captain
;
"
my
fellow
sent
me
this
toggery
,
and
said
that
it
was
the
sort
of
thing
.
<EOS>
I
'll
change
with
you
if
you
like
it
.
"
<EOS>
But
Cheesacre
could
not
have
worn
that
jacket
,
and
he
walked
on
,
hating
himself
.
  
<EOS>
It
will
be
remembered
that
Mrs.
Greenow
had
spoken
with
considerable
severity
of
Captain
Bellfield
's
pretensions
when
discussing
his
character
with
her
niece
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
on
the
present
occasion
she
received
him
with
most
gracious
smiles
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
her
estimate
of
his
character
had
been
altered
,
or
that
she
was
making
sacrifice
of
her
own
feelings
in
consideration
of
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
who
was
known
to
be
the
captain
's
intimate
friend
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
smiles
for
both
of
them
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
wondrous
power
of
smiling
;
and
could
,
upon
occasion
,
give
signs
of
peculiar
favour
to
half
a
dozen
different
gentlemen
in
as
many
minutes
.
<EOS>
They
found
her
in
the
midst
of
hampers
which
were
not
yet
wholly
packed
,
while
Mrs.
Jones
,
Jeannette
,
and
the
cook
of
the
household
moved
around
her
,
on
the
outside
of
the
circle
,
ministering
to
her
wants
.
<EOS>
She
had
in
her
hand
an
outspread
clean
napkin
,
and
she
wore
fastened
round
her
dress
a
huge
coarse
apron
,
that
she
might
thus
be
protected
from
some
possible
ebullition
of
gravy
,
or
escape
of
salad
mixture
,
or
cream
;
but
in
other
respects
she
was
clothed
in
the
fullest
honours
of
widowhood
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
mitigated
her
weeds
by
half
an
inch
.
<EOS>
She
had
scorned
to
make
any
compromise
between
the
world
of
pleasure
and
the
world
of
woe
.
<EOS>
There
she
was
,
a
widow
,
declared
by
herself
to
be
of
four
months
"
standing
,
with
a
buried
heart
,
making
ready
a
dainty
banquet
with
skill
and
liberality
.
<EOS>
She
was
ready
on
the
instant
to
sit
down
upon
the
baskets
in
which
the
grouse
pie
had
been
just
carefully
inhumed
,
and
talked
about
her
sainted
lamb
with
a
deluge
of
tears
.
<EOS>
If
anybody
did
n't
like
it
,
that
person
 
might
do
the
other
thing
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
and
Captain
Bellfield
thought
that
they
did
like
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
if
you
have
n't
caught
me
before
I
've
half
done
!
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
,
I
hope
you
think
my
apron
becoming
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Everything
that
you
wear
,
Mrs.
Greenow
,
is
always
becoming
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
talk
in
that
way
when
you
know
 
;
but
never
mind
 
we
will
think
of
nothing
sad
to
-
day
if
we
can
help
it
.
<EOS>
Will
we
,
Mr.
Cheesacre
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
<EOS>
no
<EOS>
;
I
should
think
not
;
 
unless
it
should
come
on
to
rain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
wo
n't
rain
 
we
wo
n't
think
of
such
a
thing
.
<EOS>
But
,
by
the
by
,
Captain
Bellfield
,
I
and
my
niece
do
mean
to
send
out
a
few
things
,
just
in
a
bag
you
know
,
so
that
we
may
tidy
ourselves
up
a
little
after

sea
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
it
mentioned
,
because
if
it
gets
about
among
the
other
ladies
,
they
'd
think
we
wanted
to
make
a
dressing
of
it
;
 
and
there
would
n't
be
room
for
them
all
;
would

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
there
would
n't
,
"
said
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
who
had
been
out
on
the
previous

,
inspecting
,
and
perhaps
limiting
,
the
carpenters
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
just
it
,
"
said

Greenow
.
<EOS>
"
But
there
wo
n't
be
any
harm
,
will

,
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
in
Jeanette
's
going

with

?
<EOS>
She
'll

,

,

.
<EOS>
I
know

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be
delighted
to
have
Jeanette
,
"
said

Cheesacre
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
ye
,

,
"
said
Jeannette
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Jeannette
,
do
n't
you
let
Mr.
Cheesacre
turn

;
and
mind
you
behave

and
be

.
<EOS>
Well
;
let

see
;
 
what
else
is

?
<EOS>
Mrs.
Jones
,
you
might
as

give
me
that
ham
now
.
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
,
hand
it
over
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you

it
into
the
basket
,
because
you
'd
turn

the

down
.
<EOS>
There
now
,
if
you
have
n't
nearly
made
me
upset

apricot
pie
.
"
<EOS>
Then
,
in
the
transfer
of
the
dishes
between
the
captain
and
the
widow
,
there
occurred
some
little
innocent
by
-
play
,
which
seemed
to
give

to
Mr.
Cheesacre
;
so
that
that
gentleman
turned
his
back
upon
the
hampers
and
took
a
step
away
towards
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
saw
the
thing
at
a
glance
,
and
immediately
applied
herself
to
cure
the
wound
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
,
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
"
said

,
"
Kate
would
n't
come
down
because
she
did
n't
choose
that
you
should
see
her
with
an
apron
on
over
her

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
I
do
n't
know
why
Miss
Vavasor
should
care
about
my
seeing
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
I
either
.
<EOS>
That
's
just
what
I
said
.
<EOS>
Do
step
up
into
the
drawing
-
room
;
you
'll
find
her
there
,
and
you
can
make

answer
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
would
n't
come
down
for
me
,
"
said
Mr.
Cheesacre
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
n't
stir
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
was
n't
willing
to
leave
his
friend
with
the
widow
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
the
last
of
the
dishes
was
packed
and
Mrs.
Greenow
went
up
-
stairs
with
the
two
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
There
they
found
Kate
and
two
or
three
other
ladies
who
had
promised
to
embark
under
the
protection
of
Mrs.
Greenow
's
wings
.
<EOS>
There
were
the
two
Miss
Fairstairs
,
whom
Mrs.
Greenow
had
especially
patronized
,
and
who
repaid
that
lady
for
her

by
an
amount
of
outspoken
eulogy
which
startled
Kate
by
its
audacity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
dear
aunt
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Fanny
Fairstairs
had
said
on
coming
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
I
ever
came
across
a
woman
with
such
genuine
milk
of
human
kindness
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
with
so
much
true
wit
,
"
said
her
sister
Charlotte
,
 
who
had
been
called
Charlie
on
the
sands
of
Yarmouth
for
the
last
twelve
years
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
widow
came
into
the
room
,
they
flew
at
her
and
devoured
her
with
kisses
,
and
swore
that
they
had
never
seen
her
looking
so
well
.
<EOS>
But
as
the
bright
new
gloves
which
both
the
girls
wore
had
been
presents
from
Mrs.
Greenow
,
they
certainly
did
owe
her
some
affection
.
<EOS>
There
are
not
many
ladies
who
would
venture
to
bestow
such
gifts
upon
their
friends
after
so
very
short
an
acquaintance
;
but
Mrs.
Greenow
had
a
power
that
was
quite
her
own
in
such
matters
.
<EOS>
She
was
already
on
a
very
confidential
footing
with
the
Miss
Fairstairs
,
and
had
given
them
much
useful
advice
as
to
their
future
prospects
.
  
<EOS>
And
then
was
there
a
Mrs.
Green
,
whose
husband
was
first
-
lieutenant
on
board
a
man
-
of
-
war
on
the
West
Indian
Station
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Green
was
a
quiet
,
ladylike
little
woman
,
rather
pretty
,
very
silent
,
and
,
as
one
would
have
thought
,
hardly
adapted
for
the
special
intimacy
of
Mrs.
Greenow
.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Greenow
had
found
out
that
she
was
alone
,
not
very
rich
,
and
in
want
of
the
solace
of
society
.
<EOS>
Therefore
she
had
,
from
sheer
good
-
nature
,
forced
herself
upon
Mrs.
Green
,
and
<EOS>
Mrs.
Green
,
with
much
trepidation
,
had
consented
to
be
taken
to
the
picnic
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
your
husband
would
like
it
,
"
Mrs.
Greenow
had
said
,
"
<EOS>
and
I
hope
I
may
live
to
tell
him
that
I
made
you
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
came
in
also
a
brother
of
the
Fairstairs
girls
,
Joe
Fairstairs
,
a
lanky
,
useless
,
idle
young
man
,
younger
than
them
,
who
was
supposed
to
earn
his
bread
in
an
attorney
's
office
at
Norwich
,
or
rather
to
be
preparing
to
earn
it
at
some
future
time
,
and
who
was
a
heavy
burden
upon
all
his
friends
.
<EOS>
"
We
told
Joe
to
come
to
the
house
,
"
said
Fanny
to
the
widow
,
apologetically
,
"
because
we
thought
he
might
be
useful
in
carrying
down
the
cloaks
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
smiled
graciously
upon
Joe
,
and
assured
him
that
she
was
charmed
to
see
him
,
without
any
reference
to
such
services
as
those
mentioned
.
  
<EOS>
And
then
they
started
.
<EOS>
When
they
got
to
the
door
both
Cheesacre
and
the

made
an

get

of

's

.
<EOS>
But
she
had
it
all
arranged
.
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
found
himself
constrained
to
attend
to
Mrs.
Green
,
while
Mr.
Cheesacre

down
to
the
beach

Kate
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take

,

,
"

,
"
and

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

,
round

,

,
 
although

were
for

his

,

.
<EOS>
He

that
which
contained
Kate

,
and
was

while

Mrs.

's

.
<EOS>
He
had

to

that
it

otherwise
;
and
that

had
to

,

play
as

.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Greenow
with

two
had
settled

,

Mr.

had
found

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
absurd
Bellfield
looks
in
that

,

n't

?
"
<EOS>
he

Kate
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
so
?
<EOS>
I
thought
it
was
so
very
pretty
and
becoming
for
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
hated
Captain
Bellfield
,
and
regretted
more
than

that
he
had
not

something
for

.
<EOS>
He
could
not
endure
to
think
that
his
friend
,
who
paid

nothing
,
should
carry
away

honours
of

and

of
the

which
should

to

,
"
It
may
be
becoming
,
"
said
Cheesacre
;
"
but
do
n't
you
think
it
's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
to
that
I
ca
n't
tell
.
<EOS>
You
see
I
do
n't
at
all
know
what
is

of
a
jacket
covered

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
the

,
Miss
Vavasor
!
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

I
should
think
must
have

expensive
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dreadful
!
<EOS>
and
he
's
got
nothing
,
Miss
Vavasor
;
literally
nothing
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
"
 
<EOS>
and

,
 
<EOS>
"
I
lent

twenty
pounds
the
day
before
yesterday
;
I
did
indeed
.
<EOS>
You
wo
n't

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Beef

<EOS>
The
Rivals
.
 
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>

"
dresses
,

.

"

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
People

must

.
<EOS>
But

,

.

.

.
<EOS>

wo

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
 
and

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
took

.
<EOS>
It

nothing

.
<EOS>
He

,

Bellfield

.
<EOS>
"
One

;

?
"
<EOS>
he

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

.
"
<EOS>
Given
what
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
the

.
<EOS>
There
are
some
people
full
of
that
kind
of
impudence
.
<EOS>
How
they
manage
to
carry
it
on
without

,
I
never
could

.
<EOS>
I
know
I
have
to
pay
my
way
,
and
something
over
and
beyond
generally
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Maria
's
mother
said
,
"
Yes
,
indeed
.
"
<EOS>
She
had
other

there

,
and
was

.
<EOS>
Her

,
her

,

,

ne'er

Joe

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

liked

of
that

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

Greenow
's

.
<EOS>
The

had

.
<EOS>
It

that
the

better

.
<EOS>
Cheesacre
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is

the

?
"

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Matter
!
"
said

.
<EOS>
Then

,

.
<EOS>
Kate
watched

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
I
never

a

,
"

in

.
<EOS>
"
Eleven
,

,

,

,
"
said

to

,

the

for

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
real

.
<EOS>
The
thing
was
indecent
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
If

,
Captain
Bellfield
,
"

,

in

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nothing

,

"

"

.
"
  
<EOS>
Cheesacre
grunted

down
.
<EOS>
He
certainly
could
not
propose
his
own

,
nor

.
<EOS>
It
was
very

that
his

should
be
drunk
,
and
he
had
now
to

of
the

which
he
would

.
<EOS>
But
the

may

when

Greenow
.
<EOS>
For

.
<EOS>
Yarmouth
,
he
said
,
had
never

as

this

by

.
<EOS>
She
had
come

,

,

,

something

.
<EOS>
Then

Greenow
had

,

.
<EOS>
Altogether

,

.
<EOS>
They
were
the
very
words
that
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

-

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

tuning
-
up

,

went

.
<EOS>
Then

was
that
the

of

Greenow
,
in

sent
Jeannette
with

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It
was
said
that
the
widow
herself
actually
changed
her
cap
,
 
which
was
considered
by
some
to
be
very

,
as
there
had

that

no

.
<EOS>
On
such

ladies
are
generally

to
forego
the
advantage
of
dressing
on
the
condition
that
other
ladies
shall
forego
the
same

;
but
when
this
compact
is
broken
by
any
special

,
the

is
thought
to
be

.
<EOS>
It
is
as
though
a
fencer
should
remove

button
from

end

.
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Greenow
was
so
good
-
natured
in

Jeannette
to

,
and

which
her

,
that
her

was
forgiven
her

present
.
  
<EOS>
When
ladies
have
made
up
their
minds
to
dance
they
will
dance
let
the
circumstances
of
the
moment
be
ever
so
antagonistic
to
that
exercise
.
<EOS>
A
ploughed
field
in
February
would
not
be
too
wet
,
nor
the
side
of
a
house
too
uneven
.
<EOS>
In
honest
truth
the
sands
of
the
seashore
are
not
adapted
for
the
exercise
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
very
well
for
Venus
to
make
the
promise
,
but
when
making
it
she
knew
that
Adonis
would
not
keep
her
to
her
word
.
<EOS>
Let
any
lightest
-
limbed
nymph
try
it
,
and
she
will
find
that
she
leaves
most
palpable
footing
.
<EOS>
The
sands
in
question
were
doubtless
compact
,
firm
,
and
sufficiently
moist
to
make
walking
on
them
comfortable
;
but
they
ruffled
themselves
most
uncomfortably
under
the
unwonted
pressure
to
which
they
were
subjected
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
our
friends
did
dance
on
the

;
finding
,
however
,
that
quadrilles
and
Sir
Roger
de
Coverley
suited

than

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my

,

,
"
Mrs.
Greenow

Cheesacre

;
"
Kate
will
be

I
am
sure
to

you
,
 
<EOS>
but
as

,

must

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Cheesacre
was
not

Kate
Vavasor
to

.
<EOS>
He
was

undefined

that
Kate
had
snubbed

,
and

Kate
's

was
,

,

,

court

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
at
that

was
seen

away

,
whither

by
a

;
and
Mr.
Cheesacre
saw
that
now

last
he
might
reap
the

for
which

had
laboured
.
<EOS>
He
was
alone
with
the
widow
,
and
having
been
made
bold
by
wine
,
had
an
opportunity
of
fighting
his
battle
,
than
which
none
better
could
ever

found
.
<EOS>
He
was
himself
by
no

a

,
and
he
despised

in

.
<EOS>
It
was
well
that

poor

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
As

Mrs.
Greenow
's

,

no

.
<EOS>
He
knew
it
all
to
a

.
<EOS>
She
had
spread
for

,
or
some

else
had
spread
for

,
a
report
that
her

was
almost

;
but
the

pounds
was
a

,

as
that

might
well

.
<EOS>
And
she
was
handsome

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
,

,
sometimes

that

.
"
<EOS>
By
George
!
<EOS>
there
's
flesh
and

,
"
he
had
once

friend
Bellfield

.
<EOS>
His

must
then

sincere
,

.
<EOS>
Looking

in

Mr.

could
n't

.
<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
He

,
and

two

?
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

"

.
<EOS>
Kate

.

"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
There

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

,

?
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
good
night
.
<EOS>
Indeed
you
shall
not
;
 
not
a
step
.
<EOS>
"
There

that
in
her

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Kate
,

?
<EOS>
"
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
think

about
such
days
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
It
was
all

well
,
but
I
fear

for

.
<EOS>
I
envied
Ophelia
Walker
because
she

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

Greenow
,
"
I
do
,

;
 
and
young
men
too
.
<EOS>
It
seems

;
why

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Or

either
for
the

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Or

,
 
if

.
<EOS>
I

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>

;
 
till

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
That
was
Mrs.
Greenow
's
doctrine
on

of

.
   
<EOS>
Nethercoats
.
 
<EOS>
We
will
leave
Mrs.
Greenow
with
her
niece
and
two
sisters
at
Yarmouth
,
and
returning
by
stages
to
London
,
will
call
upon
Mr.
Grey
at
his
place
in
Cambridgeshire
as
we
pass
by
.
<EOS>
I
believe
it
is
conceded
by
all
the
other
counties
,
that
Cambridgeshire
possesses
fewer
rural
beauties
than
any
other
county
in
England
.
<EOS>
It
is
very
flat
;
it
is
not
well
timbered
;
the
rivers
are
merely
dikes
;
and
in
a
very
large
portion
of
the
county
the
farms
and
fields
are
divided
simply
by
ditches
 
not
by
hedgerows
.
<EOS>
Such
arrangements
are
,
no
doubt
,
well
adapted
for
agricultural
purposes
,
but
are
not
conducive
to
rural
beauty
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
's
residence
was
situated
in
a
part
of
Cambridgeshire
in
which
the
above
-
named
characteristics
are
very
much
marked
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
the
Isle
of
Ely
,
some
few
miles
distant
from
the
Cathedral
town
,
on
the
side
of
a
long
straight
road
,
which
ran
through
the
fields
for
miles
without
even
a
bush
to
cheer
it
.
<EOS>
The
name
of
his
place
was
Nethercoats
,
and
here
he
lived
generally
throughout
the
year
,
and
here
he
intended
to
live
throughout
his
life
.
  
<EOS>
His
father
had
held
a
prebendal
stall
at
Ely
in
times
when
prebendal
stalls
were
worth
more
than
they
are
at
present
,
and
having
also
been
possessed
of
a
living
in
the
neighbourhood
,
had
amassed
a
considerable
sum
of
money
.
<EOS>
With
this
he
had
during
his
life
purchased
the
property
of
Nethercoats
,
and
had
built
on
it
the
house
in
which
his
son
now
lived
.
<EOS>
He
had
married
late
in
life
,
and
had
lost
his
wife
soon
after
the
birth
of
an
only
child
.
<EOS>
The
house
had
been
built
in
his
own
parish
,
and
his
wife
had
lived
there
for
a
few
months
and
had
died
there
.
<EOS>
But
after
that
event
the
old
clergyman
had
gone
back
to
his
residence
in
the
Close
at
Ely
,
and
there
John
Grey
had
had
the
home
of
his
youth
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
brought
up
under
his
father
's
eye
,
having
been
sent
to
no
public
school
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
gone
to
Cambridge
,
had
taken
college
honours
,
and
had
then
,
his
father
dying
exactly
at
this
time
,
declined
to
accept
a
fellowship
.
<EOS>
His
father
had
left
to
him
an
income
of
some
fifteen
hundred
a
year
,
and
with
this
he
sat
himself
down
,
near
to
his
college
friends
,
near
also
to
the
old
cathedral
which
he
loved
,
in
the
house
which
his
father
had
built
.
  
<EOS>
But
though
Nethercoats
possessed
no
beauty
of
scenery
,
though
the
country
around
it
was
in
truth
as
uninteresting
as
any
country
could
be
,
it
had
many
delights
of
its
own
.
<EOS>
The
house
itself
was
as
excellent
a
residence
for
a
country
gentleman
of
small
means
as
taste
and
skill
together
could
construct
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
prettier
rooms
were
ever
seen
than
the
drawing
-
room
,
the
library
,
and
the
dining
-
room
at
Nethercoats
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
on
the
ground
-
floor
,
and
all
opened
out
on
to
the
garden
and
lawn
.
<EOS>
The
library
,
which
was
the
largest
of
the
three
,
was
a
handsome
chamber
,
and
so
filled
as
to
make
it
well
known
in
the
University
as
one
of
the
best
private
collections
in
that
part
of
England
.
<EOS>
But
perhaps
the
gardens
of
Nethercoats
constituted
its
greatest
glory
.
<EOS>
They
were
spacious
and
excellently
kept
up
,
and
had
been
originally
laid
out
with
that
knowledge
of
gardening
without
which
no
garden
,
merely
as
a
garden
,
can
be
effective
.
<EOS>
And
such
,
of
necessity
,
was
the
garden
of
Nethercoats
.
<EOS>
Fine
single
forest
trees
there
were
none
there
,
nor
was
it
possible
that
there
should
have
been
any
such
.
<EOS>
Nor
could
there
be
a
clear
rippling
stream
with
steep
green
banks
,
and
broken
rocks
lying
about
its
bed
.
<EOS>
Such
beauties
are
beauties
of
landscape
,
and
do
not
of
their
nature
belong
to
a
garden
.
<EOS>
But
the
shrubs
of
Nethercoats
were
of
the
rarest
kind
,
and
had
been
long
enough
in
their
present
places
to
have
reached
the
period
of
their
beauty
.
<EOS>
Nothing
had
been
spared
that
a
garden
could
want
.
<EOS>
The
fruit
-
trees
were
perfect
in
their
kind
,
and
the
glass
-
houses
were
so
good
and
so
extensive
that
John
Grey
in
his
prudence
<EOS>
was
some
times
tempted
to
think
that
he
had
too
much
of
them
.
  
<EOS>
It
must
be
understood
that
there
were
no
grounds
,
according
to
the
meaning
usually
given
to
that
word
,
belonging
to
the
house
at
Nethercoats
.
<EOS>
Between
the
garden
and
the
public
road
there
was
a
paddock
belonging
to
the
house
,
along
the
side
of
which
,
but
divided
from
it
by
a
hedge
and

,
ran
the
private
carriageway
up
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
This
swept
through
the
small
front
flower
-

,
dividing
it
equally
;
but
the
lawns
and
indeed
the
whole
of
that
which
made
the
beauty
of
the
place
lay
on
the
back
of
the
house
,
on
which
side
opened

windows
from
the
three
sitting
-

.
<EOS>
Down
on
the
public
road
there
stood
a
lodge
at
which
lived
one
of
the
gardeners
.
<EOS>
There
was
another
field
of
some
six
or
seven
acres
,
to
which
there
was
a
gate
from
the
corner
of
the
front

,
and
which
went
round
two
sides
of
the
garden
.
<EOS>
This
was
Nethercoats
,
and
the
whole
estate
covered
about
twelve
acres
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
place
for
much
bachelor
enjoyment
of
that
sort
generally
popular
with
bachelors
;
nevertheless
Mr.
Grey
had
been
constant
in
his
residence
there
for
the
seven
years
which
had
now
elapsed
since
he
had
left
his
college
.
<EOS>
His
easy
access
to
Cambridge
had
probably
done
much
to
mitigate
what
might
otherwise
have
been
the
too
great
tedium
of
his
life
;
and
he
had
,
prompted
thereto
by
early
associations
,
found
most
of
his
society
in
the
Close
of
Ely
Cathedral
.
<EOS>
But
,
with
all
the
delight
he
could
derive
from
these
two
sources
,
there
had
still
been
many
solitary
hours
in
his
life
,
and
he
had
gradually
learned
to
feel
that
he
of
all
men
wanted
a
companion
in
his
home
.
  
<EOS>
His
visits
to
London
had
generally
been
short
and
far
between
,
occasioned
probably
by
some
need
in
the
library
,
or
by
the
necessity
of
some
slight
literary
transaction
with
the
editor
or
publisher
of
a
periodical
.
<EOS>
In
one
of
these
visits
he
had
met
Alice
Vavasor
,
and
had
remained
in
Town
,
 
I
will
not
say
till
Alice
had
promised
to
share
his
home
in
Cambridgeshire
,
but
so
long
that
he
had
resolved
before
he
went
that
he
would
ask
her
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
He
had
asked
her
,
and
we
know
that
he
had
been
successful
.
<EOS>
He
had
obtained
her
promise
,
and
from
that
moment
all
his
life
had
been
changed
for
him
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
at
Nethercoats
his
little
smoking
-
room
,
his
books
,
and
his
plants
had
been
everything
to
him
.
<EOS>
Now
he
began
to
surround
himself
with
an
infinity
of
feminine
belongings
,
and
to
promise
himself
an
infinity
of
feminine
blessings
,
wondering
much
that
he
should
have
been
content
to
pass
so
long
a
portion
of
his
life
in
the
dull
seclusion
which
he
had
endured
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
by
nature
an
impatient
man
;
but
now
he
became
impatient
,
longing
for
the
fruition
of
his
new
idea
of
happiness
,
 
longing
to
have
that
as
his
own
which
he
certainly
loved
beyond
all
else
in
the
world
,
and
which
,
perhaps
,
was
all
he
had
ever
loved
with
the
perfect
love
of
equality
.
<EOS>
But
though
impatient
,
and
fully
aware
of
his
own
impatience
,
he
acknowledged
to
himself
that
Alice
could
not
be
expected
to
share
it
.
<EOS>
He
could
plan
nothing
now
,
 
could
have
no
pleasure
in
life
that
she
was
not
expected
to
share
.
<EOS>
But
as
yet
it
could
not
be
so
with
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
her
house
in
London
,
her
town
society
,
and
her
father
.
<EOS>
And
,
inasmuch
as
the
change
for
her
would
be
much
greater
than
it
would
be
for
him
<EOS>
,
it
was
natural
that
she
should
require
some
small
delay
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
pressed
her
.
<EOS>
At
least
he
had
not
pressed
her
with
that
eager
pressure
which
a
girl
must
resist
with
something
of
the
opposition
of
a
contest
,
if
she
resist
it
at
all
.
<EOS>
But
in
truth
his
impatience
was
now
waxing
strong
,
and
during
the
absence
in
Switzerland
of
which
we
have
spoken
,
he
resolved
that
a
marriage
very
late
in
the
autumn
,
 
that
a
marriage
even
in
winter
,
would
be
better
than
a
marriage
postponed
till
the
following
year
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
yet
late
in
August
when
the
party
returned
from
their
tour
.
<EOS>
Would
not
a
further
delay
of
two
months
suffice
for
his
bride
?
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
written
to
him
occasionally
from
Switzerland
,
and
her
first
two
letters
had
been
very
charming
.
<EOS>
They
had
referred
almost
exclusively
to
the
tour
,
and
had
been
made
pleasant
with
some
slightly
coloured
account
of
George
Vavasor
's
idleness
,
and
of
Kate
's
obedience
to
her
brother
's
behests
.
<EOS>
Alice
had
never
written
much
of
love
in
her
love
-
letters
,
and
Grey
was
well
enough
contented
with
her
style
,
though
it
was
not
impassioned
.
<EOS>
As
for
doubting
her
love
,
it
was
not
in
the
heart
of
the
man
to
do
so
after
it
had
been
once
assured
to
him
by
her
word
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
so
slightly
respect
himself
or
her
as
to
leave
room
for
such
a
doubt
in
his
bosom
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
who
could
never
have
suggested
to
himself
that
a
woman
loved
him
till
the
fact
was
there
before
him
;
but
who
having
ascertained
,
as
he
might
think
,
the
fact
,
could
never
suggest
to
himself
that
her
love
would
fail
him
.
<EOS>
Her
first
two
letters
from
Switzerland
had
been
very
pleasant
;
but
after
that
there
had
seemed
to
have
crept
over
her
a
melancholy
which
she
unconsciously
transferred
to
her
words
,
and
which
he
could
not
but
taste
in
them
,
 
at
first
unconsciously
,
also
,
but
soon
with
so
plain
a
flavour
that
he
recognised
it
,
and
made
it
a
matter
of
mental
inquiry
.
<EOS>
During
the
three
or
four
last
days
of
the
journey
,
while
they
were
at
Basle
and
on
their
way
home
,
she
had
not
written
.
<EOS>
But
she
did
write
on
the
day
after
her
arrival
,
having
then
received
from
Mr.
Grey
a
letter
,
in
which
he
told
her
how
very
much
she
would
add
to
his
happiness
if
she
would
now
agree
that
their
marriage
should
not
be
postponed
beyond
the
end
of
October
.
<EOS>
This
letter
she
found
in
her
room
on
her
return
,
and
this
she
answered
at
once
.
<EOS>
And
she
answered
it
in
such
words
that
Mr.
Grey
resolved
that
he
would
at
once
go
to
her
in
London
.
<EOS>
I
will
give
her
letter
at
length
,
as
I
shall
then
be
best
able
to
proceed
with
my
story
quickly
.
  
<EOS>
Queen
Anne
Street
,
 
August
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
DEAREST
JOHN
,
    
<EOS>
We
reached
home
yesterday
tired
enough
,
as
we
came
through
from
Paris
without
stopping
.
<EOS>
I
may
indeed
say
that
we
came
through
from
Strasbourg
,
as
we
only
slept
in
Paris
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
Strasbourg
.
<EOS>
A
steeple
,
after
all
,
is
not
everything
,
and
putting
the
steeple
aside
,
I
do
n't
think
the
style
is
good
.
<EOS>
But
the
hotel
was
uncomfortable
,
which
goes
for
so
much
;
 
and
then
we
were
saturated
with
beauty
of
a
better
kind
.
  
<EOS>
I
got
your
letter
<EOS>
directly
I
came
in
last
night
,
and
I
suppose
I
had
better
dash
at
it
at
once
.
<EOS>
I
would
so
willingly
delay
doing
so
,
saying
nice
little
things
the
while
,
did
I
not
know
that
this
would
be
mere
cowardice
.
<EOS>
Whatever
happens
I
wo
n't
be
a
coward
,
and
therefore
I
will
tell
you
at
once
that
I
can
not
let
you
hope
that
we
should
be
married
this
year
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
will
ask
me
why
,
as
you
have
a
right
to
do
,
and
of
course
I
am
bound
to
answer
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
I
can
give
any
answer
with
which
you
will
not
have
a
right
to
complain
.
<EOS>
If
it
be
so
,
I
can
only
ask
your
pardon
for
the
injury
I
am
doing
you
.
  
<EOS>
Marriage
is
a
great
change
in
life
,
 
much
greater
to
me
than
to
you
,
who
will
remain
in
your
old
house
,
will
keep
your
old
pursuits
,
will
still
be
your
own
master
,
and
will
change
in
nothing
,
 
except
in
this
,
that
you
will
have
a
companion
who
probably
may
not
be
all
that
you
expect
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
change
everything
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
to
me
as
though
I
were
passing
through
a
grave
to
a
new
world
.
<EOS>
I
shall
see
nothing
that
I
have
been
accustomed
to
see
,
and
must
abandon
all
the
ways
of
life
that
I
have
hitherto
adopted
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
should
have
thought
of
this
before
I
accepted
you
;
and
I
did
think
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
made
up
my
mind
that
,
as
I
truly
loved
you
,
I
would
risk
the
change
;
 
that
I
would
risk
it
for
your
sake
and
for
mine
,
hoping
that
I
might
add
something
to
your
happiness
,
and
that
I
might
secure
my
own
.
<EOS>
Dear
John
,
do
not
suppose
that
I
despair
that
it
may
be
so
;
but
,
indeed
,
you
must
not
hurry
me
.
<EOS>
I
must
tune
myself
to
the
change
that
I
have
to
make
.
<EOS>
What
if
I
should
wake
some
morning
after
six
months
living
with
you
,
and
tell
you
that
the
quiet
of
your
home
was
making
me
mad
?
  
<EOS>
You
must
not
ask
me
again
till
the
winter
shall
have
passed
away
.
<EOS>
If
in
the
meantime
I
shall
find
that
I
have
been
wrong
,
I
will
humbly
confess
that
I
have
wronged
you
,
and
ask
you
to
forgive
me
.
<EOS>
And
I
will
freely
admit
this
.
<EOS>
If
the
delay
which
I
now
purpose
is
so
contrary
to
your
own
plans
as
to
make
your
marriage
,
under
such

,
not
that
which

had
expected
,
I
know
that
you
are
free
to
tell

so
,
and
to
say
that
our
engagement
shall
be
over
.
<EOS>
I
am
well
aware
that
I
can
have
no
right
to
bind
you
to
a
marriage
at
one
period
which
you
had
only
contemplated
as
to
take

at
another
period
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
may
promise
that
I
will
obey
any
wish
you
may
express
in
anything
,
 
except
in
that
one
thing
which
you
urged
in
your
last

.
  
<EOS>
Kate
is
going
down
to
Yarmouth
with
Mrs.
Greenow
,
and
I
shall
see
no
more
of
her
probably
till
next
year
,
as
she
will
be
due
in
Westmoreland
after
that
.
<EOS>
George
left
me
at
the
door
when
he
brought
me
home
,
and
declared
that
he
intended
to
vanish
out
of
London
.
<EOS>
Whether
in
town
or
out
,
he
is
never
to
be
seen
at
this
period
of
the
year
.
<EOS>
Papa
offers
to
go
to
Ramsgate
for
a
fortnight
,
but
he
looks
so
wretched
when
he
makes
the
offer
,
that
I
shall
not
have
the
heart
to
hold
him
to
it
.
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
very
much
wants
me
to
go
to
Cheltenham
.
<EOS>
I
very
much
want
not
to
go
,
simply
because
I
can
never
agree
with
her
about
anything
;
but
it
will
probably
end
in
my
going
there
for
a
week
or
two
.
<EOS>
Over
and
beyond
that
,
I
have
no
prospects
before
Christmas
which
are
not
purely

.
<EOS>
There
is
a
project
that
we
shall
all
eat
our
Christmas
dinner
at
Vavasor
Hall
,
 
of
course
not
including
George
,
 
but
<EOS>
this
project
is
quite
in
the
clouds
,
and
,
as
far
as
I
am
concerned
,
will
remain
there
.
  
<EOS>
Dear
John
,
let
me
hear
that
this
letter
does
not
make
you
unhappy
.
  
<EOS>
Most
affectionately
yours
,
  
ALICE
VAVASOR
.
  
<EOS>
At
Nethercoats
,
the
post
was
brought
in
at
breakfast
-
time
,
and
Mr.
Grey
was
sitting
with
his
tea
and
eggs
before
him
,
when
he
read
Alice
's
letter
.
<EOS>
He
read
it
twice
before
he
began
to
think
what
he
would
do
in
regard
to
it
,
and
then
referred
to
one
or
two
others
which
he
had
received
from
Switzerland
,
 
reading
them
also
very
carefully
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
he
took
up
the
slouch
hat
which
he
had
been
wearing
in
the
garden
before
he
was
called
to
his
breakfast
,
and
,
with
the
letters
in
his
hand
,
sauntered
down
among
the
shrubs
and
lawns
.
  
<EOS>
He
knew
,
he
thought
he
knew
,
that
there
was
more
in
Alice
's
mind
than
a
mere
wish
for
delay
.
<EOS>
There
was
more
in
it
than
that
hesitation
to
take
at
once
a
step
which
she
really
desired
to
take
,
if
not
now
,
then
after
some
short
interval
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
she
was
unhappy
,
and
unhappy
because
she
distrusted
the
results
of
her
marriage
;
but
it
never
for
a
moment
occurred
to
him
that
,
therefore
,
the
engagement
between
them
should
be
broken
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
he
loved
her
too
well
to
allow
of
his
admitting
such
an
idea
without
terrible
sorrow
to
himself
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
constant
,
firm
man
,
somewhat
reserved
,
and
unwilling
to
make
new
acquaintances
,
and
,
therefore
,
specially
unwilling
to
break
away
from
those
which
he
had
made
.
<EOS>
Undoubtedly
,
had
he
satisfied
himself
that
Alice
's
happiness
demanded
such
a
sacrifice
of
himself
,
he
would
have
made
it
,
and
made
it
without
a
word
of
complaint
.
<EOS>
The
blow
would
not
have
prostrated
him
,
but
the
bruise
would
have
remained
on
his
heart
,
indelible
,
not
to
be
healed
but
by
death
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
submitted
,
and
no
man
would
have
seen
that
he
had
been
injured
.
<EOS>
But
it
did
not
once
occur
to
him
that
such
a
proceeding
on
his
part
would
be
beneficial
to
Alice
.
<EOS>
Without
being
aware
of
it
,
he
reckoned
himself
to
be
the
nobler
creature
of
the
two
,
and
now
thought
of
her
as
of
one
wounded
,
and
wanting
a
cure
.
<EOS>
Some
weakness
had
fallen
on
her
,
and
strength
must
be
given
to
her
from
another
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
in
the
least
doubt
her
love
,
but
he
knew
that
she
had
been
associated
,
for
a
few
weeks
past
,
with
two
persons
whose
daily
conversation
would
be
prone
to
weaken
the
tone
of
her
mind
.
<EOS>
He
no
more
thought
of
giving
her
up
than
a
man
thinks
of
having
his
leg
cut
off
because
he
has
sprained
his
sinews
.
<EOS>
He
would
go
up
to
town
and
see
her
,
and
would
not
even
yet
abandon
all
hope
that
she
might
be
found
sitting
at
