board
when
Christmas
should
come
.
<EOS>
By
that
day
's
post
he
wrote
a
short
note
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dearest
Alice
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
have
resolved
to
go
to
London
at
once
.
<EOS>
I
will
be
with
you
in
the
evening
at
eight
,
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yours
,
J.
G.
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
no
more
in
the
letter
than
that
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
she
said
,
when
she
received
it
,
"
I
must
dare
to
tell
him
the
whole
truth
.
"
   
<EOS>
John
Grey
Goes
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
And
what
was
the
whole
truth
?
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
,
when
she
declared
to
herself
that
she
must
tell
her
lover
the
whole
truth
,
was
expressing
to
herself
her
intention
of
putting
an
end
to
her
engagement
with
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
She
was
acknowledging
that
that
which
had
to
be
told
was
not
compatible
with
the
love
and
perfect
faith
which
she
owed
to
the
man
who
was
her
affianced
husband
.
<EOS>
And
yet
,
why
should
it
be
so
?
<EOS>
She
did
not
intend
to
tell
him
that
she
had
been
false
in
her
love
to
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
her
heart
had
again
veered
itself
round
and
given
itself
to
that
wild
cousin
of
hers
.
<EOS>
Though
she
might
feel
herself
constrained
to
part
from
John
Grey
,
George
Vavasor
could
never
be
her
husband
.
<EOS>
Of
that
she
assured
herself
fifty
times
during
the
two
days
'
grace
which
had
been
allowed
her
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
she
went
farther
than
that
with
herself
,
and
pronounced
a
verdict
against
any
marriage
as
possible
to
her
if
she
now
decided
against
this
marriage
which
had
for
some
months
past
been
regarded
as
fixed
by
herself
and
all
her
friends
.
  
<EOS>
People
often
say
that
marriage
is
an
important
thing
,
and
should
be
much
thought
of
in
advance
,
and
marrying
people
are
cautioned
that
there
are
many
who
marry
in
haste
and
repent
at
leisure
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
sure
,
however
,
that
marriage
may
not
be
pondered
over
too
much
;
nor
do
I
feel
certain
that
the
leisurely
repentance
does
not
as
often
follow
the
leisurely
marriages
as
it
does
the
rapid
ones
.
<EOS>
That
some
repent
no
one
can
doubt
;
but
I
am
inclined
to
believe
that
most
men
and
women
take
their
lots
as
they
find
them
,
marrying
as
the
birds
do
by
force
of
nature
,
and
going
on
with
their
mates
with
a
general
,
though
not
perhaps
an
undisturbed
satisfaction
,
feeling
inwardly
assured
that
Providence
,
if
it
have
not
done
the
very
best
for
them
,
has
done
for
them
as
well
as
they
could
do
for
themselves
with
all
the
thought
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
a
woman
can
assure
to
herself
,
by
her
own
prudence
and
taste
,
a
good
husband
any
more
than
she
can
add
two
cubits
to
her
stature
;
but
husbands
have
been
made
to
be
decently
good
,
 
and
wives
too
,
for
the
most
part
,
in
our
country
,
 
so
that
the
thing
does
not
require
quite
so
much
thinking
as
some
people
say
.
  
<EOS>
That
Alice
Vavasor
had
thought
too
much
about
it
,
I
feel
quite
sure
.
<EOS>
She
had
gone
on
thinking
of
it
till
she
had
filled
herself
with
a
cloud
of
doubts
which
even
the
sunshine
of
love
was
unable
to
drive
from
her
heavens
.
<EOS>
That
a
girl
should
really
love
the
man
she
intends
to
marry
,
 
that
,
at
any
rate
,
may
be
admitted
.
<EOS>
But
love
generally
comes
easily
enough
.
<EOS>
With
all
her
doubts
Alice
never
doubted
her
love
for
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
she
doubt
his
character
,
nor
his
temper
,
nor
his
means
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
gone
on
thinking
of
the
matter
till
her
mind
had
become
filled
with
some
undefined
idea
of
the
importance
to
her
of
her
own
life
.
<EOS>
What
should
a
woman
do
with
her
life
?
<EOS>
There
had
arisen
round
her
a
flock
of
learned
ladies
asking
that
question
,
to
whom
it
seems
that
the
proper
answer
has
never
yet
occurred
.
<EOS>
Fall
in
love
,
marry
the
man
,
have
two
children
,
and
live
happy
ever
afterwards
.
<EOS>
I
maintain
that
answer
has
as
much
wisdom
in
it
as
any
other
that
can
be
given
;
 
or
perhaps
more
.
<EOS>
The
advice
contained
in
it
can
not
,
perhaps
,
always
be
followed
to
the
letter
;
but
neither
can
the
advice
of
the
other
kind
,
which
is
given
by
the
flock
of
learned
ladies
who
ask
the
question
.
  
<EOS>
A
woman
's
life
is
important
to
her
,
 
as
is
that
of
a
man
to
him
,
 
not
chiefly
in
regard
to
that
which
she
shall
do
with
it
.
<EOS>
The
chief
thing
for
her
to
look
to
is
the
manner
in
which
that
something
shall
be
done
.
<EOS>
It
is
of
moment
to
a
young
man
when
entering
life
to
decide
whether
he
shall
make
hats
or
shoes
;
but
not
of
half
the
moment
that
will
be
that
other
decision
,
whether
he
shall
make
good
shoes
or
bad
.
<EOS>
And
so
with
a
woman
;
 
if
she
shall
have
recognised
the
necessity
of
truth
and
honesty
for
the
purposes
of
her
life
,
I
do
not
know
that
she
need
ask
herself
many
questions
as
to
what
she
will
do
with
it
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
was
ever
asking
herself
that
question
,
and
had
by
degrees
filled
herself
with
a
vague
idea
that
there
was
a
something
to
be
done
;
a
something
over
and
beyond
,
or
perhaps
altogether
beside
that
marrying
and
having
two
children
;
 
if
she
only
knew
what
it
was
.
<EOS>
She
had
filled
herself
,
or
had
been
filled
by
her
cousins
,
with
an
undefined
ambition
that
made
her
restless
without
giving
her
any
real
food
for
her
mind
.
<EOS>
When
she
told
herself
that
she
would
have
no
scope
for
action
in
that
life
in
Cambridgeshire
which
Mr.
Grey
was
preparing
for
her
,
she
did
not
herself
know
what
she
meant
by
action
.
<EOS>
Had
any
one
accused
her
of
being
afraid
to
separate
herself
from
London
society
,
she
would
have
declared
that
she
went
very
little
into
society
and
disliked
that
little
.
<EOS>
Had
it
been
whispered
to
her
that
she
loved
the
neighbourhood
of
the
shops
,
she
would
have
scorned
the
whisperer
.
<EOS>
Had
it
been
suggested
that
the
continued
rattle
of
the
big
city
was
necessary
to
her
happiness
,
she
would
have
declared
that
she
and
her
father
had
picked
out
for
their
residence
the
quietest
street
in
London
because
she
could
not
bear
noise
;
 
and
yet
she
told
herself
that
she
feared
to
be
taken
into
the
desolate
calmness
of
Cambridgeshire
.
  
<EOS>
When
she
did
contrive
to
find
any
answer
to
that
question
as
to
what
she
should
do
with
her
life
,
 
or
rather
what
she
would
wish
to
do
with
it
if
she
were
a
free
agent
,
it
was
generally
of
a
political
nature
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
so
far
advanced
as
to
think
that
women
should
be
lawyers
and
doctors
,
or
to
wish
that
she
might
have
the
privilege
of
the
franchise
for
herself
;
but
she
had
undoubtedly
a
hankering
after
some
second
-
hand
political
manoeuvering
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
liked
,
I
think
,
to
have
been
the
wife
of
the
leader
of
a
Radical
opposition
,
in
the
time
when
such
men
were
put
into
prison
,
and
to
have
kept
up
for
him
his
seditious
correspondence
while
he
lay
in
the
Tower
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
carried
the
answers
to
him
inside
her
stays
,
 
and
have
made
long
journeys
down
into
northern
parts
without
any
money
,
if
the
cause
required
it
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
liked
to
have
around
her
ardent
spirits
,
male
or
female
,
who
would
have
talked
of
"
the
cause
,
"
and
have
kept
alive
in
her
some
flame
of
political
fire
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
she
had
no
cause
.
<EOS>
Her
father
's
political
views
were
very
mild
.
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
's
were
deadly
conservative
.
<EOS>
Kate
Vavasor
was
an
aspiring
Radical
just
now
,
because
her
brother
was
in
the
same
line
;
but
during
the
year
of
the
love
-
passages
between
George
and
Alice
,
George
Vavasor
's
politics
had
been
as
conservative
as
you
please
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
become
a
Radical
till
he
had
quarrelled
with
his
grandfather
.
<EOS>
Now
,
indeed
,
he
was
possessed
of
very
advanced
views
,
 
views
with
which
Alice
felt
that
she
could
sympathize
.
<EOS>
But
what
would
be
the
use
of
sympathizing
down
in
Cambridgeshire
?
<EOS>
John
Grey
had
,
so
to
speak
,
no
politics
.
<EOS>
He
had
decided
views
as
to
the
treatment
which
the
Roman
Senate
received
from
Augustus
,
and
had
even
discussed
with
Alice
the
conduct
of
the
Girondists
at
the
time
of
Robespierre
's

;
but
for
Manchester
and
its
cares
he
had
no
apparent

,
and
had
declared
to
Alice
that
he
would
not
accept
a
seat
in
the
British
House
of
Commons
if
it
were
offered
to
him
free
of
expense
.
<EOS>
What
political
enthusiasm
could
she
indulge
with
such
a
companion
down
in
Cambridgeshire
?
  
<EOS>
She
thought
too
much
of
all
this
,
 
and
was
,
if
I
may
say
,
over
-
prudent
in
calculating
the
chances
of
her
happiness
and
of
his
.
<EOS>
For
,
to
give
her
credit
for
what
was
her
due
,
she
was
quite
as
anxious
on
the
latter

as
on
the
former
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
for
the
Roman
Senate
,
"
she
would
say
to
herself
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
much
for
the
Girondists
.
<EOS>
How
am
I
to
talk
to
him
day
after

,
night
after

,
when
we
shall
be
alone

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
No
doubt
her
tour
in
Switzerland
with
her
cousin
had
had
some
effect
in
making
such
thoughts
stronger
now
than
they
had
ever
been
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
again
learned
to
love
her
cousin
.
<EOS>
She
was
as
firmly
sure
as
ever
that
she
could
never
love
him
more
.
<EOS>
He
had
insulted
her
love
;
and
though
she
had
forgiven
him
and
again
enrolled
him
among
her
dearest
friends
,
she
could
never
again
feel
for
him
that
passion
which
a
woman
means
when
she
acknowledges
that
she
is
in
love
.
<EOS>
That
,
as
regarded
her
and
George
Vavasor
,
was
over
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
there
had
been
a
something
of
romance
during
those
days
in
Switzerland
which
she
feared
she
would
regret
when
she
found
herself
settled
at
Nethercoats
.
<EOS>
She
envied
Kate
.
<EOS>
Kate
could
,
as
his
sister
,
attach
herself
on
to
George
's
political
career
,
and
obtain
from
it
all
that
excitement
of

which
Alice
desired
for
herself
.
<EOS>
Alice
could
not
love
her
cousin
and
marry
him
;
but
she
felt
that
if
she
could
do
so
without
impropriety
she
would
like
to
stick
close
to

like

sister
,
to
spend
her
money
in
aiding
his

in
Parliament
as
Kate
would
do
,
and
trust
herself
and
her

into
the
boat
which
he
was
to
command
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
love
her
cousin
;
but
she
still
believed
in
him
,
 
with
a
faith
which
he
certainly
did
not
deserve
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
two
days
passed
over
her
,
her
mind
grew
more
and
more
fixed
as
to
its
purpose
.
<EOS>
She
would
tell
Mr.
Grey
that
she
was
not
fit
to
be
his
wife
 
<EOS>
and
she
would
beg
him
to
pardon
her
and
to
leave
her
.
<EOS>
It
never
occurred
to
her
that
perhaps
he
might
refuse
to
let
her
go
.
<EOS>
She
felt
quite
sure
that
she
would
be
free
as
soon
as
she
had
spoken
the
word
which
she
intended
to
speak
.
<EOS>
If
she
could
speak
it
with
decision
she
would
be
free
,
and
to
attain
that
decision
she
would
school
herself
with
her
utmost
strength
.
<EOS>
At
one
moment
she
thought
of
telling
all
to
her
father
and
of

him
to
break

to
Mr.
Grey
;
but
she
knew
that
her
father
would
not
understand
her
,
and
that
he
would
be
very
hostile
to
her
,
 
saying
hard
,
uncomfortable
words
,
which
would
probably
be
spared
if
the
thing
were
done
before
he
was
informed
.
<EOS>
Nor
would
she
write
to
Kate
,
whose

to

at
this
time
were
full
of
wit
at
the

of
Mrs.
Greenow
.
<EOS>
She
would
tell
Kate
as
soon
as
the
thing
was
done
,
but
not
before
.
<EOS>
That
Kate
would
sympathize
with
her
,
she
was
quite
certain
.
  
<EOS>
So
the
two
days
passed
by
and
the
time
came
at
which
John
Grey
was
to
be
there
.
<EOS>
As
the
minute
hand
on
the
drawing
-
room
clock
came
round
to
the
full

,
she
felt
that
her
heart
was
beating
with
a
violence
which
she
could
not
repress
.
<EOS>
The
thing
seemed
to
her
to
assume
bigger
dimensions
than
it
had
hitherto
done
.
<EOS>
She
began
to
be
aware
that
she
was
about
to
be
guilty
of
a
great
iniquity
,
when
it
was
too
late
for
her
to
change
her
mind
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
bring
herself
to
resolve
that
she
would
,
on
the

,
change
her
mind
.
<EOS>
She
believed
that
she
could
never
pardon
herself
such
weakness
.
<EOS>
But
yet
she
felt
herself
to
be
aware
that
her
purpose
was
wicked
.
<EOS>
When
the
knock
at
the
door
was
at
last
heard
she
trembled
and
feared
that
she
would
almost
be
unable
to
speak
to
him
.
<EOS>
Might
it
be
possible
that
there
should
yet
be
a
reprieve
for
her
?
<EOS>
No
;
it
was
his
step
on
the
stairs
,
and
there
he
was
in
the
room
with
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
,
"
he
said
,
coming
to
her
.
<EOS>
His
smile
was
sweet
and
loving
as
it
ever
was
,
and
his
voice
had
its
usual
manly
,
genial
,
loving
tone
.
<EOS>
As
he
walked
across
the
room
Alice
felt
that
he
was
a
man
of
whom
a
wife
might
be
very
proud
.
<EOS>
He
was
tall
and
very
handsome
,
with
brown
hair
,
with
bright
blue
eyes
,
and
a
mouth
like
a
god
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
beauty
of
his
mouth
,
 
beauty
which
comprised
firmness
within
itself
,
that
made
Alice
afraid
of
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
dressed
in
his
morning
clothes
;
but
he
was
a
man
who
always
seemed
to
be
well
dressed
.
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
,
"
he
said
,
advancing
across
the
room
,
and
before
she
knew
how
to
stop
herself
or
him
,
he
had
taken
her
in

and

.
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
immediately
begin
about
the
letter
,
but
placed
her
upon
the
sofa
,
seating
himself
by
her
side
,
and
looked
into
her

with
loving

,
 
not
as
though
to

might
be
amiss

,
but

though
determined
to

his

.
<EOS>
There
was
no
reproach
at
any
rate

;
 
none
as
yet
;
nor
did
it
seem
that
he
thought
that
he
had
any
cause
for
fear
.
<EOS>
They
sat
in
this
way
for
a
moment
or
two
in

,
and
during
those

Alice
was
summoning
up
her

to
speak
.
<EOS>
The
palpitation
at
her
heart
was
already
gone
,
and
she
was
determined
that
she
would
speak
.
  
<EOS>
"
Though
I
am
very
glad

,
"
she

,
at

,
"
I
am

my
letter

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Trouble
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
you
ought
to
know
that
it
is
no

.
<EOS>
I
have
not
enough

do
down

Nethercoats
to

.
<EOS>
So

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
it
went
off

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
she
said
in
that
tone
of
voice
which
clearly
implies
that

speaker
is
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
that

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Certainly

.
<EOS>
Certainly

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

"
  
"

;

,

<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
Shall

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;

,

.
"
  
"
Perhaps
it
may
be
better
.
<EOS>
I
learned
,
love
,
that
something
had
been
said
or
done
during
your
journey
,
 
or
perhaps
only
something

,
that
had
made
you

,
and
filled
your
mind
for
a

with
those

for
the
past
which
we
are
all
apt
to
feel
at
certain

of
our
life
.
<EOS>
There
are
few
of
us
who
do
not
encounter
,
now
and
again
,
some
of
that
irrational
spirit
of
sadness
which
,
when
over
-

,
drives
men
to

and
self

.
<EOS>
I
used
to
know

what

was

you
;
but

I
have
had

,
I

.
<EOS>
In
that
I
think
I
have

than

.
<EOS>
Do
not
speak

of
that
spirit
till

have

you

,
can
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
tried
,
and
it
will
not
be

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Try
again
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
damned
spirit
,
and
belongs
neither
to
heaven
nor

.
<EOS>
Do
not
say
to
me

words
that
you
were
about
to

till
you
have
wrestled
with

.
<EOS>
I
think
I
know
what
those
words
were
to

.
<EOS>
If
you
love
me
,
those
words
should
not
be
spoken
.
<EOS>
If
you
do
not
 
"
  
"
If
I
do
not
love
you
,
I
love
no
one
upon
earth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
it
.
<EOS>
I
believe
it
as
I
believe
in
my
own

for
you
.
<EOS>
I
trust
your
love
implicitly
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
I
know

you
love
me
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
can
read

mind
.
<EOS>
Tell

that
I
may
return
to
Cambridgeshire
,
and
again

for
an
early

thence
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
take
such
speech
from
you
to
mean
more
than
it
says
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
sat
quiet
,
looking
at
him
 
looking
full
into
his
face
.
<EOS>
She
had
in
nowise
changed
her
mind
,
but
after
such
words
from
him
,
she
did
not
know
how
to
declare
to
him
her
resolution
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
his
manner
that
awed
her
,
 
and
something
also
that
softened
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
I
may
see
you
again
to
-
morrow
morning
in
our
usual
quiet
,
loving
way
,
and
that
I
may
return
home
to
-
morrow
evening
.
<EOS>
Pronounce
a
yea
to
that
speech
from
me
,
and
I
will
ask
for
nothing
further
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
can
not
do
so
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
And
the
tone
of
her
voice
,
as
she
spoke
,
was
different
to
any
tone
that
he
had
heard
before
from
her
mouth
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
melancholy
fiend
too
strong
for
you
?
"
<EOS>
He
smiled
as
he
said
this
,
and
as
he
smiled
,
he
took
her
hand
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
attempt
to
withdraw
it
,
but
sat
by
him
in
a
strange
calmness
,
looking
straight
before
her
into
the
middle
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
not
struggled
with
it
.
<EOS>
You
know
,
as
I
do
,
that
it
is
a
bad
fiend
and
a
wicked
one
,
 
a
fiend
that
is
prompting
you
to
the
worst
cruelty
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
Alice
!
<EOS>
Alice
!
<EOS>
Alice
!
<EOS>
Try
to
think
of
all
this
as
though
some
other
person
were
concerned
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
your
friend
,
what
advice
would
you
give
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
bid
her
tell
the
man
who
had
loved
her
,
 
<EOS>
that
is
,
if
he
were
noble
,
good
,
and
great
,
 
that
she
found
herself
to
be
unfit
to
be
his
wife
;
and
then
I
would
bid
her
ask
his
pardon
humbly
on
her
knees
.
<EOS>
"
As
she
said
this
,
she
sank
before
him
on
to
the
floor
,
and
looked
up
into
his
face
with
an
expression
of
sad
contrition
which
almost
drew
him
from
his
purposed
firmness
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
purposed
to
be
firm
,
 
to
yield
to
her
in
nothing
,
resolving
to
treat
all
that
she
might
say
as
the
hallucination
of
a
sickened
imagination
,
 
as
the
effect
of
absolute
want
of
health
,
for
which
some
change
in
her
mode
of
life
would
be
the
best
cure
.
<EOS>
She
might
bid
him
begone
in
what
language
she
would
.
<EOS>
He
knew
well
that
such
was
her
intention
.
<EOS>
But
he
would
not
allow
a
word
coming
from
her
in
such
a
way
to
disturb
arrangements
made
for
the
happiness
of
their
joint
lives
.
<EOS>
As
a
loving
husband
would
treat
a
wife
,
who
,
in
some
exceptionable
moment
of
a
melancholy
malady
,
should
declare
herself
unable
to
remain
longer
in
her
home
,
so
would
he
treat
her
.
<EOS>
As
for
accepting
what
she
might
say
as
his
dismissal
,
he
would
as
soon
think
of
taking
the
fruit
-
trees
from
the
southern
wall
because
the
sun
sometimes
shines
from
the
north
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
treat
either
his
interests
or
hers
so
lightly
as
that
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
if
he
granted
no
such
pardon
,
Alice
?
<EOS>
I
will
grant
none
such
.
<EOS>
You
are
my
wife
,
my
own
,
my
dearest
,
my
chosen
one
.
<EOS>
You
are
all
that
I
value
in
the
world
,
my
treasure
and
my
comfort
,
my
earthly
happiness
and
my
gleam
of
something
better
that
is
to
come
hereafter
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
that
I
shall
let
you
go
from
me
in
that
way
?
<EOS>
No
,
love
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
ill
I
will
wait
till
your
illness
is
gone
by
;
and
,
if
you
will
let
me
,
I
will
be
your
nurse
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
ill
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
ill
with
any
defined
sickness
.
<EOS>
You
do
not
shake
with
ague
,
nor
does
your
head
rack
you
with
aching
;
but
yet
you
may
be
ill
.
<EOS>
Think
of
what
has
passed
between
us
.
<EOS>
Must
you
not
be
ill
when
you
seek
to
put
an
end
to
all
that
without
any
cause
assigned
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
hear
my
reasons
,
"
 
she
was
still
kneeling
before
him
and
looking
up
into
his
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
hear
them
if
you
will
tell
me
that
they
refer
to
any
supposed
faults
of
my
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
not
hear
them
.
<EOS>
It
is
for
me
to
find
out
your
faults
,
and
when
I
have
found
out
any
that
require
complaint
,
I
will
come
and
make
it
.
<EOS>
Dear
Alice
,
I
wish
you
knew
how
I
long
for
you
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
put
his
hand
upon
her
hair
,
as
though
he
would
caress
her
.
  
<EOS>
But
this
she
would
not
suffer
,
so
she
rose
slowly
,
and
stood
with
her
hand
upon
the
table
in
the
middle
of
the
room
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
 
<EOS>
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
call
me
so
,
I
shall
think
it
only
a
part
of
your
malady
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Grey
,
"
she
continued
,
"
I
can
only
hope
that
you
will
take
me
at
my
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
I
will
not
;
certainly
I
will
not
,
if
that
would
be
adverse
to
my
own
interests
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
thinking
of
your
interests
;
I
am
,
indeed
;
 
at
any
rate
as
much
as
of
my
own
.
<EOS>
I
feel
quite
sure
that
I
should
not
make
you
happy
as
your
wife
,
 
quite
sure
;
and
feeling
that
,
I
think
that
I
am
right
,
even
after
all
that
has
passed
,
to
ask
your
forgiveness
,
and
to
beg
that
our
engagement
may
be
over
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Alice
,
no
;
never
with
my
consent
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
tell
you
with
what
contentment
I
would
marry
you
to
-
morrow
,
 
to
-
morrow
,
or
next
month
,
or
the
month
after
.
<EOS>
But
if
it
can
not
be
so
,
then
I
will
wait
.
<EOS>
Nothing
but
your
marriage
with
some
one
else
would
convince
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
convince
you
in
that
way
,
"
she
said
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
convince
me
in
no
other
.
<EOS>
You
have
not
spoken
to
your
father
of
this
as
yet
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
as
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
do
so
,
at
any
rate
for
the
present
.
<EOS>
You
will
own
that
it
might
be
possible
that
you
would
have
to
unsay
what
you
had
said
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
it
is
not
possible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Give
yourself
and
me
the
chance
.
<EOS>
It
can
do
no
harm
.
<EOS>
And
,
Alice
,
I
ask
you
now
for
no
reasons
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
ask
your
reasons
,
or
even
listen
to
them
,
because
I
do
not
believe
that
they
will
long
have
effect
even
on
yourself
.
<EOS>
Do
you
still
think
of
going
to
Cheltenham
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
decided
nothing
as
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
were
you
,
I
would
go
.
<EOS>
I
think
a
change
of
air
would
be
good
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
you
treat
me
as
though
I
were
partly
silly
,
and
partly
insane
;
but
it
is
not
so
.
<EOS>
The
change
you
speak
of
should
be
in
my
nature
,
and
in
yours
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
shook
his
head
and
still
smiled
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
the
imperturbed
security
of
his
manner
which
almost
made
her
angry
with
him
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
though
he
assumed
so
great
a
superiority
that
he
felt
himself
able
to
treat
any
resolve
of
hers
as
the
petulance
of
a
child
.
<EOS>
And
though
he
spoke
in
strong
language
of
his
love
,
and
of
his
longing
that
she
should
come
to
him
,
yet
he
was
so
well
able
to
command
his
feelings
,
that
he
showed
no
sign
of
grief
at
the
communication
she
had
made
to
him
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
doubt
his
love
,
but
she
believed
him
to
be
so
much
the
master
of
his
love
,
 
as
he
was
the
master
of
everything
else
,
that
her
separation
from
him
would
cause
him
no
uncontrollable
grief
.
<EOS>
In
that
she
utterly
failed
to
understand
his
character
.
<EOS>
Had
she
known
him
better
,
she
might
have
been
sure
that
such
a
separation
now
would
with
him
have
carried
its
mark
to
the
grave
.
<EOS>
Should
he
submit
to
her
decision
,
he
would
go
home
and
settle
himself
to
his
books
the
next
day
;
but
on
no
following
day
would
he
be
again
capable
of
walking
forth
among
his
flowers
with
an
easy
heart
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
strong
,
constant
man
,
perhaps
over
-
conscious
of
his
own
strength
;
but
then
his
strength
was
great
.
"
<EOS>
He
is
perfect
!
"
<EOS>
Alice
had
said
to
herself
often
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
that
he
were
less
perfect
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
stay
with
her
long
after
the
last
word
that
has
been
recorded
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"
he
said
,
as
for
a
moment
he
held
her
hand
at
parting
,
"
I
had
better
not
come
to
-
morrow
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
it
is
better
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
advise
you
not
to
tell
your
father
of
this
,
and
doubtless
you
will
think
of
it
before
you
do
so
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
do
tell
him
,
let
me
know
that
you
have
done
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
in
such
case
I
also
must
see
him
.
<EOS>
God
bless
you
,
Alice
!
<EOS>
God
bless
you
,
dearest
,
dearest
Alice
!
"
<EOS>
Then
he
went
,
and
she
sat
there
on
the
sofa
without
moving
,
till
she
heard
her
father
's
feet
as
he
came
up
the
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
Alice
,
are
you
not
in
bed
yet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
papa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
John
Grey
has
been
here
.
<EOS>
He
has
left
his
stick
in
the
hall
.
<EOS>
I
should
know
it
among
a
thousand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
he
has
been
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
anything
the
matter
,
Alice
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
papa
,
nothing
is
the
matter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
not
made
himself
disagreeable
,
has
he
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
He
never
does
anything
wrong
.
<EOS>
He
may
defy
man
or
woman
to
find
fault
with
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
that
is
it
,
is
it
?
<EOS>
He
is
just
a
shade
too
good
.
<EOS>
Well
,
I
have
always
thought
that
myself
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
a
fault
on
the
right
side
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
fault
,
Papa
.
<EOS>
If
there
be
any
fault
,
it
is
not
with
him
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
yawning
and
tired
,
and
I
will
go
to
bed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
to
be
here
to
-
morrow
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
he
returns
to
Nethercoats
early
.
<EOS>
Good
night
,
papa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Vavasor
,
as
he
went
up
to
his
bedroom
,
felt
sure
that
there
had
been
something
wrong
between
his
daughter
and
her
lover
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
she
'll
ever
put
up
with
him
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
"
he
is
so
terribly
conceited
.
<EOS>
I
shall
never
forget
how
he
went
on
about
Charles
Kemble
,
and
what
a
fool
he
made
of
himself
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
,
before
she
went
to
bed
,
sat
down
and
wrote
a
letter
to
her
cousin
Kate
.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
George
Vavasor
at
Home
.
 
<EOS>
It
can
not
perhaps
fairly
be
said
that
George
Vavasor
was
an
unhospitable
man
,
seeing
that
it
was
his
custom
to
entertain
his
friends
occasionally
at
Greenwich
,
Richmond
,
or
such
places
;
and
he
would
now
and
again
have
a
friend
to
dine
with
him
at
his
club
.
<EOS>
But
he
never
gave
breakfasts
,
dinners
,
or
suppers
under
his
own
roof
.
<EOS>
During
a
short
period
of
his
wine
-
selling
career
,
at
which
time
he
had
occupied
handsome
rooms
over
his
place
of
business
in
New
Burlington
Street
,
he
had
presided
at
certain
feasts
given
to
customers
or
expectant
customers
by
the
firm
;
but
he
had
not
found
this
employment
to
his
taste
,
and
had
soon
relinquished
it
to
one
of
the
other
partners
.
<EOS>
Since
that
he
had
lived
in
lodgings
in
Cecil
Street
,
 
down
at
the
bottom
of
that
retired
nook
,
near
to
the
river
and
away
from
the
Strand
.
<EOS>
Here
he
had
simply
two
rooms
on
the
first
floor
,
and
hither
his
friends
came
to
him
very
rarely
.
<EOS>
They
came
very
rarely
on
any
account
.
<EOS>
A
stray
man
might
now
and
then
pass
an
hour
with
him
here
;
but
on
such
occasions
the
chances
were
that
the
visit
had
some
reference
,
near
or
distant
,
to
affairs
of
business
.
<EOS>
Eating
or
drinking
there
was
never
any
to
be
found
here
by
the
most
intimate
of
his
allies
.
<EOS>
His
lodgings
were
his
private
retreat
,
and
they
were
so
private
that
<EOS>
but
few
of
his
friends
knew
where
he
lived
.
  
<EOS>
And
had
it
been
possible
<EOS>
he
would
have
wished
that
no
one
should
have
known
his
whereabouts
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
aware
that
he
had
any
special
reason
for
this
peculiarity
,
or
that
there
was
anything
about
his
mode

life
that
required
hiding
;
but
he
was
a
man
who
had
always
lived
as
though
secrecy
in
certain

might
at
any
time
become
useful
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
mode
of
dressing
himself
when
he
went
out
at
night
that
made
it
almost
impossible
that
any
one
should
recognise
him
.
<EOS>
The
people
at
his
lodgings
did
not
even
know
that
he
had
relatives
,
and
his
nearest
relatives
hardly
knew
that
he
had
lodgings
.
<EOS>
Even
Kate
had
never
been
at
the
rooms
in
Cecil
Street
,
and
addressed
all
her
letters
to
his
place
of
business
or
his
club
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
who
would
bear
no
inquiry
into
himself
.
<EOS>
If
he
had
been
out
of
view
for
a
month
,
and
his
friends
asked
him
where
he
had
been
,
he
always
answered

,
or
left

unanswered
.
<EOS>
There
are
many
men
of
whom
everybody
knows
all
about

;
 
as
to
whom
everybody
knows
where

,
whither

go
<EOS>
,
what
is

,

.
<EOS>
But
there
are
others
of
whom
no
man
knows
anything
,
and
George
Vavasor
was
such
a
one
.
<EOS>
For
myself
I
like
the
open
babbler
the
best
.
<EOS>
Babbling
may
be
a
weakness
,
but
to
my
thinking
mystery
is
a
vice
.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
also
maintained
another

,
down
in
Oxfordshire
;
but
the
two

did
not

's

.
<EOS>
There

third
,

,

the
world
's

,
which
shall

nameless
;
but
of
the
establishment
in
Oxfordshire
he
did
sometimes

,
in
very

,
among

.
<EOS>
When
he

among

,

two

Roebury
,

had

,

;
but
that

at

two

of
his
if

.
<EOS>
And
men
very
often
did
buy
Vavasor
's

.
<EOS>
When
he
was
on
them
they
always
went
well
and
sold

.
<EOS>
And
though
he
thus
spoke
of
two
,

perhaps

,
he
always

to
have
horses
enough
when

was
down

.
<EOS>
No
one

George
Vavasor
not
to
hunt
because

short

stuff
.
<EOS>
And
here
,

Roebury
,

could

.
<EOS>
Many

George

,
in

.
<EOS>
Bat
regarded
his
master
as
a
man
wholly

to

,
but
often

why
he

in

.
<EOS>
Of

's

Bat

.
<EOS>
Bat
could

his
master
's
club
in
London
,
but
he
could

.
  
<EOS>
But
though
Vavasor
's
private

were
so

,
he
had
,

,

.
<EOS>
The

in
the

was

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
He

's

.
<EOS>
He

a

,
others

,

again

.
<EOS>
The
room
was
as
pretty

's

,
but
you

,
by
the

,
that

.
<EOS>
Here

,
late
on

September
,
when
all

world
was

.
<EOS>
He
was

which

.
<EOS>
Though

of

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

,
keeping
,

,

.
<EOS>
And
yet

letter
was
of
much

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
If

,
"

,
"
it

more

cutting

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

Grey
,

's

one
instigating

.
<EOS>
And
Vavasor
was
in

,

,

<EOS>
Indeed

.
<EOS>
He
had

Kate

Alice
's

,

that
her

was
past

;
and
he

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
How

,

.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps

's

,

.
<EOS>
Nevertheless

,

.
<EOS>
But
I

.
<EOS>
Alice
had
once

,
had

,

,

.
<EOS>
When

,
and

,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
And

had

,

;
but

.
<EOS>
Such

under

.
<EOS>
But
George
Vavasor
,
when
he
hated
,
was
apt

.
<EOS>
He
could
not

a

.
<EOS>
At
present
,

<EOS>
Kate

.
<EOS>
Alice

wo

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
This

,

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Now

;
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
Then

's

<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
Vavasor

.
<EOS>
It

that

.
<EOS>
Even

at
Bicester
<EOS>
the

,

charge

.
<EOS>
And
George
Vavasor
was
no

.
<EOS>
He
did

.
<EOS>
A

's

,

George
had

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
gentleman
!
<EOS>
"
said

to

girl
.
<EOS>
"
Does

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
And
the

was
a

-

keeper
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
was
pretty

of
his

.
<EOS>
It

Mr.
Grimes
from

"
Handsome
Man
"
public

,
in

,

Mr.
Vavasor

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grimes
was
a
man
who
knew
that
business
was
business
,
and
as

had
some
considerable
weight
in
his
own

.
<EOS>
With

was

,

,
and

-

,

;
 
in
the
fabrication
of
which
latter
article
<EOS>
Mr.
Grimes
was
supposed
to
have
an
extended

.
<EOS>
To
such

him
,
when

,
Mr.
Vavasor

;
and

idle

London

,
Mr.

.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
had
been
,
as
I
have
said
,
lately

,
and
the
new
member
who
had

at

.
<EOS>
Under

reign
he
was

,
and

,

<EOS>

;

To

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.

.

he
had
completed
the
study
.
"
<EOS>
But
nobody
shall
say
I
had
n't
the
courage
to
play
the
game
out
,
and
that
old
fellow
must
die
some
day
,
one
supposes
.
<EOS>
If
I
were
not
a
fool
,
I
should
make
it
up
with
him
before
he
went
;
but
I
am
a
fool
,
and
shall
remain
so
to
the
last
.
<EOS>
"
Soon
after
that
he
dressed
himself
slowly
,
reading
a
little
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
as
he
did
so
.
<EOS>
When
his
toilet
was
completed
,
and
his
Sunday
newspapers
sufficiently
perused
,
he
took
up
his
hat
and
umbrella
and
sauntered
out
.
   
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
Becomes
Troubled
.
 
<EOS>
Kate
Vavasor
had
sent
to
her
brother
only
the
first
half
of
her
cousin
's
letter
,
that
half
in
which
Alice
had
attempted
to
describe
what
had
taken
place
between
her
and
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
In
doing
this
,
Kate
had
been
a
wicked
traitor
,
 
a
traitor
to
that
feminine
faith
against
which
treason
on
the
part
of
one
woman
is
always
unpardonable
in
the
eyes
of
other
women
.
<EOS>
But
her
treason
would
have
been
of
a
deeper
die
<EOS>
had
she
sent
the
latter
portion
,
for
in
that
Alice
had
spoken
of
George
Vavasor
himself
.
<EOS>
But
even
of
this
treason
,
Kate
would
,
I
think
,
have
been
guilty
,
had
the
words
which
Alice
wrote
been
of
a
nature
to
serve
her
own
purpose
if
read
by
her
brother
.
<EOS>
But
they
had
not
been
of
this
nature
.
<EOS>
They
had
spoken
of
George
as
a
man
with
whom
any
closer
connection
than
that
which
existed
at
present
was
impossible
,
and
had
been
written
with
the
view
of
begging
Kate
to
desist
from
making
futile
attempts
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
"
I
feel
myself
driven
,
"
Alice
had
said
,
"
to
write
all
this
,
as
otherwise
,
 
if
I
were
simply
to
tell
you
that
I
have
resolved
to
part
from
Mr.
Grey
,
 
you
would
think
that
the
other
thing
might
follow
.
<EOS>
The
other
thing
can
not
follow
.
<EOS>
I
should
think
myself
untrue
in
my
friendship
to
you
if
I
did
not
tell
you
about
Mr.
Grey
;
and
you
will
be
untrue
in
your
friendship
to
me
if
you
take
advantage
of
my
confidence
by
saying
more
about
your
brother
.
<EOS>
"
This
part
of
Alice
's
letter
Kate
had
not
sent
to
George
Vavasor
;
 
"
But
the
other
thing
shall
follow
,
"
Kate
had
said
,
as
she
read
the
words
for
the
second
time
,
and
then
put
the
papers
into
her
desk
.
<EOS>
"
It
shall
follow
.
"
  
<EOS>
To
give
Kate
Vavasor
her
due
,
she
was
,
at
any
rate
,
unselfish
in
her
intrigues
.
<EOS>
She
was
obstinately
persistent
,
and
she
was
moreover
unscrupulous
,
but
she
was
not
selfish
.
<EOS>
Many
years
ago
she
had
made
up
her
mind
that
George
and
Alice
should
be
man
and
wife
,
feeling
that
such
a
marriage
would
be
good
at
any
rate
for
her
brother
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
almost
brought
about
,
and
had
then
been
hindered
altogether
through
a
fault
on
her
brother
's
part
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
forgiven
him
this
sin
as
she
had
forgiven
many
others
,
and
she
was
now
at
work
in
his
behalf
again
,
determined
that
they
two
should
be
married
,
even
though
neither
of
them
might
be
now
anxious
that
it
should
be
so
.
<EOS>
The
intrigue
itself
was
dear
to
her
,
and
success
in
it
was
necessary
to
her
self
-
respect
.
  
<EOS>
She
answered
Alice
's
letter
with
a
pleasant
,
gossiping
epistle
,
which
shall
be
recorded
,
as
it
will
tell
us
something
of
Mrs.
Greenow
's
proceedings
at
Yarmouth
.
<EOS>
Kate
had
promised
to
stay
at
Yarmouth
for
a
month
,
but
she
had
already
been
there
six
weeks
,
and
was
still
under
her
aunt
's
wing
.
  
<EOS>
Yarmouth
,
October
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
DEAREST
ALICE
,
  
<EOS>
Of
course
I
am
delighted
.
<EOS>
It
is
no
good
saying
that
I
am
not
.
<EOS>
I
know
how
difficult
it
is
to
deal
with
you
,
and
therefore
I
sit
down
to
answer
your
letter
with
fear
and
trembling
,
lest
I
should
say
a
word
too
much
,
and
thereby
drive
you
back
,
or
not
say
quite
enough
and
thereby
fail
to
encourage
you
on
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
am
glad
.
<EOS>
I
have
long
thought
that
Mr.
Grey
could
not
make
you
happy
,
and
as
I
have
thought
so
,
how
can
I
not
be
glad
?
<EOS>
It
is
no
use
saying
that
he
is
good
and
noble
,
and
all
that
sort
of
thing
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
denied
it
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
not
suited
to
you
,
and
his
life
would
have
made
you
wretched
.
<EOS>
Ergo
,
I

.
<EOS>
And
as
you
are
the
dearest
friend
I
have
,
of
course
I
rejoice
mightily
.
  
<EOS>
I
can
understand
accurately
the
sort
of
way
in
which
the
interview
went
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
had
the
best
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
can
see
him
so
plainly
as
he
stood

in
unruffled
self

,
ignoring
all

you
said
,

.
<EOS>
I
suppose

's
very

,

,
and

,

,
another

;
but
there

is
almost
too

.
<EOS>
I
think

of
you
,
<EOS>
my

,
as
women

,

John
Grey
's

.
  
<EOS>
Of
course
I
'm
very
glad
.
<EOS>
You
have
known
my
mind
from
the
first
to
the
last
,
and
,
therefore
,
what

good

my

?
<EOS>
No
woman

.
<EOS>
You
would

,

Mrs.
Grey

,

.
<EOS>
I
do

what
Nethercoats

,
 
but

.
<EOS>
A
flat
Eden
I
can
fancy

,

,
in
which

,

;

.
<EOS>
But

Eden

not

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I
can
fancy

poor

the

,

that

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
I

of

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
He

.

.
<EOS>
But

,

.

;

.

I

!
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

But

,

.
<EOS>
My

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Otherwise

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

solid

,

by

.
<EOS>
He

,

Mrs.
Cheesacre
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
Oileymead
is
the
name

;
 
not

pretty

Nethercoats
,

?
<EOS>
And

!
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
I

by

out
your
hand
.
<EOS>
"
When
I
remarked
that
his
mind
seemed
to
be
intent
on
low
things
,
and
specially
named
the
muck
,
she
only
laughed
at
me
.
<EOS>
"
Money
's
never
dirty
,
"
she
said
,
"
nor
yet
what
makes
money
.
"
<EOS>
She
talks
of
taking
lodgings
in
Norwich
for
the
winter
,
saying
that
in
her
widowed
state
she
will
be
as
well
there
as
anywhere
else
,
and
she
wants
me
to
stay
with
her
up
to
Christmas
.
<EOS>
Indeed
she
first
proposed
the
Norwich
plan
on
the
ground
that
it
might
be
useful
to
me
,
 
with

view

Mr.
Cheesacre
,
of

;
but
I
fancy
that
she
is
unwilling
to

away
from
Captain
Bellfield
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
to
Norwich
she
will
go
,
and
I
have
promised
not
to
leave
her
before
the
second
week
in
November
.
<EOS>
With
all
her

I
like
her
.
<EOS>
Her
faults
are
terrible

,
but
she
has
not
the
fault
of
hiding
them
by
falsehood
.
<EOS>
She
is
never
stupid
,
and
she
is
very
good

natured
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
allowed
me
to
equip

from
head

at
her

,
if
I

accepted
her

,
and
absolutely

to
give

I
would

Mr.
Cheesacre
.
  
<EOS>
I
live
in

that
you
will
come
down

the
old

at
Christmas
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't

more

I

.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
he
wo
n't
be
there
.
<EOS>
And

I
do

,

to

?
<EOS>
If
I

I
would

go
to
Cheltenham
.
<EOS>
You
are
never
happy
there
.
  
<EOS>
Do

the
river
at
Basle
?
<EOS>
I
do
;
 
so
often
.
  
<EOS>
Most
affectionately
yours
,
  
KATE
VAVASOR
.
  
<EOS>
Alice

almost

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

not

"

"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
As

term

,
and

,

,

in

,

.
<EOS>
So

,

"
any

daughter
.
"
<EOS>
And

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"

,
"

"

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
And

.
"
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
But

,

.

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

;

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
His

Districts
would

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
Alice

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Somebody
told

that

,
"
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
So

,

is
not

your

Nimrods
,
 
men
who
are
hunters
upon

earth
.
<EOS>
Two
days
among
the
grouse
and
two
more
among

partridges
are
about

of
it
.
<EOS>
Capel
Court
is
the
preserve
in
which
I
am
usually

.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
knew
nothing
of
Capel
Court
,
and
said
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have

Kate
?
"
George

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
once
or

;

Aunt
Greenow
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
is
going
to
Norwich
,
as
she

.
<EOS>
Kate
seems
to
have
made
a
league
with
Aunt
Greenow
.
<EOS>
I
,
who
do
n't

disinterested
in

,

that
she
is

.
<EOS>
No

Aunt
Greenow
may
marry
again
,
but
friends
with

are
always

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
that
Kate
thinks
much
of
that
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
so
much
as
she
ought
,
I
dare

.
<EOS>
Poor
Kate
is
not
a
rich

,

,
I

,
likely
to

.
<EOS>
She
does
n't
seem
to
dream
of
getting
married
,
and
her
own

is
less
than
a
hundred
a
year
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Girls
who
never
dream
of
getting
married
are
just
those
who
make
the
best
marriages
at
last
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
so
,
<EOS>
but
I
wish
I
was
easier
about
Kate
.
<EOS>
She
is
the
best
sister
a
man
ever
had
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
she
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
have
done
nothing
for
her
as
yet
.
<EOS>
I
did
think
,
while
I
was
in
that
wine
business
,
that
I
could
have
done
anything
I
pleased
for
her
.
<EOS>
But
my
grandfather
's
obstinacy
put
me
out
of
that
;
and
now
I
'm
beginning
the
world
again
,
 
that
is
,
comparatively
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
you
think
I
'm
wrong
in
trying
to
get
into
Parliament
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
quite
right
.
<EOS>
I
admire
you
for
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
just
what
I
would
do
in
your
place
.
<EOS>
You
are
unmarried
,
and
have
a
right
to
run
the
risk
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
glad
to
hear
you
speak
like
that
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
He
had
now
managed
to
take
up
that
friendly
,
confidential
,
almost
affectionate
tone
of
talking
which
he
had
so
often
used
when
abroad
with
her
,
and
which
he
had
failed
to
assume
when
first
entering
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
thought
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
never
said
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have
n't
I
?
<EOS>
I
thought
I
had
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
heartily
like
that
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
people
abuse
me
;
 
<EOS>
my
own
people
,
my
grandfather
,
and
probably
your
father
,
 
saying
that
I
am
reckless
and
the
rest
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
risk
everything
for
my
object
;
but
I
do
not
know
that
any
one
can
blame
me
,
 
unless
it
be
Kate
.
<EOS>
To
whom
else
do
I
owe
anything
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Kate
does
not
blame
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
she
sympathizes
with
me
;
<EOS>
she
,
and
she
only
,
unless
it
be
you
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
paused
for
an
answer
,
but
she
made
him
none
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
is
brave
enough
to
give
me
her
hearty
sympathy
.
<EOS>
But
perhaps
for
that
very
reason
I
ought
to
be
the
more
chary
in
endangering
the
only
support
that
she
is
like
to
have
.
<EOS>
What
is
ninety
pounds
a
year
for
the
maintenance
of
a
single
lady
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
that
Kate
will
always
live
with
me
,
"
said
Alice
;
"
that
is
,
as
soon
as
she
has
lost
her
home
at
Vavasor
Hall
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
very
crafty
and
had
laid
a
trap
for
her
.
<EOS>
He
had
laid
a
trap
for
her
,
and
she
had
fallen
into
it
.
<EOS>
She
had
determined
not
to
be
induced
to
talk
of
herself
;
but
he
had
brought
the
thing
round
so
cunningly
that
the
words
were
out
of
her
mouth
before
she
remembered
whither
they
would
lead
her
.
<EOS>
She
did
remember
this
as
she
was
speaking
them
,
but
then
it
was
too
late
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
;
 
at
Nethercoats
?
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Neither
she
nor
I
doubt
your
love
,
but
few
men
would
like
such
an
intruder
as
that
into
their
household
,
and
of
all
men
Mr.
Grey
,
whose
nature
is
retiring
,
would
like
it
the
least
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
thinking
of
Nethercoats
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
no
;
that
is
it
,
you
see
.
<EOS>
Kate
says
so
often
to
me
that
when
you
are
married
she
will
be
alone
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
she
will
ever
find
that
I
shall
separate
myself
from
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
not
by
any
will
of
your
own
.
<EOS>
Poor
Kate
!
<EOS>
You
can
not
be
surprised
that
she
should
think
of
your
marriage
with
dread
.
<EOS>
How
much
of
her
life
has
been
made
up
of
her
companionship
with
you
;
 
and
all
the
best
of
it
too
!
<EOS>
You
ought
not
to
be
angry
with
her
for
regarding
your
withdrawal
into
Cambridgeshire
with
dismay
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
could
not
act
the
lie
which
now
seemed
to
be
incumbent
on
her
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
let
him
talk
of
Nethercoats
as
though
it
were
to
be
her
future
home
.
<EOS>
She
made
the
struggle
,
and
she
found
that
she
could
not
do
it
.
<EOS>
She
was
unable
to
find
the
words
which
should
tell
no
lie
to
the
ear
,
and
which
should
yet
deceive
him
.
"
<EOS>
Kate
may
still
live
with
me
,
"
she
said
slowly
.
<EOS>
"
Everything
is
over
between
me
and
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Alice
!
 
is
that
true
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
George
;
it
is
true
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
allow
me
to
say
so
<EOS>
,
I
would
rather
not
talk
about
it
;
 
not
just
at
present
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
does
Kate
know
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Kate
knows
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
my
uncle
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
papa
knows
it
also
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
how
can
I
help
speaking
of
it
?
<EOS>
How
can
I
not
tell
you
that
I
am
rejoiced
that
you
are
saved
from
a
thraldom
which
I
have
long
felt
sure
would
break
your
heart
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
not
talk
of
it
further
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
if
I
am
forbidden
I
shall
of
course
obey
.
<EOS>
But
I
own
it
is
hard
to
me
.
<EOS>
How
can
I
not
congratulate
you
?
"
<EOS>
To
this
she
answered
nothing
,
but
beat
with
her
foot
upon
the
floor
as
though
she
were
impatient
of
his
words
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Alice
,
I
understand
.
<EOS>
You
are
angry
with
me
,
"
he
continued
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
you
have
no
right
to
be
surprised
that
when
you
tell
me
this
I
should
think
of
all
that
passed
between
us
in
Switzerland
.
<EOS>
Surely
the
cousin
who
was
with
you
then
has
a
right
to
say
what
he
thinks
of
this
change
in
your
life
;
at
any
rate
he
may
do
so
,
if
as
in
this
case
he
approves
altogether
of
what
you
are
doing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
of
your
approval
,
George
;
but
pray
let
that
be
an
end
to
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
that
the
two
sat
silent
for
a
minute
or
two
.
<EOS>
She
was
waiting
for
him
to
go
,
but
she
could
not
bid
him
leave
the
house
.
<EOS>
She
was
angry
with
herself
,
in
that
she
had
allowed
herself
to
tell
him
of
her
altered
plans
,
and
she
was
angry
with
him
because
he
would
not
understand
that
she
ought
to
be
spared
all
conversation
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
So
she
sat
looking
through
the
window
at
the
row
of
gaslights
as
they
were
being
lit
,
and
he
remained
in
his
chair
with
his
elbow
on
the
table
and
his
head
resting
on
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember
asking
me
whether
I
ever
shivered
,
"
he
said
at
last
;
"
 
whether
I
ever
thought
of
things
that
made
me
shiver
?
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
remember
;
on
the
bridge
at
Basle
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
remember
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Alice
;
 
one
cause
for
my
shivering
is
over
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
say
more
than
that
now
.
<EOS>
Shall
you
remain
long
at
Cheltenham
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just
a
month
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
then
you
come
back
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
so
.
<EOS>
Papa
and
I
will
probably
go
down
to
Vavasor
Hall
before
Christmas
.
<EOS>
How
much
before
I
can
not
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
shall
see
you
at
any
rate
after
your
return
from
Cheltenham
?
<EOS>
Of
course
Kate
will
know
,
and
she
will
tell
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
Kate
will
know
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
she
will
stay
here
when
she
comes
up
from
Norfolk
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
I
shall
have
fewer
fits
of
that
inward
shivering
that
you
spoke
of
,
 
many
less
,
on
account
of
what
I
have
now
heard
.
<EOS>
God
bless
you
,
Alice
;
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
George
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
went
he
took
her
hand
and
pressed
it
closely
between
his
own
.
<EOS>
In
those
days
when
they
were
lovers
,
 
engaged
lovers
,
a
close
,
long
-
continued
pressure
of
her
hand
had
been
his
most
eloquent
speech
of
love
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
given
to
many
kisses
,
 
not
even
to
many
words
of
love
.
<EOS>
But
he
would
take
her
hand
and
hold
it
,
even
as
he
looked
away
from
her
,
and
she
remembered
well
the
touch
of
his
palm
.
<EOS>
It
was
ever
cool
,
 
cool
,
and
with
a
surface
smooth
as
a
woman
's
,
 
a
small
hand
that
had
a
firm
grip
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
days
when
she
had
loved
to
feel
that
her
own
was
within
it
,
when
she
trusted
in
it
,
and
intended
that
it
should
be
her
staff
through
life
.
<EOS>
Now
she
distrusted
it
;
and
as
the
thoughts
of
the
old
days
came
upon
her
,
and
the
remembrance
of
that
touch
was
recalled
,
she
drew
her
hand
away
rapidly
.
<EOS>
Not
for
that
had
she
driven
from
her
as
honest
a
man
as
had
ever
wished
to
mate
with
a
woman
.
<EOS>
He
,
George
Vavasor
,
had
never
so
held
her
hand
since
the
day
when
they
had
parted
,
and
now
on
this
first
occasion
of
her
freedom
she
felt
it
again
.
<EOS>
What
did
he
think
of
her
?
<EOS>
Did
he
suppose
that
she
could
transfer
her
love
in
that
way
,
as
a
flower
may
be
taken
from
one
buttonhole
and
placed
in
another
?
<EOS>
He
read
it
all
,
and
knew
that
he
was
hurrying
on
too
quickly
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
understand
well
,
"
he
said
in
a
whisper
,
"
what
your
present
feelings
are
;
but
I
do
not
think
you
will
be
really
angry
with
me
because
I
have
been
unable
to
repress
my
joy
at
what
I
can
not
but
regard
as
your
release
from
a
great
misfortune
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
went
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
release
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
seating
herself
on
the
chair
from
which
he
had
risen
.
<EOS>
"
My
release
from
a
misfortune
!
<EOS>
No
;
 
but
my
fall
from
heaven
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
a
man
he
is
!
<EOS>
That
he
should
have
loved
me
,
and
that
I
should
have
driven
him
away
from
me
!
"
<EOS>
Her
thoughts
travelled
off
to
the
sweetness
of
that
home
at
Nethercoats
,
to
the
excellence
of
that
master
who
might
have
been
hers
;
and
then
in
an
agony
of
despair
she
told
herself
that
she
had
been
an
idiot
and
a
fool
,
as
well
as
a
traitor
.
<EOS>
What
had
she
wanted
in
life
that
she
should
have
thus
quarrelled
with
as
happy
a
lot
as
ever
had
been
offered
to
a
woman
?
<EOS>
Had
she
not
been
mad
,
when
she
sent
from
her
side
the
only
man
that
she
loved
,
 
the
only
man
that
she
had
ever
truly
respected
?
<EOS>
For
hours
she
sat
there
,
all
alone
,
putting
out
the
candles
which
the
servant
had
lighted
for
her
,
and
leaving
untasted
the
tea
that
was
brought
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Alice
!
<EOS>
I
hope
that
she
may
be
forgiven
.
<EOS>
It
was
her
special
fault
,
that
when
at
Rome
she
longed
for
Tibur
,
and
when
at
Tibur
she
regretted
Rome
.
<EOS>
Not
that
her
cousin
George
is
to
be
taken
as
representing
the
joys
of
the
great
capital
,
though
Mr.
Grey
may
be
presumed
to
form
no
inconsiderable
part
of
the
promised
delights
of
the
country
.
<EOS>
Now
that
she
had
sacrificed
her
Tibur
,
because
it
had
seemed
to
her
that
the
sunny
quiet
of
its
pastures
lacked
the
excitement
necessary
for
the
happiness
of
life
,
she
was
again
prepared
to
quarrel
with
the
heartlessness
of
Rome
,
and
already
was
again
sighing
for
the
tranquillity
of
the
country
.
  
<EOS>
Sitting
there
,
full
of
these
regrets
,
she
declared
to
herself
that
she
would
wait
for
her
father
's
return
,
and
then
,
throwing
herself
upon
his
love
and
upon
his
mercy
,
would
beg
him
to
go
to
Mr.
Grey
and
ask
for
pardon
for
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
very
humble
to
him
,
"
she
said
;
"
but
he
is
so
good
,
that
I
may
dare
to
be
humble
before
him
.
"
<EOS>
So
she
waited
for
her
father
.
<EOS>
She
waited
till
twelve
,
till
one
,
till
two
;
 
but
still
he
did
not
come
.
<EOS>
Later
than
that
she
did
not
dare
to
wait
for
him
.
<EOS>
She
feared
to
trust
him
on
such
business
returning
so
late
as
that
,
 
after
so
many
cigars
;
after
,
perhaps
,
some
superfluous
beakers
of
club
nectar
.
<EOS>
His
temper
at
such
a
moment
would
not
be
fit
for
such
work
as
hers
.
<EOS>
But
if
he
was
late
in
coming
home
,
who
had
sent
him
away
from
his
home
in
unhappiness
?
<EOS>
Between
two
and
three
<EOS>
she
went
to
bed
,
and
on
the
following
morning
she
left
Queen
Anne
Street
for
the
Great
Western
Station
before
her
father
was
up
.
   
<EOS>
Paramount
Crescent
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
lived
at
No
.
3
,
Paramount
Crescent
,
in
Cheltenham
,
where
she
occupied
a
very
handsome
first
-
floor
drawing
-
room
,
with
a
bedroom
behind
it
,
looking
over
a
stable
-
yard
,
and
a
small
room
which
would
have
been
the
dressing
-
room
had
the
late
Sir
Archibald
been
alive
,
but
which
was
at
present
called
the
dining
-
room
:
and
in
it
Lady
Macleod
did
dine
whenever
her
larger
room
was
to
be
used
for
any
purposes
of
evening
company
.
<EOS>
The
vicinity
of
the
stable
-
yard
was
not
regarded
by
the
tenant
as
among
the
attractions
of
the
house
;
but
it
had
the
effect
of
lowering
the
rent
,
and
Lady
Macleod
was
a
woman
who
regarded
such
matters
.
<EOS>
Her
income
,
though
small
,
would
have
sufficed
to
enable
her
to
live
removed
from
such
discomforts
;
but
she
was
one
of
those
women
who
regard
it
as
a
duty
to
leave
something
behind
them
,
 
even
though
it
be
left
to
those
who
do
not
at
all
want
it
;
and
Lady
Macleod
was
a
woman
who
wilfully
neglected
no
duty
.
<EOS>
So
she
pinched
herself
,
and
inhaled
the
effluvia
of
the
stables
,
and
squabbled
with
the
cabmen
,
in
order
that
she
might
bequeath
a
thousand
pounds
or
two
to
some
Lady
Midlothian
,
who
cared
,
perhaps
,
little
for
her
,
and
would
hardly
thank
her
memory
for
the
money
.
  
<EOS>
Had
Alice
consented
to
live
with
her
,
she
would
have
merged
that
duty
of
leaving
money
behind
her
in
that
other
duty
of
finding
a
home
for
her
adopted
niece
.
<EOS>
But
Alice
had
gone
away
,
and
therefore
the
money
was
due
to
Lady
Midlothian
rather
than
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
saving
,
however
,
was
postponed
whenever
Alice
would
consent
to
visit
Cheltenham
;
and
a
bedroom
was
secured
for
her
which
did
not
look
out
over
the
stables
.
<EOS>
Accommodation
was
also
found
for
her
maid
much
better
than
that
provided
for
Lady
Macleod
's
own
maid
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
hospitable
,
good
old
woman
,
painfully
struggling
to
do
the
best
she
could
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
pity
that
she
was
such
a
bore
,
a
pity
that
she
was
so
hard
to
cabmen
and
others
,
a
pity
that
she
suspected
all
tradesmen
,
servants
,
and
people
generally
of
a
rank
of
life
inferior
to
her
own
,
a
pity
that
she
was
disposed
to
condemn
for
ever
and
ever
so
many
of
her
own
rank
because
they
played
cards
on
week
days
,
and
did
not
go
to
church
on
Sundays
,
 
and
a
pity
,
as
I
think
above
all
,
that
while
she
was
so
suspicious
of
the
poor
she
was
so
lenient
to
the
vices
of
earls
,
earl
's
sons
,
and
such
like
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
,
having
fully
considered
the
matter
,
had
thought
it
most
prudent
to
tell
Lady
Macleod
by
letter
what
she
had
done
in
regard
to
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
many
objections
to
the
writing
of
such
a
letter
,
but
there
appeared
to
be
stronger
objection
to
that
telling
it
face
to
face
which
would
have
been
forced
upon
her
<EOS>
had
she
not
written
.
<EOS>
There
would
in
such
case
have
arisen
on
Lady
Macleod
's
countenance
a
sternness
of
rebuke
which
Alice
did
not
choose
to
encounter
.
<EOS>
The
same
sternness
of
rebuke
would
come
upon
the
countenance
on
receipt
of
the
written
information
;
but
it
would
come
in
its
most
aggravated
form
on
the
immediate

of
the
letter
,
and
some
of
its
bitterness
would
have
passed
away
before
Alice
's
arrival
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
Alice
was
right
.
<EOS>
It
is
better
for
both
parties
that
any
great
offence
should
be
confessed
by
letter
.
  
<EOS>
But
Alice
trembled
as
the
cab
drew
up
at
No
.
3
,
Paramount
Crescent
.
<EOS>
She
met
her
aunt
,
as
was
usual
,
just
inside
the
drawing

room
door
,
and
she
saw
at
once
that
if
any
bitterness
had
passed
away
from
that
face
,
the
original

must
indeed
have
been
bitter
.
<EOS>
She
had
so
timed
her
letter
that
Lady
Macleod
should
have
no

of
answering
it
.
<EOS>
The
answer
was
written
there
in
the
mingled

of
those

features
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
!
"
<EOS>
she

,
as
she
took
her
niece
in

kissed
her
;
"
oh
,
Alice
,
what
is
this
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
aunt
;
it
is
very
bad
,
I
know
,
"
and
poor
Alice
tried
to
make
a
jest
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
Young
ladies
are
very
wicked
when
they
do
n't
know

own

.
<EOS>
But
if
they
have
n't
known
them
and
have
been
wicked
,
what
can

do
but
repent
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Repent
!
"
said
Lady
Macleod
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
hope
you
will
repent
.
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Grey
;
 
<EOS>
what
must
he
think
of
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
only
hope
,
aunt
,
that
he
wo

think
of
it
at
all
for
very
long
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
nonsense
,
my
dear
,
Of
course

'll
think

it
,
and
of
course

'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shall

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
will
.
<EOS>
Why
,
Alice
,
has

it
been
all
settled
among

?
<EOS>
Lady
Midlothian
knew

just

I

.
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
I

what
you

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
when

that

;
 
but
I
really

is
worse

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
they
may
if
they
please
put
me

of

;
 
only
that
I
do
n't
know

I
'm
particularly
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
the
wickedness
of
the
thing
,
Alice
!
<EOS>
I
'm

to
say

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When

talk

about
society
,
aunt
,
and
about
Lady
Midlothian
,
I
give
up
to
you
,
willingly
;
 
the
more
willingly
,
perhaps
,
because
I
do
n't
care
much
for
one
or
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
Here
Lady
Macleod
tried
to
say
a
word
;
but
she
failed
,
and
Alice
went
on
,
boldly
looking
up
into
her
aunt
's
face
,
which
became
a
shade
more
bitter
than
ever
.
"
<EOS>
But
when
you
tell
me
about
wickedness
and
my

,
then
I
must
be
my
own
judge
.
<EOS>
It
is
my
conscience
,
and
the
fear
of
committing
wickedness
,
that
has
made
me
do
this
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
submit
to
be
guided
by
your
elders
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
my
elders
in
such
a
matter
as
this
can
not
teach
me
.
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
right
that
I
should
go
to
a
man
's
house
and
be
his
wife
,
if
I
do
not
think
that
I
can
make
him
happy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
did
you
accept

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
was
mistaken
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
going
to
defend
that
.
<EOS>
If
you
choose
to
scold
me
for
that
,
you
may
do
so
,
aunt
,
and
I
will
not
answer
you
.
<EOS>
But
as
to
marrying
him
or
not
marrying
him
now
,
 
as
to
that
,
I
must
judge
for
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
pity
<EOS>
you
did
not
know
your
own
mind
earlier
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
pity
,
 
a
great
pity
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
myself
an
injury
that
is
quite
irretrievable
;
 
I
know
that
,
and
am
prepared
to
bear
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
him
,
too
,
an
injustice
which
I
regret
with
my
whole
heart
.
<EOS>
I
can
only
excuse
myself
by
saying
that
I
might
have
done
him
a
worse
injustice
.
"
  
<EOS>
All
this
was
said
at
the
very
moment
of
her
arrival
,
and
the
greeting
did
not
seem
to
promise
much
for
the
happiness
of
the
next
month
;
but
perhaps
it
was
better
for
them
both
that
the
attack
and
the
defence
should
thus
be
made
suddenly
,
at
their
first
meeting
.
<EOS>
It
is
better
to
pull
the
string
at
once
when
you
are
in
the
shower
-
bath
,
and
not
to
stand
shivering
,
thinking
of
the
inevitable
shock
which
you
can
only
postpone
for
a
few
minutes
.
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
in
this
case
had
pulled
the
string
,
and
thus
reaped
the
advantage
of
her
alacrity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
,
"
said

,
"
I
suppose
you
will
like
to
go
up
-
stairs
and
take

bonnet
.
<EOS>
Mary
shall
bring
you
some
tea
when
you
come
down
.
"
<EOS>
So
Alice
escaped
,
and
when
she
returned
to
the
comfort
of
her
cup
of
tea
in
the
drawing
-
room
,
the
fury
of
the
storm
had
passed
away
.
<EOS>
She
sat
talking
of
other
things
till

;
and
though
Lady
Macleod
did
during
the
evening
make
one
allusion
to
"
poor
Mr.
Grey
,
"
the
subject
was
allowed
to
drop
.
<EOS>
Alice
was
very
tender
as
to
her
aunt
's

,
was
more
than
ordinarily

to
the
long
list
of
Cheltenham
iniquities
which
was
displayed
to
her
,
and
refrained
from
combating
any
of
her
aunt
's

.
<EOS>
After

got
upon

subject
of
Aunt
Greenow
,
for
whose

Lady

had
a

,
 
as

<EOS>
she
had
for

the
Vavasor
side

Alice
's

;
and
then
Alice

to
read
,
and
did

to
her
aunt
many

out
of
one
of
those

books
of

,
which
from

to

come
forth
and
tell
us
that
there
is
no
hope
for
us
.
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
liked
to
be
so
told
;
and
as
she
now
,
poor
woman
,
could
not
read
at
nights
herself
,
she
enjoyed
her

.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
no

did
enjoy
her
niece
's
sojourn
at
Cheltenham
,
but
I
do
not
think
it

.
<EOS>
On

nothing

Grey
,
and
Alice
hoped
that
by
her

in
the
book

<EOS>
her

's

might

her
.
<EOS>
But

that
Lady
Macleod
measured

,
for
on

third

.
"
<EOS>
Did
John
Grey
still

?
"
<EOS>
she

,

.
<EOS>
It

that
Alice
tried

,

.
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
insisted

her

to

,
and
Alice
was
driven
to

did

.
<EOS>
She
could

,
seeing

at

him
in

,

,
and

this

from
London
to
Cheltenham
would

and

to

.
<EOS>
He
certainly
did
,
in
a
fashion
,
wave
his

over
her
,
as
Kate
had
said
of
him
.
<EOS>
This
letter
Alice
had
resolved
that
she
would
not

.
<EOS>
He
would
probably
write
again
,
and
she
would
beg
him
to
desist
.
<EOS>
Instead
of
Cheltenham
bringing
her
round
,
Cheltenham
had
made
her
firmer
than
ever
in
her
resolution
.
<EOS>
I
am

to
think

at
this

,

.
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
's

would
certainly

.
  
<EOS>
After
ten

,
ten

,
devoted

,

,
 
relieved

,

of
Cheltenham
were

at
length
,
 
Lady
Macleod
herself
got
a
letter
from
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
's
kindest
compliments
to
Lady
Macleod
.
<EOS>
He
believed
that
Lady
Macleod
was
aware
of
the
circumstances
of
his
engagement
with
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Might
he
call
on
Miss
Vavasor
at

Macleod
's

in
Cheltenham
?
<EOS>
and
might
he
also
hope
to
have
the

of
making
Lady
Macleod
's
acquaintance
?
<EOS>
Alice
had
been
in
the
room
when
her
aunt
received
this
letter
,
but
her
aunt
had
said
nothing
,
and
Alice
had
not
known
from
whom
the
letter
had
come
.
<EOS>
When

aunt
crept
away

she
had

nothing
,
and
had
never
imagined
that
Lady
Macleod
,
in
the
privacy
of
her
own
room
looking
out
upon
the

,
had
addressed
a
letter
to
Nethercoats
.
<EOS>
But
such
a
letter
had
been
addressed
to
Nethercoats
,
and
Mr.
Grey
had
been
informed
that
he

received
in
Paramount

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
had
even

the
day
on
which
he
would
come
,
and

Lady

presided

in

.
<EOS>
More

,

specially

aunt

,
but

so

that

.
<EOS>
"
There
's
nothing
the
matter
,
my

,
at

,
"

to

<EOS>
Then

.
<EOS>
She

's

,

<EOS>
"
Alice

.
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>
Lady

.
<EOS>
At

was

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

was

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
Alice

.

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

my

that
I

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
Her

,
if

,

.
<EOS>
He
glared
in

,
and
was

in

.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Grey
when
speaking
of
the
happiness
of
his
entire

,
when
confessing
that
it
was
now
at
stake
with
a
decision
against

that
would
be
ruinous
to
it
,
spoke
without

,
and

of

in

than
if

were

gardener
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
 
and
believe
that
you
will
find
your
happiness
elsewhere
,
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
we
can
but
differ
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
In
that
we
do
differ
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
will
say
one
word
to
explain
why
I
have
come
here
.
<EOS>
If
I
were
to
write
to
you
against
your
will
,
it
would
seem
that
I
were
persecuting
you
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
bring
myself
to
do
that
,
even
though
I
had
the
right
.
<EOS>
But
if
I
were
to
let
you
go
from
me
,
taking
what
you
have
said
to
me
and
doing
nothing
,
it
would
seem
that
I
had
accepted
your
decision
as
final
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
do
so
.
<EOS>
I
come
simply
to
tell
you
that
I
am
still

.
<EOS>
If
you
will
let
me
,
I
will
see
you
again
early
in
January
,
 
as
soon
as
you
have
returned
to
town
.
<EOS>
You
will
hardly
refuse
to
see
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
said
;
"
I
can
not
refuse
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
it
shall
be
so
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
I
will
not
trouble
you
with
letters
,
nor
will

trouble

longer
now
with
words
.
<EOS>
Tell
your
aunt
that
I
have
said
what
I
came
to
say
,
and
that
I
give
her
my
kindest
thanks
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
took
her
hand
and
pressed
it
,
 
not
as
George
Vavasor
had
pressed
it
,
 
and
was
gone
.
<EOS>
When
Lady
Macleod
returned
,
she
found
that
the
question
of
the
evening
's
tea
arrangements
had
settled
itself
.
   
<EOS>
The
Roebury
Club
.
 
<EOS>
It
has
been
said
that
George
Vavasor
had
a
little
establishment
at
Roebury
,
down
in
Oxfordshire
,
and
thither
he
betook
himself
about
the
middle
of
November
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
long
known
in
this
county
,
and
whether
or
no
men
spoke
well
of
him
as
a
man
of
business
in
London
,
men
spoke
well
of
him
down
there
,
as
one
who
knew
how
to
ride
to
hounds
.
<EOS>
Not
that
Vavasor
was
popular
among
fellow
-
sportsmen
.
<EOS>
It
was
quite
otherwise
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
man
that
made
himself
really
popular
in
any
social
meetings
of
men
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
himself
care
for
the
loose
little
talkings
,
half
flat
and
half
sharp
,
of
men
when
they
meet
together
in
idleness
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
open
enough
in
his
nature
for
such
popularity
.
<EOS>
Some
men
were
afraid
of
him
,
and
some
suspected
him
.
<EOS>
There
were
others
who
made
up
to
him
,
seeking
his
intimacy
,
but
these
he
usually
snubbed
,
and
always
kept
at
a
distance
.
<EOS>
Though
he
had
indulged
in
all
the
ordinary
pleasures
of
young
men
,
he
had
never
been
a
jovial
man
.
<EOS>
In
his
conversations
with
men
he
always
seemed
to
think
that
he
should
use
his
time
towards
serving
some
purpose
of
business
.
<EOS>
With
women
he
was
quite
the
reverse
.
<EOS>
With
women
he
could
be
happy
.
<EOS>
With
women
he
could
really
associate
.
<EOS>
A
woman
he
could
really
love
;
 
<EOS>
but
I
doubt
whether
for
all
that
he
could
treat
a
woman
well
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
was
known
in
the
Oxfordshire
country
as
a
man
who
knew
what
he
was
about
,
and
such
men
are
always
welcome
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
man
who
does
not
know
how
to
ride
that
is
made
uncomfortable
in
the
hunting
field
by
cold
looks
or
expressed
censure
.
<EOS>
And
yet
it
is
very
rarely
that
such
men
do
any
real
harm
.
<EOS>
Such
a
one
may
now
and
then
get
among
the
hounds
or
override
the
hunt
,
but
it
is
not
often
so
.
<EOS>
Many
such
complaints
are
made
;
but
in
truth
the
too
forward
man
,
who
presses
the
dogs
,
is
generally
one
who
can
ride
,
but
is
too
eager
or
too
selfish
to
keep
in
his
proper
place
.
<EOS>
The
bad
rider
,
like
the
bad
whist
player
,
pays
highly
for
what
he
does
not
enjoy
,
and
should
be
thanked
.
<EOS>
But
at
both
games
he
gets
cruelly
snubbed
.
<EOS>
At
both
games
George
Vavasor
was
great
and
he
never
got
snubbed
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
men
who
lived
together
at
Roebury
in
a
kind
of
club
,
 
four
or
five
of
them
,
who
came
thither
from
London
,
running
backwards
and
forwards
as
hunting
arrangements
enabled
them
to
do
so
,
 
a
brewer
or
two
and
a
banker
,
with
a
would
-
be
fast
attorney
,
a
sporting
literary
gentleman
,
and
a
young
unmarried
Member
of
Parliament
who
had
no
particular
home
of
his
own
in
the
country
.
<EOS>
These
men
formed
the
Roebury
Club
,
and
a
jolly
life
they
had
of
it
.
<EOS>
They
had
their
own
wine
closet
at
the
King
's
Head
,
 
or
Roebury
Inn
as
the
house
had
come
to
be
popularly
called
,
 
and
supplied
their
own
game
.
<EOS>
The
landlord
found
everything
else
;
and
as
they
were
not
very
particular
about
their
bills
,
they
were
allowed
to
do
pretty
much
as
they
liked
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
They
were
rather
imperious
,
very
late
in
their
hours
,
sometimes
,
though
not
often
,
noisy
,
and
once
there
had
been
a
hasty
quarrel
which
had
made
the
landlord
in
his
anger
<EOS>
say
that
the
club
should
be
turned
out
of
his
house
.
<EOS>
But
they
paid
well
,
chaffed
the
servants
much
oftener
than
they
bullied
them
,
and
on
the
whole
were
very
popular
.
  
<EOS>
To
this
club
Vavasor
did
not
belong
,
alleging
that
he
could
not
afford
to
live
at
their
pace
,
and
alleging
,
also
,
that
his
stays
at
Roebury
were
not
long
enough
to
make
him
a
desirable
member
.
<EOS>
The
invitation
to
him
was
not
repeated
and
he
lodged
elsewhere
in
the
little
town
.
<EOS>
But
he
occasionally
went
in
of
an
evening
,
and
would
make
up
with
the
members
a
table
at
whist
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
come
down
to
Roebury
by
mail
train
,
ready
for
hunting
the
next
morning
,
and
walked
into
the
club
-
room
just
at
midnight
.
<EOS>
There
he
found
Maxwell
the
banker
,
Grindley
the
would
-
be
fast
attorney
,
and
Calder

the
Member

,
playing
dummy
.
<EOS>
Neither
of
the
brewers
were
there
,
nor
was
the
sporting

gentleman
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
's
Vavasor
,
"

,
"
and
now

wo

blackguard

.
<EOS>
Somebody

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

;
 
what

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
By

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Yes

<EOS>
Vavasor

.
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,
and

,
 
or

.
"
<EOS>

plate
a
second
mutton
chop
,
which
had
just
been
brought
up
hot
into
the
room
especially
for
him
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
mistake
men
make
about
horses
,
and
that
's
why
there
's
so
much
cheating
.
<EOS>
I
never
ask
for
a
warranty
with
a
horse
,
and
do
n't
very
often
have
a
horse
examined
.
<EOS>
Yet
I
do
as
well
as
others
.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
have
perfect
horses
any
more
than
you
can
perfect

,
or
perfect

.
<EOS>
You
put
up
with
red

,
or
bad

,
or
big
feet
,
 
or
sometimes
with
the

of

.
<EOS>
But
a
man
when
he
wants
a
horse
wo
n't
put
up
with
anything
!
<EOS>
Therefore
those
who
've

to
sell
must
lie
.
<EOS>
When
I
go
into
the
market
with
three
hundred
pounds
I
expect
a
perfect
animal
.
<EOS>
As
I
never
do
that
now
I
never
expect
a
perfect
animal
.
<EOS>
I
like
"
em
to
see
;
I
like
"
<EOS>
em

four

;
and
I
like
"

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
much

anything

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
Jove
you
're
about
right
,
"
said
Calder
Jones
.
<EOS>
The
reader
will
therefore

see
that
Mr.
Maxwell
the

as

.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor

in

Bat

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

Bat
with

about

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
They

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
What

them
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

,

;
 
very

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
And

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
There

"

"
  
<EOS>
George

,
but

.
<EOS>
Now
I
here
protest
that
there

.
<EOS>
Towards
the

had

had

,
and

by

with

.
<EOS>
Then

gone

a

,

attached

to

,
as

.
<EOS>
He

Tattersall
's
,

had

,
thinking

,
from

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

Bat

.
<EOS>
But

went
with

,
and

Bat
Smithers
thought

well

be

.
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
knew
as
much

,

,

,

,

;
but

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Therefore
he
took
Bat
's
word
and
felt

that
the
horse
was
wrong
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
have

,
"

George
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
they

,

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Then
,

,

Roebury
Club

.
  
<EOS>
There

,

,

.
<EOS>
Bat

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are

?

.
  
<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
That

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Whereupon

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Had

Vavasor
alone
<EOS>
he

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grindley
was
not

,
and
were

to

his

down

.
  
<EOS>
The

of
such
men
as
Mr.
Grindley
,
 
men
who
are

in
the
daily
society
of
others
who
are

,
do

seem

many

.
<EOS>
And
yet
how
many
such
men
does
one
see
in
almost

set
?
<EOS>
Why
Mr.
Grindley
should
have

to
Mr.
Maxwell
the

,
or

Stone
,
or

Prettyman
who

,
or

Mr.
Pollock
<EOS>
the
heavy
-

,
I
can

.
<EOS>
An

by
his

is
at
any
rate
as
good
as
a

,
and
there
are
many

who
hold

.
<EOS>
Grindley
was

rich

,
 
or

.
<EOS>
I
do

,

Maxwell
's
.
<EOS>
He
was
not

,
or
a

;
 
whereas
I
rather
think
Maxwell
was
a
fool
.
<EOS>
Grindley
had
made
his
own
way
in
the
world
,
but
Maxwell
would
certainly
not
have
made
himself
a
banker
if
his
father
had
not

before

;
nor
could

<EOS>
had

who

.
<EOS>
Grindley
knew
that
he
had
a

than
Maxwell
;
and
yet
he
allowed
Maxwell
to
snub

,
and
he
toadied
Maxwell
in

.
<EOS>
It
was
not
on
the
score
of

that
Maxwell
claimed
and
held

,
for
Grindley
did
not
want

,
and
every
one
knew
that
Maxwell
had
lived
freely
and
that
his
nerves
were
not
what
they
had
been
.
<EOS>
I
think
it
had
come
from
the
outward
look
of
the
men
,
from
the
form
of
each
,
from
the
gait
and
visage
which
in
one
was
good
and
in
the
other
insignificant
.
<EOS>
The
nature
of
such
dominion
of
man
over
man
is
very
singular
,
but
this
is
certain
that
when
once
obtained
in
manhood
it
may
be
easily
held
.
  
<EOS>
Among
boys
at
school
the
same
thing
is
even
more
conspicuous
,
because
boys
have
less
of
conscience
than
men
,
are
more
addicted
to
tyranny
,
and
when
weak
are
less
prone
to
feel
the
misery
and
disgrace
of
succumbing
.
<EOS>
Who
has
been
through
a
large
school
and
does
not
remember
the
Maxwells
and
Grindleys
,
 
the
tyrants
and
the
slaves
,
 
those
who
domineered
and
those
who
submitted
?
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
,
even
then
,
personal
strength
,
nor
always
superior
courage
,
that
gave
the
power
of
command
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
it
intellect
,
or
thoughtfulness
,
nor
by
any
means
such
qualities
as
make
men
and
boys
lovable
.
<EOS>
It
is
said
by
many
who
have
had
to
deal
with
boys
,
that
certain
among
them
claim
and
obtain
ascendancy
by
the
spirit
within
them
;
but
I
doubt
whether
the
ascendancy
is
not
rather
thrust
on
them
than
claimed
by
them
.
<EOS>
Here
again
I
think
the
outward
gait
of
the
boy
goes
far
towards
obtaining
for
him
the
submission
of
his
fellows
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
tyrant
boy
does
not
become
the
tyrant
man
,
or
the
slave
boy
the
slave
man
,
because
the
outward
visage
,
that
has
been
noble
or
mean
in
the
one
,
changes
and
becomes
so
often
mean
or
noble
in
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
By
George
,
there
's
Pollock
!
<EOS>
"
said
Maxwell
,
as
he
rode
into
the
field
by
the
church
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
bet
half
a
crown
that
he
's
come
down
from
London
this
morning
,
that
he
was
up
all
night
last
night
,
and
that
he
tells
us
<EOS>
so
three
times
before
the
hounds
go
out
of
the
paddock
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Pollock
was
the
heavy
-
weight
sporting
literary
gentleman
.
   
<EOS>
Edgehill
.
 
<EOS>
Of
all
sights
in
the
world
there
is
,
I
think
,
none
more
beautiful
than
that
of
a
pack
of
fox
-
hounds
seated
,
on
a
winter
morning
,
round
the
huntsman
,
if
the
place
of
meeting
has
been
chosen
with
anything
of
artistic
skill
.
<EOS>
It
should
be
in
a
grassy
field
,
and
the
field
should
be
small
.
<EOS>
It
should
not
be
absolutely
away
from
all
buildings
,
and
the
hedgerows
should
not
have
been
clipped
and
pared
,
and
made
straight
with
reference
to
modern
agricultural
economy
.
<EOS>
There
should
be
trees
near
,
and
the
ground
should
be
a
little
uneven
,
so
as
to
mark
some
certain
small
space
as
the
exact
spot
where
the
dogs
and
servants
of
the
hunt
should
congregate
.
  
<EOS>
There
are
well
-
known
grand
meets
in
England
,
in
the
parks
of
noblemen
,
before
their
houses
,
or
even
on
what
are
called
their
lawns
;
but
these
magnificent
affairs
have
but
little
of
the
beauty
of
which
I
speak
.
<EOS>
Such
assemblies
are
too
grand
and
too
ornate
,
and
,
moreover
,
much
too
far
removed
from
true
sporting
proprieties
.
<EOS>
At
them
,
equipages
are
shining
,
and
ladies
"
dresses
are
gorgeous
,
and
crowds
of
tradesmen
from
the
neighbouring
town
have
come
there
to
look
at
the
grand
folk
.
<EOS>
To
my
eye
there
is
nothing
beautiful
in
that
.
<EOS>
The
meet
I
speak
of
is
arranged
with
a
view
to
sport
,
but
the
accident
of
the
locality
may
make
it
the
prettiest
thing
in
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
Such
,
in
a
special
degree
,
was
the
case
at
Edgehill
.
<EOS>
At
Edgehill
the
whole
village
consisted
of
three
or
four
cottages
;
but
there
was
a
small
old
church
,
with
an
old
grey
tower
,
and
a
narrow
,
green
,
almost
dark
,
churchyard
,
surrounded
by
elm
-
trees
.
<EOS>
The
road
from
Roebury
to
the
meet
passed
by
the
church
stile
,
and
turning
just
beyond
it
came
upon
the
gate
which
led
into
the
little
field
in
which
the
hounds
felt
themselves
as
much
at
home
as
in
their
kennels
.
<EOS>
There
might
be
six
or
seven
acres
in
the
field
,
which
was
long
and
narrow
,
so
that
the
huntsman
had
space
to
walk
leisurely
up
and
down
with
the
pack
clustering
round
him
,
when
he
considered
that
longer
sitting
might
chill
them
.
<EOS>
The
church
tower
was
close
at
hand
,
visible
through
the
trees
,
and
the
field
itself
was
green
and
soft
,
though
never
splashing
with
mud
or
heavy
with
holes
.
  
<EOS>
Edgehill
was
a
favourite
meet
in
that
country
,
partly
because
foxes
were
very
abundant
in
the
great
wood
adjacent
,
partly
because
the
whole
country
around
is
grass
-
land
,
and
partly
,
no
doubt
,
from
the
sporting
propensities
of
the
neighbouring
population
.
<EOS>
As
regards
my
own
taste
,
I
do
not
know
that
I
do
like
beginning
a
day
with
a
great
wood
,
 
and
if
not
beginning
it
,
certainly
not
ending
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
hard
to
come
upon
the
cream
of
hunting
,
as
it
is
upon
the
cream
of
any
other
delight
.
<EOS>
Who
can
always
drink
Lafitte
of
the
finest
,
can
always
talk
to
a
woman
who
is
both
beautiful
and
witty
,
or
can
always
find
the
right
spirit
in
the
poetry
he
reads
?
<EOS>
A
man
has
usually
to
work
through
much
mud
before
he
gets
his
nugget
.
<EOS>
It
is
so
certainly
in
hunting
,
and
a
big
wood
too
frequently
afflicts
the
sportsman
,
as
the
mud
does
the
miner
.
<EOS>
The
small
gorse
cover
is
the
happy
,
much
-
envied
bit
of
ground
in
which
the
gold
is
sure
to
show

readily
.
<EOS>
But
without
the
woods
the
gorse
would
not
hold
the
foxes
,
and
without
the
mud
the
gold
would
not
have
found
its

-

.
  
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
have
said
,
Edgehill
was
a
popular
meet
,
and
,
as

meet

,
was
eminently

.
<EOS>
On
the
present

the
little
field
was
full

,

,

.
<EOS>
There

old

,

from

;

who

,
and

of
the
country
are
common

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

was
,

,

.
<EOS>
The

long
,

the

in
Cranby

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
A

,

,

<EOS>
one

.
<EOS>
But
a

,

he

,
 
and

had

,

of

.
<EOS>
He
may

,

.
<EOS>
No

against

;
no

meet

;
 
that

,

.
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

two

three
flashes
in
the
pan
,
and
false
reports
as
to
foxes
which
had
gone
away
,
which
first
set
men
galloping
,
and
then
made
them
very
angry
.
<EOS>
After
three
,
men
began
to
say
naughty
things
,
to
abuse
Cranby
Wood
,
to
wish
violently
that
they
had
remained
at
home
or
gone
elsewhere
,
and
to
speak
irreverently
of
their
ancient

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
cussidest
place
in
all
creation
,
"
said
Maxwell
.
<EOS>
"
I
often
said
I
'd
not
come
here
any
more
,
and
now
I
say
it
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet
you
'll

here

next

,
"

,
who
had

.
  
<EOS>
"
Grindems
,
you
know
a
sight

much
,
"
said

;
"
you
do

.
<EOS>
An
ordinary

has
no

with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Grindley

again

,

,

<EOS>
"
He
is

,
Tom
,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

;
 
and

.
<EOS>
Vavasor
changed

,

to

brown

,

to

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Then

,

.
<EOS>
At

came
upon
Sir
William
,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hold

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
The
hounds

of

wood

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Is

fox

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
's

good

that
if
we
ca
n't

?
 
<EOS>
Yes
,

's

.
<EOS>
He
passed

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Then

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Tom

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Then

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Some

;

.
<EOS>
But

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Ah

,

<EOS>
If

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
No

,

<EOS>
A

;

.
<EOS>
He

,

somewhat
away

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
On

,
twenty

,
 
but

,

,
thus

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
After

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

,

,

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
Pollock

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

George

<EOS>

<EOS>
He
