The
huntsman
and
Burgo
were
leading
with
some
fortunate
county
gentleman
whose
good
stars
had
brought
him
in
upon
them
at
the
farmyard
gate
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
injustice
of
such
accidents
as
this
that
breaks
the
heart
of
a
man
who
has
honestly
gone
through
all
the
heat
and
work
of
the
struggle
!
<EOS>
And
the
hounds
had
veered
a
little
round
to
the
left
,
making
,
after
all
,
for
Claydon
's
.
<EOS>
"
Darned
if
the
Squire
warn't
<EOS>
right
,
"
said
Tom
.
<EOS>
Sir
William
,
though
a
baronet
,
was
familiarly
called
the
Squire
throughout
the
hunt
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
ai
n't
going
for
Claydon
's
now
?
"
asked
Burgo
.
  
<EOS>
"
Them
's
Claydon
's
beeches
we
sees
over
there
,
"
said
Tom
.
"
<EOS>
"
Tain't
often
the
Squire
's
wrong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Here
they
came
to
a
little
double
rail
and
a
little
quick
-
set
hedge
.
<EOS>
A
double
rail
is
a
nasty
fence
always
if
it
has
been
made
any
way
strong
,
and
one
which
a
man
with
a
wife
and
a
family
is
justified
in
avoiding
.
<EOS>
They
mostly
can
be
avoided
,
having
gates
;
and
this
could
have
been
avoided
.
<EOS>
But
Burgo
never
avoided
anything
,
and
went
over
it
beautifully
.
<EOS>
The
difficulty
is
to
be
discreet
when
the
man
before
one
has
been
indiscreet
.
<EOS>
Tom
went
for
the
gate
,
as
did
Pollock
,
who
knew
that
he
could
have
no
chance
at
the
double
rails
.
<EOS>
But
Calder
Jones
came
to
infinite
grief
,
striking
the
top
bar
of
the
second
rail
,
and
going
head
-
foremost
out
of
his
saddle
,
as
though
thrown
by
a
catapult
.
<EOS>
There
we
must
leave
him
.
<EOS>
Grindley
,
rejoicing
greatly
at
this
discomfiture
,
made
for
the
gate
;
but
the
country
gentleman
with
the
fresh
horse
accomplished
the
rails
,
and
was
soon
alongside
of
Burgo
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
see
you
at
the
start
,
"
said
Burgo
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
did
n't
see
you
,
"
said
the
country
gentleman
;
"
so
it
's
even
.
"
  
<EOS>
Burgo
did
not
see
the
thing
in
the
same
light
,
but
he
said
no
more
.
<EOS>
Grindley
and
Tom
were
soon
after
them
,
Tom
doing
his
utmost
to
shake
off
the
attorney
.
<EOS>
Pollock
was
coming
on
also
;
but
the
pace
had
been
too
much
for
him
,
and
though
the
ground
rode
light
his
poor
beast
laboured
and
grunted
sorely
.
<EOS>
The
hounds
were
still
veering
somewhat
to
the
left
,
and
Burgo
,
jumping
over
a
small
fence
into
the
same
field
with
them
,
saw
that
there
was
a
horseman
ahead
of
him
.
<EOS>
This
was
George
Vavasor
,
who
was
going
well
,
without
any
symptom
of
distress
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
they
were
at
Claydon
's
,
having
run
over
some
seven
miles
of
ground
in
about
thirty
-
five
minutes
.
<EOS>
To
those
who
do
not
know
what
hunting
is
,
this
pace
does
not
seem
very
extraordinary
;
but
it
had
been
quite
quick
enough
,
as
was
testified
by
the
horses
which
had
gone
the
distance
.
<EOS>
Our
party
entered
Claydon
's
Park
at
back
,
through
a
gate
in
the
park
palings
that
was
open
on
hunting
days
;
but
a
much
more
numerous
lot
was
there
almost
as
soon
as
them
,
who
had
come
in
by
the
main
entrance
.
<EOS>
This
lot
was
headed
by
Sir
William
,
and
our
friend
Maxwell
was
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
jolly
thing
so
far
,
"
said
Burgo
to
Maxwell
;
"
about
the
best
we
've
had
this
year
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
see
a
yard
of
it
,
"
said
Maxwell
.
<EOS>
"
I
had
n't
nerve
to
get
off
the
first
road
,
and
I
have
n't
been
off
it
ever
since
.
<EOS>
"
Maxwell
was
a
man
who
never
lied
about
his
hunting
,
or
had
the
slightest
shame
in
riding
roads
.
<EOS>
"
Who
's
been
with
you
?
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
've

Tom
and
I
;
 
and
Calder
Jones
was
there
for
a
while
.
<EOS>
I
think
he
killed
himself
somewhere
.
<EOS>
And
there

Pollock
,
and
your
friend
Grindley
,
and
a
chap
whose

I
do

who
dropped

about
half

;
and
there

another
man
whose
back
I
saw
just
now
;
there
he
is
,
 
by
heavens
,
it
's
Vavasor
!
<EOS>
I
did

he
was
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
hung
about
the
Claydon
covers
for
ten
minutes
,
and
then
their
fox
went
off
again
,
 
their
fox
or
another
,
as
to
which
there
was
a
great
discussion
afterwards
;
but
he
who
would
have
suggested
the
idea
of
a
new
fox
to
Sir
William
would
have
been
a
bold
man
.
<EOS>
A
fox
,
however
,
went
off
,
turning
still
to
the
left
from
Claydon
's
towards
Roebury
.
<EOS>
Those
ten
minutes
had
brought
up
some
fifty
men
;
but
it
did
not
bring
up
Calder
Jones
nor
Tufto
Pearlings
,
nor
some

who
had

to

;
but
Grindley
was
there
,
very

in
his
own

,
and
already
talking
of
Jones
's

.
<EOS>
And
Pollock
was
there

,
thankful
for
the
ten
minutes
"
law
,
and
trusting
that
wind
might
be
given
to
his
horse
to
finish

triumphantly
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
pace
on
leaving
Claydon
's
was
better
than
ever
.
<EOS>
This
may
have
come
from
the

that
the
scent
was
keener
,
as
they
got

so
close
upon

.
<EOS>
But
I
think
they
must
have
changed
their
fox
.
<EOS>
Maxwell
,
who
saw
him
go
,
swore
that
he
was
fresh

clean
.
<EOS>
Burgo
said
that

knew

to

fox
,
but

.
"
<EOS>
Same
fox
!
<EOS>
in
course
it
was
;
why
should

it
be
the
same
?
"
said
Tom
.
<EOS>
The
country
gentleman
who
had
dropped
from
heaven
was
quite
sure
that
they
had
changed
,
and
so

most

who
had

.
<EOS>
Pollock
confined
himself
to
hoping
that
he
might
soon
be
killed
,
and
that
thus
his
triumph
for

.
  
<EOS>
On
they
went
,
and
the
pace
soon
became
too
good
for
the
poor
author
.
<EOS>
His
horse
at
last
refused
a
little
hedge
,
and
there
was
not
another
trot
to
be
got
out
of
him
.
<EOS>
That
night
Pollock
turned
up
at
Roebury
about
nine
o'clock
,
very

,
 
and
it
was
known
that
his
animal
was
alive
;
 
but
the
poor
horse
ate
not
a
grain
of
oats
that
night
,
nor
on

next
morning
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
had
again
taken
a
line
to
himself
,
on
this

a
little
to
the
right
of
the
meet
;
but
Maxwell
followed
him
and
rode
close
with
him
to
the
end
.
<EOS>
Burgo
for
a
while
still
led
the
body
of
the
field
,
incurring
at
first
much

from
Sir
William
,
 
nominally
for
hurrying
on
among
the
hounds
,
but
in
truth
because
he
got
before
Sir
William
himself
.
<EOS>
During

Sir
William
stuck
to
the
hounds
in
spite
of
his
seventy
odd
years
.
<EOS>
Going
down
into
Marham
Bottom
,
some
four
or
five
were
left
behind
,
for
they
feared
the
soft
ground
near
the
river
,
and
did
not
know
the
pass
through
it
.
<EOS>
But
Sir
William
knew
it
,
and
those
who
remained
close
to
him
got
over
that
trouble
.
<EOS>
Burgo
,
who
would
still
lead
,
nearly
foundered
in
the
bog
;
 
but
he
was
light
,
and
his
horse
pulled
him
through
,
 
leaving
a
fore
-
shoe
in
the
mud
.
<EOS>
After
that
Burgo
was
contented
to
give
Sir
William
the
lead
.
  
<EOS>
Then
they
came
up
by
Marham
Pits
to
Cleshey
Small
Wood
,
which
they
passed
without
hanging
there
a
minute
,
and
over
the
grass
lands
of
Cleshey
Farm
.
<EOS>
Here
Vavasor
and
Maxwell
joined
the
others
,
having

some
three

in
distance
by
their

,
but
having
been
forced
to
jump
the
Marham
Stream
which
Sir
William
had
forded
.
<EOS>
The
pace
now
was
as
good
as
the
horses
could
make
it
,
 
and
perhaps
something
better
as
regarded
some

.
<EOS>
Sir
William
's

had
been
with

,
and
he
had
got

second
horse
at
Claydon
's
;
Maxwell
had
been
equally
fortunate
;
Tom
's
second
horse
had
not
come
up
,
and
his
beast
was
in
great

;
Grindley
had
remained
behind
at
Marham
Bottom
,
being
contented
perhaps
with
having
beaten
Calder
Jones
,
 
from
whom
by
-
the
-
by
I
may
here
declare

.
<EOS>
Burgo
,
Vavasor
,
and
the
country
gentleman
still
held
on
;
but
it
was
devoutly
desired
by
all

them
that
the
fox
might
soon
come
to
the
end
of
his

.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
that
intense
longing
that
the
fox
may
fail
,
when
the
failings
of
the
horse
begin
to
make

known
,
 
and
<EOS>
the
consciousness
comes
on
that
all
that
one
has
done
will
go

nothing
unless
the
thing
can

to

close
in
a
field
or

!
<EOS>
So
far
you
have
triumphed
,
leaving

of

behind
;
but
of
what
good
is
all
that
,
if
you
also

to

at

?
  
<EOS>
It
was
manifest
now
to
all
who
knew

country
that
the
fox
was
making
for
Thornden
Deer
Park
,
but
Thornden
Deer
Park
was
still
two
miles
ahead
of

,
and
the
hounds
were
so
near
to
their

that
the
poor
beast
could
hardly
hope
to
live

.
<EOS>
He
had
tried
a
well
-
known

near
Cleshey
Farm
House
;
but
it
had
been
inhospitably
,
nay

,
closed
against

.
<EOS>
Soon

threw

down
in
a

,
and

overran

,
giving

a
moment
's
law
,
 
and
giving

a
moment
's
law
to
horses
that
wanted

as

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm

done

,
"
said

.
"
<EOS>
Luckily

,
"
said

,
"
the
fox

much
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
the
fox
had
still
more

than
poor
Burgo
Fitzgerald
's

.
<EOS>
He
gained

's

,

.
<EOS>
The

of

,

:
"
Yoicks
,

;

!
"
<EOS>
The

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
the
d
 
---

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"
<EOS>
Whereupon

,

.
  
<EOS>
Away

again
,
off
Cleshey
and
into
Thornden
parish
,
on
the
land
of
Sorrel
Farm
,
 
a
spot
well
to
be

by
one

two

.
<EOS>
Here
Sir
William
made
for
a
gate
which
took
him
a
little
out
of
the
line
,
but
Maxwell
and
Burgo
Fitzgerald
,
followed

,

.
<EOS>
There
was
a
huge
ditch
and
boundary
bank
there
which
Sir
William
had
known
and
had
avoided
.
<EOS>
Maxwell
,
whose
pluck
had
returned
to
him
at
last
,
took
it
well
.
<EOS>
His
horse
was
comparatively
fresh
and
made
nothing
of
it
.
<EOS>
Then
came
poor
Burgo
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
Burgo
,
hadst
thou
not
have
been
a
very
child
,
thou
shouldst
have
known
that
now
,
at
this
time
of
the
day
,
 
after
all
that
thy
gallant
horse
had
done
for
thee
,
 
it
was
impossible
to
thee
or
him
.
<EOS>
But
when
did
Burgo
Fitzgerald
know
anything
?
<EOS>
He
rode
at
the
bank
as
though
it
had
been
the
first
fence
of
the
day
,
striking
his
poor
beast
with
his
spurs
,
as
though
muscle
,
strength
,
and
new
power
could
be
imparted
by
their
rowels
.
<EOS>
The
animal
rose
at
the
bank
and
in
some
way
got
upon
it
,
scrambling
as
he
struck
it
with
his
chest
,
and
then
fell
headlong
into
the
ditch
at
the
other
side
,
a
confused
mass
of
head
,
limbs
,
and
body
.
<EOS>
His
career
was
at
an
end
,
and
he
had
broken
his
heart
!
<EOS>
Poor
noble
beast
,
noble
in
vain
!
<EOS>
To
his
very
last
gasp
he
had
done
his
best
,
and
had
deserved
that
he
should
have
been
in
better
hands
.
<EOS>
His
master
's
ignorance
had
killed
him
.
<EOS>
There
are
men
who
never
know
how
little
a
horse
can
do
,
 
or
how
much
!
  
<EOS>
There
was
to
some
extent
a
gap
in
the
fence
when
Maxwell
had
first
ridden
it
and
Burgo
had
followed
him
;
a
gap
,
or
break
in
the
hedge
at
the
top
,
indicating
plainly
the
place
at
which
a
horse
could
best
get
over
.
<EOS>
To
this
spot
Vavasor
followed
,
and
was
on
the
bank
at
Burgo
's
heels
before
he
knew
what
had
happened
.
<EOS>
But
the
man
had
got
away
and
only
the
horse
lay
there
in
the
ditch
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
hurt
?
"
said
Vavasor
;
"
can
I
do
anything
?
"
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
stop
,
"
If
you
can
find
a
chap
just
send
him
to
me
,
"
said
Burgo
in
a
melancholy
tone
.
<EOS>
Then
he
sat
down
,
with
his
feet
in
the
ditch
,
and
looked
at
the
carcase
of
his
horse
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
no
more
need
of
jumping
that
day
.
<EOS>
The
way
was
open
into
the
next
field
,
 
a
turnip
field
,
 
and
there
amidst
the
crisp
breaking
turnip
-
tops
,
with
the
breath
of
his
enemies
hot
upon
him
,
with
their
sharp
teeth
at
his
entrails
,
biting
at
them
impotently
in
the
agonies
of
his
death
struggle
,
poor
Reynard
finished
his
career
.
<EOS>
Maxwell
was
certainly
the
first
there
,
 
but
Sir
William
and
George
Vavasor
were
close
upon
him
.
<EOS>
That
taking
of
brushes
of
which
we
used
to
hear
is
a
little
out
of
fashion
;
but
if
such
honour
were
due
to
any
one
it
was
due
to
Vavasor
,
for
he
and
he
only
had
ridden
the
hunt
throughout
.
<EOS>
But
he
claimed
no
honour
,
and
none
was
specially
given

.
<EOS>
He
and
Maxwell
rode
homewards
together
,
having
sent

to
poor
Burgo
Fitzgerald
;
and
as

,
saying
but
little
to

other
,
Maxwell
,
in
a

,
asked

question
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
for
that
horse
,
Vavasor
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
hundred
and
fifty
,
"
said
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
mine
,
"
said
Maxwell
.
<EOS>
So
the
brown
horse
was
sold
for
about
half
his
value
,
because
he
had
brought
with
him
a
bad
character
.
   
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
's
Great
Relations
.
 
<EOS>
Burgo
Fitzgerald
,
of
whose
hunting
experiences
something
has
been
told
in
the
last
chapter
,
was
a
young
man
born
in
the
purple
of
the
English

.
<EOS>
He
was
related
to
half
the
dukes
in
the
kingdom
,
and
had
three
countesses
for
his
aunts
.
<EOS>
When
he
came
of
age
he
was
master
of
a
sufficient
fortune
to
make
it
quite
out
of
the
question
that
he
should
be
asked
to
earn
his
bread
;
and
though
that
,
and
other
windfalls
that
had
come
to
him
,
had
long
since
been
spent
,
no
one
had
ever
made
to
him
so
ridiculous

as
that
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
thirty
,
and
for
some
years
past
had
been
known
to
be
much
worse
than
penniless
;
but
still
he
lived
on
in
the
same
circles
,
still
slept
softly
and
drank
of
the
best
,
and
went
about
with
his
valet
and
his
groom
and
his
horses
,
and
fared
sumptuously
every
day
.
<EOS>
Some
people
said
the
countesses
did
it
for
him
,
and
some
said
that
it
was
the
dukes
;
 
while
others
,
again
,
declared
that
the
Jews
were
his
most

.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
he
still
seemed
to
live
as
he
had
always
lived
,
setting
tradesmen
at
defiance
,
and
laughing
to
scorn
all
the
rules
which
regulate
the
lives
of
other

.
  
<EOS>
About
eighteen
months
before
the
time
of
which
I
am
now
speaking
,

had
come
in
this

's

,
and
he

almost

one

.
<EOS>
There

been

a

,
on

the
properties
of
half
-
a

;
and
Burgo
,
who
in

still

in
the

-
rooms
of
the
great
,
had

,
 
as

that
he

the
heart
,
 
of

Lady
Glencora
M'Cluskie
.
<EOS>
But
sundry

,

at
the

,
had

put
their

together
,
and
the

had
been
that
the
Lady

had
heard

.
<EOS>
She
had
listened
,
 
with
many

of

,

;
but

.
<EOS>
She
saw
Burgo
,
for
the
last

,
and

that

was
the

of
Plantagenet
Palliser
,

.
  
<EOS>
He
had
borne

like

man
,

,

any

the

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
Who

,

,

?
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
I

now
,
 
that

,
"
he

<EOS>
and

,

old

,

.
<EOS>
He
was
one

,
 
who

,

.
<EOS>
No

;

,
 
that

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
He
chiefly

,
 
and

<EOS>
him

those

it
<EOS>
,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Lady

,

<EOS>
But

aloof

,

.
<EOS>
With

,

,

for

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
Burgo

,

,

,

's

.

.
"
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

"
<EOS>
Just

,
 
so

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

.
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

!
<EOS>

!
"

,

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Next

I

.
"
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
Then

had

,

that

.
<EOS>
Alice

,

,

of

<EOS>
Then

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,
 
"

,
"

,

.

She

.
  
<EOS>
From

to
this

Alice
had
heard

Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
married
late
in
the

and
had

,

.
<EOS>
They
had

to
England
till

had
come
for

to
encounter
the

of
Mr.
Palliser
's

,

.
<EOS>
On
this

Gatherum
Castle
,
the

had
built

,

opened
,

;
 
for

's

had
married
to
the
Duke
's
liking
,
and
the
Duke
was
a
man
who
could
do

.
<EOS>
Then

had

a

,
and

bridal

which
had
continued

even

time

Palliser

due

;
 
and
Mr.
Palliser
was
a

who
served
his

with

.
<EOS>
So
the
London
season
commenced
,
progressed
,
and
was
consumed
;
and
still
Alice
heard
nothing
more
of
her
friend
and
cousin
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
But
this
had
troubled
her
not
at
all
.
<EOS>
A
chance
circumstance
,
the
story
of
which
she
had
told
to
no

,
had
given
her
a
short

with
this
fair
child
of
the
gold

,
but
she
had
felt
that
they
two
could
not
live
together
in
habits
of
much

.
<EOS>
She
had
,
when
thinking
of
the
young

,
only
thought
of
that
wild
love
episode
in
the
girl
's
life
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
strange

her
that

should
in
one
week
have
listened
to
the
most
passionate

from
her
friend
of
love
for
one
man
,
and
then
have

in
the
next
that
another

to

her

's

!
<EOS>
But
she
reflected
that
her
own
career
was
much
the
same
,
 
only
with
the
interval
of
some

.
  
<EOS>
But
her
own
career
was
not
the
same
.
<EOS>
Glencora
had
married
Mr.
Palliser
,
 
had
married
him
without
pausing
to
doubt
;
 
but
Alice
had
gone
on
doubting
till
at
last
<EOS>
she
had
resolved
that
she
would
not
marry
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
She
thought
of
this
much
in
those
days
at
Cheltenham
,
and
wondered
often
whether
Glencora
lived
with
her
husband
in
the
full
happiness
of
conjugal
love
.
  
<EOS>
One
morning
,
about
three
days
after
Mr.
Grey
's
visit
,
there
came
to
her
two
letters
,
as
to
neither
of
which
did
she
know
the
writer
by

.
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
had
told
her
,
 
with
some

,
indeed
,
for
Lady
Macleod
was
afraid
of
her
,
 
but
had
told
her
,
nevertheless
,
more
than

,
that
those
noble
relatives
had
heard
of
the
treatment
to
which
Mr.
Grey
was
being
subjected
,
and
had
expressed
their
great
sorrow
,
 
if
not
dismay
or
almost
anger
.
<EOS>
Lady
Macleod
,
indeed
,
had
gone
as
far
as
she
dared
,
and
might
have
gone
further
without
any

of
truth
.
<EOS>
Lady
Midlothian
had
said
that

to
the
family
,
and
Lady
Glencora
's

,

of
Auld

,
had

the
girl
wanted
.
  
<EOS>
When

letters
came
Lady
Macleod
was
not

,
and
I
am
disposed

think

one

had

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
This

from

.
<EOS>
Of

other
Lady
Macleod
certainly

,

had

which
had

as
to

.
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
Alice

,
one
without

,

.
<EOS>
Lady
Midlothian
's
was

,
and
then

's

as

,

.
<EOS>

's

,
"
Glencora
Palliser
,
"

read
that
letter

,

before

Midlothian
's

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
Castle
Reekie
,
<EOS>
N.B.
 
Oct.
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
MY
DEAR
MISS
VAVASOR
,
  
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
pleasure

,

,

.
<EOS>
Your

,
 
by

mother
's

,
 
Lady
Flora
Macleod
,

,

;

,

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
"
Since

!
"
 
<EOS>

?
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Why

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
[

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
  
<EOS>
You

<EOS>
My

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
[

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
MARGARET

.
  
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.

<EOS>
Matching
Priory
,
Thursday
.
  
<EOS>
DEAR
COUSIN
,
  
<EOS>
I
have
just
come
home
from
Scotland
,
where
they
have
been
telling
me
something
of
your
little
troubles
.
<EOS>
I
had
little
troubles
once
too
,
and
you
were
so
good
to
me
!
<EOS>
Will
you
come
to
us
here
for
a
few
weeks
?
<EOS>
We
shall
be
here
till
Christmas

,
when
we
go
somewhere
else
.
<EOS>
I
have
told

that
you

as

,
and
that
he
must
be

.
<EOS>
He

very

,
and
works
very
hard

;
but
I

.
<EOS>
Do
come
!
<EOS>
There

many

here
,
so
that

.
<EOS>
If

Matching

,
and

dare

I
can
manage

.
  
<EOS>
Yours

,
  
G.
PALLISER
.
  
<EOS>
P.S.
<EOS>
I
know

.
<EOS>
You

,

?
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
Dear

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

!

This

,

,

.

,

Lady

's

she

,

Midlothian

.
  
<EOS>
About

Macleod

.
<EOS>
For

-
an
-
hour

;

.

,

's

,

.
<EOS>
At
last

.
  
<EOS>
"
Aunt
,
"

,
"

,
Lady
Midlothian
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She

,

;

.
"
  
"
Your

,
aunt
.
<EOS>
But

that
she

.
<EOS>
She

,
nor

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Alice
,
 
from

position
 
"
  
"
Her

can

nothing

,
aunt
.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
After

may

.
<EOS>
I
need

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

,

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Nothing

,

;
 
from

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
Then

.
"
<EOS>
And
I
have

,

Glencora
,
who
married

Palliser
,
and
whom
I
knew
in
London
last

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
has

,

?
"
  
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
She
asks

go
and
see

at
Matching
Priory
,
her

's
house
;
but
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
at
last
Alice
agreed
to
pay
this
visit
,
and
it
may

as

.
<EOS>
She

Lady
Glencora
,
declining
,
and
explaining

that
she
did
decline
,
because
she
thought
it
probable
that
she
might
there
meet
Lady
Midlothian
.
<EOS>
Lady
Midlothian
,
she
said
,
had
interfered
very
unwarrantably
in
her
affairs
,
and
she
did
not
wish
to

.
<EOS>
To

Glencora
replied
,
post

,
that
she
had

as
that
for

;
that
neither

Lady
Midlothian
be
there
,
nor
any
of
that
set
;
by
which
Alice
knew
that
Lady
Glencora
referred
specially
to
her
aunt
the
Marchioness
;
that
no
one
would
be
at
Matching
who
could
torment
Alice
,
either
with
right
or
without
it
,
"
except
so
far
as
I
myself
may
do
so
,
"
Lady
Glencora
said
;
and
then
she
named
an
early
day
in
November
,
at
which
she
would
herself
undertake
to
meet
Alice
at
the
Matching
Station
.
<EOS>
On
receipt
of
this
letter
,
Alice
,
after
two
days
'
doubt
,
accepted
the
invitation
.
   
<EOS>
Tribute
from
Oileymead
.
 
<EOS>
Kate
Vavasor
,
in
writing
to
her
cousin
Alice
,
felt
some
little
difficulty
in
excusing
herself
for
remaining
in
Norfolk
with
Mrs.
Greenow
.
<EOS>
She
had
laughed
at
Mrs.
Greenow
before
she
went
to
Yarmouth
,
and
had
laughed
at
herself
for
going
there
.
<EOS>
And
in
all
her
letters
since
,
she
had
spoken
of
her
aunt
as
a
silly
,
vain
,
worldly
woman
,
weeping
crocodile
tears
,
for
an
old
husband
whose
death
had
released
her
from
the
tedium
of
his
company
,
and
spreading
lures
to
catch
new
lovers
.
<EOS>
But
yet
she
agreed
to
stay
with
her
aunt
,
and
remain
with
her
in
lodgings
at
Norwich
for
a
month
.
  
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Greenow
had
about
her
something
more
than
Kate
had
acknowledged
when
she
first
attempted
to
read
her
aunt
's
character
.
<EOS>
She
was
clever
,
and
in
her
own
way
persuasive
.
<EOS>
She
was
very
generous
,
and
possessed
a
certain
power
of
making
herself
pleasant
to
those
around
her
.
<EOS>
In
asking
Kate
to
stay
with
her
she
had
so
asked
as
to
make
it
appear
that
Kate
was
to
confer
the
favour
.
<EOS>
She
had
told
her
niece
that
she
was
all
alone
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
money
,
"
she
had
said
,
with
more
appearance
of
true
feeling
than
Kate
had
observed
before
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
money
,
but
I
have
nothing
else
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
home
.
<EOS>
Why
should
I
not
remain
here
in
Norfolk
,
where
I
know
a
few
people
?
<EOS>
If
you
'll
say
that
you
'll
go
anywhere
else
with
me
,
I
'll
go
to
any
place
you
'll
name
.
<EOS>
"
Kate
had
believed
this
to
be
hardly
true
.
<EOS>
She
had
felt
sure
that
her
aunt
wished
to
remain
in
the
neighbourhood
of
her
seaside
admirers
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
she
had
yielded
,
and
at
the
end
of
October
the
two
ladies
,
with
Jeannette
,
settled
themselves
in
comfortable
lodgings
within
the
precincts
of
the
Close
at
Norwich
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Greenow
at
this
time
had
been
dead
very
nearly
six
months
,
but
his
widow
made
some
mistakes
in
her
dates
and
appeared
to
think
that
the
interval
had
been
longer
.
<EOS>
On
the
day
of
their
arrival
at
Norwich
it
was
evident
that
this
error
had
confirmed
itself
in
her
mind
.
"
<EOS>
Only
think
,
"
she
said
,
as
she
unpacked
a
little
miniature
of
the
departed
one
,
and
sat
with
it
for
a
moment
in
her
hands
,
as
she
pressed
her
handkerchief
to
her
eyes
,
"
only
think
,
that
it
is
barely
nine
months
since
he
was
with
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Six
,
you
mean
,
aunt
,
"
said
Kate
,
unadvisedly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
nine
months
"
repeated
Mrs.
Greenow
,
as
though
she
had
not
heard
her
niece
.
"
<EOS>
Only
nine
months
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
After
that
Kate
attempted
to
correct
no
more
such
errors
.
<EOS>
"
It
happened
in
May
,
Miss
,
"
Jeannette
said
afterwards
to
Miss
Vavasor
,
"
and
that
,
as
we
reckons
,
it
will
be
just
a
twelvemonth
come
Christmas
.
"
<EOS>
But
Kate
paid
no
attention
to
this
.
  
<EOS>
And
Jeannette
was
very
ungrateful
,
and
certainly
should
have
indulged
herself
in
no
such
sarcasms
.
<EOS>
When
Mrs.
Greenow
made
a
slight
change
in
her
mourning
,
which
she
did
on
her
arrival
at
Norwich
,
using
a
little
lace
among
her
crapes
,
Jeannette
reaped
a
rich
harvest
in
gifts
of
clothes
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
knew
well
enough
that
she
expected
more
from
a
servant
than
mere
service
;
 
that
she
wanted
loyalty
,
discretion
,
and
perhaps
sometimes
a
little
secrecy
;
 
and
as
she
paid
for
these
things
,
she
should
have
had
them
.
  
<EOS>
Kate
undertook
to
stay
a
month
with
her
aunt
at
Norwich
,
and
Mrs.
Greenow
undertook
that
Mr.
Cheesacre
should
declare
himself
as
Kate
's
lover
,
before
the
expiration
of
the
month
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
that
Kate
protested
that
she
wanted
no
such
lover
,
and
that
she
would
certainly
reject
him
if
he
came
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
very
well
,
my
dear
,
"
Aunt
Greenow
would
say
.
<EOS>
"
A
girl
must
settle
herself
some
day
,
you
know
;
 
and
you
'd
have
it
all
your
own
way
at
Oileymead
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
the
offer
certainly
showed
much
generosity
on
the
part
of
Aunt
Greenow
,
inasmuch
as
Mr.
Cheesacre
's
attentions
were
apparently
paid
to
herself
rather
than
to
her
niece
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
was
very
attentive
.
<EOS>
He
had
taken
the
lodgings
in
the
Close
,
and
had
sent
over
fowls
and
cream
from
Oileymead
,
and
had
called
on
the
morning
after
their
arrival
;
but
in
all
his
attentions
he
distinguished
the
aunt
more
particularly
than
the
niece
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
all
for
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
Miss
,
"
said
Jeannette
once
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Captain
is
perhaps
the
nicerer
-
looking
gentleman
,
and
he
ai
n't
so
podgy
like
;
but
what
's
good
looks
if
a
gentleman
has
n't
got
nothing
?
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
abide
anything
that
's
poor
;
neither
ca
n't
Missus
.
"
<EOS>
From
which
it
was
evident
that
Jeannette
gave
Miss
Vavasor
no
credit
in
having
Mr.
Cheesacre
in
her
train
.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
was
also
at
Norwich
,
having
obtained
some
quasi
-
military
employment
there
in
the
matter
of
drilling
volunteers
.
<EOS>
Certain
capacities
in
that
line
it
may
be
supposed
that
he
possessed
,
and
,
as
his
friend
Cheesacre
said
of
him
,
he
was
going
to
earn
an
honest
penny
once
in
his
life
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
and
Mr.
Cheesacre
had
made
up
any
little
differences
that
had
existed
between
them
at
Yarmouth
,
and
were
close
allies
again
when
they
left
that
place
.
<EOS>
Some
little
compact
on
matters
of
business
must
have
been
arranged
between
them
,
 
for
the
Captain
<EOS>
was
in
funds
again
.
<EOS>
He
was
in
funds
again
through
the
liberality
of
his
friend
,
 
and
no
payment
of
former
loans
had
been
made
,
nor
had
there
been
any
speech
of
such
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
had
drawn
his
purse
-
strings
liberally
,
and
had
declared
that
if
all
went
well
the
hospitality
of
Oileymead
should
not
be
wanting
during
the
winter
.
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
had
nodded
his
head
and
declared
that
all
should
go
well
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
see
much
of
the
Captain
,
I
suppose
,
"
said
Mr.
Cheesacre
to
Mrs.
Greenow
on
the
morning
of
the
day
after
her
arrival
at
Norwich
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
across
the
whole
way
from
Oileymead
to
ask
her
if
she
found
herself
comfortable
,
 
and
perhaps
with
an
eye
to
the
Norwich
markets
at
the
same
time
.
<EOS>
He
now
wore
a
pair
of
black
riding
boots
over
his
trousers
,
and
a
round
topped
hat
,
and
looked
much
more
at
home
than
he
had
done
by
the
seaside
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
much
,
I
dare
say
,
"
said
the
widow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
tells
me
that
he
must
be
on
duty
ten
or
twelve
hours
a
day
.
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
deuced
good
thing
for
him
,
and
he
ought
to
be
very
much
obliged
to
me
for
putting
him
in
the
way
of
getting
it
.
<EOS>
But
he
told
me
to
tell
you
that
if
he
did
n't
call
,
you
were
not
to
be
angry
with
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
;
 
I
shall
remember
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
if
he
do
n't
work
now
he
must
come
to
grief
.
<EOS>
He
has
n't
got
a
shilling
that
he
can
call
his
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Has
n't
he
really
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
a
shilling
,
Mrs.
Greenow
;
 
and
then
he
's
awfully
in
debt
.
<EOS>
He
is
n't
a
bad
fellow
,
you
know
,
only
there
's
no
trusting
him
for
anything
.
"
<EOS>
Then
after
a
few
further
inquiries
that
were
almost
tender
,
and
a

of
further
supplies
from
the
dairy
,
Mr.
Cheesacre
took
his

,
almost
forgetting
to
ask

Miss
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
But
as
he
left
the
house
he
had
a

say
to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
has
n't
been
here
,
has

,
Jenny
?
"
<EOS>
"
We
have
n't
seen
a
sight
of
him
yet
,
sir
,
 
<EOS>
and
I
have
thought
it
a
little
odd
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Cheesacre
gave
the
girl
half
-
a
-
crown
,
and
went
his
way
.
<EOS>
Jeannette
,
I
think
,
must
have
forgotten
that
the
Captain
had
looked
in
after
leaving
his
military
duties
on
the
preceding
evening
.
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
's
ten
or
twelve
hours
of
daily
work
was
performed
,
no
doubt
,
at
irregular
intervals
,
 
some
days
late
and
some
days
early
,
 
for
he
might
be
seen
about
Norwich
almost
at
all
times
,
during
the
early
part
of
that
November
;
 
and
he
might
be
very
often
seen
going
into
the
Close
.
<EOS>
In
Norwich
there
are
two
weekly
market
-
days
,
but
on
those
days
the
Captain
was
no
doubt
kept
more
entirely
to
his
military
employment
,
for
at
such
times
he
never
was
seen
near
the
Close
.
<EOS>
Now
Mr.
Cheesacre
's
visits
to
the
town
were
generally
made
on
market
-
days
,
and
so
it
happened
that
they
did
not
meet
.
<EOS>
On
such
occasions
Mr.
Cheesacre
always
was
driven
to
Mrs.
Greenow
's
door
in
a
cab
,
 
for
he
would
come
into
town
by
railway
,
 
and
he
would
deposit
a
basket
bearing
the
rich
produce
of
his
dairy
.
<EOS>
It
was
in
vain
that
Mrs.
Greenow
protested
against
these
gifts
,
 
for
she
did
protest
and
declared
that
if
they
were
continued
,
they
would
be
sent
back
.
<EOS>
They
were
,
however
,
continued
,
and
Mrs.
Greenow
was
at
her
wits
"
end
about
them
.
<EOS>
Cheesacre
would
not
come
up
with
them
;
but
leaving
them
,
would
go
about
his
business
,
and
would
return
to
see
the
ladies
.
<EOS>
On
such
occasions
he
would
be
very
particular
in
getting
his
basket
from
Jeannette
.
<EOS>
As
he
did
so
he
would
generally
ask
some
question
about
the
Captain
,
and
Jeannette
would
give
him
answers
confidentially
,
 
so
that
there
was
a
strong
friendship
between
these
two
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
to
do
about
it
?
"
said
Mrs.
Greenow
,
as
Kate
came
into
the
sitting
-
room
one
morning
,
and
saw
on
the
table
a
small
hamper
lined
with
a
clean
cloth
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
as
much
as
Jeannette
has
been
able
to
carry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
it
is
,
ma'am
,
 
quite
;
and
I
'm
strong
in
the
arm
,
too
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
to
do
,
Kate
?
<EOS>
He
is
such

good

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
he
do

you

so

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of

I
do
n't

him

many

,
"
said
the
aunt
,
looking

niece
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
anything
about
your

,
aunt
,
but

I

,
I
should
leave

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Would

,

,

wo

.
<EOS>

,

wo

<EOS>
"
  
"

.
<EOS>
They

.

<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

;
 
before

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
And

ai

:
 
nor

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder

there

in

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"
I
declare
if
there
is
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A

!
<EOS>
Why
,
that
's
worth
ten
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Upon

I

n't
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
,
ma'am
,
"
said

:
"
let
me

who
they
're
for
;
 
he
'll
tell

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
do
anything
of
the
kind
,
Jeannette
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
,
aunt
,
they
're

for
you
.
<EOS>
There
's
no

.
<EOS>
A

does
n't
bring
cream
and
turkeys
to
 
<EOS>
I
've
never

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

why

to

just

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
told

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,

,

,
and

may
find

there
.
"
<EOS>
And
Kate

off

.
  
<EOS>
"
Leave

alone
,
Kate
,
"

Greenow
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

wo

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
The

never

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

.

"

,
 
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

!

because

?
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
On

,

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>
The

;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

,

a

as

's

.
<EOS>
Altogether

was
a

the

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
"
  
<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

;
 
light

air
<EOS>
,

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
Which
Shall
It
Be
?
 
<EOS>
The
next
day
was
Sunday
,
and

was

-

in

Close
that
Mr.

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

had
specially

that

,
fearing

.
<EOS>
In

aunt
and

,
and

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Charlie

,

,

,

,

;

,

,

,

Captain
Bellfield
.
<EOS>
A
very
nice

they
had
.
<EOS>
The

carved
the

,
giving

to
Mr.
Cheesacre
as

did

;
and

,

about

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
So

,
"

Bellfield
,
"

'll

.
<EOS>
Poor

Cheesy
!
<EOS>
It
's

n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
It

,

,

,

;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,
 
"

,
"

,

!
"
<EOS>
Therefore

;

<EOS>
But

,
dears
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So

,

Mr.
Cheesacre
's

used

.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
had
not

idly

.
<EOS>
In

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm

wine
is

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But

ca
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,

;

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
daresay

wine

of

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Captain
Bellfield
;
but
a
woman

as

,
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
It
's

I
lost
all
that
made

desirable
,
and

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
Mrs.

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

I

overcome

.
<EOS>
"
Upon
this
soft

trickled
down

,
showing
in

that
she
at
any
rate
used
no
paint
in
producing
that
freshness
of
colour
which
was
one
of
her
great
charms
.
<EOS>
Then

pressed
her
handkerchief
to
her

,
and

,

on
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
I
did

to
treat

,
Captain
Bellfield
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

nothing

,

Greenow
,
I

so

,
as
permission

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Time
alone
can
do

,
Captain
Bellfield
;
 
time

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
can
not

be

by

and

and

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
By
friendship
,
yes
.
<EOS>
What
would
life
be
worth
without
the

of
friendship
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
how
much
better
is
the
warm
glow
of
love
?
"
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
,
as
he
asked
this

,
deliberately
got

,
and
moved
his
chair
over
to
the
widow
's
side
.
<EOS>
But
the
widow
as

changed
her

to
the

a
sofa
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
did
not
at

follow

,
nor

he
was

had

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
much
better
is
the
warm
glow
of
love
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
again
,
contenting
himself
with
looking

her

with

.
<EOS>
He
had
hoped
that
he
would
have
been
able
to
press
her

by
this
time
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
warm
,
glow
of
love
,
Captain
Bellfield
,
if
you
have
ever

it
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

!
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
I

really
 
<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"

"

D
 
---

"

.
   
<EOS>
Alice
Is
Taught
to
Grow
Upwards
,
Towards
the
Light
.
 
<EOS>
Before
the
day
came
on
which
Alice
was
to
go
to
Matching
Priory
,
she
had
often
regretted
that
she
had
been
induced
to
make
the
promise
,
and
yet
she
had
as
often
resolved
that
there
was
no
possible
reason
why
she
should
not
go
to
Matching
Priory
.
<EOS>
But
she
feared
this
commencement
of
a
closer
connection
with
her
great
relations
.
<EOS>
She
had
told
herself
so
often
that
she
was
quite
separated
from
them
,
that
the
slight
accident
of
blood
in
no
way
tied
her
to
them
or
them
to
her
,
 
<EOS>
this
lesson
had
been
so
thoroughly
taught
to
her
by
the
injudicious
attempts
of
Lady
Macleod
to
teach
an
opposite
lesson
,
that
she
did
not
like
the
idea
of
putting
aside
the
effect
of
that
teaching
.
<EOS>
And
perhaps
she
was
a
little
afraid
of
the
great
folk
whom
she
might
probably
meet
at
her
cousin
's
house
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
herself
she
had
liked
,
 
and
had
loved
too
with
that
momentary
love
which
certain
circumstances
of
our
life
will
sometimes
produce
,
a
love
which
is
strong
while
it
lasts
,
but
which
can
be
laid
down
when
the
need
of
it
is
passed
.
<EOS>
She
had
liked
and
loved
Lady
Glencora
,
and
had
in
no
degree
been
afraid
of
her
during
those
strange
visitings
in
Queen
Anne
Street
;
 
but
she
was
by
no
means
sure
that
she
should
like
Lady
Glencora
in
the
midst
of
her
grandeur
and
surrounded
by
the
pomp
of
her
rank
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
no
other
friend
or
acquaintance
in
that
house
,
and
feared
that
she
might
find
herself
desolate
,
cold
,
and
wounded
in
her
pride
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
tricked
into
the
visit
,
too
,
or
rather
had
tricked
herself
into
it
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
sure
that
there
had
been
a
joint
scheme
between
her
cousin
and
Lady
Midlothian
,
and
could
not
resist
the
temptation
of
repudiating
it
in
her
letter
to
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
But
there
had
been
no
such
scheme
;
she
had
wronged
Lady
Glencora
,
and
had
therefore
been
unable
to
resist
her
second
request
.
<EOS>
But
she
felt
unhappy
,
fearing
that
she
would
be
out
of
her
element
,
and
more
than
once
half
made
up
her
mind
to
excuse
herself
.
  
<EOS>
Her
aunt
had
,
from
the
first
,
thought
well
of
her
going
,
believing
that
it
might
probably
be
the
means
of
reconciling
her
to
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
it
was
a
step
altogether
in
the
right
direction
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
would
,
if
she
lived
,
become
a
Duchess
,
and
as
she
was
decidedly
Alice
's
cousin
,
of
course
Alice
should
go
to
her

when

.
<EOS>
It
must
be
acknowledged
that
Lady
Macleod
was
not
selfish
in
her

rank
.
<EOS>
She
had
played
out
her
game
in
life
,
and
there
was
no
probability
that
she
would
live
to
be
called

by
a
Duchess
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
She
bade
<EOS>
Alice
go
to
Matching
Priory
,
simply
because
she
loved
her
niece
,
and
therefore
wished

to
live
in
the
best
and
most
eligible

within
her

.
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
owe

as

your
family
to
go
,
"
said
Lady
Macleod
.
  
<EOS>
What

about
her

had
passed
between
Lady

and
Lady
Midlothian
Alice
never
knew
.
<EOS>
She
steadily

that

,
and
at
last

her
aunt
that

further
urged
she

,
 
telling

that

had

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
becoming

,

,
"

,
piteously

"
<EOS>
and
I
suppose

.
<EOS>
Whatever
I
have
said
I
have
always
meant

be
for

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
Alice
got
up
,
and

,
tried

her
that
she

from
her
,
and

all

both

;
but

not

whom

,
and
who
thought

to
meddle

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
because
they
are
cousins

,
"
said
Lady
Macleod
,
in

,

.
  
<EOS>
Alice
left
Cheltenham
about
the
middle
of
November
on
her

to
Matching
Priory
.
<EOS>
She
was
to
sleep
in
London
one
night
,
and
go
down
to
Matching
in
Yorkshire
with
her
maid
on

following

.
<EOS>
Her
father
undertook
to
meet

at
the
Great
Western
Station
,
and
to

on
the
following
morning
to
the
Great
Northern
.
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
in
his
letter
about
dining
with
her
,
but
when

met

,
muttered
something
about
an
engagement
,
and
taking

home
graciously
promised
that
he
would
breakfast
with
her
on
the
following
morning
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
very
glad
you
are
going
,
Alice
,
"
he
said
when

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
papa
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
 
<EOS>
because
I
think

's

proper

to

.
<EOS>
You
know

've

.
<EOS>
They

,

;
 
not

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

'm

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
Rank

,

.
<EOS>

?
"

"
But

sha

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
Take

,

.
<EOS>
I
have

run

myself
,
though

married
,
as

,
among

.
<EOS>
That
very

rather

otherwise
.
<EOS>
But
you
may

sure

,
that
men

,

,

.
<EOS>
Everybody

stand

,
and
if

,

,
 
unless
,

,

.
<EOS>
I
do

,

.
<EOS>
It
's

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Alice

's

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

,

"
<EOS>

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
Then

not

,

.

.

"

<EOS>

V.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.

.

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
As

,

her

before
nine
,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Well
;

,

"
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

:
"
How

?
"

"

,

"

.

<EOS>

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Alice

still

.
<EOS>
And

;

herself
had
been
imprudent
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
understand
it
,
"
continued
George
,
speaking
without
looking
at
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
was
but
the
other
day
that
we
were
such
dear
friends
!
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
the
balcony
at
Basle
?
<EOS>
and
now
it
seems
that
we
are
quite
estranged
;
 
nay
,
worse
than
estranged
;
that
I
am
,
as
it
were
,
under
some
ban
.
<EOS>
Have
I
done
anything
to
offend
you
,
Alice
?
<EOS>
If
so
,
speak
out
,
like
a
woman
of
spirit
as
you
are
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
am
I
tabooed
?
<EOS>
Why
was
I
told
the
other
day
that
I
might
not
congratulate
you
on
your
happy

?
<EOS>
I
say
boldly
,
that
had
you
resolved
on
that
while
we
were
together
in
Switzerland
,
you
would
have
permitted
me
,
as

,
almost

,
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think

,
George
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
you
would
.
<EOS>
And
why
has
Kate
been
warned
not
to
tell

of
this
visit
to
the
Pallisers
?
<EOS>
I
know
she
has
been
warned
though
she
has
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
sat

,
not

to
say
in

to
this
charge
brought
against
her
,
 
thinking
,
perhaps
,
that
the

would

to

.
<EOS>
But
Vavasor
was
not
so

.
<EOS>
"
If
there
be
any
reason
,
Alice
,
I
think
that
I
have
a
right
to
ask
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
For
a
few
seconds
she
did
not
speak

word
,
but
sat
considering
.
<EOS>
He
also
remained
silent
with
his
eyes
fixed
upon
her
.
<EOS>
She
looked
at
him
and
saw
nothing
but
his
scar
,
 
nothing
but
his
scar
and
the
brightness
of
his
eyes
,
which
was
almost
fierce
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
he
was
in
earnest
,
and
therefore
resolved
that
she
would
be
in
earnest
also
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
that
you
have
such
a
right
,
"
she
said
at
last
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
let
me
exercise
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
that
you
have
such
a
right
,
but
I
think
also
that
you
are
ungenerous
to
exercise
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
understand
that
.
<EOS>
By
heavens
,
Alice
,
I
can
not
be
left
in
this

!
<EOS>
If
I
have
done
anything
to
offend
you
,
perhaps
I
can
remove
the

by

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
done
nothing
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Or
if
there

,
 
why

different

in
Switzerland
<EOS>
,
I

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will

,
George
,

so
will
,

,

.
"
<EOS>
She

,

;
but
he

all

.
  
<EOS>
"
Your

,
George
,

.
<EOS>
You

<EOS>
You

.
"
  
<EOS>

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
George
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

<EOS>
I

,

"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

"

.
"
<EOS>
She

,

,

<EOS>
"
I

"

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said

;
"
no
.
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

"
  
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

!
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
that

.
<EOS>
It

;
but

,

,
 
strong

.
<EOS>
A

ca

,

,

.
<EOS>
A

ca

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't

.
<EOS>
I
do

that

myself
.
<EOS>
But
a

.
<EOS>
Such

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
George
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

I

.
<EOS>
My

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By

,

;

.
<EOS>
Do

nowadays

?
<EOS>
Almost

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

;

,

<EOS>
George

without

about
her
marriage

past
or

,
and
Alice

.
   
<EOS>
Dandy
and
Flirt
.
 
<EOS>
Alice
reached
the
Matching
Road
Station
about
three

in
the
afternoon
without
adventure
,
and
immediately
on
the

of

train
became
aware
that
all

was
off
her
own
hands
.
<EOS>
A
servant
in
livery
came
to
the
open
window
,
and
touching
his
hat
to

,
inquired
if
she
were
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Then
her
dressing
-
bag
and
shawls
and

were
taken
from

,
and

was

through

by

,

,

.
<EOS>
She
instantly
perceived
that
she
had
become
possessed
of
great

by
belonging
even
for
a
time
to
Matching
Priory
,
and
that
she
was
essentially
growing
upwards
towards
the
light
.
  
<EOS>
Outside
,

broad

before

little

,

that
was

,
intended

had
not
grown

as
had
been
her

;
and

which
she

a
Whitechapel
<EOS>
had

in

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
Of

was
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
Another

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Alice
,
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Look

,
dear
;
your
maid

,
"
 
it

dog

,

;
 
"
she

;

.
<EOS>
Are

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
You
've

in
the
stuffy

,
but
you
'll

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

Glencora
,

,
"
said
Alice
,
getting
in
and
taking

place
<EOS>
assigned

next

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
nonsense
!
<EOS>
Sorry
!
<EOS>
Why
I
've
looked
forward
to
meeting
you
all
alone
,
ever

I

.
<EOS>
If

I

just

.
<EOS>
I
drive

almost
every

when
I
'm

here
,
 
<EOS>
that

,
when

not

,

.
<EOS>
Wrap

;
there

.
<EOS>
You
shall

if
you
like
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
however
,
declined
the

,
expressing
her

in
what

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
like
driving
better
than
anything
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
does
n't
like

to
hunt
,
and

n't

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

should
like

drive
four
-
in

hand
,
 
<EOS>
only
I
know
I
should
be

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
look
very

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
would
n't
it
?
<EOS>
The
look
would
be
the

of
it
;
as
it
is
all
the
world

.
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
wish

no
such
things
as

.
<EOS>
I
do

,

;
only

,
right

,
for

Grundy
.
<EOS>
I

had

<EOS>

,
as
Topsy
used
to
say
.
<EOS>
Do
you
hunt
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
shoot
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shoot
!
<EOS>
What
;
with
a
gun
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
was
staying
in
a
house
last
week
with
a
lady
who
shot
a
good
deal
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
do
n't
shoot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
ride
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
wish
I
did
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
ridden
because
I
've
no
one
to
ride
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
drive
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
do
n't
drive
either
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
what
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
sit
at
home
,
and
 
"
  
"
Mend
your
stockings
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
do
n't
do
that
,
because
it
's
disagreeable
;
but
I
do
work
a
good
deal
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
have
amused
myself
by
reading
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
they
never
do
that
here
.
<EOS>
I
have
heard
that
there
is
a
library
,
but
the
clue
to
it
has
been
lost
,
and
nobody
now
knows
the
way
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
in
libraries
.
<EOS>
Nobody
ever
goes
into
a
library
to
read
,
any
more
than
you
would
into
a
larder
to
eat
.
<EOS>
But
there
is
this
difference
;
 
the
food
you
consume
does
come
out
of
the
larders
,
but
the
books
you
read
never
come
out
of
the
libraries
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Except
Mudie
's
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
yes
;
he
is
the
great
librarian
.
<EOS>
And
you
mean
to
read
all
the
time
you
are
here
,
Miss
Vavasor
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
walk
about
the
priory
ruins
sometimes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
must
go
by
moonlight
,
and
I
'll
go
with
you
.
<EOS>
Only
is
n't
it
rather
late
in
the
year
for
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
it
is
,
 
for
you
,
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
the
Duke
spoke
to
her
again
,
and
she
found
that
she
got
on
very
well
during
dinner
.
<EOS>
But
she
could
not
but
feel
angry
with
herself
in
that
she
had
any
fear
on
the
subject
;
 
and
yet
she
could
not
divest
herself
of
that
fear
.
<EOS>
She
acknowledged
to
herself
that
she
was
conscious
of
a
certain
inferiority
to
Lady
Glencora
and
to
Mr.
Jeffrey
Palliser
,
which
almost
made
her
unhappy
.
<EOS>
As
regarded
the
Duke
on
the
other
side
of
her
,
she
had
no
such
feeling
.
<EOS>
He
was
old
enough
to
be
her
father
,
and
was
a
Cabinet
Minister
;
therefore
he
was
entitled
to
her
reverence
.
<EOS>
But
how
was
it
that
she
could
not
help
accepting
the
other
people
<EOS>
round
her
as
being
indeed
superior
to
herself
?
<EOS>
Was
she
really
learning
to
believe
that
she
could
grow
upwards
by
their
sunlight
?
  
<EOS>
"
Jeffrey
is
a
pleasant
fellow
,
is
he
not
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
to
her
as
they
passed
back
through
the
billiard

room
to
the
drawing
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
pleasant
;
 
a
little
sarcastic
,
perhaps
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
you
would
soon
find
yourself
able
to
get
the
better
of
that
if
he
tries
it
upon
you
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
;
and
then
the
ladies
were
all
in
the
drawing
-
room
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
quite
deliciously
warm
,
coming
from
one
room
to
another
,
"
said
the
Duchess
,
putting
her
emphasis
on
the
"
one
"
and
the
"
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
we
had
better
keep
continually
moving
,
"
said
a
certain
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
,
a

,
who
had
been
very
handsome
,
who
was
still
very
clever
,
who
was
not
perhaps
very
good
-
natured
,
and
of
whom
the
Duchess
of
St.
Bungay
was
rather
afraid
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
we
may
be
warm
here
too
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
not
deliciously
warm
,
"
said
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
makes
me
tremble
in
every

when
Mrs.
Sparkes
attacks
her
,
"
Lady
Glencora

,
"
for

'll

the
Duke
;

,

man

red

Palliser
,

I

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's

political

.
<EOS>
His
name
is
Bott
,
and
he
's
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
why
should
he

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
's
his
business
.
<EOS>
I
do

quite

all
the
ins
and
outs
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
believe
he
's
to
be
one

Mr.
Palliser
's

he

Chancellor
of
the

.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
does
n't
tell
;
 
<EOS>
only
I
think
he
does
all
the
same
.
<EOS>
He
always
calls
me
Lady
Glen
-

.
<EOS>
He
comes
out
of
Lancashire
,
and
made
calico
as
long
as
he
could
get
any

.
<EOS>
"
But
this
happened
in
the

,
and
we
must

.
  
<EOS>
The
Duchess
had
made
no

to
Mrs.
Sparkes
,
and
<EOS>
so
nothing
further
was
said
about
the

.
<EOS>
Nor
,
indeed
,
was
there
any
conversation
that
was
comfortably

.
<EOS>
The
number

ladies
in
the
room
was
too
great
for
that
,
and
ladies
do
not
divide
themselves

into
small

,
as
men
and
women
do
when

mixed
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
behaved
pretty
by
telling
the
Duchess
all
about
her

;
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
told
ill
-
natured

of
some
one
to
Miss
Euphemia
Palliser
;
one
of
the
Duchess
's

walked
off
to
a
distant
piano
with
an
admiring
friend
and
touched
a
few
notes
;
while
Iphigenia
Palliser
boldly
took
up
a
book
,
and
placed
herself
at
a
table
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
who
was
sitting
opposite
to
Lady
Glencora
,
began
to
speculate
whether
she
might
do
the
same
;
but
her

failed
her
,
and
she
sat
on
,
telling
herself
that
she
was
out
of
her

.
"
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
after

,

,
and
in

,
"
can
you
play
billiards
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Alice
,
rather

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
shall
learn
to
-
night
,
and
if
nobody
else
will
teach
you
,
you
shall
be
my
pupil
.
"
<EOS>
Whereupon
Lady
Glencora
rang
the
bell
and
ordered
that
the
billiard
-
table
might
be
got
ready
.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
play
,
Duchess
,
of

,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
nice
and
warm
,
that
I
think
I
will
,
"
said
the
Duchess
;
but
as

looked

to
that

room
where
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
was

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
all

,
"
said
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
,
"
and
then
it
will
be
nicer
,
 
and
perhaps

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
joined
them
just
as

were
settling
themselves
round
the
table
,
and
as
many

them
stayed
there
,

-
room
became
full
.
<EOS>
Alice
had
first
a
cue
put
into
her
hand
,
and
making
nothing
of
that
was
permitted
to
play
with
a
mace
.
<EOS>
The
duty
of
instructing
her
devolved
on
Jeffrey
Palliser
,
and
the
next
hour
passed
pleasantly
;
 
not
so
pleasantly
,
she
thought
afterwards
,
as
did
some
of
those
hours
in
Switzerland
when
her
cousins
were
with
her
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
she
could
get
more
out
of
her
life
with
such

as
them
,
than
she
could
with
any
of
these
people
at

.
<EOS>
She
felt
quite
sure
of
that
;
 
though
Jeffrey
Palliser
did
take
great
trouble
to
teach
her
the
game
,
and
once
or
twice
made
her
laugh
heartily
by
quizzing
the
Duchess
's
attitude
as
she
stood
up
to
make
her
stroke
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
could
play
billiards
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sparkes
,
on
one
of
these

;
"
I
do
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
said

were
coming
to
play
,
"
said
the
Duchess
,
almost

,
and
with
a

of

evidently
produced
by
her
own
successes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
to
see
your
Grace
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sparkes
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

that
there

anything
more
to

,
"

Duchess
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,

.
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
Duchess
,
you
hit

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very
well
;
 
then
I
suppose
Miss
Vavasor
plays
now
.
<EOS>
That
was
a
miss
.
<EOS>
Will
you
mark
that
,
if
you
please
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
latter
demand
was
made
with
great
stress
,
as
though

had
been
defrauded
in
the
matter
of
the

,
and
was

.
<EOS>
Before

,
the
Duchess
,
with

,

,

,
 
which

,

,
was
,
I

,
owing
rather
to
Alice
's

than
to

Grace
's

.
<EOS>
The
Duchess
,
however
,
was
very

,
and
made

back
into
the
drawing
-
room
with
a
step
which
seemed
to
declare
loudly
that
she

Mrs.
Sparkes
at

.
  
<EOS>
Not

this
the
ladies
went

.
<EOS>
Many
of

,
perhaps
,
did
not
go
to

at
once
,
as

was
as
yet
not
eleven

,
and
it
was
past

when
they
all

.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
Alice
,
who
had

up
at
seven
,
did
not
go
to
bed
then
,
nor
for

next
two

.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
come
into
your
room
just
for
one

,
"
Lady
Glencora
said
as
she
passed

from

;
and

was
back
with

.
"
<EOS>
Would
you
mind
going
into
my
room
 
<EOS>
it
's
just
there
,
and

Ellen
for
a

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
Lady
Glencora
said
in
the

to
the
girl
who

waiting

Alice
;
and
then
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
keep
you
up

a

.
<EOS>
But

,
how

you

?
<EOS>
Will
you
be
able

?
"
<EOS>
Alice
of

that
she

;

that

in
which
the

Mr.
Bott
,
the
man

the
red

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

've

something
to

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
anything
terrible
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
nothing

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Lady
Glencora
,
if
it
's
 
"
  
"
I
wo
n't

call
me
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
Do

Alice
?
<EOS>
Why

so

?
<EOS>
I
have

now

do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
are

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
felt
sure
that
the
thing

some

Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
and
she
did

Mr.
Fitzgerald
's

from
her
cousin
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell

something
;
 
of
course
I
am
.
<EOS>
I
'm
going
to
tell

that
,
 
that

I

a

.
<EOS>
But
it
was

that
I
wished
to

;
 
only

could

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know

had

in
London
last

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
not

I
came

:
was
that
it
?
<EOS>
But
never
mind
.
<EOS>
Why
should
you
have
cared
?
<EOS>
But
I
cared
.
<EOS>
I
told
you
in
my
letter
that
I
did
n't

because
I
had
so
many
things
on

.
<EOS>
Of
course
that
was
a
fib
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Everybody
makes
excuses
of
that
kind
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
they
do
n't
make
them
to
the
very
people
of
all
others
whom
they
want
to
know
and
love
.
<EOS>
I
was
longing
to
come
to
you
every
day
.
<EOS>
But
I
feared
I
could
not
come
without
speaking
of
him
;
 
and
I
had
determined
never
to
speak
of
him
again
.
<EOS>
"
This
she
said
in
that
peculiar
low
voice
which
she
assumed
at
times
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
why
do
it
now
,
Lady
Glencora
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
be
called
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
Call
me
Cora
.
<EOS>
I
had
a
sister
once
,
older
than
I
,
and
she
used
to
call
me
Cora
.
<EOS>
If
she
had
lived
 
.
<EOS>
But
never
mind
that
now
.
<EOS>
She
did
n't
live
.
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
why
I
do
it
now
.
<EOS>
Because
I
can
not
help
it
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
've
met
him
.
<EOS>
I
've
been
in
the
same
room
with
him
,
and
have
spoken
to
him
.
<EOS>
What
's
the
good
of
any
such
resolution
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
met
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
he
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
 
knew
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
When
he
talked
of
taking
me
to
the
house
,
I
whispered
to
him
that
I
thought
Burgo
would
be
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
call
him
by
his
Christian
name
,
"
said
Alice
,
almost
with
a
shudder
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
 
<EOS>
why
not
his
Christian
name
?
<EOS>
I
did
when
I
told
my
husband
.
<EOS>
Or
perhaps
I
said
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
he
bade
me
go
.
<EOS>
He
said
it
did
n't
signify
,
and
that
I
had
better
learn
to
bear
it
.
<EOS>
Bear
it
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
If
I
am
to
meet
him
,
and
speak
to
him
,
and
look
at
him
,
surely
I
may
mention
his
name
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
she
paused
for
an
answer
.
"
<EOS>
May
I
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
am
I
to
say
?
"
exclaimed
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Anything
you
please
,
that
's
not
a
falsehood
.
<EOS>
But
I
've
got
you
here
because
I
do
n't
think
you
will
tell
a
falsehood
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Alice
,
I
do
so
want
to
go
right
,
and
it
is
so
hard
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hard
,
indeed
,
poor
creature
,
for
one
so
weighted
as
she
had
been
,
and
sent
out
into
the
world
with
so
small
advantages
of
previous
training
or
of
present
friendship
!
<EOS>
Alice
began
to
feel
now
that
she
had
been
enticed
to
Matching
Priory
because
her
cousin
wanted
a
friend
,
and
of
course
she
could
not
refuse
to
give
the
friendship
that
was
asked
from
her
.
<EOS>
She
got
up
from
her
chair
,
and
kneeling
down
at
the
other
's
feet
put
up
her
face
and
kissed
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
knew
you
would
be
good
to
me
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
you
would
.
<EOS>
And
you
may
say
whatever
you
like
.
<EOS>
But
I
could
not
bear
that
you
should
not
know
the
real
reason
why
I
neither
came
to
you
nor
sent
for
you
after
we
went
to
London
.
<EOS>
You
'll
come
to
me
now
;
wo
n't
you
,
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
;
 
and
you
'll
come
to
me
,
"
said
Alice
,
making
in
her
mind
a
sort
of
bargain
that
she
was
not
to

received
into
Mr.
Palliser
's
house
after
the
fashion
in
which
Lady
Midlothian
had
proposed
to
receive

.
<EOS>
But
it
struck
her
at
once
that
this
was
unworthy
of
her
,
and
ungenerous
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
'll
come
to
you
,
"
she
added
,
"
<EOS>
whether
you
come
to
me
or
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
to
you
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
"
of
course
,
 
why
should
n't
I
?
<EOS>
But
you
know
what
I
mean
.
<EOS>
We
shall
have
dinners
and
parties
and
lots
of
people
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
we
shall
have
none
,
"
said
Alice
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
therefore
there
is
so
much
more
excuse
for
your
coming
to
me
;
 
or
rather
<EOS>
I
mean
so
much
more
reason
,
for
I
do
n't
want
excuses
.
<EOS>
Well
,
dear
,
I
'm
so
glad
I
've
told
you
.
<EOS>
I
was
afraid
to
see
you
in
London
.
<EOS>
I
should
hardly
have
known
how
to
look
at
you
then
.
<EOS>
But
I
've
got
over
that
now
.
<EOS>
"
Then
she
smiled
and
returned
the
kiss
which
Alice
had
given
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
singular
to
see
her
standing
on
the
bedroom
rug
with
all
her
magnificence
of
dress
,
but
with
her
hair
pushed
back
behind
her
ears
,
and
her
eyes
red
with
tears
,
 
as
though
the
burden
of
the
magnificence
remained
to
her
after
its
purpose
was
over
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
declare
it
's
ever
so
much
past
twelve
.
<EOS>
Good
night
,
now
,
dear
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
he
's
come
up
.
<EOS>
But
I
should
have
heard
his
step
if
he
had
.
<EOS>
He
never
treads
lightly
.
<EOS>
He
seldom
gives
over
work
till
after
one
,
and
sometimes
goes
on
till
three
.
<EOS>
It
's
the
only
thing
he
likes
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
<EOS>
good
night
.
<EOS>
I
've
such
a
deal
more
to
say
to
you
;
and
Alice
,
you
must
tell
me
something
about
yourself
,
too
;
wo
n't
you
,
dear
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
without
waiting
for
an
answer
Lady
Glencora
went
,
leaving
Alice
in
a
maze
of
bewilderment
.
<EOS>
She
could
hardly
believe
that
all
she
had
heard
,
and
all
she
had
done
,
had
happened
since
she
left
Queen
Anne
Street
that
morning
.
   
<EOS>
Three
Politicians
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
one
of
those
politicians
in
possessing
whom
England
has
perhaps
more
reason
to
be
proud
than
of
any
other
of
her
resources
,
and
who
,
as
a
body
,
give
to
her
that
exquisite
combination
of
conservatism
and
progress
which
is
her
present
strength
and
best
security
for
the
future
.
<EOS>
He
could
afford
to
learn
to
be
a
statesman
,
and
had
the
industry
wanted
for
such
training
.
<EOS>
He
was
born
in
the
purple
,
noble
himself
,
and
heir
to
the
highest
rank
as
well
as
one
of
the
greatest
fortunes
of
the
country
,
already
very
rich
,
surrounded
by
all
the
temptations
of
luxury
and
pleasure
;
and
yet
he
devoted
himself
to
work
with
the
grinding
energy
of
a
young
penniless
barrister
labouring
for
a
penniless
wife
,
and
did
so
without
any
motive
more
selfish
than
that
of
being
counted
in
the
roll
of
the
public
servants
of
England
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
brilliant
man
,
and
understood
well
that
such
was
the
case
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
listened
to
in
the
House
,
as
the
phrase
goes
;
but
he
was
listened
to
as
a
laborious
man
,
who
was
in
earnest
in
what
he
did
,
who
got
up
his
facts
with
accuracy
,
and
who
,
dull
though
he
be
,
was
worthy
of
confidence
.
<EOS>
And
he
was
very
dull
.
<EOS>
He
rather
prided
himself
on
being
dull
,
and
on
conquering
in
spite
of
his
dullness
.
<EOS>
He
never
allowed
himself
a
joke
in
his
speeches
,
nor
attempted
even
the
smallest
flourish
of
rhetoric
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
careful
in
his
language
,
labouring
night
and
day
to
learn
to
express
himself
with
accuracy
,
with
no
needless
repetition
of
words
,
perspicuously
with
regard
to
the
special
object
he
might
have
in
view
.
<EOS>
He
had
taught
himself
to
believe
that
oratory
,
as
oratory
,
was
a
sin
against
that
honesty
in
politics
by
which
he
strove
to
guide
himself
.
<EOS>
He
desired
to
use
words
for
the
purpose
of
teaching
things
which
he
knew
and
which
others
did
not
know
;
and
he
desired
also
to
be
honoured
for
his
knowledge
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
no
desire
to
be
honoured
for
the
language
in
which
his
knowledge
was
conveyed
.
<EOS>
He
was
an
upright
,
thin
,
laborious
man
;
who
by
his
parts
alone
could
have
served
no
political
party
materially
,
but
whose
parts
were
sufficient
to
make
his
education
,
integrity
,
and
industry
useful
in
the
highest
degree
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
trust
which
such
men
inspire
which
makes
them
so
serviceable
;
 
trust
not
only
in
their
labour
,
 
for
any
man
rising
from
the
mass
of
the
people
may
be
equally
laborious
;
nor
yet
simply
in
their
honesty
and
patriotism
.
<EOS>
The
confidence
is
given
to
their
labour
,
honesty
,
and
patriotism
joined
to
such
a
personal
stake
in
the
country
as
gives
them
a
weight
and
ballast
which
no
politician
in
England
can
possess
without
it
.
  
<EOS>
If
he
was
dull
as
a
statesman
he
was
more
dull
in
private
life
,
and
it
may
be
imagined
that
such
a
woman
as
his
wife
would
find
some
difficulty
in
making
his
society
the
source
of
her
happiness
.
<EOS>
Their
marriage
,
in
a
point
of
view
regarding
business
,
had
been
a
complete
success
,
 
and
a
success
,
too
,
when
on
the
one
side
,
that
of
Lady
Glencora
,
there
had
been
terrible
dangers
of
shipwreck
,
and
when
on
his
side
also
there
had
been
some
little
fears
of
a
mishap
.
<EOS>
As
regards
her
it
has
been
told
how
near
she
went
to
throwing
herself
,
with
all
her
vast
wealth
,
into
the
arms
of
a
young
man
,
whom
no
father
,
no
guardian
could
have
regarded
as
a
well
-
chosen
husband
for
any
girl
;
 
one
who
as
yet
had
shown
no
good
qualities
,
who
had
been
a
spendthrift
,
unprincipled
,
and
debauched
.
<EOS>
Alas
,
she
had
loved
him
!
<EOS>
It
is
possible
that
her
love
and
her
wealth
might
have
turned
him
from
evil
to
good
.
<EOS>
But
who
would
have
ventured
to
risk
her
,
 
I
will
not
say
her
and
her
vast
inheritances
,
 
on
such
a
chance
?
<EOS>
That
evil
,
however
,
had
been
prevented
,
and
those
about
her
had
managed
to
marry
her
to
a
young
man
,
very
steady
by
nature
,
with
worldly
prospects
as
brilliant
as
her
own
,
and
with
a
station
than
which
the
world
offers
nothing
higher
.
<EOS>
His
little
threatened
mischance
,
 
a
passing
fancy
for
a
married
lady
who
was
too
wise
to
receive
vows
which
were
proffered
not
in
the
most
ardent
manner
,
 
had
,
from
special
reasons
,
given
some
little
alarm
to
his
uncle
,
which
had
just
sufficed
at
the
time
to
make
so
very
judicious
a
marriage
doubly
pleasant
to
that
noble
duke
,
So
that
all
things
and
all
people
had
conspired
to
shower
substantial
comforts
on
the
heads
of
this
couple
,
when
they
were
joined
together
,
and
men
and
women
had
not
yet
ceased
to
declare
how
happy
were
both
in
the
accumulated
gifts
of
fortune
.
  
<EOS>
And
as
regards
Mr.
Palliser
,
I
think
that
his
married
life
,
and
the
wife
,
whom
he
certainly
had
not
chosen
,
but
who
had
dropped
upon
him
,
suited
him
admirably
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
great
wealth
for
that
position
at
which
he
aimed
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
rich
before
his
marriage
with
his
own
wealth
,
 
so
rich
that
he
could
throw
thousands
away
if
he
wished
it
;
but
for
him
and
his
career
was
needed
that
colossal
wealth
which
would
make
men
talk
about
it
,
 
which
would
necessitate
an
expansive
expenditure
,
reaching
far
and
wide
,
doing
nothing
,
or
less
than
nothing
,
for
his
own
personal
comfort
,
but
giving
to
him
at
once
that
rock
-
like
solidity
which
is
so
necessary
to
our
great
aristocratic
politicians
.
<EOS>
And
his
wife
was
,
as
far
as
he
knew
,
all
that
he
desired
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
dabbled
much
in
the
fountains
of
Venus
,
though
he
had
forgotten
himself
once
,
and
sinned
in
coveting
another
man
's
wife
.
<EOS>
But
his
sin
then
had
hardly
polluted
his
natural
character
,
and
his
desire
had
been
of
a
kind
which
was
almost
more
gratified
in
its
disappointment
than
it
would
have
been
in
its
fruition
.
<EOS>
On
the
morning
after
the
lady
had
frowned
on
him
he
had
told
himself
that
he
was
very
well
out
of
that
trouble
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
it
would
never
be
for
him
to
hang
up
on
the
walls
of
a
temple
a
well
-
worn
lute
as
a
votive
offering
when
leaving
the
pursuits
of
love
.
<EOS>
_
Idoneus
puellis
_
he
never
could
have
been
.
<EOS>
So
he
married
Lady
Glencora
and
was
satisfied
.
<EOS>
The
story
of
Burgo
Fitzgerald
was
told
to
him
,
and
he
supposed
that
most
girls
had
some
such
story
to
tell
.
<EOS>
He
thought
little
about
it
,
and
by
no
means
understood
her
when
she
said
to
him
,
with
all
the
impressiveness
which
she
could
throw
into
the
words
,
"
You
must
know
that
I
have
really
loved
him
.
"
<EOS>
"
You
must
love
me
now
,
"
he
had
replied
with
a
smile
;
and
then
as
regarded
his
mind
,
the
thing
was
over
.
<EOS>
And
since
his
marriage
he
had
thought
that
things
matrimonial
had
gone
well
with
him
,
and
with
her
too
.
<EOS>
He
gave
her
almost
unlimited
power
of
enjoying
her
money
,
and
interfered
but
little
in
her
way
of
life
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
would
say
a
word
of
caution
to
her
with
reference
to
those
childish
ways
which
hardly
became
the
dull
dignity
of
his
position
;
and
his
words
then
would
have
in
them
something
of
unintentional
severity
,
 
whether
instigated
or
not
by
the
red
-
haired
Radical
Member
of
Parliament
,
I
will
not
pretend
to
say
;
 
but
on
the
whole
he
was
contented
and
loved
his
wife
,
as
he
thought
,
very
heartily
,
and
at
least
better
than
he
loved
any
one
else
.
<EOS>
One
cause
of
unhappiness
,
or
rather
one
doubt
as
to
his
entire
good
fortune
,
was
beginning
to
make
itself
felt
,
as
his
wife
had
to
her
sorrow
already
discovered
.
<EOS>
He
had
hoped
that
before
this
he
might
have
heard
that
she
would
give
him
a
child
.
<EOS>
But
the
days
were
young
yet
for
that
trouble
,
and
the
care
had
not
become
a
sorrow
.
  
<EOS>
But
this
judicious
arrangement
as
to
properties
,
this
well
-
ordered
alliance
between
families
,
had
not
perhaps
suited
her
as
well
as
it
had
suited
him
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
she
might
have
learned
to
forget
her
early
lover
,
or
to
look
back
upon
it
with
a
soft
melancholy
hardly
amounting
to
regret
,
had
her
new
lord
been
more
tender
in
his
ways
with
her
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
Lady
Glencora
's
heart
was
made
of
that
stern
stuff
which
refuses
to
change
its
impressions
;
but
it
was
a
heart
,
and
it
required
food
.
<EOS>
To
love
and
fondle
someone
,
 
to
be
loved
and
fondled
,
were
absolutely
necessary
to
her
happiness
.
<EOS>
She
wanted
the
little
daily
assurance
of
her
supremacy
in
the
man
's
feelings
,
the
constant
touch
of
love
,
half
accidental
half
contrived
,
the
passing
glance
of
the
eye
telling
perhaps
of
some
little
joke
understood
only
between
them
two
rather
than
of
love
,
the
softness
of
an
occasional
kiss
given
here
and
there
when
chance
might
bring
them
together
,
some
half
-
pretended
interest
in
her
little
doings
,
a
nod
,
a
wink
,
a
shake
of
the
head
,
or
even
a
pout
.
<EOS>
It
should
have
been
given
to
her
to
feed
upon
such
food
as
this
daily
,
and
then
she
would
have
forgotten
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Palliser
understood
none
of
these
things
;
and
therefore
the
image
of
Burgo
Fitzgerald
in
all
his
beauty
was
ever
before
her
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
But
not
the
less
was
Mr.
Palliser
<EOS>
a
prosperous
man
,
as
to
the
success
of
whose
career
few
who
knew
him
had
much
doubt
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
written
in
the
book
of
his
destiny
that
he
would
have
to
pass
through
some
violent
domestic
trouble
,
some
ruin
in
the
hopes
of
his
home
,
of
a
nature
to
destroy
then
and
for
ever
the
worldly
prospects
of
other
men
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
one
who
would
pass
through
such
violence
,
should
it
come
upon
him
,
without
much
scathe
.
<EOS>
To
lose
his
influence
with
his
party
would
be
worse
to
him
than
to
lose
his
wife
,
and
public
disgrace
would
hit
him
harder
than
private
dishonour
.
  
<EOS>
And
the
present
was
the
very
moment
in
which
success
was
,
as
was
said
,
coming
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
already
held
laborious
office
under
the
Crown
,
but
had
never
sat
in
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
He
had
worked
much
harder
than
Cabinet
Ministers
generally
work
,
 
but
hitherto
had
worked
without
any
reward
that
was
worth
his
having
.
<EOS>
For
the
stipend
which
he
had
received
had
been
nothing
to
him
,
 
as
the
great
stipend
which
he
would
receive
,
if
his
hopes
were
true
,
would
also
be
nothing
to
him
.
<EOS>
To
have
ascendancy
over
other
men
,
to
be
known
by
his
countrymen
as
one
of
their
real
rulers
,
to
have
an
actual
and
acknowledged
voice
in
the
management
of
nations
,
 
those
were
the
rewards
for
which
he
looked
;
and
now
in
truth
it
seemed
as
though
they
were
coming
to
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
but
known
that
the
existing
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
would
separate
himself
from
the
Government
,
carrying
various
others
with

,
either
before
or

on
the

of

;
 
and
it
was
all
but
known
,
also
,
that
Mr.
Palliser
would
fill
his
place
,
taking
that
high
office
at
once
,
although
he
had
never
hitherto
sat
in
that
august
assembly
which
men
call
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
He
could
thus
afford
to
put
up
with
the
small
everyday
calamity
of
having
a
wife
who
loved
another
man
better
than
she
loved
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
presence
of
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
at
Matching
was
assumed
to
be
a
sure
sign
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
coming
triumph
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
was
a
statesman
of
a
very
different
class
,
but
he
also
had
been
eminently
successful
as
an
aristocratic
pillar
of
the
British
Constitutional
Republic
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
minister
of
very
many
years
"
standing
,
being
as
used
to
cabinet
sittings
as
other
men
are
to
their
own
armchairs
;
but
he
had
never
been
a
hard
-
working
man
.
<EOS>
Though
a
constant
politician
,
he
had
ever
taken
politics
easy
whether
in
office
or
out
.
<EOS>
The
world
had
said
before
now
that
the
Duke
might
be
Premier
,
only
that
he
would
not
take
the
trouble
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
consulted
by
a
very
distinguished
person
,
 
so
the
papers
had
said
more
than
once
,
 
as
to
the
making
of
Prime
Ministers
.
<EOS>
His
voice
in
council
was
esteemed
to
be
very
great
.
<EOS>
He
was
regarded
as
a
strong
rock
of
support
to
the
liberal
cause
,
and
yet
nobody
ever
knew
what
he
did
;
nor
was
there
much
record
of
what
he
said
.
<EOS>
The
offices
which
he
held
,
or
had
held
,
were
generally
those
to
which
no
very
arduous
duties
were
attached
.
<EOS>
In
severe
debates
he
never
took
upon
himself
the
brunt
of
opposition
oratory
.
<EOS>
What
he
said
in
the
House
was
generally
short
and
pleasant
,
 
with
some
slight
,
drolling
,
undercurrent
of
uninjurious
satire
running
through
it
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
walking
miracle
of
the
wisdom
of
common
sense
.
<EOS>
He
never
lost
his
temper
.
<EOS>
He
never
made
mistakes
.
<EOS>
He
never
grew
either
hot
or
cold
in
a
cause
.
<EOS>
He
was
never
reckless
in
politics
,
and
never
cowardly
.
<EOS>
He
snubbed
no
man
,
and
took
snubbings
from
no
man
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
Knight
of
the
Garter
,
a
Lord
Lieutenant
of
his
county
,
and
at
sixty
-
two
had
his
digestion
unimpaired
and
his
estate
in
excellent
order
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
great
buyer
of
pictures
,
which
,
perhaps
,
he
did
not
understand
,
and
a
great
collector
of
books
which
certainly
he
never
read
.
<EOS>
All
the
world
respected
him
,
and
he
was
a
man
to
whom
the
respect
of
all
the
world
was
as
the
breath
of
his
nostrils
.
  
<EOS>
But
even
he
was
not
without
his
peacock
on
the
wall
,
his
skeleton
in
the
closet
,
his
thorn
in
his
side
;
though
the
peacock
did
not
scream
loud
,
the
skeleton
was
not
very
terrible
in
his
anatomical
arrangement
,
nor
was
the
thorn
likely
to
fester
to
a
gangrene
.
<EOS>
The
Duke
was
always
in
awe
about
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
ever
uneasy
about
his
wife
,
but
it
must
not
be
supposed
that
he
feared
the
machinations
of
any
Burgo
Fitzgerald
as
being
destructive
of
his
domestic
comfort
.
<EOS>
The
Duchess
was
and
always
had
been
all
that
is
proper
.
<EOS>
Ladies
in
high
rank
,
when
gifted
with
excelling
beauty
,
have
often
been
made
the
marks
of
undeserved
calumny
;
 
but
no
breath
of
slander
had
ever
touched
her
name
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
if
any
man
alive
had
ever
had
the
courage
even
to
wink
at
her
since
the
Duke
had
first
called
her
his
own
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
she
a
spendthrift
,
or
a
gambler
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
fast
in
her
tastes
,
or
given
to
any
pursuit
that
was
objectionable
.
<EOS>
She
was
simply
a
fool
,
and
as
a
fool
was
ever
fearing
that
she
was
the
mark
of
ridicule
.
<EOS>
In
all
such
miseries
she
would
complain
sorrowfully
,
piteously
,
and
occasionally
very
angrily
,
to
her
dear
Duke
and
protector
;
till
sometimes
her
dear
Duke
did
not
quite
know
what
to
do
with
her
or
how
to
protect
her
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
suit
him
,
a
Knight
of
the
Garter
and
a
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
,
to
beg

for
that
poor
wife
of
his
from
such

Mrs.
Conway

;
nor

more
in

way
to

against
that
lady
before
his
host
or

,
 
as

sometimes

.
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
like
the
people
,
my
dear
,

,
"
he

.
"
<EOS>
No
,
"
she

,
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
I

,

Longroyston
wo

.
<EOS>
But
I

.
"
<EOS>
And
the

came
strong

"
something
,
"
and

upon
"
woman
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Duke
did
not
know
how
to
silence
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
principle
of
his
life
never
to
be

any

.
<EOS>
How
could
he
get
at
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
?
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
she
is

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
That

Duke
,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
But
I

in

,

.
<EOS>
I

Lady
Glencora
should

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Lady
Glencora
is
very
young
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
about

so

young
,
"

the
Duchess
,
whose

poor

Glencora
's

.
<EOS>
Now
as

this
kind
were

to

Duke
,
and
as

,
to
some

Duchess
,

an

,
and
at

that
her
Grace
was
at
 
Longroyston
.
  
<EOS>
And
there
was
a
third
politician
staying
at
Matching
Priory
who
had
never
yet
risen
to
the
rank

a

,
but
who
had
his

.
<EOS>
This
was
Mr.
Bott
,
the

St.

,
whom

had
described
as
a
man
who
stood
about
,
with
red
hair
,
 
and
perhaps
told
tales
of
her
to
her
husband
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
was
a
person
who
certainly
had
had
some
success
in
life
and
who
had
won
it
for
himself
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
very
young
,
being
at
this

just

.
<EOS>
He
was
now

his
second
session
in
Parliament
,
having
been
returned
as
a
pledged

of
the
Manchester

.
<EOS>
Nor
had
he
apparently
been
false
to
his
pledges
.
<EOS>
At
St.
Helens
he
was
still
held
to
be
a
good
man
and
true
.
<EOS>
But
they
who
sat
on
the
same
side

him
in
the
House
and
watched
his
political

,
knew
that
he
was
striving
hard
to
get
his
finger
into
the
public
pie
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
rich
man
,
though
he
had
made
calico
and
had
got
into
Parliament
.
<EOS>
And
though
he
claimed
to
be
a
thoroughgoing
<EOS>
Radical
<EOS>
,
he
was
a
man
who
liked
to
live
with
aristocrats
,
and
was
fond
of
listening
to
the
whispers
of
such
as
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
or
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
It
was
supposed
that
he
did
understand
something
of
finance
.
<EOS>
He
was
at
any
rate
great
in
figures
;
and
as
he
was
possessed
of
much
industry
,
and
was
obedient
withal
,
he
was
a
man
who
might
make
himself
useful
to
a
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
ambitious
of
changes
.
  
<EOS>
There
are
men
who
get
into
such
houses
as
Matching
Priory
and
<EOS>
whose
presence

is
a
mystery
to
many
;
 
as

of

house
never

.
"
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Bott
is
coming
,
"
Mr.
Palliser

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
!
"
<EOS>
Lady

had

.
<EOS>
"
Goodness
me
!
<EOS>
who

Bott
?
"
<EOS>
"
He
is
member
for

Helens
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
A

man

.
"
<EOS>
"
And

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
He
is
a
man
who
has
a
great

,
and
I
dare

will

in

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
Mr.
Bott
arrived
.
<EOS>
But
though
a
huge
pile
of
letters
and
papers
came
to
him
every
morning
by
post
,
he
unfortunately
did
not
seem
to
spend
much
of
his
time
in
the
library
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
had
not
found
the
clue
to
that
lost
apartment
.
<EOS>
Twice
he
went
out
shooting
,
but
as
on
the
first
day
he
shot
the
keeper
,
and
on
the
second
very
nearly
shot
the
Duke
,
he
gave
that
up
.
<EOS>
Hunting
he
declined
,
though
much
pressed
to
make
an
essay
in
that
art
by
Jeffrey
Palliser
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
spend
his
time
,
as
Lady
Glencora
said
,
in
standing
about
,
 
except
at
certain
times
when
he
was
closeted
with
Mr.
Palliser
,
and
when
,
it
may
be
presumed
,
he
made
himself
useful
.
<EOS>
On
such
days
he
would
be
seen
at
the
hour
of
lunch
with
fingers
much
stained
with
ink
,
and
it
was
generally
supposed
that
on
those
occasions
he
had
been
counting
up
taxes
and
calculating
the
effect
of
great
financial
changes
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
tall
,
wiry
,
strong
man
,
with
a
bald
head
and
bristly
red
beard
,
which
,
however
,
was
cut
off
from
his
upper
and
under
lip
.
<EOS>
This
was
unfortunate
,
as
had
he
hidden
his
mouth
<EOS>
he
would
not
have
been
in
so
marked
a
degree
an
ugly
man
.
<EOS>
His
upper
lip
was
very
long
,
and
his
mouth
was
mean
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
found
that
without
the
help
of
a
razor
to
these
parts
he
could
not
manage
his
soup
to
his
satisfaction
,
and
preferring
cleanliness
to
beauty
had
shaved
himself
accordingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
n't
dislike
Mr.
Bott
so
much
,
"
Lady
Glencora
said
to
her
husband
,
"
if
he
did
n't
rub
his
hands
and
smile
so
often
,
and
seem
to
be
going
to
say
something
when
he
really
is
not
going
to
say
anything
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
you
need
trouble
yourself
about
him
,
my
dear
,
"
Mr.
Palliser
had
answered
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
when
he
looks
at
me
in
that
way
,
I
ca
n't
help
stopping
,
as
I
think
he
is
going
to
speak
;
and
then
he
always
says
,
"
Can
I
do
anything
for

,
Lady
Glen
-

?
"
<EOS>
"
  
She
instantly
saw
that
her
husband
did
not
like
this
.
"
Do
n't
be
angry
with

,
dear
,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
You
must
admit
that
he
is
rather
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
at
all
angry
,
Glencora
,
"
said
the
husband
;
"
and
if
you
insist
upon
it
,
I
will
see
that
he
leaves
;
 
and
in
such
case
will
of
course
never
ask

again
.
<EOS>
But
that
might
be
prejudicial
to
me
,
as
he
is
a
man
whom
I
trust
in
politics
,
and
who
may
perhaps

serviceable
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Of
course
Lady
Glencora
declared
that
Mr.
Bott
might
remain
as
long
as
he
and
her
husband
desired
,
and
of
course
she
mentioned
his
name
no

to
Mr.
Palliser
;
but

forth
she
regarded
Mr.
Bott
as
an

,
and
felt
also
that
Mr.
Bott
regarded

in

.
  
<EOS>
When
it
was
known
among
outside
politicians
that
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
was
staying
at
Matching
Priory
,
outside
<EOS>
politicians
became
more
sure
than
ever
that
Mr.
Palliser
would
be
the
new
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
.
<EOS>
The
old
minister
and
the
young
minister
were
of
course
arranging
matters
together
.
<EOS>
But
I
doubt
whether
Mr.
Palliser
and
the
Duke
ever
spoke
on
any
such
topic
during
the
entire
visit
.
<EOS>
Though
Mr.
Bott
was
occasionally
closeted
with
Mr.
Palliser
,
the
Duke
never
troubled
himself
with
such
closetings
.
<EOS>
He
went
out
shooting
 
on
his
pony
,
read
his
newspaper
,
wrote
his
notes
,
and
looked
with
the

of
a
connoisseur
over
all
Mr.

's

.
<EOS>
"
You
seem
to
have
a
good
man
,
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
Hubbings
?
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
he
was
a

from

Priory
.
"
<EOS>
"
A
very

man
,

.
<EOS>
Of

wo

;
but

;
 
which

.
<EOS>
I
could
never

rent

land
that
I

,
 
never
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
not
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
who
did

.
<EOS>
The

would

by

about

had

been

;
but

.
<EOS>
Nor

's

.
  
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Bott
was

.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
muster

,
"

<EOS>

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

;
 
that

,

.
<EOS>
By
-
the
-

,
Mr.
Bott
 
<EOS>
"

,

"
telling
.
"
   
<EOS>
In
Which
Much
of

History
of

Pallisers

.
 
<EOS>
At
the
end
of
ten
days
Alice
found
herself
quite
comfortable
at
Matching
Priory
.
<EOS>
She
had
now
promised
to
remain
there
till
the
second
week
of
December
,
at
which
time
she
was
to
go
to
Vavasor
Hall
,
 
there
to
meet
her
father
and
Kate
.
<EOS>
The
Pallisers
were
to
pass
their
Christmas
with
the
Duke
of
Omnium
in
Barsetshire
.
<EOS>
"
We
always
are
to
do
that
,
"
said
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
state

at
Gatherum

,
but
it
only

for
one

.
<EOS>
Then
we
go
somewhere

.
<EOS>
Oh
dear
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
say
"
oh
dear
"
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Because
 
;
I
do
n't
think
I
mean

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
'm

I
wo

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
so

,

.
<EOS>
But
I
can

,
and
I
'm

wo

unless
you
do

.
<EOS>
"
But
Alice
did
not

,
and
it
was

before
Lady

's

gave

.
  
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
have
said
,
Alice
had
become
quite
comfortable
at
Matching
Priory
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
she
was
already
growing
upwards
towards
the
light
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
she
could
listen
with

to
the
few

Duke
would
say
to

.
<EOS>
She
could
even

Duchess
,
 
so
that

Grace
had
observed

that
"

,

.
<EOS>
What

!
"
<EOS>
Lady

had
to

,
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do

she
 
jilted

?
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
Dear

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
<EOS>
And

next

;
 
but

.
  
<EOS>
Alice
also
had
learned

,
 
or

,

.
<EOS>
Jeffrey

had

,

,

had

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
rather

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
what

?
<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Upon

;

.
"
  
"

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Those

.
<EOS>
Only

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"
I

,
 
some

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
had
gone

,
much

's

,

.
<EOS>
On

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

;
 
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.

"
  
<EOS>
"
It

;

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
<EOS>
I

,

"

"

<EOS>
"

"
I

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

<EOS>
"

"

.
"

"
But

.
<EOS>
Then

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

,
"

,
"
