.
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Now
this

Mr.
Bott
has
come

,
and
only

,
I

.
<EOS>
He

,
and

more
than

,
because
he

.
<EOS>
Is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

you
need

him

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
but
I
am
the
mistress
here
,
and
am
told
that
I
am
to
entertain
the
people
.
<EOS>
Fancy
entertaining
the
Duchess
of
St.
Bungay
and
Mr.
Bott
!
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
now
become
so
intimate
with
Lady
Glencora
that
she
did
not
scruple
to
read
her
wise
lectures
,
 
telling
her
that
she
allowed
herself
to
think
too
much
of
little
things
,
 
and
too
much
also
of
some
big
things
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
regards
Mr.
Bott
,
"
said

,
"
I
think
you
should
bear
it
as
though
there
were
no
such
person
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
that
would
be
pretence
,
 
especially
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
it
would
not

;
it
would
be
the

which
all
women
should
practise
,
 
and
you
,
in
your
position
,
more
almost
than
any

woman
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Glencora
pouted
,
told
Alice
that
it
was
a

she
had
not
married
Mr.
Palliser
,

.
  
<EOS>
That

,
 
the

of
Mr.
Bott
's

to
Matching
,
that
gentleman
found
a
place
near
to
Alice
in
the

.
<EOS>
He
had
often
come
up
to
her
,
rubbing

together
,
and
saying
little
words
,
as

there
was
some
reason

positions
that
they
two
should
be

.
<EOS>
Alice
had
perceived
this
,
and
had
endeavoured
with
all
her
force
to
shake
him
off
;
but
he
was
a
man
,
who
if
he
understood
a
hint
,
never
took
it
.
<EOS>
A
cold
shoulder
was
nothing
to
him
,
if
he
wanted
to
gain
the
person
who
showed
it
him
.
<EOS>
His
code
of
perseverance
taught
him
that
it
was
a
virtue
to
overcome
cold
shoulders
.
<EOS>
The
man
or
woman
who
received
his
first
overtures
with
grace
would
probably
be
one
on
whom
it
would
be
better
that
he
should
look
down
and
waste
no
further

;
whereas
he
or
she
who
could
afford
to
treat

with

would
no

be
worth
gaining
.
<EOS>
Such
men
as
Mr.
Bott
are
ever
gracious
to
cold
shoulders
.
<EOS>
The
colder
the
shoulders
,
the
more
gracious
are
the
Mr.
Botts
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
delightful
person
is

,
Lady
Glencora
!
"
said

Bott
,
having

in

.
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
half
a
mind
to

,
or
to

Bott
.
<EOS>
But

might

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
How

is
to
-

!
"
<EOS>
She
was

as

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
You

,

.

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

Mr.

.
"
  
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>
Alice

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

ca

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

;

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
Then
she

,
and

the
Member
of

,

rather

her

.
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
constant
man
,
and
his
inner
resolve
was
simply
to
the
effect
that
he
would
try

again
.
  
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
Jeffrey
Palliser
did
think
much
of
the
difference
between
his
present
position
and
that
which
would
have
been
his
had
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
been
the
happy

of
a

up
-
stairs
with
a
boy
in

.
<EOS>
I
suppose
he
must
have
done
so
.
<EOS>
It
is
hardly
possible
that
any
man
should
not
be
alive
to
the
importance
of
such
a
chance
.
<EOS>
His
own
present
position
was
one
of
the
most
unfortunate
which
can
fall
to
the
lot
of
a
man
.
<EOS>
His
father
,
the
Duke
's
youngest

,
had
left

about
six

a
year
,
and
had
left

a
taste
for

with

of

.
<EOS>
The
propriety
of
earning
his
bread
had
never
been
put
before
him
.
<EOS>
His
father
had
been
in
Parliament
,
and
had
been
the
most
favoured
son
of
the
old
Duke
,
who
for
some
years
before
his
death
had
never
spoken
to
him
who
now
reigned
over
the
house
of
the
Pallisers
.
<EOS>
Jeffrey
's
father
had
been
brought
up
at
Matching
Priory
as
scions
of
ducal
houses
are
brought
up
,
and
on
the
old
man
's
death
had
been
possessed
of
means
sufficient
to
go
on
in
the
same
path
,
though
with
difficulty
.
<EOS>
His
brother
had
done
something
for

,
and
at
various

had
held
some
place
near
the

.
<EOS>
But
on

,
when
the

was

between

son
and

,
Jeffrey
Palliser
became
possessed
of
the
income
above
stated
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
could
live
on
it
,
 
and
as
during
the
winter
months
of
the
year
a
home
was
found
for
him
free
of
cost
,
he
could
keep
hunters
,
and
live
as
rich
men
live
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
poor
,

,
without

,
 
until
this
fine
ducal
prospect
became
opened
to

by

that

at

.
  
<EOS>
But
the

was
no

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
might
yet
have
as
many

as
Hecuba
.
<EOS>
Or
she
might
die
,
and
some

might

's

.
<EOS>
Or

might

.
<EOS>
And
,

,

cousin
was

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
his
hand
might
now

had
Lady
Glencora
possessed

-

.
<EOS>
We

must

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

.
<EOS>
Jeffrey
had

in

's

,

.

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

;
 
I

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

,

,

.

<EOS>
Jeffrey

,

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

;

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
Civilization

.
<EOS>

.

"

.

.

,

.

?

.
<EOS>

my

.
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Do

;

.
"
  
<EOS>
Jeffrey
,

cousin
with

500

,

that

,

.
<EOS>
A
seat

!
<EOS>
Yes
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
If

would
so
far
use

,

,

;

,

!
<EOS>
But

,

,
 
his

Zealand

would
be
better

.
<EOS>
And
then

went

that

yet
to

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
going
to
ride
with
us
after
lunch
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
to
him
as
he
strolled
into
the
drawing
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Jeffrey
;
"
I
'm
going
to
study
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
do
what
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
study
;
 
or
rather
I
shall
spend
to
-
day
in
sitting
down
and
considering
what
I
will
study
.
<EOS>
My
cousin
has
just
been
telling
me
that
I
ought
to
do
something
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
you
ought
,
"
said
Iphigenia
energetically
from
her

-

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
did
n't
seem
to
have
any
clear
opinion
what
it
ought
to
be
.
<EOS>
You
see
there
ca
n't

of
the

the
same

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sparkes
,
what
ought
a
young
man
like
me
to
set
about
doing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go
into
Parliament
,
I
should
say
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sparkes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
yes
;
exactly
.
<EOS>
He
had
some
notion
of
that
kind
,

,
but
he
did
n't

.
<EOS>
I
think
I
'll
try
the
City
of
London
.
<EOS>
They
've
four
there
,
and
of
course
the
chance
of
getting
in
would
thereby
be
doubled
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
that
commercial

were
generally

in
the
City
,
"
said
the
Duchess
,
taking
a

in
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Palliser
means
to
make
a
fortune
in
trade
as
a

,
"
said
Mrs.
Sparkes
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
he
meant
anything
of
the
kind
,
"
said
the
Duchess
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
I
have
got
to
do
something
,
so
I
ca
n't
go
and
ride
,
"
said
Jeffrey
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
ought
to
do
something
,
"
said
Iphigenia
from
her
desk
.
  
<EOS>
Twice
during
this
little
conversation
Lady
Glencora
had
looked
up
,
catching
Alice
's
eye
,
and
Alice
had
well
known
what
she
had
meant
.
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
"
the
glance
had
said
,
"
Plantagenet
is
beginning
to
take
an
interest
in
his
cousin
,
and
you
know
why
.
<EOS>
The
man
who
is
to
be
the
father
of
the
future

must
not

to
fritter
away

time
in

.
<EOS>
Had
I
that
cradle
up
-
stairs
Jeffrey
might
be
as
idle
as
he
pleased
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
understood
it
well
.
  
<EOS>
Of
course
Jeffrey
did
join
the
riding
party
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
a
man
like
me
to
do
who
wants
to
do
something
?
"
he
said
to
Alice
.
<EOS>
Alice
was
quite
aware
that
Lady
Glencora
had
contrived
some
little
scheme
that
Mr.
Palliser
should
be
riding
next
to

.
<EOS>
She
liked
Mr.
Palliser
,
and
therefore
had
no

;
but
she
declared
to

that
her
cousin
was
a

for

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Sparkes
says
you
ought

Parliament
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
and
the
dear
Duchess
would
perhaps

a
house
in
Belgrave
Square
.
<EOS>
I
want
to

now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
only

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
Iphy
?
<EOS>
About

?
<EOS>
But
you
see
the
more

he

the
better

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

Plantagenet
suggested

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

"
<EOS>
only

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Who

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my

I
do

.
<EOS>
In

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
For

,

ought

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
"
said
Alice
,

had

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
 
;
perhaps
that
's
too

.
<EOS>
But
the
lower
one
went
in
the

,

greater

the
number
to

,

.
<EOS>
I

something

my

,
 
not

;
so

's
ten

we

,
 
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
When

,

"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
declare
I
do
n't
think
he
could
do
anything
better
,
"
her
cousin
said
to
her
that
night
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
now
in
the
habit
of
having
Alice
with
her
in
what
she
called
her
dressing
-
room
every
evening
,
and
then
they
would
sit
till
the
small
hours
came
upon
them
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
always
burnt
the
midnight
oil
and
came
to
bed
with
the
owls
.
<EOS>
They
would
often
talk
of
him
and
his
prospects
till
Alice
had
perhaps
inspired
his
wife
with
more
of
interest
in
him
and
them
than
she
had
before
felt
.
<EOS>
And
Alice
had
managed
generally
to
drive
her
friend
away
from
those
topics
which
were
so
dangerous
,
 
those
allusions
to
her
childlessness
,
and
those
hints
that
Burgo
Fitzgerald
was
still
in
her
thoughts
.
<EOS>
And
sometimes
,
of
course
,
they
had
spoken
of
Alice
's
own
prospects
,
till
she
got
into
a
way
of
telling
her
cousin
freely
all
that
she
felt
.
<EOS>
On
such
occasions
Lady
Glencora
would
always
tell
her
that
she
had
been
right
,
 
if
she
did
not
love
the
man
.
"
<EOS>
Though
your
finger
were
put
out
for
the
ring
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
on
one
such

,
"
you
should
go
back
,
if
you
did
not
love
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
did
love
him
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
do
n't
understand
it
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
;
and
,
in
truth
,
close
as
was
their
intimacy
,
they
did
not
perfectly

each
other
.
  
<EOS>
But
on
this
occasion
they
were
speaking
of
Jeffrey
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
I
declare
I
do
n't
think
he
could
do
any
better
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
talk
such
nonsense
,
I
will
not
stay
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
why
should
it
be
nonsense
?
<EOS>
You
would
be
very
comfortable
with
your

.
<EOS>
He

one
of
the
best

.
<EOS>
It
is
clear
that
he
likes
you
;
and
then
we

so

.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
Mr.
Palliser
would
do
something
for
him

married
,
 
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
only

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why

?
<EOS>
What

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But
one
ca

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
what

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
This

,
"
said

,

;
"
that
I

,
and
that

as

.
"
  
<EOS>
As

her

she

.
<EOS>
It
was
exactly
what
Glencora
had
done
.
<EOS>
She
had
loved
a
man
and
had
separated
herself
from
him
and
had
married
another
all
within
a
month
or
two
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
first
became
red
as
fire
over
her

and

,
and
Alice
afterwards
did
the
same
as
she

up
,
as
though

in
her

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
an
unmaidenly
thing
to
do
,

,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
very
slowly
,
and
in
her
lowest

.
"
<EOS>
Nay
,
it
is
unwomanly
;
but
one
may
be
driven
.
<EOS>
One
may
be
so
driven
that
all
gentleness
of
womanhood
is
driven
out
of
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Glencora
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
propose
that
you
should

as

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Glencora
!
"
  
"
I
did
do
it
suddenly
.
<EOS>
I
know
it
.
<EOS>
I
did
it
like
a
beast
that
is
driven
as
its
owner
chooses
.
<EOS>
I
know
it
.
<EOS>
I
was
a
beast
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Alice
,
if
you
know

I

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I

,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
Glencora
,
I
have
learned
to
love
you
so

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
are
the
only
being
that
does
.
<EOS>
He
ca
n't
love
me
.
<EOS>
How
is
it
possible
?
<EOS>
You
,
 
and
perhaps
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
many
who
love
you
.
<EOS>
He
loves
you
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
loves
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
impossible
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
said
a
word
to
him
that
could
make
him
love
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
done
a
thing
for
him
that
can
make
him
love
me
.
<EOS>
The
mother
of
his
child
he
might
have
loved
,
because
of
that
.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
love
me
?
<EOS>
We
were
told
to
marry
each
other
and
did
it
.
<EOS>
When
could
he
have
learned
to
love
me
?
<EOS>
But
,
Alice
,
he
requires
no
loving
,
either
to
take
it
or
to
give
it
.
<EOS>
I
wish
it
were
so
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
said
what
she
could
to
comfort
her
,
but
her
words
were
but
of
little
avail
as
regarded
those
marriage
sorrows
.
  
<EOS>
"
Forgive
you
!
"
<EOS>
at
last
Glencora
said
.
<EOS>
"
What
have
I
to
forgive
?
<EOS>
You
do
n't
suppose
I
do
not
know
it
all
,
and
think
of
it
all
without
the
chance
of
some
stray
word
like
that
!
<EOS>
Forgive
you
!
<EOS>
I
am
so
grateful
that
you
love
me
!
<EOS>
Some
one
's
love
<EOS>
I
must
have
found
,
 
or
I
could
not
have
remained
here
.
"
   
<EOS>
Lady
Midlothian
.
 
<EOS>
A
week
or
ten
days
after
this
,
Alice
,
when
she
came
down
to
the
breakfast
-
parlour
one
morning
,
found
herself
alone
with
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
fashion
at
Matching
Priory
for
people
to
assemble
rather
late
in
the
day
.
<EOS>
The
nominal
hour
for
breakfast
was
ten
,
and
none
of
the
ladies
of
the
party
were
ever
seen
before
that
.
<EOS>
Some
of
the
gentlemen
would
breakfast
earlier
,
especially
on
hunting
mornings
;
and
on
some
occasions
the
ladies
,
when
they
came
together
,
would
find
themselves
altogether
deserted
by
their
husbands
and
brothers
.
<EOS>
On
this
day
it
was
fated
that
Mr.
Bott
alone
should
represent
the
sterner
sex
,
and
when
Alice
entered
the
room
he
was
standing
on
the
rug
with
his
back
to
the
fire
,
waiting
till
the
appearance
of
some
other
guest
should
give
him
the
sanction
necessary
for
the
commencement
of
his
morning
meal
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
when
she
saw
him
,
would
have
retreated
had
it
been
possible
,
for
she
had
learned
to
dislike
him
greatly
,
and
was
,
indeed
,
almost
afraid
of
him
;
but
she
could
not
do
so
without
making
her
flight
too
conspicuous
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
intend
to
prolong
your
stay
here
,
Miss
Vavasor
?
"
said
Mr.
Bott
,
taking
advantage
of
the
first
moment
at
which
she
looked
up
from
a
letter
which
she
was
reading
.
  
<EOS>
"
For
a
few
more
days
,
I
think
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
 
I
'm
glad
of
that
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
has
pressed
me
so
much
to
remain
till
he
goes
to
the
Duke
's
,
that
I
can
not
get
away
sooner
.
<EOS>
As
I
am
an
unmarried
man
myself
,
I
can
employ
my
time
as
well
in
one
place
as
in
another
;
 
at
this
time
of
the
year
at
least
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
find
that
very
convenient
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
is
convenient
.
<EOS>
You
see
in
my
position
,
 
Parliamentary
position
,
I
mean
,
 
I
am
obliged
,
as
a
public
man
,
to
act
in
concert
with
others
.
<EOS>
A
public
man
can
be
of
no
service
unless
he
is
prepared
to
do
that
.
<EOS>
We
must
give
and
take
,
you
know
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
Miss
Vavasor
made
no
remark
in
answer
to
this
,
Mr.
Bott
continued
 
<EOS>
"
I
always
say
to
the
men
of
my
party
,
 
<EOS>
of
course
I
regard
myself
as
belonging
to
the
extreme
Radicals
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
indeed
!
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
came
into
Parliament
on
that
understanding
;
and
I
have
never
seen
any
occasion
as
yet
to
change
any
political
opinion
that
I
have
expressed
.
<EOS>
But
I
always
say
to
the
gentlemen
with
whom
I
act
,
that
nothing
can
be
done
if
we
do
n't
give
and
take
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
saying
to
you
,
Miss
Vavasor
,
that
I
look
upon
our
friend
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
as
the
most
rising
public
man
in
the
country
.
<EOS>
I
do
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
happy
to
hear
you
say
so
,
"
said
his
victim
,
who
found
herself
driven
to
make
some
remark
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
,
as
an
extreme
Radical
,
do
not
think
I
can
serve
my
party
better
than
by
keeping
in
the
same
boat
with
him
,
as
long
as
it
will
hold
the
two
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
'll
make
a
Government
hack
of
you
,
"
a
friend
of
mine
said
to
me
the
other
day
.
"
<EOS>
And
I
'll
make
a
Manchester
school
Prime
Minister
of
him
,
"
I
replied
.
<EOS>
I
rather
think
I
know
what
I
'm
about
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
doubt
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
does
he
;
 
and
so
does
he
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
is
not
the
man
to
be
led
by
the
nose
by
any
one
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
a
fair
system
of
give
and
take
.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
get
on
in
politics
without
it
.
<EOS>
What
a
charming
woman
is
your
relative
,
Lady
Glencowrer
!
<EOS>
I
remember
well
what
you
said
to
me
the
other
evening
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
?
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
quite
agree
with
you
that
confidential
intercourse
regarding
dear
friends
should
not
be
lightly
made
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
not
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
there
are
occasions
,
Miss
Vavasor
;
there
are
occasions
when
the
ordinary
laws
by
which
we
govern
our
social
conduct
must
be
made
somewhat
elastic
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
this
one
of
them
,
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
?
<EOS>
Just
listen
to
me
for
one
moment
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Our
friend
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
I
am
proud
to
say
,
relies
much
upon
my
humble
friendship
.
<EOS>
Our
first
connection
has
,
of
course
,
been
political
;
but
it
has
extended
beyond
that
,
and
has
become
pleasantly
social
;
 
I
may
say
,
very
pleasantly
social
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
taste
Mr.
Palliser
must
have
!
"
<EOS>
Alice
thought
to
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
need
not
tell
you
that
Lady
Glencowrer
is
 
very
young
;
we
may
say
,
very
young
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Bott
,
I
will
not
talk
to
you
about
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
Alice
said
in
a
determined
voice
,
and
with
all
the
power
of
resistance
at
her
command
.
<EOS>
She
frowned
too
,
and
looked
savagely
at
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
man
of
considerable
courage
,
and
knew
how
to
bear
such
opposition
without
flinching
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
tell
you
,
Miss
Vavasor
,
that
I
speak
solely
with
a
view
to
her
domestic
happiness
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
that
she
wishes
to
have
any
such
guardian
of
her
happiness
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
if
he
wishes
it
,
Miss
Vavasor
!
<EOS>
Now
I
have
the
means
of
knowing
that
he
has
the
greatest
reliance
on
your
judgement
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hereupon
Alice
got
up
with
the
intention
of
leaving
the
room
,
but
she
was
met
at
the
door
by
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
running
from
your
breakfast
,
Miss
Vavasor
?
"
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Mrs.
Sparkes
;
I
am
running
from
Mr.
Bott
,
"
said
Alice
,
who
was
almost
beside
herself
with
anger
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Bott
,
what
is
this
?
"
said
Mrs.
Sparkes
.
<EOS>
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
,
"
laughed
Mr.
Bott
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
returned
to
the
room
,
and
Mrs.
Sparkes
immediately
saw
that
she
had
in
truth
been
running
from
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
shall
be
able
to
keep
the
peace
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
I
trust
his
offence
was
not
one
that
requires
special
punishment
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ha
,
ha
,
ha
,
"
again
laughed
Mr.
Bott
,
who
rather
liked
his
position
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
was
very
angry
with
herself
,
feeling
that
she
had
told
more
of
the
truth
to
Mrs.
Sparkes
than
she
should
have
done
,
unless
she
was
prepared
to
tell
the
whole
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
she
wanted
to
say
something
,
and
did
not
know
what
to
say
;
but
her
confusion
was
at
once
stopped
by
the
entrance
of
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Sparkes
,
good
morning
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
nobody
has
waited
breakfast
.
<EOS>
Good
morning
,
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Alice
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
said
Alice
,
going
up
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Alice
,
such
a
blow
!
"
<EOS>
But
Alice
could
see
that
her
cousin
was
not
quite
in
earnest
;
 
that
the
new
trouble
,
though
it
might
be
vexatious
,
was
no
great
calamity
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Come
here
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
;
and
they
both
went
into
an
embrasure
of
the
window
.
<EOS>
"
Now
I
shall
have
to
put
your
confidence
in
me
to
the
test
.
<EOS>
This
letter
is
from
,
 
whom
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
guess
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
From
Lady
Midlothian
!
<EOS>
and
she
's
coming
here
on
Monday
,
on
her
road
to
London
.
<EOS>
Unless
you
tell
me
that
you
are
quite
sure
this
is
as
unexpected
by
me
as
by
you
,
I
will
never
speak
to
you
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
sure
of
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
then
we
can
consult
.
<EOS>
But
first
we
'll
go
and
have
some
breakfast
.
"
<EOS>
Then
more
ladies
swarmed
into
the
room
,
 
the
Duchess
and
her
daughter
,
and
the
two
Miss
Pallisers
,
and
others
;
and
Mr.
Bott
had
his
hands
full
in
attending
,
 
or
rather
in
offering
to
attend
,
to
their
little
wants
.
  
<EOS>
The
morning
was
nearly
gone
before
Alice
and
her
cousin
had
any
further
opportunity
of
discussing
in
private
the
approach
of
Lady
Midlothian
;
but
Mr.
Palliser
had
come
in
among
them
,
and
had
been
told
of
the
good
thing
which
was
in
store
for
him
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be
delighted
to
see
Lady
Midlothian
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
there
is
somebody
here
who
will
not
be
at
all
delighted
to
see
her
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
to
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
there
,
indeed
?
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
Who
is
that
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Her
most
undutiful
cousin
,
Alice
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
But
,
Alice
,
Mr.
Palliser
knows
nothing
about
it
,
and
it
is
too
long
to
explain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
extremely
sorry
 
<EOS>
"
began
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
assure
you
it
does
not
signify
in
the
least
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
only
be
taking
me
away
three
days
earlier
.
"
  
<EOS>
Upon
hearing
this
Mr.
Palliser
looked
very
serious
.
<EOS>
What
quarrel
could
Miss
Vavasor
have
had
with
Lady
Midlothian
which
should
make
it
impossible
for
them
to
be
visitors
at
the
same
house
?
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
do
no
such
thing
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
to
say
that
you
are
coward
enough
to
run
away
from
her
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
,
Miss
Vavasor
,
that
we
can
hardly
bid
her
not
come
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
In
answer
to
this
,
Alice
protested
that
she
would
not
for
worlds
have
been
the
means
of
keeping
Lady
Midlothian
away
from
Matching
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
tell
you
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
that
I
have
never
seen
Lady
Midlothian
,
though
she
is
my
far
-
away
cousin
.
<EOS>
Nor
have
I
ever
quarrelled
with
her
.
<EOS>
But
she
has
given
me
advice
by
letter
,
and
I
did
not
answer
her
because
I
thought
she
had
no
business
to
interfere
.
<EOS>
I
shall
go
away
,
not
because
I
am
afraid
of
her
,
but
because
,
after
what
has
passed
,
our
meeting
would
be
unpleasant
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
could
tell
her
that
Miss
Vavasor
is
here
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
then
she
need
not
come
unless
she
pleased
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
matter
was
so
managed
at
last
that
Alice
found
herself
unable
to
leave
Matching
without
making
more
of
Lady
Midlothian
's
coming
than
it
was
worth
.
<EOS>
It
would
undoubtedly
be
very
disagreeable
,
 
this
unexpected
meeting
with
her
relative
;
but
,
as
Lady
Glencora
said
,
Lady
Midlothian
would
not
eat
her
.
<EOS>
In
truth
,
she
felt
ashamed
of
herself
in
that
she
was
afraid
of
her
relative
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
she
was
afraid
of
her
.
<EOS>
So
much
she
was
forced
to
admit
to
herself
.
<EOS>
But
she
resolved
at
last
that
she
would
not
let
her
drive
her
out
of
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr.
Bott
an
admirer
of
your
cousin
?
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Sparkes
said
that
evening
to
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
distant
one
I
should
think
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
Goodness
gracious
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
an
old
lady
who
had
been
rather
awed
by
Alice
's
intimacy
and
cousinship
with
Lady
Glencora
;
"
it
's
the
very
last
thing
I
should
have
dreamt
of
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
did
n't
dream
it
,
first
or
last
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sparkes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
ask
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
suppose
that
I
am
asking
whether
Miss
Vavasor
is
an
admirer
of
his
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sparkes
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
suspicion
of
that
nature
.
<EOS>
I
rather
think
that
when
he
plays
Bacchus
she
plays
Ariadne
,
with
full
intention
of
flying
from
him
in
earnest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Mr.
Bott
inclined
to
play
Bacchus
?
"
asked
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
rather
thought
he
was
this
morning
.
<EOS>
If
you
observe
,
he
has
something
of
a
godlike
and
triumphant
air
about
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
his
godship
will
triumph
there
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
think
she
would
be
throwing
herself
very
much
away
,
"
said
the
old
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Vavasor
is
not
at
all
disposed
to
do
that
,
"
said
Mrs.
Sparkes
.
<EOS>
Then
that
conversation
was
allowed
to
drop
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
following
Monday
,
Lady
Midlothian
arrived
.
<EOS>
The
carriage
was
sent
to
meet
her
at
the
station
about
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
,
and
Alice
had
to
choose
whether
she
would
undergo
her
first
introduction
immediately
on
her
relative
's
arrival
,
or
whether
she
would
keep
herself
out
of
the
way
till
she
should
meet
her
in
the
drawing
-
room
before
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
receive
her
when
she
comes
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
"
and
of
course
will
tell
her
that
you
are
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
that
will
be
best
;
and
 
;
dear
me
,
I
declare
I
do
n't
know
how
to
manage
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
bring
her
to
you
in
my
room
if
you
like
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
that
would
be
too
solemn
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
That
would
make
her
understand
that
I
thought
a
great
deal
about
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
we
'll
let
things
take
their
chance
,
and
you
shall
come
across
her
just
as
you
would
any
other
stranger
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
settled
at
last
that
this
would
be
the
better
course
,
but
that
Lady
Midlothian
was
to
be
informed
of
Alice
's
presence
at
the
Priory
as
soon
as
she
should
arrive
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
was
in
her
own
room
when
the
carriage
in
which
sat
the
unwelcome
old
lady
was
driven
up
to
the
hall
-
door
.
<EOS>
She
heard
the
wheels
plainly
,
and
knew
well
that
her
enemy
was
within
the
house
.
<EOS>
She
had
striven
hard
all
the
morning
to
make
herself
feel
indifferent
to
this
arrival
,
but
had
not
succeeded
;
and
was
angry
with
herself
at
finding
that
she
sat
up
-
stairs
with
an
anxious
heart
,
because
she
knew
that
her
cousin
was
in
the
room
down
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
What
was
Lady
Midlothian
to
her
that
she
should
be
afraid
of
her
?
<EOS>
And
yet
she
was
very
much
afraid
of
Lady
Midlothian
.
<EOS>
She
questioned
herself
on
the
subject
over
and
over
again
,
and
found
herself
bound
to
admit
that
such
was
the
fact
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
about
five
o'clock
,
having
reasoned
much
with
herself
,
and
rebuked
herself
for
her
own
timidity
,
she
descended
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
 
Lady
Glencora
having
promised
that
she
would
at
that
hour
be
there
,
 
and
on
opening
the
door
became
immediately
conscious
that
she
was
in
the
presence
of
her
august
relative
.
<EOS>
There
sat
Lady
Midlothian
in
a
great
chair
opposite
the
fire
,
and
Lady
Glencora
sat
near
to
her
on
a
stool
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
Miss
Pallisers
was
reading
in
a
further
part
of
the
room
,
and
there
was
no
one
else
present
in
the
chamber
.
  
<EOS>
The
Countess
of
Midlothian
was
a
very
little
woman
,
between
sixty
and
seventy
years
of
age
,
who
must
have
been
very
pretty
in
her
youth
.
<EOS>
At
present
she
made
no
pretension
either
to
youth
or
beauty
,
 
as
some
ladies
above
sixty
will
still
do
,
 
but
sat
confessedly
an
old
woman
in
all
her
external
relations
.
<EOS>
She
wore
a
round
bonnet
which
came
much
over
her
face
,
 
being
accustomed
to
continue
the
use
of
her
bonnet
till
dinner
time
when
once
she
had
been
forced
by
circumstances
to
put
it
on
.
<EOS>
She
wore
a
short
cloak
which
fitted
close
to
her
person
,
and
,
though
she
occupied
a
great
arm
-
chair
,
sat
perfectly
upright
,
looking
at
the
fire
.
<EOS>
Very
small
she
was
,
but
she
carried
in
her
grey
eyes
and
sharp
-
cut
features
a
certain
look
of
importance
which
saved
her
from
being
considered
as
small
in
importance
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
as
soon
as
she
saw
her
,
knew
that
she
was
a
lady
over
whom
no
easy
victory
could
be
obtained
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
is
Alice
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
rising
as
her
cousin
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
let
me
introduce
you
to
Lady
Midlothian
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
,
as
she
came
forward
,
was
able
to
assume
an
easy
demeanour
,
even
though
her
heart
within
was
failing
her
.
<EOS>
She
put
out
her
hand
,
leaving
it
to
the
elder
lady
to
speak
the
first
words
of
greeting
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
at
last
to
be
able
to
make
your
acquaintance
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Lady
Midlothian
;
"
very
glad
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
still
Alice
did
not
speak
.
"
<EOS>
Your
aunt
,
Lady
Macleod
,
is
one
of
my
oldest
friends
,
and
I
have
heard
her
speak
of
you
very
often
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
Lady
Macleod
has
often
spoken
to
me
of
your
ladyship
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
we
know
each
other
's
names
,
"
said
the
Countess
;
"
and
it
will
be
well
that
we
should
be
acquainted
with
each
other
's
persons
.
<EOS>
I
am
becoming
an
old
woman
,
and
if
I
did
not
learn
to
know
you
now
,
or
very
shortly
,
I
might
never
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
could
not
help
thinking
that
even
under
those
circumstances
neither
might
have
had
,
so
far
as
that
was
concerned
,
much
cause
of
sorrow
,
but
she
did
not
say
so
.
<EOS>
She
was
thinking
altogether
of
Lady
Midlothian
's
letter
to
her
,
and
trying
to
calculate
whether
or
no
it
would
be
well
for
her
to
rush
away
at
once
to
the
subject
.
<EOS>
That
Lady
Midlothian
would
mention
the
letter
,
Alice
felt
well
assured
;
and
when
could
it
be
better
mentioned
than
now
,
in
Glencora
's
presence
,
 
when
no
other
person
was
near
them
to
listen
to
her
?
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
kind
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
wish
to
be
so
,
"
said
Lady
Midlothian
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Blood
is
thicker
than
water
,
my
dear
;
and
I
know
no
earthly
ties
that
can
bind
people
together
if
those
of
family
connection
will
not
do
so
.
<EOS>
Your
mother
,
when
she
and
I
were
young
,
was
my
dearest
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
knew
my
mother
,
"
said
Alice
,
 
feeling
,
however
,
as
she
spoke
,
that
the
strength
of
her
resistance
to
the
old
woman
was
beginning
to
give
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
,
you
never
did
;
and
that
is
to
my
thinking
another
reason
why
they
who
loved
her
should
love
you
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Macleod
is
your
nearest
relative
,
 
on
your
mother
's
side
,
I
mean
,
 
and
she
has
done
her
duty
by
you
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
she
has
,
Lady
Midlothian
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
,
and
others
,
therefore
,
have
been
the
less
called
upon
to
interfere
.
<EOS>
I
only
say
this
,
my
dear
,
in
my
own
vindication
,
 
feeling
,
perhaps
,
that
my
conduct
needs
some
excuse
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
Alice
does
not
think
that
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
what
I
think
rather
than
what
Alice
thinks
that
concerns
my
own
shortcomings
,
"
said
Lady
Midlothian
,
with
a
smile
which
was
intended
to
be
pleasant
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
wished
to
make
up
for
former
lost
opportunities
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
knew
that
she
was
about
to
refer
to
her
letter
,
and
trembled
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
anxious
now
to
be
reckoned
one
of
Alice
Vavasor
's
friends
,
if
she
will
allow
me
to
become
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
only
be
too
proud
,
 
if
 
"
  
"
If
what
,
my
dear
?
"
said
the
old
lady
.
<EOS>
I
believe
that
she
meant
to
be
gracious
,
but
there
was
something
in
her
manner
,
or
,
perhaps
,
rather
in
her
voice
,
so
repellant
,
that
Alice
felt
that
they
could
hardly
become
true
friends
.
<EOS>
"
If
what
,
my
dear
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
means
 
"
began
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
Alice
say
what
she
means
herself
,
"
said
Lady
Midlothian
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
know
how
to
say
what
I
do
mean
,
"
said
Alice
,
whose
spirit
within
her
was
rising
higher
as
the
occasion
for
using
it
came
upon
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
assured
that
you
and
I
,
Lady
Midlothian
,
differ
very
much
as
to
a
certain
matter
;
and
as
it
is
one
in
which
I
must
be
guided
by
my
own
opinion
,
and
not
that
of
any
other
person
,
<EOS>
perhaps
 
"
  
"
You
mean
about
Mr.
Grey
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Alice
;
"
I
mean
about
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
so
much
about
that
matter
,
and
your
happiness
as
therein
concerned
,
that
when
I
heard
that
you
were
here
I
was
determined
to
take
Matching
in
my
way
to
London
,
so
that
I
might
have
an
opportunity
of
speaking
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
knew
that
Alice
was
here
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
did
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
have
heard
all
the
history
,
Glencora
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
forced
to
acknowledge
that
she
had
heard
the
history
,
 
"
the
history
"
being
poor
Alice
's
treatment
of
Mr.
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
you
think
of
it
?
"
<EOS>
Both
Alice
and
her
hostess
looked
round
to
the
further
end
of
the
room
in
which
Miss
Palliser
was
reading
,
intending
thus
to
indicate
that
the
lady
knew
as
yet
none
of
the
circumstances
,
and
that
there
could
be
no
good
reason
why
she
should
be
instructed
in
them
at
this
moment
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
another
time
and
another
place
may
be
better
,
"
said
Lady
Midlothian
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
must
go
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
,
 
indeed
<EOS>
,
I
thought
of
going
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Lady
Midlothian
!
"
exclaimed
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
regard
this
as
merely
a
passing
visit
,
made
upon
business
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
was
saying
,
when
shall
I
get
an
opportunity
of
speaking
to
Alice
where
we
need
not
be
interrupted
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
suggested
her
room
up
-
stairs
,
and
offered
the
use
of
it
then
,
or
on
that
night
when
the
world
should
be
about
to
go
to
bed
.
<EOS>
But
the
idea
of
this
premeditated
lecture
was
terrible
to
Alice
,
and
she
determined
that
she
would
not
endure
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Midlothian
,
it
would
really
be
of
no
use
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Of
no
use
,
my
dear
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
did
get
your
letter
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
as
you
have
not
answered
it
,
I
have
come
all
this
way
to
see
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
so
sorry
if
I
give
offence
,
but
it
is
a
subject
which
I
can
not
bring
myself
to
discuss
"
 
<EOS>
she
was
going
to
say
with
a
stranger
,
but
she
was
able
to
check
herself
before
the
offensive
word
was
uttered
,
 
"
which
I
can
not
bring
myself
to
discuss
with
any
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
do
n't
mean
to
say
that
you
wo
n't
see
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
talk
upon
that
matter
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
do
it
even
with
Lady
Macleod
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Lady
Midlothian
,
and
<EOS>
her
sharp
grey
eyes
now
began
to
kindle
with
anger
;
"
and
therefore
it
is
so
very
necessary
that
other
friends
should
interfere
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
will
endure
no
interference
,
"
said
Alice
,
"
either
from
persons
who
are
friends
or
who
are
not
friends
.
"
<EOS>
And
as
she
spoke
she
rose
from
her
chair
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
forgive
me
,
Lady
Midlothian
,
if
I
say
that
I
can
have
no
conversation
with
you
on
this
matter
.
<EOS>
"
Then
she
walked
out
of
the
room
,
leaving
the
Countess
and
Lady
Glencora
together
.
<EOS>
As
she
went
Miss
Palliser
lifted
her
eyes
from
her
book
,
and
knew
that
there
had
been
a
quarrel
,
but
I
doubt
if
she
had
heard
any
of
the
words
which
had
been
spoken
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
most
self
-
willed
young
woman
I
ever
met
in
my
life
,
"
said
Lady
Midlothian
,
as
soon
as
Alice
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
knew
very
well
how
it
would
be
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
quite
frightful
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
She
has
been
engaged
,
with
the
consent
of
all
her
friends
,
to
this
young
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
all
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
must
think
she
is
very
wrong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
quite
understand
her
,
but
I
suppose
she
fears
they
would
not
be
happy
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Understand
her
!
<EOS>
I
should
think
not
;
nobody
can
understand
her
.
<EOS>
A
young
woman
to
become
engaged
to
a
gentleman
in
that
way
,
 
before
all
the
world
,
as
one
may
say
;
 
to
go
to
his
house
,
as
I
am
told
,
and
talk
to
the
servants
,
and
give
orders
about
the
furniture
and
then
turn
round
and
simply
say
that
she
has
changed
her
mind
!
<EOS>
She
has
n't
given
the
slightest
reason
to
my
knowledge
.
"
<EOS>
And
Lady
Midlothian
,
as
she
insisted
on
the
absolute
iniquity
of
Alice
's
proceedings
,
almost
startled
Lady
Glencora
by
the
eagerness
of
her
countenance
.
<EOS>
Lady
Midlothian
had
been
one
of
those
who
,
even
now
not
quite
two
years
ago
,
had
assisted
in
obtaining
the
submission
of
Lady
Glencora
herself
.
<EOS>
Lady
Midlothian
seemed
on
the
present
occasion
to
remember
nothing
of
this
,
but
Lady
Glencora
remembered
it
very
exactly
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
give
it
up
,
"
continued
Lady
Midlothian
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
the
greatest
possible
objection
to
her
father
,
who
contrived
to
connect
himself
with
our
family
in
a
most
shameful
manner
,
without
the
slightest
encouragement
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
I
have
spoken
to
him
since
,
but
I
shall
see
him
now
and
tell
him
my
opinion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
held
her
ground
,
and
avoided
all
further
conversation
with
Lady
Midlothian
.
<EOS>
A
message
came
to
her
through
Lady
Glencora
imploring
her
to
give
way
,
but
she
was
quite
firm
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
to
you
,
"
Lady
Midlothian
said
to
her
as
she
went
.
"
<EOS>
Even
yet
I
hope
that
things
may
go
right
,
and
if
so
you
will
find
that
I
can
forget
and
forgive
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
perseverance
merits
success
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
to
Alice
,
"
she
ought
to
succeed
.
"
<EOS>
"
But
she
wo
n't
succeed
,
"
said
Alice
.
   
<EOS>
The
Priory
Ruins
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Midlothian
went
away
on
her
road
to
London
on
the
Wednesday
morning
,
and
Alice
was
to
follow
her
on
the
next
day
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
December
,
and
the
weather
was
very
clear
and
frosty
,
but
at
night
there
was
bright
moonlight
.
<EOS>
On
this
special
night
the
moon
would
be
full
,
and
Lady
Glencora
had
declared
that
she
and
Alice
would
go
out
amidst
the
ruins
.
<EOS>
It
was
no
secret
engagement
,
having
been
canvassed
in
public
,
and
having
been
met
with
considerable
discouragement
by
some
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
remarked
that
the
night
air
would
be
very
cold
,
and
Mr.
Bott
had
suggested
all
manner
of
evil
consequences
.
<EOS>
Had
Mr.
Palliser
alone
objected
,
Lady
Glencora
might
have
given
way
,
but
Mr.
Bott
's
word
riveted
her
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
not
going
to
be
frightened
,
"
Lady
Glencora
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
People
do
not
generally
walk
out
at
night
in
December
,
"
Mr.
Palliser
observed
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
just
the
reason
why
we
want
to
do
it
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
But
we
shall
wrap
ourselves
up
,
and
nobody
need
be
afraid
.
<EOS>
Jeffrey
,
we
shall
expect
you
to
stand
sentinel
at
the
old
gate
,
and
guard
us
from
the
ghosts
.
"
  
<EOS>
Jeffrey
Palliser
,
bargaining
that
he
might
be
allowed
a
cigar
,
promised
that
he
would
do
as
he
was
bidden
.
  
<EOS>
The
party
at
Matching
Priory
had
by
this
time
become
very
small
.
<EOS>
There
were
indeed
no
guests
left
,
not
counting
those
of
the
Palliser
family
,
excepting
Miss
Vavasor
,
Mr.
Bott
,
and
an
old
lady
who
had
been
a
great
friend
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
mother
.
<EOS>
It
was
past
ten
in
the
evening
when
Lady
Glencora
declared
that
the
time
had
arrived
for
them
to
carry
out
their
purpose
.
<EOS>
She
invited
the
two
Miss
Pallisers
to
join
her
,
but
they
declined
,
urging
their
fear
of
the
night
air
,
and
showing
by
their
manner
that
they
thought
the
proposition
a
very
imprudent
one
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
offered
to
accompany
them
,
but
Lady
Glencora
declined
his
attendance
very
stoutly
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
indeed
,
Mr.
Bott
;
you
were
one
of
those
who
preached
a
sermon
against
my
dissipation
in
the
morning
,
and
I
'm
not
going
to
allow
you
to
join
it
,
now
the
time
for
its
enjoyment
has
come
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Lady
Glencora
,
if
I
were
you
,
indeed
I
would
n't
,
"
said
the
old
lady
,
looking
round
towards
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mrs.
Marsham
,
if
you
were
me
,
indeed
you
would
,
"
and
Lady
Glencora
also
looked
at
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
a
foolish
thing
to
do
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
sternly
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
forbid
it
,
of
course
we
wo
n't
go
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
Forbid
it
:
 
<EOS>
no
;
I
shall
not
forbid
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Allons
donc
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
She
and
Alice
were
already
muffled
in
cloaks
and
thick
shawls
,
and
Alice
now
followed
her
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
door
which
opened
from
the
billiard
-
room
out
on
to
the
grand
terrace
,
which
ran
in
front
of
the
house
,
and
here
they
found
Jeffrey
Palliser
already
armed
with
his
cigar
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
to
tell
the
truth
,
would
much
have
preferred
to
abandon
the
expedition
,
but
she
had
felt
that
it
would
be
cowardly
in
her
to
desert
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
There
had
not
arisen
any
very
close
intimacy
between
her
and
Mr.
Palliser
,
but
she
entertained
a
certain
feeling
that
Mr.
Palliser
trusted
her
,
and
liked
her
to
be
with
his
wife
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
wished
to
justify
this
supposed
confidence
,
and
was
almost
sure
that
Mr.
Palliser
expected
her
to
do
so
in
this
instance
.
<EOS>
She
did
say
a
word
or
two
to
her
cousin
up
-
stairs
,
urging
that
perhaps
her
husband
would
not
like
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
say
so
plainly
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
"
and
I
'll
give
it
up
instantly
.
<EOS>
But
I
'm
not
going
to
be
lectured
out
of
my
purposes
<EOS>
secondhand
by
Mr.
Bott
or
old
Mother
Marsham
.
<EOS>
I
understand
all
these
people
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
throw
me
over
,
Alice
,
I
'll
never
forgive
you
,
"
Lady
Glencora
added
.
  
<EOS>
After
this
Alice
resolved
that
she
would
not
throw
her
friend
over
.
<EOS>
She
was
afraid
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
also
becoming
a
little
afraid
of
her
friend
,
 
<EOS>
afraid
that
she
would
be
driven
some
day
either
to
throw
her
over
,
or
to
say
words
to
her
that
would
be
very
unpalatable
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Jeffrey
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
as
they
walked
abreast
along
the
broad
terrace
towards
the
ruins
,
"
when
we
get
under
the
old
gateway
you
must
let
me
and
Alice
go
round
the
dormitory
and
the
chapel
alone
.
<EOS>
Then
we
'll
come
back
by
the
cloisters
,
and
we
'll
take
another
turn
outside
with
you
.
<EOS>
The
outside
is
the
finest
by
this
light
,
 
only
I
want
to
show
Alice
something
by
ourselves
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
not
afraid
,
I
know
,
and
if
Miss
Vavasor
is
not
 
"
  
"
Miss
Vavasor
,
 
who
,
I
think
,
would
have
allowed
you
to
call
her
by
her
other
name
on
such
an
occasion
as
this
,
 
is
never
afraid
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
,
how
dare
you
say
so
?
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
I
really
think
we
had
better
go
back
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
felt
herself
to
be
very
angry
with
her
cousin
.
<EOS>
She
almost
began
to
fear
that
she
had
mistaken
her
,
and
had
thought
better
of
her
than
she
had
deserved
.
<EOS>
What
she
had
now
said
struck
Alice
as
being
vulgar
,
 
as
being
premeditated
vulgarity
,
and
her
annoyance
was
excessive
.
<EOS>
Of
course
Mr.
Palliser
would
think
that
she
was
a
consenting
party
to
the
proposition
made
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
back
!
"
said
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
We
'll
go
on
,
and
leave
him
here
.
<EOS>
Then
he
can
call
nobody
anything
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
angry
with
me
,
"
she
said
,
as
soon
as
they
were
out
of
hearing
.
<EOS>
"
The
truth
is
this
;
 
if
you
choose
to
have
him
for
your
husband
,
you
may
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
if
I
do
not
choose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
there
can
be
no
harm
done
,
and
I
will
tell
him
so
.
<EOS>
But
,
Alice
,
 
think
of
this
.
<EOS>
Whom
will
you
meet
that
would
suit
you
better
?
<EOS>
And
you
need
not
decide
now
.
<EOS>
You
need
not
say
a
word
,
but
leave
me
to
tell
him
,
that
if
it
is
to
be
thought
of
at
all
,
it
can
not
be
thought
of
till
he
meets
you
in
London
.
<EOS>
Trust
me
,
you
will
be
safe
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
tell
him
nothing
of
the
kind
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
you
to
be
joking
throughout
,
and
I
think
the
joke
is
a
bad
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
there
you
wrong
me
.
<EOS>
Indeed
I
am
not
joking
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
in
what
I
am
saying
I
am
telling
you
the
simple
truth
.
<EOS>
He
has
said
enough
to
me
to
justify
me
in
saying
so
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
think
of
it
all
.
<EOS>
It
would
reconcile
me
to
much
,
and
it
would
be
something
to
be
the
mother
of
the
future
Duke
of
Omnium
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
me
it
would
be
nothing
,
"
said
Alice
;
"
less
than
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
mean
to
say
that
the
temptation
is
one
so
easily
resisted
that
it
acts
in
the
other
way
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
say
anything
more
about
it
,
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
wish
it
,
I
will
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I
do
not
wish
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
I
ever
saw
moonlight
so
bright
as
this
.
<EOS>
Look
at
the
lines
of
that
window
against
the
light
.
<EOS>
They
are
clearer
than
you
ever
see
them
in
the
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
now
standing
just
within
the
gateway
of
the
old
cruciform
chapel
,
having
entered
the
transept
from
a
ruined
passage
which
was
supposed
to
have
connected
the
church
with
the
dormitory
.
<EOS>
The
church
was
altogether
roofless
,
but
the
entire
walls
were
standing
.
<EOS>
The
small
clerestory
windows
of
the
nave
were
perfect
,
and
the
large
windows
of
the
two
transepts
and
of
the
west
end
were
nearly
so
.
<EOS>
Of
the
opposite
window
,
which
had
formed
the
back
of
the
choir
,
very
little
remained
.
<EOS>
The
top
of
it
,
with
all
its
tracery
,
was
gone
,
and
three
broken
upright
mullions
of
uneven
heights
alone
remained
.
<EOS>
This
was
all
that
remained
of
the
old
window
,
but
a
transom
or
cross
-
bar
of
stone
had
been
added
to
protect
the
carved
stone
-
work
of
the
sides
,
and
save
the
form
of
the
aperture
from
further
ruin
.
<EOS>
That
this
transom
was
modern
was
to
be
seen
from
the
magnificent
height
and
light
grace
of
the
workmanship
in
the
other
windows
,
in
which
the
long
slender
mullions
rose
from
the
lower
stage
or
foundation
of
the
whole
up
into
the
middle
tracery
of
the
arch
without
protection
or
support
,
and
then
lost
themselves
among
the
curves
,
not
running
up
into
the
roof
or
soffit
,
and
there
holding
on
as
though
unable
to
stand
alone
.
<EOS>
Such
weakness
as
that
had
not
as
yet
shown
itself
in
English
church
architecture
when
Matching
Priory
was
built
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
beautiful
!
"
said
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
love
it
so
!
<EOS>
And
there
is
a
peculiar
feeling
of
cold
about
the
chill
of
the
moon
,
different
from
any
other
cold
.
<EOS>
It
makes
you
wrap
yourself
up
tight
,
but
it
does
not
make
your
teeth
chatter
;
and
it
seems
to
go
into
your
senses
rather
than
into
your
bones
.
<EOS>
But
I
suppose
that
's
nonsense
,
"
she
added
,
after
a
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
more
so
than
what
people
are
supposed
to
talk
by
moonlight
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
unkind
.
<EOS>
I
'd
like
what
I
say
on
such
an
occasion
to
be
more
poetical
or
else
more
nonsensical
than
what
other
people
say
under
the
same
circumstances
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
'll
tell
you
why
I
always
think
of
you
when
I
come
here
by
moonlight
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
suppose
you
do
n't
often
come
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
;
that
is
to
say
,
I
did
come
very
often
when
we
had
the
full
moon
in
August
.
<EOS>
The
weather
was
n't
like
this
,
and
I
used
to
run
out
through
the
open
windows
and
nobody
knew
where
I
was
gone
.
<EOS>
I
made
him
come
once
,
but
he
did
n't
seem
to
care
about
it
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
that
part
of
the
refectory
wall
was
falling
;
so
he
looked
at
that
,
and
had
a
mason
sent
the
next
day
.
<EOS>
If
anything
is
out
of
order
he
has
it
put
to
rights
at
once
.
<EOS>
There
would
have
been
no
ruins
if
all
the
Pallisers
had
been
like
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
better
for
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I
say
no
.
<EOS>
Things
may
live
too
long
.
<EOS>
But
now
I
'm
going
to
tell
you
.
<EOS>
Do
you
remember
that
night
I
brought
you
home
from
the
play
to
Queen
Anne
Street
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
do
,
 
very
well
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
occasion
to
remember
it
,
for
it
had
been
in
the
carriage
on
that
evening
that
she
had
positively
refused
to
give
any
aid
to
her
cousin
in
that
matter
relating
to
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
do
you
remember
how
the
moon
shone
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
think
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
do
.
<EOS>
As
we
came
round
the
corner
out
of
Cavendish
Square
<EOS>
he
was
standing
there
,
 
and
a
friend
of
yours
was
standing
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
friend
of
mine
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
that
;
it
does
not
matter
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
my
cousin
George
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
mean
your
cousin
;
and
oh
,
Alice
!
<EOS>
dear
Alice
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
why
I
should
love
you
,
for
if
you
had
not
been
hardhearted
that
night
,
 
<EOS>
stony
cruel
in
your
hard
propriety
,
I
should
have
gone
with
him
then
,
and
all
this
icy
coldness
would
have
been
prevented
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
standing
quite
close
to
Alice
,
and
as
she
spake
she
shook
with
shivering
and
wrapped
her
furs
closer
and
still
closer
about
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
cold
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
We
had
better
go
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
am
not
cold
,
 
not
in
that
way
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
go
in
yet
.
<EOS>
Jeffrey
will
come
to
us
directly
.
<EOS>
Yes
;
 
we
should
have
escaped
that
night
if
you
would
have
allowed
him
to
come
into
your
house
.
<EOS>
Ah
,
well
!
<EOS>
we
did

,
and
there
's
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
Glencora
,
 
you
can
not
regret
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
regret
it
!
<EOS>
Alice
,
where
can
your
heart
be
?
<EOS>
Or
have
you
a
heart
?
<EOS>
Not
regret
it
!
<EOS>
I
would
give
everything
I
have
in
the
world
to
have
been
true
to
him
.
<EOS>
They
told
me
that
he
would
spend
my
money
.
<EOS>
Though
he
should
have
spent
every
farthing
of
it
,
I
regret
it
;
though
he
should
have
made
me
a
beggar
,
I
regret
it
.
<EOS>
They
told
me
that
he
would
ill
-
use
me
,
and
desert
me
,
 
perhaps
beat
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
believe
it
;
but
even
though
that
should
have
been
so
,
I
regret
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
better
to
have
a
false
husband
than
to
be
a
false
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
,
do
not
speak
like
that
.
<EOS>
Do
not
try
to
make
me
think
that
anything
could
tempt
you
to
be
false
to
your
vows
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tempt
me
to
be
false
!
<EOS>
Why
,
child
,
it
has
been
all
false
throughout
.
<EOS>
I
never
loved
him
.
<EOS>
How
can
you
talk
in
that
way
,
when
you
know
that
I
never
loved
him
?
<EOS>
They
browbeat
me
and
frightened
me
till
I
did
as
I
was
told
;
 
and
now
;
 
what
am
I
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
his
honest
wife
.
<EOS>
Glencora
,
listen
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
Alice
took
hold
of
her
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
said
,
"
no
;
I
am
not
honest
.
<EOS>
By
law
I
am
his
wife
;
but
the
laws
are
liars
!
<EOS>
I
am
not
his
wife
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
the
thing
that
I
am
.
<EOS>
When
I
went
to
him
at
the
altar
,
I
knew
that
I
did
not
love
the
man
that
was
to

my

.
<EOS>
But
him
,
 
Burgo
,
 
I
love
him
with
all

and

.
<EOS>
I
could
stoop
at
his
feet
and
clean
his

for

,
and
think
it
no
disgrace
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Cora
,
my
friend
,
do
not
say
such
words
as
those
!
<EOS>
Remember
what
you
owe
your
husband
and
yourself
,
and
come
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
know
what
I
owe
him
,
and
I
will
pay
it
him
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
if
I
had
a
child
I
think
I
would
be
true
to
him
.
<EOS>
Think
!
<EOS>
I
know
I
would
;
 
though
I
had
no
hour
of
happiness
left
to
me
in
my

.
<EOS>
But
what
now
is
the
only

that
I
can
do
?
<EOS>
Why
,
leave
him
;
 
so
leave
him
that
he
may
have
another
wife
and
be
the
father
of
a
child
.
<EOS>
What
injury
shall
I
do
him
by
leaving
him
?
<EOS>
He
does
not
love
me
;
you
know
yourself
that
he
does
not
love
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
he
does
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
that
is
untrue
.
<EOS>
He
does
not
;
and
you
have
seen
clearly
that
it

so
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
he
can

no

.
<EOS>
But
another
woman
would
give
him
a

,
and
he
would
be

.
<EOS>
I
tell

that
every

every

,
 
every

every
day
and
of
every
night
,
 
I
am
thinking
of
the
man
I
love
.
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
else
to
think

.
<EOS>
I
have
no
occupation
,
 
no
friends
,
 
no
one
to

.
<EOS>
But
I
am
always
talking
to
Burgo
in

;
and
he
listens
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
dream
that
his
arm
is
round
me
 
"
  
"
Oh
,
Glencora
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
 
<EOS>
Do
you
begrudge
me
that
I
should
tell
you
the

?
<EOS>
You
have

that

would

my

,

my

.
<EOS>
And
now
,
 
this
is

I

.
 
<EOS>
Immediately
after
Christmas
,
we
are
to

to
Monkshade
,
and
he
will
be
there
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
is
his
aunt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
go
.
<EOS>
No
power
should
take
you
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is

said
,
child
;
but
all

I
must
go
.
<EOS>
I
told
Mr.
Palliser
that
he
would
be
there
,
and
he
said

did
not

.
<EOS>
He
actually
said

did
not

.
<EOS>
I

;
 
whether

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
<EOS>
Glencora
,
"
he

,
 
and

,
and

,
 
<EOS>
"
This

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Could
I

that

?
<EOS>
Could

's

?
<EOS>
You
are

,

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,

.
<EOS>
I

I

,
and
what
I
am

.
<EOS>
I
loathe

,

I

.
<EOS>
I

have

man

,
to
his
very

,
and
loved

!
 
<EOS>
ay
,
even
though
he
had
ill
-
treated

,
 
if
I

to
choose
a
husband

.
<EOS>
Burgo
would
have
spent
my

,
 
all

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
But

that
man
 
!
<EOS>
Alice
you
are
very
wise
.
<EOS>
What
am
I
to

?
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
no
doubt
as
to
what
her
cousin
should
do
.
<EOS>
She
should
be
true
to
her
marriage
-
vow
,
whether
that

when

were
true
or
false
.
<EOS>
She
should
be
true

it
as
far
as
truth
would
now
carry
her
.
<EOS>
And
in
order
that
she
might
be
true
,
she
should

as
much
as
might

to

to
spare

the

to
Monkshade
.
<EOS>
All
that
she
said
to
Lady
Glencora
,
as
they
walked
slowly
across
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Glencora
was
more
occupied
with
her
own

than
with
her
friend
's
advice
.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
Jeffrey
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
What
an
unconscionable
time
we
have
kept
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
mention
it
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
And
I
should
n't
have
come
to
you
now
,
only
that
I
thought
I
should
find
you
both
freezing
into
marble
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
not
such
cold
-
blooded
creatures
as
that
,
 
are
we
,
Alice
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
And
now
we
'll
go
round
the
outside
;
only
we
must
not
stay
long
,
or
we
shall
frighten
those
two
delicious
old
duennas
,
Mrs.
Marsham
and
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
These
last
words
were
said
as
it
were
in
a
whisper
to
Alice
;
but
they
were
so
whispered
that
there
was
no
real
attempt
to
keep
them
from
the
ears
of
Mr.
Jeffrey
Palliser
.
<EOS>
Glencora
,
Alice
thought
,
should
not
have
allowed
the
word
duenna
to
have
passed
her
lips
in
speaking
to
any
one
;
but
,
above
all
,
she
should
not
have
done
so
in
the
hearing
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
cousin
.
  
<EOS>
They
walked
<EOS>
all
round
the
ruin
,
on
a
raised
gravel
-
path
which
had
been
made
there
;
and
Alice
,
who
could
hardly
bring
herself
to
speak
,
 
so
full
was
her
mind
of
that
which
had
just
been
said
to
her
,
 
was
surprised
to
find
that
Glencora
could
go
on
,
in
her
usual
light
humour
,
chatting
as
though
there
were
no
weight
within
her
to
depress
her
spirits
.
   
<EOS>
Alice
Leaves
the
Priory
.
 
<EOS>
As
they
came
in
at
the
billiard
-
room
door
,
Mr.
Palliser
was
there
to
meet
them
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
very
cold
,
"
he
said
to
Glencora
,
who
entered
first
.
"
<EOS>
No
,
indeed
,
"
said
Glencora
;
 
but
her
teeth
were
chattering
,
and
her
whole
appearance
gave
the
lie
to
her
words
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Jeffrey
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
turning
to
his
cousin
,
"
I
am
angry
with
you
.
<EOS>
You
,
at
least
,
should
have
known
better
than
to
have
allowed
her
to
remain
so
long
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Palliser
turned
away
,
and
walked
his
wife
off
,
taking
no
notice
whatsoever
of
Miss
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
felt
the
slight
,
and
understood
it
all
.
<EOS>
He
had
told
her
plainly
enough
,
though
not
in
words
,
that
he
had
trusted
his
wife
with
her
,
and
that
she
had
betrayed
the
trust
.
<EOS>
She
might
have
brought
Glencora
in
within
five
or
six
minutes
,
instead
of
allowing
her
to
remain
out
there
in
the
freezing
night
air
for
nearly
three
-
quarters
of
an
hour
.
<EOS>
That
was
the
accusation
which
Mr.
Palliser
made
against
her
,
and
he
made
it
with
the
utmost
severity
.
<EOS>
He
asked
no
question
of
her
whether
she
were
cold
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
no
word
to
her
,
nor
did
he
even
look
at
her
.
<EOS>
She
might
get
herself
away
to
her
bedroom
as
she
pleased
.
<EOS>
Alice
understood
all
this
completely
,
and
though
she
knew
that
she
had
not
deserved
such
severity
,
she
was
not
inclined
to
resent
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
so
much
in
Mr.
Palliser
's
position
that
was
to
be
pitied
,
that
Alice
could
not
find
it
in
her
heart
to
be
angry
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
provoked
with
us
,
now
,
"
said
Jeffrey
Palliser
,
standing
with
her
for
a
moment
in
the
billiard
-
room
,
as
he
handed
her
a
candle
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
afraid
that
she
will
have
caught
cold
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
and
he
thinks
it
wrong
that
she
should
remain
out
at
night
so
long
.
<EOS>
You
can
easily
understand
,
Miss
Vavasor
,
that
he
has
not
much
sympathy
for
romance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
he
is
right
,
"
said
Alice
,
not
exactly
knowing
what
to
say
,
and
not
being
able
to
forget
what
had
been
said
about
herself
and
Jeffrey
Palliser
when
they
first
left
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Romance
usually
means
nonsense
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
not
Glencora
's
doctrine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
but
she
is
younger
than
I
am
.
<EOS>
My
feet
are
very
cold
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
and
I
think
I
will
go
up
to
my
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
"
said
Jeffrey
,
offering
her
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
so
hard
that
you
should
have
incurred
his
displeasure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
not
hurt
me
,
"
said
Alice
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
but
he
does
not
forget
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Even
that
will
not
hurt
me
.
<EOS>
Good
night
,
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
it
is
the
last

,
may
I
say

night
,
Alice
?
<EOS>
I
shall
be
away
to
-
morrow
before
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
still
held

;
but

not

in

for

,
and
she
had

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
"
said

,
"
Glencora
was
very

there
,
 
doing
an
injury
without

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Can

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
Good

;
 
and

not

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-

.
<EOS>
Had

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To

.
<EOS>
Good

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then

,
and

.
<EOS>
Whether

and

considered
herself
right
in
presuming
that

was
broken

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
 
Plantagenet
Palliser
,
according
to
all

courtesy
should
have
said

to

as

;
but
,

,

want

on

.
<EOS>
So
she
went
up
alone
to
her
room
,
and
was
very
glad
to
find
herself
able
to
get
close
to
a
good
fire
.
<EOS>
She
was
,
in
truth
,
very
cold
 
cold
to
her

,
in

of
what
Lady
Glencora
had
said
on
behalf
of
the
moonlight
.
<EOS>
They

had
been
standing
all
but

during
the
greater

the
time
that
they
had
been
talking
,
and
Alice
,
as
she
sat
herself
down
,
found
that
her
feet
were
numbed
with
the
damp
that
had
penetrated
through

.
<EOS>
Certainly
Mr.
Palliser
had
reason
to

that

wife
should
have
remained
out
in
the
night
air
so
long
,
 
though
perhaps

with
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
And
then

began
to
think
of
what
had
been
told

;
and
to
try

think
of
what
,
under
such

,
it

do
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
doubt
that
Lady
Glencora
had
intended

,

,

,

;
and

,

,

that
the
poor

had
taught

to
think
that

for
this
sin
to

,

thus

might

.
<EOS>
Alice
well

would

even

who
had

.
<EOS>
But
still

would
operate
,
 
manifestly
had

,
on
her

,
teaching

to
hope

good
might

.
<EOS>
Alice
,
who
was
perfectly

as

,

much

her

might

with

,
saw

,

the

,
in

.
<EOS>
To

was
black
in

;
and
she

that
to
Glencora
<EOS>
also

.
<EOS>
"
I
loathe

,
"
Glencora
had
said
,
"

the

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
What
was

to

under

?
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
she

aware
,
had

;
for

;
and

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
What

Palliser
might

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

an

that
was
in
every

feminine
,
 
that
in
such

she

no

to

.
<EOS>
When
one

to
another
woman
,
the
confidant
always
feels
that
she
will
be
a
traitor
if
she
reveals
the
secret
.
<EOS>
Had
Lady
Glencora
made

,

,
Alice
would
have
had
no

in

,
and
thus

.
<EOS>
But
now

hesitated
,
feeling
that

by

her

.
<EOS>
And
,

,

the

?
  
<EOS>
As

,

,

,

,

's

,

.

<EOS>

,
"

?
<EOS>
I

!
"
<EOS>
Alice

,

.
  
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
had
made

little

with

Miss

.
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>
These

,

.
<EOS>
A

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

"
  
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
He

.

<EOS>
You

.

Mr.

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

"

When

"

"

.

,

"

<EOS>
Yes
;
 
she
has
told
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
he
is
to
be
at
Lady
Monk
's
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
told
me
that
Mr.
Palliser
expects
her
to
meet
him
at
the
place
to
which
they
are
going
when
they
leave
the
Duke
's
,
and
that
she
thinks
it
hard
that
she
should
be
subjected
to
such
a
trial
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
should
be
no
trial
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
it
be
otherwise
?
<EOS>
Come
,
Miss
Palliser
;
if
you
are
her
friend
,
be
fair
to
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
her
friend
;
 
but
I
am
,
above
everything
,
my
cousin
's
friend
.
<EOS>
He
has
told
me
that
she
has
complained
of
having
to
meet
this
man
.
<EOS>
He
declares
that
it
should
be
nothing
to
her
,
and
that
the
fear
is
an
idle
folly
.
<EOS>
It
should
be
nothing
to
her
,
but
still
the
fear
may
not
be
idle
.
<EOS>
Is
there
any
reason
,
 
any
real
reason
,
 
why
she
should
not
go
?
<EOS>
Miss
Vavasor
,
I
conjure
you
to
tell
me
,
 
even
though
in
doing
so
you
must
cast
so
deep
reproach
upon
her
name
!
<EOS>
Anything
will
be
better
than
utter
disgrace
and
sin
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
conceive
that
I
cast
no
reproach
upon
her
in
saying
that
there
is
great
reason
why
she
should
not
go
to
Monkshade
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
think
there
is
absolute
grounds
for
interference
?
<EOS>
I
must
tell
him
,
you
know
,
openly
what
he
would
have
to
fear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
 
nay
,
Miss
Palliser
,
I
know
,
 
that
there
is
ample
reason
why
you
should
save
her
from
being
taken
to
Monkshade
,
if
you
have
the
power
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
only
do
it
,
or
attempt
to
do
it
,
by
telling
him
just
what
you
tell
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
tell
him
.
<EOS>
You
must
have
thought
of
that
,
I
suppose
,
before
you
came
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
yes
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
I
had
thought
of
it
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
I
had
thought
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
had
believed
all
through
that
you
would
assure
me
that
there
was
no
danger
.
<EOS>
I
believed
that
you
would
have
said
that
she
was
innocent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
she
is
innocent
,
"
said
Alice
,
rising
from
her
chair
,
as
though
she
might
thus
give
emphasis
to
words
which
she
hardly
dared
to
speak
above
a
whisper
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
innocent
.
<EOS>
Who
accuses
her
of
guilt
?
<EOS>
You
ask
me
a
question
on
his
behalf
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
On
hers
 
and
on
his
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
question
which
I
feel
myself
bound
to
answer
truly
,
 
to
answer
with
reference
to
the
welfare
of
them
both
;
but
I
will
not
have
it
said
that
I
accuse
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
attached
to
Mr.
Fitzgerald
when
your
cousin
married
her
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
this
had
been
the
case
.
<EOS>
She
told
him
the
whole
truth
.
<EOS>
In
a
worldly
point
of
view
her
marriage
with
Mr.
Fitzgerald
would
probably
have
been
very
imprudent
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
have
been
utterly
ruinous
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
so
;
I
say
nothing
about
that
.
<EOS>
But
as
it
turned
out
,
she
gave
up
her
own
wishes
and
married
your
cousin
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
about
her
own
wishes
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
what
she
did
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
married
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
had
she
not
been
hindered
by
the
advice
of
those
around
her
.
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
supposed
that
she
has
forgotten
him
in
so
short
a
time
.
<EOS>
There
can
be
no
guilt
in
her
remembrance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
guilt
in
loving
any
other
than
her
husband
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Miss
Palliser
,
it
was
her
marriage
that
was
guilty
,
and
not
her
love
.
<EOS>
But
all
that
is
done
and
past
.
<EOS>
It
should
be
your
cousin
's
object
to
teach
her
to
forget
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
and
he
will
not
do
that
by
taking
her
to
a
house
where
that
gentleman
is
staying
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
said
so
much
to
you
herself
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
that
I
need
declare
to
you
what
she
has
said
herself
.
<EOS>
You
have
asked
me
a
question
,
and
I
have
answered
it
,
and
I
am
thankful
to
you
for
having
asked
it
.
<EOS>
What
object
can
either
of
us
have
but
to
assist
her
in
her
position
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
to
save
him
from
dishonour
.
<EOS>
I
had
so
hoped
that
this
was
simply
a
childish
dread
on
her
part
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
so
.
<EOS>
It
is
no
childish
dread
.
<EOS>
If
you
have
the
power
to
prevent
her
going
to
Lady
Monk
's
,
I
implore
you
to
use
it
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
will
ask
you
to
promise
me
that
you
will
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
After
what
you
have
said
,
I
have
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Exactly
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
Either
for
his
sake
or
for
hers
,
there
is
none
.
"
  
<EOS>
Thereupon
Miss
Palliser
got
up
,
and
wishing
her
companion
good
night
,
took
her
departure
.
<EOS>
Throughout
the
interview
there
had
been
no
cordiality
of
feeling
between
them
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
pretence
of
friendship
,
even
as
they
were
parting
.
<EOS>
They
acknowledged
that
their
objects
were
different
.
<EOS>
That
of
Alice
was
to
save
Lady
Glencora
from
ruin
.
<EOS>
That
of
Miss
Palliser
was
to
save
her
cousin
from
disgrace
,
 
with
perhaps
some
further
honest
desire
to
prevent
sorrow
and
sin
.
<EOS>
One
loved
Lady
Glencora
,
and
the
other
clearly
did
not
love
her
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
Alice
felt
that
Miss
Palliser
,
in
coming
to
her
,
had
acted
well
,
and
that
to
herself
this
coming
had
afforded
immense
relief
.
<EOS>
Some
step
would
now
be
taken
to
prevent
that
meeting
which
she
had
so
deprecated
,
and
it
would
be
taken
without
any
great
violation
of
confidence
on
her
part
.
<EOS>
She
had
said
nothing
as
to
which
Lady
Glencora
could
feel
herself
aggrieved
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
next
morning
she
was
down
in
the
breakfast
-
room
soon
after
nine
,
and
had
not
been
in
the
room
many
minutes
before
Mr.
Palliser
entered
.
<EOS>
"
The
carriage
is
ordered
for
you
at
a
quarter
before
ten
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
I
have
come
down
to
give
you
your
breakfast
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
smile
on
his
face
as
he
spoke
,
and
Alice
could
see
that
he
intended
to
make
himself
pleasant
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
allow
me
to
give
you
yours
instead
?
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
But
as
it
happened
,
no
giving
on
either
side
was
needed
,
as
Alice
's
breakfast
was
brought
to
her
separately
.
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
bids
me
say
that
she
will
be
down
immediately
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
then
made
some
inquiry
with
reference
to
the
effects
of
last
night
's
imprudence
,
which
received
only
a
half
-
pronounced
reply
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
willing
to
be
gracious
,
but
did
not
intend
to
be
understood
as
having
forgiven
the
offence
.
<EOS>
The
Miss
Pallisers
then
came
in
together
,
and
after
them
Mr.
Bott
,
closely
followed
by
Mrs.
Marsham
,
and
all
of
them
made
inquiries
after
Lady
Glencora
,
as
though
it
was
to
be
supposed
that
she
might
probably
be
in
a
perilous
state
after
what
she
had
undergone
on
the
previous
evening
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
was
particularly
anxious
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
frost
was
so
uncommonly
severe
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
any
delicate
person
like
Lady
Glencora
must
have
suffered
in
remaining
out
so
long
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
insinuation
that
Alice
was
not
a
delicate
person
and
that
,
as
regarded
her
,
the
severity
of
the
frost
was
of
no
moment
,
was
very
open
,
and
was
duly
appreciated
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
was
aware
that
his
great
patron
had
in
some
sort
changed
his
opinion
about
Miss
Vavasor
,
and
he
was
of
course
disposed
to
change
his
own
.
<EOS>
A
fortnight
since
Alice
might
have
been
as
delicate
as
she
pleased
in
Mr.
Bott
's
estimation
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
do
not
consider
Lady
Glencora
delicate
,
"
said
Alice
to
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
not
robust
,
"
said
the
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
By
no
means
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
no
,
"
said
Mr.
Bott
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
knew
that
she
was
being
accused
of
being
robust
herself
;
but
she
bore
it
in
silence
.
<EOS>
Ploughboys
and
milkmaids
are
robust
,
and
the
accusation
was
a
heavy
one
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
however
,
thought
that
she
would
not
have
minded
it
,
if
she
could
have
allowed
herself
to
reply
;
but
this
at
the
moment
of
her
going
away
she
could
not
do
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
she
is
as
strong
as
the
rest
of
us
,
"
said
Iphigenia
Palliser
,
who
felt
that
after
last
night
she
owed
something
to
Miss
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
some
of
us
,
"
said
Mr.
Bott
,
determined
to
persevere
in
his
accusation
.
  
<EOS>
At
this
moment
Lady
Glencora
entered
,
and
encountered
the
eager
inquiries
of
her
two
duennas
.
<EOS>
These
,
however
,
she
quickly
put
aside
,
and
made
her
way
up
to
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
The
last
morning
has
come
,
then
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
indeed
,
"
said
Alice
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
must
have
thought
that
I
was
never
going
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
On
the
other
hand
,
"
said
he
,
"
<EOS>
I
have
felt
much
obliged
to
you
for
staying
.
"
<EOS>
But
he
said
it
coldly
;
and
Alice
began
to
wish
that
she
had
never
seen
Matching
Priory
.
  
<EOS>
"
Obliged
!
"
exclaimed
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
tell
you
how
much
obliged
I
am
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Alice
,
I
wish
you
were
going
to
stay
with
us
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
leaving
this
in
a
week
's
time
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
we
are
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
all
my
heart
I
wish
we
were
not
.
<EOS>
Dear
Alice
!
<EOS>
I
suppose
we
shall
not
meet
till
we
are
all
in
town
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
let
me
know
when
you
come
up
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
send
to
you
instantly
;
and
,
Alice
,
I
will
write
to
you
from
Gatherum
,
 
or
from
Monkshade
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
could
not
help
looking
around
and
catching
Miss
Palliser
's
eye
.
<EOS>
Miss
Palliser
was
standing
with
her
foot
on
the
fender
,
but
was
so
placed
that
she
could
see
Alice
.
<EOS>
She
made
a
slight
sign
with
her
head
,
as
much
as
to
say
that
Lady
Glencora
must
have
no
opportunity
of
writing
from
the
latter
place
;
but
she
said
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
Then
the
carriage
was
announced
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
took
Alice
out
on
his
arm
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
come
to
the
door
,
Glencora
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
especially
wish
you
not
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
The
two
cousins
then
kissed
each
other
,
and
Alice
went
away
to
the
carriage
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
Miss
Vavasor
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
;
but
he
expressed
no
wish
that
he
might
see
her
again
as
his
guest
at
Matching
Priory
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
,
as
she
was
driven
in
solitary
grandeur
to
the
railway
station
,
could
not
but
wish
that
she
had
never
gone
there
.
   
<EOS>
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
night
before
Christmas
Eve
two
men
were
sitting
together
in
George
Vavasor
's
rooms
in
Cecil
Street
.
<EOS>
It
was
past
twelve
o'clock
,
and
they
were
both
smoking
;
there
were
square
bottles
on
the
table
containing
spirits
,
with
hot
water
and
cold
water
in
jugs
,
and
one
of
the
two
men
was
using
,
and
had
been
using
,
these
materials
for
enjoyment
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
had
not
been
drinking
,
nor
did
it
appear
as
though
he
intended
to
begin
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
weak
brandy
and
water
in
a
glass
by
his
side
,
but
there
it
had
remained
untouched
for
the
last
twenty
minutes
.
<EOS>
His
companion
,
however
,
had
twice
in
that
time
replenished
his
beaker
,
and
was
now
puffing
out
the
smoke
of
his
pipe
with
the
fury
of
a
steamer
's
funnel
when
she
has
not
yet
burned
the
black
off
her
last
instalment
of
fresh
coals
.
<EOS>
This
man
was
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
He
was
as
handsome
as
ever
;
 
a
man
whom
neither
man
nor
woman
could
help
regarding
as
a
thing
beautiful
to
behold
;
 
but
not
the
less
was
there
in
his
eyes
and
cheeks
a
look
of
haggard
dissipation
,
 
of
riotous
living
,
which
had
become
wearisome
,
by
its
continuance
,
even
to
himself
,
 
that
told
to
all
who
saw
him
much
of
the
history
of
his
life
.
<EOS>
Most
men
who
drink
at
nights
,
and
are
out
till
cockcrow
doing
deeds
of
darkness
,
become
red
in
their
faces
,
have
pimpled
cheeks
and
watery
eyes
,
and
are
bloated
and
not
comfortable
to
be
seen
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
kind
dispensation
of
Providence
who
thus
affords
to
such
sinners
a
visible
sign
,
to
be
seen
day
by
day
,
of
the
injury
which
is
being
done
.
<EOS>
The
first
approach
of
a
carbuncle
on
the
nose
,
about
the
age
of
thirty
,
has
stopped
many
a
man
from
drinking
.
<EOS>
No
one
likes
to
have
carbuncles
on
his
nose
,
or
to
appear
before
his
female
friends
with
eyes
which
look
as
though
they
were
swimming
in
grog
.
<EOS>
But
to
Burgo
Fitzgerald
Providence
in
her
anger
had
not
afforded
this
protection
.
<EOS>
He
became
at
times
pale
,
sallow
,
worn
,
and
haggard
.
<EOS>
He
grew
thin
,
and
still
thinner
.
<EOS>
At
times
he
had
been
ill
to
death
's
door
.
<EOS>
Among
his
intimate
friends
there
were
those
who
heard
him
declare
frequently
that
his
liver
had
become
useless
to
him
;
and
that
,
as
for
gastric
juices
,
he
had
none
left
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
still
his
beauty
remained
.
<EOS>
The
perfect
form
of
his
almost
god

like
face
was
the
same
as
ever
,
and
the
brightness
of
his
bright

was
never

.
  
<EOS>
On
the
present

he
had
come
to

's

from
him
certain

,

.
<EOS>
But
as

he

,
I
think
,
in

most

when

who
shall

.
<EOS>
Advice

but

.
<EOS>
These

in
the

,
previous
to

's

.
<EOS>
When

,

,

.
<EOS>
Any

George

.
<EOS>
Some

<EOS>

<EOS>
All

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
I

,
"
