But
the
thing
was
one
which
came
within
the
pale
of
his
laws
.
<EOS>
Such
assistance
as
that
he
might
ask
of
others
,
and
had
asked
and
received
before
now
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
reckless
deed
on
his
part
,
but
then
all
his
doings
were
reckless
.
<EOS>
It
was
consonant
with
his
mode
of
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
would
,
old
fellow
,
"
said
Burgo
,
as
he
got
up
to
go
away
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
you
know
,
I
shall
pull
through
in
this
;
and
perhaps
,
after
all
,
some
part
of
her
fortune
will
come
with
her
.
<EOS>
If
so
you
'll
be
all
right
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
may
.
<EOS>
But
look
here
,
Burgo
,
 
do
n't
you
give
that
fellow
up
the
bill
till
you
've
got
the
money
into
your
fist
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
quite
easy
about
that
.
<EOS>
I
know
their
tricks
.
<EOS>
He
and
I
will
go
to
the
bank
together
,
and
we
shall
squabble
there
at
the
door
about
four
or
five
<EOS>
odd
sovereigns
<EOS>
,
 
and
at
last
I
shall
have
to
give
him
up
two
or
three
.
<EOS>
Beastly
old
robber
!
<EOS>
I
declare
I
think
he
's
worse
than
I
am
myself
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Burgo
Fitzgerald
took
a
little
more
brandy
and
water
and
went
away
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
living
at
this
time
in
the
house
of
one
of
his
relatives
in
Cavendish
Square
,
north
of
Oxford
Street
.
<EOS>
His
uncles
and
his
aunts
,
and
all
those
who
were
his
natural
friends
,
had
clung
to
him
with
a
tenacity
that
was
surprising
;
for
he
had
never
been
true
to
any
of
them
,
and
did
not
even
pretend
to
like
them
.
<EOS>
His
father
,
with
whom
for
many
years
he
had
not
been
on
speaking
terms
,
was
now
dead
;
but
he
had
sisters
whose
husbands
would
still
open
their
houses
to
him
,
either
in
London
or
in
the
country
;
 
would
open
their
houses
to
him
,
and
lend
him
their
horses
,
and
provide
him
with
every
luxury
which
the
rich
enjoy
,
 
except
ready
money
.
<EOS>
When
the
uttermost
stress
of
pecuniary
embarrassment
would
come
upon
him
,
they
would
pay
something
to
stave
off
the
immediate
evil
.
<EOS>
And
so
Burgo
went
on
.
<EOS>
Nobody
now
thought
of
saying
much
to
reproach
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
known
to
be
waste
of
words
,
and
trouble
in
vain
.
<EOS>
They
were
still
fond
of
him
because
he
was
beautiful
and
never
vain
of
his
beauty
;
 
because
in
the
midst
of
his
recklessness
there
was
always
about
him
a
certain
kindliness
which
made
him
pleasant
to
those
around
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
soft
and
gracious
with
children
,
and
would
be
very
courteous
to
his
lady
cousins
.
<EOS>
They
knew
that
as
a
man
he
was
worthless
,
but
nevertheless
they
loved
him
.
<EOS>
I
think
the
secret
of
it
was
chiefly
in
this
,
 
that
he
seemed
to
think
so
little
of
himself
.
  
<EOS>
But
now
as
he
walked
home
in
the
middle
of
the
night
from
Cecil
Street
to
Cavendish
Square
he
did
think
much
of
himself
.
<EOS>
Indeed
such
self
-
thoughts
come
naturally
to
all
men
,
be
their
outward
conduct
ever
so
reckless
.
<EOS>
Every
man
to
himself
is
the
centre
of
the
whole
world
;
 
the
axle
on
which
it
all
turns
.
<EOS>
All
knowledge
is
but
his
own
perception
of
the
things
around
him
.
<EOS>
All
love
,
and
care
for
others
,
and
solicitude
for
the
world
's
welfare
,
are
but
his
own
feelings
as
to
the
world
's
wants
and
the
world
's
merits
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
played
his
part
as
a
centre
of
all
things
very
badly
.
<EOS>
Of
that
he
was
very
well
aware
.
<EOS>
He
had
sense
enough
to
know
that
it
should
be
a
man
's
lot
to
earn
his
bread
after
some
fashion
,
and
he
often
told
himself
that
never
as
yet
had
he
earned
so
much
as
a
penny
roll
.
<EOS>
He
had
learned
to
comprehend
that
the
world
's
progress
depends
on
the
way
in
which
men
do
their
duty
by
each
other
,
 
that
the
progress
of
one
generation
depends
on
the
discharge
of
such
duties
by
that
which
preceded
it
;
 
and
he
knew
that
he
,
in
his
generation
,
had
done
nothing
to
promote
such
progress
.
<EOS>
He
thoroughly
despised
himself
,
 
if
there
might
be
any
good
in
that
!
<EOS>
But
on
such
occasions
as
these
,
when
the
wine
he
had
drunk
was
sufficient
only
to
drive
away
from
him
the
numbness
of
despair
,
when
he
was
all
alone
with
the
cold
night
air
upon
his
face
,
when
the
stars
were
bright
above
him
and
the
world
around
him
was
almost
quiet
,
he
would
still
ask
himself
whether
there
might
not
yet
be
,
even
for
him
,
some
hope
of
a
redemption
,
 
some
chance
of
a
better
life
in
store
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
young
,
 
wanting
some
years
of
thirty
.
<EOS>
Could
there
be
,
even
for
him
,
some
mode
of
extrication
from
his
misery
?
  
<EOS>
We
know
what
was
the
mode
which
now
,
at
this
moment
,
was
suggesting
itself
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
proposing
to
himself
,
as
the
best
thing
that
he
could
do
,
to
take
away
another
man
's
wife
and
make
himself
happy
with
her
!
<EOS>
What
he
had
said
to
Vavasor
as
to
disregarding
Lady
Glencora
's
money
had
been
perfectly
true
.
<EOS>
That
in
the
event
of
her
going
off
with
him
,
some
portion
of
her
enormous
wealth
would
still
cling
to
her
,
he
did
believe
.
<EOS>
Seeing
that
she
had
no
children
he
could
not
understand
where
else
it
should
all
go
.
<EOS>
But
he
thought
of
this
as
it
regarded
her
,
not
as
it
regarded
him
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
before
made
his
suit
to
her
,
 
<EOS>
a
suit
which
was
then
honourable
,
however
disadvantageous
it
might
have
seemed
to
be
to
her
 
he
had
made
in
his
mind
certain
calculations
as
to
the
good
things
which
would
result
to
him
if
he
were
successful
He
would
keep
hounds
,
and
have
three
or
four
horses
every
day
for
his
own
riding
,
and
he
would
have
no
more
interviews
with
Magruin
,
waiting
in
that
rogue
's
dingy
back
parlour
for
many
a
weary
wretched
half
-
hour
,
till
the
rogue
should
be
pleased
to
show
himself
.
<EOS>
So
far
he
had
been
mercenary
;
but
he
had
learned
to
love
the
girl
,
and
to
care
more
for
her
than
for
her
money
,
and
when
the
day
of
disappointment
came
upon
him
,
 
the
day
on
which
she
had
told
him
that
all
between
them
was
to
be
over
for
ever
,
 
he
had
,
for
a
few
hours
,
felt
the
loss
of
his
love
more
than
the
loss
of
his
money
.
  
<EOS>
Then
he
had
had
no
further
hope
.
<EOS>
No
such
idea
as
that
which
now
filled
his
mind
had
then
come
upon
him
.
<EOS>
The
girl
had
gone
from
him
and
married
another
man
,
and
there
was
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
by
degrees
tidings
had
reached
him
that
she
was
not
happy
,
 
reaching
him
through
the
mouths
of
people
who
were
glad
to
exaggerate
all
that
they
had
heard
.
<EOS>
A
whole
tribe
of
his
female
relatives
had
been
anxious
to
promote
his
marriage
with
Lady
Glencora
M'Cluskie
,
declaring
that
,
after
all
that
was
come
and
gone
,
Burgo
would
come
forth
from
his
troubles
as
a
man
of
great
wealth
.
<EOS>
So
great
was
the
wealth
of
the
heiress
that
it
might
withstand
even
his
propensities
for
spending
.
<EOS>
That
whole
tribe
had
been
bitterly
disappointed
;
and
when
they
heard
that
Mr.
Palliser
's
marriage
had
given
him
no
child
,
and
that
Lady
Glencora
was
unhappy
,
 
they
made
their
remarks
in
triumph
rather
than
in
sorrow
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
that
they
looked
forward
approvingly
to
such
a
step
as
that
which
Burgo
now
wished
to
take
,
 
though
as
regarded
his
aunt
,
Lady
Monk
,
he
himself
had
accused
her
;
but
they
whispered
that
such
things
had
been
done
and
must
be
expected
,
when
marriages
were
made
up
as
had
been
that
marriage
between
Mr.
Palliser
and
his
bride
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
walked
on
,
thinking
of
his
project
,
he
strove
hard
to
cheat
himself
into
a
belief
that
he
would
do
a
good
thing
in
carrying
Lady
Glencora
away
from
her
husband
.
<EOS>
Bad
as
had
been
his
life
he
had
never
before
done
aught
so
bad
as
that
.
<EOS>
The
more
fixed
his
intention
became
,
the
more
thoroughly
he
came
to
perceive
how
great
and
grievous
was
the
crime
which
he
contemplated
.
<EOS>
To
elope
with
another
man
's
wife
no
longer
appeared
to
him
to
be
a
joke
at
which
such
men
as
he
might
smile
.
<EOS>
But
he
tried
to
think
that
in
this
case
there
would
be
special
circumstances
which
would
almost
justify
him
,
and
also
her
.
<EOS>
They
had
loved
each
other
and
had
sworn
to
love
each
other
with
constancy
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
no
change
in
the
feelings
or
even
in
the
wishes
of
either
of
them
.
<EOS>
But
cold
people
had
come
between
them
with
cold
calculations
,
and
had
separated
them
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
,
he
told
himself
,
made
to
marry
a
man
she
did
not
love
.
<EOS>
If
they
two
loved
each
other
truly
,
would
it
not
still
be
better
that
they
should
come
together
?
<EOS>
Would
not
the
sin
be
forgiven
on
account
of
the
injustice
which
had
been
done
to
them
?
<EOS>
Had
Mr.
Palliser
a
right
to
expect
more
from
a
wife
who
had
been
made
to
marry
him
without
loving
him
?
<EOS>
Then
he
reverted
to
those
dreams
of
a
life
of
love
,
in
some
sunny
country
,
of
which
he
had
spoken
to
Vavasor
,
and
he
strove
to
nourish
them
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
had
laughed
at
him
,
talking
of
Juan
and
Haidée
.
<EOS>
But
Vavasor
,
he
said
to
himself
,
was
a
hard
cold
man
,
who
had
no
touch
of
romance
in
his
character
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
be
laughed
out
of
his
plan
by
such
as
he
,
 
nor
would
he
be
frightened
by
the
threat
of
any
Lambro
who
might
come
after
him
,
whether
he
might
come
in
the
guise
of
indignant
uncle
or
injured
husband
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
crossed
from
Regent
Street
through
Hanover
Square
,
and
as
he
came
out
by
the
iron
gates
into
Oxford
Street
,
a
poor
wretched
girl
,
lightly
clad
in
thin
raiment
,
into
whose
bones
the
sharp
freezing
air
was
penetrating
,
asked
him
for
money
.
<EOS>
Would
he
give
her
something
to
get
drink
,
so
that
for
a
moment
she
might
feel
the
warmth
of
her
life
renewed
?
<EOS>
Such
midnight
petitions
were
common
enough
in
his
ears
,
and
he
was
passing
on
without
thinking
of
her
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
urgent
,
and
took
hold
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
love
of
God
,
"
she
said
,
"
if
it
's
only
a
penny
to
get
a
glass
of
gin
!
<EOS>
Feel
my
hand
,
 
how
cold
it
is
.
"
<EOS>
And
she
strove
to
put
it
up
against
his
face
.
  
<EOS>
He
looked
round
at
her
and
saw
that
she
was
very
young
,
 
sixteen
,
perhaps
,
at
the
most
,
and
that
she
had
once
,
 
nay
very
lately
,
 
been
exquisitely
pretty
.
<EOS>
There
still
lingered
about
her
eyes
some
remains
of
that
look
of
perfect
innocency
and
pure
faith
which
had
been
hers
not
more
than
twelve
months
since
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
at
midnight
,
in
the
middle
of
the
streets
,
she
was
praying
for
a
pennyworth
of
gin
,
as
the
only
comfort
she
knew
,
or
could
expect
!
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
cold
!
"
<EOS>
said
he
,
trying
to
speak
to
her
cheerily
.
  
<EOS>
"
Cold
!
"
said
she
,
repeating
the
word
,
and
striving
to
wrap
herself
closer
in
her
rags
,
as
she
shivered
 
"
Oh
God
!
<EOS>
if
you
knew
what
it
was
to
be
as
cold
as
I
am
!
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
in
the
world
,
 
not
one
penny
,
 
not
a
hole
to
lie
in
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
alike
then
,
"
said
Burgo
,
with
a
slight
low
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
I
also
have
nothing
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
be
poorer
than
I
am
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
poor
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
<EOS>
And
then
she
looked
up
into
his
face
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Gracious
;
how
beautiful
you
are
!
<EOS>
Such
as
you
are
never
poor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
laughed
again
,
 
in
a
different
tone
.
<EOS>
He
always
laughed
when
any
one
told
him
of
his
beauty
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
deal
poorer
than
you
,
my
girl
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
have
thirty
thousand
pounds
worse
than
nothing
.
<EOS>
But
come
along
,
and
I
will
get
you
something
to
eat
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
?
"
said
she
,
eagerly
.
<EOS>
Then
looking
up
at
him
again
,
she
exclaimed
 
"
Oh
,
you
are
so
handsome
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
took
her
to
a
public
-
house
and
gave
her
bread
and
meat
and
beer
,
and
stood
by
her
while
she
ate
it
.
<EOS>
She
was
shy
with
him
then
,
and
would
fain
have
taken
it
to
a
corner
by
herself
,
had
he
allowed
her
.
<EOS>
He
perceived
this
,
and
turned
his
back
to
her
,
but
still
spoke
to
her
a
word
or
two
as
she
ate
.
<EOS>
The
woman
at
the
bar
who
served
him
looked
at
him
wonderingly
,
staring
into
his
face
;
and
the
pot
-
boy
woke
himself
thoroughly
that
he
might
look
at
Burgo
;
and
the
waterman
from
the
cab
-
stand
stared
at
him
;
and
women
who
came
in
for
gin
looked
almost
lovingly
up
into
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
He
regarded
them
all
not
at
all
,
showing
no
feeling
of
disgrace
at
his
position
,
and
no
desire
to
carry
himself
as
a
ruffler
.
<EOS>
He
quietly
paid
what
was
due
when
the
girl
had
finished
her
meal
,
and
then
walked
with
her
out
of
the
shop
.
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
"
said
he
,
"
what
must
I
do
with
you
?
<EOS>
If
I
give
you
a
shilling
can
you
get
a
bed
?
"
<EOS>
She
told
him
that
she
could
get
a
bed
for
sixpence
.
"
<EOS>
Then
keep
the
other
sixpence
for
your
breakfast
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
must
promise
me
that
you
will
buy
no
gin
to
-
night
.
"
<EOS>
She
promised
him
,
and
then
he
gave
her
his
hand
as
he
wished
her
good
night
;
 
his
hand
,
which
it
had
been
the
dearest
wish
of
Lady
Glencora
to
call
her
own
.
<EOS>
She
took
it
and
pressed
it
to
her
lips
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
might
once
see
you
again
,
"
she
said
,
"
because
you
are
so
good
and
so
beautiful
.
"
<EOS>
He
laughed
again
cheerily
,
and
walked
on
,
crossing
the
street
towards
Cavendish
Square
.
<EOS>
She
stood
looking
at
him
till
he
was
out
of
sight
,
and
then
as
she
moved
away
,
 
let
us
hope
to
the
bed
which
his
bounty
had
provided
,
and
not
to
a
gin
-
shop
,
 
she
exclaimed
to
herself
again
and
again
 
<EOS>
"
Gracious
,
how
beautiful
he
was
!
"
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
good
un
,
"
the
woman
at
the
public
-
house
had
said
as
soon
as
he
left
it
;
"
but
,
my
!
<EOS>
did
you
ever
see
a
man
's
face
handsome
as
that
fellow
's
?
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Burgo
!
<EOS>
All
who
had
seen
him
since
life
had
begun
with
him
had
loved
him
and
striven
to
cherish
him
.
<EOS>
And
with
it
all
,
to
what
a
state
had
he
come
!
<EOS>
Poor
Burgo
!
<EOS>
had
his
eyes
been
less
brightly
blue
,
and
his
face
less
godlike
in
form
,
it
may
be
that
things
would
have
gone
better
with
him
.
<EOS>
A
sweeter
-
tempered
man
than
he
never
lived
,
 
nor
one
who
was
of
a
kinder
nature
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
he
had
barely
money
about
him
to
take
him
down
to
his
aunt
's
house
at
Monkshade
,
and
as
he
had
promised
to
be
there
before
Christmas
Day
,
he
was
bound
to
start
on
the
next
morning
,
before
help
from
Mr.
Magruin
was
possible
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
out
of
his
very
narrow
funds
he
had
given
half
a
crown
to
comfort
the
poor
creature
who
had
spoken
to
him
in
the
street
.
   
<EOS>
Containing
a
Love
Letter
.
 
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
as
he
sat
alone
in
his
room
,
after
Fitzgerald
had
left
him
,
began
to
think
of
the
days
in
which
he
had
before
wished
to
assist
his
friend
in
his
views
with
reference
to
Lady
Glencora
;
 
or
rather
he
began
to
think
of
Alice
's
behaviour
then
,
and
of
Alice
's
words
.
<EOS>
Alice
had
steadfastly
refused
to
give
any
aid
.
<EOS>
No
less
likely
assistant
for
such
a
purpose
could
have
been
selected
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
been
very
earnest
in
declaring
that
it
was
Glencora
's
duty
to
stand
by
her
promise
to
Burgo
.
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
desperate
spendthrift
,
"
Kate
Vavasor
had
said
to
her
.
"
<EOS>
Then
let
her
teach
him
to
be
otherwise
,
"
Alice
had
answered
.
<EOS>
"
That
might
have
been
a
good
reason
for
refusing
his
offer
when
he
first
made
it
;
but
it
can
be
no
excuse
for
untruth
,
now
that
she
has
told
him
that
she
loves
him
!
"
<EOS>
"
If
a
woman
,
"
she
had
said
again
,
"
wo
n't
venture
her
fortune
for
the
man
she
loves
,
her
love
is
not
worth
having
.
<EOS>
"
All
this
George
Vavasor
remembered
now
;
and
as
he
remembered
it
he
asked
himself
whether
the
woman
that
had
once
loved
him
would
venture
her
fortune
for
him
still
.
  
<EOS>
Though
his
sister
had
pressed
him
on
the
subject
with
all
the
vehemence
that
she
could
use
,
he
had
hardly
hitherto
made
up
his
mind
that
he
really
desired
to
marry
Alice
.
<EOS>
There
had
grown
upon
him
lately
certain
Bohemian
propensities
,
 
a
love
of
absolute
independence
in
his
thoughts
as
well
as
actions
,
 
which
were
antagonistic
to
marriage
.
<EOS>
He
was
almost
inclined
to
think
that
marriage
was
an
old
-
fashioned
custom
,
fitted
indeed
well
enough
for
the
usual
dull
life
of
the
world
at
large
,
 
as
many
men
both
in
heathen
and
in
Christian
ages
have
taught
themselves
to
think
of
religion
,
 
but
which
was
not
adapted
to
his
advanced
intelligence
.
<EOS>
If
he
loved
any
woman
he
loved
his
cousin
Alice
.
<EOS>
If
he
thoroughly
respected
any
woman
he
respected
her
.
<EOS>
But
that
idea
of
tying
himself
down
to
a
household
was
in
itself
distasteful
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
thing
terrible
to
think
of
,
"
he
once
said
to
a
congenial
friend
in
these
days
of
his
life
,
"
that
a
man
should
give
permission
to
a
priest
to
tie
him
to
another
human
being
like
a
Siamese
twin
,
so
that
all
power
of
separate
and
solitary
action
should
be
taken
from
him
for
ever
!
<EOS>
The
beasts
of
the
field
do
not
treat
each
other
so
badly
.
<EOS>
They
neither
drink
themselves
drunk
,
nor
eat
themselves
stupid
;
 
nor
do
they
bind
themselves
together
in
a
union
which
both
would
have
to
hate
.
<EOS>
"
In
this
way
George
Vavasor
,
trying
to
imitate
the
wisdom
of
the
brutes
,
had
taught
himself
some
theories
of
a
peculiar
nature
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
as
he
thought
of
Alice
Vavasor
on
this
occasion
,
he
began
to
feel
that
if
a
Siamese
twin
were
necessary
for
him
,
she
of
all
others
was
the
woman
to
whom
he
would
wish
to
be
so
bound
.
  
<EOS>
And
if
he
did
it
at
all
,
he
must
do
it
now
.
<EOS>
Under
the
joint
instigation
of
himself
and
his
sister
,
 
as
he
thought
,
and
perhaps
not
altogether
without
reason
,
 
she
had
broken
her
engagement
with
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
That
she
would
renew
it
again
if
left
to
herself
,
he
believed
probable
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
despite
that
advanced
intelligence
which
had
taught
him
to
regard
all
forms
and
ceremonies
with
the
eye
of
a
philosopher
,
he
had
still
enough
of
human
frailty
about
him
to
feel
keenly
alive
to
the
pleasure
of
taking
from
John
Grey
the
prize
which
John
Grey
had
so
nearly
taken
from
him
.
<EOS>
If
Alice
could
have
been
taught
to
think
as
he
did
as
to
the
absurdity
of
those
indissoluble
ties
,
that
would
have
been
better
.
<EOS>
But
nothing
would
have
been
more
impossible
than
the
teaching
of
such
a
lesson
to
his
cousin
Alice
.
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
was
a
man
of
courage
,
and
dared
do
most
things
;
 
but
he
would
not
have
dared
to
commence
the
teaching
of
such
a
lesson
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
,
at
this
moment
,
what
was
his
outlook
into
life
generally
?
<EOS>
He
had
very
high
ambition
,
and
a
fair
hope
of
gratifying
it
if
he
could
only
provide
that
things
should
go
well
with
him
for
a
year
or
so
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
a
poor
man
,
having
been
once
nearly
a
rich
man
;
but
still
so
much
of
the
result
of
his
nearly
acquired
riches
remained
to
him
,
that
on
the
strength
of
them
he
might
probably
find
his
way
into
Parliament
.
<EOS>
He
had
paid
the
cost
of
the
last
attempt
,
and
might
,
in
a
great
degree
,
carry
on
this
present
attempt
on
credit
.
<EOS>
If
he
succeeded
there
would
be
open
to
him
a
mode
of
life
,
agreeable
in
itself
,
and
honourable
among
men
.
<EOS>
But
how
was
he
to
bear
the
cost
of
this
for
the
next
year
,
or
the
next
two
years
?
<EOS>
His
grandfather
was
still
alive
,
and
would
probably
live
over
that
period
.
<EOS>
If
he
married
Alice
he
would
do
so
with
no
idea
of
cheating
her
out
of
her
money
.
<EOS>
She
should
learn
,
 
nay
,
she
had
already
learned
from
his
own
lips
,
 
how
perilous
was
his
enterprise
.
<EOS>
But
he
knew
her
to
be
a
woman
who
would
boldly
risk
all
in
money
,
though
no
consideration
would
induce
her
to
stir
a
hair
's
breadth
towards
danger
in
reputation
.
<EOS>
Towards
teaching
her
that
doctrine
at
which
I
have
hinted
,
he
would
not
have
dared
to
make
an
attempt
;
but
he
felt
that
he
should
have
no
repugnance
to
telling
her
that
he
wanted
to
spend
all
her
money
in
the
first
year
or
two
of
their
married
life
!
  
<EOS>
He
was
still
in
his
arm
-
chair
,
thinking
of
all
this
,
with
that
small
untasted
modicum
of
brandy
and
water
beside
him
,
when
he
heard
some
distant
Lambeth
clock
strike
three
from
over
the
river
.
<EOS>
Then
he
rose
from
his
seat
,
and
taking
the
candles
in
his
hand
,
sat
himself
down
at
a
writing
-
desk
on
the
other
side
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
I
need
n't
send
it
when
it
's
written
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
"
and
the
chances
are
that
I
wo
n't
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
he
took
his
paper
,
and
wrote
as
follows
:
    
DEAR
ALICE
,
  
<EOS>
The
time
was
when
the
privilege
was
mine
of
beginning
my
letters
to
you
with
a
warmer
show
of
love
than
the
above
word
contains
,
 
when
I
might
and
did
call
you
dearest
;
but
I
lost
that
privilege
through
my
own
folly
,
and
since
that
it
has
been
accorded
to
another
.
<EOS>
But
you
have
found
,
 
with
a
thorough
honesty
of
purpose
than
which
I
know
nothing
greater
,
 
that
it
has
behoved
you
to
withdraw
that
privilege
also
.
<EOS>
I
need
hardly
say
that
I
should
not
have
written
as
I
now
write
,
had
you
not
found
it
expedient
to
do
as
you
have
done
.
<EOS>
I
now
once
again
ask
you
to
be
my
wife
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
all
that
passed
in
those
old
days
,
 
of
all
the
selfish
folly
of
which
I
was
then
guilty
,
I
think
you
know
,
and
at
the
time
knew
,
that
I
ever
loved
you
.
<EOS>
I
claim
to
say
for
myself
that
my
love
to
you
was
true
from
first
to
last
,
and
I
claim
from
you
belief
for
that
statement
.
<EOS>
Indeed
I
do
not
think
that
you
ever
doubted
my
love
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
when
you
told
me
that
I
might
no
longer
hope
to
make
you
my
wife
,
I
had
no
word
of
remonstrance
that
I
could
utter
.
<EOS>
You
acted
as
any
woman
would
act
whom
love
had
not
made
a
fool
.
<EOS>
Then
came
the
episode
of
Mr.
Grey
;
and
bitter
as
have
been
my
feelings
whilst
that
engagement
lasted
,
I
never
made
any
attempt
to
come
between
you
and
the
life
you
had
chosen
.
<EOS>
In
saying
this
I
do
not
forget
the
words
which
I
spoke
last
summer
at
Basle
,
when
,
as
far
as
I
knew
,
you
still
intended
that
he
should
be
your
husband
.
<EOS>
But
what
I
said
then
was
nothing
to
that
which
,
with
much
violence
,
I
refrained
from
saying
.
<EOS>
Whether
you
remember
those
few
words
I
can
not
tell
;
but
certainly
you
would
not
have
remembered
them
,
 
would
not
even
have
noticed
them
,
 
had
your
heart
been
at
Nethercoats
.
  
<EOS>
But
all
this
is
nothing
.
<EOS>
You
are
now
again
a
free
woman
;
and
once
again
I
ask
you
to
be
my
wife
.
<EOS>
We
are
both
older
than
we
were
when
we
loved
before
,
and
will
both
be
prone
to
think
of
marriage
in
a
somewhat
different
light
.
<EOS>
Then
personal
love
for
each
other
was
most
in
our
thoughts
.
<EOS>
God
forbid
that
it
should
not
be
much
in
our
thoughts
now
!
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
am
deceiving
myself
in
saying
that
it
is
not
even
now
stronger
in
mine
than
any
other
consideration
.
<EOS>
But
we
have
both
reached
that
time
of
life
,
when
it
is
probable
that
in
any
proposition
of
marriage
we
should
think
more
of
our
adaptability
to
each
other
than
we
did
before
.
<EOS>
For
myself
I
know
that
there
is
much
in
my
character
and
disposition
to
make
me
unfit
to
marry
a
woman
of
the
common
stamp
.
<EOS>
You
know
my
mode
of
life
,
and
what
are
my
hopes
and
my
chances
of
success
.
<EOS>
I
run
great
risk
of
failing
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
I
shall
encounter
ruin
where
I
look
for
reputation
and
a
career
of
honour
.
<EOS>
The
chances
are
perhaps
more
in
favour
of
ruin
than
of
success
.
<EOS>
But
,
whatever
may
be
the
chances
,
I
shall
go
on
as
long
as
any
means
of
carrying
on
the
fight
are
at
my
disposal
.
<EOS>
If
you
were
my
wife
to
-
morrow
<EOS>
I
should
expect
to
use
your
money
,
if
it
were
needed
,
in
struggling
to
obtain
a
seat
in
Parliament
and
a
hearing
there
.
<EOS>
I
will
hardly
stoop
to
tell
you
that
I
do
not
ask
you
to
be
my
wife
for
the
sake
of
this
aid
;
 
but
if
you
were
to
become
my
wife
I
should
expect
all
your
cooperation
;
 
with
your
money
,
possibly
,
but
certainly
with
your
warmest
spirit
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
,
once
again
,
Alice
,
 
dearest
Alice
,
will
you
be
my
wife
?
<EOS>
I
have
been
punished
,
and
I
have
kissed
the
rod
,
 
as
I
never
kissed
any
other
rod
.
<EOS>
You
can
not
accuse
my
love
.
<EOS>
Since
the
time
in
which
I
might
sit
with
my
arm
round
your
waist
,
I
have
sat
with
<EOS>
it
round
no
other
waist
.
<EOS>
Since
your
lips
were
mine
,
no
other
lips
have
been
dear
to
me
.
<EOS>
Since
you
were
my
counsellor
,
I
have
had
no
other
counsellor
,
 
unless
it
be
poor
Kate
,
whose
wish
that
we
may
at
length
be
married
is
second
in
earnestness
only
to
my
own
.
<EOS>
Nor
do
I
think
you
will
doubt
my
repentance
.
<EOS>
Such
repentance
indeed
claims
no
merit
,
as
it
has
been
the
natural
result
of
the
loss
which
I
have
suffered
.
<EOS>
Providence
has
hitherto
been
very
good
to
me
in
not
having
made
that
loss
irremediable
by
your
marriage
with
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
I
wish
you
now
to
consider
the
matter
well
,
and
to
tell
me
whether
you
can
pardon
me
and
still
love
me
.
<EOS>
Do
I
flatter
myself
when
I
feel
that
I
doubt
your
pardon
almost
more
than
I
doubt
your
love
?
  
<EOS>
Think
of
this
thing
in
all
its
bearings
before
you
answer
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
anxious
that
you
should
think
of
it
that
I
will
not
expect
your
reply
till
this
day
week
.
<EOS>
It
can
hardly
be
your
desire
to
go
through
life
unmarried
.
<EOS>
I
should
say
that
it
must
be
essential
to
your
ambition
that
you
should
join
your
lot
to
that
of
some
man
the
nature
of
whose
aspirations
would
be
like
to
your
own
.
<EOS>
It
is
because
this
was
not
so
<EOS>
as
regarded
him
whose
suit
you
had
accepted
,
that
you
found
yourself
at
last
obliged
to
part
from
him
.
<EOS>
May
I
not
say
that
with
us
there
would
be
no
such
difference
?
<EOS>
It
is
because
I
believe
that
in
this
respect
we
are
fitted
for
each
other
,
as
man
and
woman
seldom
are
fitted
,
that
I
once
again
ask
you
to
be
my
wife
.
  
<EOS>
This
will
reach
you
at
Vavasor
,
where
you
will
now
be
with
the
old
squire
and
Kate
.
<EOS>
I
have
told
her
nothing
of
my
purpose
in
writing
this
letter
.
<EOS>
If
it
should
be
that
your
answer
is
such
as
I
desire
,
I
should
use
the
opportunity
of
our
re
-
engagement
to
endeavour
to
be
reconciled
to
my
grandfather
.
<EOS>
He
has
misunderstood
me
and
has
ill
-
used
me
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
ready
to
forgive
that
,
if
he
will
allow
me
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
In
such
case
you
and
Kate
would
arrange
that
,
and
I
would
,
if
possible
,
go
down
to
Vavasor
while
you
are
there
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
galloping
on
a
-
head
foolishly
in
thinking
of
this
,
and
am
counting
up
my
wealth
while
the
crockery
in
my
basket
is
so
very
fragile
.
<EOS>
One
word
from
you
will
decide
whether
or
no
I
shall
ever
bring
it
into
market
.
  
<EOS>
If
that
word
is
to
be
adverse
do
not
say
anything
of
a
meeting
between
me
and
the
Squire
.
<EOS>
Under
such
circumstances
it
would
be
impossible
.
<EOS>
But
,
oh
,
Alice
!
<EOS>
do
not
let
it
be
adverse
.
<EOS>
I
think
you
love
me
.
<EOS>
Your
woman
's
pride
towards
me
has
been
great
and
good
and
womanly
;
but
it
has
had
its
way
;
and
,
if
you
love
me
,
might
now
be
taught
to
succumb
.
  
<EOS>
Dear
Alice
,
will
you
be
my
wife
?
  
<EOS>
Yours
,
in
any
event
,
most
affectionately
,
  
GEORGE
VAVASOR
.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
when
he
had
finished
his
letter
,
went
back
to
his
seat
over
the
fire
,
and
there
he
sat
with
it
close
at
his
hand
for
nearly
an
hour
.
<EOS>
Once
or
twice
he
took
it
up
with
fingers
almost
itching
to
throw
it
into
the
fire
.
<EOS>
He
took
it
up
and
held
the
corners
between
his
forefinger
and
thumb
,
throwing
forward
his
hand
towards
the
flame
,
as
though
willing
that
the
letter
should
escape
from
him
and
perish
if
chance
should
so
decide
.
<EOS>
But
chance
did
not
so
decide
,
and
the
letter
was
put
back
upon
the
table
at
his
elbow
.
<EOS>
Then
when
the
hour
was
nearly
over
he
read
it
again
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
bet
two
to
one
that
she
gives
way
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
as
he
put
the
sheet
of
paper
back
into
the
envelope
.
"
<EOS>
Women
are
such
out
-
and
-
out
fools
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
took
his
candle
,
and
carrying
his
letter
with
him
,
went
into
his
bedroom
.
  
<EOS>
The
next
morning
was
the
morning
of
Christmas
Eve
.
<EOS>
At
about
nine
o'clock
a
boy
came
into
his
room
who
was
accustomed
to
call
for
orders
for
the
day
.
<EOS>
"
Jem
,
"
he
said
to
the
boy
,
"
there
's
half
a
crown
lying
there
on
the
looking
-
glass
.
"
<EOS>
Jem
looked
and
acknowledged
the
presence
of
the
half
-
crown
.
"
<EOS>
Is
it
a
head
or
a
tail
,
Jem
?
"
<EOS>
asked
the
boy
's
master
.
<EOS>
Jem
scrutinized
the
coin
,
and
declared
that
the
uppermost
surface
showed
a
tail
.
"
<EOS>
Then
take
that
letter
and
post
it
,
"
said
George
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Whereupon
Jem
,
asking
no
question
and
thinking
but
little
of
the
circumstances
under
which
the
command
was
given
,
did
take
the
letter
and
did
post
it
.
<EOS>
In
due
accordance
with
postal
regulations
it
reached
Vavasor
Hall
and
was
delivered
to
Alice
on
the
Christmas
morning
.
  
<EOS>
A
merry
<EOS>
Christmas
did
not
fall
to
the
lot
of
George
Vavasor
on
the
present
occasion
.
<EOS>
An
early
Christmas
-
box
he
did
receive
in
the
shape
of
a
very
hurried
note
from
his
friend
Burgo
.
<EOS>
"
This
will
be
brought
to
you
by
Stickling
,
"
the
note
said
;
but
who
Stickling
was
Vavasor
did
not
know
.
<EOS>
"
I
send
the
bill
.
<EOS>
Could
n't
you
get
the
money
and
send
it
me
,
as
I
do
n't
want
to
go
up
to
town
again
before
the
thing
comes
off
?
<EOS>
You
're
a
trump
;
and
will
do
the
best
you
can
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
that
rogue
off
for
less
than
a
hundred
and
twenty
.
 
<EOS>
Yours
,
B.
F.
"
Vavasor
,
therefore
,
having
nothing
better
to
do
,
spent
his
Christmas
morning
in
calling
on
Mr.
Magruin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
"
said
Magruin
;
"
really
this
is
no
morning
for
business
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Time
and
tide
wait
for
no
man
,
Mr.
Magruin
,
and
my
friend
wants
his
money
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
 
to
-
morrow
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
If
time
and
tide
wo
n't
wait
,
neither
will
love
.
<EOS>
Come
,
Mr.
Magruin
,
out
with
your
cheque
-
book
,
and
do
n't
let
's
have
any
nonsense
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
is
the
lady
sure
,
Mr.
Vavasor
?
"
asked
Mr.
Magruin
,
anxiously
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ladies
never
are
sure
,
"
said
Vavasor
;
"
hardly
more
sure
than
bills
made
over
to
money
-
lenders
.
<EOS>
I
'm
not
going
to
wait
here
all
day
.
<EOS>
Are
you
going
to
give
him
the
money
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Christmas
-
day
,
Mr.
Vavasor
!
<EOS>
There
's
no
getting
money
in
the
city
to
-
day
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
Vavasor
before
he
left
did
get
the
money
from
Mr.
Magruin
,
 
£
122
10s
.
 
<EOS>
for
which
an
acceptance
at
two
months
for
£
500
was
given
in
exchange
,
 
and
carried
it
off
in
triumph
.
<EOS>
"
Do
tell
him
to
be
punctual
,
"
said
Mr.
Magruin
,
when
Vavasor
took
his
leave
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
so
like
young
men
to
be
punctual
.
<EOS>
But
I
really
think
Mr.
Fitzgerald
is
the
most
unpunctual
young
man
I
ever
did
know
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
is
,
"
said
George
Vavasor
,
as
he
went
away
.
  
<EOS>
He
ate
his
Christmas
dinner
in
absolute
solitude
at
an
eating
-
house
near
his
lodgings
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
supposed
that
no
man
dares
to
dine
at
his
club
on
a
Christmas
Day
.
<EOS>
He
at
any
rate
did
not
so
dare
;
 
and
after
dinner
he
wandered
about
through
the
streets
,
wondering
within
his
mind
how
he
would
endure
the
restraints
of
married
life
.
<EOS>
And
the
same
dull
monotony
of
his
days
was
continued
for
a
week
,
during
which
he
waited
,
not
impatiently
,
for
an
answer
to
his
letter
.
<EOS>
And
before
the
end
of
the
week
the
answer
came
.
   
<EOS>
Among
the
Fells
.
 
<EOS>
Alice
came
down
to
breakfast
on
that
Christmas
morning
at
Vavasor
Hall
without
making
any
sign
as
to
the
letter
she
had
received
.
<EOS>
The
party
there
consisted
of
her
grandfather
,
her
father
,
her
cousin
Kate
,
and
herself
.
<EOS>
They
all
made
their
Christmas
salutations
as
is
usual
,
and
Alice
received
and
made
hers
as
did
the
others
,
without
showing
that
anything
had
occurred
to
disturb
her
tranquillity
.
<EOS>
Kate
remarked
that
she
had
heard
that
morning
from
Aunt
Greenow
,
and
promised
to
show
Alice
the
letter
after
breakfast
.
<EOS>
But
Alice
said
no
word
of
her
own
letter
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
did
n't
your
aunt
come
here
to
eat
her
Christmas
dinner
?
"
said
the
Squire
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
sir
,
because
you
did
n't
ask
her
,
"
said
Kate
,
standing
close
to
her
grandfather
,
 
for
the
old
man
was
somewhat
deaf
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
did
n't
you
ask
her
;
 
that
is
,
if
she
stands
upon
asking
to
come
to
her
old
home
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nay
,
sir
,
but
I
could
n't
do
that
without
your
bidding
.
<EOS>
We
Vavasors
are
not
always
fond
of
meeting
each
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hold
your
tongue
,
Kate
.
<EOS>
I
know
what
you
mean
,
and
you
should
be
the
last
to
speak
of
it
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
my
dear
,
come
and
sit
next
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
much
obliged
to
you
for
coming
down
all
this
way
to
see
your
old
grandfather
at
Christmas
.
<EOS>
I
am
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
only
wish
you
had
brought
better
news
about
your
sweetheart
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
'll
think
better
of
it
before
long
,
sir
,
"
said
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
Papa
,
you
should
n't
say
that
.
<EOS>
You
would
not
wish
me
to
marry
against
my
own
judgement
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
much
about
ladies
"
judgements
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
It
does
seem
to
me
that
when
a
lady
makes
a
promise
she
ought
to
keep
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
According
to
that
,
"
said
Kate
,
"
if
I
were
engaged
to
a
man
,
and
found
that
he
was
a
murderer
,
I
still
ought
to
marry
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
Mr.
Grey
is
not
a
murderer
,
"
said
the
Squire
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
 
pray
,
do
n't
talk
about
it
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
I
really
can
not
sit
and
hear
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
given
over
saying
anything
on
the
subject
,
"
said
John
Vavasor
,
speaking
as
though
he
had
already
expended
upon
it
a
vast
amount
of
paternal
eloquence
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
however
,
never
said
more
than
has
been
recorded
in
these
pages
.
<EOS>
Alice
during
this
conversation
,
sat
with
her
cousin
's
letter
in
her
pocket
,
and
as
yet
had
not
even
begun
to
think
what
should
be
the
nature
of
her
reply
.
  
<EOS>
The
Squire
of
Vavasor
Hall
was
a
stout
old
man
,
with
a
red
face
and
grey
eyes
,
which
looked
fiercely
at
you
,
and
with
long
grey
hair
,
and
a
rough
grey
beard
,
which
gave
him
something
of
the
appearance
of
an
old
lion
.
<EOS>
He
was
passionate
,
unreasoning
,
and
specially
impatient
of
all
opposition
;
but
he
was
affectionate
,
prone
to
forgive
when
asked
to
do
so
,
unselfish
,
and
hospitable
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
moreover
,
guided
strictly
by
rules
,
which
he
believed
to
be
rules
of
right
.
<EOS>
His
grandson
George
had
offended
him
very
deeply
,
 
had
offended
him
and
never
asked
his
pardon
.
<EOS>
He
was
determined
that
such
pardon
should
never
be
given
,
unless
it
were
asked
for
with
almost
bended
knees
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
this
grandson
should
be
his
heir
.
<EOS>
That
was
his
present
intention
.
<EOS>
The
right
of
primogeniture
could
not
,
in
accordance
with
his
theory
,
be
abrogated
by
the
fact
that
it
was
,
in
George
Vavasor
's
case
,
protected
by
no
law
.
<EOS>
The
Squire
could
leave
Vavasor
Hall
to
whom
he
pleased
,
but
he
could
not
have
hoped
to
rest
quietly
in
his
grave
<EOS>
should
it
be
found
that
he
had
left
it
to
any
one
but
the
eldest
son
of
his
own
eldest
son
.
<EOS>
Though
violent
,
and
even
stern
,
he
was
more
prone
to
love
than
to
anger
;
and
though
none
of
those
around
him
dared
to
speak
to
him
of
his
grandson
,
yet
he
longed
in
his
heart
for
some
opportunity
of
being
reconciled
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
whole
party
went
to
church
on
this
Christmas
morning
.
<EOS>
The
small
parish
church
of
Vavasor
,
an
unpretending
wooden
structure
,
with
a
single
bell
which
might
be
heard
tinkling
for
a
mile
or
two
over
the
fells
,
stood
all
alone
about
half
a
mile
from
the
Squire
's
gate
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
was
a
parish
situated
on
the
intermediate
ground
between
the
mountains
of
the
lake
country
and
the
plains
.
<EOS>
Its
land
was
unproductive
,
ill
-
drained
,
and
poor
,
and
yet
it
possessed
little
or
none
of
the
beauty
which
tourists
go
to
see
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
amidst
the
fells
,
and
very
dreary
.
<EOS>
There
were
long
skirtings
of
dark
pines
around
a
portion
of
the
Squire
's
property
,
and
at
the
back
of
the
house
there
was
a
thick
wood
of
firs
running
up
to
the
top
of
what
was
there
called
the
Beacon
Hill
.
<EOS>
Through
this
there
was
a
wild
steep
walk
which
came
out
upon
the
moorland
,
and
from
thence
there
was
a
track
across
the
mountain
to
Hawes
Water
and
Naddale
,
and
on
over
many
miles
to
the
further
beauties
of
Bowness
and
Windermere
.
<EOS>
They
who
knew
the
country
,
and
whose
legs
were
of
use
to
them
,
could
find
some
of
the
grandest
scenery
in
England
within
reach
of
a
walk
from
Vavasor
Hall
;
but
to
others
the
place
was
very
desolate
.
<EOS>
For
myself
,
I
can
find
I
know
not
what
of
charm
in
wandering
over
open
,
unadorned
moorland
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
more
in
the
softness
of
the
grass
to
the
feet
,
and
the
freshness
of
the
air
to
the
lungs
,
than
in
anything
that
meets
the
eye
.
<EOS>
You
might
walk
for
miles
and
miles
to
the
north
-
east
,
or
east
,
or
south
-
east
of
Vavasor
without
meeting
any
object
to
arrest
the
view
.
<EOS>
The
great
road
from
Lancaster
to
Carlisle
crossed
the
outskirts
of
the
small
parish
about
a
mile
from
the
church
,
and
beyond
that
the
fell
seemed
to
be
interminable
.
<EOS>
Towards
the
north
it
rose
,
and
towards
the
south
it
fell
,
and
it
rose
and
fell
very
gradually
.
<EOS>
Here
and
there
some
slight
appearance
of
a
valley
might
be
traced
which
had
been
formed
by
the
action
of
the
waters
;
but
such
breakings
of
ground
were
inconsiderable
,
and
did
not
suffice
to
interrupt
the
stern
sameness
of
the
everlasting
moorland
.
  
<EOS>
The
daily
life
at
Vavasor
was
melancholy
enough
for
such
a
one
as
the
Squire
's
son
,
who
regarded
London
as
the
only
place
on
the
earth
's
surface
in
which
a
man
could
live
with
comfort
.
<EOS>
The
moors
offered
no
charms
to
him
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
he
much
appreciate
the
homely
comforts
of
the
Hall
;
for
the
house
,
though
warm
,
was
old
-
fashioned
and
small
,
and
the
Squire
's
cook
was
nearly
as
old
as
the
Squire
himself
.
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
's
visits
to
Vavasor
were
always
visits
of
duty
rather
than
of
pleasure
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
so
with
Alice
.
<EOS>
She
could
be
very
happy
there
with
Kate
;
for
,
like
herself
,
Kate
was
a
good
walker
and
loved
the
mountains
.
<EOS>
Their
regard
for
each
other
had
grown
and
become
strong
because
they
had
gone
together
o'er
river
and
moor
,
and
because
they
had
together
disregarded
those
impediments
of
mud
and
wet
which
frighten
so
many
girls
away
from
the

of

.
  
<EOS>
On
this
Christmas
Day
they
all
went
to
church
,
the
Squire
being
accompanied
by
Alice
in
a
vehicle
which
in
Ireland
is
called
an
inside
jaunting
-
car
,
and
which
is
perhaps
the
most
uncomfortable
kind

vehicle
yet
invented
;
while
John
Vavasor
walked
with
his
niece
.
<EOS>
But
the
girls
had
arranged
that
immediately

they
would

for
a

up
the
Beacon
Hill
,
across
the
fells
,
towards
Hawes
Water
.
<EOS>
They
always
dined
at
the
Hall
at
the
vexatious

of
five
;
but
as
their
church
service
,
with
the

,
would
be
completed
soon
after
twelve
,
and
as
lunch
was
a
meal
which
the
Squire
did
not
himself
attend
,
they
could
have
full
four
hours
for
their
excursion
.
<EOS>
This
had
all
been
planned
before
Alice
received
her
letter
;
but
there
was
nothing
in
that
to
make

change
her
mind
about

.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
my
dear
,
"

old
man
to

when

in

,
"
you
ought
to
get
married
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Squire
was
hard
of
hearing
,
and
under
any
circumstances
an
inside
jaunting
-
car
is
a
bad

for
conversation
,
as
your

are
nearly

.
<EOS>
Alice

nothing
,
but

,
in

.
<EOS>
On

,

that

.
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
You

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Gentlemen
wo

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"
We
sha

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

;
"
<EOS>
but

the

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Do

,

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>
And

soaking

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

!
<EOS>
That

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

;
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

wo

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then

,

.
<EOS>
It

hitherto

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

<EOS>
"

"

,
 
<EOS>
that

,

.
<EOS>
You
ca

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice

,

.
<EOS>
Poor
Bellfield
was
working
very

at

,
Mrs.
Greenow
went
on

;
so

that
sometimes

.
<EOS>
He
would
come

of
an

just

;
 
generally
on

and

.
<EOS>
"
These
are
not
market

at
Norwich
,
"
said
Kate
;
"
and
thus

are

.
"
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

,
"
and
takes

;
and
sometimes
I

that

will

.
"
<EOS>
"
That

on

,
"

,
"
and

his

twice

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Really
I
do
n't

what

.
<EOS>
Sometimes

that
she
likes

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
That
's
her

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>
I

.
"
<EOS>
"

?
"

;
"
with

I

.
<EOS>
I
think
she
'd
lend

money
without

.
"
<EOS>
Then
Aunt
Greenow
's
letter
was
put
up
,
and
the
two
girls
had
come
out
upon
the
open

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
delicious
afternoon
for
a
winter
's
walk
.
<EOS>
The
air
was
clear
and
cold
,
but
not
actually
frosty
.
<EOS>
The
ground
beneath
their
feet
was
dry
,
and
the
sky
,
though
not
bright
,
had
that
appearance
of
enduring
weather
which
gives
no
foreboding
of
rain
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
special
winter
's
light
,
which
is
very
clear
though
devoid
of
all
brilliancy
,
 
through
which
every
object
strikes
upon
the
eye
with
well
-
marked
lines
,
and
under
which
almost
all
forms
of
nature
seem
graceful
to
the
sight
if
not
actually
beautiful
.
<EOS>
But
there
is
a
certain
melancholy
which
ever
accompanies
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
light
of
the
afternoon
,
and
gives
token
of
the
speedy
coming
of
the
early
twilight
.
<EOS>
It
tells
of
the
shortness
of
the
day
,
and
contains
even
in
its
clearness
a
promise
of
the
gloom
of
night
.
<EOS>
It
is
absolute
light
,
but
it
seems
to
contain
the
darkness
which
is
to
follow
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
it
is
ever
to
be
seen
and
felt
so
plainly
as
on
the
wide
moorland
,
where
the
eye
stretches
away
over
miles
,
and
sees
at
the
world
's
end
the
faint
low
lines
of
distant
clouds
settling
themselves
upon
the
horizon
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
light
of
this
Christmas
afternoon
,
and
both
the
girls
had
felt
the
effects
of
it
before
they
reached
the
big
stone
on
Swindale
Fell
,
from
which
they
intended
to
look
down
upon
the
loveliness
of
Hawes
Water
.
<EOS>
As
they
went
up
through
the
wood
there
had
been
some
laughter
between
them
over
Aunt
Greenow
's
letter
;
and
they
had
discussed
almost
with
mirth
the
merits
of
Oileymead
and
Mr.
Cheesacre
;
but
as
they
got
further
on
to
the
fell
,
and
as

half
-

wildness
of
the
place
struck
them
,
their
words
became
less
light
,
and
after
a
while
they
almost
ceased
to
speak
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
still
her
letter
in
her
pocket
.
<EOS>
She
had
placed
it
there
when
she
came
down

,
and
had

.
<EOS>
She

as
to

,

Kate
.
<EOS>
Kate

ever

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>
This

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

.

an

promise
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
no
<EOS>
;
I
want
nothing
of
the
kind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
yet
I
could
not
deny
myself
the
comfort
of
your
friendship
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Alice
,
I
will
not
hurry
you
.
<EOS>
I
will
do
nothing
that
you
do
not
wish
.
<EOS>
But
you
can
not
be
surprised
that
I
should
be
very
eager
.
<EOS>
Has
it
not
been
the
longing
of
all
my
life
?
<EOS>
Have
I
not
passed
my
time
plotting
and
planning
and
thinking
of
it
till
I
have
had
time
to
think
of
nothing
else
?
<EOS>
Do
you
know
what
I
suffered
when
,
through
George
's
fault
,
the
engagement
was
broken
off
?
<EOS>
Was
it
not
martyrdom
to
me
,
 
that
horrid
time
in
which
your
Crichton
from
Cambridgeshire
was
in
the
ascendant
?
<EOS>
Did
I
not
suffer
the
tortures
of
purgatory
while
that
went
on
;
 
and
yet
,
on
the
whole
,
did
I
not
bear
them
with

?
<EOS>
And
,
now
,
can
you
be

that
I
am
wild
with
joy
when
I
begin
to
see
that
everything
will
be
as
I
wish
;
 
<EOS>
for
it
will
be
as
I
wish
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
It
may

that
you
have
not

.
<EOS>
But
you
would
have
resolved

instantly
had
<EOS>
that

.
<EOS>
"

,

,
Kate

:
"
You
will
not

without

?
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
at

,
not

,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
let
me

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
"
said

;
"
I
will
not

that
.
<EOS>
But
if

I
will
show
it
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
shall
never

,
"

Kate
,

.
<EOS>
"
But
that
is

.
<EOS>
I

love
-

that

.
<EOS>
I

will

.
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
<EOS>
how
I

!
"
  
<EOS>
Then
they
were
at
home
;
and
the
old
man
met

at
the
front

,
glowering

angrily
from
out
his
old

,
because
the
roast

was
already

.
<EOS>
He
had
his

uncouth

in

,
which
was
always

quarter

an

,
and

,

the
minute

at

past

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
grandpapa
,
you
are
always

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

miss
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,

not

.
<EOS>
Is

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
ten

;
 
are

,
Alice
?
<EOS>
And
,
grandpapa
,
pray
do
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
wait
!
<EOS>
That
's

they
always

"
he

,

"
<EOS>
As

on

table
.
<EOS>
"
But

.
  
<EOS>
Nothing

Kate
about

;
but

,

just

<EOS>
"
Pray

,
"

,
"
as

love

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
made
no
answer
,
but
we
may
believe
that
she
did
as
she
was
desired
to
do
.
   
<EOS>
Containing
an
Answer
to
the
Love
Letter
.
 
<EOS>
Alice
had
had
a
week
allowed
to
her
to
write
her

;
but
she
sent

off
before

.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
keep
him
in

?
"
<EOS>
she

.
<EOS>
"
If

is
to

so
,

.
"
<EOS>
Then

,

it

Mr.
Grey
that

.
<EOS>
She
had
treated
him
badly
,
 
very

.
<EOS>
She

that
the

;

.
<EOS>
She

.
"
<EOS>
He

,
"

.
<EOS>
But

deceived

.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
in

Love
could
be
very
passionate
;
 
and
was
,
moreover
,
one

could

.
  
<EOS>
Each

whether

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
"

;
 
for

illuminated
Vavasor
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
given

,
"

<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Kate

.
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
But

!
 
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

;

,
much

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

.
"
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
Mercury
,

,

.
<EOS>
And
,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
It

;

six
months
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

"

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

?
<EOS>
Kate
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
And

.
"

"

.
<EOS>

?
"

"

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Exactly
;
 
and

that

whenever

.
"
  
<EOS>
Kate
was
very

in
her

to

till
George
's

came
.
<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
She

;
but

;

her

's

.
<EOS>
But
her

's
letter
for
the

stopped

.
<EOS>
It
would
be
necessary
that
she
should

again

.
  
<EOS>
In

Alice
had

it

reader

,

of

;

,

I

to

of
George
Vavasor
's

as
he

.
<EOS>
George
's

was
very

.
<EOS>
He

of

,

.
<EOS>
He

,
 
and

_
carte

blanche
_
to

.
<EOS>
If

any
kind

,

,
 
and

,

,
he
,
George
,
would
,

,

.
<EOS>
He
would

as
a
simple

,

by

.
<EOS>
As

's

,

her
heartily
for
her
confidence
.
<EOS>
If
the
nature
of
his
coming
contest
at
Chelsea
should
make
it
necessary
,
he
would
use
her
offer
as
frankly
as
it
had
been
made
.
<EOS>
Such
was
his
letter
to
Alice
.
<EOS>
What
was
contained
in
his
letter
to
Kate
,
Alice
never
knew
.
  
<EOS>
Then
came
the
business
of
telling
this
new
love
tale
,
 
<EOS>
the
third
which
poor
Alice
had
been
forced
to
tell
her
father
and
grandfather
;
 
and
a
grievous
task
it
was
.
<EOS>
In
this
matter
she
feared
her
father
much
more
than
her
grandfather
,
and
therefore
she
resolved
to
tell
her
grandfather
first
;
 
or
,
rather
,
she
determined
that
she
would
tell
the
Squire
,
and
that
in
the
mean
time
Kate
should
talk
to
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
Grandpapa
,
"
she
said
to
him
the
morning
after
she
had
received
her
cousin
's
second
letter
.
 
<EOS>
The
old
man
was
in
the
habit
of
breakfasting
alone
in
a
closet
of
his
own
,
which
was
called
his
dressing
-
room
,
but
in
which
he
kept
no
appurtenances
for
dressing
,
but
in
lieu
of
them
a
large
collection
of
old
spuds
and
sticks
and
horse's
-
bits
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
broken
spade
here
,
and
a
hoe
or
two
;
and
a
small
table
in
the
corner
was
covered
with
the
debris
of
tradesmen
's
bills
from
Penrith
,
and
dirty
scraps
which
he
was
wo
nt
to
call
his
farm
accounts
.
 
<EOS>
"
Grandpapa
,
"
said
Alice
,
rushing
away
at
once
into
the
middle
of
her
subject
,
"
you
told
me
the
other
day
that
you
thought
I
ought
to
be
 
married
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
Well
,
yes
;
so
I
did
.
<EOS>
And
so
you
ought
;
 
I
mean
to
that
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
impossible
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
what
's
the
use
of
your
coming
and
talking
to
me
about
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
This
made
Alice
's
task
not
very
easy
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
she
persevered
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
come
,
grandpapa
,
to
tell
you
of
another
engagement
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Another
!
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
And
by
the
tone
of
his
voice
he
accused
his
granddaughter
of
having
a
larger
number
of
favoured
suitors
than
ought
to
fall
to
the
lot
of
any
young
lady
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
hard
upon
her
,
but
still
she
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
"
said
she
,
"
that
some
years
ago
I
was
to
have
been
married
to
my
cousin
George
;
"
 
and
then
she
paused
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
the
old
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
remember
you
told
me
then
that
you
were
much
pleased
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
was
.
<EOS>
George
was
doing
well
then
;
or
,
 
which
is
more
likely
,
 
had
made
us
believe
that
he
was
doing
well
.
<EOS>
Have
you
made
it
up
with
him
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
that
's
the
meaning
of
your
jilting
Mr.
Grey
,
is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Alice
!
<EOS>
It
is
hard
to
explain
how
heavy
a
blow
fell
upon
her
from
the
open
utterance
of
that
word
!
<EOS>
Of
all
words
in
the
language
it
was
the
one
which
she
now
most
dreaded
.
<EOS>
She
had
called
herself
a
jilt
,
with
that
inaudible
voice
which
one
uses
in
making
self
-
accusations
;
 
but
hitherto
no
lips
had
pronounced
the
odious
word
to
her
ears
.
<EOS>
Poor
Alice
!
<EOS>
She
was
a
jilt
;
and
perhaps
it
may
have
been
well
that
the
old
man
should
tell
her
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
Grandpapa
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
;
and
there
was
that
in
the
tone
of
her
voice
which
somewhat
softened
the
Squire
's
heart
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
,
I
do
n't
want
to
be
ill
-
natured
.
<EOS>
So
you
are
going
at
last
to
marry
George
,
are
you
?
<EOS>
I
hope
he
'll
treat
you
well
;
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
Does
your
father
approve
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
told
you
first
,
sir
;
 
because
I
wish
to
obtain
your
consent
to
seeing
George
again
here
as
your
grandson
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
snarling
;
 
"
never
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
he
has
been
wrong
,
he
will
beg
your
pardon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
he
has
been
wrong
!
<EOS>
Did
n't
he
want
to
squander
every
shilling
of
the
property
,
 
property
which
has
never
belonged
to
him
;
 
property
which
I
could
give
to
Tom
,
Dick
,
or
Harry
to
-
morrow
,
if
I
liked
?
 
<EOS>
If
he
has
been
wrong
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
defending
him
,
sir
;
 
but
I
thought
that
,
perhaps
,
on
such
an
occasion
as
this
 
"
  
"
A
Tom
Fool
's
occasion
!
<EOS>
You
've
got
money
of
your
own
.
<EOS>
He
'll
spend
all
that
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
will
be
less
likely
to
do
so
if
you
will
recognise
him
as
your
heir
.
<EOS>
Pray
believe
,
sir
,
that
he
is
not
the
sort
of
man
that
he
was
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
must
be
a
very
clever
sort
of
man
,
I
think
,
when
he
has
talked
you
out
of
such
a
husband
as
John
Grey
.
<EOS>
It
's
astounding
to
me
,
 
with
that
ugly
mug
of
his
!
<EOS>
Well
,
my
dear
,
if
your
father
approves
of
it
,
and
if
George
will
ask
my
pardon
,
 
but
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
he
ever
will
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
will
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
am
his
messenger
for
as
much
as
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
are
,
are
you
?
<EOS>
Then
you
may
also
be
my
messenger
to
him
,
and
tell
him
that
,
for
your
sake
,
I
will
let
him
come
back
here
.
<EOS>
I
know
he
'll
insult
me
the
first
day
;
but
I
'll
try
and
put
up
with
it
,
 
for
your
sake
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
must
know
what
your
father
thinks
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
may
be
imagined
that
Kate
's
success
was
even
less
than
that
which
Alice
achieved
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
it
would
be
so
,
"
said
John
Vavasor
,
when
his
niece
first
told
him
;
 
<EOS>
and
as
he
spoke
he
struck
his
hand
upon
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
I
knew
all
along
how
it
would
be
.
"
  
"
And
why
should
it
not
be
so
,
Uncle
John
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
your
brother
,
and
I
will
not
tell
you
why
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
think
that
he
is
a
spendthrift
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
that
he
is
as
unsafe
a
man
as
ever
<EOS>
I
knew
to
be
intrusted
with
the
happiness
of
any
young
woman
.
<EOS>
That
is
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
hard
upon
him
,
uncle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
so
.
<EOS>
Tell
Alice
this
from
me
,
 
that
as
I
have
never
yet
been
able
to
get
her
to
think
anything
of
my
opinion
,
I
do
not
at
all
expect
that
I
shall
be
able
to
induce
her
to
do
so
now
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
even
make
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
As
my
son
-
in
-
law
I
will
not
receive
George
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Tell
Alice
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
was
told
her
father
's
message
;
but
Kate
in
telling
it
felt
no
deep
regret
.
<EOS>
She
well
knew
that
Alice
would
not
be
turned
back
from
her
present
intention
by
her
father
's
wishes
.
<EOS>
Nor
would
it
have
been
very
reasonable
that
she
should
.
<EOS>
Her
father
had
for
many
years
relieved
himself
from
the
burden
of
a
father
's
cares
,
and
now
had
hardly
the
right
to
claim
a
father
's
privileges
.
  
<EOS>
We
will
now
go
once
again
to
George
Vavasor
's
room
in
Cecil
Street
,
in
which
he
received
Alice
's
letter
.
<EOS>
He
was
dressing
when
it
was
first
brought
to
him
;
and
when
he
recognised
the
handwriting
he
put
it
down
on
his
toilet
table
unopened
.
<EOS>
He
put
it
down
,
and
went
on
brushing
his
hair
,
as
though
he
were
determined
to
prove
to
himself
that
he
was
indifferent
as
to
the
tidings
which
it
might
contain
.
<EOS>
He
went
on
brushing
his
hair
,
and
cleaning
his
teeth
,
and
tying
his
cravat
carefully
over
his
turned
-
down
collar
,
while
the
unopened
letter
lay
close
to
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
was
thinking
of
it
,
 
<EOS>
of
course
he
was
anxious
,
 
<EOS>
of
course
his
eye
went
to
it
from
moment
to
moment
.
<EOS>
But
he
carried
it
with
him
into
the
sitting
-
room
still
unopened
,
and
so
it
remained
until
after
the
girl
had
brought
him
his
tea
and
his
toast
.
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
said
he
,
as
he
threw
himself
into
his
arm
-
chair
,
"
let
us
see
what
the
girl
of
my
heart
says
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
The
girl
of
his
heart
said
to
him
as
follows
:
    
MY
DEAR
GEORGE
,
  
<EOS>
I
feel
great
difficulty
in
answering
your
letter
.
<EOS>
Could
I
have
my
own
way
,
I
should
make
no
answer
to
it
at
present
,
but
leave
it
for
the
next
six
months
,
so
that
then
such
answer
might
hereafter
be
made
as
circumstances
should
seem
to
require
.
<EOS>
This
will
be
little
flattering
to
you
,
but
it
is
less
flattering
to
myself
.
<EOS>
Whatever
answer
I
may
make
,
how
can
anything
in
this
affair
be
flattering
either
to
you
or
to
me
?
<EOS>
We
have
been
like
children
who
have
quarrelled
over
our
game
of
play
,
till
now
,
at
the
close
of
our
little
day
of
pleasure
,
we
are
fain
to
meet
each
other
in
tears
,
and
acknowledge
that
we
have
looked
for
delights
where
no
delights
were
to
be
found
.
  
<EOS>
Kate
,
who
is
here
,
talks
to
me
of
passionate
love
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
such
passion
left
to
me
;
 
nor
,
as
I
think
,
to
you
either
.
<EOS>
It
would
not
now
be
possible
that
you
and
I
should
come
together
on
such
terms
as
that
.
<EOS>
We
could
not
stand
up
together
as
man
and
wife
with
any
hope
of
a
happy
marriage
,
unless
we
had
both
agreed
that
such
happiness
might
be
had
without
passionate
love
.
  
<EOS>
You
will
see
from
all
this
that
I
do
not
refuse
your
offer
.
<EOS>
Without
passion
,
I
have
for
you
a
warm
affection
,
which
enables
me
to
take
a
livelier
interest
in
your
career
than
in
any
other
of
the
matters
which
are
around
me
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
if
I
become
your
wife
that
interest
will
be
still
closer
and
dearer
,
and
I
do
feel
that
I
can
take
in
it
that
concern
which
a
wife
should
have
in
her
husband
's
affairs
.
  
<EOS>
If
it
suits
you
,
I
will
become
your
wife
;
 
but
it
can
not
be
quite
at
once
.
<EOS>
I
have
suffered
much
from
the
past
conflicts
of
my
life
,
and
there
has
been
very
much
with
which
I
must
reproach
myself
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
I
have
behaved
badly
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
I
have
to
undergo
the
doubly
bitter
self
-
accusation
of
having
behaved
in
a
manner
which
the
world
will
call
unfeminine
.
<EOS>
You
must
understand
that
I
have
not
passed
through
this
unscathed
,
and
I
must
beg
you
to
allow
me
some
time
for
a
cure
.
<EOS>
A
perfect
cure
<EOS>
I
may
never
expect
,
but
I
think
that
in
twelve
months
from
this
time
I
may
so
far
have
recovered
my
usual
spirit
and
ease
of
mind
as
to
enable
me
to
devote
myself
to
your
happiness
.
<EOS>
Dear
George
,
if
you
will
accept
me
under
such
circumstances
,
I
will
be
your
wife
,
and
will
endeavour
to
do
my
duty
by
you
faithfully
.
  
<EOS>
I
have
said
that
even
now
,
as
your
cousin
,
I
take
a
lively
interest
in
your
career
,
 
of
course
<EOS>
I
mean
your
career
as
a
politician
,
 
and
especially
in
your
hopes
of
entering
Parliament
.
<EOS>
I
understand
,
accurately
as
I
think
,
what
you
have
said
about
my
fortune
,
and
I
perfectly
appreciate
your
truth
and
frankness
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
nothing
of
my
own
you
,
in
your
circumstances
,
could
not
possibly
take
me
as
your
wife
.
<EOS>
I
know
,
moreover
,
that
your
need
of
assistance
from
my
means
is
immediate
rather
than
prospective
.
<EOS>
My
money
may
be
absolutely
necessary
to
you
within
this
year
,
during
which
,
as
I
tell
you
most
truly
,
I
can
not
bring
myself
to
become
a
married
woman
.
<EOS>
But
my
money
shall
be
less
cross
-
grained
than
myself
.
<EOS>
You
will
take
it
as
frankly
as
I
mean
it
when
I
say
,
that
whatever
you
want
for
your
political
purposes
shall
be
forthcoming
at
your
slightest
wish
.
<EOS>
Dear
George
,
let
me
have
the
honour
and
glory
of
marrying
a
man
who
has
gained
a
seat
in
the
Parliament
of
Great
Britain
!
<EOS>
Of
all
positions
which
a
man
may
attain
that
,
to
me
,
is
the
grandest
.
  
<EOS>
I
shall
wait
for
a
further
letter
from
you
before
I
speak
either
to
my
father
or
to
my
grandfather
.
<EOS>
If
you
can
tell
me
that
you
accede
to
my
views
,
I
will
at
once
try
to
bring
about
a
reconciliation
between
you
and
the
Squire
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
that
will
be
almost
easier
than
inducing
my
father
to
look
with
favour
upon
our
marriage
.
<EOS>
But
I
need
hardly
say
that
should
either
one
or
the
other
oppose
it
,
 
or
should
both
do
so
,
 
that
would
not
turn
me
from
my
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
I
also
wait
for
your
answer
to
write
a
last
line
to
Mr.
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
Your
affectionate
cousin
,
  
ALICE
VAVASOR
.
  
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
when
he
had
read
the
letter
threw
it
carelessly
from
him
on
to
the
breakfast
table
,
and
began
to

.
<EOS>
He
threw
it
carelessly
from
him
,
as
though
taking
a
certain

in

.
"
<EOS>
Very
well
,
"
said

;
"
so

.
<EOS>
It
is
probably

,
whatever
the
effect
may

on
her
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
took

his
newspaper
.
<EOS>
But

was
over
he
had
made
many

,

almost

,
 
as
to
the
benefit

.
<EOS>
And

had

of

;
and
had

his

a
letter
,
of
which
Kate
had
kept

contents
to

.
   
<EOS>
Monkshade
.
 
<EOS>
When
the
first
of
the
new
year
came
round
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
not
keeping
her
appointment
at
Lady
Monk
's
house
.
<EOS>
She
went
to
Gatherum
Castle
,
and
let
us
hope
that
she
enjoyed
the
magnificent
Christmas

of
the
Duke
;
but
when

came
for
moving
on
to
Monkshade
,
she
was

,
and
Mr.
Palliser
went

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
returned
to
Matching
and
remained
at
home
,
while
her
husband
was
away
,
in
company
with
the
two
Miss
Pallisers
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
tidings
reached
Monkshade
that
Lady
Glencora
was
not
to
be
expected
,
Burgo
Fitzgerald
was
already
there
,
armed
with
such
pecuniary
assistance
as
George
Vavasor
had
been
able
to
wrench
out
of
the
hands

Mr.
Magruin
.
<EOS>
"
Burgo
,
"
said
his
aunt
,
catching
him
one
morning
near
his
bedroom
door
as
he

stairs
in
hunting

,
"
Burgo
,
your
old
flame
,
Lady
Glencora
,
is
not
coming
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lady
Glencora
not
coming
!
"
<EOS>
said
Burgo
,
betraying
by
his
look
and
the
tone
of
his
voice
too
clearly
that
this
change
in
the
purpose
of
a
married
lady
was
to

of
more
importance
than
it
should

been
.
<EOS>
Such

,
however
,
to

was

much

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
;
she
is
not
coming
.
<EOS>
It
ca

be
matter
of
any
moment
to
you
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,

,
it
is
,
"
said

,

,
and

the

.
<EOS>
"
It
is
matter
of
moment
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
the
most

devil
that
ever

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fie
,
Burgo
,
fie
!
<EOS>
You
must
not

in
that
way
of
a
married
woman
.
<EOS>
I
begin
to
think
it
is
better
that
she
should
not

.
"
<EOS>
At
this
moment
another
man
booted

,
upon
whom
Lady
Monk
smiled

,
speaking
some
pretty
little
word
as
he
passed
.
<EOS>
Burgo
spoke
never
a
word
,
but
still
stood
leaning
against
the
wall
,
with
his
hand
to
his
forehead
,
showing
that
he
had
heard
something
which
had
moved

greatly
.
<EOS>
"
Come
back
into
your
room
,
Burgo
,
"

;
and

in

,
for

had

on

,

.
<EOS>
"
If

,

!
<EOS>
What
will

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I

what

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you

,
I

?
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
If

I

in

.
"
  
<EOS>
Burgo

for
a

into
his
aunt
's
face
without

her
,
and
then
turned

.
<EOS>
"
You

do

,
"

;
"
but
you
know

I

I

do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
Burgo
;
I
know
nothing

the
kind
.
<EOS>
But
do

go
down

stairs
to
breakfast
,
and
do
n't
look
like
that
when
you
go

there
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
was
a
woman
now
about
fifty
years
of
age
,
who
had
been
a
great
beauty
,
and
who
was
still
handsome
in
her
advanced
age
.
<EOS>
Her
figure
was
very
good
.
<EOS>
She
was
tall
and
of
fine
proportion
,
though
by
no
means
verging
to
that
state
of
body
which
our
excellent
American
friend
and
critic
Mr.
Hawthorne
has
described
as
beefy
and
has
declared
to
be
the
general
condition
of
English
ladies
of
Lady
Monk
's
age
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
was
not
beefy
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
comely
,
handsome
,
upright
,
dame
,
 
one
of
whom
,
as
regards
her
outward
appearance
,
England
might
be
proud
,
 
and
of
whom
Sir
Cosmo
Monk
was
very
proud
.
<EOS>
She
had
come
of
the
family
of
the
Worcestershire
Fitzgeralds
,
of
whom
it
used
to
be
said
that
there
never
was
one
who
was
not
beautiful
and
worthless
.
<EOS>
Looking
at
Lady
Monk
you
would
hardly
think
that
she
could
be
a
worthless
woman
;
but
there
were
one
or
two
who
professed
to
know
her
,
and
who
declared
that
she
was
a
true
scion
of
the
family
to
which
she
belonged
;
 
that
even
her
husband
's
ample
fortune
had
suffered
from
her
extravagance
,
that
she
had
quarrelled
with
her
only
son
,
and
had
succeeded
in
marrying
her
daughter
to
the
greatest
fool
in
the
peerage
.
<EOS>
She
had
striven
very
hard
to
bring
about
a
marriage
between
her
nephew
and
the
great
heiress
,
and
was
a
woman
not
likely
to
pardon
those
who
had
foiled
her
.
  
<EOS>
At
this
moment
Burgo
felt
very
certain
that
his
aunt
was
aware
of
his
purpose
,
and
could
not
forgive
her
for
pretending
to
be
innocent
of
it
.
<EOS>
In
this
he
was
most
ungrateful
,
as
well
as
unreasonable
,
 
and
very
indiscreet
also
.
<EOS>
Had
he
been
a
man
who
ever
reflected
he
must
have
known
that
such
a
woman
as
his
aunt
could
only
assist
him
as
long
as
she
might
be
presumed
to
be

of
his
intention
.
<EOS>
But
Burgo
never
reflected
.
<EOS>
The
Fitzgeralds
never
reflected
till
they
were
nearer
forty
than
thirty
,
and
then
people
began
to
think
worse
of
them
than
they
had
thought
before
.
  
<EOS>
When
Burgo
reached
the
dining
-
room
there
were
many
men
there
,
but
no
ladies
.
<EOS>
Sir
Cosmo
Monk
,
a
fine
bald
-
headed
hale
man
of
about

,
was
standing
up
at
the

,
cutting
a
huge
game
pie
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
also
who
did
not
reflect
much
,
but
who
contrived
to
keep
straight
in
his
course
through
the
world
without
much
reflection
.
<EOS>
"
Palliser
is
coming
without
her
,
"
he
said
in
his
loud
clear
voice
,
thinking
nothing
of

wife
's

.
<EOS>
"
She
's
ill
,
she
says
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
'm
sorry
for
it
,
"
said
one
man
.
<EOS>
"
She
's
a
deal
the
better
fellow
of

two
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
twice
more
go
in

than
Planty
Pall
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Planty
is
no

,
I

,
"
said
Sir
Cosmo
,
coming

with
his

full
of

.
<EOS>
"
We
think
he
's
about
the
most
rising
man
we

.
"
<EOS>
Sir
Cosmo
was
the
member
for
his

,
and
was
a
Liberal
.
<EOS>
He
had
once
,
when
a
much

,
been
at

Treasury
,
and
had
since
always
spoken
of

Whig

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
Burgo
,

?
"

man
,
 
a

,

the

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
,
 
and
be
d
 
<EOS>
---
d
to

,
"
said
Burgo
.
<EOS>
Then

in

room
,
and

.
<EOS>
It

,
this
clear

a

with

the
wife
of
another

!
<EOS>
Burgo
regarded

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Burgo
,
you
had

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

.
"
<EOS>
He
took
,
however
,
a
bit
of

,
and

hand
as

,
went

a

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
eat
any
breakfast
the
less
of
that
you
take
the
better
,
"
said
Sir
Cosmo
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
all
right
now
,
"
said
he
,
and
coming
back
to
the
table
,
went
through
some
form
of
making
a
meal
with
a
roll
and
a
cup
of
tea
.
  
<EOS>
They
who
were
then
present
used
afterwards
to
say
that
they
should
never
forget
that
breakfast
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
something
,
they
declared
,
in
the
tone
of
Burgo
's
voice
when
he
uttered
his
