against
Mr.
Palliser
,
which
had
struck
them
all
with
dread
.
<EOS>
There
had
,
too
,
they
said
,
been
a
blackness
in
his
face
,
so
terrible
to
be
seen
,
that
it
had
taken
from
them
all
the
power
of
conversation
.
<EOS>
Sir
Cosmo
,
when
he
had
broken
the
ominous
silence
,
had
done
so
with
a
manifest
struggle
.
<EOS>
The
loud
clatter
of
glasses
with
which
Burgo
had
swallowed
his
dram
,
as
though
resolved
to
show
that
he
was
regardless
who
might
know
that
he
was
drinking
,
added
to
the
feeling
.
<EOS>
It
may
easily
be
understood
that
there
was
no
further
word
spoken
at
that
breakfast
-
table
about
Planty
Pall
or
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
On
that
day
Burgo
Fitzgerald
startled
all
those
who
saw
him
by
the
mad
way
in
which
he
rode
.
<EOS>
Early
in
the
day
there
was
no
excuse
for
any
such
rashness
.
<EOS>
The
hounds
went
from
wood
to
wood
,
and
men
went
in
troops
along
the
forest
sides
as
they
do
on
such
occasions
.
<EOS>
But
Burgo
was
seen
to
cram
his
horse
at
impracticable
places
,
and
to
ride
at
gates
and
rails
as
though
resolved
to
do
himself
and
his
uncle
's
<EOS>
steed
a
mischief
.
<EOS>
This
was
so
apparent
that
some
friend
spoke
to
Sir
Cosmo
Monk
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
do
nothing
,
"
said
Sir
Cosmo
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
man
whom
no
one
's
words
will
control
.
<EOS>
Something
has
ruffled
him
this
morning
,
and
he
must
run
his
chance
till
he
becomes
quiet
.
<EOS>
"
In
the
afternoon
there
was
a
good
run
,
and
Burgo
again
rode
as
hard
as
he
could
make
his
horse
carry
him
;
 
but
then
there
was
the
usual
excuse
for
hard
riding
;
and
such
riding
in
a
straight
run
is
not
dangerous
,
as
it
is
when
the
circumstances
of
the
occasion
do
not
warrant
it
,
But
<EOS>
,
be
that
as
it
may
,
Burgo
went
on
to
the
end
of
the
day
without
accident
,
and
as
he
went
home
,
assured
Sir
Cosmo
,
in
a
voice
which
was
almost
cheery
,
that
his
mare
Spinster
was
by
far
the
best
thing
in
the
Monkshade
stables
.
<EOS>
Indeed
Spinster
made
quite
a
character
that
day
,
and
was
sold
at
the
end
of
the
season
for
three
hundred
guineas
on
the
strength
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
,
however
,
inclined
to
believe
that
there
was
nothing
particular
about
the
mare
.
<EOS>
Horses
always
catch
the
temperament
of
their
riders
,
and
when
a
man
wishes
to
break
his
neck
,
he
will
generally
find
a
horse
willing
to
assist
him
in
appearance
,
but
able
to
save
him
in
the
performance
.
<EOS>
Burgo
,
at
any
rate
,
did
not
break
his
neck
,
and
appeared
at
the
dinner
-
table
in
a
better
humour
than
that
which
he
had
displayed
in
the
morning
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
day
appointed
Mr.
Palliser
reached
Monkshade
.
<EOS>
He
was
,
in
a
manner
,
canvassing
for
the
support
of
the
Liberal
party
,
and
it
would
not
have
suited
him
to
show
any
indifference
to
the
invitation
of
so
influential
a
man
as
Sir
Cosmo
.
<EOS>
Sir
Cosmo
had
a
little
party
of
his
own
in
the
House
,
consisting
of
four
or
five
other
respectable
country
gentlemen
,
who
troubled
themselves
little
with
thinking
,
and
who
mostly
had
bald
heads
.
<EOS>
Sir
Cosmo
was
a
man
with
whom
it
was
quite
necessary
that
such
an
aspirant
as
Mr.
Palliser
should
stand
well
,
and
therefore
Mr.
Palliser
came
to
Monkshade
,
although
Lady
Glencora
was
unable
to
accompany
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
so
sorry
,
"
said
Lady
Monk
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
looking
forward
to
having
Lady
Glencora
with
us
beyond
everything
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
declared
that
Lady
Glencora
herself
was
overwhelmed
with
grief
in
that
she
should
have
been
debarred
from
making
this
special
visit
.
<EOS>
She
had
,
however
,
been
so
unwell
at
Gatherum
,
the
anxious
husband
declared
,
as
to
make
it
unsafe
for
her
to
go
again
away
from
home
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
is
nothing
serious
,
"
said
Lady
Monk
,
with
a
look
of
grief
<EOS>
so
well
arranged
that
any
stranger
would
have
thought
that
all
the
Pallisers
must
have
been
very
dear
to
her
heart
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Palliser
went
on
to
explain
that
Lady
Glencora
had
unfortunately
been
foolish
.
<EOS>
During
one
of
those
nights
of
hard
frost
she
had
gone
out
among
the
ruins
at
Matching
,
to
show
them
by
moonlight
to
a
friend
.
<EOS>
The
friend
had
thoughtlessly
,
foolishly
,
and
in
a
manner
which
Mr.
Palliser
declared
to
be
very
reprehensible
,
allowed
Lady
Glencora
to
remain
among
the
ruins
till
she
had
caught
cold
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
very
wrong
!
"
said
Lady
Monk
with
considerable
emphasis
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
very
wrong
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
speaking
of
poor
Alice
almost
maliciously
.
"
<EOS>
However
,
she
caught
a
cold
which
,
unfortunately
,
has
become
worse
at
my
uncle
's
,
and
so
I
was
obliged
to
take
her
home
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
perceived
that
Mr.
Palliser
had
in
truth
left
his
wife
behind
because
he
believed
her
to
be
ill
,
and
not
because
he
was
afraid
of
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
So
accomplished
a
woman
as
Lady
Monk
felt
no
doubt
that
the
wife
's
absence
was
caused
by
fear
of
the
lover
,
and
not
by
any
cold
caught
in
viewing
ruins
by
moonlight
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
to
be
deceived
in
such
a
matter
.
<EOS>
But
she
became
aware
that
Mr.
Palliser
had
been
deceived
.
<EOS>
As
she
was
right
in
this
we
must
go
back
for
a
moment
,
and
say
a
word
of
things
as
they
went
on
at
Matching
after
Alice
Vavasor
had
left
that
place
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
told
Miss
Palliser
that
steps
ought
to
be
taken
,
whatever
might
be
their
cost
,
to
save
Lady
Glencora
from
the
peril
of
a
visit
to
Monkshade
.
<EOS>
To
this
Miss
Palliser
had
assented
,
and
,
when
she
left
Alice
,
was
determined
to
tell
Mr.
Palliser
the
whole
story
.
<EOS>
But
when
the
time
for
doing
so
had
come
,
her
courage
failed
her
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
find
words
in
which
to
warn
the
husband
that
his
wife
would
not
be
safe
in
the
company
of
her
old
lover
.
<EOS>
The
task
with
Lady
Glencora
herself
,
bad
as
that
would
be
,
might
be
easier
,
and
this
task
<EOS>
she
at
last
undertook
,
 
not
without
success
.
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
,
"
she
said
,
when
she
found
a
fitting
opportunity
,
"
you
wo
n't
be
angry
,
I
hope
,
if
I
say
a
word
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
depends
very
much
upon
what
the
word
is
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
And
here
it
must
be
acknowledged
that
Mr.
Palliser
's
wife
had
not
done
much
to
ingratiate
herself
with
Mr.
Palliser
's
cousins
;
 
not
perhaps
so
much
as
she
should
have
done
,
seeing
that
she
found
them
in
her
husband
's
house
.
<EOS>
She
had
taught
herself
to
think
that
they
were
hard
,
stiff
,
and
too
proud
of
bearing
the
name
of
Palliser
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
some
little
attempt
may
have
been
made
by
one
or
both
of
them
to
teach
her
something
,
and
it
need
hardly
be
said
that
such
an
attempt
on
the
part
of
a
husband
's
unmarried
female
relations
would
not
be
forgiven
by
a
young
bride
.
<EOS>
She
had
undoubtedly
been
ungracious
,
and
of
this
Miss
Palliser
was
well
aware
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
 
the
word
shall
be
as
little
unpleasant
as
I
can
make
it
,
"
said
Miss
Palliser
,
already
appreciating
fully
the
difficulty
of
her
task
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
why
say
anything
that
is
unpleasant
?
<EOS>
However
,
if
it
is
to
be
said
,
let
us
have
it
over
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
going
to
Monkshade
,
I
believe
,
with
Plantagenet
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
;
 
and
what
of
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Glencora
,
I
think
you
had
better
not
go
.
<EOS>
Do
you
not
think
so
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
has
been
talking
to
you
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
turning
upon
her
very
sharply
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nobody
has
been
talking
to
me
;
 
not
in
the
sense
you
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Plantagenet
has
spoken
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
word
,
"
said
Miss
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
sure
that
he
would
not
utter
a
word
on
such
a
subject
to
anyone
unless
it
were
to
yourself
.
<EOS>
But
,
dear
Glencora
,
you
should
not
go
there
;
 
<EOS>
I
mean
it
in
all
kindness
and
love
,
 
I
do
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
Saying
this
she
offered
her
hand
to
Glencora
,
and
Glencora
took
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
do
,
"
said
she
in
a
low
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
do
.
<EOS>
The
world
is
so
hard
and
cruel
in
what
it
says
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
do
not
care
two
straws
for
what
the
world
says
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
he
might
care
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
my
fault
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
want
to
go
to
Monkshade
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
was
my
friend
once
,
but
I
do
not
care
if
I
never
see
her
again
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
arrange
this
visit
.
<EOS>
It
was
Plantagenet
who
did
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
will
not
take
you
there
if
you
say
you
do
not
wish
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
so
,
and
he
told
me
that
I
must
go
.
<EOS>
You
will
hardly
believe
me
,
 
but
I
condescended
even
to
tell
him
why
I
thought
it
better
to
remain
away
.
<EOS>
He
told
me
,
in
answer
,
that
it
was
a
silly
folly
which
I
must
live
down
,
and
that
it
did
not
become
me
to
be
afraid
of
any
man
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
are
not
afraid
,
but
 
"
  
"
I
am
afraid
.
<EOS>
That
is
just
the
truth
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
;
 
but
what
can
I
do
more
than
I
have
done
?
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
very
terrible
to
Miss
Palliser
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
thought
that
Lady
Glencora
would
say
so
much
,
and
she
felt
a
true
regret
in
having
been
made
to
hear
words
which
so
nearly
amounted
to
a
confession
.
<EOS>
But
for
this
there
was
no
help
now
.
<EOS>
There
were
not
many
more
words
between
them
,
and
we
already
know
the
result
of
the
conversation
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
became
so
ill
from
the
effects
of
her
imprudent
lingering
among
the
ruins
that
she
was
unable
to
go
to
Monkshade
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
remained
three
days
at
Monkshade
,
and
cemented
his
political
alliance
with
Sir
Cosmo
much
in
the
same
way
as
he
had
before
done
with
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
.
<EOS>
There
was
little
or
nothing
said
about
politics
,
and
certainly
not
a
word
that
could
be
taken
as
any
definite
party
understanding
between
the
men
;
but
they
sat
at
dinner
together
at
the
same
table
,
drank
a
glass
of
wine
or
two
out
of
the
same
decanters
,
and
dropped
a
chance
word
now
and
again
about
the
next
session
of
Parliament
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
anything
more
had
been
expected
either
by
Mr.
Palliser
or
by
Sir
Cosmo
;
but
it
seemed
to
be
understood
when
Mr.
Palliser
went
away
that
Sir
Cosmo
was
of
opinion
that
that
young
scion
of
a
ducal
house
ought
to
become
the
future
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
in
the
Whig
Government
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
see
that
there
's
so
much
in
him
,
"
said
one
young
member
of
Parliament
to
Sir
Cosmo
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
rather
think
that
there
is
,
all
the
same
,
"
said
the
baronet
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
good
deal
in
him
,
I
believe
!
<EOS>
I
dare
say
he
's
not
very
bright
,
but
I
do
n't
know
that
we
want
brightness
.
<EOS>
A
bright
financier
is
the
most
dangerous
man
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
We
've
had
enough
of
that
already
.
<EOS>
Give
me
sound
common
sense
,
with
just
enough
of
the
gab
in
a
man
to
enable
him
to
say
what
he
's
got
to
say
!
<EOS>
We
do
n't
want
more
than
that
nowadays
.
"
<EOS>
From
which
it
became
evident
that
Sir
Cosmo
was
satisfied
with
the
new
political
candidate
for
high
place
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
took
an
occasion
to
introduce
Mr.
Palliser
to
Burgo
Fitzgerald
;
with
what
object
it
is
difficult
to
say
,
unless
she
was
anxious
to
make
mischief
between
the
men
.
<EOS>
Burgo
scowled
at
him
;
but
Mr.
Palliser
did
not
notice
the
scowl
,
and
put
out
his
hand
to
his
late
rival
most
affably
.
<EOS>
Burgo
was
forced
to
take
it
,
and
as
he
did
so
made
a
little
speech
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sorry
that
we
have
not
the
pleasure
of
seeing
Lady
Glencora
with
you
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
unfortunately
indisposed
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
for
it
,
"
said
Burgo
 
"
very
sorry
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
turned
his
back
and
walked
away
.
<EOS>
The
few
words
he
had
spoken
,
and
the
manner
in
which
he
had
carried
himself
,
had
been
such
as
to
make
all
those
around
them
notice
it
.
<EOS>
Each
of
them
knew
that
Lady
Glencora
's
name
should
not
have
been
in
Burgo
's
mouth
,
and
all
felt
a
fear
not
easily
to
be
defined
that
something
terrible
would
come
of
it
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Palliser
himself
did
not
seem
to
notice
anything
,
or
to
fear
anything
;
and
nothing
terrible
did
come
of
it
during
that
visit
of
his
to
Monkshade
.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Vavasor
Speaks
to
His
Daughter
.
 
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
returned
to
London
with
her
father
,
leaving
Kate
at
Vavasor
Hall
with
her
grandfather
.
<EOS>
The
journey
was
not
a
pleasant
one
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Vavasor
knew
that
it
was
his
duty
to
do
something
,
 
to
take
some
steps
with
the
view
of
preventing
the
marriage
which
his
daughter
meditated
;
but
he
did
not
know
what
that
something
should
be
,
and
he
did
know
that
,
whatever
it
might
be
,
the
doing
of
it
would
be
thoroughly
disagreeable
.
<EOS>
When
they
started
from
Vavasor
he
had
as
yet
hardly
spoken
to
her
a
word
upon
the
subject
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
congratulate
you
,
"
he
had
simply
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
the
time
may
come
,
papa
,
when
you
will
,
"
Alice
had
answered
;
and
that
had
been
all
.
  
<EOS>
The
squire
had
promised
that
he
would
consent
to
a
reconciliation
with
his
grandson
,
if
Alice
's
father
would
express
himself
satisfied
with
the
proposed
marriage
.
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
had
certainly
expressed
nothing
of
the
kind
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
so
badly
of
him
,
"
he
had
said
,
speaking
to
the
old
man
of
George
,
"
that
I
would
rather
know
that
almost
any
other
calamity
was
to
befall
her
,
than
that
she
should
be
united
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
Then
the
squire
,
with
his
usual
obstinacy
,
had
taken
up
the
cudgels
on
behalf
of
his
grandson
;
and
had
tried
to
prove
that
the
match
after
all
would
not
be
so
bad
in
its
results
as
his
son
seemed
to
expect
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
do
very
well
for
the
property
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
settle
the
estate
on
their
eldest
son
,
so
that
he
could
not
touch
it
;
and
I
do
n't
see
why
he
should
n't
reform
as
well
as
another
.
"
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
had
then
declared
that
George
was
thoroughly
bad
,
that
he
was
an
adventurer
;
that
he
believed
him
to
be
a
ruined
man
,
and
that
he
would
never
reform
.
<EOS>
The
squire
upon
this
had
waxed
angry
,
and
in
this
way
George
obtained
aid
and
assistance
down
at
the
old
house
,
which
he
certainly
had
no
right
to
expect
.
<EOS>
When
Alice
wished
her
grandfather
good
-
bye
the
old
man
gave
her
a
message
to
his
grandson
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
tell
him
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
I
will
never
see
him
again
unless
he
begs
my
pardon
for
his
personal
bad
conduct
to
me
,
but
that
if
he
marries
you
,
I
will
take
care
that
the
property
is
properly
settled
upon
his
child
and
yours
.
<EOS>
I
shall
always
be
glad
to
see
you
,
my
dear
;
and
for
your
sake
,
I
will
see
him
if
he
will
humble
himself
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
no
word
spoken
then
about
her
father
's
consent
;
and
Alice
,
when
she
left
Vavasor
,
felt
that
the
squire
was
rather
her
friend
than
her
enemy
in
regard
to
this
thing
which
she
contemplated
.
<EOS>
That
her
father
was
and
would
be
an
uncompromising
enemy
to
her
,
 
uncompromising
though
probably
not
energetical
,
 
<EOS>
she
was
well
aware
;
and
,
therefore
,
the
journey
up
to
London
was
not
comfortable
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
resolved
,
with
great
pain
to
herself
,
that
in
this
matter
she
owed
her
father
no
obedience
.
<EOS>
"
There
can
not
be
obedience
on
one
side
,
"
she
said
to
herself
,
"
without
protection
and
support
on
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
Now
it
was
quite
true
that
John
Vavasor
had
done
little
in
the
way
of
supporting
or
protecting
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
Early
in
life
,
before
she
had
resided
under
the
same
roof
with
him
in
London
,
he
had
,
as
it
were
,
washed
his
hands
of
all
solicitude
regarding
her
;
and
having
no
other
ties
of
family
,
had
fallen
into
habits
of
life
which
made
it
almost
impossible
for
him
to
live
with
her
as
any
other
father
would
live
with
his
child
.
<EOS>
Then
,
when
there
first
sprang
up
between
them
that
manner
of
sharing
the
same
house
without
any
joining
together
of
their
habits
of
life
,
he
had
excused
himself
to
himself
by
saying
that
Alice
was
unlike
other
girls
,
and
that
she
required
no
protection
.
<EOS>
Her
fortune
was
her
own
,
and
at
her
own
disposal
.
<EOS>
Her
character
was
such
that
she
showed
no
inclination
to
throw
the
burden
of
such
disposal
on
her
father
's
shoulders
.
<EOS>
She
was
steady
,
too
,
and
given
to
no
pursuits
which
made
it
necessary
that
he
should
watch
closely
over
her
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
girl
,
he
thought
,
who
could
do
as
well
without
surveillance
as
with
it
,
 
as
well
,
or
perhaps
better
.
<EOS>
So
it
had
come
to
pass
that
Alice
had
been
the
free
mistress
of
her
own
actions
,
and
had
been
left
to
make
the
most
she
could
of
her
own
hours
.
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
supposed
that
she
had
eaten
her
lonely
dinners
in
Queen
Anne
Street
night
after
night
,
week
after
week
,
month
after
month
,
without
telling
herself
that
her
father
was
neglecting
her
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
perceive
that
he
spent
every
evening
in
society
,
but
never
an
evening
in
her
society
,
without
feeling
that
the
tie
between
her
<EOS>
and
him
was
not
the
strong
bond
which
usually
binds
a
father
to
his
child
.
<EOS>
She
was
well
aware
that
she
had
been
ill
-
used
in
being
thus
left
desolate
in
her
home
.
<EOS>
She
had
uttered
no
word
of
complaint
;
but
she
had
learned
,
without
being
aware
that
she
was
doing
so
,
to
entertain
a
firm
resolve
that
her
father
should
not
guide
her
in
her
path
through
life
.
<EOS>
In
that
affair
of
John
Grey
they
had
both
for
a
time
thought
alike
,
and
Mr.
Vavasor
had
believed
that
his
theory
with
reference
to
Alice
had
been
quite
correct
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
left
to
herself
,
and
was
going
to
dispose
of
herself
in
a
way
than
which
nothing
could
be
more
eligible
.
<EOS>
But
evil
days
were
now
coming
,
and
Mr.
Vavasor
,
as
he
travelled
up
to
London
,
with
his
daughter
seated
opposite
to
him
in
the
railway
carriage
,
felt
that
now
,
at
last
,
he
must
interfere
.
<EOS>
In
part
of
the
journey
they
had
the
carriage
to
themselves
,
and
Mr.
Vavasor
thought
that
he
would
begin
what
he
had
to
say
;
but
he
put
it
off
till
others
joined
them
,
and
then
there
was
no
further
opportunity
for
such
conversation
as
that
which
would
be
necessary
between
them
.
<EOS>
They
reached
home
about
eight
in
the
evening
,
having
dined
on
the
road
.
<EOS>
"
She
will
be
tired
to
-
night
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
as
he
went
off
to
his
club
,
"
and
I
will
speak
to
her
to
-
morrow
.
"
<EOS>
Alice
specially
felt
his
going
on
this
evening
.
<EOS>
When
two
persons
had
together
the
tedium
of
such
a
journey
as
that
from
Westmoreland
up
to
London
,
there
should
be
some
feeling
between
them
to
bind
them
together
while
enjoying
the
comfort
of
the
evening
.
<EOS>
Had
he
stayed
and
sat
with
her
at
her
tea
-
table
,
Alice
would
at
any
rate
have
endeavoured
to
be
soft
with
him
in
any
discussion
that
might
have
been
raised
;
but
he
went
away
from
her
at
once
,
leaving
her
to
think
alone
over
the
perils
of
the
life
before
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
speak
to
you
after
breakfast
to
-
morrow
,
"
he
said
as
he
went
out
.
<EOS>
Alice
answered
that
she
should
be
there
,
 
as
a
matter
of
course
.
<EOS>
She
scorned
to
tell
him
that
she
was
always
there
,
 
always
alone
at
home
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
uttered
a
word
of
complaint
,
and
she
would
not
begin
now
.
  
<EOS>
The
discussion
after
breakfast
the
next
day
was
commenced
with
formal
and
almost
ceremonial
preparation
.
<EOS>
The
father
and
daughter
breakfasted
together
,
with
the
knowledge
that
the
discussion
was
coming
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
give
to
either
of
them
a
good
appetite
,
and
very
little
was
said
at
table
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
come
up
-
stairs
?
"
<EOS>
said
Alice
,
when
she
perceived
that
her
father
had
finished
his
tea
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
that
will
be
best
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
Then
he
followed
her
into
the
drawing
-
room
in
which
the
fire
had
just
been
lit
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
must
speak
to
you
about
this
engagement
of
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
sit
down
,
papa
?
<EOS>
It
does
look
so
dreadful
,
your
standing
up
over
one
in
that
way
.
<EOS>
"
He
had
placed
himself
on
the
rug
with
his
back
to
the
incipient
fire
,
but
now
,
at
her
request
,
he
sat
himself
down
opposite
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
greatly
grieved
when
I
heard
of
this
at
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
that
you
should
be
grieved
,
papa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
grieved
.
<EOS>
I
must
confess
that
I
never
could
understand
why
you
treated
Mr.
Grey
as
you
have
done
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
papa
,
that
's
done
and
past
.
<EOS>
Pray
let
that
be
among
the
bygones
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Does
he
know
yet
of
your
engagement
with
your
cousin
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
will
know
it
by
this
time
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
beg
of
you
,
as
a
great
favour
,
to
postpone
your
letter
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
To
this
Alice
made
no
answer
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
troubled
you
with
many
such
requests
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
Will
you
tell
me
that
this
one
shall
be
granted
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
that
I
owe
it
to
him
as
an
imperative
duty
to
let
him
know
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
may
change
your
mind
again
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
found
that
this
was
hard
to
bear
and
hard
to
answer
;
but
there
was
a
certain
amount
of
truth
in
the
grievous
reproach
conveyed
in
her
father
's
words
,
which
made
her
bow
her
neck
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
right
to
say
that
it
is
impossible
,
"
she
replied
,
in
words
that
were
barely
audible
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
exactly
so
,
"
said
her
father
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
therefore
it
will
be
better
that
you
should
postpone
any
such
communication
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
how
long
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Till
you
and
I
shall
have
agreed
together
that
he
should
be
told
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
papa
;
I
will
not
consent
to
that
.
<EOS>
I
consider
myself
bound
to
let
him
know
the
truth
without
delay
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
him
a
great
injury
,
and
I
must
put
an
end
to
that
as
soon
as
possible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
done
him
an
injury
certainly
,
my
dear
;
 
a
very
great
injury
,
"
said
Mr.
Vavasor
,
going
away
from
his
object
about
the
proposed
letter
;
"
and
I
believe
he
will
feel
it
as
such
to
the
last
day
of
his
life
,
if
this
goes
on
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
.
<EOS>
I
believe
that
it
will
not
be
so
.
<EOS>
I
feel
sure
that
it
will
not
be
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
of
course
what
I
am
thinking
of
now
is
your
welfare
,
 
not
his
.
<EOS>
When
you
simply
told
me
that
you
intended
to
 
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
winced
,
for
she
feared
to
hear
from
her
father
that
odious
word
which
her
grandfather
had
used
to
her
;
and
indeed
the
word
had
been
on
her
father
's
lips
,
but
he
had
refrained
and
spared
her
 
"
that
you
intended
to
break
your
engagement
with
Mr.
Grey
,
"
he
continued
,
"
I
said
little
or
nothing
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
ask
you
to
marry
any
man
,
even
though
you
had
yourself
promised
to
marry
him
.
<EOS>
But
when
you
tell
me
that
you
are
engaged
to
your
cousin
George
,
the
matter
is
very
different
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
well
of
your
cousin
.
<EOS>
Indeed
I
think
anything
but
well
of
him
.
<EOS>
It
is
my
duty
to
tell
you
that
the
world
speaks
very
ill
of
him
.
"
<EOS>
He
paused
,
but
Alice
remained
silent
.
<EOS>
"
When
you
were
about
to
travel
with
him
,
"
he
continued
,
"
I
ought
perhaps
to
have
told
you
the
same
.
<EOS>
But
I
did
not
wish
to
pain
you
or
his
sister
;
and
,
moreover
,
I
have
heard
worse
of
him
since
then
,
 
much
worse
than
I
had
heard
before
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
you
did
not
tell
me
before
,
I
think
you
might
spare
me
now
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
;
I
can
not
allow
you
to
sacrifice
yourself
without
telling
you
that
you
are
doing
so
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
not
for
your
money
he
would
never
think
of
marrying
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
that
I
am
well
aware
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
has
told
me
so
himself
very
plainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet
you
will
marry
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
will
.
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
,
papa
,
that
there
is
a
great
deal
of
false
feeling
about
this
matter
of
money
in
marriage
,
 
or
rather
,
perhaps
,
a
great
deal
of
pretended
feeling
.
<EOS>
Why
should
I
be
angry
with
a
man
for
wishing
to
get
that
for
which
every
man
is
struggling
?
<EOS>
At
this
point
of
George
's
career
the
use
of
money
is
essential
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
marry
without
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
then
give
him
your
money
without
yourself
,
"
said
her
father
,
speaking
in
irony
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
just
what
I
mean
to
do
,
papa
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
"
said
Mr.
Vavasor
,
jumping
up
from
his
seat
.
<EOS>
"
You
mean
to
give
him
your
money
before
you
marry
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
do
;
 
if
he
should
want
it
;
 
or
,
I
should
rather
say
,
as
much
as
he
may
want
of
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heavens
and
earth
!
"
exclaimed
Mr.
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
you
must
be
mad
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
part
with
my
money
to
my
friend
?
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
kind
of
madness
of
which
I
need
not
at
any
rate
<EOS>
be
ashamed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
this
,
Alice
;
has
he
got
any
of
it
as
yet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
shilling
.
<EOS>
Papa
,
pray
do
not
look
at
me
like
that
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
no
thought
of
marrying
him
you
would
not
call
me
mad
because
I
lent
to
my
cousin
what
money
he
might
need
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
only
say
that
so
much
of
your
fortune
was
thrown
away
,
and
if
it
were
not
much
that
would
be
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
would
sooner
see
you
surrender
to
him
the
half
of
all
you
have
,
without
any
engagement
to
marry
him
,
than
know
that
he
had
received
a
shilling
from
you
under
such
a
promise
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
prejudiced
against
him
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
it
prejudice
that
made
you
reject
him
once
before
?
<EOS>
Did
you
condemn
him
then
through
prejudice
?
<EOS>
Had
you
not
ascertained
that
he
was
altogether
unworthy
of
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
were
both
younger
,
then
,
"
said
Alice
,
speaking
very
softly
,
but
very
seriously
.
<EOS>
"
We
were
both
much
younger
then
,
and
looked
at
life
with
other
eyes
than
those
which
we
now
use
.
<EOS>
For
myself
I
expected
much
then
,
which
I
now
seem
hardly
to
regard
at
all
;
and
as
for
him
,
he
was
then
attached
to
pleasures
to
which
I
believe
he
has
now
learned
to
be
indifferent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Psha
!
"
ejaculated
the
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
only
speak
as
I
believe
,
"
continued
Alice
.
"
<EOS>
And
I
think
I
may
perhaps
know
more
of
his
manner
of
life
than
you
do
,
papa
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
prepared
to
run
risks
now
which
I
feared
before
.
<EOS>
Even
though
he
were
all
that
you
think
him
to
be
,
I
would
still
endeavour
to
do
my
duty
to
him
,
and
to
bring
him
to
other
things
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
you
expect
to
get
by
marrying
him
?
"
asked
Mr.
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
husband
whose
mode
of
thinking
is
congenial
to
my
own
,
"
answered
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
husband
who
proposes
to
himself
a
career
in
life
with
which
I
can
sympathize
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
I
may
perhaps
help
my
cousin
in
the
career
which
he
has
chosen
,
and
that
alone
is
a
great
reason
why
I
should
attempt
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
With
your
money
?
"
said
Mr.
Vavasor
with
a
sneer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Partly
with
my
money
,
"
said
Alice
,
disdaining
to
answer
the
sneer
.
<EOS>
"
Though
it
were
only
with
my
money
,
even
that
would
be
something
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Alice
,
as
your
father
,
I
can
only
implore
you
to
pause
before
you
commit
yourself
to
his
hands
.
<EOS>
If
he
demands
money
from
you
,
and
you
are
minded
to
give
it
to
him
,
let
him
have
it
in
moderation
.
<EOS>
Anything
will
be
better
than
marrying
him
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
I
can
not
hinder
you
;
you
are
as
much
your
own
mistress
as
I
am
my
own
master
,
 
or
rather
a
great
deal
more
,
as
my
income
depends
on
my
going
to
that
horrid
place
in
Chancery
Lane
.
<EOS>
But
yet
I
suppose
you
must
think
something
of
your
father
's
wishes
and
your
father
's
opinion
.
<EOS>
It
will
not
be
pleasant
for
you
to
stand
at
the
altar
without
my
being
there
near
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
To
this
Alice
made
no
answer
;
but
she
told
herself
that
it
had
not
been
pleasant
to
her
to
have
stood
at
so
many
places
during
the
last
four
years
,
 
and
to
have
found
herself
so
often
alone
,
 
without
her
father
being
near
to
her
.
<EOS>
That
had
been
his
fault
,
and
it
was
not
now
in
her
power
to
remedy
the
ill
-
effects
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Has
any
day
been
fixed
between
you
and
him
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
papa
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
has
been
said
about
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
something
has
been
said
.
<EOS>
I
have
told
him
that
it
can
not
be
for
a
year
yet
.
<EOS>
It
is
because
I
told
him
that
,
that
I
told
him
also
that
he
should
have
my
money
when
he
wanted
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
all
of
it
?
"
said
Mr.
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suppose
he
will
need
it
all
.
<EOS>
He
intends
to
stand
again
for
Chelsea
,
and
it
is
the
great
expense
of
the
election
which
makes
him
want
money
.
<EOS>
You
are
not
to
suppose
that
he
has
asked
me
for
it
.
<EOS>
When
I
made
him
understand
that
I
did
not
wish
to
marry
quite
yet
,
I
offered
him
the
use
of
that
which
would
be
ultimately
his
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
he
has
accepted
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
answered
me
just
as
I
had
intended
,
 
that
when
the
need
came
he
would
take
me
at
my
word
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
Alice
,
I
will
tell
you
what
is
my
belief
.
<EOS>
He
will
drain
you
of
every
shilling
of
your
money
,
and
when
that
is
gone
,
there
will
be
no
more
heard
of
the
marriage
.
<EOS>
We
must
take
a
small
house
in
some
cheap
part
of
the
town
and
live
on
my
income
as
best
we
may
.
<EOS>
I
shall
go
and
insure
my
life
,
so
that
you
may
not
absolutely
starve
when
I
die
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Having
said
this
,
Mr.
Vavasor
went
away
,
not
immediately
to
the
insurance
office
,
as
his
words
seemed
to
imply
,
but
to
his
club
where
he
sat
alone
,
reading
the
newspaper
,
very
gloomily
,
till
the
time
came
for
his
afternoon
rubber
of
whist
,
and
the
club
dinner
bill
for
the
day
was
brought
under
his
eye
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
no
such
consolations
in
her
solitude
.
<EOS>
She
had
fought
her
battle
with
her
father
tolerably
well
,
but
she
was
now
called
upon
to
fight
a
battle
with
herself
,
which
was
one
much
more
difficult
to
win
.
<EOS>
Was
her
cousin
,
her
betrothed
as
she
now
must
regard
him
,
the
worthless
,
heartless
,
mercenary
rascal
which
her
father
painted
him
?
<EOS>
There
had
certainly
been
a
time
,
and
that
not
very
long
distant
,
in
which
Alice
herself
had
been
almost
constrained
so
to
regard
him
.
<EOS>
Since
that
any
change
for
the
better
in
her
opinion
of
him
had
been
grounded
on
evidence
given
either
by
himself
or
by
his
sister
Kate
.
<EOS>
He
had
done
nothing
to
inspire
her
with
any
confidence
,
unless
his
reckless
daring
in
coming
forward
to
contest
a
seat
in
Parliament
could
be
regarded
as
a
doing
of
something
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
owned
himself
to
be
a
man
almost
penniless
;
he
had
spoken
of
himself
as
being
utterly
reckless
,
 
as
being
one
whose
standing
in
the
world
was
and
must
continue
to
be
a
perch
on
the
edge
of
a
precipice
,
from
which
any
accident
might
knock
him
headlong
.
<EOS>
Alice
believed
in
her
heart
that
this
last
profession
or
trade
to
which
he
had
applied
himself
,
was
becoming
as
nothing
to
him
,
 
that
he
received
from
it
no
certain
income
;
 
no
income
that
a
man
could
make
to
appear
respectable
to
fathers
or
guardians
when
seeking
a
girl
in
marriage
.
<EOS>
Her
father
declared
that
all
men
spoke
badly
of
him
.
<EOS>
Alice
knew
her
father
to
be
an
idle
man
,
a
man
given
to
pleasure
,
to
be
one
who
thought
by
far
too
much
of
the
good
things
of
the
world
;
but
she
had
never
found
him
to
be
either
false
or
malicious
.
<EOS>
His
unwonted
energy
in
this
matter
was
in
itself
evidence
that
he
believed
himself
to
be
right
in
what
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
To
tell
the
truth
,
Alice
was
frightened
at
what
she
had
done
,
and
almost
repented
of
it
already
.
<EOS>
Her
acceptance
of
her
cousin
's
offer
had
not
come
of
love
;
 
nor
had
it
,
in
truth
,
come
chiefly
of
ambition
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
so
much
asked
herself
why
she
should
do
this
thing
,
as
why
she
should
not
do
it
,
 
seeing
that
it
was
required
of
her
by
her
friend
.
<EOS>
What
after
all
did
it
matter
?
<EOS>
That
was
her
argument
with
herself
.
<EOS>
It
can
not
be
supposed
that
she
looked
back
on
the
past
events
of
her
life
with
any
self
-
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
self
-
satisfaction
,
but
in
truth
there
was
more
self
-
reproach
than
she
deserved
.
<EOS>
As
a
girl
she
had
loved
her
cousin
George
passionately
,
and
that
love
had
failed
her
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
tell
herself
that
she
had
been
wrong
when
she
gave
him
up
,
but
she
thought
herself
to
have
been
most
unfortunate
in
the
one
necessity
.
<EOS>
After
such
an
experience
as
that
,
would
it
not
have
been
better
for
her
to
have
remained
without
further
thought
of
marriage
?
  
<EOS>
Then
came
that
terrible
episode
in
her
life
for
which
she
never
could
forgive
herself
.
<EOS>
She
had
accepted
Mr.
Grey
because
she
liked
him
and
honoured
him
.
"
<EOS>
And
I
did
love
him
,
"
she
said
to
herself
,
now
on
this
morning
.
<EOS>
Poor
,
wretched
,
heart
-
wrung
woman
!
<EOS>
As
she
sat
there
thinking
of
it
all
in
her
solitude
she
was
to
be
pitied
at
any
rate
,
if
not
to
be
forgiven
.
<EOS>
Now
,
as
she
thought
of
Nethercoats
,
with
its
quiet
life
,
its
gardens
,
its
books
,
and
the
peaceful
affectionate
ascendancy
of
him
who
would
have
been
her
lord
and
master
,
her
feelings
were
very
different
from
those
which
had
induced
her
to
resolve
that
she
would
not
stoop
to
put
her
neck
beneath
that
yoke
.
<EOS>
Would
it
not
have
been
well
for
her
to
have
a
master
who
by
his
wisdom
and
strength
could
save
her
from
such
wretched
doubtings
as
these
?
<EOS>
But
she
had
refused
to
bend
,
and
then
she
had
found
herself
desolate
and
alone
in
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
can
do
him
good
why
should
I
not
marry
him
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
that
feeling
had
been
the
chief
argument
which
had
induced
her
to
return
such
an
answer
as
she
had
sent
to
her
cousin
.
"
<EOS>
For
myself
,
what
does
it
matter
?
<EOS>
As
to
this
life
of
mine
and
all
that
belongs
to
it
,
why
should
I
regard
it
otherwise
than
to
make
it
of
some
service
to
some
one
who
is
dear
to
me
?
"
<EOS>
He
had
been
ever
dear
to
her
from
her
earliest
years
.
<EOS>
She
believed
in
his
intellect
,
even
if
she
could
not
believe
in
his
conduct
.
<EOS>
Kate
,
her
friend
,
longed
for
this
thing
.
<EOS>
As
for
that
dream
of
love
,
it
meant
nothing
;
and
as
for
those
arguments
of
prudence
,
 
that
cold
calculation
about
her
money
,
which
all
people
seemed
to
expect
from
her
,
 
she
would
throw
it
to
the
winds
.
<EOS>
What
if
she
were
ruined
!
<EOS>
There
was
always
the
other
chance
.
<EOS>
She
might
save
him
from
ruin
,
and
help
him
to
honour
and
fortune
.
  
<EOS>
But
then
,
when
the
word
was
once
past
her
lips
,
there
returned
to
her
that
true
woman
's
feeling
which
made
her
plead
for
a
long
day
,
 
which
made
her
feel
that
that
long
day
would
be
all
too
short
,
 
which
made
her
already
dread
the
coming
of
the
end
of
the
year
.
<EOS>
She
had
said
that
she
would
become
George
Vavasor
's
wife
,
but
she
wished
that
the
saying
so
might
be
the
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
When
he
came
to
her
to
embrace
her
how
should
she
receive
him
?
<EOS>
The
memory
of
John
Grey
's
last
kiss
still
lingered
on
her
lips
.
<EOS>
She
had
told
herself
that
she
scorned
the
delights
of
love
;
if
it
were
so
,
was
she
not
bound
to
keep
herself
far
from
them
;
if
it
were
so
,
 
would
not
her
cousin
's
kiss
pollute
her
?
  
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
as
my
father
says
,
"
she
thought
.
<EOS>
"
It
may
be
that
he
wants
my
money
only
;
if
so
,
let
him
have
it
.
<EOS>
Surely
when
the
year
is
over
I
shall
know
.
<EOS>
"
Then
a
plan
formed
itself
in
her
head
,
which
she
did
not
make
willingly
,
with
any
voluntary
action
of
her
mind
,
 
but
which
came
upon
her
as
plans
do
come
,
 
and
recommended
itself
to
her
in
despite
of
herself
.
<EOS>
He
should
have
her
money
as
he
might
call
for
it
,
 
all
of
it
excepting
some
small
portion
of
her
income
,
which
might
suffice
to
keep
her
from
burdening
her
father
.
<EOS>
Then
,
if
he
were
contented
,
he
should
go
free
,
without
reproach
,
and
there
should
be
an
end
of
all
question
of
marriage
for
her
.
  
<EOS>
As
she
thought
of
this
,
and
matured
it
in
her
mind
,
the
door
opened
,
and
the
servant
announced
her
cousin
George
.
   
<EOS>
Passion
versus
Prudence
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
not
occurred
to
Alice
that
her
accepted
lover
would
come
to
her
so
soon
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
told
him
expressly
of
the
day
on
which
she
would
return
,
and
had
not
reflected
that
Kate
would
certainly
inform
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
thinking
so
much
of
the
distant
perils
of
this
engagement
,
that
this
peril
,
so
sure
to
come
upon
her
before
many
days
or
hours
could
pass
by
,
had
been
forgotten
.
<EOS>
When
the
name
struck
her
ear
,
and
George
's
step
was
heard
outside
on
the
landing
-
place
,
she
felt
the
blood
rush
violently
to
her
heart
,
and
she
jumped
up
from
her
seat
panic
-
stricken
and
in
utter
dismay
.
<EOS>
How
should
she
receive
him
?
<EOS>
And
then
again
,
with
what
form
of
affection
would
she
be
accosted
by
him
?
<EOS>
But
he
was
there
in
the
room
with
her
before
she
had
had
a
moment
allowed
to
her
for
thought
.
  
<EOS>
She
hardly
ventured
to
look
up
at
him
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
she
became
aware
that
there
was
something
in
his
appearance
and
dress
brighter
,
more
lover
-
like
,
perhaps
newer
,
than
was
usual
with
him
.
<EOS>
This
in
itself
was
an
affliction
to
her
.
<EOS>
He
ought
to
have
understood
that
such
an
engagement
as
theirs
not
only
did
not
require
,
but
absolutely
forbade
,
any
such
symptom
of
young
love
as
this
.
<EOS>
Even
when
their
marriage
came
,
if
it
must
come
,
it
should
come
without
any
customary
sign
of
smartness
,
without
any
outward
mark
of
exaltation
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
very
good
in
him
to
have
remained
away
from
her
for
weeks
and
months
;
but
to
come
upon
her
thus
,
on
the
first
morning
of
her
return
,
was
a
cruelty
not
to
be
forgiven
.
<EOS>
These
were
the
feelings
with
which
Alice
regarded
her
betrothed
when
he
came
to
see
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
said
he
,
coming
up
to
her
with
his
extended
hand
,
 
"
Dearest
Alice
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
gave
him
her
hand
,
and
muttered
some
word
which
was
inaudible
even
to
him
;
she
gave
him
her
hand
,
and
immediately
endeavoured
to
resume
it
,
but
he
held
it
clenched
within
his
own
,
and
she
felt
that
she
was
his
prisoner
.
<EOS>
He
was
standing
close
to
her
now
,
and
she
could
not
escape
from
him
.
<EOS>
She
was
trembling
with
fear
lest
worse
might
betide
her
even
than
this
.
<EOS>
She
had
promised
to
marry
him
,
and
now
she
was
covered
with
dismay
as
she
felt
rather
than
thought
how
very
far
she
was
from
loving
the
man
to
whom
she
had
given
this
promise
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
am
a
man
once
again
.
<EOS>
It
is
only
now
that
I
can
tell
you
what
I
have
suffered
during
these
last
few
years
.
"
<EOS>
He
still
held
her
hand
,
but
he
had
not
as
yet
attempted
any
closer
embrace
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
she
was
standing
away
from
him
awkwardly
,
almost
showing
her
repugnance
to
him
;
but
it
was
altogether
beyond
her
power
to
assume
an
attitude
of
ordinary
ease
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
continued
,
"
I
feel
that
I
am
a
strong
man
again
,
armed
to
meet
the
world
at
all
points
.
<EOS>
Will
you
not
let
me
thank
you
for
what
you
have
done
for
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
must
speak
to
him
!
<EOS>
Though
the
doing
so
should
be
ever
so
painful
to
her
,
she
must
say
some
word
to
him
which
should
have
in
it
a
sound
of
kindness
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
it
was
his
undoubted
right
to
come
to
her
,
and
the
footing
on
which
he
assumed
to
stand
was
simply
that
which
she
herself
had
given
to
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
his
fault
if
at
this
moment
he
inspired
her
with
disgust
rather
than
with
love
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
nothing
for
you
,
George
,
"
she
said
,
"
nothing
at
all
.
"
<EOS>
Then
she
got
her
hand
away
from
him
,
and
retreated
back
to
a
sofa
where
she
seated
herself
,
leaving
him
still
standing
in
the
space
before
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"
That
you
may
do
much
for
yourself
is
my
greatest
hope
.
<EOS>
If
I
can
help
you
,
I
will
do
so
most
heartily
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
she
became
thoroughly
ashamed
of
her
words
,
feeling
that
she
was
at
once
offering
to
him
the
use
of
her
purse
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
will
help
me
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
full
of
plans
,
all
of
which
you
must
share
with
me
.
<EOS>
But
now
,
at
this
moment
,
my
one
great
plan
is
that
in
which
you
have
already
consented
to
be
my
partner
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
you
are
my
wife
now
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
that
it
will
make
you
happy
to
call
me
your
husband
.
"
  
<EOS>
Not
for
worlds
could
she
have
said
so
at
this
moment
.
<EOS>
It
was
ill
-
judged
in
him
to
press
her
thus
.
<EOS>
He
should
already
have
seen
,
with
half
an
eye
,
that
no
such
triumph
as
that
which
he
now
demanded
could
be
his
on
this
occasion
.
<EOS>
He
had
had
his
triumph
when
,
in
the
solitude
of
his
own
room
,
with
quiet
sarcasm
he
had
thrown
on
one
side
of
him
the
letter
in
which
she
had
accepted
him
,
as
though
the
matter
had
been
one
almost
indifferent
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
right
to
expect
the
double
triumph
.
<EOS>
Then
he
had
frankly
told
himself
that
her
money
would
be
useful
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
should
have
been
contented
with
that
conviction
,
and
not
have
required
her
also
to
speak
to
him
soft
winning
words
of
love
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
must
be
still
distant
,
George
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
suffered
so
much
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
it
has
been
my
fault
that
you
have
suffered
;
I
know
that
.
<EOS>
These
years
of
misery
have
been
my
doing
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
,
however
,
the
year
of
coming
misery
that
was
the
most
to
be
dreaded
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
say
that
,
"
she
replied
,
"
nor
have
I
ever
thought
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
myself
and
myself
only
to
blame
.
<EOS>
"
Here
he
altogether
misunderstood
her
,
believing
her
to
mean
that
the
fault
for
which
she
blamed
herself
had
been
committed
in
separating
herself
from
him
on
that
former
occasion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
dear
,
let
bygones
be
bygones
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Bygones
will
not
be
bygones
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
well
for
people
to
say
so
,
but
it
is
never
true
.
<EOS>
One
might
as
well
say
so
to
one
's
body
as
to
one
's
heart
.
<EOS>
But
the
hairs
will
grow
grey
,
and
the
heart
will
grow
cold
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
see
that
one
follows
upon
the
other
,
"
said
George
.
<EOS>
"
My
hair
is
growing
very
grey
;
"
 
and
to
show
that
it
was
so
,
he
lifted
the
dark
lock
from
the
side
of
his
forehead
,
and
displayed
the
incipient
grizzling
of
the
hair
from
behind
.
<EOS>
"
If
grey
hairs
make
an
old
man
,
Alice
,
you
will
marry
an
old
husband
;
but
even
you
shall
not
be
allowed
to
say
that
my
heart
is
old
.
"
  
<EOS>
That
word
"
husband
,
"
which
her
cousin
had
twice
used
,
was
painful
to
Alice
's
ear
.
<EOS>
She
shrunk
from
it
with
palpable
bodily
suffering
.
<EOS>
Marry
an
old
husband
!
<EOS>
His
age
was
nothing
to
the
purpose
,
though
he
had
been
as
old
as
Enoch
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
again
obliged
to
answer
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
spoke
of
my
own
heart
,
"
said
she
:
"
<EOS>
I
sometimes
feel
that
it
has
grown
very
old
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
that
is
hardly
cheering
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
come
to
me
too
quickly
,
George
,
and
do
not
reflect
how
much
there
is
that
I
must
remember
.
<EOS>
You
have
said
that
bygones
should
be
bygones
.
<EOS>
Let
them
be
so
,
at
any
rate
as
far
as
words
are
concerned
.
<EOS>
Give
me
a
few
months
in
which
I
may
learn
,
 
not
to
forget
them
,
for
that
will
be
impossible
,
 
but
to
abstain
from
speaking
of
them
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
her
look
as
she
spoke
,
and
in
the
tone
of
her
voice
that
was
very
sad
.
<EOS>
It
struck
him
forcibly
,
but
it
struck
him
with
anger
rather
than
with
sadness
.
<EOS>
Doubtless
her
money
had
been
his
chief
object
when
he
offered
to
renew
his
engagement
with
her
.
<EOS>
Doubtless
he
would
have
made
no
such
offer
<EOS>
had
she
been
penniless
,
or
even
had
his
own
need
been
less
pressing
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
he
desired
something
more
than
money
.
<EOS>
The
triumph
of
being
preferred
to
John
Grey
,
 
of
having
John
Grey
sent
altogether
adrift
,
in
order
that
his
old
love
might
be
recovered
,
would
have
been
too
costly
a
luxury
for
him
to
seek
,
had
he
not
in
seeking
it
been
able
to
combine
prudence
with
the
luxury
.
<EOS>
But
though
his
prudence
had
been
undoubted
,
he
desired
the
luxury
also
.
<EOS>
It
was
on
a
calculation
of
the
combined
advantage
that
he
had
made
his
second
offer
to
his
cousin
.
<EOS>
As
he
would
by
no
means
have
consented
to
proceed
with
the
arrangement
without
the
benefit
of
his
cousin
's
money
,
so
also
did
he
feel
unwilling
to
dispense
with
some
expression
of
her
love
for
him
,
which
would
be
to
him
triumphant
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
in
their
present
interview
<EOS>
there
had
certainly
been
no
expression
of
her
love
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
said
,
"
your
greeting
to
me
is
hardly
all
that
I
had
hoped
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
?
"
said
she
.
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
George
,
I
am
sorry
that
you
should
be
disappointed
;
but
what
can
I
say
?
<EOS>
You
would
not
have
me
affect
a
lightness
of
spirit
which
I
do
not
feel
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
wish
,
"
said
he
,
very
slowly
,
 
<EOS>
"
if
you
wish
to
retract
your
letter
to
me
,
you
now
have
my
leave
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
an
opportunity
was
this
of
escape
!
<EOS>
But
she
had
not
the
courage
to
accept
it
.
<EOS>
What
girl
,
under
such
circumstances
,
would
have
had
such
courage
?
<EOS>
How
often
are
offers
made
to
us
which
we
would
almost
give
our
eyes
to
accept
,
but
dare
not
accept
because
we
fear
the
countenance
of
the
offerer
?
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
wish
to
retract
my
letter
,
"
said
she
,
speaking
as
slowly
as
he
had
spoken
;
"
but
I
wish
to
be
left
awhile
,
that
I
may
recover
my
strength
of
mind
.
<EOS>
Have
you
not
heard
doctors
say
,
that
muscles
which
have
been
strained
,
should
be
allowed
rest
,
or
they
will
never
entirely
renew
their
tension
?
<EOS>
It
is
so
with
me
now
;
if
I
could
be
quiet
for
a
few
months
,
I
think
I
could
learn
to
face
the
future
with
a
better
courage
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
is
that
all
you
can
say
to
me
,
Alice
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
you
have
me
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
would
fain
hear
one
word
of
love
from
you
;
is
that
unreasonable
?
<EOS>
I
would
wish
to
know
from
your
own
lips
that
you
have
satisfaction
in
the
renewed
prospect
of
our
union
;
is
that
too
ambitious
?
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
that
I
was
over
-
bold
in
pressing
my
suit
upon
you
again
;
but
as
you
accepted
it
,
have
I
not
a
right
to
expect
that
you
should
show
me
that
you
have
been
happy
in
accepting
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
she
had
not
been
happy
in
accepting
it
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
happy
now
that
she
had
accepted
it
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
show
to
him
any
sign
of
such
joy
as
that
which
he
desired
to
see
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
at
this
moment
,
she
feared
with
an
excessive
fear
that
there
would
come
some
demand
for
an
outward
demonstration
of
love
,
such
as
he
in
his
position
might
have
a
right
to
make
.
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
be
aware
that
this
might
be
prevented
only
by
such
demeanour
on
her
part
as
that
which
she
had
practised
,
and
she
could
not
,
therefore
,
be
stirred
to
the
expression
of
any
word
of
affection
.
<EOS>
She
listened
to
his
appeal
,
and
when
it
was
finished
she
made
no
reply
.
<EOS>
If
he
chose
to
take
her
in
dudgeon
,
he
must
do
so
.
<EOS>
She
would
make
for
him
any
sacrifice
that
was
possible
to
her
,
but
this
sacrifice
was
not
possible
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
not
a
word
to
say
to
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
<EOS>
She
looked
up
at
him
,
and
saw
that
the
cicature
on
his
face
was
becoming
ominous
;
his
eyes
were
bent
upon
her
with
all
their
forbidding
brilliance
,
and
he
was
assuming
that
look
of
angry
audacity
which
was
so
peculiar
to
him
,
and
which
had
so
often
cowed
those
with
whom
he
was
brought
in
contact
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
other
word
,
at
present
,
George
;
I
have
told
you
that
I
am
not
at
ease
.
<EOS>
Why
do
you
press
me
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
her
letter
to
him
in
the
breast
-
pocket
of
his
coat
,
and
his
hand
was
on
it
,
that
he
might
fling
it
back
to
her
,
and
tell
her
that
he
would
not
hold
her
to
be
his
promised
wife
under
such
circumstances
as
these
.
<EOS>
The
anger
which
would
have
induced
him
to
do
so
was
the
better
part
of
his
nature
.
<EOS>
Three
or
four
years
since
,
this
better
part
would
have
prevailed
,
and
he
would
have
given
way
to
his
rage
.
<EOS>
But
now
,
as
his
fingers
played
upon
the
paper
,
he
remembered
that
her
money
was
absolutely
essential
to
him
,
 
that
some
of
it
was
needed
by
him
almost
instantly
,
 
that
on
this
very
morning
he
was
bound
to
go
where
money
would
be
demanded
from
him
,
and
that
his
hopes
with
regard
to
Chelsea
could
not
be
maintained
unless
he
was
able
to
make
some
substantial
promise
of
providing
funds
.
<EOS>
His
sister
Kate
's
fortune
was
just
two
thousand
pounds
.
<EOS>
That
,
and
no
more
,
was
now
the
capital
at
his
command
,
if
he
should
abandon
this
other
source
of
aid
.
<EOS>
Even
that
must
go
,
if
all
other
sources
should
fail
him
;
but
he
would
fain
have
that
untouched
,
if
it
were
possible
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
that
that
old
man
in
Westmoreland
would
die
and
be
gathered
to
his
fathers
,
now
that
he
was
full
of
years
and
ripe
for
the
sickle
!
<EOS>
But
there
was
no
sign
of
death
about
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
So
his
fingers
released
their
hold
on
the
letter
,
and
he
stood
looking
at
her
in
his
anger
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
wish
me
then
to
go
from
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
not
be
angry
with
me
,
George
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Angry
!
<EOS>
I
have
no
right
to
be
angry
.
<EOS>
But
,
by
heaven
,
I
am
wrong
there
.
<EOS>
I
have
the
right
,
and
I
am
angry
.
<EOS>
I
think
you
owed
it
me
to
give
me
some
warmer
welcome
.
<EOS>
Is
it
to
be
thus
with
us
always
for
the
next
accursed
year
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Oh
,
George
!
"
  
"
To
me
it
will
be
accursed
.
<EOS>
But
is
it
to
be
thus
between
us
always
?
<EOS>
Alice
,
I
have
loved
you
above
all
women
.
<EOS>
I
may
say
that
I
have
never
loved
any
woman
but
you
;
and
yet
I
am
sometimes
driven
to
doubt
whether
you
have
a
heart
in
you
capable
of
love
.
<EOS>
After
all
that
has
passed
,
all
your
old

,
all
my
repentance
,
and
your
proffer
of
forgiveness
,
you
should
have
received
me
with
open
arms
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
may
go
now
,
and
feel
that
I
have
been
kicked
out
of
your
house
like
a
dog
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
speak
to
me
like
that
,
and
look
at
me
like
that
,
how
can
I
answer
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
no
answer
.
<EOS>
I
wanted
you
to
put
your
hand
in
mine
,
to
kiss
me
,
and
to
tell
me
that
you
are
once

.
<EOS>
Alice
,
think
better
of
it
;
kiss
me
,
and
let
me
feel
my
arm
once
more
round

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
shuddered
as
she

,
still

,
on

,
and
he
saw
that
she

.
<EOS>
With

his
desire
for
her
money
,
 
his
instant

of
it
,
 
this
was
too
much
for
him
;
and
he
turned
upon

,
and
left
the
room
without
another

.
<EOS>
She
heard
his
quick
step
as
he
hurried
down
the
stairs
,
but
she
did
not
rise
to
arrest

.
<EOS>
She
heard
the
door

as
he
left
the
house
,
but
still

did
not

from
her

.
<EOS>
Her
immediate
desire
had
been
that
he
should
go
,
 
and
now
he
was
gone
.
<EOS>
There
was
in
that

relief

almost

her
.
<EOS>
And
this
was
the
man
from
whom
,
within
the
last

days
,
she
had
accepted
an
offer
of

.
  
<EOS>
George
,
when
he
left
the

,

into
Cavendish

,
and
down
along
the
east
side
,
till

,

.
<EOS>
Close

,
in

,

,
Mr.

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

nothing

that
too

which
his

Alice
had

.
<EOS>
He
had
been
feeding
on
his
anger
,
and

,

at

that
he

from

whither

list
,
 
and

.
<EOS>
But

Scruby
.
<EOS>
To
Mr.
Scruby
was

;
but

,

.
<EOS>

months
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Metropolitan

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Other

,

.
<EOS>
As
George
Vavasor

,

,

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

.

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
per

.

<EOS>

Mr.

.
   
<EOS>
John
Grey
Goes
a
Second
Time
to
London
.
 
<EOS>
Early

Vavasor

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.

.
<EOS>
She

off
to
other

;
 
to
George

's

.
<EOS>
Alice

,

felt

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

"

<EOS>
"

.

"

"

"

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>
"

"
said
Grey
,
after
a
minute
's
pause
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
would
,
old
fellow
;
I
do
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
a
tone
of
special
affection
in
his
voice
which
struck
Seward
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
can
be
of
the
slightest
service
or
comfort
to
you
,
I
will
of
course
.
"
  
<EOS>
Grey
again
sat
silent
for
a
little
while
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
would
;
I
do
,
indeed
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
.
"
<EOS>
And
again
there
was
a
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
a
letter
here
from
 
Miss
Vavasor
,
"
said
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
hope
that
 
"
  
"
No
;
 
it
does
not
bring
good
news
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
I
can
tell
it
you
all
.
<EOS>
I
would
if
I
could
,
but
the
whole
story
is
one
not
to
be
told
in
a
hurry
.
<EOS>
I
should
leave
false
impressions
.
<EOS>
There
are
things
which
a
man
can
not
tell
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
there
are
,
"
said
Seward
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
with
all
my
heart
that
you
knew
it
all
as
I
know
it
;
but
that
is
impossible
.
<EOS>
There
are
things
which
happen
in
a
day
which
it
would
take
a
lifetime
to
explain
.
<EOS>
"
Then
there
was
another
pause
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
bad
news
this
morning
,
and
I
must
go
up
to
London
at
once
.
<EOS>
I
shall
go
into
Ely
so
as
to
be
there
by
twelve
;
and
if
you
will
,
you
shall
drive
me
over
.
<EOS>
I
may
be
back
in
a
day
;
certainly
in
less
than
a
week
;
but
it
will
be
a
comfort
to
me
to
know
that
I
shall
find
you
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
matter
was
so
arranged
,
and
at
eleven
they
started
.
<EOS>
During
the
first
two
miles
not
a
word
was
spoken
between
them
.
"
<EOS>
Seward
,
"
Grey
said
at
last
,
"
if
I
fail
in
what
I
am
going
to
attempt
,
it
is
probable
that
you
will
never
hear
Alice
Vavasor
's
name
mentioned
by
me
again
;
but
I
want
you
always
to
bear
this
in
mind
;
 
that
at
no
moment
has
my
opinion
of
her
ever
been
changed
,
nor
must
you
in
such
case
imagine
from
my
silence
that
it
has
changed
.
<EOS>
Do
you
understand
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
my
thinking
she
is
the
finest
of
God
's
creatures
that
I
have
known
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
that
in
her
future
life
she
will
be
severed
from
me
altogether
;
but
I
shall
not
,
therefore
,
think
the
less
well
of
her
;
and
I
wish
that
you
,
as
my
friend
,
should
know
that
I
so
esteem
her
,
even
though
her
name
should
never
be
mentioned
between
us
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Seward
,
in
some
few
words
,
assured
him
that
it
should
be
so
,
and
then
they
finished
their
journey
in
silence
.
  
<EOS>
From
the
station
at
Ely
,
Grey
sent
a
message
by
the
wires
up
to
John
Vavasor
,
saying
that
he
would
call
on
him
that
afternoon
at
his
office
in
Chancery
Lane
.
<EOS>
The
chances
were
always
much
against
finding
Mr.
Vavasor
at
his
office
;
but
on
this
occasion
the
telegram
did
reach
him
there
,
and
he
remained
till
the
unaccustomed
hour
of
half
<EOS>
past
four
to
meet
the
man
who
was
to
have
been
his
son
-
in
-
law
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
heard
from
her
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
as
soon
as
Grey
entered
the
dingy
little
room
,
not
in
Chancery
Lane
,
but
in
its
neighbourhood
,
which
was
allocated
to
him
for
his
signing
purposes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
 
said
Grey
;
"
she
has
written
to
me
.
"
  
"
And
told
you
about
her
cousin
George
.
<EOS>
I
tried
to
hinder
her
from
writing
,
but
she
is
very
wilful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
have
hindered
her
?
<EOS>
If
the
thing
was
to
be
told
,
it
is
better
that
it
should
be
done
at
once
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
hoped
that
there
might
be
an
escape
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
you
think
of
all
this
,
Grey
,
but
to
me
it
is
the
bitterest
misfortune
that
I
have
known
.
<EOS>
And
I
've
had
some
bitter
things
,
too
,
"
he
added
,
 
thinking
of
that
period
of
his
life
,
when
the
work
of
which
he
was
ashamed
was
first
ordained
as
his
future
task
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
escape
that
you
hoped
?
"
asked
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
know
.
<EOS>
The
whole
thing
seems
to
me
to
be
so
mad
,
that
I
partly
trusted
that
she
would
see
the
madness
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
sure
whether
you
know
anything
of
my
nephew
George
?
"
asked
Mr.
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
little
,
"
said
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
him
to
be
utterly
an
adventurer
,
 
a
man
without
means
and
without
principle
,
 
upon
the
whole
about
as
bad
a
man
as
you
may
meet
.
<EOS>
I
give
you
my
word
,
Grey
,
that
I
do
n't
think
I
know
a
worse
man
.
<EOS>
He
's
going
to
marry
her
for
her
money
;
then
he
will
beggar
her
,
after
that
he
'll
ill
-
treat
her
,
and
yet
what
can
I
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Prevent
the
marriage
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
how
,
my
dear
fellow
?
<EOS>
Prevent
it
!
<EOS>
It
's
all
very
well
to
say
that
,
and
it
's
the
very
thing
I
want
to
do
.
<EOS>
But
how
am
I
to
prevent
it
?
<EOS>
She
's
as
much
her
own
master
as
you
are
yours
.
<EOS>
She
can
give
him
every
shilling
of
her
fortune
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
How
am
I
to
prevent
her
from
marrying
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
her
give
him
every
shilling
of
her
fortune
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
is
she
to
do
then
?
"
asked
Mr.
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
 
then
,
 
then
,
 
then
let
her
come
to
me
,
"
said
John
Grey
;
and
as
he
spoke
there
was
the
fragment
of
a
tear
in
his
eye
,
and
the
hint
of
quiver
in
his
voice
.
  
<EOS>
Even
the
worldly
,
worn
-
out
,
unsympathetic
nature
of
John
Vavasor
was
struck
,
and
,
as
it
were
,
warmed
by
this
.
  
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
;
God
bless
you
,
my
dear
fellow
.
<EOS>
I
heartily
wish
for
her
sake
that
I
could
look
forward
to
any
such
an
end
to
this
affair
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
why
not
look
forward
to
it
?
<EOS>
You
say
that
he
merely
wants
her
money
.
<EOS>
As
he
wants
it
let
him
have
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
Grey
,
you
do
not
know
Alice
;
you
do
not
understand
my
girl
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
lost
her
fortune
nothing
would
induce
her
to
become
your
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Leave
that
to
follow
as
it
may
,
"
said
John
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
Our
first
object
must
be
to
sever
her
from
a
man
,
who
is
,
as
you
say
,
himself
on
the
verge
of
ruin
;
and
who
would
certainly
make
her
wretched
.
<EOS>
I
am
here
now
,
not
because
I
wish
her
to
be
my
own
wife
,
but
because
I
wish
that
she
should
not
become
the
wife
of
such
a
one
as
your
nephew
.
<EOS>
If
I
were
you
I
would
let
him
have
her
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
were
I
,
you
would
have
nothing
more
to
do
with
it
than
the
man
that
is
as
yet
unborn
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
she
will
give
him
her
money
because
she
has
said
so
;
but
I
have
no
power
as
to
her
giving
it
<EOS>
or
as
to
her
withholding
it
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
hardship
of
my
position
;
 
but
it
is
of
no
use
to
think
of
that
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John
Grey
certainly
did
not
think
about
it
.
<EOS>
He
knew
well
that
Alice
was
independent
,
and
that
she
was
not
inclined
to
give
up
that
independence
to
anyone
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
expected
that
her
father
would
be
able
to
do
much
towards
hindering
his
daughter
from
becoming
the
wife
of
George
Vavasor
,
but
he
had
wished
that
he
himself
and
her
father
should
be
in
accord
in
their
views
,
and
he
found
that
this
was
so
.
<EOS>
When
he
left
Mr.
Vavasor
's
room
nothing
had
been
said
about
the
period
of
the
marriage
.
<EOS>
Grey
thought
it
improbable
that
Alice
would
find
herself
able
to
give
herself
in
marriage
to
her
cousin
immediately
,
 
so
soon
after
her
breach
with
him
;
but
as
to
this
he
had
no
assurance
,
and
he
determined
to
have
the
facts
from
her
own
lips
,
if
she
would
see
him
.
<EOS>
So
he
wrote
to
her
,
naming
a
day
on
which
he
would
call
upon
her
early
in
the
morning
;
and
having
received
from
her
no
prohibition
,
he
was
in
Queen
Anne
Street
at
the
hour
appointed
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
conceived
a
scheme
which
he
had
not
made
known
to
Mr.
Vavasor
,
and
as
to
the
practicability
of
which
he
had
much
doubt
;
but
which
,
nevertheless
,
he
was
resolved
to
try
if
he
should
find
the
attempt
possible
.
<EOS>
He
himself
would
buy
off
George
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
He
had
ever
been
a
prudent
man
,
and
he
had
money
at
command
.
<EOS>
If
Vavasor
was
such
a
man
as
they
,
who
knew
him
best
,
represented
him
,
such
a
purchase
might
be
possible
.
<EOS>
But
then
,
before
this
was
attempted
,
he
must
be
quite
sure
that
he
knew
his
man
,
and
he
must
satisfy
himself
also
that
in
doing
so
he
would
not
,
in
truth
,
add
to
Alice
's
misery
.
<EOS>
He
could
hardly
bring
himself
to
think
it
possible
that
she
did
,
in
truth
,
love
her
cousin
with
passionate
love
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
him
,
as
he
remembered
what
Alice
had
been
to
himself
,
that
this
must
be
impossible
.
<EOS>
But
if
it
were
so
,
that
of
course
must
put
an
end
to
his
interference
.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
if
he
saw
her
he
might
learn
all
this
,
and
therefore
he
went
to
Queen
Anne
Street
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
he
must
come
if
he
will
,
"
she
said
to
herself
when
she
received
his
note
.
<EOS>
"
It
can
make
no
matter
.
<EOS>
He
will
say
nothing
half
so
hard
to
me
as
what
I
say
to
myself
all
day
long
.
"
<EOS>
But
when
the
morning
came
,
and
the
hour
came
,
and
the
knock
at
the
door
for
which
her
ears
were
on
the
alert
,
her
heart
misgave
her
,
and
<EOS>
she
felt
that
the
present
moment
of
her
punishment
,
though
not
the
heaviest
,
would
still
be
hard
to
bear
.
  
<EOS>
He
came
slowly
up
-
stairs
,
 
his
step
was
ever
slow
,
 
and
gently
opened
the
door
for
himself
.
<EOS>
Then
,
before
he
even
looked
at
her
,
he
closed
it
again
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
how
to
explain
that
it
was
so
;
but
it
was
this
perfect
command
of
himself
at
all
seasons
which
had
in
part
made
Alice
afraid
of
him
,
and
drove
her
to
believe
that
they
were
not
fitted
for
each
other
.
<EOS>
She
,
when
he
thus
turned
for
a
moment
from
her
,
and
then
walked
slowly
towards
her
,
stood
with
both
her
hands
leaning
on
the
centre
table
of
the
room
,
and
with
her
eyes
fixed
upon
its
surface
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
said
,
walking
up
to
her
very
slowly
.
  
<EOS>
Her
whole
frame
shuddered
as
she
heard
the
sweetness
of
his
voice
.
<EOS>
Had
I
not
better
tell
the
truth
of
her
at
once
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
if
she
could
only
have
been
his
again
!
<EOS>
What
madness
during
these
last
six
months
had
driven
her
to
such
a
plight
as
this
!
<EOS>
The
old
love
came
back
upon
her
.
<EOS>
Nay
;
it
had
never
gone
.
<EOS>
But
that
trust
in
his
love
returned
to
her
,
 
that
trust
which
told
her
that
such
love
and
such
worth
would
have
sufficed
to
make
her
happy
.
<EOS>
But
this
confidence
in
him
was
worthless
now
!
<EOS>
Even
though
he
should
desire
it
,
she
could
not
change
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
said
again
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
as
slowly
she
looked
up
at
him
,
he
asked
her
for
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
give
it
me
,
"
he
said
,
"
as
to
an
old
friend
.
"
<EOS>
She
put
her
hand
in
his
hand
,
and
then
,
withdrawing
it
,
felt
that
she
must
never
trust
herself
to
do
so
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
continued
,
"
I
do
not
expect
you
to
say
much
to
me
;
but
there
is
a
question
or
two
which
I
think
you
will
answer
.
<EOS>
Has
a
day
been
fixed
for
this
marriage
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
it
be
in
a
month
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
;
 
not
for
a
year
,
"
she
replied
hurriedly
;
 
and
he
knew
at
once
by
her
voice
that
she
already
dreaded
this
new
wedlock
.
<EOS>
Whatever
of
anger
he
might
before
have
felt
for
her
was
banished
.
<EOS>
She
had

<EOS>
The
Inn
at
Shap
.
 
<EOS>
When
George
Vavasor
left
Mr.
Scruby
's
office
 
the
attentive
reader
will
remember
that
he
did
call
upon
Mr.
Scruby
,
the
Parliamentary
lawyer
,
and
there
recognised
the
necessity
of
putting
himself
in
possession
of
a
small
sum
of
money
with
as
little
delay
as
possible
;
 
when
he
left
the
attorney
's
office
,
he
was
well
aware
that
the
work
to
be
done
was
still
before
him
.
<EOS>
And
he
knew
also
that
the
job
to
be
undertaken
was
a
very
disagreeable
job
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
like
the
task
of
borrowing
his
cousin
Alice
's
money
.
  
<EOS>
We
all
of
us
know
that
swindlers
and
rogues
do
very
dirty
tricks
,
and
we
are
apt
to
picture
to
ourselves
a
certain
amount
of
gusto
and
delight
on
the
part
of
the
swindlers
in
the
doing
of
them
.
<EOS>
In
this
,
I
think
we
are
wrong
.
<EOS>
The
poor
,
broken
,
semi
-
genteel
beggar
,
who
borrows
half
-
sovereigns
apiece
from
all
his
old
acquaintances
,
knowing
that
they
know
that
he
will
never
repay
them
,
suffers
a
separate
little
agony
with
each
petition
that
he
makes
.
<EOS>
He
does
not
enjoy
pleasant
sailing
in
this
journey
which
he
is
making
.
<EOS>
To
be
refused
is
painful
to
him
.
<EOS>
To
get
his
half
sovereign
with
scorn
is
painful
.
<EOS>
To
get
it
with
apparent
confidence
in
his
honour
is
almost
more
painful
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
D
 
---
it
<EOS>
,
"
he
says
to
himself
on
such
rare
occasions
,
"
I
will
pay
that
fellow
;
"
and
yet
,
as
he
says
it
,
he
knows
that
he
never
will
pay
even
that
fellow
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
comfortless
unsatisfying
trade
,
that
of
living
upon
other
people
's
money
.
  
<EOS>
How
was
George
Vavasor
to
make
his
first
step
towards
getting
his
hand
into
his
cousin
's
purse
?
<EOS>
He
had
gone
to
her
asking
for
her
love
,
and
she
had
shuddered
when
he
asked
her
.
<EOS>
That
had
been
the
commencement
of
their
life
under
their
new
engagement
.
<EOS>
He
knew
very
well
that
the
money
would
be
forthcoming
when
he
demanded
it
,
 
but
under
their
present
joint
circumstances
<EOS>
,
how
was
he
to
make
the
demand
?
<EOS>
If
he
wrote
to
her
,
should
he
simply
ask
for
money
,
and
make
no
allusion
to
his
love
?
<EOS>
If
he
went
to
her
in
person
,
should
he
make
his
visit
a
mere
visit
of
business
,
 
as
he
might
call
on
his
banker
?
  
<EOS>
He
resolved
at
last
that
Kate
should
do
the
work
for
him
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
had
felt
all
along
that
it
would
be
well
that
Kate
should
act
as
ambassador
between

and
Alice
in
money

,
as
she
had
long
done
in
other

.
<EOS>
He
could
talk
to
Kate
as
he
could
not

to
Alice
;
 
and
then
,
between
the
women
,
those
hard
money

would
be
softened
down
by
a
romantic
phraseology
which
he
would
not
himself

how
to
use
with
any
effect
.
<EOS>
He
made
up
his
mind
to
see
Kate
,
and
with
this
view
he
went
down
to
Westmoreland
;
and
took
himself
to
a
small
wayside
inn
at
Shap
among
the
fells
,
which
had
been
known
to
him
of
old
.
<EOS>
He
gave
his
sister
notice
that
he
would
be
there
,
and
begged
her
to
come
over
to
him
as
early
as
she
might
find
it
possible
on
the
morning
after
his
arrival
.
<EOS>
He
himself
reached
the
place
late
in
the
evening
by
train
from
London
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
station
at
Shap
,
by
which
the
railway
company
no
doubt
conceives
that
it
has
conferred
on
that
somewhat
rough
and
remote
locality
all
the
advantages
of
a
refined
civilization
;
but
I
doubt
whether
the
Shappites
have
been
thankful
for
the
favour
.
<EOS>
The
landlord
at
the
inn
,
for
one
,
is
not
thankful
.
<EOS>
Shap
had
been
a
place
owing
all
such
life
as
it
had
possessed
to
coaching
and
posting
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
a
stage
on
the
high
road
from
Lancaster
to
Carlisle
,
and
though
it
lay
high
and
bleak
among
the
fells
,
and
was
a
cold
,
windy
,
thinly
-
populated
place
,
 
filling
all
travellers
with
thankfulness
that
they
had
not
been
made
Shappites
,
nevertheless
,
it
had
had
its
glory
in
its
coaching
and
posting
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
doubt
that
there
are
men
and
women
who
look
back
with
a
fond
regret
to
the
palmy
days
of
Shap
.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
reached
the
little
inn
about
nine
in
the
evening
on
a
night
that
was
pitchy
dark
,
and
in
a
wind
which
made
it
necessary
for
him
to
hold
his
hat
on
to
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
beastly
country
to
live
in
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
resolving
that
he
would
certainly
sell
Vavasor
Hall
in
spite
of
all
family
associations
,
if
ever
the
power
to
do
so
should
be
his
.
"
<EOS>
What
trash
it
is
,
"
he
said
,
"
hanging
on
to
such
a
place
as
that
without
the
means
of
living
like
a
gentleman
,
simply
because
one
's
ancestors
have
done
so
.
"
<EOS>
And

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

George
,
"

,
"
a

's
guid

.
<EOS>
It

o'er
lang
since
you
've
been
<EOS>
doon

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
So

in

hardly

"
<EOS>
He
was

one

as
never

for

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Seems

.
"
<EOS>

was

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

very

.
<EOS>
He
had

through

all
that

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

John

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Dark

<EOS>
But

had
<EOS>
in

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
A

,

,

at

's

.

He

.

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
Hall
was
,
by

,
about

,

,
and
my
neck
,
though
I
were
ever
so
willing
to
risk
it
,
is
of
no
service
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Whatever
I
have
can
be
yours
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Kate
,
in
a
hesitating
voice
,
which
too
plainly
pronounced
her
misery
as
she
made
the
offer
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
refrain
herself
from
making
it
.
<EOS>
Though
her
grandfather
's
threat
was
ringing
in
her
ears
,
 
though
she
knew
that
she
might
be
ruining
her
brother
by
proposing
such
a
loan
,
she
had
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
When
her
brother
told
her
of
his
want
of
money
,
she
could
not
abstain
from
tendering
to
him
the
use
of
what
was
her
own
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
take
your
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
not
scruple
,
if
you
knew
how
welcome
you
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
I
shall
not
take
it
.
<EOS>
I
should
not
think
it
right
.
<EOS>
All
that
you
have
would
only
just
suffice
for
my
present
wants
,
and
I
should
not
choose
to
make
you
a
beggar
.
<EOS>
There
would
,
moreover
,
be
a
difficulty
about

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
would
be
no
difficulty
,
because
no
one
need
be
consulted
but
us

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
think
it
right
,
and
therefore
let
there
be
an
end
of
it
,
"
said
George
in
a
tone
of

which
had
in

something

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
you
wish
then
?
"
said
Kate
,
who
knew
too
well
what
he
did
wish
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
explain
to
you
.
<EOS>
When
Alice

,

will

her
,
and

we
are
both
the

of
the
old
squire
<EOS>

propose
that
the

shall
be
hers
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

,

of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
squire

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
know

wo

,

,

.
<EOS>
In

I
have

,
because

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,

;
 
do

.
"
<EOS>

,

.

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
 
<EOS>
that
was
not
wrong
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
anybody
could

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
Will

Alice
,
 
or

,

,

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
It

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Scruby
has

three

by
these

,
and
he
is

that

will
not

.
"
<EOS>
Then

Kate
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
George
,
"
she

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
That

woman
;
 
to

only

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
Alice

.
<EOS>

,

"

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Very

.
<EOS>
Alice

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
Kate
did

.
<EOS>
She

her

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

;
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
would
walk
to
London
to

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

will

me
?
"
<EOS>
said

,

into

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

that
she
would
not
,
but
I

.
<EOS>
There

something

that

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
there
is
anything
on
earth
<EOS>
I
hate
,
"
said
George
,

about

room
,
"
it
is
romance
.
<EOS>
If

keep
it
for

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
Alice

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

;

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

"
  
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>
"

Hall
solely

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
It

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
To

consented

;

,

,

,

for

,

.
<EOS>
Thereupon
,
George
graciously
consented
to
proceed
to

,

with

view
to

Hall
.
  
<EOS>
"
I

Providence
,
Kate
,

above

.
<EOS>
I
have
not
linen

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

wo

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Do

<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
's
Hospitality
.
 
<EOS>
As

away
,
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
happy

was

,
and

with

augean

of

,
fretted

with
an

to
bring
to
a
close
<EOS>
that
affair
which
he
had
on
his
hands
with
the
widow
Greenow
.
<EOS>
There
were
two
special
dangers
which
disturbed
him
.
<EOS>
She
would
give
herself
and
all

to
that

,
Bellfield
;
or
else

would

her
own

so
fast
before
he
got
hold
upon

,
that
the

would
be

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
 
---
if
she
has
n't
been
and
set
up
a
carriage
!
"
<EOS>
he

one

,
as

,

,

issue

,

<EOS>
"
She
's
been
and

as

my
name
's
Cheesacre
!
"
  
<EOS>
Whatever

might

to
fear
the
former
danger
,
we
may

that
he
had
none

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
knew
what

was

.
<EOS>
The

,
and

,

?
<EOS>
If

fifty

through
with

Joe

.
<EOS>
He

,
 
in

.
<EOS>
Any

.
  
<EOS>
But

Bellfield
more

.
<EOS>
That

fair

,

,
Captain
Bellfield
's

,
and

,
in

he

.
<EOS>
In

,
no

,
all

are
fair
.
<EOS>
The
one
general
is
quite

making

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
In

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Had

<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

,

I

,

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Her

were
all

.
<EOS>
This
was
harassing
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
though
no

to

in
the

of

,

which
ought

have

.
<EOS>
With

,

,

<EOS>
After

"

,

,

,

That

,

"

Bellfield

Each

"

?
"

Charlie

,

"

"

"

<EOS>
Mr.

I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
"
Charlie
's
mother
had
been
the
daughter
of
a
small
squire
who
had
let
his
land
to
tenants
,
and
she
was
,
therefore
,
justified
by
circumstances
in
looking
down
upon
a
farmer
.
  
<EOS>
The
matter
was
so
settled
,
 
pending
the
consent
of
Mr.
Cheesacre
;
and
Bellfield
went
out
to
Oileymead
.
<EOS>
He
knew
the
ways
of
the
house
,
and
was
not
surprised
to
find
himself
left
alone
till
after
dusk
;
nor
was
he
much
surprised
when
he
learned
that
he
was
not
put
into
one
of
the
mahogany
-
furnitured
chambers
,
but
into
a
back
room
looking
over
the
farm
-
yard
in
which
there
was
no
fire
-
place
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
had
already
endured
some
of
the
evils
of
poverty
,
and
could
have
put
up
with
this
easily
had
nothing
been
said
about
it
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
Cheesacre
brought
the
matter
forward
,
and
apologized
,
and
made
the
thing
difficult
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
old
fellow
,
"
he
said
,
"
there
are
the
rooms
,
and
of
course
they
're
empty
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
such
a
bore
hauling
out
all
the
things
and
putting
up
the
curtains
.
<EOS>
You
'll
be
very
snug
where
you
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
do
very
well
,
"
said
Bellfield
rather
sulkily
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
'll
do
very
well
.
<EOS>
It
's
the
warmest
room
in
the
house
in
one
way
.
<EOS>
"
He
did
not
say
in
what
way
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
near
neighbourhood
of
the
stables
may
have
had
a
warming
effect
.
  
<EOS>
Bellfield
did
not
like
it
;
but
what
is
a
poor
man
to
do
under
such
circumstances
?
<EOS>
So
he
went
up
-
stairs
and
washed
his
hands
before
dinner
in
the
room
without
a
fire
-
place
,
flattering
himself
that
he
would
yet
be
even
with
his
friend
Cheesacre
.
  
<EOS>
They
dined
together
not
in
the
best

,
and
after

they
sat
down
to
enjoy
themselves
with
pipes
and
brandy
and
water
.
<EOS>
Bellfield
,
having
a
taste
for
everything
that
was
expensive
,
would
have
preferred
cigars
;
but
his
friend
put
none
upon
the
table
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
though
he
could
spend
his
money
liberally
when
occasion
required
such
spending
,
knew
well
the
value
of
domestic
economy
.
<EOS>
He
was
n't
going
to
put
himself
out
,
as
he
called

,
for
Bellfield
!
<EOS>
What
was
good
enough
for
himself
was
good
enough
for
Bellfield
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
beggar
,
you
know
;
just

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
as

was

to
Mrs.
Greenow
on
some

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
He
only
wants
money
to
make

,
"
Mrs.
Greenow
had
answered
;
 
and

had

.
  
<EOS>
Both

of

,

.
<EOS>
He

,
 
thinking

.
<EOS>
But
he
reflected
that
he
was
at
any

a

Cheesacre
when
they
were
present

,
and

that
the

.
<EOS>
"
I
had
to

just

you

,
"
he

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
my
dear
fellow
,
how
foolishly

are
.
<EOS>
If

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

.
<EOS>
A

who
sits
upon

own
ground
as
I

has

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
 
but
we

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
If

he
ought

have

;

,

.
<EOS>
By

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
This

to

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Shall

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Cheesacre

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Ha

,

.
"

.
<EOS>
Words

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
only

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
She

"

,

<EOS>
"
  
"

!
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

,
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

Greenow

,

,

.
<EOS>
Cheesacre

,

,

<EOS>
had

.

.

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dear

,
"

.
"

Effects

,
"

And

,

<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
's
Little
Dinner
in

Close
.
 
<EOS>
How
deep
and
cunning
are
the

of
love
!
<EOS>
When

not

to

.
<EOS>
"
You

dog
-
cart
in
?
"
<EOS>
Captain

had

overnight
.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

who

,

,

,

,
of

.
<EOS>
But

knew
that
Cheesacre
must
take
the
dog
-
cart
,
and
was

.
<EOS>
His

would
leave
him
behind
,
if

,
but
Bellfield
would
take

that

.
  
<EOS>
Before

Mr.
Cheesacre
surreptitiously
carried

into

yard
a

containing
all
his

for

,
 
his
marrow
oil
for

,
his

with
the
wondrous
worked
front
upon

under
-

of
pink
to

colour
,
his
shiny

,
and
all

rest
of
the

.
<EOS>
When
dining
in
Norwich
on
ordinary

,
he
simply
washed
his
hands
there
,
trusting
to
the

at
the
inn
to

him

;
and
now

came
down

,

back

dog

cart
with
secret
,
but
alas
,
not

hands
,
hoping

would
forget

.
<EOS>
But
when

such
a
Captain
ever
forget

?
<EOS>
Cheesacre
,

,
perceived

bag

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

deuce

?
"
<EOS>
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Put

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
D
 
---
the
window
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How

do
hack

"

.
<EOS>
"
If

.
<EOS>
"
This
was

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

the
mischief
did
you

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

;

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Who

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

ca

,
"

;
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
But

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

"
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
In

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
Captain

,

,

ladies
"

.
<EOS>
The

,

upon

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

's

,

<EOS>
"

"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
"
  
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
He
would

and
ride

.
  
<EOS>
The
widow
was
almost

.
<EOS>
I
believe
that
she
had
not

in
her

against

the

's

.
<EOS>
The
materials
were
those
which

to

.
<EOS>
As
regarded
every
item
of
the
written
law
her

was

.
<EOS>
There
was
the
widow
's
cap
,
generally
so

,
so

the

,

.
<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
There

the
dress
of
deep
,

,
 
of

,
and

six
months
"
widow

,

.
<EOS>
There

,

's

.
<EOS>
But

,

to
some

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Cheesacre
had

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

had
not

,
and
she

,
which
with

were

,

.
<EOS>
Her

were

,

would

.
<EOS>
Her
kerchief
was

close
round

close

;
but

well

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

Charlie

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
Mrs.

's

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
Jeannette

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

's

,

.
<EOS>
Under

,

.
  
<EOS>
Nothing
,

,

.
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
She

,
"

<EOS>

"

Ten

.
  
<EOS>
Bellfield

,

.
<EOS>
Cheesacre

.

"

"

"

"

<EOS>
"

"

do

.
<EOS>
I
take
as
little
time
as
anybody
could
.
<EOS>
That
other
fellow
has
only
been
dead
about
nine
months
,
and
I
've
got
the
thing
in
excellent
training
already
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
harm
do
I
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
disturb
me
,
and
you
disturb
her
.
<EOS>
You
do
it
on
purpose
.
<EOS>
Do
you
suppose
I
ca
n't
see
?
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
<EOS>
what
,
now
;
if
you
'll
go
clean
out
of
Norwich
for
a
month
,
I
'll
lend
you
two
hundred
pounds
on
the
day
she
becomes
Mrs.
Cheesacre
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
where
am
I
to
go
to
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
stay
at
Oileymead
,
if
you
like
;
 
that

,
on

that
you
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
be

that
I
hack
the
ham
because
it
's
not
my
own
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
tell
you
a
piece
of
my
mind
,
Cheesacre
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
woman
has
no
more
idea
of
marrying
you
than
she
has
of

the
Bishop
.
<EOS>
Wo
n't
you
fill
your
glass
,
old

?
<EOS>
I
know
where
the
tap
is
if
you
want
another

.
<EOS>
You
may
as
well
give
it
up
,
and
spend
no
more
money
in
pink

and

on
her

.
<EOS>
You
're
a
podgy
man
,
you
see
,
and
Mrs.
Greenow
does
n't
like
podgy
men
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Cheesacre
sat
looking
at
him
with
his
mouth
open
,
dumb
with
surprise
,
and
almost
paralysed
with
impotent
anger
.
<EOS>
What
had
happened
during
the
last
few
hours
to
change
so
entirely
the
tone
of
his
dependent
captain
?
<EOS>
Could
it
be
that
Bellfield
had
been
there
during
the
morning
,
and
that
she
had
accepted

?
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
podgy
,
Cheesacre
,
"
Bellfield
continued
,
"
and
then
you
so
often
smell
of
the
farm
