that
she
could
not
bring
herself
to
like
,
 
still
she
would
not
allow
her
heart
to
contradict
her
words
.
  
<EOS>
They
sat
so
long
over
the
fire
in
the
drawing
-
room
that
at
last
they
agreed
that
the
driving
should
be
abandoned
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
use
of
it
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
nothing
to
see
,
and
the
wind
is
as
cold
as
charity
.
<EOS>
We
are
much
more
comfortable
here
;
are
we
not
?
"
<EOS>
Alice
quite
acquiesced
in
this
,
having
no
great
desire
to
be
driven
through
the
parks
in
the
gloom
of
a
February
afternoon
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
Dandy
and
Flirt
up
here
,
there
would
be
some
fun
in
it
;
but
Mr.
Palliser
does
n't
wish
me
to
drive
in
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
would
be
dangerous
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
it
's
that
he
minds
;
but
he
has
an
idea
that
it
looks
fast
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
it
does
.
<EOS>
If
I
were
a
man
,
I
'm
sure
I
should
n't
like
my
wife
to
drive
horses
about
London
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
?
<EOS>
Just
because
you
'd
be
a
tyrant
,
 
like
other
husbands
?
<EOS>
What
's
the
harm
of
looking
fast
,
if
one
does
n't
do
anything
improper
?
<EOS>
Poor
Dandy
,
and
dear
Flirt
!
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
they
'd
like
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
Mr.
Palliser
does
n't
care
for
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
tell
you
something
else
he
does
n't
care
for
.
<EOS>
He
does
n't
care
whether
Dandy
's
mistress
likes
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
say
that
,
Glencora
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
not
say
it
,
 
to
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
teach
yourself
to
think
it
.
<EOS>
That
's
what
I
mean
.
<EOS>
I
believe
he
would
consent
to
anything
that
he
did
n't
think
wrong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Such
as
lectures
about
the
British
Constitution
!
<EOS>
But
never
mind
about
that
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
Of
course
the
British
Constitution
is
everything
to
him
,
and
I
wish
I
knew
more
about
it
;
 
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
n't
told
you
whom
you
are
to
meet
at
dinner
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
have
 
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
there
's
another
guest
,
a
Mrs.
Marsham
.
<EOS>
I
thought
I
'd
got
rid
of
her
for
to
-
day
,
when
I
wrote
to
you
;
but
I
had
n't
.
<EOS>
She
's
coming
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
wo
n't
hurt
me
at
all
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
will
hurt
me
very
much
.
<EOS>
She
'll
destroy
the
pleasure
of
our
whole
evening
.
<EOS>
I
do
believe
that
she
hates
you
,
and
that
she
thinks
you
instigate
me
to
all
manner
of
iniquity
.
<EOS>
What
fools
they
all
are
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
are
they
all
,
Glencora
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
and
that
man
,
and
 
.
<EOS>
Never
mind
.
<EOS>
It
makes
me
sick
when
I
think
that
they
should
be
so
blind
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
I
hardly
know
how
much
I
owe
to
you
;
I
do
n't
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
Everything
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
as
she
spoke
,
put
her
hand
into
her
pocket
,
and
grasped
the
letter
which
lay
there
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
nonsense
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
it
's
not
nonsense
.
<EOS>
Who
do
you
think
came
to
Matching
when
I
was
there
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
;
 
to
the
house
?
"
said
Alice
,
feeling
almost
certain
that
Mr.
Fitzgerald
was
the
person
to
whom
Lady
Glencora
was
alluding
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
not
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
it
is
the
person
of
whom
I
am
thinking
,
"
said
Alice
,
solemnly
,
"
let
me
implore
you
not
to
speak
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
should
I
not
speak
of
him
?
<EOS>
Did
I
not
speak
of
him
before
to
you
,
and
was
it
not
for
good
?
<EOS>
How
are
you
to
be
my
friend
,
if
I
may
not
speak
to
you
of
everything
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
should
not
think
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
nonsense
you
talk
,
Alice
!
<EOS>
Not
think
of
him
!
<EOS>
How
is
one
to
help
one
's
thoughts
?
<EOS>
Look
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Her
hand
was
on
the
letter
,
and
it
would
have
been
out
in
a
moment
,
and
thrown
upon
Alice
's
lap
,
had
not
the
servant
opened
the
door
and
announced
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
how
I
do
wish
we
had
gone
to
drive
!
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
in
a
voice
which
the
servant
certainly
heard
,
and
which
Mrs.
Marsham
would
have
heard
had
she
not
been
a
little
hard
of
hearing
,
 
in
her
bonnet
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
,
my
dear
?
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
.
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
'd
just
come
across
from
Norfolk
Street
and
see
you
,
though
I
am
coming
to
dinner
in
the
evening
.
<EOS>
It
's
only
just
a
step
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
How
d'ye
do
,
Miss
Vavasor
?
"
<EOS>
and
she
made
a
salutation
to
Alice
which
was
nearly
as
cold
as
it
could
be
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
was
a
woman
who
had
many
good
points
.
<EOS>
She
was
poor
,
and
bore
her
poverty
without
complaint
<EOS>
She
was
connected
by
blood
and
friendship
with
people
rich
and
titled
;
but
she
paid
to
none
of
them
egregious
respect
on
account
of
their
wealth
or
titles
.
<EOS>
She
was
staunch
in
her
friendships
,
and
staunch
in
her
enmities
.
<EOS>
She
was
no
fool
,
and
knew
well
what
was
going
on
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
She
could
talk
about
the
last
novel
,
or
 
if
need
be
 
about
the
Constitution
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
a
true
wife
,
though
sometimes
too
strong
-
minded
,
and
a
painstaking
mother
,
whose
children
,
however
,
had
never
loved
her
as
most
mothers
like
to
be
loved
.
  
<EOS>
The
catalogue
of
her
faults
must
be
quite
as
long
as
that
of
her
virtues
.
<EOS>
She
was
one
of
those
women
who
are
ambitious
of
power
,
and
not
very
scrupulous
as
to
the
manner
in
which
they
obtain
it
.
<EOS>
She
was
hardhearted
,
and
capable
of
pursuing
an
object
without
much
regard
to
the
injury
she
might
do
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
flatter
wealth
or
fawn
before
a
title
,
but
she
was
not
above
any
artifice
by
which
she
might
ingratiate
herself
with
those
whom
it
suited
her
purpose
to
conciliate
.
<EOS>
She
thought
evil
rather
than
good
.
<EOS>
She
was
herself
untrue
in
action
,
if
not
absolutely
in
word
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
say
that
she
would
coin
lies
,
but
she
would
willingly
leave
false
impressions
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
the
bosom
friend
,
and
in
many
things
the
guide
in
life
,
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
mother
;
and
she
took
a
special
interest
in
Mr.
Palliser
's
welfare
.
<EOS>
When
he
married
,
she
heard
the
story
of
the
loves
of
Burgo
and
Lady
Glencora
;
and
though
she
thought
well
of
the
money
,
she
was
not
disposed
to
think
very
well
of
the
bride
.
<EOS>
She
made
up
her
mind
that
the
young
lady
would
want
watching
,
and
she
was
of
opinion
that
no
one
would
be
so
well
able
to
watch
Lady
Glencora
as
herself
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
plainly
opened
her
mind
on
this
matter
to
Mr.
Palliser
;
she
had
not
made
any
distinct
suggestion
to
him
that
she
would
act
as
Argus
to
his
wife
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
would
have
rejected
any
such
suggestion
,
and
Mrs.
Marsham
knew
that
he
would
do
so
;
but
she
had
let
a
word
or
two
drop
,
hinting
that
Lady
Glencora
was
very
young
,
 
hinting
that
Lady
Glencora
's
manners
were
charming
in
their
childlike
simplicity
;
but
hinting
also
that
precaution
was
,
for
that
reason
,
the
more
necessary
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
who
suspected
nothing
as
to
Burgo
or
as
to
any
other
special
peril
,
whose
whole
disposition
was
void
of
suspicion
,
whose
dry
nature
realized
neither
the
delights
nor
the
dangers
of
love
,
acknowledged
that
Glencora
was
young
.
<EOS>
He
especially
wished
that
she
should
be
discreet
and
matronly
;
he
feared
no
lovers
,
but
he
feared
that
she
might
do
silly
things
,
 
that
she
would
catch
cold
,
 
and
not
know
how
to
live
a
life
becoming
the
wife
of
a
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
.
<EOS>
Therefore
he
submitted
Glencora
,
 
and
,
to
a
certain
extent
,
himself
,
 
into
the
hands
of
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
had
not
been
twenty
-
four
hours
in
the
house
with
this
lady
before
she
recognized
in
her
a
duenna
.
<EOS>
In
all
such
matters
no
one
could
be
quicker
than
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
She
might
be
very
ignorant
about
the
British
Constitution
,
and
,
alas
!
<EOS>
very
ignorant
also
as
to
the
real
elements
of
right
and
wrong
in
a
woman
's
conduct
,
but
she
was
no
fool
.
<EOS>
She
had
an
eye
that
could
see
,
and
an
ear
that
could
understand
,
and
an
abundance
of
that
feminine
instinct
which
teaches
a
woman
to
know
her
friend
or
her
enemy
at
a
glance
,
at
a
touch
,
at
a
word
.
<EOS>
In
many
things
Lady
Glencora
was
much
quicker
,
much
more
clever
,
than
her
husband
,
though
he
was
to
be
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
,
and
though
she
did
know
nothing
of
the
Constitution
.
<EOS>
She
knew
,
too
,
that
he
was
easily
to
be
deceived
,
 
that
though
his
intelligence
was
keen
,
his
instincts
were
dull
,
 
that
he
was
gifted
with
no
fineness
of
touch
,
with
no
subtle
appreciation
of
the
characters
of
men
and
women
;
and
,
to
a
certain
extent
,
she
looked
down
upon
him
for
his
obtusity
.
<EOS>
He
should
have
been
aware
that
Burgo
was
a
danger
to
be
avoided
;
and
he
should
have
been
aware
also
that
Mrs.
Marsham
was
a
duenna
not
to
be
employed
.
<EOS>
When
a
woman
knows
that
she
is
guarded
by
a
watch
-
dog
,
she
is
bound
to
deceive
her
Cerberus
,
if
it
be
possible
,
and
is
usually
not
ill
-
disposed
to
deceive
also
the
owner
of
Cerberus
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
felt
that
Mrs.
Marsham
was
her
Cerberus
,
and
she
was
heartily
resolved
that
if
she
was
to
be
kept
in
the
proper
line
at
all
,
she
would
not
be
so
kept
by
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
rose
and
accepted
Mrs.
Marsham
's
salutation
quite
as
coldly
as
it
had
been
given
,
and
from
that
time
forward
those
two
ladies
were
enemies
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
,
groping
quite
in
the
dark
,
partly
guessed
that
Alice
had
in
some
way
interfered
to
prevent
Lady
Glencora
's
visit
to
Monkshade
,
and
,
though
such
prevention
was
,
no
doubt
,
good
in
that
lady
's
eyes
,
she
resented
the
interference
.
<EOS>
She
had
made
up
her
mind
that
Alice
was
not
the
sort
of
friend
that
Lady
Glencora
should
have
about
her
.
<EOS>
Alice
recognized
and
accepted
the
feud
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
I
might
find
you
at
home
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
,
"
as
I
know
you
are
lazy
about
going
out
in
the
cold
,
 
unless
it
be
for
a
foolish
midnight
ramble
,
"
and
Mrs.
Marsham
shook
her
head
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
little
woman
,
with
sharp
small
eyes
,
with
a
permanent
colour
in
her
face
,
and
two
short
,
crisp
,
grey
curls
at
each
side
of
her
face
;
always
well
dressed
,
always
in
good
health
,
and
,
as
Lady
Glencora
believed
,
altogether
incapable
of
fatigue
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
ramble
you
speak
of
was
very
wise
,
I
think
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
;
"
but
I
never
could
see
the
use
of
driving
about
in
London
in
the
middle
of
winter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
One
ought
to
go
out
of
the
house
every
day
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hate
all
those
rules
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
,
Alice
?
<EOS>
"
Alice
did
not
hate
them
,
therefore
she
said
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Glencora
,
one
must
live
by
rules
in
this
life
.
<EOS>
You
might
as
well
say
that
you
hated
sitting
down
to
dinner
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
do
,
very
often
;
almost
always
when
there
's
company
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
get
over
that
feeling
after
another
season
in
town
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
,
pretending
to
suppose
that
Lady
Glencora
alluded
to
some
remaining
timidity
in
receiving
her
own
guests
.
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
I
do
n't
think
I
shall
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
thing
that
seems
always
to
be
getting
more
grievous
,
instead
of
less
so
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
is
coming
to
dine
here
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
no
mistaking
the
meaning
of
this
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
pretending
even
to
mistake
it
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Mrs.
Marsham
had
accepted
the
right
hand
of
fellowship
from
Mr.
Bott
,
 
not
because
she
especially
liked
him
,
but
in
compliance
with
the
apparent
necessities
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
position
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
had
made
good
his
ground
about
Mr.
Palliser
;
and
Mrs.
Marsham
,
as
she
was
not
strong
enough
to
turn
him
off
from
it
,
had
given
him
the
right
hand
of
fellowship
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
is
a
Member
of
Parliament
,
and
a
very
serviceable
friend
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
"
All
the
same
;
we
do
not
like
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
 
<EOS>
do
we
,
Alice
?
<EOS>
He
is
Doctor
Fell
to
us
;
only
I
think
we
could
tell
why
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
do
not
like
him
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
can
be
but
of
small
matter
to
you
,
Miss
Vavasor
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
,
"
as
you
will
not
probably
have
to
see
much
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Of
the
very
smallest
moment
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
did
annoy
me
once
,
but
will
never
,
I
dare
say
,
have
an
opportunity
of
doing
so
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
the
annoyance
may
have
been
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
do
n't
,
Mrs.
Marsham
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
should
n't
have
thought
it
likely
that
a
person
so
fully
employed
as
Mr.
Bott
,
and
employed
,
too
,
on
matters
of
such
vast
importance
,
would
have
gone
out
of
his
way
to
annoy
a
young
lady
whom
he
chanced
to
meet
for
a
day
or
two
in
a
country
-
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
that
Alice
means
that
he
attempted
to
flirt
with
her
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Fancy
Mr.
Bott
's
flirtation
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
did
not
attempt
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
;
and
the
words
,
the
tone
,
and
the
innuendo
together
were
more
than
Alice
was
able
to
bear
with
equanimity
.
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
,
"
said
she
,
rising
from
her
chair
,
"
I
think
I
'll
leave
you
alone
with
Mrs.
Marsham
.
<EOS>
I
'm
not
disposed
to
discuss
Mr.
Bott
's
character
,
and
certainly
not
to
hear
his
name
mentioned
in
disagreeable
connection
with
my
own
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
Lady
Glencora
would
not
let
her
go
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nonsense
,
Alice
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
and
I
ca
n't
fight
our
little
battles
against
Mr.
Bott
and
Mrs.
Marsham
without
running
away
,
it
is
odd
.
<EOS>
There
is
a
warfare
in
which
they
who
run
away
never
live
to
fight
another
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
,
Glencora
,
you
do
not
count
me
as
your
enemy
?
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
,
drawing
herself
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall
,
 
certainly
,
if
you
attack
Alice
.
<EOS>
Love
me
,
love
my
dog
.
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Alice
;
but
what
I
meant
was
this
,
Mrs.
Marsham
;
Love
me
,
love
the
best
friend
I
have
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
mean
to
offend
Miss
Vavasor
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
,
looking
at
her
very
grimly
.
<EOS>
Alice
merely
bowed
her
head
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
offended
,
and
she
would
not
deny
it
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
Mrs.
Marsham
took
herself
off
,
saying
that
she
would
be
back
to
dinner
.
<EOS>
She
was
angry
,
but
not
unhappy
.
<EOS>
She
thought
that
she
could
put
down
Miss
Vavasor
,
and
she
was
prepared
to
bear
a
good
deal
from
Lady
Glencora
 
for
Mr.
Palliser
's
sake
,
as
she
said
to
herself
,
with
some
attempt
at
a
sentimental
remembrance
of
her
old
friend
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
's
a
nasty
old
cat
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
as
soon
as
the
door
was
closed
;
and
she
said
these
words
with
so
droll
a
voice
,
with
such
a
childlike
shaking
of
her
head
,
with
so
much
comedy
in
her
grimace
,
that
Alice
could
not
but
laugh
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
her
,
and
you
'll
have
to
know
her
,
too
,
before
you
've
done
with
her
.
<EOS>
It
wo
n't
at
all
do
for
you
to
run
away
when
she
spits
at
you
.
<EOS>
You
must
hold
your
ground
,
and
show
your
claws
,
 
and
make
her
know
that
if
she
spits
,
you
can
scratch
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
want
to
be
a
cat
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
'll
find
I
'm
of
the
genus
,
but
of
the
tiger
kind
,
if
she
persecutes
me
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
there
's
one
thing
I
have
made
up
my
mind
about
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
be
persecuted
.
<EOS>
If
my
husband
tells
me
to
do
anything
,
as
long
as
he
is
my
husband
I
'll
do
it
;
but
I
wo
n't
be
persecuted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
remember
that
she
was
a
very
old
friend
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
mother
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
remember
;
and
that
may
be
a
very
good
reason
why
she
should
come
here
occasionally
,
or
go
to
Matching
,
or
to
any
place
in
which
we
may
be
living
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
bore
,
of
course
;
but
it
's
a
natural
bore
,
and
one
that
ought
to
be
borne
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
that
will
be
the
beginning
and
the
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
not
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
It
may
perhaps
be
the
end
of
it
,
but
I
fear
it
wo
n't
be
the
beginning
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
be
persecuted
.
<EOS>
If
she
gives
me
advice
,
I
shall
tell
her
to
her
face
that
it
's
not
wanted
;
and
if
she
insults
any
friend
of
mine
,
as
she
did
you
,
I
shall
tell
her
that
she
had
better
stay
away
.
<EOS>
She
'll
go
and
tell
him
,
of
course
;
but
I
ca
n't
help
that
.
<EOS>
I
've
made
up
my
mind
that
I
wo
n't
be
persecuted
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
that
,
Lady
Glencora
felt
no
further
inclination
to
show
Burgo
's
letter
to
Alice
on
that
occasion
.
<EOS>
They
sat
over
the
drawing
-
room
fire
,
talking
chiefly
of
Alice
's
affairs
,
till
it
was
time
for
them
to
dress
.
<EOS>
But
Alice
,
though
she
spoke
much
of
Mr.
Grey
,
said
no
word
as
to
her
engagement
with
George
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
How
could
she
speak
of
it
,
inasmuch
as
she
had
already
resolved
,
 
already
almost
resolved
,
 
that
that
engagement
also
should
be
broken
?
  
<EOS>
Alice
,
when
she
came
down
to
the
drawing
-
room
,
before
dinner
,
found
Mr.
Bott
there
alone
.
<EOS>
She
had
dressed
more
quickly
than
her
friend
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
had
not
yet
made
his
appearance
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
expect
the
pleasure
of
meeting
Miss
Vavasor
to
-
day
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
came
up
,
offering
his
hand
.
<EOS>
She
gave
him
her
hand
,
and
then
sat
down
,
merely
muttering
some
word
of
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
spent
a
very
pleasant
month
down
at
Matching
together
;
 
did
n't
you
think
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
spent
a
pleasant
month
there
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
left
,
if
I
remember
,
the
morning
after
that
late
walk
out
among
the
ruins
?
<EOS>
That
was
unfortunate
,
was
it
not
?
<EOS>
Poor
Lady
Glencora
!
<EOS>
it
made
her
very
ill
;
so
much
so
,
that
she
could
not
go
to
Monkshade
,
as
she
particularly
wished
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
sad
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
is
very
delicate
,
 
very
delicate
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
We
,
who
have
the
privilege
of
being
near
her
,
ought
always
to
remember
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
she
is
at
all
delicate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
do
n't
you
?
<EOS>
I
'm
afraid
that
's
your
mistake
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
she
has
very
good
health
,
which
is
the
greatest
blessing
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
By
delicate
I
suppose
you
mean
weak
and
infirm
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
,
no
,
 
not
in
the
least
,
 
not
infirm
certainly
!
<EOS>
I
should
be
very
sorry
to
be
supposed
to
have
said
that
Lady
Glencora
is
infirm
.
<EOS>
What
I
mean
is
,
not
robust
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Her
general
organization
,
if
you
understand
me
,
is
exquisitely
delicate
.
<EOS>
One
can
see
that
,
I
think
,
in
every
glance
of
her
eye
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
was
going
to
protest
that
she
had
never
seen
it
at
all
,
when
Mr.
Palliser
entered
the
room
along
with
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
gentlemen
shook
hands
,
and
then
Mr.
Palliser
turned
to
Alice
.
<EOS>
She
perceived
at
once
by
his
face
that
she
was
unwelcome
,
and
wished
herself
away
from
his
house
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
all
very
well
for
Lady
Glencora
to
fight
with
Mrs.
Marsham
,
 
and
with
her
husband
,
too
,
in
regard
to
the
Marsham
persecution
,
 
but
there
could
be
no
reason
why
she
should
do
so
.
<EOS>
He
just
touched
her
hand
,
barely
closing
his
thumb
upon
her
fingers
,
and
asked
her
how
she
was
.
<EOS>
Then
he
turned
away
from
her
side
of
the
fire
,
and
began
talking
to
Mrs.
Marsham
on
the
other
.
<EOS>
There
was
that
in
his
face
and
in
his
manner
which
was
positively
offensive
to
her
.
<EOS>
He
made
no
allusion
to
his
former
acquaintance
with
her
,
 
spoke
no
word
about
Matching
,
no
word
about
his
wife
,
as
he
would
naturally
have
done
to
his
wife
's
friend
.
<EOS>
Alice
felt
the
blood
mount
into
her
face
,
and
regretted
greatly
that
she
had
ever
come
among
these
people
.
<EOS>
Had
she
not
long
since
made
up
her
mind
that
she
would
avoid
her
great
relations
,
and
did
not
all
this
prove
that
it
would
have
been
well
for
her
to
have
clung
to
that
resolution
?
<EOS>
What
was
Lady
Glencora
to
her
that
she
should
submit
herself
to
be
treated
as
though
she
were
a
poor
companion
,
 
a
dependent
,
who
received
a
salary
for
her
attendance
,
 
an
indigent
cousin
,
hanging
on
to
the
bounty
of
her
rich
connection
?
<EOS>
Alice
was
proud
to
a
fault
.
<EOS>
She
had
nursed
her
pride
till
it
was
very
faulty
.
<EOS>
All
her
troubles
and
sorrows
in
life
had
come
from
an
overfed
craving
for
independence
.
<EOS>
Why
,
then
,
should
she
submit
to
be
treated
with
open
want
of
courtesy
by
any
man
;
but
,
of
all
men
,
why
should
she
submit
to
it
from
such
a
one
as
Mr.
Palliser
,
 
the
heir
of
a
ducal
house
,
rolling
in
wealth
,
and
magnificent
with
all
the
magnificence
of
British
pomp
and
pride
?
<EOS>
No
;
she
would
make
Lady
Glencora
understand
that
the
close
intimacies
of
daily
life
were
not
possible
to
them
!
  
<EOS>
"
I
declare
I
'm
very
much
ashamed
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
as
she
entered
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
I
sha
n't
apologize
to
you
,
Alice
,
for
it
was
you
who
kept
me
talking
;
but
I
do
beg
Mrs.
Marsham
's
pardon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
was
all
smiles
and
forgiveness
,
and
hoped
that
Lady
Glencora
would
not
make
a
stranger
of
her
.
<EOS>
Then
dinner
was
announced
,
and
Alice
had
to
walk
down
stairs
by
herself
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
care
a
doit
for
that
,
but
there
had
been
a
disagreeable
little
contest
when
the
moment
came
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
had
wished
to
give
up
Mr.
Bott
to
her
cousin
,
but
Mr.
Bott
had
stuck
manfully
to
Lady
Glencora
's
side
.
<EOS>
He
hoped
to
take
Lady
Glencora
down
to
dinner
very
often
,
and
was
not
at
all
disposed
to
abate
his
privilege
.
  
<EOS>
During
dinner
-
time
Alice
said
very
little
,
nor
was
there
given
to
her
opportunity
of
saying
much
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
but
think
of
the
day
of
her
first
arrival
at
Matching
Priory
,
when
she
had
sat
between
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
and
Jeffrey
Palliser
,
and
when
everybody
had
been
so
civil
to
her
!
<EOS>
She
now
occupied
one
side
of
the
table
by
herself
,
away
from
the
fire
,
where
she
felt
cold
and
desolate
in
the
gloom
of
the
large
half
-
lighted
room
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
occupied
himself
with
Mrs.
Marsham
,
who
talked
politics
to
him
;
and
Mr.
Bott
never
lost
a
moment
in
his
endeavours
to
say
some
civil
word
to
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
gave
him
no
encouragement
;
but
she
hardly
dared
to
snub
him
openly
in
her
husband
's
immediate
presence
.
<EOS>
Twenty
times
during
dinner
she
said
some
little
word
to
Alice
,
attempting
at
first
to
make
the
time
pleasant
,
and
then
,
when
the
matter
was
too
far
gone
for
that
,
attempting
to
give
some
relief
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
of
no
avail
.
<EOS>
There
are
moments
in
which
conversation
seems
to
be
impossible
,
 
in
which
the
very
gods
interfere
to
put
a
seal
upon
the
lips
of
the
unfortunate
one
.
<EOS>
It
was
such
a
moment
now
with
Alice
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
as
yet
been
used
to
snubbing
.
<EOS>
Whatever
position
she
had
hitherto
held
,
in
that
she
had
always
stood
foremost
,
 
much
more
so
than
had
been
good
for
her
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
gone
to
Matching
,
she
had
trembled
for
her
position
;
but
there
all
had
gone
well
with
her
;
there
Lady
Glencora
's
kindness
had
at
first
been
able
to
secure
for
her
a
reception
that
had
been
flattering
,
and
almost
better
than
flattering
.
<EOS>
Jeffrey
Palliser
had
been
her
friend
,
and
would
,
had
she
so
willed
it
,
have
been
more
than
her
friend
.
<EOS>
But
now
she
felt
that
the
halls
of
the
Pallisers
were
too
cold
for
her
,
and
that
the
sooner
she
escaped
from
their
gloom
and
hard
discourtesy
the
better
for
her
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
,
when
the
three
ladies
had
returned
to
the
drawing
-
room
together
,
was
a
little
triumphant
.
<EOS>
She
felt
that
she
had
put
Alice
down
;
and
with
the
energetic
prudence
of
a
good
general
who
knows
that
he
should
follow
up
a
victory
,
let
the
cost
of
doing
so
be
what
it
may
,
she
determined
to
keep
her
down
.
<EOS>
Alice
had
resolved
that
she
would
come
as
seldom
as
might
be
to
Mr.
Palliser
's
house
in
Park
Lane
.
<EOS>
That
resolution
on
her
part
was
in
close
accordance
with
Mrs.
Marsham
's
own
views
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
Miss
Vavasor
going
to
walk
home
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Walk
home
;
 
all
along
Oxford
Street
!
<EOS>
Good
gracious
!
<EOS>
no
.
<EOS>
Why
should
she
walk
?
<EOS>
The
carriage
will
take
her
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Or
a
cab
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
used
to
go
about
London
in
a
cab
by
myself
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
they
are
nice
for
young
ladies
after
dark
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
going
to
offer
my
servant
to
walk
with
her
.
<EOS>
She
is
an
elderly
woman
,
and
would
not
mind
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
Alice
is
very
much
obliged
,
"
said
Lady
.
<EOS>
Glencora
;
"
but
she
will
have
the
carriage
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
-
natured
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
;
"
but
gentlemen
do
so
dislike
having
their
horses
out
at
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
gentleman
's
horses
will
be
out
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
savagely
;
"
and
as
for
mine
,
it
's
what
they
are
there
for
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
often
that
Lady
Glencora
made
any
allusion
to
her
own
property
,
or
allowed
any
one
near
her
to
suppose
that
she
remembered
the
fact
that
her
husband
's
great
wealth
was
,
in
truth
,
her
wealth
.
<EOS>
As
to
many

her
mind
was
wrong
.
<EOS>
In
some
things
her
taste
was
not
delicate
as
should
be
that
of
a
woman
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
regarded
her
money
,
no
woman
could
have

with
greater

,
or

.
<EOS>
But
now
,
when
she
was

by
her

's
special
friend
with
ill
-
usage
to
her
husband
's
horses
,
because
she
chose
to
send
her
own

home
in
her
own

,
she
did
find
it
hard
to
bear
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
it
's
all
right
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
all
right
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
has
given
me

for

own

,
to
do

with

;
and

take

when
they
ought

left
at
home
,
he
can
tell

.
<EOS>
Nobody
else
has
a
right
to
do

.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
by
this

,

almost

,
and
showed
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

Glencora
,
you
have
mistaken
me
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
;
"
I
did
not

of
that
kind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
sorry
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
it
is
such
a
pity
,
as
I
am
quite
used
to
going
about
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
are
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
n't
you
?
<EOS>
I
'd
go
home
in
a

if
I
could
n't

,
and

.
<EOS>
That
's
not
the
question
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
understands

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Upon
my
word
,
I
do
n't

anything
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

Glencora
;
"
that

,

.
<EOS>
Come
,

,

,
"
 
<EOS>
and
she
rang

bell
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
fuss
we
have
made
about
a
stupid
old

!
"
  
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
did
not

that

,

,
no

,

,

.
   
<EOS>
The
Election
for
the
Chelsea
Districts
.
 
<EOS>
March
came
,
and
still
the
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
held
his
position
.
<EOS>
In
the
early
days
of
March
there
was
given
in
the
House
a
certain
parliamentary
explanation
on
the
subject
,
which
,
however
,
did
not
explain
very
much
to
any
person
.
<EOS>
A
statement
was
made
which
was
declared
by
the
persons
making
it
to
be
altogether
satisfactory
,
but
nobody
else
seemed
to
find
any
satisfaction
in
it
.
<EOS>
The
big
wigs
of
the
Cabinet
had
made
an
arrangement
which
,
from
the
language
used
by
them
on
this
occasion
,
they
must
be
supposed
to
have
regarded
as
hardly
less
permanent
than
the
stars
;
but
everybody
else
protested
that
the
Government
was
going
to
pieces
;
and
Mr.
Bott
was
heard
to
declare
in
clubs
and

,
and
wherever
he
could
get
a
semi
-
public
,
political
hearing
,
that
this
kind
of
thing
would
n't
do
.
<EOS>
Lord
Brock
must
either
blow
hot
or
cold
.
<EOS>
If
he
chose
to
lean
upon
Mr.
Palliser
,
he
might
lean
upon
him
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
would
not
be
found
wanting
.
<EOS>
In
such
case
no
opposition
could
touch
Lord
Brock
or

Government
.
<EOS>
That
was
Mr.
Bott
's

.
<EOS>
But

Lord
Brock
did
not
so

,
why
,

,
he
must
expect
that
Mr.
Palliser
,
and

Palliser
's

,
would
 
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
did
not

;

to

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
This

wo
n't

long
,

,
"

Bott
for

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Planty
Pall
wo

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

,

sha

.
<EOS>
All

,

.
<EOS>

ca

?
<EOS>

ca

?
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

!
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

But

"

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

;

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
In

election
came
on

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
Vote
for
Vavasor
and

.
<EOS>
"
That

;

,

.
<EOS>
His

and

,
and

was

on
all

by
questions
as
to
Father
Thames
.
<EOS>
It
was
Mr.
Scruby
who

,
and

Vavasor
an

by

.
<EOS>
There

as

up

,

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.

,

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
and
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

Vavasor

,

<EOS>
"

"

.

,

<EOS>
"

,

;

.

<EOS>

Bank
"
 
<EOS>
the
same

repeated
in

down

.
<EOS>
Vavasor
himself
declared
that
he
was
ashamed
to

among
his
future

,
so

had

name

.
<EOS>
Grimes
saw

,
and

.
<EOS>
At

,

cry

's

.
"
<EOS>

,

he
do

all

gammon
about
the
River
Bank
,
"
said

,
as

other

.
<EOS>
But

,

Scruby

.
"
<EOS>
He
is
a
sharp
"
un
,
that

is
,
"
said

in

inside

of

"
Handsome

;
"
and

that

Scruby
,
although

.
  
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
,
with
much
labour
,
actually
did
get
up
the
subject
of
the
River
Bank
.
<EOS>
He
got
himself

to
men

to
the
Metropolitan
Board
,
and
went
manfully
into
the
matter
of
pounds
,

,
and
pence
.
<EOS>
He
was
able
even
to
work
himself
into
an
apparent
heat
when
he
was
told
that
the
thing
was
out
of
the
question
;
and
soon
found
that
he
had
disciples
who
really
believed
in
him
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
have
brought

thing
,
 
if

been

whether
Chelsea
was
to

no
,
the
work

.
<EOS>
In

,

.
<EOS>
But
such

was

.
<EOS>
He
had
gone
too

in

to

,
or

,
such
things
.
<EOS>
He
was

of
having

in
the
government
of
his
country
,
but
he
was
not
capable
of
caring
even

.
  
<EOS>
But
he
worked
.
<EOS>
He
worked
hard
,
and
spoke
vehemently
,
and
promised
the
men
of
Chelsea
,
Pimlico
,
and
Brompton
that
the
path
of
London
westwards
had
hardly

as
yet
.
<EOS>
Sloane
Street
should
be
the
new
Cheapside
.
<EOS>
Squares
should
arise
around
the
Chelsea
barracks
,
with
sides
open
to
the
water
,
for

Belgravia
would
be

.
<EOS>
There
should
be
palaces
there
for
the
rich
,
because
the
rich
spend
their
riches
;
but
no

's

's

.
<EOS>
Three

noble

,

;

;
 
from

bags

,
Vavasor
once

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
was

own

his
pupil
worked
the
subject
well
.
"
<EOS>
Upon
my
word
,
that
was
uncommon
good
,
"
he
said
,
almost
patting
Vavasor
on

,

that

represent

Chelsea

had
all

of
his
long
-

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
was
in

.
<EOS>
In

,
when

,

;
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

had

Mr.

's

,
and
had

.
  
<EOS>
The

come
so

upon
George
Vavasor
that
there

for

to

<EOS>
Had

,
 
<EOS>
let

<EOS>
what

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

,

himself
,

,

.
<EOS>
The
election

come

,

she

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

as
to

.
<EOS>
He
had
not

because

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
Within

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
There

no

of

,
 
no

,
 
no

.
<EOS>
Vavasor
,

in

,

in

.
<EOS>
She

ill

,
and
there

comfort

.
<EOS>
"
It
serves

,
"

.
"
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

,

In

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Travers
,

,

,

.

"

"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Grimes
went

,

The

.

And

.
<EOS>
Vavasor

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
"
<EOS>

,

,
"

,
"

!
<EOS>

,

,

,
 
that

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And

"

"

!
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

House

,

.
   
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
Takes
His
Seat
.
 
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
's
feeling
of
triumph
was
not
unjustifiable
.
<EOS>
It
is
something
to
have
sat
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
though
it
has
been
but
for
one
session
!
<EOS>
There
is
on
the
left
-
hand
side
of
our
great
national
hall
,
 
on
the
left
-
hand
side
as
one
enters
it
,
and
opposite
to
the
doors
leading
to
the
Law
Courts
,
 
a
pair
of
gilded
lamps
,
with
a
door
between
them
,
near
to
which
a
privileged
old
dame
sells
her
apples
and
her
oranges
solely
,
as
I
presume
,
for
the
accommodation
of
the
Members
of
the
House
and
of
the
great
policeman
who
guards
the
pass
.
<EOS>
Between
those
lamps
is
the
entrance
to
the
House
of
Commons
,
and
none
but
Members
may
go
that
way
!
<EOS>
It
is
the
only
gate
before
which
I
have
ever
stood
filled
with
envy
,
 
sorrowing
to
think
that
my
steps
might
never
pass
under
it
.
<EOS>
There
are
many
portals
forbidden
to
me
,
as
there
are
many
forbidden
to
all
men
;
and
forbidden
fruit
,
they
say
,
is
sweet
;
but
my
lips
have
watered
after
no
other
fruit
but
that
which
grows
so
high
,
within
the
sweep
of
that
great
policeman
's
truncheon
.
  
<EOS>
Ah
,
my
male
friend
and
reader
,
who
earnest
thy
bread
,
perhaps
,
as
a
country
vicar
;
or
sittest
,
may
-
be
,
at
some
weary
desk
in
Somerset
House
;
or
who
,
perhaps
,
rulest
the
yard
behind
the
Cheapside
counter
,
hast
thou
never
stood
there
and
longed
,
 
<EOS>
hast
thou
never
confessed
,
when
standing
there
,
that
Fate
has
been
unkind
to
thee
in
denying
thee
the
one
thing
that
thou
hast
wanted
?
<EOS>
I
have
done
so
;
and
as
my
slow
steps
have
led
me
up
that
more
than
royal

,
to
those
passages
and
halls
which
require
the
hallowing
breath
of
centuries
to
give
them
the
glory
in
British
eyes
which
they
shall
one
day
possess
,
I
have
told
myself
,
in
anger
and
in
grief
,
that
to
die
and
not
to
have
won
that
right
of
way
,
though
but
for
a
session
,
 
not
to
have
passed
by
the
narrow
entrance
through
those
lamps
,
 
is
to
die
and
not
to
have
done
that
which
it
most
becomes
an
Englishman
to
have
achieved
.
  
<EOS>
There
are
,
doubtless
,
some
who
come
out
by
that
road
,
the
loss
of
whose
society
is
not
to
be
regretted
.
<EOS>
England
does
not
choose
her
six
hundred
and
fifty
-
four
best
men
.
<EOS>
One
comforts
one
's
self
,
sometimes
,
with
remembering
that
.
<EOS>
The
George
Vavasors
,
the
Calder
Joneses
,
and
the
Botts
are
admitted
.
<EOS>
Dishonesty
,
ignorance
,
and
vulgarity
do
not
close
the
gate
of
that
heaven
against
aspirants
;
and
it
is
a
consolation
to
the
ambition
of
the
poor
to
know
that
the
ambition
of
the
rich
can
attain
that
glory
by
the
strength
of
its
riches
alone
.
<EOS>
But
though
England
does
not
send
thither
none
but
her
best
men
,
the
best
of
her
Commoners
do
find
their
way
there
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
highest
and
most
legitimate
pride
of
an
Englishman
to
have
the
letters
M.P.
written
after
his
name
.
<EOS>
No
selection
from
the
alphabet
,
no
doctorship
,
no
fellowship
<EOS>
,
be
it
of
ever
so
learned
or
royal
a
society
,
no
knightship
,
 
not
though
it
be
of
the
Garter
,
 
confers
so
fair
an
honour
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
was
right
when
he
declared
that
this
country
is
governed
from
between
the
walls
of
that
House
,
though
the
truth
was
almost
defiled
by
the
lips
which
uttered
it
.
<EOS>
He
might
have
added
that
from
thence
flow
the
waters
of
the
world
's
progress
,
 
the
fullest
fountain
of
advancing
civilization
.
  
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
,
as
he
went
in
by
the
lamps
and
the
apple
-
stall
,
under
the
guardianship
of
Mr.
Bott
,
felt
all
the
pride
of
which
I
have
been
speaking
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
quite
capable
of
feeling
such
pride
as
it
should
be
felt
,
 
capable
,
in
certain
dreamy
moments
,
of
looking
at
the
thing
with
pure
and
almost
noble
eyes
;
of
understanding
the
ambition
of
serving
with
truth
so
great
a
nation
as
that
which
fate
had
made
his
own
.
<EOS>
Nature
,
I
think
,
had
so
fashioned
George
Vavasor
,
that
he
might
have
been
a
good
,
and
perhaps
a
great
man
;
whereas
Mr.
Bott
had
been
born
small
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
had
educated
himself
to
badness
with
his
eyes
open
.
<EOS>
He
had
known
what
was
wrong
,
and
had
done
it
,
having
taught
himself
to
think
that
bad
things
were
best
.
<EOS>
But
poor
Mr.
Bott
had
meant
to
do
well
,
and
thought
that
he
had
done
very
well
indeed
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
tuft
-
hunter
and
a
toady
,
but
he
did
not
know
that
he
was
doing
amiss
in
seeking
to
rise
by
tuft
-
hunting
and
toadying
.
<EOS>
He
was
both
mean
and
vain
,
both
a
bully
and
a
coward
,
and
in
politics
<EOS>
,
I
fear
,
quite
unscrupulous
in
spite
of
his
grand
dogmas
;
but
he
believed
that
he
was
progressing
in
public
life
by
the
proper
and
usual
means
,
and
was
troubled
by
no
idea
that
he
did
wrong
.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
in
those
dreamy
moments
of
which
I
have
spoken
,
would
sometimes
feel
tempted
to
cut
his
throat
and
put
an
end
to
himself
,
because
he
knew
that
he
had
taught
himself
amiss
.
<EOS>
Again
he
would
sadly
ask
himself
whether
it
was
yet
too
late
;
always
,
however
,
answering
himself
that
it
was
too
late
.
<EOS>
Even
now
,
at
this
moment
,
as
he
went
in
between
the
lamps
,
and
felt
much
of
the
honest
pride
of
which
I
have
spoken
,
he
told
himself
that
it
was
too
late
.
<EOS>
What
could
he
do
now
,
hampered
by
such
a
debt
as
that
which
he
owed
to
his
cousin
,
and
with
the
knowledge
that
it
must
be
almost
indefinitely
increased
,
unless
he
meant
to
give
up
this
seat
in
Parliament
,
which
had
cost
him
so
dearly
,
almost
before
he
had
begun
to
enjoy
it
?
<EOS>
But
his
courage
was
good
,
and
he
was
able
to
resolve
that
he
would
go
on
with
the
business
that
he
had
in
hand
,
and
play
out
his
game
to
the
end
.
<EOS>
He
had
achieved
his
seat
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
and
was
so
far
successful
.
<EOS>
Men
who
had
ever
been
gracious
to
him
were
now
more
gracious
than
ever
,
and
they
who
had
not
hitherto
treated
him
with
courtesy
,
now
began
to
smile
and
to
be
very
civil
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
no
doubt
,
a
great
thing
to
have
the
privilege
of
that
entrance
between
the
lamps
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
had
the
new
Member
now
in
hand
,
not
because
there
had
been
any
old
friendship
between
them
,
but
Mr.
Bott
was
on
the
look
-
out
for
followers
,
and
Vavasor
was
on
the
look
-
out
for
a
party
.
<EOS>
A
man
gets
no
great
thanks
for
attaching
himself
to
existing
power
.
<EOS>
Our
friend
might
have
enrolled
himself
among
the
general
supporters
of
the
Government
without
attracting
much
attention
.
<EOS>
He
would
in
such
case
have
been
at
the
bottom
of
a
long
list
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Palliser
was
a
rising
man
,
round
whom
,
almost
without
wish
of
his
own
,
a
party
was
forming
itself
.
<EOS>
If
he
came
into
power
,
 
as
come
he
must
,
according
to
Mr.
Bott
and
many
others
,
 
then
they
who
had
acknowledged
the
new
light
before
its
brightness
had
been
declared
,
might
expect
their
reward
.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
as
he
passed
through
the
lobby
to
the
door
of
the
House
,
leaning
on
Mr.
Bott
's
arm
,
was
very
silent
.
<EOS>
He
had
spoken
but
little
since
they
had
left
their
cab
in
Palace
Yard
,
and
was
not
very
well
pleased
by
the
garrulity
of
his
companion
.
<EOS>
He
was
going
to
sit
among
the
first
men
of
his
nation
,
and
to
take
his
chance
of
making
himself
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
He
believed
in
his
own
ability
;
he
believed
thoroughly
in
his
own
courage
;
but
he
did
not
believe
in
his
own
conduct
.
<EOS>
He
feared
that
he
had
done
,
 
feared
still
more
strongly
that
he
would
be
driven
to
do
,
 
that
which
would
shut
men
's
ears
against
his
words
,
and
would
banish
him
from
high
places
.
<EOS>
No
man
believes
in
himself
who
knows
himself
to
be
a
rascal
,
however
great
may
be
his
talent
,
or
however
high
his
pluck
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
have
heard
a
debate
?
"
said
Mr.
Bott
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
answered
Vavasor
,
who
wished
to
remain
silent
.
  
<EOS>
"
Many
,
probably
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
heard
debates
from
the
gallery
.
<EOS>
Now
you
'll
hear
them
from
the
body
of
the
House
,
and
you
'll
find
how
very
different
it
is
.
<EOS>
There
's
no
man
can
know
what
Parliament
is
who
has
never
had
a
seat
.
<EOS>
Indeed
no
one
can
thoroughly
understand
the
British
Constitution
without
it
.
<EOS>
I
felt
,
very
early
in
life
,
that
that
should
be
my
line
;
and
though
it
's
hard
work
and
no
pay
,
I
mean
to
stick
to
it
.
<EOS>
How
do
,
Thompson
?
<EOS>
You
know
Vavasor
?
<EOS>
He
's
just
returned
for
the
Chelsea
Districts
,
and
I
'm
taking
him
up
.
<EOS>
We
sha
n't
divide
to
-
night
;
shall
we
?
<EOS>
Look
!
<EOS>
there
's
<EOS>
Farringcourt
just
coming
out
;
he
's
listened
to
better
than
any
man
in
the
House
now
,
but
he
'll
borrow
half
-
a
-
crown
from
you
if
you
'll
lend
him
one
.
<EOS>
How
d'ye
do
,
my
lord
?
<EOS>
I
hope
I
have
the
pleasure
of
seeing
you
well
?
"
<EOS>
and
Bott
bowed
low
to
a
lord
who
was
hurrying
through
the
lobby
as
fast
as
his
shuffling
feet
would
carry
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
you
know
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
however
,
did
not
know
the
lord
in
question
,
and
was
obliged
to
say
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
were
up
to
all
these
things
?
"
said
Bott
.
  
<EOS>
"
Taking
the
peerage
generally
,
I
am
not
up
to
it
,
"
said
Vavasor
,
with
a
curl
on
his
lip
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
ought
to
have
known
him
.
<EOS>
That
was
Viscount
Middlesex
;
he
has
got
something
on
to
-
night
about
the
Irish
Church
.
<EOS>
His
father
is
past
ninety
,
and
he
's
over
sixty
.
<EOS>
We
'll
go
in
now
;
but
let
me
give
you
one
bit
of
advice
,
my
dear
fellow
 
do
n't
think
of
speaking
this
session
.
<EOS>
A
Member
can
do
no
good
at
that
work
till
he
has
learned
something
of
the
forms
of
the
House
.
<EOS>
The
forms
of
the
House
are
everything
;
upon
my
word
they
are
.
<EOS>
This
is
Mr.
Vavasor
,
the
new
Member
for
the
Chelsea
Districts
.
"
  
<EOS>
Our
friend
was
thus
introduced
to
the
doorkeeper
,
who
smiled
familiarly
,
and
seemed
to
wink
his
eye
.
<EOS>
Then
George
Vavasor
passed
through
into
the
House
itself
,
under
the
wing
of
Mr.
Bott
.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
as
he
walked
up
the
House
to
the
Clerk
's
table
and
took
the
oath
and
then
walked
down
again
,
felt
himself
to
be
almost
taken
aback
by
the
little
notice
which
was
accorded
to
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
he
had
expected
to
create
a
sensation
,
or
that
he
had
for
a
moment
thought
on
the
subject
,
but
the
thing
which
he
was
doing
was
so
great
to
him
,
that
the
total
indifference
of
those
around
him
was
a
surprise
to
him
.
<EOS>
After
he
had
taken
his
seat
,
a
few
men
came
up
by
degrees
and
shook
hands
with
him
;
but
it
seemed
,
as
they
did
so
,
merely
because
they
were
passing
that
way
.
<EOS>
He
was
anxious
not
to
sit
next
to
Mr.
Bott
,
but
he
found
himself
unable
to
avoid
this
contiguity
.
<EOS>
That
gentleman
stuck
to
him
pertinaciously
,
giving
him
directions
which
,
at
the
spur
of
the
moment
,
he
hardly
knew
how
not
to
obey
.
<EOS>
So
he
found
himself
sitting
behind
Mr.
Palliser
,
a
little
to
the
right
,
while
Mr.
Bott
occupied
the
ear
of
the
rising
man
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
debate
in
progress
,
but
it
seemed
to
Vavasor
,
as
soon
as
he
was
able
to
become
critical
,
to
be
but
a
dull
affair
,
and
yet
the
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
was
on
his
legs
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
was
watching
him
as
a
cat
watches
a
mouse
.
<EOS>
The
speaker
was
full
of
figures
,
as
becomes
a
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
;
and
as
every
new
budget
of
them
fell
from
him
,
Mr.
Bott
,
with
audible
whispers
,
poured
into
the
ear
of
his
chief
certain
calculations
of
his
own
,
most
of
which
went
to
prove
that
the
financier
in
office
was
altogether
wrong
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
thought
that
he
could
see
that
Mr.
Palliser
was
receiving
more
of
his
assistance
than
was
palatable
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
would
listen
,
if
he
did
listen
,
without
making
any
sign
that
he
heard
,
and
would
occasionally
shake
his
head
with
symptoms
of
impatience
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Bott
was
a
man
not
to
be
repressed
by
a
trifle
.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Palliser
shook
his
head
he
became
more
assiduous
than
ever
,
and
when
Mr.
Palliser
slightly
moved
himself
to
the
left
,
he
boldly
followed
him
.
  
<EOS>
No
general
debate
arose
on
the
subject
which
the
Minister
had
in
hand
,
and
when
he
sat
down
,
Mr.
Palliser
would
not
get
up
,
though
Mr.
Bott
counselled
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
The
matter
was
over
for
the
night
,
and
the
time
had
arrived
for
Lord
Middlesex
.
<EOS>
That
nobleman
got
upon
his
feet
,
with
a
roll
of
papers
in
his
hand
,
and
was
proceeding
to
address
the
House
on
certain
matters
of
church
reform
,
with
great
energy
;
but
,
alas
,
for
him
and
for
his
feelings
!
<EOS>
before
his
energy
had
got
itself
into
full
swing
,
the
Members
were
swarming
away
through
the
doors
like
a
flock
of
sheep
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
got
up
and
went
,
and
was
followed
at
once
by
Mr.
Bott
,
who
succeeded
in
getting
hold
of
his
arm
in
the
lobby
.
<EOS>
Had
not
Mr.
Palliser
been
an
even
-
tempered
,
calculating
man
,
with
a
mind
and
spirit
well
under
his
command
,
he
must
have
learned
to
hate
Mr.
Bott
before
this
time
.
<EOS>
Away
streamed
the
Members
,
but
still
the
noble
lord
went
on
speaking
,
struggling
hard
to
keep
up
his
fire
as
though
no
such
exodus
were
in
process
.
<EOS>
There
was
but
little
to
console
him
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
the
papers
would
not
report
one
sentence
in
twenty
of
those
he
uttered
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
no
one
would
listen
to
him
willingly
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
had
worked
for
weeks
and
months
to
get
up
his
facts
,
and
he
was
beginning
to
know
that
he
had
worked
in
vain
.
<EOS>
As
he
summoned
courage
to
look
round
,
he
began
to
fear
that
some
enemy
would
count
the
House
,
and
that
all
would
be
over
.
<EOS>
He
had
given
heart
and
soul
to
this
affair
.
<EOS>
His
cry
was
not
as
Vavasor
's
cry
about
the
River
Bank
.
<EOS>
He
believed
in
his
own
subject
with
a
great
faith
,
thinking
that
he
could
make
men
happier
and
better
,
and
bring
them
nearer
to
their
God
.
<EOS>
I
said
that
he
had
worked
for
weeks
and
months
.
<EOS>
I
might
have
said
that
he
had
been
all
his
life
at
this
work
.
<EOS>
Though
he
shuffled
with
his
feet
when
he
walked
,
and
knocked
his
words
together
when
he
talked
,
he
was
an
earnest
man
,
meaning
to
do
well
,
seeking
no
other
reward
for
his
work
than
the
appreciation
of
those
whom
he
desired
to
serve
.
<EOS>
But
this
was
never
to
be
his
.
<EOS>
For
him
there
was
in
store
nothing
but
disappointment
.
<EOS>
And
yet
he
will
work
on
to
the
end
,
either
in
this
House
or
in
the
other
,
labouring
wearily
,
without
visible
wages
of
any
kind
,
and
,
one
may
say
,
very
sadly
.
<EOS>
But
when
he
has
been
taken
to
his
long
rest
,
men
will
acknowledge
that
he
has
done
something
,
and
there
will
be
left
on
the
minds
of
those
who
shall
remember
him
a
conviction
that
he
served
a
good
cause
diligently
,
and
not
altogether
inefficiently
.
<EOS>
Invisible
are
his
wages
,
yet
in
some
coin
are
they
paid
.
<EOS>
Invisible
is
the
thing
he
does
,
and
yet
it
is
done
.
<EOS>
Let
us
hope
that
some
sense
of
this
tardy
appreciation
may
soothe
his
spirit
beyond
the
grave
.
<EOS>
On
the
present
occasion
there
was
nothing
to
soothe
his
spirit
.
<EOS>
The
Speaker
sat
,
urbane
and
courteous
,
with
his
eyes
turned
towards
the
unfortunate
orator
;
but
no
other
ears
in
the
House
seemed
to
listen
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
corps
of
reporters
had
dwindled
down
to
two
,
and
they
used
their
pens
very
listlessly
,
taking
down
here
a
sentence
and
there
a
sentence
,
knowing
that
their
work
was
naught
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
sat
it
out
to
the
last
,
as
it
taught
him
a
lesson
in
those
forms
of
the
House
which
Mr.
Bott
had
truly
told

it
would
be
well
that
he
should
learn
.
<EOS>
And
at
last
he
did
learn
the
form
of
a
"
count
-
out
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Some
one
from
a
back

muttered
something
,
which
the
Speaker
understood
;
and
that
high
officer
,
having
had

attention
called
to
a
fact
of
which
he
would
never
have
taken

without
such

,
did

House
,
and
finding
that
it
contained
but
<EOS>
twenty
-
three
Members
,
he
put
an
end
to
his
own
labours
and
to
those
of
poor
Lord
Middlesex
.
<EOS>
With
what
feelings
that
noble
lord
must
have
taken

home
,
and
sat

down
in

,
vainly

book
before
his

,
can
we
not
all

?
<EOS>
A
man
he
was
with
ample

,
with
children
who
would
do

name
;
one
whose
wife
believed
in

,

else

;
a

,
let
us

,
with
a
clear

,
to
whom

things
had
been

.
<EOS>
But
of
whom
now
was
he
thinking
with

?
<EOS>
Early
on
that

day
Farringcourt
had
spoken
in
the
House
,
 
a
man
to
whom
no

would
lend

,
whom
the

that
House

out

,
whose
word
no

;
who

,

,

.
<EOS>
But
three
hundred
men
had
hung

upon
his
words
.
<EOS>
When
he
laughed
in
his
speech
,
they

;
when
he
was
indignant
against
the
Minister
,
they
sat
breathless
,
as
the
Spaniard
sits
in
the

of
the
bull

.
<EOS>
Whichever

he
turned
himself
,

with

.
<EOS>
Crowds
of
Members
flocked
into
the
House
from
libraries
and
smoking
-
rooms
when
it
was
known
that
this
ne'er
-
do

well
was
on
his

.
<EOS>
The
Strangers
"
Gallery
was
filled
to

.
<EOS>
The
reporters
turned
their
rapid
pages
,
working
their
fingers
wearily
till
the
sweat
drops
stood
upon

.
<EOS>
And
as
the
Premier
was
attacked
with
some

of
redoubled

,
men
declared
that

driven
to
enrol
the
speaker
among
his

,
in

of
dishonoured

and

.
<EOS>
A
man
who
could
shake
the
thunderbolts
like
that
must
be
paid
to
shake
them
on
the
right
side
.
<EOS>
It
was
of
this
man
,
and

his
success
,
that
Lord
Middlesex
was
envious
,
as
he
sat
,
wretched

respectable
,
in

!
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
had
left
the
House
with
Mr.
Palliser
;
and
Vavasor
,
after
the
count
-
out
,
was
able
to
walk
home
by
himself
,
and
think
of
the
position
which
he
had
achieved
.
<EOS>
He
told
himself
over
and
over
again
that
he
had
done
a
great
thing
in
obtaining
that
which
he
now
possessed
,
and
he
endeavoured
to
teach

that
the
price
he
was

for

was
not
too

.
<EOS>
But
already
there
had
come
upon

something
of
that
feeling
,
 
that
terribly
human
feeling
,
 
which
deprives
every
prize
that
is
gained
of
half
its

.
<EOS>
The
mere
having
it
robs
the
diamond
of
its
purity
,
and
mixes
vile

with
the
gold
.
<EOS>
Lord
Middlesex
,
as
he
had
floundered
on
into
terrible
disaster
,
had
not
been
a
subject
to
envy
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
nothing
of

in
the

,
and
the
Members
had
loomed
no
larger
than
ordinary
men
at
ordinary

.
<EOS>
The
very
doorkeepers
had
hardly
treated
them
with

.
<EOS>
The
great
men
with
whose
names
the
papers
are
filled
had
sat
silent
,

,
and

.
<EOS>
As

a

was

they

out

the
House
,
as
boys
might
escape
from

.
<EOS>
Everybody
had
rejoiced
in
the
break
-
up
of
the
evening
,
except
that
one
poor
old
lord
who
had
worked
so
hard
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
had
spent
everything
that
he
had
to

a

that

,

now
,

,

whether

was
worth
the

-
money
.
  
<EOS>
But
his
courage
was
still
high
.
<EOS>
Though
he
was
gloomy
,
and
almost
sad
,
he
knew
that
he
could
trust
himself
to
fight

to

.
<EOS>
On

morrow
he
would
go
to
Queen
Anne
Street
,
and
would

from
her
who
had

.
<EOS>
With
her
,

,

his
Membership

.
<EOS>
She
had
only

play
acted

boxes
;
and
to
her

the
dresses
would
still
be
of
silk

,
and
the

of
bright

.
   
<EOS>
A
Love
Gift
.
 
<EOS>
When
Alice
heard
of
her
cousin
's
success
,
and
understood
that
he
was
actually
Member
of
Parliament
for
the
Chelsea
Districts
,
she
resolved
that
she
would
be
triumphant
.
<EOS>
She
had
sacrificed
nearly
everything
to
her
desire
for
his
success
in
public
life
,
and
now
that
he
had
achieved
the
first

step
towards
that
success
,
it
would
have
been
madness
on
her
part
to
decline
her

in
the
ovation
.
<EOS>
If
she
could
not
rejoice
in
that
,
what
source
of
joy
would
then
be
left
for
her
?
<EOS>
She
had
promised
to
be
his
wife
,
and
at
present
she
was
under
the
bonds
of
that

.
<EOS>
She
had
so
promised
because
she
had
desired
to

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

done

,
and

had

.
<EOS>
She
strove
,

,
to
be

on
his

,
but
she
knew
that
she

.
<EOS>
She
had
made

,
and
the
days
were

in

would

to
own

that
she
had
done
so
in

,
and
to

.
  
<EOS>
But
yet
she
struggled
to
be

.
<EOS>
The

,
and
then

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
She

written

had
left

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

the

.
<EOS>
"
It

.
"
<EOS>
But

Kate
,

.
<EOS>
Kate

.
<EOS>
To

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
She

;
 
about

;

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Poor

!
<EOS>
One

"

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
She

;

<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
So
George

,
"

<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon

.
<EOS>
He

;

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Two

<EOS>

"
  
"

<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>
Indeed
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
On

her
father
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,
and
I
know
well
that
nothing
that
I
can
say
will
turn
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
believe
that
when
he
has
spent
all
your
money
he
will
not
take
you
,
and
that
thus
you
will
be
saved
.
<EOS>
Thinking
as
I
do
about
him
,
you
can
hardly
expect
that
I
should
triumph
because
he
has
got
himself
into
Parliament
with
your
money
!
"
  
<EOS>
Then
he
left
her
,
and
it
seemed
to
Alice
that
he
had
been
very
cruel
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
little
,
she
thought
,
nay
,
nothing
of
a
father
's
loving
tenderness
in
his
words
to
her
.
<EOS>
If
he
had
spoken
to
her
differently
,
might
she
not
even
now
have
confessed
everything
to
him
?
<EOS>
But
herein
Alice
accused
him
wrongfully
.
<EOS>
Tenderness
from
him
on
this
subject
had
,
we
may
say
,
become
impossible
.
<EOS>
She
had
made
it
impossible
.
<EOS>
Nor
could
he
tell
her
the
extent
of
his
wishes
without
damaging
his
own
cause
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
let
her
know
that
all
that
was
done
was
so
done
with
the
view
of
driving
her
into
John
Grey
's
arms
.
  
<EOS>
But
what
words
were
those
for
a
father
to
speak
to
a
daughter
!
<EOS>
Had
she
brought
herself
to
such
a
state
that
her
own
father
desired
to
see
her
deserted
and
thrown
aside
?
<EOS>
And
was
it
probable
that
this
wish
of
his
should
come
to
pass
?
<EOS>
As
to
that
,
Alice
had
already
made
up
her
mind
.
<EOS>
She
thought
that
she
had
made
up
her
mind
that
she
would
never
become
her
cousin
's
wife
.
<EOS>
It
needed
not
her
father
's
wish
to
accomplish
her
salvation
,
if
her
salvation
lay
in
being
separated
from
him
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
next
morning
George
went
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
reader
will
,
perhaps
,
remember
their
last
interview
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
her
after
her
letter
to
him
from
Westmoreland
,
and
had
asked
her
to
seal
their
reconciliation
with
a
kiss
;
but
she
had
refused
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
offered
to
embrace
her
,
and
she
had
shuddered
before
him
,
fearing
his
touch
,
telling
him
by
signs
much
more
clear
than
any
words
,
that
she
felt
for
him
none
of
the
love
of
a
woman
.
<EOS>
Then
he
had
turned
from
her
in
anger
,
declaring
to
her
honestly
that
he
was
angry
.
<EOS>
Since
that
he
had
borrowed
her
money
,
 
had
made
two
separate
assaults
upon
her
purse
,
 
and
was
now
come
to
tell
her
of
the
results
.
<EOS>
How
was
he
to
address
her
?
<EOS>
I
beg
that
it
may
be
also
remembered
that
he
was
not
a
man
to
forget
the
treatment
he
had
received
.
<EOS>
When
he
entered
the
room
,
Alice
looked
at
him
,
at
first
,
almost
furtively
.
<EOS>
She
was
afraid
of
him
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
confessed
that
she
already
feared
him
.
<EOS>
Had
there
been
in
the
man
anything
of
lofty
principle
he
might
still
have
made
her
his
slave
,
though
I
doubt
whether
he
could
ever
again
have
forced
her
to
love
him
.
<EOS>
She
looked
at
him
furtively
,
and
perceived
that
the
gash
on
his
face
was
nearly
closed
.
<EOS>
The
mark
of
existing
anger
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
her
intending
to
be
gentle
,
if
it
might
be
possible
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
careful
in
his
dress
,
as
though
he
wished
to
try
once
again
if
the
rôle
of
lover
might
be
within
his
reach
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
was
the
first
to
speak
.
"
<EOS>
George
,
I
am
so
glad
that
you
have
succeeded
!
<EOS>
I
wish
you
joy
with
my
whole
heart
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thanks
,
dearest
.
<EOS>
But
before
I
say
another
word
,
let
me
acknowledge
my
debt
.
<EOS>
Unless
you
had
aided
me
with
your
money
,
I
could
not
have
succeeded
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
George
!
<EOS>
pray
do
n't
speak
of
that
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
rather
speak
of
it
at
once
,
and
have
done
.
<EOS>
If
you
will
think
of
it
,
you
will
know
that
I
must
speak
of
it
sooner
or
later
.
"
<EOS>
He
smiled
and
looked
pleasant
,
as
he
used
to
do
in
those
Swiss
days
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
,
speak
and
have
done
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
have
trusted
me
in
thus
giving
me
the
command
of
your
fortune
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
believe
that
you
have
.
<EOS>
I
need
hardly
say
that
I
could
not
have
stood
for
this
last
election
without
it
;
and
I
must
try
to
make
you
understand
that
if
I
had
not
come
forward
at
this
vacancy
,
I
should
have
stood
no
chance
for
the
next
;
otherwise
,
I
should
not
have
been
justified
in
paying
so
dearly
for
a
seat
for
one
session
.
<EOS>
You
can
understand
that
;
eh
,
Alice
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
think
so
?
  
<EOS>
"
Anybody
,
even
your
father
,
would
tell
you
that
;
though
,
probably
,
he
regards
my
ambition
to
be
a
Member
of
Parliament
as
a
sign
of
downright
madness
.
<EOS>
But
I
was
obliged
to
stand
now
,
if
I
intended
to
go
on
with
it
,
as
that
old
lord
died
so
inopportunely
.
<EOS>
Well
,
about
the
money
!
<EOS>
It
is
quite
upon
the
cards
that
I
may
be
forced
to
ask
for
another
loan
when
the
autumn
comes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
it
,
George
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thanks
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
And
now
I
will
tell
you
what
I
propose
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
I
have
been
reconciled
,
 
with
a
sort
of
reconciliation
,
 
to
my
grandfather
?
<EOS>
Well
,
when
the
next
affair
is
over
,
I
propose
to
tell
him
exactly
how
you
and
I
then
stand
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
go
into
that
now
,
George
.
<EOS>
It
is
enough
for
you
at
present
to
be
assured
that
such
assistance
as
I
can
give
you
is
at
your
command
.
<EOS>
I
want
you
to
feel
the
full
joy
of
your
success
,
and
you
will
do
so
more
thoroughly
if
you
will
banish
all
these
money
troubles
from
your
mind
for
a
while
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
shall
,
at
any
rate
,
be
banished
while
I
am
with
you
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
There
;
let
them
go
!
"
<EOS>
And
he
lifted
up
his
right
hand
,
and
blew
at
the
tips
of
his
fingers
.
<EOS>
"
Let
them
vanish
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
always
well
to
be
rid
of
such
troubles
for
a
time
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
is
well
to
be
rid
of
them
at
any
time
,
or
at
all
times
,
if
only
they
can
be
banished
without
danger
.
<EOS>
But
when
a
man
has
overused
his
liver
till
it
will
not
act
for
him
any
longer
,
it
is
not
well
for
him
to
resolve
that
he
will
forget
the
weakness
of
his
organ
just
as
he
sits
down
to
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
pretty
bit
of
acting
,
that
of
Vavasor
's
,
when
he
blew
away
his
cares
;
and
,
upon
the
whole
,
I
do
not
know
that
he
could
have
done
better
.
<EOS>
But
Alice
saw
through
it
,
and
he
knew
that
she
did
so
.
<EOS>
The
whole
thing
was
uncomfortable
to
him
,
except
the
fact
that
he
had
the
promise
of
her
further
moneys
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
intend
to
rest
satisfied
with
this
.
<EOS>
He
must
extract
from
her
some
meed
of
approbation
,
some
show
of
sympathy
,
some
spark
of
affection
,
true
or
pretended
,
in
order
that
he
might
at
least
affect
to
be
satisfied
,
and
be
enabled
to
speak
of
the
future
without
open
embarrassment
.
<EOS>
How
could
even
he
take
her
money
from
her
,
unless
he
might
presume
that
he
stood
with
her
upon
some
ground
that
belonged
mutually
to
them
both
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
already
taken
my
seat
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
saw
that
in
the
newspapers
.
<EOS>
My
acquaintance
among
Members
of
Parliament
is
very
small
,
but
I
see
that
you
were
introduced
,
as
they
call
it
,
by
one
of
the
few
men
that
I
do
know
.
<EOS>
Is
Mr.
Bott
a
friend
of
yours
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
 
certainly
not
a
friend
.
<EOS>
I
may
probably
have
to
act
with
him
in
public
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
that
's
just
what
they
said
of
Mr.
Palliser
when
they
felt
ashamed
of
his
having
such
a
man
as
his
guest
.
<EOS>
I
think
if
I
were
in
public
life
I
should
try
to
act
with
people
that
I
could
like
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
dislike
Mr.
Bott
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
like
him
,
but
my
feelings
about
him
are
not
violent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
vulgar
ass
,
"
said
George
,
"
with
no
more
pretensions
to
rank
himself
a
gentleman
than
your
footman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
If
I
had
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
will
get
on
in
Parliament
,
to
a
certain
extent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afraid
I
do
n't
quite
understand
what
are
the
requisites
for
Parliamentary
success
,
or
indeed
of
what
it
consists
.
<EOS>
Is
his
ambition
,
do
you
suppose
,
the
same
as
yours
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
His
ambition
,
I
take
it
,
does
not
go
beyond
a
desire
to
be
Parliamentary
flunkey
to
a
big
man
,
 
with
wages
,
if
possible
,
but
without
,
if
the
wages
are
impossible
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
yours
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
as
to
mine
;
 
there
are
some
things
,
Alice
,
that
a
man
does
not
tell
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
there
?
<EOS>
They
must
be
very
terrible
things
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
schoolboy
,
when
he
sits
down
to
make
his
rhymes
,
dares
not
say
,
even
to
his
sister
,
that
he
hopes
to
rival
Milton
;
but
he
nurses
such
a
hope
.
<EOS>
The
preacher
,
when
he
preaches
his
sermon
,
does
not
whisper
,
even
to
his
wife
,
his
belief
that
thousands
may
perhaps
be
turned
to
repentance
by
the
strength
of
his
words
;
but
he
thinks
that
the
thousand
converts
are
possible
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
you
,
though
you
will
not
say
so
,
intend
to
rival
Chatham
,
and
to
make
your
thousand
converts
in
politics
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
like
to
hear
you
laugh
at
me
,
 
I
do
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
It
does
me
good
to
hear
your
voice
again
with
some
touch
of
satire
in
it
.
<EOS>
It
brings
back
the
old
days
,
 
the
days
to
which
I
hope
we
may
soon
revert
without
pain
.
<EOS>
Shall
it
not
be
so
,
dearest
?
"
  
<EOS>
Her
playful
manner
at
once
deserted
her
.
<EOS>
Why
had
he
made
this
foolish
attempt
to
be
tender
?
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
,
"
she
said
,
gloomily
.
  
<EOS>
For
a
few
minutes
he
sat
silent
,
fingering
some
article
belonging
to
her
which
was
lying
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
small
steel
paper
-
knife
,
of
which
the
handle
was
cast
and
gilt
;
a
thing
of
no
great
value
,
of
which
the
price
may
have
been
five
shillings
.
<EOS>
He
sat
with
it
,
passing
it
through
his
fingers
,
while
she
went
on
with
her
work
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
gave
you
this
paper
-
cutter
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
suddenly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Goodness
me
,
why
do
you
ask
?
<EOS>
and
especially
,
why
do
you
ask
in
that
way
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
asked
simply
because
if
it
is
a
present
to
you
from
any
one
,
I
will
take
up
something
else
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
given
me
by
Mr.
Grey
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
let
it
drop
from
his
fingers
on
to
the
table
with
a
noise
,
and
then
pushed
it
from
him
,
so
that
it
fell
on
the
other
side
,
near
to
where
she
sat
.
  
<EOS>
"
George
,
"
she
said
,
as
she
stooped
and
picked
it
up
,
"
your
violence
is
unreasonable
;
pray
do
not
repeat
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
mean
it
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
I
beg
your
pardon
.
<EOS>
I
was
simply
unfortunate
in
the
article
I
selected
.
<EOS>
And
who
gave
you
this
?
"
<EOS>
In
saying
which
he
took
up
a
little
ivory
foot
-
rule
that
was
folded
up
so
as
to
bring
it
within
the
compass
of
three
inches
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
so
happens
that
no
one
gave
me
that
;
I
bought
it
at
a
stupid
bazaar
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
this
will
do
.
<EOS>
You
shall
give
it
me
as
a
present
,
on
the
renewal
of
our
love
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
too
poor
a
thing
to
give
,
"
said
she
,
speaking
still
more
gloomily
than
she
had
done
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
By
no
means
;
nothing
is
too
poor
,
if
given
in
that
way
.
<EOS>
Anything
will
do
;
a
ribbon
,
a
glove
,
a
broken
sixpence
.
<EOS>
Will
you
give
me
something
that
I
may
take
,
and
,
taking
it
,
may
know
that
your
heart
is
given
with
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take
the
rule
,
if
you
please
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
about
the
heart
?
"
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
He
should
have
been
more
of
a
rascal
or
less
.
<EOS>
Seeing
how
very
much
of
a
rascal
he
was
already
,
I
think
it
would
have
been
better
that
he
should
have
been
more
,
 
that
he
should
have
been
able
to
content
his
spirit
with
the
simple
acquisition
of
her
money
,
and
that
he
should
have
been
free
from
all
those
remains
of
a
finer
feeling
which
made
him
desire
her
love
also
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
so
.
<EOS>
It
was
necessary
for
his
comfort
that
she
should
,
at
any
rate
,
say
she
loved
him
.
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Alice
,
and
what
about
the
heart
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
so
much
rather
talk
about
politics
,
George
,
"
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
The
cicatrice
began
to
make
itself
very
visible
in
his
face
,
and
the
debonair
manner
was
fast
vanishing
.
<EOS>
He
had
fixed
his
eyes
upon
her
,
and
had
inserted
his
thumbs
in
the
armholes
of
his
waistcoat
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
that
is
not
quite
fair
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
mean
to
be
unfair
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
so
sure
of
that
.
<EOS>
I
almost
think
that
you
do
mean
it
.
<EOS>
You
have
told
me
that
you
intend
to
become
my
wife
.
<EOS>
If
,
after
that
,
you
wilfully
make
me
miserable
,
will
not
that
be
unfair
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
making
you
miserable
,
 
certainly
not
wilfully
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
that
letter
which
you
wrote
to
me
from
Westmoreland
mean
anything
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
George
,
do
not
strive
to
make
me
think
that
it
meant
too
much
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
it
did
,
you
had
better
say
so
at
once
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
Alice
,
though
she
would
have
said
so
had
she
dared
,
made
no
answer
to
this
.
<EOS>
She
sat
silent
,
turning
her
face
away
from
his
gaze
,
longing
that
the
meeting
might
be
over
,
and
feeling
that
she
had
lost
her
own
self
-
respect
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
Alice
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
find
it
very
hard
to
understand
you
.
<EOS>
When
I
look
back
over
all
that
has
passed
between
us
,
and
to
that
other
episode
in
your
life
,
summing
it
all
up
with
your
conduct
to
me
at
present
,
I
find
myself
at
a
loss
to
read
your
character
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
I
can
not
help
you
in
the
reading
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
you
first
loved
me
;
 
for
you
did
love
me
.
<EOS>
I
understood
that
well
enough
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
young
man
who
in
early
life
does
not
read
with
sufficient
clearness
that
sweetest
morsel
of
poetry
.
 
<EOS>
And
when
you
quarrelled
with
me
,
judging
somewhat
harshly
of
my
offences
,
I
understood
that
also
;
for
it
is
the
custom
of
women
to
be
hard
in
their
judgement
on
such
sins
.
<EOS>
When
I
heard
that
you
had
accepted
the
offer
made
to
you
by
that
gentleman
in
Cambridgeshire
,
I
thought
that
I
understood
you
still
,
 
knowing
how
natural
it
was
that
you
should
seek
some
cure
for
your
wound
.
<EOS>
I
understood
it
,
and
accused
myself
,
not
you
,
in
that
I
had
driven
you
to
so
fatal
a
remedy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
Alice
turned
round
towards
him
sharply
,
as
though
she
were
going
to
interrupt
him
,
but
she
said
nothing
,
though
he
paused
for
her
to
speak
;
and
then
he
went
on
.
"
<EOS>
And
I
understood
it
well
when
I
heard
that
this
cure
had
been
too
much
for
you
.
<EOS>
By
heavens
,
yes
!
<EOS>
there
was
no
misunderstanding
that
.
<EOS>
I
meant
no
insult
to
the
man
when
I
upset
his
little
toy
just
now
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
a
word
to
say
against
him
.
<EOS>
For
many
women
he
would
make
a
model
husband
,
but
you
are
not
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
And
when
you
discovered
this
yourself
,
as
you
did
,
I
understood
that
without
difficulty
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
by
heavens
!
<EOS>
if
ever
woman
had
been
driven
to
a
mistake
,
you
had
been
driven
to
one
there
.
<EOS>
"
Here
she
looked
at
him
again
,
and
met
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
She
looked
at
him
with
something
of
his
own
fierceness
in
her
face
,
as
though
she
were
preparing
herself
to
fight
with
him
;
but
she
said
nothing
at
the
moment
,
and
then
he
again
went
on
.
"
<EOS>
And
,
Alice
,
I
understood
it
also
when
you
again
consented
to
be
my
wife
.
<EOS>
I
thought
that
I
still
understood
you
then
.
<EOS>
I
may
have
been
vain
to
think
so
,
but
surely
it
was
natural
.
<EOS>
I
believed
that
the
old
love
had
come
back
upon
you
,
and
again
warmed
your
heart
.
<EOS>
I
thought
that
it
had
been
cold
during
our
separation
,
and
I
was
pleased
to
think
so
.
<EOS>
Was
that
unnatural
?
<EOS>
Put
yourself
in
my
place
,
and
say
if
you
would
not
have
thought
so
.
<EOS>
I
told
myself
that
I
understood
you
then
,
and
I
told
myself
that
in
all
that
you
had
done
you
had
acted
as
a
true
,
and
good
,
and
loving
woman
.
<EOS>
I
thought
of
you
much
,
and
I
saw
that
your
conduct
,
as
a
whole
,
was
intelligible
and
becoming
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
last
word
grated
on
Alice
's
ears
,
and
she
showed
her
anger
by
the
motion
of
her
foot
upon
the
floor
.
<EOS>
Her
cousin
noted
it
all
,
but
went
on
as
though
he
had
not
noted
it
.
"
<EOS>
But
now
your
present
behaviour
makes
all
the
rest
a
riddle
.
<EOS>
You
have
said
that
you
would
be
my
wife
,
declaring
thereby
that
you
had
forgiven
my
offences
,
and
,
as
I
suppose
,
reassuring
me
of
your
love
;
and
yet
you
receive
me
with
all
imaginable
coldness
.
<EOS>
What
am
I
to
think
of
it
,
and
in
what
way
would
you
have
me
behave
to
you
?
<EOS>
When
last
I
was
here
I
asked
you
for
a
kiss
.
"
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
he
looked
at
her
with
all
his
eyes
,
with
his
mouth
just
open
,
so
as
to
show
the
edges
of
his
white
teeth
,
with
the
wound
down
his
face
all
wide
and
purple
.
<EOS>
The
last
word
came
with
a
stigmatizing
hiss
from
his
lips
.
<EOS>
Though
she
did
not
essay
to
speak
,
he
paused
again
,
as
if
he
were
desirous
that
she
might
realize
the
full
purport
of
such
a
request
.
<EOS>
I
think
that
,
in
the
energy
of
his
speaking
,
a
touch
of
true
passion
had
come
upon
him
;
that
he
had
forgotten
his
rascaldom
,
and
his
need
of
her
money
,
and
that
he
was
punishing
her
with
his
whole
power
of
his
vengeance
for
the
treatment
which
he
had
received
from
her
.
<EOS>
"
I
asked
you
for
a
kiss
.
<EOS>
If
you
are
to
be
my
wife
you
can
have
no
shame
in
granting
me
such
a
request
.
<EOS>
Within
the
last
two
months
you
have
told
me
that
you
would
marry
me
.
<EOS>
What
am
I
to
think
of
such
a
promise
if
you
deny
me
all
customary
signs
of
your
affection
?
<EOS>
"
Then
he
paused
again
,
and
she
found
that
the
time
had
come
in
which
she
must
say
something
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
you
can
not
understand
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
I
have
suffered
much
.
"
  
"
And
is
that
to
be
my
answer
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
answer
you
want
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Alice
,
do
not
be
untrue
;
you
do
know
what
answer
I
want
,
and
you
know
also
whether
my
wanting
it
is
unreasonable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
one
ever
told
me
that
I
was
untrue
before
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
know
what
it
is
that
I
desire
.
<EOS>
I
desire
to
learn
that
the
woman
who
is
to
be
my
wife
,
in
truth
,
loves
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
standing
up
,
and
so
was
he
also
,
<EOS>
but
still
she
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
He
had
in
his
hand
the
little
rule
which
she
had
told
him
that
he
might
take
,
but
he
held
it
as
though
in
doubt
what
he
would
do
with
it
.
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Alice
,
am
I
to
hear
anything
from
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
now
,
George
;
you
are
angry
,
and
I
will
not
speak
to
you
in
your
anger
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have
I
not
cause
to
be
angry
?
<EOS>
Do
you
not
know
that
you
are
treating
me
badly
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
my
head
aches
,
and
that
I
am
very
wretched
.
<EOS>
I
wish
you
would
leave
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
then
,
is
your
gift
,
"
said
he
,
and
he
threw
the
rule
over
on
to
the
sofa
behind
her
.
"
<EOS>
And
there
is
the
trumpery
trinket
which
I
had
hoped
you
would
have
worn
for
my
sake
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Whereupon
something
which
he
had
taken
from
his
waistcoat
-
pocket
was
thrown
violently
into
the
fender
,
beneath
the
fire
-
grate
.
<EOS>
He
then
walked
with
quick
steps
to
the
door
;
but
when
his
hand
was
on
the
handle
,
he
turned
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
said
,
"
when
I
am
gone
,
try
to
think
honestly
of
your
conduct
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
went
,
and
she
remained
still
,
till
she
heard
the
front
door
close
behind
him
.
  
<EOS>
When
she
was
sure
that
he
was
gone
,
her
first
movement
was
made
in
search
of
the
trinket
.
<EOS>
I
fear
that
this
was
not
dignified
on
her
part
;
but
I
think
that
it
was
natural
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
she
had
any
desire
for
the
jewel
,
or
any
curiosity
even
to
see
it
.
<EOS>
She
would
very
much
have
preferred
that
he
should
have
brought
nothing
of
the
kind
to
her
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
a
feminine
reluctance
that
anything
of
value
should
be
destroyed
without
a
purpose
.
<EOS>
So
she
took
the
shovel
,
and
poked
among
the
ashes
,
and
found
the
ring
which
her
cousin
had
thrown
there
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
valuable
ring
,
bearing
a
ruby
on
it
between
two
small
diamonds
.
<EOS>
Such
at
least
,
she
became
aware
,
had
been
its
bearing
;
but
one
of
the
side
stones
had
been
knocked
out
by
the
violence
with
which
the
ring
had
been
flung
.
<EOS>
She
searched
even
for
this
,
scorching
her
face
and
eyes
,
but
in
vain
.
<EOS>
Then
she
made
up
her
mind
that
the
diamond
should
be
lost
for
ever
,
and
that
it
should
go
out
among
the
cinders
into
the
huge
dust
-
heaps
of
the
metropolis
.
<EOS>
Better
that
,
though
it
was
distasteful
to
her
feminine
economy
,
than
the
other
alternative
of
setting
the
servants
to
search
,
and
thereby
telling
them
something
of
what
had
been
done
.
  
<EOS>
When
her
search
was
over
,
she
placed
the
ring
on
the
mantelpiece
;
but
she
knew
that
it
would
not
do
to
leave
it
there
,
 
so
she
folded
it
up
carefully
in
a
new
sheet
of
note
-
paper
,
and
put
it
in
the
drawer
of
her
desk
.
<EOS>
After
that
she
sat
herself
down
at
the
table
to
think
what
she
would
do
;
but
her
head
was
,
in
truth
,
racked
with
pain
,
and
on
that
occasion
she
could
bring
her
thoughts
to
no
conclusion
.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
's
Disappointment
.
 
<EOS>
When
Mrs.
Greenow
was
left
alone
in
her
lodgings
,
after
the
little
entertainment
which
she
had
given
to
her
two
lovers
,
she
sat
herself
down
to
think
seriously
over
her
affairs
.
<EOS>
There
were
three
paths
open
before
her
.
<EOS>
She
might
take
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
or
she
might
take
Captain
Bellfield
 
<EOS>
or
she
might
decide
that
she
would
have
nothing
more
to
say
to
either
of
them
in
the
way
of
courting
.
<EOS>
They
were
very
persistent
,
no
doubt
;
but
she
thought
that
she
would
know
how
to
make
them
understand
her
,
if
she
should
really
make
up
her
mind
that
she
would
have
neither
one
nor
the
other
.
<EOS>
She
was
going
to
leave
Norwich
after
Easter
,
and
they
knew
that
such
was
her
purpose
.
<EOS>
Something
had
been
said
of
her
returning
to
Yarmouth
in
the
summer
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
just
woman
at
heart
,
and
justice
required
that
each
of
them
should
know
what
was
to
be
his
prospect
if
she
did
so
return
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
good
deal
to
be
said
on
Mr.
Cheesacre
's
behalf
.
<EOS>
Mahogany
-
furnitured
bedrooms
assist
one
's
comfort
in
this
life
;
and
heaps
of
manure
,
though
they
are
not
brilliant
in
romance
,
are
very
efficacious
in
farming
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
by
no
means
despised
these
things
;
and
as
for
the
owner
of
them
,
though
she
saw
that
there
was
much
amiss
in
his
character
,
she
thought
that
his
little
foibles
were
of
such
a
nature
that
she
,
as
his
wife
,
or
any
other
woman
of
spirit
,
might
be
able
to
repress
them
,
if
not

cure

.
<EOS>
But
she
had
already
married
for
money
once
,
as

told
herself
very

on
this

,
and
she
thought
that
she
might
now
venture
on
a
little
love
.
<EOS>
Her
marriage
for
money
had
been
altogether

.
<EOS>
The

of
old
Greenow
had
not

,

.
<EOS>
She

that

,
and

to
his

.
<EOS>
I

think
that
among
those

some

.
<EOS>
She
was
essentially

happy

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
So

,

,

,

<EOS>
But

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>

worked

"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Thus

forth
resolved

,
 
as

death
might

which

Greenow
might

him
.
<EOS>
He
waited
,
on
this
occasion
,
for
the
coming
of
no
market
-
day
;
indeed
,
the
journey
into
the
city
was
altogether
special
,
and
he
was
desirous
that
she
should
know
that
such
was
the
case
.
<EOS>
He
drove
at
a
great
pace
into
the
inn
-
yard
,
threw
his
reins
to
the
ostler
,
took
just
one
glass
of
cherry
-
brandy
at
the
bar
,
and
then
marched
off
across
the
market
-
place
to
the
Close
,
with
quiet
and
decisive
steps
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
you
,
Cheesacre
?
"
said
a
friendly
voice
,
in
one
of
the
narrow
streets
.
<EOS>
"
Who
expected
to
see
you
in
Norwich
on
a
Thursday
!
<EOS>
"
It
was
Grimsby
,
the
son
of
old
Grimsby
of
Hatherwich
,
a
country
gentleman
,
and
one
,
therefore
,
to
whom
Cheesacre
would
generally
pay
much
respect
;
but
on
this
occasion
he
did
not
even
pull
up
for
an
instant
,
or
moderate
his
pace
.
"
<EOS>
A
little
bit
of
private
business
,
"
he
said
,
and
marched
onwards
with
his
head
towards
the
Close
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
going
to
be
afraid
of
a
woman
 
<EOS>
not
if
I
know
it
,
"
he
said
to
himself
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
at
a
certain
pastrycook
's
,
of
whose
shop
he
had
knowledge
,
he
pulled
up
and
had
another
glass
of
cherry
-
brandy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Greenow
is
at
home
,
"
he
said
to
Jeannette
,
not
deigning
to
ask
any
question
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
sir
;
she
is
at
home
,
"
said
Jeannette
,
conscious
that
some
occasion
had
arrived
;
and
in
another
second
he
was
in
the
presence
of
his
angel
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
whoever
expected
to
see
you
in
Norwich
on
a
Thursday
?
"
said
the
lady
,
as
she
welcomed
him
,
using
almost
the
same
words
as
his
friend
had
done
in
the
street
.
<EOS>
Why
should
not
he
come
into
Norwich
on
a
Thursday
,
as
well
as
any
one
else
?
<EOS>
Did
they
suppose
that
he
was
tied
for
ever
to
his
ploughs
and
carts
?
<EOS>
He
was
minded
to
conduct
himself
with
a
little
spirit
on
this
occasion
,
and
to
improve
the
opinion
which
Mrs.
Greenow
had
formed
about
him
.
<EOS>
On
this
account
he
answered
her
somewhat
boldly
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
knowing
when
I
may
be
in
Norwich
,
Mrs.
Greenow
,
or
when
I
may
n't
.
<EOS>
I
'm
one
of
those
men
of
whom
nobody
knows
anything
certain
,
except
that
I
pay
as
I
go
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
he
remembered
that
he
was
not
to
make
any
more
boasts
about
his
money
,
and
he
endeavoured
to
cover
the
error
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
one
other
thing
they
may
all
know
if
they
please
,
but
we
wo
n't
say
what
that
is
just
at
present
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
sit
down
,
Mr.
Cheesacre
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
 
thank
you
,
 
I
will
sit
down
for
a
few
minutes
if
you

let

,
Mrs.
Greenow
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
,
I
'm
in
such

mind
that
I
must
put
an
end
to
it
,
or
else
I
shall
be

,
and
doing
somebody

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
what
has
happened
to
you
?
<EOS>
You
're
going
out
shooting
,
presently
;
are
you
not
?
"
<EOS>
and
Mrs.
Greenow
looked
down
at
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
Mrs.
Greenow
,
I
'm
not
going
out
shooting
.
<EOS>
I
put
on
these
things
because
I
thought
I
might
take
a
shot
as
I
came
along
.
<EOS>
But
I
could
n't
bring
myself
to
do
it
,
and
then
I
would
n't
take
them
off
again
.
<EOS>
What
does

matter
what
a
man
wears
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not

the
least
,
so
long

he
is
decent
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
I
'm
always
that
,
Mrs.
Greenow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
,
yes
.
<EOS>
More
than
that
,
I
should
say
.
<EOS>
I
consider
you
to
be
rather
gay
in
your
attire
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
pretend
to
anything
of
that
kind
,
Mrs.
Greenow
.
<EOS>
I
like
to
be
nice
,
and
all
that
kind
of
thing
.
<EOS>
There
are
people
who
think
that
because
a
man

his

,
he
must
be
always
in
the
muck
.
<EOS>
It
