the
case
,
of
course
,
with
those
who
have
to
make
their
rent
and
living
out
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
remembered
that
he
was
again
treading
on
forbidden
ground
,
and
stopped
himself
.
"
<EOS>
But
it
do
n't
matter
what
a
man
wears
if
his
heart
is
n't
easy
within
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
why
you
should
speak
in
that
way
,
Mr.
Cheesacre
;
but
it
's
what
I
have
felt
every
hour
since
 
since
Greenow
left
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Cheesacre
was
rather
at
a
loss
to
know
how
he
should
begin
.
<EOS>
This
allusion
to
the
departed
one
did
not
at
all
assist
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
so
often
told
the
widow
that
care
killed
a
cat
,
and
that
a
live
dog
was
better
than
a
dead
lion
;
and
had
found
so
little
efficacy
in
the
proverbs
,
that
he
did
not
care
to
revert
to
them
.
<EOS>
He
was
aware
that
some
more
decided
method
of
proceeding
was
now
required
.
<EOS>
Little
hints
at
love
-
making
had
been
all
very
well
in
the
earlier
days
of
their
acquaintance
;
but
there
must
be
something
more
than
little
hints
before
he
could
hope
to
bring
the
matter
to
a
favourable
conclusion
.
<EOS>
The
widow
herself
had
told
him
that
he
ought
to
talk
about
love
;
and
he
had
taken
two
glasses
of
cherry
-
brandy
,
hoping
that
they
might
enable
him
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
He
had
put
on
a
coat
with
brilliant
buttons
,
and
new
knickerbockers
,
in
order
that
he
might
be
master
of
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
He
was
resolved
to
call
a
spade
a
spade
,
and
to
speak
boldly
of
his
passion
;
but
how
was
he
to
begin
?
<EOS>
There
was
the
difficulty
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
seated
in
a
chair
,
and
there
he
remained
silent
for
a
minute
or
two
,
while
she
smoothed
her
eyebrows
with
her
handkerchief
after
her
last
slight
ebullition
of
grief
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Greenow
,
"
he
exclaimed
at
last
,
jumping
up
before
her
;
"
dearest
Mrs.
Greenow
;
darling
Mrs.
Greenow
,
will
you
be
my
wife
?
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
I
have
said
it
at
last
,
and
I
mean
it
.
<EOS>
Everything
that
I
've
got
shall
be
yours
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
speak
specially
of
my
hand
and
heart
.
<EOS>
As
for
love
;
 
oh
,
Arabella
,
if
you
only
knew
me
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
there
's
a
man
in
Norfolk
better
able

love

woman
than
I

.
<EOS>
Ever
since
I
first
saw
you
at
Yarmouth
,
I
've
been
in

to
that

that
I
've
not

I
've
been
about
.
<EOS>
If

'll

,
they

about

,
 
not

.
<EOS>
I
have

.
<EOS>
I
do

I
've
opened

wages

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I
ca

.
<EOS>

;

wo

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
I

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Of

,
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Do

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Only

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Say

my

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

!
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
You

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Mr.
Cheesacre
;

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
why

?
<EOS>
Look

,
Arabella
!
"
<EOS>
At

rose

,

,

.
<EOS>
There

no

-

.
<EOS>
There
he
was
,
well
down
on

;
but
he
had

some

the
part
of

were

.
<EOS>
He
,
in
his
passion
,
had
probably
omitted
to
notice

;
but
Mrs.
Greenow
,
who

cool
in
her

,
was
painfully

that

might

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Cheesacre
,
do

.
<EOS>
Get

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

,

.
<EOS>
I
wo

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
<EOS>
Whereupon

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
There
;

hear
?
<EOS>
There

.
"
  
<EOS>
But

,
whose

less

's
,

.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
never

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bid

.
<EOS>
Get

knees
,
at

.
<EOS>
There
;
 
he
'll
be
in
the
room
now
before
 
"
  
Cheesacre
now
did
hear
a
sound
of
steps
,
and
the
door
was
opened
while
he
made
his
first
futile
attempt
to
get
back
to
a
standing
position
.
<EOS>
The
door
was
opened
,
and
Captain
Bellfield
entered
.
<EOS>
"
I
beg
ten
thousand
pardons
,
"
said
he
,
"
<EOS>
but
as
I
did
not
see
Jeannette
,
I
ventured
to
come

.
<EOS>
May
I
venture
to

Cheesacre
on

?
"
  
<EOS>
In
the

Cheesacre
had
risen
;
but
he
had
done
so
slowly
,
and
with
evident
difficulty
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
trouble
you
to
leave
the
room
,
Captain
Bellfield
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
particularly
engaged
with
Mrs.
Greenow
,

any

might

seen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
was
n't
the

in

,
old

,
"
said
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall
I
wish
you
joy
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
trouble
you
to
leave
the
room
,
sir
,
"
said
Cheesacre
,
walking
up
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
if
Mrs.
Greenow
will
desire
me
to
do

,
"
said
the
Captain
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Mrs.
Greenow
felt
herself
called
upon
to
speak
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
I
must
beg
that
you
will

room
a

.
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
,

,
I

was

.
<EOS>
It

consent
that
he
was

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can

,

Greenow
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
cares

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
!
<EOS>
gentlemen
!
<EOS>
this
is
really
unkind
.
<EOS>
Captain
Bellfield
,
I
think
I
had
better
ask

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
all

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
As
it

that
I

Mr.
Cheesacre
a

after

occurred
 
"
  
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
That

Bellfield
did

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Her

was

bad
with

,
"
Jeannette
said
.
   
<EOS>
Preparations
for
Lady
Monk
's
Party
.
 
<EOS>
Early
in
April
,
the
Easter
recess
being
all
over
,
Lady
Monk
gave
a
grand
party
in
London
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
's
town
house
was
in
Gloucester
Square
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
large
mansion
,
and
Lady
Monk
's
parties
in
London
were
known
to
be
very
great
affairs
.
<EOS>
She
usually
gave
two
or
three
in
the
season
,
and
spent
a
large
portion
of
her
time
and
energy
in
so
arranging
matters
that
her
parties
should
be
successful
.
<EOS>
As
this
was
her
special
line
in
life
,
a
failure
would
have
been
very
distressing
to
her
;
 
and
we
may
also
say
very
disgraceful
,
taking
into
consideration
,
as
we
should
do
in
forming
our
judgement
on
the
subject
,
the
very
large
sums
of
Sir
Cosmo
's
money
which
she
spent
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
But
she
seldom
did
fail
.
<EOS>
She
knew
how
to
select
her
days
,
so
as
not
to
fall
foul
of
other
events
.
<EOS>
It
seldom
happened
that
people
could
not
come
to
her
because
of
a
division
which
occupied
all
the
Members
of
Parliament
,
or
that
they
were
drawn
away
by
the
superior
magnitude
of
some
other
attraction
in
the
world
of
fashion
.
<EOS>
This
giving
of
parties
was
her
business
,
and
she
had
learned
it
thoroughly
.
<EOS>
She
worked
at
it
harder
than
most
men
work
at
their
trades
,
and
let
us
hope
that
the
profits
were
consolatory
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
generally
acknowledged
to
be
the
proper
thing
to
go
to
Lady
Monk
's
parties
.
<EOS>
There
were
certain
people
who
were
asked
,
and
who
went
as
a
matter
of
course
,
 
people
who
were
by
no
means
on
intimate
terms
with
Lady
Monk
,
or
with
Sir
Cosmo
;
but
they
were
people
to
have
whom
was
the
proper
thing
,
and
they
were
people
who
understood
that
to
go
to
Lady
Monk
's
was
the
proper
thing
for
them
.
<EOS>
The
Duchess
of
St.
Bungay
was
always
there
,
though
she
hated
Lady
Monk
,
and
Lady
Monk
always
abused
her
;
but
a
card
was
sent
to
the
Duchess
in
the
same
way
as
the
Lord
Mayor
invites
a
Cabinet
Minister
to
dinner
,
even
though
the
one
man
might
believe
the
other
to
be
a
thief
.
<EOS>
And
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
was
generally
there
;
she
went
everywhere
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
did
not
at
all
know
why
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
was
so
favoured
by
the
world
;
but
there
was
the
fact
,
and
she
bowed
to
it
.
<EOS>
Then
there
were
another
set
,
the
members
of
which
were
or
were
not
invited
,
according
to
circumstances
,
at
the
time
;
and
these
were
the
people
who
were
probably
the
most
legitimate
recipients
of
Lady
Monk
's
hospitality
.
<EOS>
Old
family
friends
of
her
husband
were
among
the
number
.
<EOS>
Let
the
Tuftons
come
in
April
,
and
perhaps
again
in
May
;
then
they
will
not
feel
their
exclusion
from
that
seventh
heaven
of
glory
,
 
the
great
culminating
crush
in
July
.
<EOS>
Scores
of
young
ladies
who
really
loved
parties
belonged
to
this
set
.
<EOS>
The
mothers
and
aunts
knew
Lady
Monk
's
sisters
and
cousins
.
<EOS>
They
accepted
so
much
of
Lady
Monk
's
good
things
as
she
vouchsafed
them
,
and
were
thankful
.
<EOS>
Then
there
was
another
lot
,
which
generally
became
,
especially
on
that
great
July
occasion
,
the
most
numerous
of
the
three
.
<EOS>
It
comprised
all
those
who
made
strong
interest
to
obtain
admittance
within
her
ladyship
's
house
,
 
who
struggled
and
fought
almost
with
tooth
and
nail
to
get
invitations
.
<EOS>
Against
these
people
Lady
Monk
carried
on
an
internecine
war
.
<EOS>
Had
she
not
done
so
she
would
have
been
swamped
by
them
,
and
her
success
would
have
been
at
an
end
;
but
yet
she
never
dreamed
of
shutting
her
doors
against
them
altogether
,
or
of
saying
boldly
that
none
such
should
hamper
her
staircases
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
she
must
yield
,
but
her
effort
was
made
to
yield
to
as
few
as
might
be
possible
.
<EOS>
When
she
was
first
told
by
her
factotum
in
these
operations
that
Mr.
Bott
wanted
to
come
,
she
positively
declined
to
have
him
.
<EOS>
When
it
was
afterwards
intimated
to
her
that
the
Duchess
of
St.
Bungay
had
made
a
point
of
it
,
she
sneered
at
the
Duchess
,
and
did
not
even
then
yield
.
<EOS>
But
when

that
Mr.
Palliser
wished

,
and
that
Mr.
Palliser
probably
would
not
come
himself
unless
his

were

,
she
gave
way
.
<EOS>
She
was
especially

that
Lady
Glencora
should
come
to
her

,
and
she

that
Lady
Glencora
could
not

without
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
very
much
desired
by
her
that
Lady
Glencora
should
be
there
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Burgo
,
"
said
she
to
her
nephew
,
one
morning
,
"
look
here
.
<EOS>
"
Burgo
was
at
the
time
staying
with
his
aunt
,
in
Gloucester
Square
,
much
to
the

of
Sir
Cosmo
,
who
had
become

of
his

.
<EOS>
The
aunt
and

had
been
closeted
together
more
than

,
and
perhaps
they
understood
each
other
better

than

.
<EOS>
The

had
handed

,
which
he

then

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
see
that
she
is

of

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
she
does

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
that
's

.
<EOS>
Nothing

is

.
"
  
<EOS>
Burgo

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Burgo

.
<EOS>
I
am
trying

;
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

"

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
No

"
  
<EOS>
"
I

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Look

,
Burgo
,
"
and

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
When

,

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Poor

!
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
Burgo

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

"

,

.
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
's

was
worth

.
<EOS>
He
was
a
young
man
ambitious

that

,

,

.
<EOS>
His

!
<EOS>
"
I
've
got
no

.
<EOS>
"

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
've
never
got
any

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

I

?
<EOS>
I
ca
n't

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

?
"

,

<EOS>

.

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

Lady

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

wo

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
I

She

,

.

,

.

Lady

would

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

"
<EOS>
I
never

.
<EOS>
It
's

.
<EOS>
Pray

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!

.
<EOS>
If

,

wo

.
"
<EOS>
Lady

had

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

wo
n't

,

,
"

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

ca
n't

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

know
,
Alice
,
though

all

Plantagenet
is
one
of
the
wisest
men
in
London
,
I
sometimes

that
he
is
one

.
<EOS>
Soon

came
to

I
told

that

that

's

.
<EOS>
Of

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
There

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
Dear

Marsham

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
'll

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

,

.
<EOS>
In

,
one
does
n't

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

is
so

,

I
should

.
<EOS>
I
can
fancy

woman
being

do

simply
by

to
show
her
policeman
that
she
can
be

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Will
you
go

,

,

?
<EOS>
He
asked
me
if
I
would
mind
taking
Mrs.
Marsham
with
me
in
my

.
<EOS>
So
I
up
and
spoke
,
very

,
like
the

porter
,
and
told

I
would
not
;
<EOS>
and
when
he

,
I

I
preferred

,
 
a

,

you

my
cousin
,
Lady
Jane
.
<EOS>
I

one

.
"
  
"
And

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;

,

,
about

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
You

wo

,

"
<EOS>
Alice

.
<EOS>
"
Do
,
"

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
I

if

really
thought
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
Oh
,

,
"

Glencora
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
shall
get
through

.
<EOS>
If

asks

,
I
shall
stand
up

him
,
just

though

never

.
"
<EOS>
Then

letter

,

about

this

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
This

.
  
<EOS>
Alice
regretted
,
 
regretted

that

had
not

to

with

.
<EOS>
After

?
<EOS>
Doubtless

Lady

's

;
but

?
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
But

was

.
<EOS>
Then

.
   
<EOS>
How
Lady
Glencora
Went
to
Lady
Monk
's
Party
.
 
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
's
house
in
Gloucester
Square
was
admirably
well
adapted
for
the
giving
of
parties
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
large
house
,
and
seemed
to
the
eyes
of
guests
to
be
much
larger
than
it
was
.
<EOS>
The
hall
was
spacious
,
and
the
stairs
went
up
in
the
centre
,
facing
you
as
you
entered
the
inner
hall
.
<EOS>
Round
the
top
of
the
stairs
there
was
a
broad
gallery
,
with
an
ornamented
railing
,
and
from
this
opened
the
doors
into
the
three
reception
-
rooms
.
<EOS>
There
were
two
on
the
right
,
the
larger
of
which
looked
out
backwards
,
and
these
two
were
connected
by
an
archway
,
as
though
made
for
folding
-
doors
;
but
the
doors
,
I
believe
,
never
were
there
.
<EOS>
Fronting
the
top
of
the
staircase
there
was
a
smaller
room
,
looking
out
backwards
,
very
prettily
furnished
,
and
much
used
by
Lady
Monk
when
alone
.
<EOS>
It
was
here
that
Burgo
had
held
that
conference
with
his
aunt
of
which
mention
has
been
made
.
<EOS>
Below
stairs
there
was
the
great
dining
-
room
,
on
which
,
on
these
occasions
,
a
huge

was
erected
for

,
 
what
I
may
call
a
masculine

,
as
it
was
attended
by
butlers
and
men
in
livery
,
 
and
there
was
a
smaller
room
looking
out
into
the
square
,
in
which
there
was
a
feminine

for
the

of
tea
and
such
like
smaller
good

,
and
from

female

could

in

.
<EOS>
For
such

as
that
now
on
foot
the
house
was
most
commodious
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
,
on
these
occasions
,
was
moved
by
a
noble
ambition
to
do
something
different
from
that
done
by
her
neighbours
in
similar
circumstances
,
and
therefore
she
never

to

.
<EOS>
She
ensconced

,
early
in

,
in
that

at
the
head

stairs
,
and
there
they
who
chose

made

up

her
,
and
spoke

.
<EOS>
They
who
thought
her
to
be
a

,
 
and

to

great
,
 
were
wo
nt
to
declare
that
she
never

those
who
did

,

those

did

.
<EOS>
And

desired
to

little
,
 
for
even
Lady
Monk
had
enemies
,
 
would
hint
that
though

never

room
,

and

door
whenever
any
name
very
high
in

.
<EOS>
So

a
mighty
Cabinet

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It
would
,

,

would

;
but

as
far

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

Monk

,

's

.
<EOS>
Ladies

,

.
<EOS>
The

,
 
so

"

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
How

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
Even

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"

"

"

"

<EOS>

ready
money
which

.
  
<EOS>
On

<EOS>
"
Your

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Impossible
,
Plantagenet
.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
My

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
!
"
  
"

,

to
her
because
he
does
n't
dare
to
go
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Plantagenet
Palliser
was
struck
wild
with
dismay
.
<EOS>
He
understood
well
who
it
was
whom
his
wife
intended
to
describe
;
but
that
she
should
have
spoken
of
any
man
as
a
baboon
with
red
bristles
,
was
terrible
to
his
mind
!
<EOS>
He
was
beginning
to
think
that
he
hardly
knew
how
to
manage
his
wife
.
<EOS>
And
the
picture
she
had
drawn
was
very
distressing
to
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
mother
;
neither
had
he
;
and
he
had
wished
that
Mrs.
Marsham
should
give
to
her
some
of
that
matronly
assistance
and
guidance
which
a
mother
does
give
to
her
young
married
daughter
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
,
too
,
as
he
knew
,
that
a
word
or
two
as
to
some
socially
domestic
matters
had
filtered
through
to
him
from
Mr.
Bott
,
down
at
Matching
Priory
,
but
only
in
such
a
way
as
to
enable
him
to
see
what
counsel
it
was
needful
that
he
should
give
.
<EOS>
As
for
espionage
over
his
wife
,
 
no
man
could
despise
it
more
than
he
did
!
<EOS>
No
man
would
be
less
willing
to
resort
to
it
!
<EOS>
And
now
his
wife
was
accusing
him
of
keeping
spies
,
both
male
and
female
.
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
again
;
and
then
he
stopped
,
not
knowing
what
to
say
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
my
dear
,
it
's
better
you
should
know
at
once
what
I
feel
about
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
suppose
I
'm
very
good
;
indeed
I
dare
say
I
'm
bad
enough
,
but
these
people
about
me
wo
n't
make
me
any
better
.
<EOS>
The
duennas
do
n't
make
the
Spanish
ladies
worth
much
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Duennas
!
"
<EOS>
After
that
,
Lady
Glencora
sat
herself
down
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
stood
for
some
moments
looking
at
her
.
  
<EOS>
It
ended
in
his
making
her
a
long
speech
,
in
which
he
said
a
good
deal
of
his
own
justice
and
forbearance
,
and
something
also
of
her
frivolity
and
childishness
.
<EOS>
He
told
her
that
his
only
complaint
of
her
was
that
she
was
too
young
,
and
,
as
he
did
so
,
she
made
a
little
grimace
,
 
not
to
him
,
but
to
herself
,
as
though
saying
to
herself
that
that
was
all
he
knew
about
it
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
notice
it
,
or
,
if
he
did
,
his
notice
did
not
stop
his
eloquence
.
<EOS>
He
assured
her
that
he
was
far
from
keeping
any
watch
over
her
,
and
declared
that
she
had
altogether
mistaken
Mrs.
Marsham
's
character
.
<EOS>
Then
there
was
another
little
grimace
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
somebody
has
mistaken
it
worse
than
I
have
,
"
the
grimace
said
.
<EOS>
Of
the
bristly
baboon
he
condescended
to
say
nothing
,
and
he
wound
up
by
giving
her
a
cold
kiss
,
and
saying
that
he
would
meet
her
at
Lady
Monk
's
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
evening
came
,
 
or
rather
the
night
,
 
the
carriage
went
first
for
Mrs.
Marsham
,
and
having
deposited
her
at
Lady
Monk
's
,
went
back
to
Park
Lane
for
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
Then
she
had
herself
driven
to
St.
James
's
Square
,
to
pick
up
Lady
Jane
,
so
that
altogether
the
coachman
and
horses
did
not
have
a
good
time
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
he
'd
keep
a
separate
carriage
for
her
,
"
Lady
Glencora
said
to
her
cousin
Jane
,
 
having
perceived
that
her
servants
were
not
in
a
good
humour
.
"
<EOS>
That
would
be
expensive
,
"
said
Lady
Jane
.
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
would
be
expensive
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
condescend
to
make
any
remark
as
to
the
non
-
importance
of
such

to
a
man
so
wealthy
as
her
husband
,
knowing
that
his
wealth
was
,
in
fact
,
hers
.
<EOS>
Never
to
him
or
to
any
other
,
 
not
even
to
herself
,
 
had
she
hinted
that
much
was
due
to
her
because
she
had
been
magnificent
as
an
heiress
.
<EOS>
There
were
many
things
about
this
woman
that
were
not
altogether
what
a
husband
might
wish
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
softly
delicate
in
all
her
ways
;
but
in
disposition
and
temper
she
was
altogether
generous
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
that
she
was
at
all
points
a
lady
,
but
had
Fate
so
willed
it
<EOS>
she
would
have
been
a
thorough
gentleman
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
was
by
no
means
satisfied
with
the
way
in
which
she
was
treated
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
have
cared
to
go
at
all
to
Lady
Monk
's
party
<EOS>
had
she
supposed
that
she
would
have
to
make
her
entry
there
alone
.
<EOS>
With
Lady
Glencora
she
would
have
seemed
to
receive
some
of
that
homage
which
would
certainly
have
been
paid
to
her
companion
.
<EOS>
The
carriage
called
,
moreover
,
before
she
was
fully
ready
,
and
the
footman
,
as
he
stood
at
the
door
to
hand
her
in
,
had
been
very
sulky
.
<EOS>
She
understood
it
all
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
Lady
Glencora
had
positively
declined
her
companionship
;
and
if
she
resolved
to
be
revenged
,
such
resolution
on
her
part
was
only
natural
.
<EOS>
When
she
reached
Lady
Monk
's
house
,
she
had
to
make
her
way
up
stairs
all
alone
.
<EOS>
The
servants
called
her
Mrs.
Marsh
,
and
under
that
name
she
got
passed
on
into
the
front
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
There
she
sat
down
,
not
having
seen
Lady
Monk
,
and
meditated
over
her
injuries
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
past
eleven
before
Lady
Glencora
arrived
,
and
Burgo
Fitzgerald
had
begun
to
think
that
his
evil
stars
intended
that
he
should
never
see
her
again
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
wickedly
baulked
at
Monkshade
,
by
what
influence
he
had
never
yet
ascertained
;
and
now
he
thought
that
the
same
influence
must
be
at
work
to
keep
her
again
away
from
his
aunt
's
house
.
<EOS>
He
had
settled
in
his
mind
no
accurate
plan
of
a
campaign
;
he
had
in
his
thoughts
no
fixed
arrangement
by
which
he
might
do
the
thing
which
he
meditated
.
<EOS>
He
had
attempted
to
make
some
such
plan
;
but
,
as
is
the
case
with
all
men
to
whom
thinking
is
an
unusual
operation
,
concluded
at
last
that
he
had
better
leave
it
to
the
course
of
events
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
however
,
obviously
necessary
that
he
should
see
Lady
Glencora
before
the
course
of
events
could
be
made
to
do
anything
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
written
to
her
,
making
his
proposition
in
bold
terms
,
and
he
felt
that
if
she
were
utterly
decided
against
him
,
her
anger
at
his
suggestion
,
or
at
least
her
refusal
,
would
have
been
made
known
to
him
in
some
way
.
<EOS>
Silence
did
not
absolutely
give
consent
,
but
it
seemed
to
show
that
consent
was
not
impossible
.
<EOS>
From
ten
o'clock
to
past
eleven
he
stood
about
on
the
staircase
of
his
aunt
's
house
,
waiting
for
the
name
which
he
was
desirous
of
hearing
,
and
which
he
almost
feared
to
hear
.
<EOS>
Men
spoke
to
him
,
and
women
also
,
but
he
hardly
answered
.
<EOS>
His
aunt
once
called
him
into
her
room
,
and
with
a
cautionary
frown
on
her
brow
,
bade
him
go
dance
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
look
so
dreadfully
preoccupied
,
"
she
said
to
him
in
a
whisper
.
<EOS>
But
he
shook
his
head
at
her
,
almost
savagely
,
and
went
away
,
and
did
not
dance
.
<EOS>
Dance
!
<EOS>
How
was
he
to
dance
with
such
an
enterprise
as
that
upon
his
mind
?
<EOS>
Even
to
Burgo
Fitzgerald
the
task
of
running
away
with
another
man
's
wife
had
in
it
something
which
prevented
dancing
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
was
older
,
and
was
able
to
regulate
her
feelings
with
more
exactness
.
<EOS>
But
Burgo
,
though
he
could
not
dance
,
went
down
into
the
dining
-
room
and
drank
.
<EOS>
He
took
a
large
beer
-
glass
full
of
champagne
and
soon
after
that
another
.
<EOS>
The
drink
did
not
flush
his
cheeks
or
make
his
forehead
red
,
or
bring
out
the
sweat
-
drops
on
his
brow
,
as
it
does
with
some
men
;
but
it
added
a
peculiar

to
his
blue

.
<EOS>
It
was
by
the
light
of
his
eyes
that
men
knew
when
Burgo
had
been
drinking
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
,
while
he
was
still
in
the

,

heard

Glencora
's
name

.
<EOS>
He
had
already
seen
Mr.
Palliser
come
in
and
make
his
way
<EOS>
up
-
stairs
some
quarter
of
an
hour
before
;
but
as
to
that
he
was
indifferent
.
<EOS>
He
had
known
that
the
husband
was
to
be
there
.
<EOS>
When
the
long
-
expected
name
reached
his
ears
,
his
heart
seemed
to
jump
within

.
<EOS>
What
,
on
the

,
should
he

?
<EOS>
As
he
had
resolved
that
he
would
be
doing
,
 
that
something
should
be
done
,
let

be
what
it
might
,
 
he
hurried
to
the
dining
-
room
door
,
and
was
just
in
time
to
see
and
be

as
Lady
Glencora
was
passing

.
<EOS>
She
was
just
above

as

got

into

,
so
that
he
could
not
absolutely

with

;
but
he
looked
up

,
and
caught

.
<EOS>
He
looked
up
,
and
moved
his
hand
to
her
in

.
<EOS>
She
looked
down
at
him
,
and
the
expression
of
her
face
altered

as
her
glance
met
his
.
<EOS>
She
barely
bowed
to
him
,
 
with
her

rather
than

her
head
,
but
he
flattered
himself
that
there
was
,
at
any
rate
,
no
anger
in
her
countenance
.
<EOS>
How
beautiful
he
was
as
he
gazed
up

her
,
leaning
against
the
wall
as
he
stood
,
and
watching
her
as
she
made
her
slow

up
the
stairs
!
<EOS>
She
felt
that
his
eyes
were
on
her
,
and
where
the
stairs
turned
she
could
not
restrain
herself
from
one

.
<EOS>
As
her

fell
on
his
again
,
his
mouth
opened
,
and
she
fancied
that
she
could
hear
the
faint

that
he
uttered
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
glorious
mouth
,
such
as
the
old
sculptors
gave
to
their
marble
gods
!
<EOS>
And
Burgo
,
if
it
was
so
that
he
had
not
heart
enough
to
love
truly
,
could
look
as
though
he
loved
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
in
him
deceit
,
 
or
what
men
call
acting
.
<EOS>
The
expression
came
to
him
naturally
,
though
it
expressed
so
much
more
than
there
was
within
;
as
strong

come
to
some
men
who
have
no
knowledge
that
they
are
speaking

.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
Burgo
Fitzgerald
looked
as
though
it
were
possible
that
he
might
die
of
love
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
met
at
the
top
of
the
stairs
by
Lady
Monk
,
who
came
out
to
her
,
almost
into
the
gallery
,
with
her
sweetest
smile
,
 
so
that
the
newly
-
arrived
guest
,
of
course
,
entered
into
the
small
room
.
<EOS>
There
sat
the
Duchess
of
St.
Bungay
on
her
stool
in
the
corner
,
and
there
,
next
to
the
Duchess
,
but
at
the
moment
engaged
in
no

,
stood
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
There
was
another
lady
there
,
who
stood
very
high
in
the
world
,
and
whom
Lady
Monk
was
very
glad
to
welcome
 
the
young
Marchioness
of
Hartletop
.
<EOS>
She
was
in
slight
mourning
;
for
her
father
-
in
-
law
,
the
late
Marquis
,
had
died
no
t
yet
quite
six
months
since
.
<EOS>
Very
beautiful
she
was
,
and
one
whose
presence
at
their
houses
ladies
and
gentlemen
prized
alike
.
<EOS>
She
never
said
silly
things
,
like
the
Duchess
,
never
was
troublesome
as
to
people
's
conduct
to
her
,
was
always
gracious
,
yet
was
never
led
away
into
intimacies
,
was
without
peer
the
best
-
dressed
woman
in
London
,
and
yet
gave
herself
no
airs
;
 
<EOS>
and
then
she
was
so
exquisitely
beautiful
.
<EOS>
Her
smile
was
loveliness
itself
.
<EOS>
There
were
,
indeed
,
people
who
said
that
it
meant
nothing
;
but
then
,
what
should
the
smile
of
a
young
married
woman
mean
?
<EOS>
She
had
not
been
born
in
the
purple
,
like
Lady
Glencora
,
her
father
being
a
country
clergyman
who
had
never
reached
a
higher
grade
than
that
of
an
archdeacon
;
but
she
knew
the
ways
of
high
life
,
and
what
an
exigeant
husband
would
demand
of
her
,
much
better
than
poor
Glencora
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
spoken
of
no
man
as
a
baboon
with
a
bristly
beard
.
<EOS>
She
never
talked
of
the
long
and
the
short
of
it
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
wander
out
o
'
nights
in
winter
among
the
ruins
.
<EOS>
She
made
no
fast
friendship
with
ladies
whom
her
lord
did
not
like
.
<EOS>
She
had
once
,
indeed
,
been
approached
by
a
lover
since
she
had
been
married
,
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
himself
having
been
the
offender
,
 
<EOS>
but
she
had
turned
the
affair
to
infinite
credit
and
profit
,
had
gained
her
husband
's
closest
confidence
by
telling
him
of
it
all
,
had
yet
not
brought
on
any
hostile
collision
,
and
had
even
dismissed
her
lover
without
annoying
him
.
<EOS>
But
then
Lady
Hartletop
was
a
miracle
of
a
woman
!
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
no
miracle
.
<EOS>
Though
born
in
the
purple
,
she
was
made
of
ordinary
flesh
and
blood
,
and
as
she
entered
Lady
Monk
's
little
room
,
hardly
knew
how
to
recover
herself
sufficiently
for
the
purposes
of
ordinary
conversation
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Dear
Lady
Glencora
,
do
come
in
for
a
moment
to
my
den
.
<EOS>
We
were
so
sorry
not
to
have
you
at
Monkshade
.
<EOS>
We
heard
such
terrible
things
about
your
health
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
said
that
it
was
only
a
cold
,
 
a
bad
cold
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
;
we
heard
,
 
something
about
moonlight
and
ruins
.
<EOS>
So
like
you
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
I
love
that
sort
of
thing
,
above
all
people
;
but
it
does
n't
do
;
does
it
?
<EOS>
Circumstances
are
so
exacting
.
<EOS>
I
think
you
know
Lady
Hartletop
;
 
and
there
's
the
Duchess
of
St.
Bungay
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
here
five
minutes
since
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Monk
was
obliged
to
get
to

again
and
Lady
Glencora
found
herself
standing
close
to
Lady
Hartletop
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
saw
Mr.
Palliser
just
pass
through
,
"
said
Lady
Hartletop
,
who
was
able
to

of
the
man
who
had

with
his

,
without
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
he
said

should
be
here
,
"
said

Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
great
crowd
,
"
said
Lady
Hartletop
.
<EOS>
"
I
did

think
London
was
so
full
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
great
.
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
and
<EOS>
then
they
had
said
to
each
other
all
that
society
required
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
as
we
know
,
could
talk
with
imprudent

by
the
hour
together
if
she
liked
her
companion
;
but
the
other
lady
seldom
committed
herself
by

than

uttered
now
,
 
unless

was
to
her
tirewoman
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
very
well
you
are
looking
,
"
said
the
Duchess
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
I
heard
you
had

so
ill
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
that
midnight
escapade
among

ruins
it

that
Lady
Glencora
should
never
hear

last
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
d'ye
do
,
Lady
Glencowrer
?
"
sounded
in
her
ear
,
and
there
was
a
great
red
paw
stuck

her
to
take
.
<EOS>
But
after
what
had
passed
between
Lady
Glencora
and

to

about

Bott
,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
are

,
Mr.
Bott
?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
think

'll

Palliser
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Lady
Glencora
,
"

,
in

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
turned

to
her

.
<EOS>
"
Do
let
me
go
away
with
you
.
<EOS>
There

,

Conway
Sparkes
,

I

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
had
nothing

to
take
the
Duchess
under

,
and
they
passed
into

large

.
<EOS>
It
is
,
I
think
,
more
than

that
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
had

Monk
as

.
  
<EOS>
Just
within
the
dancing
-
room
Lady
Glencora
found
her
husband
,
standing
in
a
corner
,
looking
as

he
were
making

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
going
away
,
"
said
he
,
coming
up
to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I
only
just
came
because
I
said
I
would
.
<EOS>
Shall
you
be
late
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
;
I
suppose
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
you
dance
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
once
,
 
just
to
show
that
I
'm
not
an
old
woman
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
heat
yourself
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
he
went
,
and
in

the

he
passed
Burgo
Fitzgerald
,
whose
eye
was
intently
fixed
upon

wife
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at
Burgo
,
and
some

of
that
young
man
's
former
hopes
flashed
across
his
mind
,
 
some
remembrance
,
too
,
of
a
caution
that
had
been

to
him
;
but
for
no
moment
did
a
suspicion
come
to
him
that
he
ought
to
stop
and
watch
by
his
wife
.
   
<EOS>
How
Lady
Glencora
Came
Back
from
Lady
Monk
's
Party
.
 
<EOS>
Burgo
Fitzgerald
remained
for
a
minute
or
two
leaning
where
we
last
saw
him
,
 
against
the
dining
-
room
wall
at
the
bottom
of
the
staircase
;
and
as
he
did
so
some
thoughts
that
were
almost
solemn
passed
across
his
mind
,
This
thing
that
he
was
about
to
do
,
or
to
attempt
,
 
was
it
in
itself
a
good
thing
,
and
would
it
be
good
for
her
whom
he
pretended
to
love
?
<EOS>
What
would
be
her
future
if
she
consented
now
to
go
with
him
,
and
to
divide
herself
from
her
husband
?
<EOS>
Of
his
own
future
he
thought
not
at
all
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
done
so
.
<EOS>
Even
when
he
had
first
found
himself
attracted
by
the
reputation
of
her
wealth
,
he
can
not
be
said
to
have
looked
forward
in
any
prudential
way
to
coming
years
.
<EOS>
His
desire
to
put
himself
in
possession
of
so
magnificent
a
fortune
had
simply
prompted
him
,
as
he
might
have
been
prompted
to
play
for
a
high
stake
at
a
gaming
-
table
.
<EOS>
But
now
,
during
these
moments
,
he
did
think
a
little
of
her
.
<EOS>
Would
she
be
happy
,
simply
because
he
loved
her
,
when
all
women
should
cease
to
acknowledge
her
;
when
men
would
regard
her
as
one
degraded
and
dishonoured
;
when
society
should
be
closed
against
her
;
when
she
would
be
driven
to
live
loudly
because
the
softness
and
graces
of
quiet
life
would
be
denied
to
her
?
<EOS>
Burgo
knew
well
what
must
be
the
nature
of
such
a
woman
's
life
in
such
circumstances
.
<EOS>
Would
Glencora
be
happy
with
him
while
living
such
a
life
simply
because
he
loved
her
?
<EOS>
And
,
under
such
circumstances
,
was
it
likely
that
he
would
continue
to
love
her
?
<EOS>
Did
he
not
know
himself
to
be
the
most
inconstant
of
men
,
and
the
least
trustworthy
?
<EOS>
Leaning
thus
against
the
wall
at
the
bottom
of
the
stairs
he
did
ask
himself
all
these
questions
with
something
of
true
feeling
about
his
heart
,
and
almost
persuaded
himself
that
he
had
better
take
his
hat
and
wander
forth
anywhere
into
the
streets
.
<EOS>
It
mattered
little
what
might
become
of
himself
.
<EOS>
If
he
could
drink
himself
out
of
the
world
,
it
might
be
an
end
of
things
that
would
be
not
altogether
undesirable
.
  
<EOS>
But
then
the
remembrance
of
his
aunt
's
two
hundred
pounds
came
upon
him
,
<EOS>
which
money
he
even
now
had
about
him
on
his
person
,
and
a
certain
idea
of
honour
told
him
that
he
was
bound
to
do
that
for
which
the
money
had
been

to

.
<EOS>
As
to
telling
his
aunt
that
he
had
changed
his
mind
,
and
,
therefore
,
refunding
the
money
 
<EOS>
no
such
thought
as
that
was
possible

!
<EOS>
To

two
hundred

entire
,
 
two

which

within

,

not

of
Burgo
's

.
<EOS>
Remembering

cash
,
he
told

that

no

.
<EOS>
So

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

in

's

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Burgo
,
"

,
with

,
"

?
"
<EOS>
He

without

,

about

,
 
which
,

,

the

.
<EOS>
But
she
did
not

,
and

,

something

Conway

as

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
Burgo
made
his
way
first
into
the
front

and
then
into
the
larger
room
where
the
dancing
was
in
progress
,
and

Lady
Glencora
standing

.
<EOS>
Lord
Hartletop
was
a
man
not

to

than
his
wife
,
and
Lady
Glencora
seemed
to
go
through
her
work
with

little

either
in

or

the

of

.
<EOS>
She
was
simply
standing
up
to
dance
,
because
,
as
she
had
told
Mr.
Palliser
,
ladies
of
her
age
generally

stand

on
such

.
<EOS>
Burgo
watched
her
as
she
crossed
and
re
-
crossed
the
room
,
and
at
last
she
was
aware
of
his
presence
.
<EOS>
It
made
no
change
in
her
,
except
that
she
became
even
somewhat
less

than
she
had

before
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
seem
to
see

,
nor
would

allow

to

because

was

.
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
up
to
her
at
once
,
and
ask
her
to
waltz
,
"
Burgo
said
to

,
as
soon

last

quadrille
was
in

.
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
not
ask
her
as
well
as
any
other
woman
?
"
<EOS>
Then
the
music
ceased
,
and
after
a
minute
's
interval
Lord
Hartletop
took
away
his
partner
on
his
arm
into
another
room
.
<EOS>
Burgo
,
who
had
been
standing
near
the
door
,
followed
them
at
once
.
<EOS>
The
crowd
was
great
,
so
that
he
could
not
get
near
them
or
even
keep
them
in
sight
,
but
he
was
aware
of
the
way
in

they
were
going
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
five
minutes
after
this
when
he
again

her
,
and
then
she
was
seated
on
a
cane
bench
in

,
and
an
old

was
standing
close
to

,
talking

.
<EOS>
It
was
Mrs.
Marsham
cautioning
her
against
some
petty
imprudence
,
and
Lady
Glencora
was
telling
that
lady
that
she
needed
no
such
advice
,
in
words
almost
as
curt
as
those
I
have
used
.
<EOS>
Lord
Hartletop
had
left
her
,
feeling
that
,
as
far
as
that
was
concerned
,
he
had
done
his

for

night
.
<EOS>
Burgo
knew
nothing
of
Mrs.
Marsham
,
 
had
never
seen
her
before
,
and
was
quite
unaware
that
she
had
any
special
connection
with
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
,
he
thought
,
to
find
Lady
Glencora
in
a
better
position
for
his
purpose
,
so
he
made
his
way
up
to
her
through
the

,
and
muttering
some
slight

word
,
offered
her
his
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
will
do
very
well
thank
you
,
Mrs.
Marsham
,
"
Lady
Glencora
said
at
this
moment
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
do
not
trouble
yourself
,
"
and
then
she
gave
her
hand
to
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
,
though
unknown
to
him
,
knew
with
quite
sufficient
accuracy
who
he
was
,
and
all
his
history
,
as
far
as
it
concerned
her
friend
's
wife
.
<EOS>
She
had
learned
the
whole
story
of
the
loves
of
Burgo
and
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
Though
Mr.
Palliser
had
never
mentioned
that
man
's
name
to
her
,
she
was
well
aware
that
her
duty
as
a
duenna
would
make

expedient
that
she
should
keep
a
doubly
wary
eye
upon
him
<EOS>
should
he
come
near
the
sheepfold
.
<EOS>
And
there
he
was
,
close
to
them
,
almost
leaning
over
them
,
with
the
hand
of
his
late
lady
love
,
 
the
hand
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
wife
,
 
within
his
own
!
<EOS>
How
Lady
Glencora
might
have
carried
herself
at
this
moment
had
Mrs.
Marsham
not
been
there
,
it
is
bootless
now
to
surmise
;
but
it
may
be
well

that
under
Mrs.
Marsham
's
immediate

all
her

would
be
in
Burgo
's
favour
.
<EOS>
She
looked
at

softly
and

,
and
though
she
uttered
no
articulate
word
,
her
countenance
seemed
to
show
that
the
meeting
was
not

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
waltz
?
<EOS>
"
said
Burgo
,
 
asking
it
not
at
all
as
though
it
were
a
special
favour
,
 
asking
it
exactly
as
he
might
have
done
<EOS>
had

been
in

of
dancing
with

the

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
Lady
Glencora
will
waltz
to
-
night
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
,
very

.
<EOS>
She
certainly
did
not
know
her
business
as
a
duenna
,
or
else
the
enormity
of
Burgo
's
proposition
had
struck
her
so
forcibly
as
to
take
away
from

all
her

of

.
<EOS>
Otherwise
,
she
must
have
been
aware
that
such

answer
from
her
would
surely
drive
her
friend
's
wife
into
open

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
,
Mrs.
Marsham
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
rising
from
her
seat
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
should
n't
I
waltz
to
-
night
?
<EOS>
I
rather
think
I
shall
,
the
more
especially
as
Mr.
Fitzgerald
waltzes
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
Thereupon
she
put
her
hand
upon
Burgo
's
arm
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
made
still
a
little
effort
,
 
a
little
effort
that
was
probably
involuntary
.
<EOS>
She
put
out
her
hand
,
and
laid
it
on
Lady
Glencora
's
left
shoulder
,
looking
into
her
face
as
she
did
so
with
all
the
severity
of
caution
of
which
she
was
mistress
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
shook
her
duenna
off
angrily
.
<EOS>
Whether
she
would
put
her
fate
into
the
hands
of
this
man
who
was
now
touching
her
,
or
whether
she
would
not
,
she
had
not
as
yet
decided
;
but
of
this
she
was
very
sure
,
that
nothing
said
or
done
by
Mrs.
Marsham
should
have
any
effect
in
restraining
her
.
  
<EOS>
What
could
Mrs.
Marsham
do
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
gone
.
<EOS>
Some
rumour
of
that
proposed
visit
to
Monkshade
,
and
the
way
in
which
it
had
been
prevented
,
had
reached
her
ear
.
<EOS>
Some
whispers
had
come
to
her
that
Fitzgerald
still
dared
to
love
,
as
married
,
the
woman
whom
he
had
loved
before
she
was
married
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
rumour
about
that
he
still
had
some
hope
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
had
never
believed
that
Mr.
Palliser
's
wife
would
really
be
false
to
her
vows
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
in
fear
of
any
such
catastrophe
as
a
positive
elopement
that
she
had
taken
upon
herself
the
duty
of
duenna
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
would
,
no
doubt
,
require
to
be
pressed
down
into
that
decent
mould
which
it
would
become
the
wife
of
a
Mr.
Palliser
to
assume
as
her
form
;
and
this
pressing
down
,
and
<EOS>
this
moulding
,
Mrs.
Marsham
thought
that
she
could
accomplish
.
<EOS>
It
had
not
hitherto
occurred
to
her
that
she
might
be
required
to
guard
Mr.
Palliser
from
positive
dishonour
;
but
now
 
now
she
hardly
knew
what
to
think
about
it
.
<EOS>
What
should
she
do
?
<EOS>
To
whom
should
she
go
?
<EOS>
And
then
she
saw
Mr.
Bott
looming
large
before
her
on
the
top
of
the
staircase
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Lady
Glencora
went
off
towards
the
dancers
,
leaning
on
Burgo
's
arm
.
<EOS>
"
Who
is
that
woman
?
"
said
Burgo
.
<EOS>
They
were
the
first
words
he
spoke
to
her
,
though
since
he
had
last
seen
her
he
had
written
to
her
that
letter
which
even
now
she
carried
about
her
.
<EOS>
His
voice
in
her
ears
sounded
as
it
used
to
sound
when
their
intimacy
had
been
close
,
and
questions
such
as
that
he
had
asked
were
common
between
them
.
<EOS>
And
her
answer
was
of
the
same
nature
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
such
an
odious
woman
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
Her
name
is
Mrs.
Marsham
;
she
is
my
bête
noire
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
they
were
actually
dancing
,
whirling
round
the
room
together
,
before
a
word
had
been
said
of
that
which
was
Burgo
's
settled
purpose
,
and
which
at
some
moments
was
her
settled
purpose
also
.
  
<EOS>
Burgo
waltzed
excellently
,
and
in
old
days
,
before
her
marriage
,
Lady
Glencora
had
been
passionately
fond
of
dancing
.
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
give
herself
up
to
it
now
as
though
the
old
days
had
come
back
to
her
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
,
creeping
to
the
intermediate
door
between
her
den
and
the
dancing
-
room
,
looked
in
on
them
,
and
then
crept
back
again
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
and
Mr.
Bott
standing
together
just
inside
the
other
door
,
near
to
the
staircase
,
looked
on
also
 
in
horror
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
should
n't
have
gone
away
and
left
her
,
"
said
Mr.
Bott
,
almost
hoarsely
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
who
could
have
thought
it
?
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
I
did
n't
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
'd
better
tell
him
?
"
said
Mr.
Bott
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
know
where
to
find
him
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
mean
now
at
once
,
"
said
Mr.
Bott
;
 
and
then
he
added
,
"
Do
you
think
it
is
as
bad
as
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
to
think
,
"
said
Mrs.
Marsham
.
  
<EOS>
The
waltzers
went
on
till
they
were
stopped
by
want
of
breath
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
much
out
of
practice
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
;
"
I
did
n't
think
 
I
should
have
been
able
 
to
dance
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
she
put
up
her
face
,
and
slightly
opened
her
mouth
,
and
stretched
her
nostrils
,
 
as
ladies
do
as
well
as
horses
when
the
running
has
been
severe
and
they
want
air
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
take
another
turn
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
Presently
,
"
said
she
,
beginning
to
have
some
thought
in
her
mind
as
to
whether
Mrs.
Marsham
was
watching
her
.
<EOS>
Then
there
was
a
little
pause
,
after
which
he
spoke
in
an
altered
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Does
it
put
you
in
mind
of
old
days
?
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
,
of
course
,
necessary
for
him
that
he
should
bring
her
to
some
thought
of
the
truth
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
very
sweet
,
that
dancing
with
her
,
as
they
used
to
dance
,
without
any
question
as
to
the
reason
why
it
was
so
;
that
sudden
falling
into
the
old
habits
,
as
though
everything
between
this
night
and
the
former
nights
had
been
a
dream
;
but
this
would
not
further
his
views
.
<EOS>
The
opportunity
had
come
to
him
which
he
must
use
,
if
he
intended
ever
to
use
such
opportunity
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
two
hundred
pounds
in
his
pocket
,
which
he
did
not
intend
to
give
back
.
<EOS>
"
Does
it
put
you
in
mind
of
"
old
days
?
"
<EOS>
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
The
words
roused
her
from
her
sleep
at
once
,
and
dissipated
her
dream
.
<EOS>
The
facts
all
rushed
upon
her
in
an
instant
;
the
letter
in
her
pocket
;
the
request
which
she
had
made
to
Alice
,
that
Alice
might
be
induced
to
guard
her
from
this
danger
;
the
words
which
her
husband
had
spoken
to
her
in
the
morning
,
and
her
anger
against
him
in
that
he
had
subjected
her
to
the
eyes
of
a
Mrs.
Marsham
;
her
own
unsettled
mind
 
quite
unsettled
whether
it
would
be
best
for
her
to
go
or
to
stay
!
<EOS>
It
all
came
upon
her
now
at
the
first
word
of
tenderness
which
Burgo
spoke
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
It
has
often
been
said
of
woman
that
she
who
doubts
is
lost
,
 
so
often
that
they
who
say
it
now
,
say
it
simply
because
others
have
said
it
before
them
,
never
thinking
whether
or
no
there
be
any
truth
in
the
proverb
.
<EOS>
But
they
who
have
said
so
,
thinking
of
their
words
as
they
were
uttered
,
have
known
but
little
of
women
.
<EOS>
Women
doubt
every
day
,
who
solve
their
doubts
at
last
on
the
right
side
,
driven
to
do
so
,
some
by
fear
,
more
by
conscience
,
but
most
of
them
by
that
half
-
prudential
,
half
-
unconscious
knowledge
of
what
is
fitting
,
useful
,
and
best
under
the
cirumstances
,
which
rarely
deserts
either
men
or
women
till
they
have
brought
themselves
to
the
Burgo
Fitzgerald
state
of
recklessness
.
<EOS>
Men
when
they
have
fallen
even
to
that
,
will
still
keep
up
some
outward
show
towards
the
world
;
but
women
in
this
condition
defy
the
world
,
and
declare
themselves
to
be
children
of
perdition
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
doubting
sorely
;
but
,
though
doubting
,
she
was
not
as
yet
lost
.
  
<EOS>
"
Does
it
put
you
in
mind
of
old
days
?
"
said
Burgo
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
driven
to
answer
,
and
she
knew
that
much
would
be
decided
by
the
way
in
which
she
might
now
speak
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
talk
of
that
,
"
she
said
,
very
softly
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
not
?
"
<EOS>
And
now
his
tongue
was
unloosed
,
so
that
he
began
to
speak
quickly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
May
I
not
?
<EOS>
And
why
not
?
<EOS>
They
were
happy
days
,
 
so
happy
!
<EOS>
Were
not
you
happy
when
you
thought
 
?
<EOS>
Ah
,
dear
!
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
is
best
not
even
to
think
of
them
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Much
the
best
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only
it
is
impossible
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
knew
the
inside
of
your
heart
,
Cora
,
so
that
I
could
see
what
it
is
that
you
really
wish
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In
the
old
days
he
had
always
called
her
Cora
,
and
now
the
name
came
from
his
lips
upon
her
ears
as
a
thing
of
custom
,
causing
no
surprise
.
<EOS>
They
were
standing
back
,
behind
the
circle
,
almost
in
a
corner
,
and
Burgo
knew
well
how
to
speak
at
such
moments
so
that
his
words
should
be
audible
to
none
but
her
whom
he
addressed
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
not
have
come
to
me
at
all
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
why
not
?
<EOS>
Who
has
a
better
right
to
come
to
you
?
<EOS>
Who
has
ever
loved
you
as
I
have
done
?
<EOS>
Cora
,
did
you
get
my
letter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
and
dance
<EOS>
,
"
she
said
;
"
I
see
a
pair
of
eyes
looking
at
us
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
pair
of
eyes
which
Lady
Glencora
saw
were
in
the
possession
of
Mr.
Bott
,
who
was
standing
alone
,
leaning
against
the
side
of
the
doorway
,
every
now
and
then
raising
his
heels
from
the
ground
,
so
that
he
might
look
down
upon
the
sinners
as
from
a
vantage
ground
.
<EOS>
He
was
quite
alone
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
had
left
him
,
and
had
gotten
herself
away
in
Lady
Glencora
's
own
carriage
to
Park
Lane
,
in
order
that
she
might
find
Mr.
Palliser
there
,
if
by
chance
he
should
be
at
home
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
it
be
making
mischief
?
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
had
said
when
Mr.
Bott
had
suggested
this
line
of
conduct
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
'll
be
worse
mischief
if
you
do
n't
,
"
Mr.
Bott
had
answered
.
<EOS>
"
He
can
come
back
,
and
then
he
can
do
as
he
likes
.
<EOS>
I
'll
keep
my
eyes
upon
them
.
"
<EOS>
And
so
he
did
keep
his
eyes
upon
them
.
  
<EOS>
Again
they
went
round
the
room
,
 
or
that
small
portion
of
the
room
which
the
invading
crowd
had
left
to
the
dancers
,
 
as
though
they
were
enjoying
themselves
thoroughly
,
and
in
all
innocence
.
<EOS>
But
there
were
others
besides
Mr.
Bott
who
looked
on
and
wondered
.
<EOS>
The
Duchess
of
St.
Bungay
saw
it
,
and
shook
her
head
sorrowing
,
 
for
the
Duchess
was
good
at
heart
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
saw
it
,
and
drank
it
down
with
keen
appetite
,
 
as
a
thirsty
man
with
a
longing
for
wine
will
drink
champagne
,
 
for
Mrs.
Conway
Sparkes
was
not
good
at
heart
.
<EOS>
Lady
Hartletop
saw
it
,
and
just
raised
her
eyebrows
.
<EOS>
It
was
nothing
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
liked
to
know
what
was
going
on
,
as
such
knowledge
was
sometimes
useful
;
but
,
as
for
heart
,
 
what
she
had
was
,
in
such
a
matter
,
neither
good
nor
bad
.
<EOS>
Her
blood
circulated
with
its
ordinary
precision
,
and
,
in
that
respect
,
no
woman
ever
had
a
better
heart
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
saw
it
,
and
a
frown
gathered
on
her
brow
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
fool
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
said
to
herself
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
Burgo
would
not
help
his
success
by
drawing
down
the
eyes
of
all
her
guests
upon
his
attempt
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Mr.
Bott
stood
there
,
mounting
still
higher
on
his
toes
,
straightening
his
back
against
the
wall
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
get
my
letter
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Burgo
said
again
,
as
soon
as
a
moment
's
pause
gave
him
breath
to
speak
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
answer
him
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
her
breath
did
not
return
to
her
as
rapidly
as
his
.
<EOS>
But
,
of
course
,
he
knew
that
she
had
received
it
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
quickly
signified
to
him
that
no
letter
from
him
had
come
to
her
hands
had
it
not
reached
her
.
"
<EOS>
Let
us
go
out
upon
the
stairs
,
"
he
said
,
"
for
I
must
speak
to
you
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
if
you
could
know
what
I
suffered
when
you
did
not
come
to
Monkshade
!
<EOS>
Why
did
you
not
come
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
had
not
come
here
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
you
have
seen
me
?
<EOS>
That
,
at
any
rate
,
is
not
kind
of
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
now
making
their
way
slowly
down
the
stairs
,
in
the
crowd
,
towards
the
supper
-
room
.
<EOS>
All
the
world
was
now
intent
on
food
and
drink
,
and
they
were
only
doing
as
others
did
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
not
thinking
where
she
went
,
but
,
glancing
upwards
,
as
she
stood
for
a
moment
wedged
upon
the
stairs
,
her
eyes
met
those
of
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
"
A
man
that
can
treat
me
like
that
deserves
that
I
should
leave
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
That
was
the
thought
that
crossed
her
mind
at
the
moment
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
get
you
some
champagne
with
water
in
it
,
"
said
Burgo
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
is
what
you
like
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
get
me
anything
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
They
had
now
got
into
the
room
,
and
had
therefore
escaped
Mr.
Bott
's
eyes
for
the
moment
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
"
 
and
now
her
words
had
become
a
whisper
in
his
ear
,
 
"
do
what
I
ask
you
.
<EOS>
For
the
sake
of
the
old
days
of
which
you
spoke
,
the
dear
old
days
which
can
never
come
again
 
"
  
"
By
G
 
---
!
<EOS>
they
can
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
They
can
come
back
,
and
they
shall
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
.
<EOS>
But
you
can
still
do
me
a
kindness
.
<EOS>
Go
away
,
and
leave
me
.
<EOS>
Go
to
the
sideboard
,
and
then
do
not
come
back
.
<EOS>
You
are
doing
me
an
injury
while
you
remain
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Cora
,
"
he
said
,
  
<EOS>
But
she
had
now
recovered
her
presence
of
mind
,
and
understood
what
was
going
on
.
<EOS>
She
was
no
longer
in
a
dream
,
but
words
and
things
bore
to
her
again
their
proper
meaning
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
have
it
,
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
"
she
answered
,
speaking
almost

.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
have
it
.
<EOS>
Do
as
I
bid
you
.
<EOS>
Go
and
leave
me
,
and
do
not
return
.
<EOS>
I
tell
you
that
we
are
watched
.
<EOS>
"
This
was
still
true
,
for
Mr.
Bott
had
now
again
got
his
eyes
on
them
,
round
the
supper
-
room
door
.
<EOS>
Whatever
was
the
reward
for
which
he
was
working
,
private
secretaryship
or
what
else
,
it
must
be
owned
that
he
worked
hard
for
it
.
<EOS>
But
there
are
labours
which
are
labours
of
love
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
watching
us
?
"
said
Burgo
;
"
and
what
does

matter
?
<EOS>
If
you
are
minded
to
do

I
have
asked
you
 
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
so

.
<EOS>
Do
you
not
know
that
you
insult
me
by
proposing
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
it
is
an
insult
,
Cora
,
 
unless
such

offer
be
a
joy
to
you
.
<EOS>
If
you
wish
to
be
my
wife
instead

his
,
it
is
no

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
be
that
?
"
<EOS>
Her
face
was
not
turned
to
him
,
and
her
words
were
half
-
pronounced
,
and
in
the
lowest
whisper
,
but
,
nevertheless
,
he
heard

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
with
me
,
 
abroad
,
and
you
shall
yet
be
my
wife
.
<EOS>
You
got
my
letter
?
<EOS>
Do
what
I
asked
you
,
then
.
<EOS>
Come
with
me
 
to
-
night
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
pressing
instance
of
the
suggestion
,
the
fixing
of
a
present
hour
,
startled
her
back
to
her

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
"
she
said
,
"
I
asked

to
go
and
leave

.
<EOS>
If
you
do

,
I
must

and

.
<EOS>
It
will

much

.
"
  
"
And
is
that

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
;
 
at
any
rate
,
now
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Glencora
!
<EOS>
how
could
you
be
so

?
<EOS>
Why
did

,
"
now
"
?
<EOS>
In

,
she

then
,
at

,
simply

that
she
could
thus
best

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not

,
"
he

,

,

,

,
with

as

.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
go
till

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
she

in
that

,
all
-
but
-

.
  
<EOS>
"
When
,
 
when
,
 
when
?
"
he

.
  
<EOS>
Looking

the

,
in

of
Mr.
Bott
's

,
she
saw

of
Mr.
Palliser
as

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
had
also
seen

,
and
had
tried
to
clutch

by

;
but
Mr.
Palliser
had
shaken

off
,
apparently

,
 
had
got

,
as

were
,

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
when
she

husband
,
immediately

.
<EOS>
She
would
not

,
or
show

what

had
done
.
<EOS>
For

,
if

,
she
could

to

that

loved
Burgo
Fitzgerald
much

than
she

to
Burgo

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
's

were

to

;
but
her
husband
's
glance
she
could
meet
without

.
<EOS>
"
Here

Mr.
Palliser
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
Burgo

rose
from

with

,
and

;
but
Lady
Glencora

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
made

as
best

could
through
the

up
to
his
wife
.
<EOS>
He
,

,

.
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
Burgo

as

came

,

Lady

.
<EOS>
"
I

hours

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
he

,
"
<EOS>
but
I

I
might

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

of

!
<EOS>
Well
;
I

.
<EOS>
Only
,

?
<EOS>
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
I

in

aunt
's

,
 
a

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
do

,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
;
and

,
making

up

,

as

,
and

Bott
still

.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
resolved
that
she
would
say
nothing
to
Burgo
while
her

was
gone
.
<EOS>
There

a

in

,

so

.
<EOS>
He

bade

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
She

,
that

,

.
<EOS>
Burgo

have

for

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Good

,
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
"
she

,

.
<EOS>
He
pressed

for
a

,
and
then

and

.
<EOS>
When

Palliser
came

no

.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
at
the

-
room

when
her

,
standing
close
to

Bott
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
had
spoken
to

,
but

.
<EOS>
He

again
,
but
her

had

deaf
.
"
<EOS>
And
what

Mrs.
Marsham
?
<EOS>
"
she

,
quite

,
as

's

.
<EOS>
"
I
had

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Marsham
has
gone
home
,
"
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
seen
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
did
you
see
her
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
came
to
Park
Lane
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
made

do

?
"
  
<EOS>
These

were

and

as

was

into

.
<EOS>
She
got

just
as
she

last
,
and
<EOS>
he
,

took

,

.
<EOS>
But

would

her
turn
.
<EOS>
"
What
made
Mrs.
Marsham
go
to
you
at
Park
Lane
after
she
left
Lady
Monk
's
?
"
she

again
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
sat
silent
,
not
having
made
up
his
mind
what
he
would
say
on

.
<EOS>
"
I

she
went
,
"
continued

Glencora
,
"
to

that
I
was
dancing
with
Mr.
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
Was
that
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
Glencora
,
we
had

not

now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
to
discuss
it
now
,
or

.
<EOS>
If
you
did
not

me
to
see
Mr.
Fitzgerald
you

not

me
to
Lady
Monk
's
.
<EOS>
But
,
Plantagenet
,
I
hope

will

if

that
no

to
receive
again
as

,
in
my
own
house
,
either
Mrs.
Marsham
or
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
absolutely
declined
to
say
anything
on
the
subject
on
that
occasion
,
and
the
evening
of
Lady
Monk
's
party
in
this
way
came
to
an
end
.
   
<EOS>
Bold
Speculations
on
Murder
.
 
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
was
not
in
a
very
happy
mood
when
he
left
Queen
Anne
Street
,
after
having
flung
his
gift
ring
under
the
grate
.
<EOS>
Indeed
there
was
much
in
his
condition
,
as
connected
with
the
house
which
he
was
leaving
,
which
could
not
but
make
him
unhappy
.
<EOS>
Alice
was
engaged
to
be
his
wife
,
and
had
as
yet
said
nothing
to
show
that
she
meditated
any
breach
of
that
engagement
,
but
she
had
treated
him
in
a
way
which
made
him
long
to
throw
her
promise
in
her
teeth
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
to
whom
any
personal
slight
from
a
woman
was
unendurable
.
<EOS>
To
slights
from
men
,
unless
they
were
of
a
nature
to
provoke
offence
,
he
was
indifferent
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
man
living
for
whose
liking
or
disliking
George
Vavasor
cared
anything
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
care
much
for
the
good
opinion
,
or
rather
for
the
personal
favour
,
of
any
woman
to
whom
he
had
endeavoured
to
make
himself
agreeable
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
marry
you
,
"
Alice
had
said
to
him
,
 
not
in
words
,
but
in
acts
and
looks
,
which
were
plainer
than
words
,
 
"
I
will
marry
you
for
certain
reasons
of
my
own
,
which
in
my
present
condition
make
it
seem
that
that
arrangement
will
be
more
convenient
to
me
than
any
other
that
I
can
make
;
but
pray
understand
that
there
is
no
love
mixed
up
with
this
.
<EOS>
There
is
another
man
whom
I
love
;
 
only
,
for
those
reasons
above
hinted
<EOS>
,
I
do
not
care
to
marry
him
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
thus
that
he
read
Alice
's
present
treatment
of
him
,
and
he
was
a
man
who
could
not
endure
this
treatment
with
ease
.
  
<EOS>
But
though
he
could
throw
his
ring
under
the
grate
in
his
passion
,
he
could
not
so
dispose
of
her
.
<EOS>
That
he
would
have
done
<EOS>
so
had
his
hands
been
free
<EOS>
,
we
need
not
doubt
.
<EOS>
And
he
would
have
been
clever
enough
to
do
so
in
some
manner
that
would
have
been
exquisitely
painful
to
Alice
,
willing
as
she
might
be
to
be
released
from
her
engagement
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
do
this
to
a
woman
whose
money
he
had
borrowed
,
and
whose
money
he
could
not
repay
;
 
to
a
woman
,
more
of
whose
money
he
intended
to
borrow
immediately
.
<EOS>
As
to
that
latter
part
of
it
,
he
did
say
to
himself
over
and
over
again
,
that
he
would
have
no
more
of
it
.
<EOS>
As
he
left
the
house
in
Queen
Anne
Street
,
on
that
occasion
,
he
swore
,
that
under
no
circumstances
would
he
be
indebted
to
her
for
another
shilling
.
<EOS>
But
before
he
had
reached
Great
Marlborough
Street
,
to
which
his
steps
took
him
,
he
had
reminded
himself
that
everything
depended
on
a
further
advance
.
<EOS>
He
was
in
Parliament
,
but
Parliament
would
be
dissolved
within
three
months
.
<EOS>
Having
sacrificed
so
much
for
his
position
,
should
he
let
it
all
fall
from
him
now
,
 
now
,
when
success
seemed
to
be
within
his
reach
?
<EOS>
That
wretched
old
man
in
Westmoreland
,
who
seemed
gifted
almost
with
immortality
,
 
<EOS>
why
could

not

?
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
As

.

How

"

<EOS>
I

the

<EOS>

"

a
