when
we
have
looked
into
the
matter
?
"
suggested
Mr.
Tombe
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'd
rather
know
at
once
,
"
said
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
suppose
it
can
take
you
very
long
to
find
out
whether
you
have
paid
money
to
my
account
,
by
order
of
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
I
must
know
before
I
go
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pinkle
,
Pinkle
!
"
screamed
the
old
man
through
his
coughing
;
and
again
Pinkle
came
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Pinkle
,
was
anything
of
the
kind
done
,
or
is
my
memory
deceiving
me
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Tombe
was
,
no
doubt
,
lying
shamefully
,
for
,
of
course
,
he
remembered
all
about
it
;
and
,
indeed
,
George
Vavasor
had
learned
already
quite
enough
for
his
own
purposes
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
going
to
look
,
"
said
Pinkle
;
and
Pinkle
again
went
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sorry
to
give
your
clerk
so
much
trouble
,
"
said
Vavasor
,
in
an
angry
voice
;
"
<EOS>
and
I
think
it
must
be
unnecessary
.
<EOS>
Surely
you
know
whether
Mr.
Grey
has
commissioned
you
to
pay
money
for
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
so
many
things
to
do
,
Mr.
Vavasor
;
and
so
many
clients
.
<EOS>
We
have
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
You
see
,
it
is
n't
only
one
gentleman
's
affairs
.
<EOS>
But
I
think
there
was
something
done
.
<EOS>
I
do
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
Mr.
John
Grey
's
address
?
"
asked
Vavasor
,
very
sharply
.
  
<EOS>
"
Number
5
,
Suffolk
Street
,
Pall
Mall
East
,
"
said
Mr.
Tombe
.
<EOS>
Herein
Mr.
Tombe
somewhat
committed
himself
.
<EOS>
His
client
,
Mr.
Grey
,
was
,
in
fact
,
in
town
,
but
Vavasor
had
not
known
or
imagined
that
such
was
the
case
.
<EOS>
Had
Mr.
Tombe
given
the
usual
address
of
Nethercoats
,
nothing
further
would
have
been
demanded
from
him
on
that
subject
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
foolishly
presumed
that
the
question
had
been
based
on
special
information
as
to
his
client
's
visit
to
London
,
and
he
had
told
the
plain
truth
in
a
very
simple
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
Number
5
,
Suffolk
Street
,
"
said
Vavasor
,
writing
down
the
address
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
will
be
better
that
I
should
go
to
him
,
as
you
do
not
seem
inclined
to
give
me
any
information
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
took
up
his
hat
,
and
hardly
bowing
to
Mr.
Tombe
,
left
the
chambers
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Tombe
,
as
he
did
so
,
rose
from
his
chair
,
and
bent
his
head
meekly
down
upon
the
table
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pinkle
,
Pinkle
,
"
wheezed
Mr.
Tombe
.
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
;
never
mind
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pinkle
did
n't
mind
;
and
we
may
say
that
he
had
not
minded
;
for
up
to
that
moment
he
had
taken
no
steps
towards
a
performance
of
the
order
which
had
been
given
him
.
   
<EOS>
What
Occurred
in
Suffolk
Street
,
Pall
Mall
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Tombe
had
gained
nothing
for
the
cause
by
his
crafty
silence
.
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
felt
perfectly
certain
,
as
he
walked
out
from
the
little
street
which
runs
at
the
back
of
Doctors
"
Commons
,
that
the
money
which
he
had
been
using
had
come
,
in
some
shape
,
through
the
hands
of
John
Grey
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
care
much
to
calculate
whether
the
payments
had
been
made
from
the
personal
funds
of
his
rival
,
or
whether
that
rival
had
been
employed
to
dispense
Alice
's
fortune
.
<EOS>
Under
either
view
of
the
case
his
position
was
sufficiently
bitter
.
<EOS>
The
truth
never
for
a
moment
occurred
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
never
dreamed
that
there
might
be
a
conspiracy
in
the
matter
,
of
which
Alice
was
as
ignorant
as
he
himself
had
been
.
<EOS>
He
never
reflected
that
his
uncle
John
,
together
with
John
,
the
lover
,
whom
he
so
hated
,
might
be
the
conspirators
.
<EOS>
To
him
it
seemed
to
be
certain
that
Alice
and
Mr.
Grey
were
in
league
;
 
and
if
they
were
in
league
,
what
must
he
think
of
Alice
,
and
of
her
engagement
with
himself
!
  
<EOS>
There
are
men
who
rarely
think
well
of
women
,
 
who
hardly
think
well
of
any
woman
.
<EOS>
They
put
their
mothers
and
sisters
into
the
background
,
 
as
though
they
belonged
to
some
sex
or
race
apart
,
 
and
then
declare
to
themselves
and
to
their
friends
that
all
women
are
false
,
 
that
no
woman
can
be
trusted
unless
her
ugliness
protect
her
;
and
that
every
woman
may
be
attacked
as
fairly
as
may
game
in
a
cover
,
or
deer
on
a
mountain
,
What
man
does
not
know
men
who
have
so
thought
?
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
that
such
had
been
Vavasor
's
creed
,
 
not
entirely
such
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
periods
of
his
life
when
he
had
believed
implicitly
in
his
cousin
Alice
;
 
but
then
there
had
been
other
moments
in
which
he
had
ridiculed
himself
for
his
Quixotism
in
believing
in
any
woman
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
had
grown
older
the
moments
of
his
Quixotism
had
become
more
rare
.
<EOS>
There
would
have
been
no
such
Quixotism
left
with
him
now
,
had
not
the
various
circumstances
which
I
have
attempted
to
describe
,
filled
him
,
during
the
last
twelve
months
,
with
a
renewed
desire
to
marry
his
cousin
.
<EOS>
Every
man
tries
to
believe
in
the
honesty
of
his
future
wife
;
and
,
therefore
,
Vavasor
had
tried
,
and
had
in
his
way
,
believed
.
<EOS>
He
had
flattered
himself
,
too
,
that
Alice
's
heart
had
,
in
truth
,
been
more
prone
to
him
than
to
that
other
suitor
.
<EOS>
Grey
,
as
he
thought
,
had
been
accepted
by
her
cold
prudence
;
but
he
thought
,
also
,
that
she
had
found
her
prudence
to
be
too
cold
,
and
had
therefore
returned
where
she
had
truly
loved
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
though
he
did
not
love
much
himself
,
was
willing
enough
to
be
the
object
of
love
.
  
<EOS>
This
idea
of
his
,
however
,
had
been
greatly
shaken
by
Alice
's
treatment
of
himself
personally
;
but
still
he
had
not
,
hitherto
,
believed
that
she
was
false
to
him
.
<EOS>
Now
,
what
could
he
believe
of
her
?
<EOS>
What
was
there
within
the
compass
of
such
a
one
to
believe
?
<EOS>
As
he
walked
out
into
St.
Paul
's
Churchyard
he
called
her
by
every
name
which
is
most
offensive
to
a
woman
's
ears
.
<EOS>
He
hated
her
at
this
moment
with
even
a
more
bitter
hatred
than
that
which
he
felt
towards
John
Grey
.
<EOS>
She
must
have
deceived
him
with
unparalleled
hypocrisy
,
and
lied
to
him
and
to
his
sister
Kate
as
hardly
any
woman
had
ever
lied
before
.
<EOS>
Or
could
it
be
that
Kate
,
also
,
was
lying
to
him
?
<EOS>
If
so
,
Kate
also
should
be
included
in
the
punishment
.
  
<EOS>
But
why
should
they
have
conspired
to
feed
him
with
these
moneys
?
<EOS>
There
had
been
no
deceit
,
at
any
rate
,
in
reference
to
the
pounds
sterling
which
Scruby
had
already
swallowed
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
supplied
,
whatever
had
been
the
motives
of
the
suppliers
;
and
he
had
no
doubt
that
more
would
be
supplied
if
he
would
only
keep
himself
quiet
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
walking
westward
as
he
thought
of
this
,
down
Ludgate
Hill
,
on
his
direct
line
towards
Suffolk
Street
;
and
he
tried
to
persuade
himself
that
it
would
be
well
that
he
should
hide
his
wrath
till
after
provision
should
have
been
made
for
this
other
election
.
<EOS>
They
were
his
enemies
,
 
Alice
and
Mr.
Grey
,
 
and
why
should
he
keep
any
terms
with
his
enemies
?
<EOS>
It
was
still
a
trouble
to
him
to
think
that
he
should
have
been
in
any
way
beholden
to
John
Grey
;
but
the
terrible
thing
had
been
done
,
the
evil
had
occurred
.
<EOS>
What
would
he
gain
by
staying
his
hand
now
?
<EOS>
Still
,
however
,
he
walked
on
quickly
along
Fleet
Street
,
and
along
the
Strand
,
and
was
already
crossing
under
the
Picture
Galleries
towards
Pall
Mall
East
before
he
had
definitely
decided
what
steps
he
would
take
on
this
very
day
.
<EOS>
Exactly
at
the
corner
of
Suffolk
Street
he
met
John
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Grey
,
"
he
said
,
stopping
himself
suddenly
,
"
I
was
this
moment
going
to
call
on
you
at
your
lodgings
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
my
lodgings
,
were
you
?
<EOS>
Shall
I
return
with
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
"
said
Vavasor
,
leading
the
way
up
Suffolk
Street
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
no
other
greeting
than
this
between
them
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
himself
,
though
a
man
very
courteous
in
his
general
demeanour
,
would
probably
have
passed
Vavasor
in
the
street
with
no
more
than
the
barest
salutation
.
<EOS>
Situated
as
they
were
towards
each
other
there
could
hardly
be
any
show
of
friendship
between
them
;
but
when
Vavasor
had
spoken
to
him
,
he
had
dressed
his
face
in
that
guise
of
civility
which
men
always
use
who
do
not
intend
to
be
offensive
;
 
but
Vavasor
dressed
his
as
men
dress
theirs
who
do
mean
to
be
offensive
;
and
Mr.
Grey
had
thoroughly
appreciated
the
dressing
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
will
allow
me
,
I
have
the
key
,
"
said
Grey
.
<EOS>
Then
they
both
entered
the
house
,
and
Vavasor
followed
his
host
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
,
as
he
went
up
,
felt
almost
angry
with
himself
in
having
admitted
his
enemy
into
his
lodgings
.
<EOS>
He
was
sure
that
no
good
could
come
of
it
,
and
remembered
,
when
it
was
too
late
,
that
he
might
easily
have
saved
himself
from
giving
the
invitation
while
he
was
still
in
the
street
.
<EOS>
There
they
were
,
however
,
together
in
the
sitting
-
room
,
and
Grey
had
nothing
to
do
but
to
listen
.
<EOS>
"
Will
you
take
a
chair
,
Mr.
Vavasor
?
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Vavasor
;
"
I
will
stand
up
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
stood
up
,
holding
his
hat
behind
his
back
with
his
left
hand
,
with
his
right
leg
forward
,
and
the
thumb
of
his
right
hand
in
his
waistcoat
-
pocket
.
<EOS>
He
looked
full
into
Grey
's
face
,
and
Grey
looked
full
into
his
;
and
as
he
looked
the
great
cicatrice
seemed
to
open
itself
and
to
become
purple
with
fresh
blood
stains
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
here
from
Mr.
Tombe
's
office
in
the
City
,
"
said
Vavasor
,
"
to
ask
you
of
what
nature
has
been
the
interference
which
you
have
taken
in
my
money
matters
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
a
question
which
Mr.
Grey
could
not
answer
very
quickly
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
it
was
altogether
unexpected
;
in
the
next
place
he
did
not
know
what
Mr.
Tombe
had
told
,
and
what
he
had
not
told
;
and
then
,
before
he
replied
,
he
must
think
how
much
of
the
truth
he
was
bound
to
tell
in
answer
to
a
question
so
put
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
say
that
you
have
come
from
Mr.
Tombe
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
heard
me
say
so
.
<EOS>
I
have
come
here
direct
from
Mr.
Tombe
's
chambers
.
<EOS>
He
is
your
lawyer
,
I
believe
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
I
have
come
from
him
to
ask
you
what
interference
you
have
lately
taken
in
my
money
matters
.
<EOS>
When
you
have
answered
that
,
I
shall
have
other
questions
to
ask
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
has
it
occurred
to
you
that
I
may
not
be
disposed
to
answer
questions
so
asked
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
not
occurred
to
me
to
think
that
you
will
prevaricate
.
<EOS>
If
there
has
been
no
such
interference
,
I
will
ask
your
pardon
,
and
go
away
;
but
if
there
has
been
such
interference
on
your
part
,
I
have
a
right
to
demand
that
you
shall
explain
to
me
its
nature
.
"
  
<EOS>
Grey
had
now
made
up
his
mind
that
it
would
be
better
that
he
should
tell
the
whole
story
,
 
better
not
only
for
himself
,
but
for
all
the
Vavasors
,
including
this
angry
man
himself
.
<EOS>
The
angry
man
evidently
knew
something
,
and
it
would
be
better
that
he
should
know
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
There
has
been
such
interference
,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
if
you
choose
to
call
it
so
.
<EOS>
Money
,
to
the
extent
of
two
thousand
pounds
,
I
think
,
has
by
my
directions
been
paid
to
your
credit
by
Mr.
Tombe
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Vavasor
,
taking
his
right
hand
away
from
his
waistcoat
,
and
tapping
the
round
table
with
his
fingers
impatiently
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hardly
know
how
to
explain
all
the
circumstances
under
which
this
has
been
done
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
not
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
you
must
explain
them
.
"
  
<EOS>
Grey
was
a
man
tranquil
in
temperament
,
very
little
prone
to
quarrelling
,
with
perhaps
an
exaggerated
idea
of
the
evil
results
of
a
row
,
 
a
man
who
would
take
infinite
trouble
to
avoid
any
such
scene
as
that
which
now
seemed
to
be
imminent
;
but
he
was
a
man
whose
courage
was
quite
as
high
as
that
of
his
opponent
.
<EOS>
To
bully
or
be
bullied
were
alike
contrary
to
his
nature
.
<EOS>
It
was
clear
enough
now
that
Vavasor
intended
to
bully
him
,
and
he
made
up
his
mind
at
once
that
if
the
quarrel
were
forced
upon
him
it
should
find
him
ready
to
take
his
own
part
.
<EOS>
"
My
difficulty
in
explaining
it
comes
from
consideration
for
you
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
beg
that
your
difficulty
will
cease
,
and
that
you
will
have
no
consideration
for
me
.
<EOS>
We
are
so
circumstanced
towards
each
other
that
any
consideration
must
be
humbug
and
nonsense
.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
I
intend
to
have
none
for
you
.
<EOS>
Now
,
let
me
know
why
you
have
meddled
with
my
matters
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
might
,
perhaps
,
better
refer
you
to
your
uncle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
;
Mr.
Tombe
is
not
my
uncle
's
lawyer
.
<EOS>
My
uncle
never
heard
his
name
,
unless
he
heard
of
it
from
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
was
by
agreement
with
your
uncle
that
I
commissioned
Mr.
Tombe
to
raise
for
you
the
money
you
were
desirous
of
borrowing
from
your
cousin
.
<EOS>
We
thought
it
better
that
her
fortune
should
not
be
for
the
moment
disturbed
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
had
you
to
do
with
it
?
<EOS>
Why
should
you
have
done
it
?
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
I
do
n't
believe
your
story
;
it
is
altogether
improbable
.
<EOS>
But
why
should
he
come
to
you
of
all
men
to
raise
money
on
his
daughter
's
behalf
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Unless
you
can
behave
yourself
with
more
discretion
,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
you
must
leave
the
room
,
"
said
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
Then
,
as
Vavasor
simply
sneered
at
him
,
but
spoke
nothing
,
he
went
on
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
I
who
suggested
to
your
uncle
that
this
arrangement
should
be
made
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
wish
to
see
Miss
Vavasor
's
fortune
squandered
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
was
her
fortune
to
you
,
sir
?
<EOS>
Are
you
aware
that
she
is
engaged
to
me
as
my
wife
?
<EOS>
I
ask
you
,
sir
,
whether
you
are
aware
that
Miss
Vavasor
is
to
be
my
wife
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
altogether
decline
to
discuss
with
you
Miss
Vavasor
's
present
or
future
position
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
heavens
,
then
,
you
shall
hear
me
discuss
it
!
<EOS>
She
was
engaged
to
you
,
and
she
has
given
you
your
dismissal
.
<EOS>
If
you
had
understood
anything
of
the
conduct
which
is
usual
among
gentlemen
,
or
if
you
had
had
any
particle
of
pride
in
you
,
sir
,
you
would
have
left
her
and
never
mentioned
her
name
again
.
<EOS>
I
now
find
you
meddling
with
her
money
matters
,
so
as
to
get
a
hold
upon
her
fortune
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
hold
upon
her
fortune
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
,
you
have
.
<EOS>
You
do
not
advance
two
thousand
pounds
without
knowing
that
you
have
security
.
<EOS>
She
has
rejected
you
;
and
in
order
that
you
may
be
revenged
,
or
that
you
may
have
some
further
hold
upon
her
,
 
that
she
may
be
in
some
sort
within
your
power
,
you
have
contrived
this
rascally
pettifogging
way
of
obtaining
power
over
her
income
.
<EOS>
The
money
shall
be
repaid
at
once
,
with
any
interest
that
can
be
due
;
and
if
I
find
you
interfering
again
,
I
will
expose
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Vavasor
,
"
said
Grey
very
slowly
,
in
a
low
tone
of
voice
,
but
with
something
in
his
eye
which
would
have
told
any
bystander
that
he
was
much
in
earnest
,
"
you
have
used
words
in
your
anger
which
I
can
not
allow
to
pass
.
<EOS>
You
must
recall
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
were
the
words
?
<EOS>
I
said
that
you
were
a
pettifogging
rascal
.
<EOS>
I
now
repeat
them
.
<EOS>
"
As
he
spoke
he
put
on
his
hat
,
so
as
to
leave
both
his
hands
ready
for
action
if
action
should
be
required
.
  
<EOS>
Grey
was
much
the
larger
man
and
much
the
stronger
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
doubted
whether
he
knew
himself
the
extent
of
his
own
strength
,
but
such
as
it
was
he
resolved
that
he
must
now
use
it
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
help
for
it
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
also
prepared
for
action
.
<EOS>
The
first
thing
he
did
was
to
open
the
door
,
and
as
he
did
so
he
became
conscious
that
his
mouth
was
full
of
blood
from
a
sharp
blow
upon
his
face
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
had
struck
him
with
his
fist
,
and
had
cut
his
lip
against
his
teeth
.
<EOS>
Then
there
came
a
scramble
,
and
Grey
was
soon
aware
that
he
had
his
opponent
in
his
hands
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
he
had
attempted
to
strike
a
blow
,
or
whether
he
had
so
much
as
clenched
his
fist
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
had
struck
him
repeatedly
,
but
the
blows
had
fallen
on
his
body
or
his
head
,
and
he
was
unconscious
of
them
.
<EOS>
He
had
but
one
object
now
in
his
mind
,
and
that
object
was
the
kicking
his
assailant
down
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
Then
came
a
scramble
,
as
I
have
said
,
and
Grey
had
a
hold
of
the
smaller
man
by
the
nape
of
his
neck
.
<EOS>
So
holding
him
he
forced
him
back
through
the
door
on
to
the
landing
,
and
there
succeeded
in
pushing
him
down
the
first
flight
of
steps
.
<EOS>
Grey
kicked
at
him
as
he
went
,
but
the
kick
was
impotent
.
<EOS>
He
had
,
however
,
been
so
far
successful
that
he
had
thrust
his
enemy
out
of
the
room
,
and
had
the
satisfaction
of
seeing
him
sprawling
on
the
landing
-
place
.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
when
he
raised
himself
,
prepared
to
make
another
rush
at
the
room
,
but
before
he
could
do
so
a
man
from
below
,
hearing
the
noise
,
had
come
upon
him
and
interrupted
him
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Jones
,
"
said
Grey
,
speaking
from
above
,
"
if
that
gentleman
does
not
leave
the
house
,
I
must
get
you
to
search
for
a
policeman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
though
the
lodging
-
house
man
had
hold
of
the
collar
of
his
coat
,
made
no
attempt
to
turn
upon
his
new
enemy
.
<EOS>
When
two
dogs
are
fighting
,
any
bystander
may
attempt
to
separate
them
with
impunity
.
<EOS>
The
brutes
are
so
anxious
to
tear
each
other
that
they
have
no
energies
left
for
other
purposes
.
<EOS>
It
never
occurs
to
them
to
turn
their
teeth
upon
newcomers
in
the
quarrel
.
<EOS>
So
it
was
with
George
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Jones
was
sufficient
to
prevent
his
further
attack
upon
the
foe
up
-
stairs
,
and
therefore
he
had
no
alternative
but
to
relinquish
the
fight
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
it
all
about
,
sir
?
"
said
Jones
,
who
kept
a
tailor
's
establishment
,
and
,
as
a
tailor
,
was
something
of
a
fighting
man
himself
.
<EOS>
Of
all
tradesmen
in
London
<EOS>
the
tailors
are
,
no
doubt
,
the
most
combative
,
 
as
might
be
expected
from
the
necessity
which
lies
upon
them
of
living
down
the
general
bad
character
in
this
respect
which
the
world
has
wrongly
given
them
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's
it
all
about
,
sir
?
"
said
Jones
,
still
holding
Vavasor
by
his
coat
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
man
has
ill
-
used
me
,
and
I
've
punished
him
;
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
much
about
punishing
,
"
said
the
tailor
.
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
me
he
pitched
you
down
pretty
clean
out
of
the
room
above
.
<EOS>
I
think
the
best
thing
you
can
do
now
is
to
walk
yourself
off
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
only
thing
that
Vavasor
could
do
,
and
he
did
walk
himself
off
.
<EOS>
He
walked
himself
off
,
and
went
home
to
his
own
lodgings
in
Cecil
Street
,
that
he
might
smooth
his
feathers
after
the
late
encounter
before
he
went
down
to
Westminster
to
take
his
seat
in
the
House
of
Commons
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
that
he
was
comfortable
when
he
got
there
,
or
that
he
felt
himself
very
well
able
to
fight
another
battle
that
night
on
behalf
of
the
River
Bank
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
hurt
,
but
he
had
been
worsted
.
<EOS>
Grey
had
probably
received
more
personal
damage
than
had
fallen
to
his
share
;
but
Grey
had
succeeded
in
expelling
him
from
the
room
,
and
he
knew
that
he
had
been
found
prostrate
on
the
landing
-
place
when
the
tailor
first
saw
him
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
might
probably
have
got
over
the
annoyance
of
this
feeling
<EOS>
had
he
not
been
overwhelmed
by
a
consciousness
that
everything
was
going
badly
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
already
beginning
to
hate
his
seat
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
What
good
had
it
done
for
him
,
or
was
it
likely
to
do
for
him
?
<EOS>
He
found
himself
to
be
associated
there
with
Mr.
Bott
,
and
a
few
others
of
the
same
class
,
 
men
whom
he
despised
;
and
even
they
did
not
admit
him
among
them
without
a
certain
show
of
superiority
on
their
part
.
<EOS>
Who
has
not
ascertained
by
his
own
experience
the
different
lights
through
which
the
same
events
may
be
seen
,
according
to
the
success
,
or
want
of
success
,
which
pervades
the
atmosphere
at
the
moment
?
<EOS>
At
the
present
time
everything
was
unsuccessful
with
George
Vavasor
;
and
though
he
told
himself
,
almost
from
hour
to
hour
,
that
he
would
go
on
with
the
thing
which
he
had
begun
,
 
that
he
would
persevere
in
Parliament
till
he
had
obtained
a
hearing
there
and
created
for
himself
success
,
he
could
not
himself
believe
in
the
promises
which
he
had
made
to
himself
.
<EOS>
He
had
looked
forward
to
his
entrance
into
that
Chamber
as
the
hour
of
his
triumph
;
but
he
had
entered
it
with
Mr.
Bott
,
and
there
had
been
no
triumph
to
him
in
doing
so
.
<EOS>
He
had
sworn
to
himself
that
when
there
he
would
find
men
to
hear
him
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
,
indeed
,
he
could
not
accuse
himself
of
having
missed
his
opportunities
;
his
election
had
been
so
recent
that
he
could
hardly
yet
have
made
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
been
there
long
enough
to
learn
to
fancy
that
there
was
no
glory
in
attempting
.
<EOS>
This
art
of
speaking
in
Parliament
,
which
had
appeared
to
him
to
be
so
grand
,
seemed
already
to
be
a
humdrum
,
homely
,
dull
affair
.
<EOS>
No
one
seemed
to
listen
much
to
what
was
said
.
<EOS>
To
such
as
himself
,
 
Members
without
an
acquired
name
,
 
men
did
not
seem
to
listen
at
all
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
once
,
in
his
hearing
,
spoken
for
two
hours
together
,
and
all
the
House
had
treated
his
speech
with
respect
,
 
had
declared
that
it
was
useful
,
solid
,
conscientious
,
and
what
not
;
but
more
than
half
the
House
had
been
asleep
more
than
half
the
time
that
he
was
on
his
legs
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
had
not
as
yet
commenced
his
career
as
an
orator
;
but
night
after
night
,
as
he
sat
there
,
the
chance
of
commencing
it
with
brilliance
seemed
to
be
further
from
him
,
and
still
further
.
<EOS>
Two
thousand
pounds
of
his
own
money
,
and
two
thousand
more
of
Alice
's
money
,
 
or
of
Mr.
Grey
's
,
 
<EOS>
he
had
already
spent
to
make
his
way
into
that
assembly
.
<EOS>
He
must
spend
,
at
any
rate
,
two
thousand
more
if
he
intended
that
his
career
should
be
prolonged
beyond
a
three
months
'
sitting
;
 
and
how
was
he
to
get
this
further
sum
after
what
had
taken
place
to
-
day
?
  
<EOS>
He
would
get
it
.
<EOS>
That
was
his
resolve
as
he
walked
in
by
the
apple
-
woman
's
stall
,
under
the
shadow
of
the
great
policeman
,
and
between
the
two
august
lamps
.
<EOS>
He
would
get
it
;
 
as
long
as
Alice
had
a
pound
over
which
he
could
obtain
mastery
by
any
act
or
violence
within
his
compass
.
<EOS>
He
would
get
it
;
even
though
it
should
come
through
the
hands
of
John
Grey
and
Mr.
Tombe
.
<EOS>
He
would
get
it
;
though
in
doing
so
he
might
destroy
his
cousin
Alice
and
ruin
his
sister
Kate
.
<EOS>
He
had
gone
too
far
to
stick
at
any
scruples
.
<EOS>
Had
he
not
often
declared
how
great
had
been
that
murderer
who
had
been
able
to
divest
himself
of
all
such
scruples
,
 
who
had
scoured
his
bosom
free
from
all
fears
of
the
hereafter
,
and
,
as
regarded
the
present
,
had
dared
to
trust
for
everything
to
success
?
<EOS>
He
would
go
to
Alice
and
demand
the
money
from
her
with
threats
,
and
with
that
violence
in
his
eyes
which
he
knew
so
well
how
to
assume
.
<EOS>
He
believed
that
when
he
so
demanded
it
,
the
money
would
be
forthcoming
so
as
to
satisfy
,
at
any
rate
,
his
present
emergencies
.
  
<EOS>
That
wretched
old
man
in
Westmoreland
!
<EOS>
If
he
would
but
die
,
there
might
yet
be
a
hope
remaining
of
permanent
success
!
<EOS>
Even
though
the
estate
might
be
entailed
so
as
to
give
him
no
more
than
a
life
-
interest
,
still
money
might
be
raised
on
it
.
<EOS>
His
life
-
interest
in
it
would
be
worth
ten
or
twelve
years
<EOS>
"
purchase
.
<EOS>
He
had
an
idea
that
his
grandfather
had
not
as
yet
made
any
such
will
when
he
left
the
place
in
Westmoreland
.
<EOS>
What
a
boon
it
would
be
if
death
could
be
made
to
overtake
the
old
man
before
he
did
so
!
<EOS>
On
this
very
night
he
walked
about
the
lobbies
of
the
House
,
thinking
of
all
this
.
<EOS>
He
went
by
himself
from
room
to
room
,
roaming
along
passages
,
sitting
now
for
ten
minutes
in
the
gallery
,
and
then
again

a

in
the
body

the
House
,
 
till
he
would
get

and
wander

into
the
lobby
,
impatient
of
the
neighbourhood
of
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
Certainly
just
at
this
time
he
felt
no
desire
to
bring
before
the
House
the
subject
of
the
River

.
  
<EOS>
Nor
was
Mr.
Grey
much
happier
when
he
was
left
alone
,
than
was
his
assailant
.
<EOS>
To
give
Vavasor
his
due
,
the
memory
of
the
affray
itself
did
not
long
trouble
him
much
.
<EOS>
The
success
between
the
combatants
had
been
nearly
equal
,
and
he
had
,
at
any
rate
,
spoken
his
mind
freely
.
<EOS>
His
misery
had
come
from
other
sources
.
<EOS>
But
the
reflection
that
he
had
been
concerned
in
a
row
was
in
itself
enough
to
make
John
Grey
wretched
for
the
time
.
<EOS>
Such
a
misfortune
had
never
hitherto
befallen
him
.
<EOS>
In
all
his
dealings
with
men
words
had
been
sufficient
,
and
generally
words
of
courtesy
had
sufficed
.
<EOS>
To
have
been
personally
engaged
in
a
fighting
scramble
with
such
a
man
as
George
Vavasor
was
to
him
terrible
.
<EOS>
When
ordering
that
his
money
might
be
expended
with
the
possible
object
of
saving
Alice
from
her
cousin
,
he
had
never
felt
a
moment
's
regret
;
he
had
never
thought
that
he
was
doing
more
than
circumstances
fairly
demanded
of
him
.
<EOS>
But
now
he
was
almost
driven
to
utter
reproach
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Alice
!
<EOS>
that
this
thing
should
have
come
upon
me
through
thy
fault
!
"
  
<EOS>
When
Vavasor
was
led
away
down
stairs
by
the
tailor
,
and
Grey
found
that
no
more
actual
fighting
would
be
required
of
him
,
he
retired
into
his
bedroom
,
that
he
might
wash
his
mouth
and
free
himself
from
the
stains
of
the
combat
.
<EOS>
He
had
heard
the
front
door
closed
,
and
knew
that
the
miscreant
was
gone
,
 
the
miscreant
who
had
disturbed
his
quiet
.
<EOS>
Then
he
began
to
think
what
was
the
accusation
with
which
Vavasor
had
charged
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
told
that
he
had
advanced
money
on

of
Alice
,
in
order
that
he
might
obtain
some
power
over
Alice
's

,
and
thus

upon
Alice
for
her
treatment
of
him
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
more
damnably

than
this

.
<EOS>
Of
that
he
was
well
aware
.
<EOS>
But
were
not
the
circumstances
of
a
nature
to
make
it
appear
that
the

was

?
<EOS>
Security
for
the
money
advanced
by
him
,
of
course
,
he
had
none
;
 
<EOS>
of
course
he
had
desired
none
;
 
of
course
the
money
had
been
given
out
of
his
own
pocket
with
the
sole
object
of
saving
Alice
,
if
that
might
be
possible
;
but
of
all
those
who
might
hear
of
this

,
how
many
would
know

even

?
  
<EOS>
While
he
was
in
this

of
mind
,
washing
his
mouth
,
and
disturbing

spirit
,
Mr.
Jones
,

,
came
up
to

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Jones
had
known
him
for
some
years
,
and
entertained
a
most
profound
respect
for
his
character
.
<EOS>
A
rather
sporting
man
than
otherwise
was
Mr.
Jones
.
<EOS>
His
father
had
been
a
tradesman
at
Cambridge
,
and
in
this
way
Jones
had
become
known
to
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
But
though
given
to
sport
,
by
which
he
meant
modern
prize
-
fighting
and
the
Epsom
course
on
the
Derby
day
,
Mr.
Jones
was
a
man
who
dearly
loved
respectable
customers
and
respectable

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
,
with
his
property
at
Nethercoats
,
and
his
august
manners
,
and
his
reputation
at
Cambridge
,
was
a
most
respectable
lodger
,
and
Mr.
Jones
could
hardly
understand
how
any
one
could
presume

raise
his
hand
against
such
a
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
,
sir
 
this
is
a
terrible
affair
!
"
<EOS>
he

,
as
he

into

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
very

,

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Was
the

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
know

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Any

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

.
<EOS>
I

had

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Or

to

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
It

Grey

,
but

story

that
warlike
,
worthy
,
and
very

.
   
<EOS>
The
Last
Will
of
the
Old
Squire
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Kate
Vavasor
was
living
down
in
Westmoreland
,
with
no
other
society
than
that
of
her
grandfather
,
and
did
not
altogether
have
a
very
pleasant
life
of
it
.
<EOS>
George
had
been
apt
to
represent
the
old
man
to
himself
as
being
as
strong
as
an
old
tower
,
which
,
though
it
be
but
a
ruin
,
shows
no
sign
of
falling
.
<EOS>
To
his
eyes
the
Squire
had
always
seemed
to
be
full
of
life
and
power
.
<EOS>
He
could
be
violent
on
occasions
,
and
was
hardly
ever
without
violence
in
his
eyes
and
voice
.
<EOS>
But
George
's
opinion
was
formed
by
his
wish
,
or
rather
by
the
reverses
of
his
wish
.
<EOS>
For
years
he
had
been
longing
that
his
grandfather
should
die
,
 
had
been
accusing
Fate
of
gross
injustice
in
that
she
did
not
snap
the
thread
;
and
with
such
thoughts
in
his
mind
he
had
grudged
every
ounce
which
the
Squire
's
vigour
had
been
able
to
sustain
.
<EOS>
He
had
almost
taught
himself
to
believe
that
it
would
be
a
good
deed
to
squeeze
what
remained
of
life
out
of
that
violent
old
throat
.
<EOS>
But
,
indeed
,
the
embers
of
life
were
burning
low
;
and
had
George
known
all
the
truth
,
he
would
hardly
have
inclined
his
mind
to
thoughts
of
murder
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
,
indeed
,
very
weak
with
age
,
and
tottering
with
unsteady
steps
on
the
brink
of
his
grave
,
though
he
would
still
come
down
early
from
his
room
,
and
would
,
if
possible
,
creep
out
about
the
garden
and
into
the
farmyard
.
<EOS>
He
would
still
sit
down
to
dinner
,
and
would
drink
his
allotted
portion
of
port
wine
,
in
the
doctor
's
teeth
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
by
no
means
desired
to
rob
him
of
his
last
luxury
,
or
even
to
stint
his
quantity
;
but
he
recommended
certain
changes
in
the
mode
and
time
of
taking
it
.
<EOS>
Against
this
,
however
,
the
old
Squire
indignantly
rebelled
,
and
scolded
Kate
almost
off
her
legs
when
she
attempted
to
enforce
the
doctor
's
orders
.
<EOS>
"
What
the
mischief
does
it
signify
,
"
the
old
man
said
to
her
one
evening
;
 
"
what
difference
will
it
make
whether
I
am
dead
or
alive
,
unless
it
is
that
George
would
turn
you
out
of
the
house
<EOS>
directly
he
gets
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
thinking
of
any
one
but
yourself
,
sir
,
"
said
Kate
,
with
a
tear
in
her
eye
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
be
troubled
to
think
of
me
much
longer
,
"
said
the
Squire
;
and
then
he
gulped
down
the
remaining
half
of
his
glass
of
wine
.
  
<EOS>
Kate
was
,
in
truth
,
very
good
to
him
.
<EOS>
Women
always
are
good
under
such
circumstances
;
and
Kate
Vavasor
was
one
who
would
certainly
stick
to
such
duties
as
now
fell
to
her
lot
.
<EOS>
She
was
eminently
true
and
loyal
to
her
friends
,
though
she
could
be
as
false
on
their
behalf
as
most
false
people
can
be
on
their
own
.
<EOS>
She
was
very
good
to
the
old
man
,
tending
all
his
wants
,
taking
his
violence
with
good
-
humour
rather
than
with
submission
,
not
opposing
him
with
direct
contradiction
when
he
abused
his
grandson
,
but
saying
little
words
to
mitigate
his
wrath
,
if
it
were
possible
.
<EOS>
At
such
times
the
Squire
would
tell
her
that
she
also
would
learn
to
know
her
brother
's
character
some
day
.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
live
to
be
robbed
by
him
,
and
turned
out
as
naked
as
you
were
born
,
"
he
said
to
her
one
day
.
<EOS>
Then
Kate
fired
up
and
declared
that
she
fully
trusted
her
brother
's
love
.
<EOS>
Whatever
faults
he
might
have
,
he
had
been
staunch
to
her
,
<EOS>
So
she
said
,
and
<EOS>
the
old
man
sneered
at
her
for
saying
so
.
  
<EOS>
One
morning
,
soon
after
this
,
when
she
brought
him
up
to
his
bedroom
some
mixture
of
thin
porridge
,
which
he
still
endeavoured
to
swallow
for
his
breakfast
,
he
bade
her
sit
down
,
and
began
to
talk
to
her
about
the
property
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
you
are
a
fool
,
"
he
said
,
"
about
all
matters
of
business
;
 
more
of
a
fool
than
even
women
generally
are
.
"
<EOS>
To
this
Kate
acceded
with
a
little
smile
,
 
acknowledging
that
her
understanding
was
limited
.
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
see
Gogram
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
write
to
him
a
line
,
telling
him
to
come
here
to
-
day
,
 
he
or
one
of
his
men
,
 
and
send
it
at
once
by
Peter
.
<EOS>
"
Gogram
was
an
attorney
who
lived
at
Penrith
,
and
who
was
never
summoned
to
Vavasor
Hall
unless
the
Squire
had
something
to
say
about
his
will
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
you
'd
better
put
it
off
till
you
are
a
little
stronger
?
"
said
Kate
.
<EOS>
Whereupon
the
Squire
fired
at
her
such
a
volley
of
oaths
that
she
sprang
off
the
chair
on
which
she
was
sitting
,
and
darted
across
to
a
little
table
at
which
there
was
pen
and
ink
,
and
wrote
her
note
to
Mr.
Gogram
,
before
she
had
recovered
from
the
shaking
which
the
battery
had
given
her
.
<EOS>
She
wrote
the
note
,
and
ran
away
with
it
to
Peter
,
and
saw
Peter
on
the
pony
on
his
way
to
Penrith
,
before
she
dared
to
return
to
her
grandfather
's
bedside
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
should
you
do
with
the
estate
if
I
left
it
you
?
"
<EOS>
the
Squire
said
to
her
the
first
moment
she
was
again
back
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
a
question
she
could
not
answer
instantly
.
<EOS>
She
stood
by
his
bedside
for
a
while
thinking
,
 
holding
her
grandfather
's
hand
and
looking
down
upon
the
bed
.
<EOS>
He
,
with
his
rough
watery
old
eyes
,
was
gazing
up
into
her
face
,
as
though
he
were
trying
to
read
her
thoughts
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
should
give
it
to
my
brother
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
'm
d
 
---
if
I
'll
leave
it
to
you
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
She
did
not
jump
now
,
though
he
had
sworn
at
her
.
<EOS>
She
still
stood
,
holding
his
hand
softly
,
and
looking
down
upon
the
bed
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
were
you
,
grandfather
,
"
she
said
almost
in
a
whisper
,
"
I
would
not
trust
myself
to
alter
family
arrangements
whilst
I
was
ill
.
<EOS>
I
'm
sure
you
would
advise
any
one
else
against
doing
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
if
I
were
to
leave
it
to
Alice
,
she
'd
give
it
to
him
too
,
"
he
said
,
speaking
his
thoughts
out
loud
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
it
is
<EOS>
you
see
in
him
,
I
never
could
even
guess
.
<EOS>
He
's
as
ugly
as
a
baboon
,
with
his
scarred
face
.
<EOS>
He
has
never
done
anything
to
show
himself
a
clever
fellow
.
<EOS>
Kate
,
give
me
some
of
that
bottle
the
man
sent
.
"
<EOS>
Kate
handed
him
his
medicine
,
and
then
stood
again
by
his
bedside
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
did
he
get
the
money
to
pay
for
his
election
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
the
Squire
asked
,
as
soon
as
he
had
swallowed
the
draught
.
<EOS>
"
They
would
n't
give
such
a
one
as
him
credit
a
yard
further
than
they
could
see
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
where
he
got
it
,
"
said
Kate
,
lying
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
not
had
yours
;
has
he
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
would
not
take
it
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
offered
it
to
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
he
has
not
had
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
penny
of
it
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
made
you
offer
it
to
him
after
what
I
said
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
it
was
my
own
,
"
said
Kate
,
stoutly
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
the
biggest
idiot
that
ever
I
heard
of
,
and
you
'll
know
it
yourself
some
day
.
<EOS>
Go
away
now
,
and
let
me
know
when
Gogram
comes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
went
away
,
and
for
a
time
employed
herself
about
her
ordinary
household
work
.
<EOS>
Then
she
sat
down
alone
in
the
dingy
old
dining
-
room
,
to
think
what
had
better
be
done
in
her
present
circumstances
.
<EOS>
The
carpet
of
the
room
was
worn
out
,
as
were
also
the
covers
of
the
old
chairs
and
the
horsehair
sofa
which
was
never
moved
from
its
accustomed
place
along
the
wall
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
a
comfortable
Squire
's
residence
,
this
old
house
at
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
In
the
last
twenty
years
no
money
had
been
spent
on
furniture
or
embellishments
,
and
for
the
last
ten
years
there
had
been
no
painting
,
either
inside
or
out
.
<EOS>
Twenty
years
ago
the
Squire
had
been
an
embarrassed
man
,
and
had
taken
a
turn
in
his
life
and
had
lived
sparingly
.
<EOS>
It
could
not
be
said
that
he
had
become
a
miser
.
<EOS>
His
table
was
kept
plentifully
,
and
there
had
never
been
want
in
his
house
.
<EOS>
In
some
respects
,
too
,
he
had
behaved
liberally
to
Kate
and
to
others
,
and
he
had
kept
up
the
timber
and
fences
on
the
property
.
<EOS>
But
the
house
had
become
wretched
in
its
dull
,
sombre
,
dirty
darkness
,
and
the
gardens
round
it
were
as
bad
.
  
<EOS>
What
ought
she
now
to
do
?
<EOS>
She
believed
that
her
grandfather
's
last
days
were
coming
,
and
she
knew
that
others
of
the
family
should
be
with
him
besides
herself
.
<EOS>
For
their
sakes
,
for
his
,
and
for
her
own
,
it
would
be
proper
that
she
should
not
be
alone
there
when
he
died
.
<EOS>
But
for
whom
should
she
send
?
<EOS>
Her
brother
was
the
natural
heir
,
and
would
be
the
head
of
the
family
.
<EOS>
Her
duty
to
him
was
clear
,
and
the
more
so
as
her
grandfather
was
at
this
moment
speaking
of
changes
in
his
will
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
a
question
to
her
whether
George
's
presence
at
Vavasor
,
even
if
he
would
come
,
would
not
at
this
moment
do
more
harm
than
good
to
his
own
interests
.
<EOS>
It
would
make
some
prejudicial
change
in
the
old
man
's
will
more
probable
instead
of
less
so
.
<EOS>
George
would
not
become
soft
and
mild
-
spoken
even
by
a
death
-
bed
side
,
and
it
would
be
likely
enough
that
the
Squire
would
curse
his
heir
with
his
dying
breath
.
<EOS>
She
might
send
for
her
uncle
John
;
but
if
she
did
so
without
telling
George
she
would
be
treating
George
unfairly
;
and
she
knew
that
it
was
improbable
that
her
uncle
and
her
brother
should
act
together
in
anything
.
<EOS>
Her
aunt
Greenow
,
she
thought
,
would
come
to
her
,
and
her
presence
would
not
influence
the
Squire
in
any
way
with
reference
to
the
property
.
<EOS>
So
she
made
up
her
mind
at
last
that
she
would
ask
her
aunt
to
come
to
Vavasor
,
and
that
she
would
tell
her
brother
accurately
all
that
she
could
tell
,
 
leaving
him
to
come
or
stay
,
as
he
might
think
.
<EOS>
Alice
would
,
no
doubt
,
learn
all
the
facts
from
him
,
and
her
uncle
John
would
hear
them
from
Alice
.
<EOS>
Then
they
could
do
as
they
pleased
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
Mr.
Gogram
had
been
there
she
would
write
her
letters
,
and
they
should
be
sent
over
to
Shap
early
on
the
following
morning
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Gogram
came
and
was
closeted
with
the
Squire
,
and
the
doctor
also
came
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
saw
Kate
,
and
,
shaking
his
head
,
told
her
that
her
grandfather
was
sinking
lower
and
lower
every
hour
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
infinitely
better
for
him
if
he
would
take
that
port
wine
at
four
doses
in
the
day
,
or
even
at
two
,
instead
of
taking
it
all
together
.
<EOS>
Kate
promised
to
try
again
,
but
stated
her
conviction
that
the
trial
would
be
useless
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
,
when
pressed
on
the
matter
,
said
that
his
patient
might
probably
live
a
week
,
not
improbably
a
fortnight
,
 
perhaps
a
month
,
if
he
would
be
obedient
,
 
and
so
forth
.
<EOS>
Gogram
went
away
without
seeing
Kate
;
and
Kate
,
who
looked
upon
a
will
as
an
awful
and
somewhat
tedious
ceremony
,
was
in
doubt
whether
her
grandfather
would
live
to
complete
any
new
operation
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
truth
,
the
will
had
been
made
and
signed
and
witnessed
,
 
the
parish
clerk
and
one
of
the
tenants
having
been
had
up
into
the
room
as
witnesses
.
<EOS>
Kate
knew
that
the
men
had
been
there
,
but
still
did
not
think
that
a
new
will
had
been
perfected
.
  
<EOS>
That
evening
when
it
was
dusk
the
Squire
came
into
the
dining
-
room
,
having
been
shuffling
about
the
grand
sweep
before
the
house
for
a
quarter
of
an
hour
.
<EOS>
The
day
was
cold
and
the
wind
bleak
,
but
still
he
would
go
out
,
and
Kate
had
wrapped
him
up
carefully
in
mufflers
and
great
-
coats
.
<EOS>
Now
he
came
in
to
what
he
called
dinner
,
and
Kate
sat
down
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
drank
no
wine
that
day
,
although
she
had
brought
it
to
him
twice
during
the
morning
.
<EOS>
Now
he
attempted
to
swallow
a
little
soup
,
but
failed
;
and
after
that
,
while
Kate
was
eating
her
bit
of
chicken
,
had
the
decanter
put
before
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
eat
,
and
I
suppose
it
wo
n't
hurt
you
if
I
take
my
wine
at
once
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
It
went
against
the
grain
with
him
,
even
yet
,
that
he
could
not
wait
till
the
cloth
was
gone
from
the
table
,
but
his
impatience
for
the
only
sustenance
that
he
could
take
was
too
much
for
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
should
eat
something
,
sir
;
will
you
have
a
bit
of
toast
to
sop
in
your
wine
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
word
"
sop
"
was
badly
chosen
,
and
made
the
old
Squire
angry
.
"
<EOS>
Sopped
toast
!
<EOS>
why
am
I
to
spoil
the
only
thing
I
can
enjoy
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
wine
would
do
you
more
good
if
you
would
take
something
with
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
!
<EOS>
Nothing
will
do
me
any
good
any
more
.
<EOS>
As
for
eating
,
you
know
I
ca
n't
eat
.
<EOS>
What
's
the
use
of
bothering
me
?
"
<EOS>
Then
he
filled
his
second
glass
,
and
paused
awhile
before
he
put
it
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
He
never
exceeded
four
glasses
,
but
the
four
he
was
determined
that
he
would
have
,
as
long
as
he
could
lift
them
to
his
mouth
.
  
<EOS>
Kate
finished
,
or
pretended
to
finish
,
her
dinner
within
five
minutes
,
in
order
that
the
table
might
be
made
to
look
comfortable
for
him
.
<EOS>
Then
she
poked
the
fire
,
and
brushed
up
the
hearth
,
and
closed
the
old
curtains
with
her
own
hands
,
moving
about
silently
.
<EOS>
As
she
moved
his
eye
followed
her
,
and
when
she
came
behind
his
chair
,
and
pushed
the
decanter
a
little
more
within
his
reach
,
he
put
out
his
rough
,
hairy
hand
,
and
laid
it
upon
one
of
hers
which
she
had
rested
on
the
table
,
with
a
tenderness
that
was
unusual
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
good
girl
,
Kate
.
<EOS>
I
wish
you
had
been
a
boy
,
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
,
I
should
n't
,
perhaps
,
have
been
here
to
take
care
of
you
,
"
she
said
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
you
'd
have
been
like
your
brother
,
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
Not
that
I
think
there
could
have
been
two
so
bad
as
he
is
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
grandfather
,
if
he
has
offended
you
,
you
should
try
to
forgive
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Try
to
forgive
him
!
<EOS>
How
often
have
I
forgiven
him
without
any
trying
?
<EOS>
Why
did
he
come
down
here
the
other
day
,
and
insult
me
for
the
last
time
?
<EOS>
Why
did
n't
he
keep
away
,
as
I
had
bidden
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
gave
him
leave
to
see
you
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
give
him
leave
to
treat
me
like
that
.
<EOS>
Never
mind
;
he
will
find
that
,
old
as
I
am
,
I
can
punish
an
insult
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
done
anything
,
sir
,
to
injure
him
?
"
said
Kate
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
made
another
will
,
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
Do
you
suppose
I
had
that
man
here
all
the
way
from
Penrith
for
nothing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
n't
done
yet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
it
is
done
.
<EOS>
If
I
left
him
the
whole
property
it
would
be
gone
in
two
years
"
time
.
<EOS>
What
's
the
use
of
doing
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
for
his
life
,
sir
!
<EOS>
You
had
promised
him
that
he
should
have
it
for
his
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
tell
me
that
?
<EOS>
I
never
promised
him
.
<EOS>
As
my
heir
,
he
would
have
had
it
all
,
if
he
would
have
behaved
himself
with
common
decency
.
<EOS>
Even
though
I
disliked
him
,
as
I
always
have
done
,
he
should
have
had
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
taken
it
from
him
altogether
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
answer
no
questions
about
it
,
Kate
.
"
<EOS>
Then
a
fit
of
coughing
came
upon
him
,
his
four
glasses
of
wine
having
been
all
taken
,
and
there
was
no
further
talk
about
business
.
<EOS>
During
the
evening
Kate
read
a
chapter
of
the
Bible
out
loud
.
<EOS>
But
the
Squire
was
very
impatient
under
the
reading
,
and
positively
refused
permission
for
a
second
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
n't
any
good
in
so
much
of
it
,
all
at
once
,
"
he
said
,
using
almost
exactly
the
same
words
which
Kate
had
used
to
him
about
the
port
wine
.
<EOS>
There
may
have
been
good
produced
by
the
small
quantity
to
which
he
listened
,
as
there
is
good
from
the
physic
which
children
take
with
wry
faces
,
most
unwillingly
.
<EOS>
Who
can
say
?
  
<EOS>
For
many
weeks
past
Kate
had
begged
her
uncle
to
allow
the
clergyman
of
Vavasor
to
come
to
him
;
but
he
had
positively
declined
.
<EOS>
The
vicar
was
a
young
man
to
whom
the
living
had
lately
been
given
by
the
Chancellor
,
and
he
had
commenced
his
career
by
giving
instant
offence
to
the
Squire
.
<EOS>
This
vicar
's
predecessor
had
been
an
old
man
,
almost
as
old
as
the
Squire
himself
,
and
had
held
the
living
for
forty
years
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
a
Westmoreland
man
,
had
read
the
prayers
and
preached
his
one
Sunday
sermon
in
a
Westmoreland
dialect
,
getting
through
the
whole
operation
rather
within
an
hour
and
a
quarter
.
<EOS>
He
had
troubled
none
of
his
parishioners
by
much
advice
,
and
had
been
meek
and
obedient
to
the
Squire
.
<EOS>
Knowing
the
country
well
,
and
being
used
to
its
habits
,
he
had
lived
,
and
been
charitable
too
,
on
the
proceeds
of
his
living
,
which
had
never
reached
two
hundred
a
year
.
<EOS>
But
the
new
comer
was
a
close
-
fisted
man
,
with
higher
ideas
of
personal
comfort
,
who
found
it
necessary
to
make
every
penny
go
as
far
as
possible
,
who
made
up
in
preaching
for
what
he
could
not
give
away
in
charity
;
who
established
an
afternoon
service
,
and
who
had
rebuked
the
Squire
for
saying
that
the
doing
so
was
trash
and
nonsense
.
<EOS>
Since
that
the
Squire
had
never
been
inside
the
church
,
except
on
the
occasion
of
Christmas
-
day
.
<EOS>
For
this
,
indeed
,
the
state
of
his
health
gave
ample
excuse
;
but
he
had
positively
refused
to
see
the
vicar
,
though
that
gentleman
had
assiduously
called
,
and
had
at
last
desired
the
servant
to
tell
the
clergyman
not
to
come
again
unless
he
were
sent
for
.
<EOS>
Kate
's
task
was
,
therefore
,
difficult
,
both
as
regarded
the
temporal
and
spiritual
wants
of
her
grandfather
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
reading
was
finished
,
the
old
man
dozed
in
his
chair
for
half
an
hour
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
go
up
to
bed
before
the
enjoyment
of
that
luxury
.
<EOS>
He
was
daily
implored
to
do
so
,
because
that
sleep
in
the
chair
interfered
so
fatally
with
his
chance
of
sleeping
in
bed
.
<EOS>
But
sleep
in
his
chair
he
would
and
did
.
<EOS>
Then
he
woke
,
and
after
a
fit
of
coughing
,
was
induced
,
with
much
ill
-
humour
,
to
go
up
to
his
room
.
<EOS>
Kate
had
never
seen
him
so
weak
.
<EOS>
He
was
hardly
able
,
even
with
her
assistance
and
that
of
the
old
servant
,
to
get
up
the
broad
stairs
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
still
some
power
left
to
him
for
violence
of
language
after
he
got
to
his
room
,
and
he
rated
Kate
and
the
old
woman
loudly
,
because
his
slippers
were
not
in
the
proper
place
.
<EOS>
"
Grandfather
,
"
said
Kate
,
"
would
you
like
me
to
stay
in
the
room
with
you
to
-
night
?
"
<EOS>
He
rated
her
again
for
this
proposition
,
and
then
,
with
assistance
from
the
nurse
,
he
was
gotten
into
bed
and
was
left
alone
.
  
<EOS>
After
that
Kate
went
to
her
own
room
and
wrote
her
letters
.
<EOS>
The
first
she
wrote
was
to
her
aunt
Greenow
.
<EOS>
That
was
easily
enough
written
.
<EOS>
To
Mrs.
Greenow
it
was
not
necessary
that
she
should
say
anything
about
money
.
<EOS>
She
simply
stated
her
belief
that
her
grandfather
's
last
day
was
near
at
hand
,
and
begged
her
aunt
to
come
and
pay
a
last
visit
to
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
a
great
comfort
to
me
in
my
distress
,
"
she
said
;
"
and
it
will
be
a
satisfaction
to
you
to
have
seen
your
father
again
.
"
<EOS>
She
knew
that
her
aunt
would
come
,
and
that
task
was
soon
done
.
  
<EOS>
But
her
letter
to
her
brother
was
much
more
difficult
.
<EOS>
What
should
she
tell
him
,
and
what
should
she
not
tell
him
?
<EOS>
She
began
by
describing
her
grandfather
's
state
,
and
by

to

,
as
she
had
done
to
Mrs.
Greenow
,
that
she
believed
the
old
man
's
hours
were
well
-
nigh
come
to
a
close
.
<EOS>
She
told
him
that
she
had
asked
her
aunt
to
come
to
her
;
"
not
,
"
she
said
,
"
that
I
think
her
coming
will

,
but
I
feel
the

of
the
house

.
<EOS>
I
must
leave

you
to

,
"
she

,
"
whether

had
better
be
here
.
<EOS>
If
anything
should
happen
,
"
 
people
when
writing
such
letters
are
always
afraid
to
speak
of
death
by
its
proper
name
,
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
send

a
message
,
and
no

would
come
at
once
.
"
<EOS>
Then

of
the
will
.
<EOS>
Had

that
her
own

were
involved
she
would
have
said
nothing
on
the
subject
;
but
she
feared
her
brother
,

his
misconstruction
of

,

much

,
 
and
therefore
she
resolved

.
<EOS>
He

,
and

of
a

which
had
been

.
  
<EOS>
So

told

all
,
and
the

became
long
in

.
<EOS>
"
I
write
with
a
heavy

,
"
she

,
"
because
I

will
be

.
<EOS>
He
gave

to

that
in
this
will
he
left
everything

.
<EOS>
I
can
not

.
<EOS>
Indeed
I
can
not

his

;
but
that

he
left

.
<EOS>
The
day

had

what

;
but

.
<EOS>
I
have
no

what
he
put
into

will
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
even

to

.
<EOS>
But
now
I
have
told
you
all
that
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
The
letter
was
a
very
long

,
and
was
not

till

;
but

she
had
the
two
taken

the

,
as

boy
was
to
start
with

before

.
  
<EOS>
Early
on
the
next
morning
she
crept
silently
into
her
grandfather
's
room
,
as
was
her
habit
;
but
he
was
apparently

,
and
then
she
crept
back
again
.
<EOS>
The
old
servant
told

that
the
Squire
had
been
awake
at
four
,
and
at
five
,
and
at
six
,
and
had
called
for
her
.
<EOS>
Then
he
had
seemed
to
go
to

.
<EOS>
Four
or
five
times
in
the
course
of
the
morning
<EOS>
Kate
went
into
the
room
,
but
her
grandfather
did
not

.
<EOS>
At
last
she
feared

might
already
have
passed
away
,
and
she
put
her

upon

,
and
down

.
<EOS>
He
then
gently

her
hand
with

,
showing
her
plainly
that
he
was
not
only

,

.
<EOS>
She
then
offered
him
food
,
 
the
thin
porridge
,
 
which
he
was
wo
nt
to

,
and
the
medicine
.
<EOS>
She
offered

some
wine
too
,
but
he
would
take
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
At
twelve

,
which
had

.
<EOS>
She

that

from
Alice
,
and
opening
<EOS>
it
found
that
it
was
very
long
.
<EOS>
At
that
moment
she
could
not

,
but
she
saw
words

that
made

to
know

as

as

.
<EOS>
But
she
could
not

her
grandfather

.
<EOS>
At

doctor
came
to

,
and
remained

till
the
dusk
of
the
evening
had

.
<EOS>
At
eight
o'clock
the
old
man
was
dead
.
   
<EOS>
Showing
How
Alice
Was
Punished
.
 
<EOS>
Poor
Kate
's
condition
at
the
old
Hall
on
that
night
was
very
sad
.
<EOS>
The
presence
of
death
is
always
a
source
of
sorrow
,
even
though
the
circumstances
of
the
case
are
of
a
kind
to
create
no
agony
of
grief
.
<EOS>
The
old
man
who
had
just
passed
away
up
-
stairs
was
fully
due
to
go
.
<EOS>
He
had
lived
his
span
all
out
,
and
had
himself
known
that
to
die
was
the
one
thing
left
for
him
to
do
.
<EOS>
Kate
also
had
expected
his
death
,
and
had
felt
that
the
time
had
come
in
which
it
would
be
foolish
even
to
wish
that
it
should
be
arrested
.
<EOS>
But
death
close
to
one
is
always
sad
as
it
is
solemn
.
  
<EOS>
And
she
was
quite
alone
at
Vavasor
Hall
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
acquaintance
within
some
miles
of
her
.
<EOS>
From
the
young
vicar
,
though
she
herself
had
not
quarrelled
with
him
,
she
could
receive
no
comfort
,
as
she
hardly
knew
him
;
nor
was
she
of
a

which
would
dispose

to

to
a

at
such

time
for
comfort
,
unless
to
one
who
might
have
been
an
old

.
<EOS>
Her
aunt
and
brother
would
probably
both
come
to
her
,
but
they
could
hardly
be
with
her
for
a
day
or
two
,
and
during
that
day
or
two
it
would
be
needful
that
orders
should
be
given
which
it
is
disagreeable
for
a
woman
to
have

.
<EOS>
The
servants
,
moreover
,
in
the
house
were
hardly

to

much
.
<EOS>
There
was
an
old
butler
,
or
footman
,
who
had
lived
at
the
Hall
for
more
than
fifty
years
,
but
he
was
crippled
with
rheumatism
,
and
so
laden
with
maladies
,
that
he
rarely
crept
out
of
his
own
room
.
<EOS>
He
was
simply
an
additional
burden
on
the
others
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
boy
who
had
lately
done
all
the
work
which
the
other
should
have
done
,
and
ever
so
much
more
beside
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
knowing
how
much
work
such
a
boy
will
do
when
properly
drilled
,
and
he
was
now
Kate
's
best
minister
in
her
distress
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
old
nurse
,
 
but
she
had
been
simply
good
for
nursing
,
and
there
were
two
rough
Westmoreland
girls
who
called
themselves
cook
and
housemaid
.
  
<EOS>
On
that
first
evening
,
 
the
very
day
on
which
her
grandfather
had
died
,
 
Kate
would
have
been
more
comfortable
had
she
really
found
something
that
she
could
do
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
in
truth
nothing
.
<EOS>
She
hovered
for
an
hour
or
two
in
and
out
of
the
room
,
conscious
of
the
letter
which
she
had
in
her
pocket
,
and
very
desirous
in
heart
of
reading
it
,
but
restrained
by
a
feeling
that
at
such
a
moment
she
ought
to
think
only
of
the
dead
.
<EOS>
In
this
she
was
wrong
.
<EOS>
Let
the
living
think
of
the
dead
,
when
their
thoughts
will
travel
that
way
whether
the
thinker
wish
it
or
no
.
<EOS>
Grief
taken
up
because
grief
is
supposed
to
be
proper
,
is
only
one
degree
better
than
pretended
grief
.
<EOS>
When
one
sees
it
,
one
can
not
but
think
of
the
lady
who
asked
her
friend
,
in
confidence
,
whether
hot
roast

and
bread
-

were
compatible

the
earliest

of
weeds
;
or

that
other

,
 
a
royal
lady
<EOS>
she
,
 
who
was
much

in
the
tedium
of
her
trouble
when
assured
by
one
of
the
lords
about
the
Court
that
piquet
was

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
late
at
night
,
near
eleven
,
before
Kate
took
out
her
letter
and
read

.
<EOS>
As
something
of
my
story
hangs
upon
it
,
I
will
give
it
at
length
,
though
it
was
a
long

.
<EOS>
It
had
been
written
with
great
struggles
,
and
with
many
tears
,
and
<EOS>
Kate
,
as

read

to
the
end
,
almost
forgot
that
her
grandfather
was
lying
dead
in

above

.
  
<EOS>
Queen
Anne
Street
,
April
,
186
 
.
  
<EOS>
DEAREST
KATE
,
  
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
how
to
write
to
you
 
what
I
have
to
tell
,
and
yet
I
must
tell
it
.
<EOS>
I
must
tell
it
to
you
,
but
I
shall
never
repeat
the
story
to
any
one
else
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
written
yesterday
,
when
it
occurred
,
but
I
was
so
ill
that
I
felt
myself
unable
to
make
the
exertion
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
at
one
time
,
after
your
brother
had
left
me
,
I
almost
doubted
whether
I
should
ever
be
able
to
collect
my
thoughts
again
.
<EOS>
My
dismay
was
at
first
<EOS>
so
great
that
my
reason
for
a
time
deserted
me
,
and
I
could
only
sit
and
cry
like
an
idiot
.
  
<EOS>
Dear
Kate
,
I
hope
you
will
not
be
angry
with
me
for
telling
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
endeavoured
to
think
about
it
as
calmly
as
I
can
,
and
I
believe
that
I
have
no
alternative
.
<EOS>
The
fact
that
your
brother
has
quarrelled
with
me
can
not
be
concealed
from
you
,
and
I
must
not
leave
him
to
tell
you
of
the
manner
of
it
.
<EOS>
He
came
to
me
yesterday
in
great
anger
.
<EOS>
His
anger
then
was
nothing
to
what
it
became
afterwards
;
but
even
when
he
first
came
in
he
was
full
of
wrath
.
<EOS>
He
stood
up
before
me
,
and
asked
me
how
it
had
come
to
pass
that
I
had
sent
him
the
money
which
he
had
asked
of
me
through
the
hands
of
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
had
not
done
this
,
and
so
I
told
him
at
once
.
<EOS>
I
had
spoken
of
the
matter
to
no
one
but
papa
,
and
he
had
managed
it
for
me
.
<EOS>
Even
now
I
know
nothing
of
it
,
and
as
I
have
not
yet
spoken
to
papa
<EOS>
I
can
not
understand
it
.
<EOS>
George
at
once
told
me
that
he
disbelieved
me
,
and
when
I
sat
quiet
under
this
insult
,
he
used
harsher
words
,
and
said
that
I
had
conspired
to
lower
him
before
the
world
.
  
<EOS>
He
then
asked
me
whether
I
loved
him
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Kate
,
I
must
tell
it
you
all
,
though
it
is
dreadful
to
me
that
I
should
have
to
write
it
.
<EOS>
You
remember
how
it
came
to
pass
when
we
were
in
Westmoreland
together
at
Christmas
?
<EOS>
Do
not
think
that
I
am
blaming
you
,
but
I
was
very
rash
then
in
the
answers
which
I
made
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
thought
that
I
could
be
useful
to
him
as
his
wife
,
and
I
had
told
myself
that
it
would
be
good
that
I
should
be
of
use
in
some
way
.
<EOS>
When
he
asked
me
that
question
yesterday
,
I
sat
silent
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
how
could
I
have
answered
it
in
the
affirmative
,
when
he
had
just
used
such
language
to
me
,
 
while
he
was
standing
opposite
to
me
,
looking
at
me
in
that
way
which
he
has
when
he
is
enraged
?
<EOS>
Then
he
spoke
again
and
demanded
of
me
that
I
should
at
once
send
back
to
Mr.
Grey
all
presents
of
his
which
I
had
kept
,
and
at
the
same
time
took
up
and
threw
across
the
table
on
to
the
sofa
near
me
,
a
little
paper
knife
which
Mr.
Grey
once
gave
me
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
allow
myself
to
be
so
ordered
by
him
;
so
I
said
nothing
,
but
put
the
knife
back
upon
the
table
.
<EOS>
He
then
took
it
again
and
threw
it
beneath
the
grate
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
right
to
look
upon
you
as
my
wife
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
,
as
such
,
I
will
not
allow
you
to
keep
that
man
's
things
about
you
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
told
him
then
that
I
should
never
become
his
wife
,
but
though
I
remember
many
of
his
words
,
I
remember
none
of
my
own
.
<EOS>
He
swore
,
I
know
,
with
a
great
oath
,
that
if
I
went
back
a
second
time
from
my
word
to
him
he
would
leave
me
no
peace
,
 
that
he
would
punish
me
for
my
perfidy
with
some
fearful
punishment
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Kate
,
I
can
not
tell
you
what
he
looked
like
.
<EOS>
He
had
then
come
quite
close
to
me
,
and
I
know
that
I
trembled
before
him
as
though
he
were
going
to
strike
me
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
What
could
I
say
to
a
man
who
behaved
to
me
in
such
a
manner
?
<EOS>
Then
,
as
far
as
I
can
remember
it
,
he
sat
down
and
began
to
talk
about
money
.
<EOS>
I
forget
what
he
said
at
first
,
but
I
know
that
I
assured
him
that
he
might
take
what
he
wanted
so
long
as
enough
was
left
to
prevent
my
being
absolutely
a
burden
on
papa
.
<EOS>
"
That
,
madam
,
is
a
matter
of
course
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
I
remember
those
words
so
well
.
<EOS>
Then
he
explained
that
after
what
had
passed
between
us
,
I
had
no
right
to
ruin
him
by
keeping
back
from
him
money
which
had
been
promised
to
him
,
and
which
was
essential
to
his
success
.
<EOS>
In
this
,
dear
Kate
,
I
think
he
was
mainly
right
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
have
been
right
in
putting
it
to
me
in
that
hard
,
cruel
manner
,
especially
as
I
had
never
refused
anything
that
he
had
asked
of
me
in
respect
of
money
.
<EOS>
The
money
he
may
have
while
it
lasts
;
but
then
there
must
be
an
end
of
it
all
between
us
,
even
though
he
should
have
the
power
of
punishing
me
,
as
he
says
he
will
do
.
<EOS>
Punishing
me
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
What
punishment
can
be
so
hard
as
that
which
he
has
already
inflicted
?
  
<EOS>
He
then
desired
me
to
write
a
letter
to
him
which
he
might
show
to
the
lawyer
,
 
to
our
own
lawyer
,
I
think
he
meant
,
 
in
order
that
money
might
be
raised
to
pay
back
what
Mr.
Grey
had
advanced
,
and
give
him
what
he
now
required
.
<EOS>
I
think
he
said
it
was
to
be
five
thousand
pounds
.
<EOS>
When
he
asked
this
I
did
not
move
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
was
unable
to
move
.
<EOS>
Then
he
spoke
very
loud
,
and
swore
at
me
again
,
and
brought
me
pen
and
ink
,
demanding
that
I
should
write
the
letter
.
<EOS>
I
was
so
frightened
that
I
thought
of
running
to
the
door
to
escape
,
and
I
would
have
done
so
<EOS>
had
I
not
distrusted
my
own
power
.
<EOS>
Had
it
been
to
save
my
life
<EOS>
I
could
not
have
written
the
letter
.
<EOS>
I
believe
I
was
now
crying
,
 
at
any
rate
I
threw
myself
back
and
covered
my
face
with
my
hands
.
<EOS>
Then
he
came
and
sat
by
me
,
and
took
hold
of
my
arms
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
Kate
;
I
can
not
tell
it
you
all
.
<EOS>
He
put
his
mouth
close
to
my
ear
,
and
said
words
which
were
terrible
,
though
I
did
not
understand
them
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
what
it
was
he
said
,
but
he
was
threatening
me
with
his
anger
if
I
did
not
obey
him
.
<EOS>
Before
he
left
me
,
I
believe
I
found
my
voice
to
tell
him
that
he
should
certainly
have
the
money
which
he
required
.
<EOS>
And
so
he
shall
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
to
Mr.
Round
myself
,
and
insist
on
its
being
done
.
<EOS>
My
money
is
my
own
,
and
I
may
do
with
it
as
I
please
.
<EOS>
But
I
hope
,
 
I
am
obliged
to
hope
,
that
I
may
never
be
made
to
see
my
cousin
again
.
  
<EOS>
I
will
not
pretend
to
express
any
opinion
as
to
the
cause
of
all
this
.
<EOS>
It
is
very
possible
that
you
will
not
believe
all
I
say
,
 
that
you
will
think
that
I
am
mad
and
have
deluded
myself
.
<EOS>
Of
course
your
heart
will
prompt
you
to
accuse
me
rather
than
him
.
<EOS>
If
it
is
so
,
and
if
there
must
therefore
be
a
division
between
us
,
my
grief
will
be
greatly
increased
;
but
I
do
not
know
that
I
can
help
it
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
keep
all
this
back
from
you
.
<EOS>
He
has
cruelly
ill
-
used
me
and
insulted
me
.
<EOS>
He
has
treated
me
as
I
should
have
thought
no
man
could
have
treated
a
woman
.
<EOS>
As
regards
money
,
I
did
all
that
I
could
do
to
show
that
I
trusted
him
thoroughly
,
and
my
confidence
has
only
led
to
suspicion
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
know
whether
he
understands
that
everything
must
be
over
between
us
;
but
,
if
not
,
I
must
ask
you
to
tell
him
so
.
<EOS>
And
I
must
ask
you
to
explain
to
him
that
he
must
not
come
again
to
Queen
Anne
Street
.
<EOS>
If
he
does
,
nothing
shall
induce
me
to
see
him
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
also
that
the
money
that
he
wants
shall
assuredly
be
sent
to
him
as
soon
as
I
can
make
Mr.
Round
get
it
.
  
<EOS>
Dearest
Kate
,
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
feel
for
me
.
<EOS>
If
you
do
not
answer
me
I
shall
presume
that
you
think
yourself
bound
to
support
his
side
,
and
to
believe
me
to
have
been
wrong
.
<EOS>
It
will
make
me
very
unhappy
;
but
I
shall
remember
that
you
are
his
sister
,
and
I
shall
not
be
angry
with
you
.
  
<EOS>
Yours
always
affectionately
,
  
ALICE
VAVASOR
.
  
<EOS>
Kate
,
as
she
read
her
letter
through
,
at
first
quickly
,
and
then
very
slowly
,
came
by
degrees
almost
to
forget
that
death
was
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Her
mind
,
and
heart
,
and
brain
,
were
filled
with
thoughts
and
feelings
that
had
exclusive
reference
to
Alice
and
her
brother
,
and
at
last
she
found
herself
walking
the
room
with
quick
,
impetuous
steps
,
while
her
blood
was
hot
with
indignation
.
  
<EOS>
All
her
sympathies
in
the
matter
were
with
Alice
.
<EOS>
It
never
occurred
to
her
to
disbelieve
a
word
of
the
statement
made
to
her
,
or
to
suggest
to
herself
that
it
had
been
coloured
by
any
fears
or
exaggerations
on
the
part
of
her
correspondent
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
Alice
was
true
.
<EOS>
And
,
moreover
,
much
as
she
loved
her
brother
,
 
willing
as
she
had
been
and
would
still
be
to
risk
all
that
she
possessed
,
and
herself
also
,
on
his
behalf
,
 
she
knew
that
it
would
be
risking
and
not
trusting
.
<EOS>
She
loved
her
brother
,
such
love
having
come
to
her
by
nature
,
and
having
remained
with
her
from
of
old
;
and
in
his
intellect
she
still
believed
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
ceased
to
have
belief
in
his
conduct
.
<EOS>
She
feared
everything
that
he
might
do
,
and
lived
with
a
consciousness
that
though
she
was
willing
to
connect
all
her
own
fortunes
with
his
,
she
had
much
reason
to
expect
that
she
might
encounter
ruin
in
doing
so
.
<EOS>
Her
sin
had
been
in
this
,
 
that
she
had
been
anxious
to
subject
Alice
to
the
same
danger
,
 
that
she
had
intrigued
,
sometimes
very
meanly
,
to
bring
about
the
object
which
she
had
at
heart
,
 
that
she
had
used
all
her
craft
to
separate
Alice
from
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
may
be
alleged
in
her
excuse
that
she
had
thought
,
 
had
hoped
rather
than
thought
,
 
that
the
marriage
which
she
contemplated
would
change
much
in
her
brother
that
was
wrong
,
and
bring
him
into
a
mode
of
life
that
would
not
be
dangerous
.
<EOS>
Might
<EOS>
not
she
and
Alice
together
so
work
upon
him
,
that
he
should
cease
to
stand
ever
on
the
brink
of
some
half
-
seen
precipice
?
<EOS>
To
risk
herself
for
her
brother
was
noble
.
<EOS>
But
when
she
used
her
cunning
in
inducing
her
cousin
to
share
that
risk
she
was
ignoble
.
<EOS>
Of
this
she
had
herself
some
consciousness
,
as
she
walked
up
and
down
the
old
dining
-
room
at
midnight
,
holding
her
cousin
's
letter
in
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
Her
cheeks
became
tinged
with
shame
as
she
thought
of
the
scene
which
Alice
had
described
,
 
the
toy
thrown
beneath
the
grate
,
the
loud
curses
,
the
whispered
threats
,
which
had
been
more
terrible
than
curses
,
the
demand
for
money
,
made
with
something
worse
than
a
cut
-
throat
's
violence
,
the
strong
man
's
hand
placed
upon
the
woman
's
arm
in
anger
and
in
rage
,
those
eyes
glaring
,
and
the
gaping
horror
of
that
still
raw
cicatrice
,
as
he
pressed
his
face
close
to
that
of
his
victim
!
<EOS>
Not
for
a
moment
did
she
think
of
defending
him
.
<EOS>
She
accused
him
to
herself
vehemently
of
a
sin
over
and
above
those
sins
which
had
filled
Alice
with
dismay
.
<EOS>
He
had
demanded
money
from
the
girl
whom
he
intended
to
marry
!
<EOS>
According
to
Kate
's
idea
,
nothing
could
excuse
or
palliate
this
sin
.
<EOS>
Alice
had
accounted
it
as
nothing
,
 
had
expressed
her
opinion
that
the
demand
was
reasonable
;
 
even
now
,
after
the
ill
-
usage
to
which
she
had
been
subjected
,
she
had
declared
that
the
money
should
be
forthcoming
,
and
given
to
the
man
who
had
treated
her
so
shamefully
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
well
that
Alice
should
so
feel
and
so
act
,
but
it
behoved
Kate
to
feel
and
act
very
differently
.
<EOS>
She
would
tell
her
brother
,
even
in
the
house
of
death
,
should
he
come
there
,
that
his
conduct
was
mean
and
unmanly
.
<EOS>
Kate
was
no
coward
.
<EOS>
She
declared
to
herself
that
she
would
do
this
even
though
he
should
threaten
her
with
all
his
fury
,
 
though
he
should
glare
upon
her
with
all
the
horrors
of
his
countenance
.
  
<EOS>
One
o'clock
,
and
two
o'clock
,
still
found
her
in
the
dark
sombre
parlour
,
every
now
and
then
pacing
the
floor
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
The
fire
had
gone
out
,
and
,
though
it
was
now
the
middle
of
April
,
she
began
to
feel
the
cold
.
<EOS>
But
she
would
not
go
to
bed
before
she
had
written
a
line
to
Alice
.
<EOS>
To
her
brother
a
message
by
telegraph
would
of
course
be
sent
the
next
morning
;
as
also
would
she
send
a
message
to
her
aunt
.
<EOS>
But
to
Alice
she
would
write
,
though
it
might
be
but
a
line
.
<EOS>
Cold
as
she
was
,
she
found
her
pens
and
paper
,
and
wrote
her
letter
that
night
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
short
.
"
<EOS>
Dear
Alice
,
to
-
day
<EOS>
I
received
your
letter
,
and
to
-
day
our
poor
old
grandfather
died
.
<EOS>
Tell
my
uncle
John
,
with
my
love
,
of
his
father
's
death
.
<EOS>
You
will
understand
that
I
can
not
write
much
now
about
that
other
matter
;
but
I
must
tell
you
,
even
at
such
a
moment
as
this
,
that
there
shall
be
no
quarrel
between
you
and
me
.
<EOS>
There
shall
be
none
at
least
on
my
side
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
more
till
a
few
days
shall
have
passed
by
.
<EOS>
He
is
lying
up
-
stairs
,
a
corpse
.
<EOS>
I
have
telegraphed
to
George
,
and
I
suppose
he
will
come
down
.
<EOS>
I
think
my
aunt
Greenow
will
come
also
,
as
I
had
written
to
her
before
,
seeing
that
I
wanted
the
comfort
of
having
her
here
.
<EOS>
Uncle
John
will
of
course
come
or
not
as
he
thinks
fitting
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
whether
I
am
in
a
position
to
say
that
I
shall
be
glad
to
see
him
;
but
I
should
be
very
glad
.
<EOS>
He
and
you
will
know
that
I
can
,
as
yet
,
tell
you
nothing
further
.
<EOS>
The
lawyer
is
to
see
the
men
about
the
funeral
.
<EOS>
Nothing
,
I
suppose
,
will
be
done
till
George
comes
.
<EOS>
Your
own
cousin
and
friend
,
KATE
VAVASOR
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
then
she
added
a
line
below
,
"
My
own
Alice
,
 
<EOS>
If
you
will
let
me
,
you
shall
be
my
sister
,
and
be
the
nearest
to
me
and
the
dearest
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
,
when
she
received
this
,
was
at
the
first
moment
so
much
struck
,
and
indeed
surprised
,
by
the
tidings
of
her
grandfather
's
death
,
that
she
was
forced
,
in
spite
of
the
still
existing
violence
of
her
own
feelings
,
to
think
and
act
chiefly
with
reference
to
that
event
.
<EOS>
Her
father
had
not
then
left
his
room
.
<EOS>
She
therefore
went
to
him
,
and
handed
him
Kate
's
letter
.
<EOS>
"
Papa
,
"
she
said
,
"
there
is
news
from
Westmoreland
;
bad
news
,
which
you
hardly
expected
yet
.
"
<EOS>
"
My
father
is
dead
,
"
said
John
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Whereupon
Alice
gave
him
Kate
's
letter
,
that
he
might
read
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
I
shall
go
down
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
came
to
that
part
in
which
Kate
had
spoken
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Does
she
think
I
shall
not
follow
my
father
to
the
grave
,
because
I
dislike
her
brother
?
<EOS>
What
does
she
mean
by
saying
that
there
shall
be
no
quarrel
between
you
and
her
?
"
<EOS>
"
I
will
explain
that
at
another
time
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
asked
no
further
questions
then
,
but
declared
at
first
that
he
should
go
to
Westmoreland
on
the
following
day
.
<EOS>
Then
he
altered
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
by
the
mail
train
to
-
night
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
very
disagreeable
,
but
I
ought
to
be
there
when
the
will
is
opened
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
very
little
more
said
in
Queen

on

subject

,
 
till

Vavasor

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
He

as

.
<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>
After

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll

.
<EOS>
George
,

,

,

.
<EOS>

ca

<EOS>

,
 
<EOS>
that
's

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
George
Vavasor
had

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
They

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
John

disgusted
.
<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
George

.
<EOS>
"
We
sha

"

<EOS>

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
George

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
The
Will
.
 
<EOS>

.

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

?

<EOS>

<EOS>
Kate

<EOS>
As

.
<EOS>
She

;

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

"

"

"

<EOS>

.

,

"
Mr.
Gogram
did
,
 
Mr.
Gogram
and
I
together
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
the
deuce
made
you
meddle
with
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
merely
assisted
him
.
<EOS>
But
I
believe
he
was
quite
right
.
<EOS>
I
think
it
is
usual
in
such
cases
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Balderdash
!
<EOS>
You
are
thinking
of
some
old
trumpery
of
former
days
.
<EOS>
Till
I
know
to
the
contrary
,
everything
here
belongs
to
me
as
heir
-
at
-
law
,
and
I
do
not
mean
to
allow
of
any
interference
till
I
know
for
certain
that
my
rights
have
been
taken
from
me
.
<EOS>
And
I
wo
n't
accept
a
death
-
bed
will
.
<EOS>
What
a
man
chooses
to
write
when
his
fingers
will
hardly
hold
the
pen
,
goes
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
suppose
that
I
wish
to
interfere
with
your
rights
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
George
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
I
say
,
I
hope
not
.
<EOS>
But
I
know
there
are
those
who
would
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
my
uncle
John
would
not
interfere
with
me
if
he
could
?
<EOS>
By
 
---
!
if
he
does
,
he
shall
find
that
he
does
it
to
his
cost
.
<EOS>
I
'll
lead
him
such
a
life
through
the
courts
,
for
the
next
two
or
three
years
,
that
he
'll
wish
that
he
had
remained
in
Chancery
Lane
,
and
had
never
left
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
message
was
now
brought
up
by
the
nurse
,
saying
that
Mrs.
Greenow
and
Mr.
Vavasor
were
going
into
the
room
where
the
old
Squire
was
lying
,
"
<EOS>
Would
Miss
Kate
and
Mr.
George
go
with
them
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Vavasor
!
"
shouted
out
George
,
making
the
old
woman
jump
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
understand
his
meaning
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
sir
;
the
old
Squire
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
come
,
George
?
"
<EOS>
Kate
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
what
should
I
go
there
for
?
<EOS>
Why
should
I
pretend
an
interest
in
the
dead
body
of
a
man
whom
I
hated
and
who
hated
me
;
 
whose
very
last
act
,
as
far
as
I
know
as
yet
,
was
an
attempt
to
rob
me
?
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
go
and
see
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Kate
went
,
and
was
glad
of
an
opportunity
of
getting
away
from
her
brother
.
<EOS>
Every
hour
the
idea
was
becoming
stronger
in
her
mind
that
she
must
in
some
way
separate
herself
from
him
.
<EOS>
There
had
come
upon
him
of
late
a
hard
ferocity
which
made
him
unendurable
.
<EOS>
And
then
he
carried
to
such
a
pitch
that
hatred
,
as
he
called
it
,
of
conventional
rules
,
that
he
allowed
himself
to
be
controlled
by
none
of
the
ordinary
bonds
of
society
.
<EOS>
She
had
felt
this
heretofore
,
with
a
nervous
consciousness
that
she
was
doing
wrong
in
endeavouring
to
bring
about
a
marriage
between
him
and
Alice
;
but
this
demeanour
and
mode
of
talking
had
now
so
grown
upon
him
that
Kate
began
to
feel
herself
thankful
that
Alice
had
been
saved
.
  
<EOS>
Kate
went
up
with
her
uncle
and
aunt
,
and
saw
the
face
of
her
grandfather
for
the
last
time
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poor
,
dear
old
man
!
"
said
Mrs.
Greenow
,
as
the
easy
tears
ran
down
her
face
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember
,
John
,
how
he
used
to
scold
me
,
and
say
that
I
should
never
come
to
good
.
<EOS>
He
has
said
the
same
thing
to
you
,
Kate
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
has
been
very
kind
to
me
,
"
said
Kate
,
standing
at
the
foot
of
the
bed
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
one
of
those
whose
tears
stand
near
their
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
fine
old
gentleman
,
"
said
John
Vavasor
;
 
"
belonging
to
days
that
are
now
gone
by
,
but
by
no
means
the
less
of
a
gentleman
on
that
account
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
that
he
ever
did
an
unjust
or
ungenerous
act
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
Come
,
Kate
,
we
may
as
well
go
down
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
lingered
to
say
a
word
or
two
to
the
nurse
,
of
the
manner
in
which
Greenow
's
body
was
treated
when
Greenow
was
lying
dead
,
and
then
she
followed
her
brother
and
niece
.
  
<EOS>
George
did
not
go
into
Penrith
,
nor
did
he
see
Mr.
Gogram
till
that
worthy
attorney
came
out
to
Vavasor
Hall
on
the
morning
of
the
funeral
.
<EOS>
He
said
nothing
more
on
the
subject
,
nor
did
he
break
the
seals
on
the
old
upright
desk
that
stood
in
the
parlour
.
<EOS>
The
two
days
before
the
funeral
were
very
wretched
for
all
the
party
,
except
,
perhaps
,
for
Mrs.
Greenow
,
who
affected
not
to
understand
that
her
nephew
was
in
a
bad
humour
.
<EOS>
She
called
him
"
poor
George
,
"
and
treated
all
his
incivility
to
herself
as
though
it
were
the
effect
of
his
grief
.
<EOS>
She
asked
him
questions
about
Parliament
,
which
,
of
course
,
he
did
n't
answer
,
and
told
him
little
stories
about
poor
dear
Greenow
,
not
heeding
his
expressions
of
unmistakable
disgust
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
days
at
last
went
by
,
and
the
hour
of
the
funeral
came
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
doctor
and
Gogram
,
and
the
uncle
and
the
nephew
,
to
follow
the
corpse
,
 
the
nephew
taking
upon
himself
ostentatiously
<EOS>
the
foremost
place
,
as
though
he
could
thereby
help
to
maintain
his
pretensions
as
heir
.
<EOS>
The
clergyman
met
them
at
the
little
wicket
-
gate
of
the
churchyard
,
having
,
by
some
reasoning
,
which
we
hope
was
satisfactory
to
himself
,
overcome
a
resolution
which
he
at
first
formed
,
that
he
would
not
read
the
burial
service
over
an
unrepentant
sinner
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
read
it
,
having
mentioned
his
scruples
to
none
but
one
confidential
clerical
friend
in
the
same
diocese
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
told
that
you
have
got
my
grandfather
's
will
,
"
George
said
to
the
attorney
as
soon
as
he
saw
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
it
in
my
pocket
,
"
said
Mr.
Gogram
,
"
and
purpose
to
read
it
as
soon
as
we
return
from
church
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
usual
to
take
a
will
away
from
a
man
's
house
in
that
way
?
"
<EOS>
George
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
usual
,
"
said
the
attorney
;
"
and
in
this
case
it
was
done
at
the
express
desire
of
the
testator
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
is
the
common
practice
,
"
said
John
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
George
upon
this
turned
round
at
his
uncle
as
though
about
to
attack
him
,
but
he
restrained
himself
and
said
nothing
,
though
he
showed
his
teeth
.
  
<EOS>
The
funeral
was
very
plain
,
and
not
a
word
was
spoken
by
George
Vavasor
during
the
journey
there
and
back
.
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
asked
a
few
questions
of
the
doctor
as
to
the
last
weeks
of
his
father
's
life
;
and
it
was
incidentally
mentioned
,
both
by
the
doctor
and
by
the
attorney
,
that
the
old
Squire
's
intellect
had
remained
unimpaired
up
to
the
last
moment
that
he
had
been
seen
by
either
of
them
.
<EOS>
When
they
returned
to
the
hall
Mrs.
Greenow
met
them
with
an
invitation
to
lunch
.
<EOS>
They
all
went
to
the
dining
-
room
,
and
drank
each
a
glass
of
sherry
.
<EOS>
George
took
two
or
three
glasses
.
<EOS>
The
doctor
then
withdrew
,
and
drove
himself
back
to
Penrith
,
where
he
lived
.
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
go
into
the
other
room
now
?
"
said
the
attorney
.
  
<EOS>
The
three
gentlemen
then
rose
up
,
and
went
across
to
the
drawing
-
room
,
George
leading
the
way
.
<EOS>
The
attorney
followed
him
,
and
John
Vavasor
closed
the
door
behind
them
.
<EOS>
Had
any
observer
been
there
to
watch
them
he
might
have
seen
by
the
faces
of
the
two
latter
that
they
expected
an
unpleasant
meeting
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gogram
,
as
he
had
walked
across
the
hall
,
had
pulled
a
document
out
of
his
pocket
,
and
held
it
in
his
hand
as
he
took

.
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
stood
behind
one
of
the
chairs
which
had
been
placed
at
the
table
,
and
leaned
upon
it
,
looking
across
the
room
,
up
at
the

.
<EOS>
George
stood
on
the
rug
before
the
fire
,
with
his
hands
in
the
pockets
of
his
