,
and
his
coat
tails
over
his
arms
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
will
you
sit
down
?
"
said
Mr.
Gogram
.
  
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
immediately
sat
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
prefer
to
stand
here
,
"
said
George
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Gogram
then
opened
the
document
before
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Before
that
paper
is
read
,
"
said
George
,
"
I
think
it
right
to
say
a
few
words
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
it
contains
,
but
I
believe
it
to
have
been
executed
by
my
grandfather
only
an
hour
or
two
before
his
death
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
On
the
day
before
he
died
,
 
early
in
the
day
,
"
said
the
attorney
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
 
the
day
before
he
died
;
it
is
the
same
thing
,
 
while
he
was
dying
,
in
fact
.
<EOS>
He
never
got
out
of
bed
afterwards
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
not
in
bed
at
the
time
,
Mr.
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Not
that
it
would
have
mattered
if
he
had
been
.
<EOS>
And
he
came
down
to
dinner
on
that
day
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
understand
,
however
,
why
you
make
these
observations
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
'll
listen
to
me
you
will
understand
.
<EOS>
I
make
them
because
I
deny
my
grandfather
's
fitness
to
make
a
will
in
the
last
moments
of
his
existence
,
and
at
such
an
age
.
<EOS>
I
saw
him
a
few
weeks
ago
,
and
he
was
not
fit
to
be
trusted
with
the
management
of
property
then
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
think
this
is
the
time
,
George
,
to
put
forward
such
objections
,
"
said
the
uncle
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
is
,
"
said
George
.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
that
that
paper
purports
to
be
an
instrument
by
which
I
should
be
villanously
defrauded
if
it
were
allowed
to
be
held
as
good
.
<EOS>
Therefore
I
protest
against
it
now
,
and
shall
question
it
at
law
if
action
be
taken
on
it
.
<EOS>
You
can
read
it
now
,
if
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
I
shall
read
,
"
said
Mr.
Gogram
;
"
and
I
say
that
it
is
as
valid
a
will
as
ever
a
man
signed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
say
it
's
not
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
difference
between
us
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
will
was
read
amidst
sundry
interjections
and
expressions
of
anger
from
George
,
which
it
is
not
necessary
to
repeat
.
<EOS>
Nor
need
I
trouble
my
readers
with
the
will
at
length
.
<EOS>
It
began
by
expressing
the
testator
's
great
desire
that
his
property
might
descend
in
his
own
family
,
and
that
the
house
might
be
held
and
inhabited
by
some
one
bearing
the
name
of
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
He
then
declared
that
he
felt
himself
obliged
to
pass
over
his
natural
heir
,
believing
that
the
property
would
not
be
safe
in
his
hands
;
he
therefore
left
it
in
trust
to
his
son
John
Vavasor
,
whom
he
appointed
to
be
sole
executor
of
his
will
.
<EOS>
He
devised
it
to
George
's
eldest
son
,
 
should
George
ever
marry
and
have
a
son
,
 
as
soon
as
he
might
reach
the
age
of
twenty
-
five
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
the
property
should
remain
in
the
hands
of
John
Vavasor
for
his
use
and
benefit
,
with
a
lien
on
it
of
five
hundred
a
year
to
be
paid
annually
to
his
granddaughter
Kate
.
<EOS>
In
the
event
of
George
having
no
son
,
the
property
was
to
go
to
the
eldest
son
of
Kate
,
or
failing
that
to
the
eldest
son
of
his
other
granddaughter
who
might
take
the
name
of
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
All
his
personal
property
he
left
to
his
son
,
John
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
"
said
the
attorney
,
as
he
finished
his
reading
,
"
you
will
,
I
fear
,
get
very
little
by
that
latter
clause
.
<EOS>
The
estate
now
owes
nothing
;
but
I
doubt
whether
the
Squire
had
fifty
pounds
in
his
banker
's
hands
when
he
died
,
and
the
value
of
the
property
about
the
place
is
very
small
.
<EOS>
He
has
been
unwilling
to
spend
anything
during
the
last
ten
years
,
but
has
paid
off
every
shilling
that
the
property
owed
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
as
I
supposed
,
"
said
George
.
<EOS>
His
voice
was
very
unpleasant
,
and
so
was
the
fire
of
his
eyes
and
the
ghastly
rage
of
his
scarred
face
.
<EOS>
"
The
old
man
has
endeavoured
in
his
anger
to
rob
me
of
everything
because
I
would
not
obey
him
in
his
wickedness
when
I
was
here
with
him
a
short
while
before
he
died
.
<EOS>
Such
a
will
as
that
can
stand
nowhere
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
to
that
I
have
nothing
to
say
at
present
,
"
said
the
attorney
.
  
<EOS>
"

,

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
George

<EOS>

Such

.

"

d
 
---

<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

What

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Another

.

,

.

,

<EOS>

.

"

,

<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

Psha

<EOS>

,

,

now

;

,

.
<EOS>
Her

<EOS>
She

ill

<EOS>

"

"

D
 
---

.
<EOS>
D
 
---

"
George
!
<EOS>
George
!

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

.

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

!

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

D

---

woman
there
that
I
threatened
to
murder
you
.
<EOS>
Tell
the
judge
<EOS>
so
,
when
you
're
brought
into
court
to
swear
me
out
of
my
property
.
<EOS>
You
false
liar
!
"
<EOS>
Then
he
pushed
her
from
him
with
great
violence
,
so
that
she
fell
heavily
upon
the
stony
ground
.
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
stop
to
help
her
up
,
or
even
to
look
at
her
as
she
lay
,
but
walked
away
across
the
heath
,
neither
taking
the
track
on
towards
Haweswater
,
nor
returning
by
the
path
which
had
brought
them
thither
.
<EOS>
He
went
away
northwards
across
the
wild
fell
;
and
Kate
,
having
risen
up
and
seated
herself
on
a
small
cairn
of
stones
which
stood
there
,
watched
him
as
he
descended
the
slope
of
the
hill
till
he
was
out
of
sight
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
run
,
but
he
seemed
to
move
rapidly
,
and
he
never
once
turned
round
to
look
at
her
.
<EOS>
He
went
away
,
down
the
hill
northwards
,
and
presently
the
curving
of
the
ground
hid
him
from
her
view
.
  
<EOS>
When
she
first
seated
herself
her
thoughts
had
been
altogether
of
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
feared
no
personal
injury
,
even
when
she
had
asked
him
whether
he
would
murder
her
.
<EOS>
Her
blood
had
been
hot
within
her
veins
,
and
her
heart
had
been
full
of
defiance
.
<EOS>
Even
yet
she
feared
nothing
,
but
continued
to
think
of
him
and
his
misery
,
and
his
disgrace
.
<EOS>
That
he
was
gone
for
ever
,
utterly
and
irretrievably
ruined
,
thrown
out
,
as
it
were
,
beyond
the
pale
of
men
,
was
now
certain
to
her
.
<EOS>
And
this
was
the
brother
in
whom
she
had
believed
;
for
whom
she
had
not
only
been
willing
to
sacrifice
herself
,
but
for
whose
purposes
she
had
striven
to
sacrifice
her
cousin
!
<EOS>
What
would
he
do
now
?
<EOS>
As
he
passed
from
out
of
her
sight
down
the
hill
,
it
seemed
to
her
as
though
he
were
rushing
straight
into
some
hell
from
which
there
could
be
no
escape
.
  
<EOS>
She
knew
that
her
arm
had
been
hurt
in
the
fall
,
but
for
a
while
she
would
not
move
it
or
feel
it
,
being
resolved
to
take
no
account
of
what
might
have
happened
to
herself
.
<EOS>
But
when
he
had
been
gone
some
ten
minutes
,
she
rose
to
her
feet
,
and
finding
that
the
movement
pained
her
greatly
,
and
that
her
right
arm
was
powerless
,
she
put
up
her
left
hand
and
became
aware
that
the
bone
of
her
arm
was
broken
below
the
elbow
.
<EOS>
Her
first
thought
was
given
to
the
telling
him
of
this
,
or
the
not
telling
,
when
she
should
meet
him
below
at
the
house
.
<EOS>
How
should
she
mention
the
accident
to
him
?
<EOS>
Should
she
lie
,
and
say
that
she
had
fallen
as
she
came
down
the
hill
alone
?
<EOS>
Of
course
he
would
not
believe
her
,
but
still
some
such
excuse
as
that
might
make
the
matter
easier
for
them
all
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
occur
to
her
that
she
might
not
see
him
again
at
all
that
day
;
and
that
,
as
far
as
he
was
concerned
,
there
might
be
need
for
no
lie
.
  
<EOS>
She
started
off
to
walk
down
home
,
holding
her
right
arm
steadily
against
her
body
with
her
left
hand
.
<EOS>
Of
course
she
must
give
some
account
of
herself
when
she
got
to
the
house
;
but
it
was
of
the
account
to
be
given
to
him
that
she
thought
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
others
she
cared
little
for
them
.
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
;
my
arm
is
broken
;
and
you
had
better
send
for
a
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
That
would
be
sufficient
for
them
.
  
<EOS>
When
she
got
into
the
wood
the
path
was
very
dark
.
<EOS>
The
heavens
were
overcast
with
clouds
,
and
a
few
drops
began
to
fall
.
<EOS>
Then
the
rain
fell
faster
and
faster
,
and
before
she
had
gone
a
quarter
of
a
mile
down
the
beacon
hill
,
the
clouds
had
opened
themselves
,
and
the
shower
had
become
a
storm
of
water
.
<EOS>
Suffering
as
she
was
<EOS>
she
stood
up
for
a
few

under
a
large
tree
,
taking
the
excuse
of
the
rain
for
some
minutes
of
delay
,
that
she
might
make
up
her
mind
as
to
what
she
would
say
.
<EOS>
Then
it
occurred
to
her
that
she
might
possibly
meet
him
again
before
she
reached
the
house
;
and
,
as
she
thought
of
it
,
she
began
for
the
first

to
fear
him
.
<EOS>
Would
he
come
out
upon
her
from
the

and
really

?
<EOS>
Had
he
made
his
way
round
,
when
he

out

,
that

might
fall

?
<EOS>
As

idea
came
upon

,
she

to

,
but

that

from
the

the

.
<EOS>
Then
she
walked
on
through
the
hard

,
steadily

her

against

side
,
but
still
looking
every

through
the

on
the
side
from
which
George
might
be
expected

reach
her
.
<EOS>
But
no

on

.
<EOS>
Had

to

,

known

.
<EOS>
He
must
have
come
back
up
the
steep
hill
-
side

she

seen

.
<EOS>
No
;
 
he
had
gone
away
altogether
,
across
the
fells
towards
Bampton
,
and
was
at
this
moment
vainly
buttoning
his
coat
across

,
in
his
unconscious

to
keep

wet
.
<EOS>
The
Fury
was
driving
him
on
,
and
he
himself
was
not
aware
whither
he
was
driven
.
  
<EOS>
Dinner
at
the
Hall
had
been
ordered
at
five
,
the
old

;
or
rather
that
had
been
assumed
to

the
hour
for
dinner
without
any

.
<EOS>
It
was
just
five
when
Kate

.
<EOS>
This
she
opened
with
her
left

,
and
turning
at
once
into
the

-
room
,
found
her
uncle
and
her
aunt

before

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dinner
is
ready
,
"
said
John
Vavasor
;
"
where
is
George
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
wet
,
Kate
,
"
said
aunt
Greenow
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
very
wet
,
"
said
Kate
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
go
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
'll
come
with
me
,
aunt
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
with
you
,
 
of
course
I
will
.
"
<EOS>
Aunt
Greenow
had
seen
at
once
that
something
was
amiss
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
's
George
?
"
said
John
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Has
he
come
back
with
you
,
or
are
we
to
wait
for
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
Kate
seated
herself
in
her
chair
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
quite
know
where
he
is
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
her
aunt
had
hastened
up
to
her
side
just
in
time
to
catch
her
as
she
was
falling
from
her
chair
.
<EOS>
"
My
arm
,
"
said
Kate
,
very
gently
;
"
my
arm
!
"
<EOS>
Then
she
slipped
down
against
her
aunt
,
and
had

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
done
her
a
mischief
,
"
said
Mrs.
Greenow
,
looking

her

.
<EOS>
"
This
is
his
doing
.
"
  
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
stood
confounded
,
wishing
himself
back
in
Queen
Anne
Street
.
   
<EOS>
Showing
How
the
Wild
Beast
Got
Himself
Back
from
the
Mountains
.
 
<EOS>
About
eleven
o'clock
on
that
night
,
 
the
night
of
the
day
on
which
Kate
Vavasor
's
arm
had
been
broken
,
 
there
came
a
gentle
knock
at
Kate
's
bedroom
door
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
surprising
in
this
,
as
of
all
the
household
Kate
only
was
in
bed
.
<EOS>
Her
aunt
was
sitting
at
this
time
by
her
bedside
,
and
the
doctor
,
who
had
been
summoned
from
Penrith
and
who
had
set
her
broken
arm
,
was
still
in
the
house
,
talking

the
accident
with
John
Vavasor
in
the
dining
-
room
,
before
he
proceeded
back
on
his

home
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
will
do
very
well
,
"
said
the
doctor
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
only
a
simple
fracture
.
<EOS>
I
'll
see
her
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
odd
that
such
an
accident
should
come
from
a
fall
whilst
walking
?
"
asked
Mr.
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
The
doctor
shrugged
his
shoulders
.
<EOS>
"
One
never
can
say
how
anything
may
occur
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
a
young
woman
who
broke
the
os
femoris
by
just
kicking
her
cat
;
 
at
least
,
she
said

did
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Indeed
!
<EOS>
I
suppose
you
did
n't
take
any

to
inquire
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
much
.
<EOS>
My
business
was
with
the
injury
,
not
with
the
way
she
got
it
.
<EOS>
Somebody
did
make
inquiry
,
but
she
stuck
to
her
story
and
nothing
came
of
it
.
<EOS>
Good
night
,
Mr.
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Do
n't

her
with
questions
till
she
has
had
some
hours
"
sleep
,
at
any
rate
.
<EOS>
"
Then
the
doctor
went
,
and
John
Vavasor
was
left
alone
,
standing
with
his
back
to
the
dining
-
room
fire
.
  
<EOS>
There
had
been
so
much
trouble
and
confusion
in
the
house
since
Kate
had
fainted
,
almost
immediately
upon
her
reaching
home
,
that
Mr.
Vavasor
had
not
yet
had
time
to
make
up
his
mind
as
to
the
nature
of
the
accident
which
had
occurred
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
had
at
once
ascertained
that
the
bone
was
broken
,
and
the
doctor
had
been
sent
for
.
<EOS>
Luckily
he
had
been
found
at
home
,
and
had
reached
the
Hall
a
little
before
ten
o'clock
.
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
as
soon
as
Kate
recovered
her
senses
,
she
volunteered
her
account
of
what
had
occurred
.
  
<EOS>
Her
brother
had
quarrelled
with
her
about
the
will
,
she
said
,
and
had
left
her
abruptly
on
the
mountain
.
<EOS>
She
had
fallen
,
she
went
on
to
say
,
as
she
turned
from
him
,
and
had
at
once
found
that
she
had
hurt
herself
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
been
too
angry
with
him
to
let
him
know
it
;
and
,
indeed
,
she
had
not
known
the
extent
herself
till
he
had
passed
out
of
her
sight
.
<EOS>
This
was
her
story
;
and
there
was
nothing
in
it
that
was
false
by
the
letter
,
though
there
was
much
that
was
false
in
the
spirit
.
<EOS>
It
was
certainly
true
that
George
had
not
known
that
she
was
injured
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
that
she
had
asked
him
for
no
help
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
,
in
one
sense
,
that
she
had
fallen
,
and
it
was
true
that
she
had
not
herself
known
how
severe
had
been
the
injury
done
to
her
till
he
had
gone
beyond
the
reach
of
her
voice
.
<EOS>
But
she
repressed
all
mention
of
his
violence
,
and
when
she
was
pressed
as
to
the
nature
of
the
quarrel
,
she
declined
to
speak
further
on
that
matter
.
  
<EOS>
Neither
her
uncle
nor
her
aunt
believed
her
.
<EOS>
That
was
a
matter
of
course
,
and
she
knew
that
they
did
not
believe
her
.
<EOS>
George
's
absence
,
their
recent
experience
of
his
moods
,
and
the
violence
by
which
her
arm
must
have
been
broken
,
made
them
certain
that
Kate
had
more
to
tell
if
she
chose
to
tell
it
.
<EOS>
But
in
her
present
condition
they
could
not
question
her
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
did
ask
as
to
the
probability
of
her
nephew
's
return
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
only
tell
you
,
"
said
Kate
,
"
that
he
went
away
across
the
Fell
in
the
direction
of
Bampton
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
has
gone
on
to
Penrith
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
angry
with
us
all
;
and
as
the
house
is
not
his
own
,
he
has
probably
resolved
that
he
will
not
stay
another
night
under
the
roof
.
<EOS>
But
,
who
can
say
?
<EOS>
He
is
not
in
his
senses
when
he
is
angered
.
"
  
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
,
as
he
stood
alone
after
the
doctor
's
departure
,
endeavoured
to
ascertain
the
truth
by
thinking
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
"
that
the
doctor
suspects
that
there
has
been
violence
.
<EOS>
I
know
it
from
his
tone
,
and
I
can
see
it
in
his
eye
.
<EOS>
But
how
to
prove
it
?
<EOS>
and
would
there
be
good
in
proving
it
?
<EOS>
Poor
girl
!
<EOS>
Will
it
not
be
better
for
her
to
let
it
pass
as
though
we
believed
her
story
?
"
<EOS>
He
made
up
his
mind
that
it
would
be
better
.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
take
upon
himself
the
terrible
task
of
calling
this
insane
relation
to
account
for
an
act
which
he
could
not
prove
?
<EOS>
The
will
itself
,
without
that
trouble
,
would
give
him
trouble
enough
.
<EOS>
Then
he
began
to
long
that
he
was
back
at
his
club
,
and
to
think
that
the
signing
-
room
in
Chancery
Lane
was
not
so
bad
.
<EOS>
And
so
he
went
up
to
his
bed
,
calling
at
Kate
's
door
to
ask
after
the
patient
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
there
had
come
a
messenger
to
Mrs.
Greenow
,
who
had
stationed
herself
with
her
niece
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
girls
of
the
house
brought
up
a
scrap
of
paper
to
the
door
,
saying
that
a
boy
had
brought
it
over
with
a
cart
from
Shap
,
and
that
it
was
intended
for
Miss
Vavasor
,
and
it
was
she
who
knocked
at
the
sickroom
door
.
<EOS>
The
note
was
open
and
was
not
addressed
;
indeed
,
the
words
were
written
on
a
scrap
of
paper
that
was
crumpled
up
rather
than
folded
,
and
were
as
follows
:
<EOS>
"
Send
me
my
clothes
by
the
bearer
.
<EOS>
I
shall
not
return
to
the
house
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
took
it
in
to
Kate
,
and
then
went
away
to
see
her
nephew
's
things
duly
put
into
his
portmanteau
.
<EOS>
This
was
sent
away
in
the
cart
,
and
Mr.
Vavasor
,
as
he
went
up
-
stairs
,
was
told
what
had
been
done
.
  
<EOS>
Neither
on
that
night
or
on
the
following
day
did
Mrs.
Greenow
ask
any
further
questions
;
but
on
the
morning
after
that
,
when
the
doctor
had
left
them
with
a
good
account
of
the
broken
limb
,
her
curiosity
would
brook
no
further
delay
.
<EOS>
And
,
indeed
,
indignation
as
well
as
curiosity
urged
her
on
.
<EOS>
In
disposition
she
was
less
easy
,
and
,
perhaps
,
less
selfish
,
than
her
brother
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
the
case
that
that
man
had
ill
-
treated
his
sister
,
she
would
have
sacrificed
much
to
bring
him
to
punishment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Kate
,
"
she
said
,
when
the
doctor
was
gone
,
"
I
expect
that
you
will
tell
me
the
whole
truth
as
to
what
occurred
between
you
and
your
brother
when
you
had
this
accident
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
told
you
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
not
the
whole
truth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
the
truth
I
mean
to
tell
,
aunt
.
<EOS>
He
has
quarrelled
with
me
,
as
I
think
,
most
unnecessarily
,
but
you
do
n't
suppose
that
I
am
going
to
give
an
exact
account
of
the
quarrel
?
<EOS>
We
were
both
wrong
,
probably
,
and
so
let
there
be
an
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
he
violent
to
you
when
he
quarrelled
with
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
he
is
angry
he
is
always
violent
in
his
language
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
did
he
strike
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
aunt
,
do
n't
be
angry
with
me
if
I
say
that
I
wo
n't
be
cross
-
examined
.
<EOS>
I
would
rather
answer
no
more
questions
about
it
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
questioning
can
do
no
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
knew
her
niece
well
enough
to
be
aware
that
nothing
more
would
be
told
her
,
but
she
was
quite
sure
now
that
Kate
had
not
broken
her
arm
by
a
simple
fall
.
<EOS>
She
was
certain
that
the
injury
had
come
from
positive
violence
.
<EOS>
Had
it
not
been
so
,
Kate
would
not
have
contented
herself
with
refusing
to
answer
the
last
question
that
had
been
asked
,
but
would
also
have
repelled
the
charge
made
against
her
brother
with
indignation
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
it
your
own
way
,
"
said
Mrs.
Greenow
;
"
but
let
me
just
tell
you
this
,
that
your
brother
George
had
better
keep
out
of
my
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
probable
that
he
will
,
"
said
Kate
.
<EOS>
"
Especially
if
you
remain
here
to
nurse
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Kate
's
conduct
in
answering
all
the
questions
made
to
her
was
not
difficult
,
but
she
found
that
there
was
much
difficulty
in
planning
her
own
future
behaviour
towards
her
own
brother
.
<EOS>
Must
she
abandon
him
altogether
from
henceforth
;
divide
herself
from
him
,
as
it
were
;
have
perfectly
separate
interests
,
and
interests
that
were
indeed
hostile
?
<EOS>
and
must
she
see
him
ruined
and
overwhelmed
by
want
of
money
,
while
she
had
been
made
a
rich
woman
by
her
grandfather
's
will
?
<EOS>
It
will
be
remembered
that
her
life
had
hitherto
been
devoted
to
him
;
that
all
her
schemes
and
plans
had
had
his
success
as
their
object
;
that
she
had
taught
herself
to
consider
it
to
be
her
duty
to
sacrifice
everything
to
his
welfare
.
<EOS>
It
is
very
sad
to
abandon
the
only
object
of
a
life
!
<EOS>
It
is
very
hard
to
tear
out
from
one
's
heart
and
fling
away
from
it
the
only
love
that
one
has
cherished
!
<EOS>
What
was
she
to
say
to
Alice
about
all
this
 
to
Alice
whom
she
had
cheated
of
a
husband
worthy
of
her
,
that
she
might
allure
her
into
the
arms
of
one
so
utterly
unworthy
?
<EOS>
Luckily
for
Kate
,
her
accident
was
of
such
a
nature
that
any
writing
to
Alice
was
now
out
of
the
question
.
  
<EOS>
But
a
blow
!
<EOS>
What
woman
can
bear
a
blow
from
a
man
,
and
afterwards
return
to
him
with
love
?
<EOS>
A
wife
may
have
to
bear
it
and
to
return
.
<EOS>
And
she
may
return
with
that
sort
of
love
which
is
a
thing
of
custom
.
<EOS>
The
man
is
the
father
of
her
children
,
and
earns
the
bread
which
they
eat
and
which
she
eats
.
<EOS>
Habit
and
the
ways
of
the
world
require
that
she
should
be
careful
in
his
interests
,
and
that
she
should
live
with
him
in
what
amity
is
possible
to
them
.
<EOS>
But
as
for
love
,
 
all
that
we
mean
by
love
when
we
speak
of
it
and
write
of
it
,
 
a
blow
given
by
the
defender
to
the
defenceless
crushes
it
all
!
<EOS>
A
woman
may
forgive
deceit
,
treachery
,
desertion
,
 
even
the
preference
given
to
a
rival
.
<EOS>
She
may
forgive
them
and
forget
them
;
but
I
do
not
think
that
a
woman
can
forget
a
blow
.
<EOS>
And
as
for
forgiveness
,
 
it
is
not
the
blow
that
she
can
not
forgive
,
but
the
meanness
of
spirit
that
made
it
possible
.
  
<EOS>
Kate
,
as
she
thought
of
it
,
told
herself
that
everything
in
life
was
over
for
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
long
feared
her
brother
's
nature
,
 
had
feared
that
he
was
hard
and
heartless
;
but
still
there
had
been
some
hope
with
her
fear
.
<EOS>
Success
,
if
he
could
be
made
to
achieve
it
,
would
soften
him
,
and
then
all
might
be
right
.
<EOS>
But
now
all
was
wrong
,
and
she
knew
that
it
was
so
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
compelled
her
to
write
to
Alice
for
money
,
her
faith
in
him
had
almost
succumbed
.
<EOS>
That
had
been
very
mean
,
and
the
meanness
had
shocked
her
.
<EOS>
But
now
he
had
asked
her
to
perjure
herself
that
he
might
have
his
own
way
,
and
had
threatened
to
murder
her
,
and
had
raised
his
hand
against
her
because
she
had
refused
to
obey
him
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
accused
her
of
treachery
to
himself
,
 
had
accused
her
of
premeditated
deceit
in
obtaining
this
property
for
herself
!
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
does
not
believe
it
,
"
said
Kate
to
herself
.
"
<EOS>
He
said
that
because
he
thought
it
would
vex
me
;
but
I
know
he
does
not
think
it
.
"
<EOS>
Kate
had
watched
her
brother
longing
for
money
all
his
life
,
 
had
thoroughly
understood
the
intensity
of
his
wish
for
it
,
 
the
agony
of
his
desire
.
<EOS>
But
so
far
removed
was
she
from
any
such
longing
on
her
own
account
,
that
she
could
not
believe
that
her
brother
would
in
his
heart
accuse
her
of
it
.
<EOS>
How
often
had
she
offered
to
give
him
,
on
the
instant
,
<EOS>
every
shilling
that
she
had
in
the
world
!
<EOS>
At
this
moment
she
resolved
,
in
her
mind
,
that
she
never

to
see

;
but

,

,
she
would
have
made
over
to

,
without
any

,
all
her

in
the
Vavasor

.
  
<EOS>
But
any
such
making
over
was
impossible
.
<EOS>
John
Vavasor
remained
in
Westmoreland
for
a
week
,
and
during
that
time
many
discussions
were
,
of
course
,
held
about
the
property
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Round
came
down
from
London
,
and
met
Mr.
Gogram
at
Penrith
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
validity
of
the
will
Mr.
Round
said
that
there
was
no
shadow
of
a
doubt
.
<EOS>
So
an
agent
was
appointed
for
receiving
the
rents
,
and
it
was
agreed
that
the
old
Hall
should
be
let
in
six
months
from
that

.
<EOS>
In

Kate
was
to
remain
there
till
her
arm
should
become
strong
,
and
she
could
make
her
plans
for
the
future
.
<EOS>
Aunt
Greenow
promised
to
remain
at
the
Hall
for
the
present
,
and
offered
,
indeed
,
indefinite
services
for
the
future
,
as
though
she
were
quite
forgetful
of
Captain
Bellfield
.
<EOS>
Of
Mr.
Cheesacre
she
was
not
forgetful
,
for
she
still
continued
to
speak
of
that
gentleman
to
Kate
,
as
though
he
were
Kate
's

.
<EOS>
But
she
did
not
now
press
upon
her
niece
the

of
Mr.
Cheesacre
's
hand
as
an

.
<EOS>
Kate
was
mistress
of
a
considerable
fortune
,
and
though
such
a
marriage
might
be
comfortable
,
it
was
no
longer
necessary
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
called
him
poor
Cheesacre
,
pointing
out
how
easily
he
might
be
managed
,
and
how
indubitable
were
his
possessions
;
but
she
no
longer
spoke
of
Kate
's
chances
in
the
marriage
market
as
desperate
,
even
though
she
should
decline
the
Cheesacre
alliance
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
young
woman
,
with
six
hundred
a
year
,
my
dear
,
may
do
pretty
nearly
what
she
pleases
,
"
said
aunt
Greenow
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
better
than
having
ten
years
"
grace
given
you
.
"
  
"
And
will
last
longer
,
certainly
,
"
said
Kate
.
  
<EOS>
Kate
's
desire
was
that
Alice
should
come
down
to
her
for
a
while
in
Westmoreland
,
before
the
six
months
were
over
,
and
this
desire
she
mentioned
to
her
uncle
.
<EOS>
He
promised
to
carry
the
message
up
to
Alice
,
but
could
not
be
got
to
say
more
than
that
upon
the
subject
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Vavasor
went
away
,
leaving
the
aunt
and
niece
together
at
the
Hall
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
on
earth
shall
we
do
if
that
wild
beast
shows
himself
suddenly
among
us
women
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Greenow
of
her
brother
.
  
<EOS>
The
brother
could
only
say
,
"
that
he
hoped
the
wild
beast
would
keep
his
distance
.
"
  
<EOS>
And
the
wild
beast
did
keep
his
distance
,
at
any
rate
as
long
as
Mrs.
Greenow
remained
at
the
Hall
.
<EOS>
We
will
now
go
back
to
the
wild
beast
,
and
tell
how
he
walked
across
the
mountains
,
in
the
rain
,
to
Bampton
,
a
little
village
at
the
foot
of
Haweswater
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
remembered
that
after
he
had
struck
his
sister
,
he
turned
away
from
her
,
and
walked
with
quick
steps
down
the
mountain
-
side
,
never
turning
back
to
look
at
her
.
<EOS>
He
had
found
himself
to
be
without
any
power
of
persuasion
over
her
,
as
regarded
her
evidence
to
be
given
,
if
the
will
were
questioned
.
<EOS>
The
more
he
threatened
her
the
steadier
she
had
been
in
asserting
her
belief
in
her
grandfather
's
capacity
.
<EOS>
She
had
looked
into
his
eye
and
defied
him
,
and
he
had
felt
himself
to
be
worsted
.
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
do
?
<EOS>
In
truth
,
there
was
nothing
for
him
to
do
.
<EOS>
He
had
told
her
that
he
would
murder
her
;
and
in
the
state
of
mind
to
which
his
fury
had
driven
him
,
murder
had
suggested
itself
to
him
as
a
resource
to
which
he
might
apply
himself
.
<EOS>
But
what
could
he
gain
by
murdering
her
,
 
or
,
at
any
rate
,
by
murdering
her
then
,
out
on
the
mountain
-
side
?
<EOS>
Nothing
but
a
hanging
!
<EOS>
There
would
be
no
gratification
even
to
his
revenge
.
<EOS>
If
,
indeed
,
he
had
murdered
that
old
man
,
who
was
now
,
unfortunately
,
gone
beyond
the
reach
of
murder
;
 
if
he
could
have
poisoned
the
old
man
's
cup
before
that
last
will
had
been
made
 
there
might
have
been
something
in
such
a
deed
!
<EOS>
But
he
had
merely
thought
of
it
,
letting
"
I
dare
not
wait
upon
I
would
"
 
as
he
now
told
himself
,
with
much
self
-
reproach
.
<EOS>
Nothing
was
to
be
got
by
killing
his
sister
.
<EOS>
So
he
restrained
himself
in
his
passion
,
and
walked
away
from
her
,
solitary
,
down
the
mountain
.
  
<EOS>
The
rain
soon
came
on
,
and
found
him
exposed
on
the
hill
-
side
.
<EOS>
He
thought
little
about
it
,
but
buttoned
his
coat
,
as
I
have
said
before
,
and
strode
on
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
storm
of
rain
,
so
that
he
was
forced
to
hold
his
head
to
one
side
,
as
it
hit
him
from
the
north
.
<EOS>
But
with
his
hand
to
his
hat
,
and
his
head
bent
against
the
wind
,
he
went
on
till
he
had
reached
the
valley
at
the
foot
,
and
found
that
the
track
by
which
he
had
been
led
thither
had
become
a
road
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
known
the
mountains
round
the
Hall
as
Kate
had
known
them
,
and
was
not
aware
whither
he
was
going
.
<EOS>
On
one
thing
only
had
he
made
up
his
mind
since
he
had
left
his
sister
,
and
that
was
that
he
would
not
return
to
the
house
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
could
do
nothing
there
to
serve
his
purpose
;
his
threats
would
be
vain
impotence
;
he
had
no
longer
any
friend
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
He
could
hardly
tell
himself
what
line
of
conduct
he
would
pursue
,
but
he
thought
that
he
would
hurry
back
to
London
,
and
grasp
at
whatever
money
he
could
get
from
Alice
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
,
at
this
moment
,
a
Member
of
Parliament
;
and
as
the
rain
drenched
him
through
and
through
,
he
endeavoured
to
get
consolation
from
the
remembrance
of
that
fact
in
his
favour
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
got
near
the
village
he
overtook
a
shepherd
boy
coming
down
from
the
hills
,
and
learned
his
whereabouts
from
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Baampton
,
"
said
the
boy
,
with
an
accent
that
was
almost
Scotch
,
when
he
was
asked
the
name
of
the
place
.
<EOS>
When
Vavasor
further
asked
whether
a
gig
were
kept
there
,
the
boy
simply
stared
at
him
,
not
knowing
a
gig
by
that
name
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
however
,
he
was
made
to
understand
the
nature
of
his
companion
's
want
,
and
expressed
his
belief
that
"
John
Applethwaite
,
up
at
the
Craigs
yon
,
had
got
a
mickle
cart
.
"
<EOS>
But
the
Craigs
was
a
farm
-
house
,
which
now
came
in
view
about
a
mile
off
,
up
across
the
valley
;
and
Vavasor
,
hoping
that
he
might
still
find
a
speedier
conveyance
than
John
Applethwaite
's
mickle
cart
,
went
on
to
the
public
-
house
in
the
village
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
truth
,
neither
there
,
nor
yet
from
John
Applethwaite
,
to
whom
at
last
an
application
was
sent
,
could
he
get
any
vehicle
;
and
between
six
and
seven
he
started
off
again
,
through
the
rain
,
to
make
his
weary
way
on
foot
to
Shap
.
<EOS>
The
distance
was
about
five
miles
,
and
the
little
byways
,
lying
between
walls
,
were
sticky
,
and
almost
glutinous
with
light
-
coloured
,
chalky
mud
.
<EOS>
Before
he
started
he
took
a
glass
of
hot
rum
-
and
-
water
,
but
the
effect
of
that
soon
passed
away
from
him
,
and
then
he
became
colder
and
weaker
than
he
had
been
before
.
  
<EOS>
Wearily
and
wretchedly
he
plodded
on
.
<EOS>
A
man
may
be
very
weary
in
such
a
walk
as
that
,
and
yet
be
by
no
means
wretched
.
<EOS>
Tired
,
hungry
,
cold
,
wet
,
and
nearly
penniless
,
I
have
sat
me
down
and
slept
among
those
mountain
tracks
,
 
have
slept
because
nature
refused
to
allow
longer
wakefulness
.
<EOS>
But
my
heart
has
been
as
light
as
my
purse
,
and
there
has
been
something
in
the
air
of
the
hills
that
made
me
buoyant
and
happy
in
the
midst
of
my
weariness
.
<EOS>
But
George
Vavasor
was
wretched
as
well
as
weary
,
and
every
step
that
he
took
,
plodding
through
the
mud
,
was
a
new
misfortune
to
him
.
<EOS>
What
are
five
miles
of
a
walk
to
a
young
man
,
even
though
the
rain
be
falling
and
the
ways
be
dirty
?
<EOS>
what
,
though
they
may
come
after
some
other
ten
that
he
has
already
traversed
on
his
feet
?
<EOS>
His
sister
Kate
would
have
thought
nothing
of
the
distance
.
<EOS>
But
George
stopped
on
his
way
from
time
to
time
,
leaning
on
the
loose
walls
,
and
cursing
the
misfortune
that
had
brought
him
to
such
a
pass
.
<EOS>
He
cursed
his
grandfather
,
his
uncle
,
his
sister
,
his
cousin
,
and
himself
.
<EOS>
He
cursed
the
place
in
which
his
forefathers
had
lived
,
and
he
cursed
the
whole
county
.
<EOS>
He
cursed
the
rain
,
and
the
wind
,
and
his
town
-
made
boots
,
which
would
not
keep
out
the
wet
slush
.
<EOS>
He
cursed
the
light
as
it
faded
,
and
the
darkness
as
it
came
.
<EOS>
Over
and
over
again
he
cursed
the
will
that
had
robbed
him
,
and
the
attorney
that
had
made
it
.
<EOS>
He
cursed
the
mother
that
had
borne
him
and
the
father
that
had
left
him
poor
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
Scruby
,
and
cursed
him
,
thinking
how
that
money
would
be
again
required
of
him
by
that
stern
agent
.
<EOS>
He
cursed
the
House
of
Commons
,
which
had
cost
him
so
much
,
and
the
greedy
electors
who
would
not
send
him
there
without
his
paying
for
it
.
<EOS>
He
cursed
John
Grey
,
as
he
thought
of
those
two
thousand
pounds
,
with
double
curses
.
<EOS>
He
cursed
this
world
,
and
all
worlds
beyond
;
and
thus
,
cursing
everything
,
he
made
his
way
at
last
up
to
the
inn
at
Shap
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
nearly
nine
when
he
got
there
.
<EOS>
He
had
wasted
over
an
hour
at
Bampton
in
his
endeavour
to
get
John
Applethwaite
's
cart
to
carry
him
on
,
and
he
had
been
two
hours
on
his
walk
from
Bampton
to
Shap
,
 
two
hours
amidst
his
cursing
.
<EOS>
He
ordered
supper
and
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
and
,
as
we
know
,
sent
off
a
Mercury
for
his
clothes
.
<EOS>
But
the
Mercuries
of
Westmoreland
do
not
move
on
quick
wings
,
and
it
was
past
midnight
before
he
got
his
possessions
.
<EOS>
During
all
this
time
he
had
,
by
no
means
,
ceased
from
cursing
,
but
continued
it
over
his
broiled
ham
and
while
he
swallowed
his
brandy
-
and
-
water
.
<EOS>
He
swore
aloud
,
so
that
the
red
-
armed
servant
at
the
inn
could
not
but
hear
him
,
that
those
thieves
at
the
Hall
intended
to
rob
him
of
his
clothes
;
 
that
they
would
not
send
him
his
property
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
restrain
himself
,
though
he
knew
that
every
word
he
uttered
would
injure
his
cause
,
as
regarded
the
property
in
Westmoreland
,
if
ever
he
could
make
a
cause
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
had
been
mad
to
strike
his
sister
,
and
cursed
himself
for
his
madness
.
<EOS>
Yet
he
could
not
restrain
himself
.
<EOS>
He
told
himself
that
the
battle
for
him
was
over
,
and
he
thought
of
poison
for
himself
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
poison
,
and
a
pistol
,
 
of
the
pistols
he
had
ever
loaded
at
home
,
each
with
six
shots
,
good
for
a
life
apiece
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
an
express
train
,
rushing
along
at
its
full
career
,
and
of
the
instant
annihilation
which
it
would
produce
.
<EOS>
But
if
that
was
to
be
the
end
of
him
,
he
would
not
go
alone
.
<EOS>
No
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
why
should
he
go
alone
,
leaving
those
pistols
ready
loaded
in
his
desk
?
<EOS>
Among
them
they
had
brought
him
to
ruin
and
to
death
.
<EOS>
Was
he
a
man
to
pardon
his
enemies
when
it
was
within
his
power
to
take
them
with
him
,
down
,
down
,
down
 
?
<EOS>
What
were
the
last
words
upon
his
impious
lips
,
as
with
bloodshot

,
half

,
and

Fury
,
he
took

off
to
the
bed

for
him
,
cursing
aloud
the
poor
red
-
haired
girl
as
he
went
,
I
may
not
utter
here
.
   
<EOS>
The
Pallisers
at
Breakfast
.
 
<EOS>
Gentle
reader
,
do
you
remember
Lady
Monk
's
party
,
and
how
it
ended
,
 
how
it
ended
,
at
least
as
regards
those
special
guests
with
whom
we
are
concerned
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
went
away
early
,
Mrs.
Marsham
followed
him
to
his
house
in
Park
Lane
,
caught
him
at
home
,
and
told
her
tale
.
<EOS>
He
returned
to
his
wife
,
found
her
sitting
with
Burgo
in
the
dining
-
room
,
under
the
Argus
eyes
of
the
constant
Bott
,
and
bore
her
away
home
.
<EOS>
Burgo
disappeared
utterly
from
the
scene
,
and
Mr.
Bott
,
complaining
inwardly
that
virtue
was
too
frequently
allowed
to
be
its
own
reward
,
comforted
himself
with
champagne
,
and
then
walked
off
to
his
lodgings
.
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
,
when
Mr.
Palliser
made
his
way
into
her
room
up
-
stairs
,
seeking
his
wife
's
scarf
,
 
which
little
incident
,
also
,
the
reader
may
perhaps
remember
,
 
saw
that
the
game
was
up
,
and
thought
with
regret
of
the
loss
of
her
two
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
ending
of
Lady
Monk
's
party
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
on
her
journey
home
in
the
carriage
with
her
husband
,
had
openly
suggested
that
Mrs.
Marsham
had
gone
to
Park
Lane
to
tell
of
her
doings
with
Burgo
,
and
had
declared
her
resolution
never
again
to
see
either
that
lady
or
Mr.
Bott
in
her
own
house
.
<EOS>
This
<EOS>
she
said
with
more
of
defiance
in
her
tone
than
Mr.
Palliser
had
ever
hitherto
heard
.
<EOS>
He
was
by
nature
less
ready
than
her
,
and
knowing
his
own
deficiency
in
that
respect
,
abstained
from
all
answer
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
during
that
drive
home
very
few
further
words
were
spoken
between
them
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
breakfast
with
you
to
-
morrow
,
"
he
said
to
her
,
as
she
prepared
to
go
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
work
still
to
do
to
-
night
,
and
I
will
not
disturb
you
by
coming
to
your
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
want
me
to
be
very
early
?
"
said
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
he
,
with
more
of
anger
in
his
voice
than
he
had
yet
shown
.
<EOS>
"
What
hour
will
suit
you
?
<EOS>
I
must
say
something
of
what
has
occurred
to
-
night
before
I
leave
you
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
you
can
have
got
to
say
about
to
-
night
,
but
I
'll
be
down
by
half
-
past
eleven
,
if
that
will
do
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
said
that
he
would
make
it
do
,
and
then
they
parted
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
had
played
her
part
very
well
before
her
husband
.
<EOS>
She
had
declined
to
be
frightened
by
him
;
had
been
the
first
to
mention
Burgo
's
name
,
and
had
done
so
with
no
tremor
in
her
voice
,
and
had
boldly
declared
her
irreconcilable
enmity
to
the
male
and
female
duennas
who
had
dared
to
take
her
in
charge
.
<EOS>
While
she
was
in
the
carriage
with
her
husband
she
felt
some
triumph
in
her
own
strength
;
and
as
she
wished
him
good
night
on
the
staircase
,
and
slowly
walked
up
to
her
room
,
without
having
once
lowered
her
eyes
before
his
,
something
of
this
consciousness
of
triumph
still
supported
her
.
<EOS>
And
even
while
her
maid
remained
with
her
she
held
herself
up
,
as
it
were
,
inwardly
,
telling
herself
that
she
would
not
yield
,
 
that
she
would
not
be
cowed
either
by
her
husband
or
by
his
spies
.
<EOS>
But
when
she
was
left
alone
all
her
triumph
departed
from
her
.
  
<EOS>
She
bade
her
maid
go
while
she
was
still
sitting
in
her
dressing
-
gown
;
and
when
the
girl
was
gone
<EOS>
she
got
close
over
the
fire
,
sitting
with
her
slippers
on
the
fender
,
with
her
elbows
on
her
knees
,
and
her
face
resting
on
her
hands
.
<EOS>
In
this
position
she
remained
for
an
hour
,
with
her
eyes
fixed
on
the
altering
shapes
of
the
hot
coals
.
<EOS>
During
this
hour
her
spirit
was
by
no
means
defiant
,
and
her
thoughts
of
herself
anything
but
triumphant
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
and
Mrs.
Marsham
she
had
forgotten
altogether
.
<EOS>
After
all
,
they
were
but
buzzing
flies
,
who
annoyed
her
by
their
presence
.
<EOS>
Should
she
choose
to
leave
her
husband
,
they
could
not
prevent
her
leaving
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
of
her
husband
and
of
Burgo
that
she
was
thinking
,
 
weighing
them
one
against
the
other
,
and
connecting
her
own
existence
with
theirs
,
not
as
expecting
joy
or
the
comfort
of
love
from
either
of
them
,
but
with
an
assured
conviction
that
on
either
side
there
must
be
misery
for
her
.
<EOS>
But
of
that
shame
before
all
the
world
which
must
be
hers
for
ever
,
should
she
break
her
vows
and
consent
to
live
with
a
man
who
was
not
her
husband
,
she
thought
hardly
at
all
.
<EOS>
That
which
in
the
estimation
of
Alice
was
everything
,
to
her
,
at
this
moment
,
was
almost
nothing
.
<EOS>
For
herself
,
she
had
been
sacrificed
;
and
,
 
as
she
told
herself
with
bitter
denunciations
against
herself
,
 
had
been
sacrificed
through
her
own
weakness
.
<EOS>
But
that
was
done
.
<EOS>
Whatever
way
she
might
go
,
she
was
lost
.
<EOS>
They
had
married
her
to
a
man
who
cared
nothing
for
a
wife
,
nothing
for
any
woman
,
 
so
at
least
she
declared
to
herself
,
 
but
who
had
wanted
a
wife
that
he
might
have
an
heir
.
<EOS>
Had
it
been
given
to
her
to
have
a
child
<EOS>
,
she
thought
that
she
might
have
been
happy
,
 
sufficiently
happy
in
sharing
her
husband
's
joy
in
that
respect
.
<EOS>
But
everything
had
gone
against
her
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
in
her
home
to
give
her
comfort
.
"
<EOS>
He
looks
at
me
every
time
he
sees
me
as
the
cause
of
his
misfortune
,
"
she
said
to
herself
.
<EOS>
Of
her
husband
's
rank
,
of
the
future
possession
of
his
title
and
his
estates
,
she
thought
much
.
<EOS>
But
of
her
own
wealth
she
thought
nothing
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
occur
to
her
that
she
had
given
him
enough
in
that
respect
to
make
his
marriage
with
her
a
comfort
to
him
.
<EOS>
She
took
it
for
granted
that
that
marriage
was
now
one
distasteful
to
him
,
as
it
was
to
herself
,
and
that
he
would
eventually
be
the
gainer
if
she
should
so
conduct
herself
that
her
marriage
might
be
dissolved
.
  
<EOS>
As
to
Burgo
,
I
doubt
whether
she
deceived
herself
much
as
to
his
character
.
<EOS>
She
knew
well
enough
that
he
was
a
man
infinitely
less
worthy
than
her
husband
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
he
was
a
spendthrift
,
idle
,
given
to
bad
courses
,
 
that
he
drank
,
that
he
gambled
,
that
he
lived
the
life
of
the
loosest
man
about
the
town
.
<EOS>
She
knew
also
that
whatever
chance
she
might
have
had
to
redeem
him
,
had
she
married
him
honestly
before
all
the
world
,
there
could
be
no
such
chance
if
she
went
to
him
as
his
mistress
,
abandoning
her
husband
and
all
her
duties
,
and
making
herself
vile
in
the
eyes
of
all
women
.
<EOS>
Burgo
Fitzgerald
would
not
be
influenced
for
good
by
such
a
woman
as
she
would
then
be
.
<EOS>
She
knew
much
of
the
world
and
its
ways
,
and
told
herself
no
lies
about
this
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
I
have
said
before
,
she
did
not
count
herself
for
much
.
<EOS>
What
though
she
were
ruined
?
<EOS>
What
though
Burgo
were
false
,
mean
,
and
untrustworthy
?
<EOS>
She
loved
him
,
and
he
was
the
only
man
she
ever
had
loved
!
<EOS>
Lower
and
lower
<EOS>
she
crouched
before
the
fire
;
and
then
,
when
the
coals
were
no
longer
red
,
and
the
shapes
altered
themselves
no
more
,
she
crept
into
bed
.
<EOS>
As
to
what
she
should
say
to
her
husband
on
the
following
morning
,
 
she
had
not
yet
begun
to
think
of
that
.
  
<EOS>
Exactly
at
half
-
past
eleven
she
entered
the
little
breakfast
parlour
which
looked
out
over
the
park
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
prettiest
room
in
the
house
,
and
now
,
at
this
springtide
,
when
the
town
trees
were
putting
out
their
earliest
greens
,
and
were
fresh
and
bright
almost
as
country
trees
,
it
might
be
hard
to
find
a
prettier
chamber
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
there
already
,
sitting
with
the
morning
paper
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
He
rose
when
she
entered
,
and
,
coming
up
to
her
,
just
touched
her
with
his
lips
.
<EOS>
She
put
her
cheek
up
to
him
,
and
then
took
her
place
at
the
breakfast
table
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
any
headache
this
morning
?
"
he
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
Then
he
took
his
tea
and
his
toast
,
spoke
some
word
to
her
about
the
fineness
of
the
weather
,
told
her
some
scraps
of
news
,
and
soon
returned
to
the
absorbing
interest
of
a
speech
made
by
the
leader
of
the
Opposition
in
the
House
of
Lords
.
<EOS>
The
speech
was
very
interesting
to
Mr.
Palliser
,
because
in
it
the
noble
lord
alluded
to
a
break
-
up
in
the
present
Cabinet
,
as
to
which
the
rumours
were
,
he
said
,
so
rife
through
the
country
as
to
have
destroyed
all
that
feeling
of
security
in
the
existing
Government
which
the
country
so
much
valued
and
desired
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
as
yet
heard
no
official
tidings
of
such
a
rupture
;
but
if
such
rupture
were
to
take
place
,
it
must
be
in
his
favour
.
<EOS>
He
felt
himself
at
this
moment
to
be
full
of
politics
,
 
to
be
near
the
object
of
his
ambition
,
to
have
affairs
upon
his
hands
which
required
all
his
attention
.
<EOS>
Was
it
absolutely
incumbent
on
him
to
refer
again
to
the
incidents
of
last
night
?
<EOS>
The
doing
so
would
be
odious
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
remembrance
of
the
task
now
immediately
before
him
destroyed
all
his
political
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
believe
that
his
wife
was
in
any
serious
danger
.
<EOS>
Might
it
not
yet
be
possible
for
him
to
escape
from
the
annoyance
,
and
to
wash
his
mind
clean
of
all
suspicion
?
<EOS>
He
was
not
jealous
;
he
was
indeed
incapable
of
jealousy
.
<EOS>
He
knew
what
it
would
be
to
be
dishonoured
,
and
he
knew
that
under
certain
circumstances
the
world
would
expect
him
to
exert
himself
in
a
certain
way
.
<EOS>
But
the
thing
that
he
had
now
to
do
was
a
great
trouble
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
would
rather
have
to
address
the
House
of
Commons
with
ten
columns
of
figures
than
utter
a
word
of
remonstrance
to
his
wife
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
defied
him
,
 
defied
him
by
saying
that
she
would
see
his
friends
no
more
;
and
it
was
the
remembrance
of
this
,
as
he
sat
behind
his
newspaper
,
that
made
him
ultimately
feel
that
he
could
not
pass
in
silence
over
what
had
been
done
.
  
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
he
went
on
reading
,
or
pretending
to
read
,
as
long
as
the
continuance
of
the
breakfast
made
it
certain
that
his
wife
would
remain
with
him
.
<EOS>
Every
now
<EOS>
and
then
he
said
some
word
to
her
of
what
he
was
reading
,
endeavouring
to
use
the
tone
of
voice
that
was
customary
to
him
in
his
domestic
teachings
of
politics
.
<EOS>
But
through
it
all
there
was
a
certain
hesitation
,
 
there
were
the
sure
signs
of
an
attempt
being
made
,
of
which
he
was
himself
conscious
,
and
which
she
understood
with
the
most
perfect
accuracy
.
<EOS>
He
was
deferring
the
evil
moment
,
and
vainly
endeavouring
to
make
himself
believe
that
he
was
comfortably
employed
the
while
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
newspaper
,
and
made
no
endeavour
to
deceive
herself
.
<EOS>
She
,
therefore
,
was
the
first
to
begin
the
conversation
.
  
<EOS>
"
Plantagenet
,
"
she
said
,
"
you
told
me
last
night
,
as
I
was
going
to
bed
,
that
you
had
something
to
say
about
Lady
Monk
's
party
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
put
down
the
newspaper
slowly
,
and
turned
towards
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
After
what
happened
,
I
believe
that
I
must
say
something
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
think
anything
,
pray
say
it
,
"
said
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
always
easy
for
a
man
to
show
what
he
thinks
by
what
he
says
,
"
he
replied
.
<EOS>
"
My
fear
is
that
you
should
suppose
me
to
think
more
than
I
do
.
<EOS>
And
it
was
for
that
reason
that
I
determined
to
sleep
on
it
before
I
spoke
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
anybody
is
angry
with
me
<EOS>
I
'd
much
<EOS>
rather
they
should
have
it
out
with
me
while
their
anger
is
hot
.
<EOS>
I
hate
cold
anger
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not
angry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
husbands
always
say
when
they
're
going
to
scold
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not
going
to
scold
.
<EOS>
I
am
only
going
to
advise
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'd
sooner
be
scolded
.
<EOS>
Advice
is
to
anger
just
what
cold
anger
is
to
hot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
dear
Glencora
,
surely
if
I
find
it
necessary
to
speak
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
stop
you
,
Plantagenet
.
<EOS>
Pray
,
go
on
.
<EOS>
Only
it
will
be
so
nice
to
have
it
over
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
now
more
than
ever
averse
to
the
task
before
him
.
<EOS>
Husbands
,
when
they
give
their
wives
a
talking
,
should
do
it
out
of
hand
,
uttering
their
words
hard
,
sharp
,
and
quick
,
 
and
should
then
go
.
<EOS>
There
are
some
works
that
wo
n't
bear
a
preface
,
and
this
work
of
marital
fault
-
finding
is
one
of
them
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
already
beginning
to
find
out
the
truth
of
this
.
<EOS>
"
Glencora
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
wish
you
to
be
serious
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
serious
,
"
she
replied
,
as
she
settled
herself
in
her
chair
with
an
air
of
mockery
,
while
her
eyes
and
mouth
were
bright
and
eloquent
with
a
spirit
which
her
husband
did
not
love
to
see
.
<EOS>
Poor
girl
!
<EOS>
There
was
seriousness
enough
in
store
for
her
before
she
would
be
able
to
leave
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
ought
to
be
serious
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
why
Mrs.
Marsham
came
here
from
Lady
Monk
's
last
night
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
do
.
<EOS>
She
came
to
tell
you
that
I
was
waltzing
with
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
You
might
as
well
ask
me
whether
I
knew
why
Mr.
Bott
was
standing
at
all
the
doors
,
glaring
at
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
anything
about
Mr.
Bott
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
something
about
him
though
,
"
she
said
,
again
moving
herself
in
her
chair
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
speaking
now
of
Mrs.
Marsham
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
speak
of
them
both
together
as
they
hunt
in
couples
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
,
will
you
listen
to
me
,
or
will
you
not
?
<EOS>
If
you
say
that
you
will
not
,
I
shall
know
what
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
you
would
,
Plantagenet
.
"
<EOS>
And
she
nodded
her
little
head
at
him
,
as
she
spoke
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
I
do
n't
know
what
you
would
do
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
listen
to
you
.
<EOS>
Only
,
as
I
said
before
,
it
will
be
very
nice
when
it
's
over
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Marsham
came
here
,
not
simply
to
tell
me
that
you
were
waltzing
with
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
 
and
I
wish
that
when
you
mention
his
name
you
would
call
him
Mr.
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
generally
prefix
his
Christian
name
,
which
it
would
be
much
better
that
you
should
omit
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
try
,
"
she
said
,
very
gently
;
"
but
it
's
hard
to
drop
an
old
habit
.
<EOS>
Before
you
married
me
you
knew
that
I
had
learned
to
call
him
Burgo
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
go
on
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
simply
to
tell
me
that
you
were
waltzing
that
Mrs.
Marsham
came
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
it
was
not
simply
to
see
me
waltzing
that
Mr.
Bott
stood
in
the
doorways
,
for
he
followed
me
about
,
and
came
down

me
to
the

-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
,
will
you
oblige
me
by
not
speaking
of
Mr.
Bott
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
would
oblige
me
by
not
speaking
of
Mrs.
Marsham
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
rose
quickly
from
his
chair
with
a
gesture
of
anger
,
stood
upright
for
half
a
minute
,
and
then
sat
down
again
.
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Plantagenet
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
know
what
you
want
,
and
I
'll
hold
my
tongue
till
you
bid
me
speak
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Marsham
came
here
because
she
saw
that
every
one
in
the
room
was
regarding
you
with
wonder
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
twisted
herself
about
in
her
chair
,
but
she
said
nothing
.
"
<EOS>
She
saw
that
you
were
not
only
dancing
with
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
but
that
you
were
dancing
with
him
,
 
what
shall
I
say
?
"
  
"
Upon
my
word
I
ca
n't
tell
you
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Recklessly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
recklessly
,
was
I
?
<EOS>
What
was
I
reckless
of
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Reckless
of
what
people
might
say
;
reckless
of
what
I
might
feel
about
it
;
reckless
of
your
own
position
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
to
speak
now
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
had
better
let
me
go
on
.
<EOS>
I
think
she
was
right
to
come
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
of
course
.
<EOS>
What
's
the
good
of
having
spies
,
if
they
do
n't
run
and
tell
as
soon
as
they
see
anything
,
especially
anything
 
reckless
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Glencora
,
you
are
determined
to
make
me
angry
.
<EOS>
I
am
angry
now
,
 
very
angry
.
<EOS>
I
have
employed
no
spies
.
<EOS>
When
rumours
have
reached
me
,
not
from
spies
,
as
you
choose
to
call
them
,
but
through
your
dearest
friends
and
mine
 
"
  
"
What
do
you
mean
by
rumours
from
my
dearest
friends
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
.
<EOS>
Let
me
go
on
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
not
when
you
say
my
dear
friends
have
spread
rumours
about
me
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
who
they
are
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
dear
friends
.
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
Alice
Vavasor
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
does
not
signify
.
<EOS>
But
when
I
was
warned
that
you
had
better
not
go
to
any
house
in
which
you
could
meet
that
man
,
I
would
not
listen
to
it
.
<EOS>
I
said
that
you
were
my
wife
,
and
that
as
such
I
could
trust
you
anywhere
,
everywhere
,
with
any
person
.
<EOS>
Others
might
distrust
you
,
but
I
would
not
do
so
.
<EOS>
When
I
wished
you
to
go
to
Monkshade
,
were
there
to
be
any
spies
there
?
<EOS>
When
I
left
you
last

at
Lady
Monk
's
,
do

believe
in

that
I
trusted
to
Mrs.

's

to
your
own

?
<EOS>
Do
you
think
that
I
have
lived
in
fear
of
Mr.
Fitzgerald
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
,
Plantagenet
;
I
do
not
think
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
believe
that
I
have
commissioned
Mr.
Bott
to
watch
your
conduct
?
<EOS>
Answer
me
,
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
paused
a
moment
,
thinking
what
actually
was
her
true
belief
on
that
subject
.
<EOS>
"
He
does
watch
me
,
certainly
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
does
not
answer
my
question
.
<EOS>
Do
you
believe
that
I
have
commissioned
him
to
do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
do
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
it
is
ignoble
in
you
to
talk

me
of
spies
.
<EOS>
I
have
employed
no
spies
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
ever
to
come
to
that
,
that
I
thought
spies
necessary
,
it
would
be
all
over
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
of
feeling
in
his
voice
as
he
said
this
,
 
something
that
almost
approached
to
passion
which
touched
his
wife
's
heart
.
<EOS>
Whether
or
not
spies
would
be
of
any
avail
,
she
knew
that
she
had
in
truth
done
that
of
which
he
had
declared
that
he
had
never
suspected
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
listened
to
words
of
love
from
her
former
lover
.
<EOS>
She
had
received
,
and
now
carried
about
with
her
a
letter
from
this
man
,
in
which
he
asked
her
to
elope
with
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
by
no
means
resolved
that
she
would
not
do
this
thing
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
false
to
her
husband
;
and
as
her
husband
spoke
of
his
confidence
in
her
,
her
own
spirit
rebelled
against
the
deceit
which
she
herself
was
practising
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
I
have
never
made
you
happy
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
that
I
never
can
make
you
happy
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
at
her
,
struck
by
her
altered
tone
,
and
saw
that
her
whole
manner
and
demeanour
were
changed
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
understand
what
you
mean
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
complained
.
<EOS>
You
have
not
made
me
unhappy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
was
one
of
those
men
to
whom
this
was
enough
.
<EOS>
If
his
wife
caused
him
no

,
what
more

to

?
<EOS>
No

she
might
have
done
much

for

.
<EOS>
She
might
have
given
him
an
heir
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
just
man
,
and
knew
that
the
blank
he
had
drawn
was
his
misfortune
,
and
not
her

.
  
<EOS>
But
now
her
heart
was
loosed
and
she
spoke
out
,
at

,
but

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
Plantagenet
;
I
shall
never

.
<EOS>
You
have
never

,

I

.
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
I
have

;

Lady

's
;
I

but
never

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora
!
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
Plantagenet
,
It

;

.
<EOS>
I
will

;
 
everything
!
<EOS>
I
do

Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
I

!
<EOS>
I

!
<EOS>
I
do
!
<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>
Have

not

from
the

,

?
<EOS>
Did

?
<EOS>
I
do

Burgo
Fitzgerald
,
and

Lady

's

,

,

that

go

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
  
"
He
has

,

?
"

the

,
in

,
thereby

.
  
<EOS>
Glencora
was

that

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
What

,

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

?
<EOS>
Plantagenet
,
I

;
 
not

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

.
"
<EOS>
As

she

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,
but
did

;
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

by

with
such
a

as
him
,
so
that
you
might

again
,
and
have
a

?
<EOS>
I
'd
die
;
 
I
'd
die

.
<EOS>
How
I
wish
I
could
die
!
<EOS>
Plantagenet
,
I
would
kill
myself
if
I
dared
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
a
tall
man
and
she
was
short

,

that

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
would
 
<EOS>
I
would
!
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Softly

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
are
wrong
in

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
"
  
<EOS>
She

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

I
am

apt

<EOS>
so

,

<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.

,

<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
Had

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
She

;

.
  
<EOS>
At

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
The
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
in
Search

Minister
.
 
<EOS>
It

who

,

<EOS>

The

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
She

,

turn

.
<EOS>
She
managed

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

of

,

left

,
 
without

.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that

was
minded
not
to

.
<EOS>
He
would
have
kissed
her
willingly
enough
<EOS>
had

required

.
"
<EOS>
He

,
"
said

Glencora
to

,
"
but
he
does
not
know
what
love
means
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
she
was
quite
aware
that
he
had
behaved
to
her
with
genuine
,
true
nobility
.
<EOS>
As
soon

she

alone
and

of

,

took

letter
from
her

,
and
tearing
it
into
very
small

,
without
reading

,
threw
the

on
the
fire
.
<EOS>
As
she
did
so
,
her
mind
seemed
to
be
fixed
,
at
any
rate
,
to
one
thing
,
 
that
she
would
think
no
more
of
Burgo
Fitzgerald
as
her
future
master
.
<EOS>
I
think
,
however
,
that
she
had
arrived
at
so
much
certainty
as
this
,
at
that
moment
in
which
she
had
been

Burgo
Fitzgerald
,
in
Lady
Monk
's

-

.
<EOS>
She
had
had

,
 
or

sin

,
 
to
think

with

,

;

;

,

to

to

that
she

resolved
that
it

for

.
<EOS>
But
she
was
neither

to

.
<EOS>
As
she
had
said
of
her
own

,
 
she
did
not

to
take

.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
knowing

so
,
she

letter
that
she
had
carried

,
and

in

fire
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
in
truth
told
him
everything
,
believing
that
in
doing
so
she
was
delivering
her
own
death
-
warrant
as
regarded
her
future
position
in
his
house
.
<EOS>
She
had
done
this
,
not
hoping
thereby
for
any
escape
;
not
with
any
purpose
as
regarded
herself
,
but
simply
because
deceit
had
been
grievous
to
her
,
and
had
become
unendurable
as
soon
as
his
words
and
manner
had
in
them
any
feeling
of
kindness
.
<EOS>
But
her
confession
had
no
sooner
been
made
than
her
fault
had
been
forgiven
.
<EOS>
She
had
told
him
that
she
did
not
love
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
told
him
,
even
,
that
she
had
thought
of
leaving
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
justified
by
her
own
words
any
treatment
of
his
,
however
harsh
,
which
he
might
choose
to
practise
.
<EOS>
But
the
result
had
been
 
the
immediate
result
 
that
he
had
been
more
tender
to
her
than
she
had
ever
remembered
him
to
be
before
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
he
had
conquered
her
.
<EOS>
However
cold
and
heartless
his
home
might
be
to
her
,
it
must
be
her
home
now
.
<EOS>
There
could
be
no
further
thought
of
leaving
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
gone
out
into
the
tiltyard
and
had
tilted
with
him
,
and
he
had
been
the
victor
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
himself
had
not
time
for
much
thought
before
he
found
himself
closeted
with
the
Duke
;
but
as
he
crossed
the
hall
and
went
up
the
stairs
,
a

or
two
did
pass
quickly
across
his
mind
.
<EOS>
She
had
confessed
to
him
,
and
he
had
forgiven
her
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
feel
quite
sure
that
he
had
been
right
,
but
he
did
feel
quite
sure
that
the
thing
had
been
done
.
<EOS>
He
recognized
it
for
a
fact
that
,
as
regarded
the
past
,
no
more
was
to
be
said
.
<EOS>
There
were
to
be
no
reproaches
,
and
there
must
be
some
tacit
abandoning
of
Mrs.
Marsham
's
close
attendance
.
<EOS>
As
to
Mr.
Bott
;
 
he
had
begun
to
hate
Mr.
Bott
,
and
had
felt
cruelly
ungrateful
,
when
that
gentleman
endeavoured
to
whisper
a
word
into
his
ear
as
he
passed
through
the
doorway
into
Lady
Monk
's
dining
-
room
.
<EOS>
And
he
had
offered
to
go
abroad
,
 
to
go
abroad
and
leave
his
politics
,
and
his
ambition
,
and
his
coming
honours
.
<EOS>
He
had
persisted
in
his
offer
,
even
after
his
wife
had
suggested
to
him
that
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
was
now
in
the
house
with
the
object
of
offering
him
that
very
thing
for
which
he
had
so
longed
!
<EOS>
As
he
thought
of
this
his
heart
became
heavy
within
him
.
<EOS>
Such
chances
,
 
so
he
told
himself
,
 
do
not
come
twice
in
a
man
's
way
.
<EOS>
When
returning
from
a
twelvemonth
's
residence
abroad
he
would
be
nobody
in
politics
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
lost
everything
for
which
he
had
been
working
all
his
life
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
man
of
his
word
,
and
as
he
opened
the
library
door
he
was
resolute
,
 
<EOS>
he
thought
that
he
could
be
resolute
in
adhering
to
his
promise
.
  
<EOS>
"
Duke
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
'm
afraid
I
have
kept
you
waiting
.
"
<EOS>
And
the
two
political
allies
shook
each
other
by
the
hand
.
  
<EOS>
The
Duke
was
in
a
glow
of
delight
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
no
waiting
.
<EOS>
He
was
only
too
glad
to
find
his
friend
at
home
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
prepared
to
wait
,
even
if
Mr.
Palliser
had
been
out
.
"
<EOS>
And
I
suppose
you
guess
why
I
'm
come
?
"
said
the
Duke
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
be
told
than
have
to
guess
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
smiling
for
a
moment
.
<EOS>
But
the
smile
quickly
passed
off
his
face
as
he
remembered
his
pledge
to
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
resigned
at
last
.
<EOS>
What
was
said
in
the
Lords
last
night
made
it
necessary
that
he
should
do

,
or
that
Lord
Brock
should
declare

able
to
support

through

.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
I
can
tell
you

now
.
<EOS>
He
must
have
gone
,
or
I
must
have
done

.
<EOS>
You
know
that
I
do
n't
like
him
in
the
Cabinet
.
<EOS>
I
admire
his
character
and
his
genius
,
but
I
think
him
the
most
dangerous
man
in
England
as

.
<EOS>
He
has
high
principles
,
 
the
very
highest
;
but
they
are
so
high
as
to
be
out
of
sight
to
ordinary

.
<EOS>
They
are
too
exalted
to
be
of
any
use
for
everyday

.
<EOS>
He
is
honest
as
the
sun
<EOS>
,
I
'm
sure
;
but
it
's
just
like
the
sun
's
honesty
,
 
of
a
kind
which
we
men
below
ca
n't
quite
understand
or

.
<EOS>
He
has
no
instinct
in
politics
,
but
reaches
his
conclusions
by
philosophical
deduction
.
<EOS>
Now
,
in
politics
,
I
would
a
deal
sooner
trust
to
instinct
than
to
calculation
.
<EOS>
I
think
he
may
probably
know
how
England
ought
to
be
governed
three
centuries
hence
better
than
any
man
living
,
but
of
the
proper
way
to
govern
it
now
,
I
think
he
knows
less
.
<EOS>
Brock
half
likes
him
and
half
fears
him
.
<EOS>
He
likes
the
support
of
his
eloquence
,
and
he
likes
the
power
of
the
man
;
but
he
fears
his
restless

,
and
thoroughly

.
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
he
has
left
us
,
and
I
am
here
to
ask

to
take

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
Duke
,
as
he
concluded
his
speech
,
was
quite
contented
,
and
almost
jovial
.
<EOS>
He
was
thoroughly
satisfied
with
the
new
political
arrangement
which
he
was
proposing
.
<EOS>
He
regarded
Mr.
Palliser
as
a
steady
,
practical
man
of
business
,
luckily
young
,
and
therefore
with
a
deal
of
work
in
him
,
belonging
to
the
race
from
which
English
ministers
ought
,
in
his
opinion
,
to
be
taken
,
and
as
being
,
in
some
respects
,
his
own
pupil
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
the
first
to
declare
aloud
that
Plantagenet
Palliser
was
the
coming
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
;
and
it
had
been
long
known
,
though
no
such
declaration
had
been
made
aloud
,
that
the
Duke
did
not
sit
comfortably
in
the
same
Cabinet
with
the
gentleman
who
had
now
resigned
.
<EOS>
Everything
had
now
gone
as
the
Duke
wished
;
and
he
was
prepared
to
celebrate
some
little
ovation
with
his
young
friend
before
he
left
the
house
in
Park
Lane
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
who
goes
out
with
him
?
"
asked
Mr.
Palliser
,
putting
off
the
evil
moment
of
his
own
decision
;
but
before
the
Duke
could
answer
him
,
he
had
reminded
himself
that
under
his
present
circumstances
he
had
no
right
to
ask
such
a
question
.
<EOS>
His
own
decision
could
not
rest
upon
that
point
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
does
not
matter
,
"
he
said
;
"
I
am
afraid
I
must
decline
the
offer
you
bring
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Decline
it
!
"
said
the
Duke
,
who
could
not
have
been
more
surprised
had
his
friend
talked
of
declining
heaven
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
I
must
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Duke
had
now
risen
from
his
chair
,
and
was
standing
,
with
both
his
hands
upon
the
table
.
<EOS>
All
his
contentment
,
all
his

,
had
vanished
.
<EOS>
His
fine
round
face
had
become
almost
ludicrously
long
;
his

and
mouth
were
struggling
to
convey

,
and
the

was
almost
drowned
in

.
<EOS>
Ever
since
Parliament
had
met
he
had
been

Mr.
Palliser
's
name
into

Prime

's
ear
,
and
now
 
.
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
,
and
would

,

.
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
Palliser
,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
You
must
have
got
some
false

into

.
<EOS>
There

no

.
<EOS>
Finespun

,

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Finespun

the

St.
Bungay

now

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

nothing

,
"

,

to
the

proposed

,
even

Finespun

.
<EOS>
"
It

nothing

;
 
it

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,

mercy
's

,

?
<EOS>
My

,
I

;

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is

,
Duke
.
<EOS>
I

,

I

.
"
<EOS>
As

Palliser

a

.
<EOS>
There
are

who

of

most

,

he

.
<EOS>
It

to

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
Upon

,
"

,
"
I
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

?
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Of

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Then
,

,

.
<EOS>
I

Glencora

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of

,
Palliser
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"

"

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
 
"
  
"
My

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Her

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
If

"
  
"
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

-
four

,

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser

.
<EOS>
"
I

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

.
<EOS>
She

;

less

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
I
ca
n't
say
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
I
ca
n't
say
.
<EOS>
Such
an

may
not
come

in

man
's

.
<EOS>
And
at
your

!
<EOS>
You
are

position
that
the

.
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
That

,

should
refuse
it
,
 
because
he
wants
to
take
his
wife
abroad
!
<EOS>
Palliser
,
if
she
were
dying
,
you
should
remain
under
such
an
emergency
as
this
.
<EOS>
She
might
go
,
but
you
should
remain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
remained
silent
for
a
moment
or
two
in
his
chair
;
he
then
rose
and
walked
towards
the
window
,
as
he
spoke
.
<EOS>
"
There
are
things
worse
than
death
,
"
he
said
,
when
his
back
was
turned
.
<EOS>
His
voice
was
very
low
,
and
there
was
a
tear
in
his
eye
as
he
spoke
them
;
the
words
were
indeed
whispered
,
but
the
Duke
heard
them
,
and
felt
that
he
could
not
press
him
any
more
on
the
subject
of
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
must
this
be
final
?
"
said
the
Duke
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
must
.
<EOS>
But
your
visit
here
has
come
so
quickly
on
my
resolution
to
go
abroad
,
 
which
,
in
truth
,
was
only

ten

before
your
name
was
brought
to

,
 
that
I
believe
I
ought
to
ask
for
a

twenty
-
four
hours
which
you
have

.
<EOS>
A

will

enough
.
<EOS>
Will

,

to

,

?
<EOS>
If

House
is
up
in
the
Lords
I

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be

after
eight
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
see

.
<EOS>
And
,
Duke
,
I

to

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
 
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
told
you
what
I
shall
never

to

else
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
know
that
you
are
safe
with

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
of
it
.
<EOS>
And
,
Duke
,
I
can
tell

that
the
sacrifice

me
will
be
almost

can
bear
.
<EOS>
This
thing
that
you
have
offered
me
to
-
day
is
the
only

that
I
have
ever
coveted
.
<EOS>
I
have
thought

,
have

,

,
and
have
been

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Finespun

man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Remember

much

as

to
his

.
"
<EOS>
Then
the
Duke
went
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
was
alone
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
alone
before
since
the

which
had
been
made
to
him
by
his
wife
,
and
the

she
had
spoken
were
still

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
love
Burgo
Fitzgerald
;
 
I
do
!
<EOS>
I
do
!
<EOS>
I
do
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
They
were
not
pleasant
words
for
a
young
husband
to
hear
.
<EOS>
Men
there
are
,
no
doubt
,
whose
nature
would
make
them
more
miserable
under
the
infliction
than
it
had
made
Plantagenet
Palliser
.
<EOS>
He
was
calm
,
without
strong
passion
,
not
prone
to
give
to
words
a
stronger
significance
than
they
should
bear
;
 
and
he
was
essentially

.
<EOS>
Never
for
a
moment
had
he
thought
,
even
while
those

,
that
his
wife
had
betrayed
his

.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
there
was
that
at
his

,
as
he
remembered

,
which
made
him
feel
that
the

was
almost
too
heavy
for
him
.
<EOS>
For

an

's

he
thought
more
of
his
wife
and

Burgo
Fitzgerald

Lord

and
Mr.

.
<EOS>
But
of
this
he
was
aware
,
 
that
he
had
forgiven
his
wife
;
that
he
had
put
his
arm
round
her
and
embraced
her
after
hearing
her
confession
,
 
and
that
she
,
mutely
,
with
her
eyes
,
had
promised
him
that
she
would
do
her
best
for
him
.
<EOS>
Then
something
of
an
idea
of
love
came
across
his
heart
,
and
he
acknowledged
to
himself
that
he
had
married
without
loving
or
without
requiring
love
.
<EOS>
Much
of
all
this
had
been
his
own
fault
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
had
not
the
whole
of
it
come
from
his
own
wrong
-
doing
?
<EOS>
He
acknowledged
that
it
was
so
.
<EOS>
But
now
,
 
now
he
loved
her
.
<EOS>
He
felt
that
he
could
not
bear
to
part
with
her
,
even
if
there
were
no
question
of
public

,
or
of

.
<EOS>
He
had
been
torn
inwardly
by
that
assertion
that
she
loved
another
man
.
<EOS>
She
had
got
at
his
heart
-
strings
at
last
.
<EOS>
There
are
men
who
may
love
their
wives
,
though
they
never
can
have
been
in
love
before
their
marriage
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
Duke
had

gone
about

,
and

,

ordinary

,
it

time
to
go
down
to
the
House
,
he
took
his
hat
and
walked
into
the
Park
.
<EOS>
He
made

across
Hyde
Park
,
and
into
Kensington

,
and
there
he
remained
for
an
hour
,

up
and
down
beneath
the
elms
.
<EOS>
The
quidnuncs
of
the
town
,
who
chanced
to
see

,
and
who
had
heard
something
of

political

of
the

,
thought
,
no

,
that
he

.
<EOS>
But
he
had
not

there

before

had
resolved
that
no

was
at
present

.
<EOS>
"
It
has
been
my
own

,
"
he

,

,
"

's

I
will

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
he
was
a
slow

,
and

not

off
instantly
to
the
Duke
.
<EOS>
He
had
given
himself
to
eight

,
and
he
took

.
<EOS>
He
could
not
go
down
to
the
House
of
Commons
because
men
would

of

which
he

.
<EOS>
So
he
dined

,
alone
.
<EOS>
He
had
told

wife
that
he
would
see
her
at
nine
,
and
before
that
hour
he
would
not

to

.
<EOS>
He
sat
alone
till
it
was
time
for

to
get
into
his

,
and
thought

all

.
<EOS>
That
seat
in
the
Cabinet
and

of
the
Exchequer
,
which
he

so

,
were

done

.
<EOS>
There
was
no

about

.
<EOS>
It
might

for
him
not
to
have

;
but

,

,

his
wife
's

.
<EOS>
"
We

through

,
"

,
"
to
Baden
,
and

.
<EOS>
She
has
seen
nothing

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
"
<EOS>
Then

to

House

Lords
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Palliser
,
"

,

,
"
<EOS>
of

.
<EOS>
I

I
am
very

;
 
more

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Duke
's
voice
was
very

,
and
it
might

that

.
<EOS>
In

,

had

.
<EOS>
It

!
<EOS>
How

not

to

,

!
<EOS>
"
I
never

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
must

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
God

.
<EOS>
Goodbye
!
<EOS>
good
-
bye
!
<EOS>
No
;
I
'm
not

.
<EOS>
There
shall

.
<EOS>
But
I

.
<EOS>
"
In

.
  
<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>
The
Duke

Lord
Brock

,

,
 
another

,
a

.
<EOS>
These

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
To

Session
,

,

,
and

the
Exchequer
while
all

of

,

,

of
Mr.

,

.
  
<EOS>
In

Mr.

had

,

.
<EOS>
"
We

to

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
any
rate
,
there
is
nothing
on
my

to

.
"
   
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
's
Name
Gets
into
the
Money
Market
.
 
<EOS>
Some
ten
or
twelve
days
after
George
Vavasor
's
return
to
London
from
Westmoreland
he
appeared
at
Mr.
Scruby
's
offices
with
four
small
slips
of
paper
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
,
as
usual
,
was
pressing
for
money
.
<EOS>
The
third
election
was
coming
on
,
and
money
was
already
being
spent
very
freely
among
the
men
of
the
River
Bank
.
<EOS>
So
,
at
least
,
Mr.
Scruby
declared
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grimes
,
of
the
"
Handsome
Man
,
"
had
shown
signs
of
returning
allegiance
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Grimes
could
not
afford
to
be
loyal
without
money
.
<EOS>
He
had
his
little
family
to
protect
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
,
too
,
had
his
little
family
,
and
was
not
ashamed
to
use
it
on
this
occasion
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
a
family
man
,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
and
therefore
I
never
run
any
risks
.
<EOS>
I
never
go
a
yard
further
than
I
can
see
my
way
back
.
<EOS>
"
This
he
had
said
in
answer
to
a
proposition
that
he
should
take
George
's
note
of
hand
for
the
expenses
of
the
next
election
,
payable
in
three
months
"
time
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
very
hard
to
realize
,
"
said
George
,
"
immediately
upon
a
death
,
when
all
the
property
left
is
real
property
.
"
<EOS>
"
Very
hard
indeed
,
"
said
Mr.
Scruby
,
who
had
heard
with
accuracy
all
the
particulars
of
the
old
Squire
's
will
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
understood
the
lawyer
,
cursed
him
inwardly
,
and
suggested
to
himself
that
some
day
he
might
murder
Mr.
Scruby
as
well
as
John
Grey
,
 
and
perhaps
also
a
few
more
of
his
enemies
.
<EOS>
Two
days
after
the
interview
in
which
his
own
note
of
hand
had
been
refused
,
he
again
called
in
Great
Marlborough
Street
.
<EOS>
Upon
this

he
tendered
to
Mr.
Scruby
for
his
approval
the
four
slips
of
paper
which
have
been
mentioned
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
regarded
them
with
attention
,
looking
first
at
one
side
horizontally
,
and
then
at
the
other
side
perpendicularly
.
<EOS>
But
before
we
learn
the
judgement
pronounced
by
Mr.
Scruby
as
to
these
four
slips
of
paper
,
we
must
go
back
to
their
earlier
history
.
<EOS>
As
they
were
still
in
their
infancy
,
we
shall
not
have
to
go
back
far
.
  
<EOS>
One
morning
,
at
about
eleven
o'clock
the
parlour
-
maid
came
up
to
Alice
,
as
she
sat
alone
in
the
drawing
-
room
in
Queen
Anne
Street
,
and
told
her
there
was
a
"
gentleman
"
in
the
hall
waiting
to
be
seen
by
her
.
<EOS>
We
all
know
the
tone
in
which
servants
announce
a
gentleman
when
they
know
that
the
gentleman
is
not
a
gentleman
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
gentleman
wanting
to
see
me
!
<EOS>
What
sort
of
a
gentleman
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
miss
,
I
do
n't
think
he
's
just
of
our
sort
;
but
he
's
decent
to
look
at
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
had
no
desire
to
deny
herself
to
any
person
but
one
.
<EOS>
She
was
well
aware
that
the
gentleman
in
the
hall
could
not
be
her
cousin
George
,
and
therefore
she
did
not
refuse
to
see
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
come
up
,
"
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
think
,
Jane
,
you
ought
to
ask

his
name
.
<EOS>
"
Jane
did
ask
him
his
name
,
and
came
back
immediately
,
announcing
Mr.
Levy
.
  
<EOS>
This
occurred
immediately
after
the
return
of
Mr.
John
Vavasor
from
Westmoreland
.
<EOS>
He
had
reached
home
late
on
the

,
and
at
the
moment
of
Mr.
Levy
's
call
was
in
his
dressing
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
got
up
to
receive
her
visitor
,
and
at
once
understood
the
tone
of
her
maid
's
voice
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Levy
was
certainly
not
a
gentleman
of
the
sort
to
which
she
had
been
most
accustomed
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
little

man
,
with
sharp

,
set
very
near
to
each
other
in
his

,
with
a
beaked

,
thick
at
the
bridge
,
and
a
black
moustache
,
but
no
other
beard
.
<EOS>
Alice
did
not
at
all
like
the
look
of
Mr.
Levy
,
but
she
stood
up
to
receive
him
,
made
him
a
little
bow
,
and
asked
him
to
sit
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
papa
dressed
yet
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
asked
the
servant
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
miss
,
I
do
n't
think
he
is
,
 
not
to
say
dressed
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
had
thought
it
might
be
as
well
that
Mr.
Levy
should
know
that
there
was
a
gentleman
in
the
house

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
called
about

little

,
miss
,
"

Mr.
Levy
,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
You

,
I

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Alice

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Mr.

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
dare

never

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
<EOS>
;
I

,
"

<EOS>
"

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
you
're

Vavasor
's

.
<EOS>
I
'll

his

,
if

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

,
miss
.
"
  
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
's
letter
to
his
cousin
was
as
follows
:
    
<EOS>
DEAR
ALICE
,
  
<EOS>
After
what
passed
between
us
when
I
last
saw
you
<EOS>
I
thought
that
on
my

I
should
learn
that
you
had
paid
in
at
my
bankers
"
the
money
that
I

.
<EOS>
But
I
find
that
this
is
not
so
;
and
of
course
I
excuse
you
,
because
women
so
seldom
know
when
or
how
to
do
that
which
business
demands
of
them
.
<EOS>
You
have
,
no
doubt
,
heard
the
injustice
which
my
grandfather
has
done
me
,
and
will
probably
feel
as

as
I
do
.
<EOS>
I
only
mention
this
now
,
because
the
nature
of
his
will
makes
it
more
than
ever
incumbent
on
you
that
you

.
  
<EOS>
Till
there

be
some
ground
for

between

,
 
and
this
I
do
not
doubt
will
come
,
 
<EOS>
I
think

not
to
call
,
myself
,
at
Queen

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

fourteen

"
date
,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Levy

.
<EOS>
Your

"
accepted
,
"

Messrs.
Drummonds
,
where

,

,

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,

.
<EOS>
They

at
Drummonds
"
that

,

.
  
<EOS>
I

certainly

by
not

money
as

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

,
sure
that

,

.
  
<EOS>
Affectionately

,
  
GEORGE
VAVASOR
.
  
<EOS>
The
unparalleled
impudence
of
this
letter
had
the
effect
which
the
writer
had
intended
.
<EOS>
It
made
Alice
think
immediately
of
her
own
remissness
,
 
if
she
had
been
remiss
,
 
rather
than
of
the
enormity
of
his
claim
upon
her
.
<EOS>
The
decision
with
which
he
asked
for
her
money
,
without
any
pretence
at
an

on
his
part
,
did
for
the
time
induce
her
to
believe
that
she
had
no
alternative
but
to
give
it
to
him
,
and
that
she
had
been
wrong
in
delaying

.
<EOS>
She
had
told
him
that
he
should
have
it
,
and
she
ought
to
have
been
as
good
as
her
word
.
<EOS>
She
should
not
have
forced
upon
him
the
necessity
of
demanding
it
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
idea
of
signing
four
bills
was
terrible
to
her
,
and
she
felt
sure
that
she
ought
not
to
put
her
name
to
orders
for
so
large

amount
and
then
intrust
them
to
such
a
man
as
Mr.
Levy
.
<EOS>
Her
father
was
in
the
house
,
and
she
might
have
asked
him
.
<EOS>
The
thought
that
she
would
do
so
of
course
occurred
to
her
.
<EOS>
But
then
it
occurred
to
her
also
that
were
she
to
speak
to
her
father
as
to
this
advancing
of
money
to
her
cousin
,
 
to
this

of
money
,
<EOS>
for
she
now
well

that

;
 
were

in

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

George
should

,

.
<EOS>
But
her

might
probably

able

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
So

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Levy
had
taken

,

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,
<EOS>
what

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

<EOS>

"
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Two

.
<EOS>
She

heard
much
of

,

.
<EOS>
What

,

<EOS>
"
It

,

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
Well
;

<EOS>
No

<EOS>
He

,

ai

But

<EOS>
If

<EOS>

<EOS>

No

,

,

,

;

<EOS>

She

Her

.
  
<EOS>
These

Mr.
Scruby
's

.
<EOS>
In

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

d
 
---

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Fourteen

,
"

Scruby
.
<EOS>
"
We

,

.
<EOS>
I

ca

,

,
 
<EOS>
let

,
"
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
A

.
<EOS>
Certainly

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
 
no
!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
You

collect

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
cursed
suspicious

,
Scruby
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
ai
n't
.
<EOS>
I
'm

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

;
that
's

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

as

?
<EOS>
Everybody

that
my
cousin
has

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
that

"
names

,
 
ladies

,
 
ai

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

City

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
but

ca
n't

.
<EOS>
However
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Have

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then

Scruby
turned
to
some

,

.
<EOS>
Vavasor
looked
at

,
opening

and
cursing

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
went
on
with

,
by
no

or
the

.
<EOS>
Thereupon
Vavasor
got

without

.
  
<EOS>
As
he

along

,
and

which
surround
the
Soho
district
,
and
so
on
to
the
Strand
and
his
own
lodgings
,
he
still
continued
to
think
of
some
wide
scheme
of
revenge
,
 
of
some
scheme
in
which
Mr.
Scruby
might
be
included
.
<EOS>
There
had
appeared
something
latterly
in
Mr.
Scruby
's
manner
to
him
,
something
of
mingled
impatience
and
familiarity
,
which
made
him
feel
that
he
had
fallen
in
the
attorney
's
estimation
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
the
lawyer
thought
him
to
be
less
honourable
,
or
less
clever
,
than
he
had
before
thought
him
;
but
that
the
man
was
like
a
rat
,
and
knew
a
falling
house
by
the
instinct
that
was
in
him
.
<EOS>
So
George
Vavasor
cursed
Mr.
Scruby
,
and
calculated
some
method
of
murdering
him
without
detection
.
  
<EOS>
The
reader
is
not
to
suppose
that
the
Member
for
the
Chelsea
Districts
had
,
in
truth
,
resolved
to
gratify
his
revenge
by
murder
,
 
by
murdering
any
of
those
persons
whom
he
hated
so

.
<EOS>
He
did
not
,
himself
,
think
it
probable
that
he
would

.
<EOS>
But
he
received
some
secret

in
allowing

to
dwell
upon

,
and
in

.
<EOS>
He
reflected
that
it
would
not

to

off
Scruby
and
John
Grey
at

same

,
as

;
unless

to

,
 
a

,
as
to
the

of
ending
whose

he

his

quite
as

as

did
in

to
any

he

.
<EOS>
It
need

to

reader
that
this

.
  
<EOS>
As
he

himself
in

money
<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
's

four

at

own
bankers
"
,
to

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
<EOS>
Alice
would

,

.
<EOS>
He
must

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
<EOS>
In

House
he
sat

,
making
those

I
have
spoken
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have

;

?
"

<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
George
Vavasor
was

City
by

,

Vavasor
,

.

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

ladies
"

business
.
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
cursed

,

about

.
<EOS>
Might

about

?
<EOS>
Three

,

,

.
<EOS>
Again

,

.
<EOS>
Among

,

.
<EOS>
The

was

for

,

George
cursed

.
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
knew
quite
enough
of
the

to

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Levy
had

,

.
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Papa
,

?
<EOS>
"
This

Vavasor
,

.
<EOS>
"
Papa

"
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
This

.

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

"

.
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
   
<EOS>
The
Bills
Are
Made
All
Right
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Vavasor
was
at
his
wits
"
end
about
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
She
had
put
her
name
to
four
bills
for

,
and
had

from

,
almost

,
his

to

.
<EOS>
And
she
might

her

to

,

!
<EOS>
There
was
no

how
a
man
ought
to
behave
to
such

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

her
money
,
"
the
father
said
to

;
"
and
if

,

.
<EOS>
But
to

throw
her

away
in
such

fashion
as
this
is
enough
to
break

man
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Vavasor
went
to
his
office
in
Chancery
Lane
,
but
he
did
not
go
to
the

of
Mr.
Round
,

.
<EOS>
Instead

calling
on
Mr.
Round
he
sent

to
Suffolk
Street
,
and
the
answer
to

note
came
in
the
person
of
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
John
Grey
was
living
in
town
in
these
days
,
and
was
in
the
habit
of
seeing
Mr.
Vavasor
frequently
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
had
not
left
London
since
the
memorable
occasion
on
which
he
had
pitched
his
rival
down
the
tailor
's
stairs
at
his
