.
<EOS>
He
had
made
himself
pretty
well
conversant
with
George
Vavasor
's
career
,
and
had
often
shuddered
as
he
thought
what
might
be
the
fate
of
any
girl
who
might
trust
herself
to
marry
such
a
man
as
that
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
at
home
when
Mr.
Vavasor
's
note
had
reached
his
lodgings
,
and
had
instantly
walked
off
towards
Chancery
Lane
.
<EOS>
He
knew
his
way
to
Mr.
Vavasor
's
signing
-
office
very
accurately
,
for
he
had
acquired
a
habit
of
calling
there
,
and
of
talking
to
the
father
about
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
patient
,
persevering
man
,
confident
in
himself
,
and
apt
to
trust
that
he
would
accomplish
those
things
which
he
attempted
,
though
he
was
hardly
himself
aware
of
any
such
aptitude
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
despaired
as
to
Alice
.
<EOS>
And
though
he
had
openly
acknowledged
to
himself
that
she
had
been
very
foolish
,
 
or
rather
,
that
her
judgement
had
failed
her
,
 
he
had
never
in
truth
been
angry
with
her
.
<EOS>
He
had
looked
upon
her
rejection
of
himself
,
and
her
subsequent
promise
to
her
cousin
,
as
the
effects
of
a
mental
hallucination
,
very
much
to
be
lamented
,
 
to

wept
for
,
perhaps
,
through
a
whole
life
,
as
a
source
of
terrible
sorrow
to
himself
and
to
her
.
<EOS>
But
he
regarded
it
all
as
a
disease
,
of
which
the
cure
was
yet
possible
,
 
as

"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
we
did
.
<EOS>
You
yourself
did
not

that
what

had
before
would
have

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
after
she
had

!
"
  
"
That
would
make
no

with
her
.
<EOS>
She
had

her

,
and

that
he
will

,
let

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
give

!
<EOS>
Not

I
can

.
<EOS>
I
'll
expose
him
.
<EOS>
I
will
indeed
.
<EOS>
Such

rascal
as
he
is
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
do
nothing
,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
that
will

your
daughter
.
<EOS>
I
'm

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
,
by
heavens
 
.
<EOS>
Such
sheer
robbery
as
that
!
<EOS>
Two
thousand

more
in
fourteen

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
shortness
of
the
date
at
which
the
bills
were
drawn
seemed
to

Vavasor
almost

.
<EOS>
Then

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Round
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
He
does

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

.
<EOS>
As

I

shall

Drummonds
"
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
not
do

,
"
said
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
call
at
Drummonds
"
,
instead
,
and
see

the

is
all

the

.
<EOS>
As

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
if
she
wo
n't

,
at
last
,
Grey
?
<EOS>
Upon

,
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
My

is
she
'll
never

.
<EOS>
She
'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
money
wo

,
"
said
Grey
,
with

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

!
<EOS>
that
wo

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,
 
that
she

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
The

we
have
made
shall
then

to

.
"
  
<EOS>
In
this

it
was
settled
;
and
on

following

the
father
informed

daughter
that
he

done

,

at
the
bankers
"
before

.
<EOS>
On

,

her

had
named
in

,

to
Drummonds
"
,

,
that
due

for
the
bills

.
  
<EOS>
So
far
,
I
think
we
may
say
that
Mr.
George
Vavasor
was
not

.
   
<EOS>
Going
Abroad
.
 
<EOS>
One
morning
,
early
in
May
,
a
full
week
before
Alice
's
visit
to
the
bankers
"
at
Charing
Cross
,
a
servant
in
grand
livery
,
six

,
got
out

a
cab
at
the
door
in
Queen
Anne
Street
,
and
sent
up
a
note
for
Miss
Vavasor
,
declaring
that
he
would
wait
in
the
cab
for

.
<EOS>
He
had
come
from
Lady
Glencora
,
and
had
been
specially
ordered
to
go
in
a
cab
and
come
back
in
a
cab
,
and
make

as
like
a
Mercury
,
with
wings
to

,
as
may
be
possible
to
a
London

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
arranged
his

with
his
wife
that
morning
,
 
or
,
I
should
more

say
,
had
given

,

she
,

,

in

Queen
Anne
Street
.
<EOS>
"
Do
come
;
 
instantly
if
you

,
"
the

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
so

to

,
and
so

ask
of
you
.
<EOS>
If

ca
n't

,

,

?
"
<EOS>
Alice
sent
back

,

in
Park

as

she

put

her

and

;
and
then
the

went

.
  
<EOS>
Alice
found
her

in

-

,

.
<EOS>
They

not

's

,

.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,

sha

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll

,

.
<EOS>
But
I

so

,

.
<EOS>
And
I

,

wo

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
generally

me

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
I
do
n't
,

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Do

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hours

!
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

.
<EOS>
If

I

!
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
you
.
<EOS>

,

"
  
<EOS>
"
But

Palliser
ca

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Do

,

's

.
<EOS>
Whether

.
<EOS>
To

day
is

.
<EOS>
We

,

.
<EOS>
We

breakfast

,
and
then

will

all

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
will
walk

,
and
you

,

,
 
just

,
 
and

.
<EOS>
Then

shall

on
to
Basle
<EOS>
"
 
Alice
shuddered

was

,
thinking
of
the

over

river
 
"
and
so
to
Lucerne
 
.
<EOS>
But
no
;
that
was
the
first

,
and
Mr.
Palliser
altered

.
<EOS>
He
spent
a
whole
day
up
here
with
maps
and
Bradshaw
's
and
Murray
's
guide
-
books
,
and
he
scolded
me
so
because
I
did
n't
care
whether

went
first
to
Baden
or

some

.
<EOS>
How
could
I
care
?
<EOS>
I
told

I
would
go
anywhere
<EOS>
he
chose

.
<EOS>
Then

told

I
was
heartless
;
 
and
I
acknowledged
that
I
was

.
<EOS>
"
I
am
heartless
,
"
I
said
.
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
something
I
do
n't

.
"
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Cora
,
why
did

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't

.
<EOS>
Besides
,

's

.
<EOS>
Then

,

.
<EOS>
So
I

,

'd

.
<EOS>
I
knew

would

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
Would

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

Baden

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
've

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Why

Mr.
Palliser
going

in

in

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
;
now
I
must

back

.
<EOS>
And

,
Alice
,
I

;

,

wo
n't

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
You
must

wo

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

apt

,
but
I
sha
n't

anything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
woman
you
are
for
discretion
!
<EOS>
it

that
ought
to
be

;

.
<EOS>
Only

have
n't

to

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never

now
,
Cora
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
mind

,

.
<EOS>
But

secret
is
this
.
<EOS>
They
have
asked
Mr.
Palliser
to
be
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
,
and
he
has
 
refused
.
<EOS>
Think

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Because
of
me
,
 
of
me
,
and
my

,
and

,
and

.
<EOS>
Because
he
has
been
fool
enough
to
plague

with
a
wife
 
he
who
of
all

ought

have

from
such

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
he
has
been
so
good
!
<EOS>
It
is
almost
impossible
to
make
any
one
understand
it
.
<EOS>
If
you
could
know
how
he
has
longed
for
this
office
;
 
how
he
has
worked
for
it
day
and
night
,
wearing

eyes
out
with
figures
when
everybody
else
has
been
asleep
,
shutting
himself
up
with
such
creatures
as
Mr.
Bott
when
other
men
have
been
shooting
and

and
flirting
and

.
<EOS>
He
has
been
a
slave

it
for
years
,
 
all
his
life
I
believe
,
 
in
order
that
he
might
sit
in

,
and
be
a

and
a
Chancellor
of
the

.
<EOS>
He
has
hoped
and
feared
,
and
has
been
,
I
believe
,
sometimes
half
-
mad
with
expectation
.
<EOS>
This
has
been
his
excitement
,
 
what
racing
and
gambling
are
to
other
men
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
the
place
was
there
,
ready
for
him
,
and
they

to

.
<EOS>
They
begged
him
to
take
it
,
almost

.
<EOS>
The
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
was
here
all
one

about
it
;
but
Mr.
Palliser
sent
him
away
,
and
refused
the
place
.
<EOS>
It
's
all
over
now
,
and
the
other
man
,

,
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
keep
on
telling
you
 
because
of
me
.
<EOS>
He
found
that
I
wanted
looking

,
and
that
Mrs.
Marsham
and

Bott

could
n't

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Cora
!
<EOS>
how

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
knew

,
you

could
.
<EOS>
You
remember
about
Lady
Monk
's
ball
,
that
you
would
not
go
to
,
 
as
you
ought
to
have
done
.
<EOS>
If
you
had
gone
,
Mr.
Palliser
would
have
been

the

at
this

;
he
would
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
Only
think
of
that
!
<EOS>
But
though
you
did
not
go
,
other

did
who
ought
to
have
remained
at
home
.
<EOS>
I
went
for
one
,
 
<EOS>
and
you
know
who
was
there
for
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
difference
could
that
make
to
you
?
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
might
have
made
a

deal

difference
.
<EOS>
And
,
for
the

that
,
so
it

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
there

,
but
,

,
he
went

.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
tell
you
all
the

there
had
been
about
Mrs.
Marsham
,
 
whether
I
was
to
take

.
<EOS>
However
,
I
would
n't

,

.
<EOS>
The

went
for

,

there

when

;

.
<EOS>
I
wonder

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

were

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

<EOS>
You
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
I
dared

,
at

,

,
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

Cora
!
"
  
<EOS>
"

I
?
<EOS>
At

;

.
<EOS>
Alice
,
I
never
will

again
;
 
never
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
with

now
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
I

to

,
 
<EOS>
mad
,

.
<EOS>
There

,

the

two

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
how

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
Cora
!
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice

<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Do

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
When

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.

"

<EOS>

Only

!
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
take
his
hand
willingly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
for
my
sake
you
will
go
with
us
?
<EOS>
He
understands
himself
that
I
am
not
fit
to
be
his
companion
,
and
to
have
no
companion
but
him
.
<EOS>
Now
there
is
a
spirit
of
wisdom
about
you
that
will
do
for
him
,
and
a
spirit
of
folly
that
will
suit
me
.
<EOS>
I
can
manage
to
put
myself
on
a
par
with
a
girl
who
has
played
such
a
wild
game
with
her
lovers
as
you
have
done
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
would
give
no
promise
then
.
<EOS>
Her
first
objection
was
that
she
had
undertaken
to
go
down
to
Westmoreland
and
comfort
Kate
in
the
affliction
of
her
broken
arm
.
"
<EOS>
And
I
must
go
,
"
said
Alice
,
remembering
how
necessary
it
was
that
she
should
plead
her
own
cause
with
George
Vavasor
's
sister
.
<EOS>
But
she
acknowledged
that
she
had
not
intended
to
stay
long
in
Westmoreland
,
probably
not
more
than
a
week
,
and
it
was
at
last
decided
that
the
Pallisers
should
postpone
their
journey
for
four
or
five
days
,
and
that
Alice
should
go
with
them
immediately
upon
her
return
from
Vavasor
Hall
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
objection
;
"
said
her
father
,
speaking
with
that
voice
of
resignation
which
men
use
when
they
are
resolved
to
consider
themselves
injured
whatever
may
be
done
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
get
along
in
lodgings
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
we
had
better
leave
the
house
,
as
you
have
given
away
so
much
of
your
own
fortune
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
did
not
think
it
worth
her
while
to
point
out
to
him
,
in
answer
to
this
,
that
her
contribution
to
their
joint
housekeeping
should
still
remain
the
same
as
ever
.
<EOS>
Such
,
however
,
she
knew
would
be
the
fact
,
and
she
knew
also
that
she
would
find
her
father
in
the
old
house
when
she
returned
from
her
travels
.
<EOS>
To
her
,
in
her
own
great
troubles
,
the
absence
from
London
would
be
as
serviceable
as
it
could
be
to
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
she
had
already
begun
to
feel
the
impossibility
of
staying
quietly
at
home
.
<EOS>
She
could
lecture
her
cousin
,
whose
faults
were
open
,
easy
to
be
defined
,
and
almost
loud
in
their
nature
;
but
she
was
not
on
that
account
the
less
aware
of
her
own
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
she
too
had
cause
to
be
ashamed
of
herself
.
<EOS>
She
was
half
afraid
to
show
her
face
among
her
friends
,
and
wept
grievously
over
her
own
follies
.
<EOS>
Those
cruel
words
of
her
father
rang
in
her
ears
constantly
:
 
"
Things
of
that
sort
are
so
often
over
with
you
.
"
<EOS>
The
reproach
,
though
cruel
,
was
true
,
and
what
reproach
more
galling
could
be
uttered
to
an
unmarried
girl
such
as
was
Alice
Vavasor
?
<EOS>
She
had
felt
from
the
first
moment
in
which
the
proposition
was
made
to
her
,
that
it
would
be
well
that
she
should
for
a
while
leave
her
home
,
and
especially
that
drawing
-
room
in
Queen
Anne
Street
,
which
told
her
so
many
tales
that
she
would
fain
forget
,
if
it
were
possible
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
would
not
allow
his
wife
to
remain
in
London
for
the
ten
or
twelve
days
which
must
yet
elapse
before
they
started
,
nor
could
he
send
her
into
the
country
alone
.
<EOS>
He
took
her
down
to
Matching
Priory
,
having
obtained
leave
to
be
absent
from
the
House
for
the
remainder
of
the
Session
,
and
remained
with
her
there
till
within
two
days
of
their
departure
.
<EOS>
That
week
down
at
Matching
,
as
she
afterwards
told
Alice
,
was
very
terrible
.
<EOS>
He
never
spoke
a
word
to
rebuke
her
.
<EOS>
He
never
hinted
that
there
had
been
aught
in
her
conduct
of
which
he
had
cause
to
complain
.
<EOS>
He
treated
her
with
a
respect
that
was
perfect
,
and
indeed
with
more
outward
signs
of
affection
than
had
ever
been
customary
with
him
.
"
<EOS>
But
,
"
as
Lady
Glencora
afterwards
expressed
it
,
"
he
was
always
looking
after
me
.
<EOS>
I
believe
he
thought
that
Burgo
Fitzgerald
had
hidden
himself
among
the
ruins
,
"
she
said
once
to
Alice
.
"
<EOS>
He
never
suspected
me
,
I
am
sure
of
that
;
but
he
thought
that
he
ought
to
look
after
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
Lady
Glencora
in
this
had
very
nearly
hit
the
truth
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
resolved
,
from
that
hour
in
which
he
had
walked
out
among
the
elms
in
Kensington
Gardens
,
that
he
would
neither
suspect
his
wife
,
nor
treat
her
as
though
he
suspected
her
.
<EOS>
The
blame
had
been
his
,
perhaps
,
more
than
it
had
been
hers
.
<EOS>
So
much
he
had
acknowledged
to
himself
,
thinking
of
the
confession
she
had
made
to
him
before
their
marriage
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
manifestly
his
imperative
duty
,
 
his
duty
of
duties
,
 
to
save
her
from
that
pitfall
into
which
,
as
she
herself
had
told
him
,
she
had
been
so
ready
to
fall
.
<EOS>
For
her
sake
and
for
his
this
must
be
done
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
duty
so
imperative
,
that
in
its
performance
he
had
found
himself
forced
to
abandon
his
ambition
.
<EOS>
To
have
his
wife
taken
from
him
would
be
terrible
,
but
the
having
it
said
all
over
the
world
that
such
a
misfortune
had
come
upon
him
would
be
almost
more
terrible
even
than
that
.
  
<EOS>
So
he
went
with
his
wife
hither
and
thither
,
down
at
Matching
,
allowing
himself
to
be
driven
about
behind
Dandy
and
Flirt
.
<EOS>
He
himself
proposed
these
little
excursions
.
<EOS>
They
were
tedious
to
him
,
but
doubly
tedious
to
his
wife
,
who
now
found
it
more
difficult
than
ever
to
talk
to
him
.
<EOS>
She
struggled
to
talk
,
and
he
struggled
to
talk
,
but
the
very
struggles
themselves
made
the
thing
impossible
.
<EOS>
He
sat
with
her
in
the
mornings
,
and
he
sat
with
her
in
the
evenings
;
he
breakfasted
with
her
,
lunched
with
her
,
and
dined
with
her
.
<EOS>
He
went
to
bed
early
,
having
no
figures
which
now
claimed
his
attention
.
<EOS>
And
so
the
week
at
last
wore
itself
away
.
<EOS>
"
I
saw
him
yawning
sometimes
,
"
Lady
Glencora
said
afterwards
,
"
as
though
he
would
fall
in
pieces
.
"
   
<EOS>
Mr.
John
Grey
in
Queen
Anne
Street
.
 
<EOS>
Alice
was
resolved
that
she
would
keep
her
promise
to
Kate
,
and
pay
her
visit
to
Westmoreland
before
she
started
with
the
Pallisers
.
<EOS>
Kate
had
written
to
her
three
lines
with
her
left
hand
,
begging
her
to
come
,
and
those
three
lines
had
been
more
eloquent
than
anything
she
could
have
written
had
her
right
arm
been
uninjured
.
<EOS>
Alice
had
learned
something
of
the
truth
as
to
the
accident
from
her
father
;
or
,
rather
,
had
heard
her
father
's
surmises
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
She
had
heard
,
too
,
how
her
cousin
George
had
borne
himself
when
the
will
was
read
,
and
how
he
had
afterwards
disappeared
,
never
showing
himself
again
at
the
hall
.
<EOS>
After
all
that
had
passed
she
felt
that
she
owed
Kate
some
sympathy
.
<EOS>
Sympathy
may
,
no
doubt
,
be
conveyed
by
letter
;
but
there
are
things
on
which
it
is
almost
impossible
for
any
writer
to
express
himself
with
adequate
feeling
;
and
there
are
things
,
too
,
which
can
be
spoken
,
but
which
can
not
be
written
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
though
the
journey
must
be
a
hurried
one
,
Alice
sent
word
down
to
Westmoreland
that
she
was
to
be
expected
there
in
a
day
or
two
.
<EOS>
On
her
return
she
was
to
go
at
once
to
Park
Lane
,
and
sleep
there
for
the
two
nights
which
would
intervene
before
the
departure
of
the
Pallisers
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
day
before
she
started
for
Westmoreland
her
father
came
to
her
in
the
middle
of
the
day
,
and
told
her
that
John
Grey
was
going
to
dine
with
him
in
Queen
Anne
Street
on
that
evening
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
-
day
,
papa
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
Why
not
?
<EOS>
No
man
is
less
particular
as
to
what
he
eats
than
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
thinking
of
that
,
papa
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
To
this
Mr.
Vavasor
made
no
reply
,
but
stood
for
some
minutes
looking
out
of
the
window
.
<EOS>
Then
he
prepared
to
leave
the
room
,
getting
himself
first
as
far
as
the
table
,
where
he
lifted
a
book
,
and
then
on
half
-
way
to
the
door
before
Alice
arrested
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
papa
,
you
and
Mr.
Grey
had
better
dine
alone
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
alone
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
meant
without
me
,
 
as
two
men
generally
like
to
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
wanted
that
I
should
have
asked
him
to
dine
at
the
club
,
"
said
Mr.
Vavasor
,
and
then
he
again
attempted
to
go
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
papa
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
If
you
mean
to
say
that
because
of
what
has
passed
you
object
to
meet
Mr.
Grey
<EOS>
,
I
can
only
tell
you
it
's
nonsense
,
 
confounded
nonsense
.
<EOS>
If
he
chooses
to
come
there
can
be
no
reason
why
you
should
n't
receive
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
look
as
though
 
"
  
"
Look
what
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
though
he
were
asked
as
my
guest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
nonsense
.
<EOS>
I
saw
him
yesterday
,
and
I
asked
him
to
come
.
<EOS>
I
saw
him
again
to
-
day
,
and
he
said
he
would
come
.
<EOS>
He
's
not
such
a
fool
as
to
suppose
after
that
,
that
you
asked
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
not
that
I
asked
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
if
you
run
away
you
'll
only
make
more
of
the
thing
than
it
's
worth
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
ca
n't
make
you
dine
with
me
if
you
do
n't
like
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
did
not
like
it
,
but
,
after
some
consideration
,
she
thought
that
she
might
be
open
to
the
imputation
of
having
made
more
of
the
thing
than
it
was
worth
if
she
ran
away
,
as
her
father
called
it
.
<EOS>
She
was
going
to
leave
the
country
for
some
six
or
eight
months
,
 
perhaps
for
a
longer
time
than
that
,
and
it
might
be
as
well
that
she
should
have
an
opportunity
of
telling
her
plans
to
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
She
could
do
it
,
she
thought
,
in
such
a
way
as
to
make
him
understand
that
her
last
quarrel
with
George
Vavasor
was
not
supposed
to
alter
the
footing
on
which
she
stood
with
him
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
doubt
that
her
father
had
told
everything
to
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
She
knew
well
enough
what
her
father
's
wishes
still
were
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
odd
that
he
should
be
asking
John
Grey
to
his
house
,
though
such
exercises
of
domestic
hospitality
were
very
unusual
with
him
.
<EOS>
But
,
 
so
she
declared
to
herself
,
 
such
little
attempts
on
his
part
would
be
altogether
thrown
away
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
pity
that
he
had
not
yet
learned
to
know
her
better
.
<EOS>
She
would
receive
Mr.
Grey
as
the
mistress
of
her
father
's
house
now
,
for
the
last
time
;
and
then
,
on
her
return
in
the
following
year
,
he
would
be
at
Nethercoats
,
and
the
whole
thing
would
be
over
.
  
<EOS>
She
dressed
herself
very
plainly
,
simply
changing
one
black
frock
for
another
,
and
then
sat
herself
in
her
drawing
-
room
awaiting
the
two
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
It
was
already
past
the
hour
of
dinner
before
her
father
came
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
he
was
in
the
house
,
and
in
her
heart
she
accused
him
of
keeping
out
of
the
way
,
in
order
that
John
Grey
might
be
alone
with
her
.
<EOS>
Whether
or
no
she
were
right
in
her
suspicions
John
Grey
did
not
take
advantage
of
the
opportunity
offered
to
him
.
<EOS>
Her
father
came
up
first
,
and
had
seated
himself
silently
in
his
arm
-
chair
before
the
visitor
was
announced
.
  
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Grey
entered
the
room
Alice
knew
that
she
was
flurried
,
but
still
she
managed
to
carry
herself
with
some
dignity
.
<EOS>
His
bearing
was
perfect
.
<EOS>
But
then
,
as
she
declared
to
herself
afterwards
,
no
possible
position
in
life
would
put
him
beside
himself
.
<EOS>
He
came
up
to
her
with
his
usual
quiet
smile
,
 
a
smile
that
was
genial
even
in
its
quietness
,
and
took
her
hand
.
<EOS>
He
took
it
fairly
and
fully
into
his
;
but
there
was
no
squeezing
,
no
special
pressure
,
no
love
-
making
.
<EOS>
And
when
he
spoke
to
her
he
called
her
Alice
,
as
though
his
doing
so
was
of
all
things
the
most
simply
a
matter
of
course
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
tell
-
tale
hesitation
in
his
voice
.
<EOS>
When
did
he
ever
hesitate
at
anything
?
<EOS>
"
I
hear
you
are
going
abroad
,
"
he
said
,
"
with
your
cousin
,
Lady
Glencora
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Alice
;
"
I
am
going
with
them
for
a
long
tour
.
<EOS>
We
shall
not
return
,
I
fancy
,
till
the
end
of
next
winter
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Plans
of
that
sort
are
as
easily
broken
as
they
are
made
,
"
said
her
father
.
<EOS>
"
You
wo
n't
be
your
own
mistress
;
and
I
advise
you
not
to
count
too
surely
upon
getting
further
than
Baden
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
If
Mr.
Palliser
changes
his
mind
of
course
I
shall
come
home
,
"
said
Alice
,
with
a
little
attempt
at
a
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
him
a
man
not
prone
to
changes
,
"
said
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
But
all
London
is
talking
about
his
change
of
mind
at
this
moment
.
<EOS>
They
say
at
the
clubs
that
he
might
have
been
in
the
Cabinet
if
he
would
,
but
that
he
has
taken
up
this
idea
of
going
abroad
at
the
moment
when
he
was
wanted
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
his
wife
's
doing
<EOS>
,
I
take
it
,
"
said
Mr.
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
worst
of
being
in
Parliament
,
"
said
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
A
man
ca
n't
do
anything
without
giving
a
reason
for
it
.
<EOS>
There
must
be
men
for
public
life
,
of
course
;
but
,
upon
my
word
,
I
think
we
ought
to
be
very
much
obliged
to
them
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
,
as
she
took
her
old
lover
's
arm
,
and
walked
down
with
him
to
dinner
,
thought
of
all
her
former
quarrels
with
him
on
this
very
subject
.
<EOS>
On
this
very
point
she
had
left
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
argued
the
matter
with
her
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
asked
her
to
argue
with
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
condescended
so
far
as
that
.
<EOS>
Had
he
done
so
<EOS>
,
she
thought
that
she
would
have
brought
herself
to
think
as
he
thought
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
striven
,
at
any
rate
,
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
But
she
could
not
become
unambitious
,
tranquil
,
fond
of
retirement
,
and
philosophic
,
without
an
argument
on
the
matter
,
 
without
being
allowed
even
the
poor
grace
of
owning
herself
to
be
convinced
.
<EOS>
If
a
man
takes
a
dog
with
him
from
the
country
up
to
town
,
the
dog
must
live
a
town
life
without
knowing
the
reason
why
;
 
must
live
a
town
life
or
die
a
town
death
.
<EOS>
But
a
woman
should
not
be
treated
like
a
dog
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Had
he
deigned
to
discuss
it
with
me
!
"
<EOS>
Alice
had
so
often
said
.
<EOS>
"
But
,
no
;
he
will
read
his
books
,
and
I
am
to
go
there
to
fetch
him
his
slippers
,
and
make
his
tea
for
him
.
<EOS>
"
All
this
came
upon
her
again
as
she
walked
down
-
stairs
by
his
side
;
and
with

there
came
a
consciousness
that
she
had
been
driven
by
this
usage
into
the
terrible
engagement
which
she
had
made
with
her
cousin
.
<EOS>
That
,
no
doubt
,
was
now
over
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
longer
to
her
any
question
of
her
marrying
George
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
But
the
fact
that
she
had
been
mad
enough
to
think
and

of
such
a
marriage
,
had
of
itself
been
enough
to
ruin
her
.
<EOS>
"
Things
of
that
sort
are
so
often
over
with
you
!
"
<EOS>
After
such
a
speech
as
that
to
her
from
her
father
,
Alice
told
herself
that
there
could
be
no
more
"
things
of
that
sort
"
for
her
.
<EOS>
But
all
her
misery
had
been
brought
about
by
this
scornful
superiority
to
the
ordinary
pursuits
of
the
world
,
 
this
looking
down
upon
humanity
.
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
me
,
"
she
said
,
very
quietly
,
while
her

was
yet
upon
his
arm
,
"
that
your
pity
is
hardly
needed
.
<EOS>
I
should
think
that
no
persons
can
be
happier
than
those
whom
you
call
our
public
men
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
"
said
he
,
"
that
is
our
old
quarrel
.
"
<EOS>
He
said
it
as
though
the

had
simply

an

between
them
,
or
a
dozen

,
 
as
arguments
do

up
between

;
not
as

had
served
to
separate
for
life
<EOS>
two

who
had
loved
each
other

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
old
story
of
the
town
mouse
and
the
country
mouse
,
 
as
old
as
the
hills
.
<EOS>
Mice
may
be
civil
for
a
while
,
and
compliment
each
other
;
but
when
they
come
to
speak
their
minds
freely
,
each
likes
his
own
life
best
.
"
<EOS>
She
said
nothing
more
at
the
moment
,
and
the
three
sat
down
to
their
small

-

.
<EOS>
It
was
astonishing
to
Alice
that
he
should
be
able
to
talk

this

,
to
hint

such

,
to

to
their
former

and

,
without

his

,
or
,
as
far

she
could

,
without
any
feeling
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
said
her
father
,
"
I
ca
n't
compliment
your
cook
upon
her
soup
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
encourage
her
,
papa
,
by
eating
it
often
enough
.
<EOS>
And
then
you
only
told
me
at
two

-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
a
cook
ca
n't
make
soup
between

,
she
ca
n't

in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
Mr.
Grey
will

,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
n't
it
good
?
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
say
that
it
is
,
because
I
should
be
pretending
to
have
an
opinion
;
but
I
should
not
have
found

against

of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
do
you
dine
usually
,
now
you
are
in
London
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Vavasor
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
the
old
club
,
at
the
corner
of
Suffolk
Street
.
<EOS>
It
's
the
oldest
club
in
London
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
I
never
belonged
to
any
other
,
and
therefore
ca
n't
compare
them
;
but
I
ca
n't
imagine
anything
much
nicer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
give
you
better
soup
than
ours
?
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
've
an
excellent
cook
,
"
said
Mr.
Vavasor
,
with
great
gravity
;
"
one
of
the
best
second
-
class
cooks
in
London
.
<EOS>
We
were
very
nearly
getting
him
,
but
you
nicked
him
just
in
time
.
<EOS>
I
know
him
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
great
deal
more
than
I
do
,
or
hope
to
do
.
<EOS>
There
's
another
branch
of
public
life
for
which
I
'm
quite
unfitted
.
<EOS>
I
'd
as
soon
be
called
on
to
choose
a
Prime
Minister
for
the
country
,
as
I
would
a
cook
for
a
club
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
would
,
"
said
Mr.
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
There
may
be
as
many
as
a
dozen

about
London
to
be
looked
up
,
but
there
are
never
more
than
two

Prime
Ministers
about
.
<EOS>
And
as
one
of
them
must
be
going
out
when
the
other
is
coming
in
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't

any

.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
now
-
a
-
days
,
people
do
their
politics
for

,
but
they
expect
to
have
their

for

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
little
dinner
went
on
quietly
and
very

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Vavasor
found
fault
with
nearly
everything
.
<EOS>
But
as
,
on
this

,
the
meat
and
the

,
with
the
manner
of
the
eating
and

,
did
not
constitute
the
difficulty
,
Alice
was
indifferent
to
her
father
's
censures
.
<EOS>
The
thing
needed
was
that
she
and
Mr.
Grey
should
be
able
to
sit
together
at
the
same
table
without
apparent

of
their
former
ties
.
<EOS>
Alice
felt
that
she
was
succeeding
indifferently
well
while
she
was
putting
in
little
mock
defences
for
the
cook
.
<EOS>
And
as
for
John
Grey
,
he
succeeded
so
well
that
his
success
almost
made
Alice
angry
with
him
.
<EOS>
It
required
no
effort
with
him
at
all
to
be
successful
in
this
matter
.
<EOS>
"
If
he
can
forget
all
that
has
passed
,
so
much
the
better
,
"
said
Alice
to
herself
when
she
got
up
into
the
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
Then
she
sat
herself
down
on
the
sofa
,
and
cried
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
what
had
she
not
lost
!
<EOS>
Had
any
woman
ever
been
so
mad
,
so
reckless
,
so
heartless
as
she
had
been
!
<EOS>
And
she
had
done
it
,
knowing
that
she
loved
him
!
<EOS>
She
cried
bitterly
,
and
then
went
away
to
wash
her
eyes
,
that
she
might
be
ready
to
give
him
his
coffee
when
he
should
come
up
-
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
does
not
look
well
,
"
said
Grey
as
soon
as
she
had
left
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
 
no
:
how
can
she
look
well
after
what
she
has
gone
through
?
<EOS>
I
sometimes
think
,
that
of
all
the
people
I
ever
knew
,
she
has
been
the
most
foolish
.
<EOS>
But
,
of
course
,
it
is
not
for
me
to
say
anything
against
my
own
child
;
and
,
of
all

,
not

you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
that
you
could
say
against
her
would
make
any
difference
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
sometimes
fancy
that
I
know
her
better
than
you
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
think
that
she
'll
still
come
round
again
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
say
that
I
think
so
.
<EOS>
No
one
can
venture
to
say
whether
or
not
such
wounds
as
hers
may
be
cured
.
<EOS>
There
are
hearts
and
bodies
so
organized
,
that
in
them
severe
wounds
are
incurable
,
whereas
in
others
no
injury
seems
to
be
fatal
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
say
that
if
she
be
not

it
shall
not

from
want
of
perseverance
on
my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
Grey
,
I
do
n't
know
how
to
thank
you
enough
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
does
n't
seem
to
me
to
be
a
case
for
thanking
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
is
n't
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
well
enough
.
<EOS>
And
in
the
ordinary
way
of
the
world
no
father
would
think
of

a
man
for

.
<EOS>
But

,
that
,

!
<EOS>
I
do

.
<EOS>
I

n't

saying
anything
to
you
,

.
<EOS>
That

is
n't
very

,
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
I

.
<EOS>
I

that

wine
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's

.
<EOS>
What
's

use
of
my
having
good

here
,

?
<EOS>
But
,

I
was

about
Alice
,

've

all
this

.
<EOS>
I
feel
as
though
I
were
responsible
,
and
yet
what

I

?
<EOS>
She
's
her
own

through

.
<EOS>
When

she

that
horrible

,
<EOS>
my

,
what

I

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
over
now
,
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
very

you
to

,
 
very
.
<EOS>
I
believe
she
's
a
good
girl
.
<EOS>
I

,

,
in

it

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
no
doubt
of
her
being
what
you
call
a
good
girl
,
 
none
in
the
least
.
<EOS>
What
she
has
done
to
me
does
not
impair
her
goodness
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
you
have
ever
understood
how
much
all
this
has

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Conscience
!
"
said
the
angry
father
.
<EOS>
"
I
hate
such
conscience
.
<EOS>
I
like
the
conscience
that
makes
a
girl
keep
her
word
,
and
not
bring
disgrace
upon
those
she
belongs
to
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not

am

,
"
said
Grey
,
quietly
,
"
if
she
will
come
and
be
my
wife
.
<EOS>
She
has
meant
to
do
right
,
and
has

other

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
taken
very
little

,
"
said
Mr.
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not

at

trust

to

,
 
if

so
.
<EOS>
But
she
has
been
wounded
sorely
,
and
it
must

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
,

,
what

Mr.
George
Vavasor

?
<EOS>
Two
thousand
pounds
a
quarter
comes
heavy
,
you
know
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
hope
that
he
has
had
enough
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Enough
!
<EOS>
Did
such
a
man
ever
have
enough
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
hope
,
then
,
that
she
thinks
he
has
had
enough
.
<EOS>
Come
;
 
<EOS>
may
I
go
up
-
stairs
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

.
<EOS>
I
'll

.
<EOS>
She

"
  
<EOS>
From

's

<EOS>
Not

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
Mr.

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
The
Rocks
and
Valleys
.
 
<EOS>
During

Mrs.
Greenow

Hall
down

,

<EOS>

"

feast
.
<EOS>
Thanks
to
dear
Greenow
,
"
 
here

was
again
used
 
"

,

never

.
<EOS>
Of

sha
n't

,
 
the
Captain

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
But
,
lord

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
What

's

"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

?
<EOS>
You

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

;

.
<EOS>
And

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Beggars

,

.
"
  
<EOS>

into

.
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
You
see

.
<EOS>
"
Kate
could
not

,

.
<EOS>
"
After

,

may

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

's

,

.
<EOS>
But

to

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
in

,

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.

not

the
Captain
;
but

.
  
<EOS>
Alice
arrived
,
and
,

,

.
<EOS>
Kate
still
wore
her

in

;
but
she
was
able
to
walk
out
,
and
would
take
long

in
spite
of
the
doctor
's

.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
they
went
up
on

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
all
the
walks
from
Vavasor
Hall
led
to
the
mountains
,
unless
one
chose
to

to
Shap
.
<EOS>
But
they
went
up
,
across
the
beacon

,
as

.
<EOS>
There
were
no
questions
asked
between

as
to
the
route
to

;
and
though

not

on

had
once
sat
looking

upon
Haweswater
,
they

reach

upon
which
Kate
had
encountered

.
<EOS>
"
It
was
here
I
fell
,
"
she

;
"
and
the
last

saw
of

was
his

,
as

made

into

,
there
.
<EOS>
When
I
got
upon

legs
I
could
still

.
<EOS>
It
was
one

those

when

are

,
but

.
<EOS>
I

,

,
and

;
but

never

.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
Alice
,
I
fancy

never

again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

suppose

he

with

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can

what
I

!
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
His
figure
against
the
light
was

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Of

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
But

,
 
what

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
he

.
<EOS>
If

!
<EOS>
But
,

,
I
was

.
<EOS>
Of

,

ought

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
The

!
<EOS>
He
should

.
<EOS>
He

given

,

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of

did
.
<EOS>
But

had

judge

.
<EOS>
Alice
,
dear
!
<EOS>
we

;
you

,

;
but

,

,

.
<EOS>
My

been

.
<EOS>
I

,
to

,

.
<EOS>
He

I

,
 
<EOS>
things

;

.
<EOS>
Even

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

will

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
He
has
no

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
longed
for
money
till
the
Devil
has
hardened

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet

tender

;
 
<EOS>
how
soft
he
could

!
<EOS>
Do

he
behaved
to

?
<EOS>
Do

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;
 
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
So

!
<EOS>
So

!
<EOS>
Alice
,
I
would

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

mean

,
Kate
 
"
  
"
I

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Whether

in
Westmoreland
or

,
I
must
have
found

that
my

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

mean

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Would

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Just

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
nothing

than

said
between

about
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
Even

,
Alice
could
not

.
<EOS>
She

never

to
think
,

,

by

to

.
<EOS>
She
was
sure
that
she
had
acted
on
her
own
convictions
of
what
was
right
and
wrong
;
and
now
,
though
she
had
begun
to
feel
that
she
had
been
wrong
,
she
would
hardly
confess
as
much

.
  
<EOS>
They
walked
back
,
down
the
hill
,
to
the
Hall
in
silence
for
the
greater
part
of
the
way
.
<EOS>
Once
or
twice
Kate
repeated
her
conviction
that
she
should
never
again
see
her
brother
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
know
what
may
happen
to
him
,
"
she
said
in
answer
to
her
cousin
's
questions
;
"
but
when
he
was
passing
out
of
my
sight
into
the
valley
,
I
felt
that
I
was
looking
at
him
for
the
last

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
simply
what
people
call
a
presentiment
,
"
Alice

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Exactly
so
;
and
presentiments
,
of
course
,
mean
nothing
,
"
said
Kate
.
  
<EOS>
Then
they
walked
on
towards
the
house
without
further
speech
;
but
when
they
reached
the
end
of
the
little
path
which
led
out
of
the
wood
,
on
to
the
gravelled
sweep
before
the
front
door
,
they
were
both
arrested
by
a
sight
that
met

.
<EOS>
There
was
a
man
standing
,
with
a
cigar
in
his
mouth
,
before
them
,
swinging
a
little
cane
,
and
looking
about
him
up
at
the
wood
.
<EOS>
He
had
on
his
head
a
jaunty
little
straw
-
hat
,
and
he
wore
a
jacket
with
brass
buttons
,
and
white
trousers
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
nearly
the
middle
of
May
,
but
the
summer
does
not
come
to
Westmoreland
so
early
as
that
,
and
the
man
,
as
he
stood
there
looking
about
him
,
seemed
to
be
cold
and
almost
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
as
yet
seen
the
two
girls
,
who
stood
at
the
end
of
the
walk
,
arrested
by
the
sight
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Alice
,
in
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Bellfield
,
"
said
Kate
,
speaking
with
something
very
like

in
her
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
aunt
Greenow
's
Captain
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
aunt
Greenow
's
Captain
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
fearing
this
,
and
now
,
what
on
earth
are
we
to
do
with
him
?
<EOS>
Look
at
him
.
<EOS>
That
's
what
aunt
Greenow
calls
a
sniff
of
the
rocks
and
valleys
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Captain
began
to
move
,
 
just
to
move
,
as
though
it
were
necessary
to
do
something
to
keep
the
life
in
his
limbs
.
<EOS>
He
had
finished
his
cigar
,
and
looked
at
the
end
of
it
with
manifest
regret
.
<EOS>
As
he
threw
it
away
among
a

shrubs
his
eye
fell
upon
the
two
ladies
,
and
he
uttered
a
little

.
<EOS>
Then
he
came
forward
,
waving
his
little
straw
-
hat
in
his

,
and
made
his

.
"
<EOS>
Miss
Vavasor
,
I
am
delighted
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Miss
Alice
Vavasor
,
if
I
am
not
mistaken
?
<EOS>
I
have
been
commissioned
by
my
dear
friend
Mrs.
Greenow
to
go
out
and
seek
you
,
but
,
upon
my
word
,
the
woods
looked
so
black
that
I
did
not
dare
to
venture
;
 
and
then
,
of
course
,
I
should
n't
have
found
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Kate
put
out
her
left
hand
,
and
then
introduced
her
cousin
to
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
Again
he
waved
his
little
straw
-
hat
,
and
strove
to
bear
himself
as
though
he
were
at
home
and
comfortable
.
<EOS>
But
he
failed
,
and
it
was
manifest
that
he
failed
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
the
Bellfield
who
had
conquered
Mr.
Cheesacre
on
the
sands
at
Yarmouth
,
though
he
wore
the
same
jacket
and

,
and
must
now
have
enjoyed
the
internal
satisfaction
of
feeling
that
his
future
maintenance
in
life
was
assured
to
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
not
at
his
ease
.
<EOS>
His
courage
had
sufficed
to
enable
him
to
follow
his
quarry
into
Westmoreland
,
but
it
did
not
suffice
to
make
him
comfortable
while
he
was
there
.
<EOS>
Kate
instantly
perceived
his
condition
,
and
wickedly
resolved
that
she
would
make
no
effort
to
assist
him
.
<EOS>
She
went
through
some
ceremony
of
introduction
,
and
then
expressed
her
surprise
at
seeing
him
so
far
north
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
he
;
"
I
am
a
little

myself
;
 
I
am
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
But
I
had
nothing
to
do

,
 
literally
nothing
;
and
your
aunt

so

me

this

,
"

<EOS>
,
 
"
that
I

.
<EOS>
I

I

,

Vavasor
;
only

say
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
We

,
Captain

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't

;
I
did
n't
indeed
,
miss
!
"
<EOS>
Poor
Captain
Bellfield
was

.
<EOS>
"
I
did
just
put

bag
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
wo

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

Greenow

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

till
 
Saturday
!
"
  
<EOS>
Kate

in

.
<EOS>
The
house
was
her

,
and
not
her
aunt
's
.
<EOS>
But

her

,

.
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

<EOS>
"
We

three

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

,

,

<EOS>
That

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

Cheesacre
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Quite

;
 
very

,

.
<EOS>
That

I

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
Ha
 
ha

<EOS>
That

ladies

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
was
in

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
Very

,

;
 
looking

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

.
<EOS>
We

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

;

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
Kate

.
<EOS>
"
I

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stupid

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

,

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
I

,
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well

.
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
It

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
If

I

.
<EOS>
I

had
Cheesacre
if

,

.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Greenow
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Tears
were
always
easy
with
her
,
but

almost
respected

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sure
I
hope
you
'll

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
he
makes

he
shall

;
"
and
Mrs.
Greenow
,
having

,

,
as
though
upon
this

she
quite
meant

.
  
<EOS>
At
dinner
they
were
not
very
comfortable
.
<EOS>
Either
the
gloomy
air
of
the
place
and
the
neighbourhood
of
the
black
pines
had
depressed
the
Captain
,
or
else
the

of
the

before
him
had

.
<EOS>
He
had
laid
aside
the
jacket
with
the
brass
buttons
,
and
had
dressed
himself
for
dinner
very

.
<EOS>
And
he
behaved
himself
at
dinner
and
after

with
a

,
being
very
unlike
the
Captain
who
had
sat
at

head
of

at
Mrs.
Greenow
's

.
<EOS>
When
left
to
himself
after

he
barely

two

of
the
old
Squire
's
port
wine
before
he

out
into
the
garden
to
join
the
ladies
,
whom
he
had
seen
there
;
and
when
pressed
by
Kate
to
light
a
cigar
he
positively
declined
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
Mrs.
Greenow
had
recovered
her
composure
,
but
Captain
Bellfield
was
still
in
a
rather
disturbed
state
of
mind
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
his
efforts
were
to
be
crowned
with
success
,
and
that
he
was
sure
of
his
wife
,
but
he
did
not
know
how
the
preliminary

were
to
be

,
and
he
did
not
know
what
to
do
with
himself
at
the
Hall
.
<EOS>
After

he
fidgeted
about
in
the
parlour
,
being
unable
to
contrive
for
himself
a
mode
of
escape
,
and
was
absolutely
thrown
upon
his
beam
-
ends
when
the
widow
asked
him
what
he
meant
to
do

between
that
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
I
'd
better
take
a
walk
,
"
he
said
;
"
and
perhaps
the
young
ladies
 
<EOS>
"
  
"
If
you
mean

two
nieces
,
"
said
Mrs.
Greenow
,
"
I
'm
afraid
you
'll
find
they
are
engaged
.
<EOS>
But
if
I
'm
not
too
old
to
walk
with
 
<EOS>
"
The
Captain
assured

that
she

just

for

,
as
far
as
his
taste

,
and

,

.
"
<EOS>
Never

,
Captain
,
"
said

Greenow
.
<EOS>
"
We
'll
have
our
walk
all

,
and
wo
n't
mind
those
young
girls
.
<EOS>
Come
along
.
<EOS>
"
They
started
,
not
up

,
as
Kate
always
did
when
she
walked
in
Westmoreland
,
but

,
and

a

pace
,
as
beseemed
their

,
along
the
road
towards
Shap
.
<EOS>
The
Captain
politely
opened
the
old
gate
for
the
widow
,
and
then
carefully
closed
it
again
,
 
not

it
to
swing
,
as
he
would
have
done
at
Yarmouth
.
<EOS>
Then
he
tripped
up
to
his
place

,
suggested
his
arm
,
which
she
declined
,
and
walked

paces

.
<EOS>
What
on
earth
was
he
to
say
to
her
?
<EOS>
He
had
done
his
love
-
making
successfully
,
and
what
was
he
to
do
next
?
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Captain
Bellfield
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
They
were
walking
very
slowly
,
and
he
was
cutting
the
weeds
by
the
roadside
with
his
cane
.
<EOS>
He
knew
by
her
voice
that
something
special
was
coming
,
so
he
left
the
weeds
and
ranged

close
up

of
her
.
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Captain
Bellfield
,
 
<EOS>
so
I
suppose
I
'm
to
be
good
-
natured
;
am
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Arabella
,
you
'll
make
me
the
happiest
man
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
fudge
.
<EOS>
"
She
would
have
said
,
"
all
rocks
and
valleys
,
"
only
he
would
not
have
understood
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
I
shall
make
you
respectable
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
;
certainly
.
<EOS>
I
quite
intend
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
great

that
you
should

.
<EOS>
Of

I
am
going
to
make

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
;
do
n't
say

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
do
n't
say
it
,
all
my
friends
will
say
it
for
me
.
<EOS>
It
's
lucky
for
you
that
I
do
n't
much

what

say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
It
is
lucky
;
 
I
know
that
I
'm
lucky
.
<EOS>
The
very
first
day
I
saw
you
<EOS>
I
thought
what
a
happy
fellow
I
was
to
meet
you
.
<EOS>
Then
,
of

,
I
was
only

your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Get
along
with
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
yes
.
<EOS>
Come
,
Arabella
,
as
we
are
to
be
man
and
wife
,
you
might
as
well
.
<EOS>
"
At
this

had

,

usual

;
but
she
would

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Out

high

!
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
be
so

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
might
as
well
,
you

,
 
just

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Bellfield
,
I
brought

not

,
but

the
widow
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
different
?
<EOS>
I
ai
n't
different
.
<EOS>
There

,

the

do

.
<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Mrs.

,

?
<EOS>
Inherited

!
<EOS>
Is

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.

"

But

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charlie
Fairstairs
!
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
She
has

,

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
They

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

ca

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
I

,
 
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Bellfield

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Some

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

In

<EOS>

's

.

?
"
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
I
wo

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Three

,

as

!
<EOS>
Indeed
,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

,
 
but

.
<EOS>
Let

,

;
whereas
,

.
<EOS>
Burgo
Fitzgerald
was
a

high

,
and
his

would
have

Mrs.
Greenow
possessed
;
but
with
Captain
Bellfield
she
was

.
  
<EOS>
Upon
the
whole
I
think
that
she
was

in
her

;
or
,

,

.
<EOS>
He
was
no

,
or

;

.
<EOS>
He
was

an

,
who
had
hung
about

,
doing
nothing
,
without

,

,
accustomed
to

,

to

kicked
 
morally
kicked
 
by
such

as
Cheesacre
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
moderate
in
his
greediness
,
and
possessed
of
a

of
the
comfort
of
a
daily
dinner
,
which
might
possibly

to

him
from

very
wide
as
long
as
his
intended
wife
should
be
able
to
keep

purse
-
strings
altogether
in
her

.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
I
say
that
Mrs.
Greenow
had
been
lucky
in
her
choice
,
and
not
altogether

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
of
taking
this
house
,
"
said
she
,
"
and
of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
,

Westmoreland
!
"
said

Captain
,

.
<EOS>
What

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

,
"

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

,

.
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then

.
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In

;

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
She

,

wo

.
<EOS>
"
Then

.
  
<EOS>
Upon

whole

Captain
's
visit
was
satisfactory
 
at
any

the
Captain
.
<EOS>
Everything
was

.
<EOS>
He

to
go
away
on

,

,

have

.
<EOS>
Kate
promised
to

.
<EOS>
There

Charlie
Fairstairs
,
but

.
<EOS>
"
We

,
"
said

widow

,
"

you

,
and

.
<EOS>
And

'll

here
,
and

.
<EOS>
There
's
no

for
two
journeys
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Captain
was
to

over
from
Penrith
twice

week
previous
to

;
or

.
<EOS>
I

,

?
 
<EOS>
whether

all

,

?
  
<EOS>
"
Captain
Bellfield
,
of
Vavasor
Hall
,
Westmoreland
.
<EOS>
It
do

,
"
he

,

.
   
<EOS>
Lady
Monk
's
Plan
.
 
<EOS>
On
the
night
of
Lady
Monk
's
party
,
Burgo
Fitzgerald
disappeared
;
and
when
the

were

and
the

empty
,
his
aunt
inquired
for
him
in

.
<EOS>
The
old

and

of

,

,

Burgo

.
<EOS>
Lady

,

,

with

in

;

saw

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
,

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
But
Burgo
,
as

,

"

.
<EOS>
"

when

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

that

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

,

,

<EOS>
Poor

!
  
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
He

,

"

.

"

"

"
eiress

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pretty

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

.
  
<EOS>
Burgo
from

,

,

and
a

,
into

.
<EOS>
He
had
now
passed
the
position
of
Mr.
Palliser
's

,
having

on
Park

at
a

nearer
to

;
but
he

,
walking
along
by
the
rails
of
the
Park
,
till
he
found
himself
opposite
to

.
<EOS>
Then
he
stood
there
,
leaning
back
upon
the
railings
,
and
looking
up
at
Lady
Glencora
's
windows
.
<EOS>
What
did
he
expect
to
see
?
<EOS>
Or
was
he
,
in
truth
,
moved
by
love
of
that
kind
which
can
take
joy
in
watching
the
slightest
shadow
that
is
made
by
the
one
loved
object
,
 
<EOS>
that
may
be
made
by
her
,
or
,
by
some
violent

of
the
mind
,
may
be
supposed
to
have
been
so

?
<EOS>
Such
love
as
that
is
,
I
think
,
always
innocent
.
<EOS>
Burgo
Fitzgerald
did
not
love
like
that
.
<EOS>
I
almost
doubt
whether
he
can
be
said
to
have
loved
at
all
.
<EOS>
There
was
in
his
breast
a
mixed
,
feverish
desire
,
which
he
took
no
trouble
to
analyse
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
money
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
the
thing
of
which
this
Palliser
had
robbed
him
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
revenge
,
 
though
his
desire
for
that
was
not
a
burning
desire
.
<EOS>
And
among
other
things
,
he
wanted
the
woman
's
beauty
of
the
woman
whom
he
coveted
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
to
kiss
her
again
as
he
had
once
kissed
her
,
and
to
feel
that
she
was
soft
,
and
lovely
,
and
loving
for
him
.
<EOS>
But
as
for
seeing
her
shadow
,
unless
its
movement
indicated
some
purpose
in
his
favour
,
 
I
do
not
think
that
he
cared
much
about
that
.
  
<EOS>
And
why
then
was
he
there
?
<EOS>
Because
in
his
unreasoning
folly
he
did
not
know
what
step
to
take
,
or
what
step
not
to
take
.
<EOS>
There
are
men
whose
energies
hardly
ever
carry
them
beyond
looking
for
the
thing
they
want
.
<EOS>
She
might
see
him
from
the
window
,
and
come
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
say
that
he
thought
that
it
would
be
so
.
<EOS>
I
fancy
that
he
never
thought
at
all
about
that
or
about
anything
.
<EOS>
If
you
lie
under
a
tree
,
and
open
your
mouth
,
a
plum
may
fall
into
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
probably
an
undefined
idea
of
some
such
chance
as
this
which
brought
him
against
the
railings
in
the
front
of
Mr.
Palliser
's

;
that
,
and
a
feeling

that
he
was
better
there
,
out

,

,
than
he
could

elsewhere
.
<EOS>
There
he
stood
and
looked
,
and
cursed
his
ill
-
luck
.
<EOS>
But
his
curses
had
none
of
the
bitterness
of
those
which
George
Vavasor
was
always
uttering
.
<EOS>
Through
it
all
there
remained
about
Burgo
one
honest

,
 
one
conviction
that
was
true
,
 
a
feeling
that
it
all
served
him
right
,
and
that
he
had
better
,
perhaps
,
go
to
the
devil
at
once
,
and
give
nobody
any
more
trouble
.
<EOS>
If
he
loved
no
one
sincerely
,
neither
did
he
hate
any
one
;
and
whenever
he
made
any
self
-

into
his
own

,
he
always
told
himself
that
it
was
all
his
own

.
<EOS>
When
he
cursed
his
fate
,
he
only
did
so
because
cursing
is
so
easy
.
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
would
have
ground
his
victims
up
to
powder
if
he
knew
how
;
but
Burgo
Fitzgerald
desired
to
hurt
no
one
.
  
<EOS>
There
he
stood
till
he
was
cold
,
and
then
,
as
the
plum
did
not

into

mouth
,

.
<EOS>
He
went
up
into
Oxford

,
and

along
it
the
whole
distance
to
the
corner
of
Bond

,
passing

Grosvenor

,
to

.
<EOS>
At
the

,
a
girl
took

,
and

.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
she

,
"
I
saw

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
You
've

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

"

;
"

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
I
ai

.
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
d
 
---
d
if

n't

!
"
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
"
I

?
"
thought

.
"
<EOS>
He

was

before
.
<EOS>
Should
n't
I
like

good

!
"
  
<EOS>
Burgo
went
on
,
and
made
his
way
into
the
house
in
Grosvenor
Square
,
by
some

probably
unknown
to
his
aunt
,
and
certainly

.
<EOS>
He
emptied
his
pockets
as
he
got
into
bed
,
and
counted
a
roll
of
notes
which
he
had
kept
in
one

.
<EOS>
There
were
still
a
hundred
and
thirty
pounds
left
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
had
promised
that
she
would
see
him
again
.
<EOS>
She
had
said
as
much
as
that
quite
distinctly
.
<EOS>
But
what
use
would
there
be
in
that
if
all
his
money
should
then
be
gone
?
<EOS>
He
knew
that
the
keeping
of
money
in
his
pocket
was
to
him
quite
an
impossibility
.
<EOS>
Then
he
thought
of
his
aunt
.
<EOS>
What
should
he
say
to
his
aunt
if
he
saw

in
the
course

the
coming
day
?
<EOS>
Might
it
not
be
as
well
for
him
to
avoid
his
aunt
altogether
?
  
<EOS>
He
breakfasted
up
-
stairs
in
his
bedroom
,
 
in
the
bed
,
indeed
,
eating
a
small
paté
de
foie
gras
from
the

-

,
as

read

French
