?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
she
is
very
happy
.
<EOS>
I
never
get
money
given
to
me
by
handfuls
,
and
the
man
to
whom
I
belong
gives
me
no
encouragement
when
I
want
to
amuse
myself
.
<EOS>
"
They
were
now
standing
near
to
one
end
of
the
table
,
and
suddenly
there
came
to
be
an
opening
through
the
crowd
up
to
the
table
itself
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
leaving
Alice
's
side
,
at
once
stepped
up
and
deposited
a
piece
of
gold
on
one
of
the
marked
compartments
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
placed
it
she
retreated
again
with
flushed
face
,
and
took
hold
of
Alice
's
arm
.
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
she
said
,
"
I
have
done
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
,
in
her
dismay
,
did
not
know
what
step
to
take
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
scold
her
friend
now
,
as
the
eyes
of
many
were
turned
upon
them
,
nor
could
she
,
of
course
,
leave
her
,
as
she
had
threatened
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
laughed
with
her
peculiar
little
low
laughter
,
and
stood
her
ground
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
determined
you
should
n't
frighten
me
out
of
it
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
One
of
the
ministers
at
the
table
had
in
the
meantime
gone
on
with
the
cards
,
and
had
called
the
game
;
and
another
minister
had
gently
pushed
three
or
four
more
pieces
of
gold
up
to
that
which
Lady
Glencora
had
flung
down
,
and
had
then
cunningly
caught
her
eye
,
and
,
with
all
the
courtesy
of
which
he
was
master
,
had
pushed
them
further
on
towards
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
supposed
herself
to
be
unknown
there
in
the
salon
,
but
no
doubt
all
the
croupiers
and
half
the
company
knew
well
enough
who
was
the
new
customer
at
the
table
.
<EOS>
There
was
still
the
space
open
,
near
to
which
she
stood
,
and
then
someone
motioned
to
her
to
come
and
take
up
the
money
which
she
had
won
.
<EOS>
She
hesitated
,
and
then
the
croupier
asked
her
,
in
that
low
,
indifferent
voice
which
these
men
always
use
,
whether
she
desired
that
her
money
should
remain
.
<EOS>
She
nodded
her
head
to
him
,
and
he
at
once
drew
the
money
back
again
to
the
spot
on
which
she
had
placed
the
first
napoleon
.
<EOS>
Again
the
cards
were
turned
up
softly
,
again
the
game
was
called
,
and
again
she
won
.
<EOS>
The
money
was
dealt
out
to
her
,
 
on
this
occasion
with
a
full
hand
.
<EOS>
There
were
lying
there
between
twenty
and
thirty
napoleons
,
of
which
she
was
the
mistress
.
<EOS>
Her
face
had
flushed
before
,
but
now
it
became
very
red
.
<EOS>
She
caught
hold
of
Alice
,
who
was
literally
trembling
beside
her
,
and
tried
to
laugh
again
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
that
in
her
eye
which
told
Alice
that
she
was
really
frightened
.
<EOS>
Some
one
then
placed
a
chair
for
her
at
the
table
,
and
in
her
confusion
,
not
knowing
what
she
was
to
do
,
she
seated
herself
.
<EOS>
"
Come
away
,
"
said
Alice
,
taking
hold
of
her
,
and
disregarding
everything
<EOS>
but
her
own
purpose
,
in
the
agony
of
the
moment
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
come
away
!
<EOS>
You
shall
not
sit
there
!
"
<EOS>
"
I
must
get
rid
of
that
money
,
"
said
Glencora
,
trying
to
whisper
her
words
,
"
<EOS>
and
then
I
will
come
away
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
croupier
again
asked
her
if
the
money
was
to
remain
,
and
she
again
nodded
her
head
.
<EOS>
Everybody
at
the
table
was
now
looking
at
her
.
<EOS>
The
women
especially
were
staring
at
her
,
 
those
horrid
women
with
vermilion
cheeks
,
and
loud
bonnets
half
off
their
heads
,
and
hard
,
shameless
eyes
,
and
white
gloves
,
which
,
when
taken
off
in
the
ardour
of
the
game
,
disclosed
dirty
hands
.
<EOS>
They
stared
at
her
with
that
fixed
stare
which
such
women
have
,
and
Alice
saw
it
all
,
and
trembled
.
  
<EOS>
Again
she
won
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Leave
it
,
"
said
Alice
,
"
and
come
away
.
"
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
leave
it
,
"
said
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
do
,
there
'll
be
a
fuss
.
<EOS>
I
'll
go
the
next
time
.
<EOS>
"
What
she
said
was
,
of
course
,
in
English
,
and
was
probably
understood
by
no
one
near
her
;
but
it
was
easy
to
be
seen
that
she
was
troubled
,
and
,
of
course
,
those
around
her
looked
at
her
the
more
because
of
her
trouble
.
<EOS>
Again
that
little
question
and
answer
went
on
between
her
and
the
croupier
,
and
on
this
occasion
the
money
was
piled
up
on
the
compartment
 
a
heap
of
gold
which
made
envious
the
hearts
of
many
who
stood
around
there
.
<EOS>
Alice
had
now
both
her
hands
on
the
back
of
the
chair
,
needing
support
.
<EOS>
If
the
devil
should
persist
,
and
increase
that
stock
of
gold
again
,
she
must
go
and
seek
for
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
She
knew
not
what
else
to
do
.
<EOS>
She
understood
nothing
of
the
table
,
or
of
its
laws
;
but
she
supposed
all
those
ministers
of
the
game
to
be
thieves
,
and
believed
that
all
villainous
contrivances
were
within
their
capacity
.
<EOS>
She
thought
that
they
might
go
on
adding
to
that
heap
so
long
as
Lady
Glencora
would
sit
there
,
presuming
that
they
might
thus
get
her
into
their
clutches
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
she
did
not
sift
her
suspicions
.
<EOS>
Who
does
at
such
moments
?
<EOS>
"
Come
away
at
once
,
and
leave
it
,
"
she
said
,
"
or
I
shall
go
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At
that
moment
the
croupier
raked
it
all
up
,
and
carried
it
all
away
;
but
Alice
did
not
see
that
this
had
been
done
.
<EOS>
A
hand
had
been
placed
on
her
shoulder
,
and
as
she
turned
round
her
face
her
eyes
met
those
of
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
all
gone
,
"
said
Glencora
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
And
now
she
,
turning
round
,
also
saw
her
husband
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
glad
that
you
are
come
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
Why
did
you
bring
her
here
?
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
There
was
anger
in
his
tone
,
and
anger
in
his
eye
.
<EOS>
He
took
his
wife
's
arm
upon
his
own
,
and
walked
away
quickly
,
while
Alice
followed
them
alone
.
<EOS>
He
went
off
at
once
,
down
the
front
steps
of
the
building
,
towards
the
hotel
.
<EOS>
What
he
said
to
his
wife
,
Alice
did
not
hear
;
but
her
heart
was
swelling
with
the
ill
-
usage
to
which
she
herself
was
subjected
.
<EOS>
Though
she
might
have
to
go
back
alone
to
England
,
she
would
tell
him
that
he
was
ill
-
treating
her
.
<EOS>
She
followed
him
on
,
up
into
their
drawing
-
room
,
and
there
he
stood
with
the
door
open
in
his
hand
for
her
,
while
Lady
Glencora
threw
herself
upon
a
sofa
,
and
burst
out
into
affected
laughter
.
<EOS>
"
Here
's
a
piece
of
work
,
"
she
said
,
"
about
a
little
accident
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
An
accident
!
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
an
accident
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
suppose
that
I
sat
down
there
meaning
to
win
all
that
money
?
"
<EOS>
Whereupon
he
looked
at
her
with
scorn
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Palliser
,
"
said
Alice
,
"
you
have
treated
me
this
evening
in
a
manner
I
did
not
expect
from
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
clear
that
you
blame
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
not
said
a
word
,
Miss
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
you
have
not
said
a
word
.
<EOS>
You
know
well
how
to
show
your
anger
without
speaking
.
<EOS>
As
I
do
not
choose
to
undergo
your
displeasure
,
I
will
return
to
England
by
myself
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Alice
!
<EOS>
Alice
!
<EOS>
"
said
Glencora
,
jumping
up
,
"
that
is
nonsense
!
<EOS>
What
is
all
this
trumpery
thing
about
?
<EOS>
Leave
me
,
because
he
chooses
to
be
angry
about
nothing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
nothing
that
I
find
my
wife
playing
at
a
common
gambling
-
table
,
surrounded
by
all
that
is
wretched
and
vile
,
 
established
there
,
seated
,
with
heaps
of
gold
before
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
wrong
me
,
Plantagenet
,
"
said
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
There
was
only
one
heap
,
and
that
did
not
remain
long
.
<EOS>
Did
it
,
Alice
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
impossible
to
make
you
ashamed
of
anything
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
do
n't
like
being
ashamed
,
"
she
answered
;
"
and
do
n't
feel
any
necessity
on
this
occasion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
object
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
"
said
Alice
,
"
I
will
go
to
bed
.
<EOS>
You
can
think
over
all
this
at
night
,
 
and
so
can
I.
<EOS>
Good
night
,
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
Alice
took
her
candle
,
and
marched
off
to
her
own
room
,
with
all
the
dignity
of
which
she
was
mistress
.
   
<EOS>
From
Baden
to
Lucerne
.
 
<EOS>
The
second
week
in
July
saw
Mr.
Palliser
's
party
,
carriage
and
all
,
established
at
Lucerne
,
in
Switzerland
,
safe
beyond
the
reach
of
the
German
gambling
tables
.
<EOS>
Alice
Vavasor
was
still
with
them
;
and
the
reader
will
therefore
understand
that
that
quarrel
about
Lady
Glencora
's
wickedness
had
been
settled
without
any
rupture
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
settled
amicably
,
and
by
the
time
that
they
had
reached
Lucerne
,
Alice
was
inclined
to
acknowledge
that
the
whole
thing
was
not
worth
notice
;
but
for
many
days
her
anger
against
Mr.
Palliser
had
not
been
removed
,
and
her
intimacy
with
him
had
been
much
checked
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
a
month
since
the
occurrence
of
that
little
scene
in
the
salon
at
Baden
,
which
was
described
in
the
last
chapter
,
 
since
Mr.
Palliser
had
marched
off
with
his
wife
,
leaving
Alice
to
follow
as
she
best
could
by
herself
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
as
the
reader
may
remember
,
he
had
almost
told
her
that
she
was
to
be
blamed
because
of
his
wife
's
indiscretion
;
and
when
she
had
declared
her
intention
of
leaving
him
,
and
making
her
way
home
to
England
by
herself
,
he
had
answered
her
not
at
all
,
and
had
allowed
her
to
go
off
to
her
own
room
under
the
full
ban
of
his
displeasure
.
<EOS>
Since
that
he
had
made
no
apology
to
her
;
he
had
not
,
in
so
many
words
,
acknowledged
that
he
had
wronged
her
;
but
Alice
had
become
aware
that
he
intended
to
apologize
by
his
conduct
,
and
she
had
been
content
so
far
to
indulge
his
obstinacy
as
to
accept
this
conduct
on
his
part
in
lieu
of
any
outspoken
petition
for
pardon
.
<EOS>
The
acknowledgement
of
a
mistake
and
the
asking
for
grace
is
almost
too
much
for
any
woman
to
expect
from
such
a
man
as
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
Early
on
the
morning
after
the
scene
in
question
,
Lady
Glencora
had
gone
into
Alice
's
bedroom
,
and
had
found
her
cousin
in
her
dressing
-
gown
,
packing
up
her
things
,
or
looking
as
though
she
intended
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
such
a
fool
,
"
she
said
,
"
as
to
think
anything
of
what
occurred
yesterday
?
<EOS>
"
Alice
assured
her
that
,
whether
fool
or
not
,
she
did
think
a
great
deal
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
In
point
of
fact
,
"
said
Alice
,
"
I
ca
n't
stand
it
.
<EOS>
He
expects
me
to
take
care
of
you
,
and
chooses
to
show
himself
offended
if
you
do
n't
do
just
what
he
thinks
proper
;
whereas
,
as
you
know
well
enough
,
I
have
not
the
slightest
influence
over
you
.
<EOS>
"
All
these
positions
Lady
Glencora
contradicted
vigorously
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
Mr.
Palliser
had
been
wrong
in
walking
out
of
the
Assembly
Rooms
as
he
had
done
,
leaving
Alice
behind
him
.
<EOS>
So
much
Lady
Glencora
admitted
.
<EOS>
But
this
had
come
of
his
intense
anxiety
.
"
<EOS>
And
you
know
what
a
man
he
is
,
"
said
his
wife
 
<EOS>
"
how
stiff
,
and
hard
,
and
unpleasant
he
can
be
without
meaning
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
reason
why
I
should
bear
his
unpleasantness
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
there
is
,
 
great
reason
.
<EOS>
You
are
to
do
it
for
the
sake
of
friendship
.
<EOS>
And
as
for
my
not
doing
what
you
tell
me
,
you
know
that
's
not
true
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
not
beg
you
to
keep
away
from
the
table
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
did
,
and
of
course
I
was
naughty
;
but
that
was
only
once
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
I
want
you
more
than
I
ever
wanted
you
before
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
tell
you
more
now
,
but
you
must
stay
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
consented
to
come
down
to
breakfast
without
any
immediate
continuance
of
her
active
preparations
for
going
,
and
at
last
,
of
course
,
she
stayed
.
<EOS>
When
she
entered
the
breakfast
-
room
Mr.
Palliser
came
up
to
her
,
and
offered
her
his
hand
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
alternative
but
to
take
it
,
and
then
seated
herself
.
<EOS>
That
there
was
an
intended
apology
in
the
manner
in
which
he
offered
her
toast
and
butter
,
she
was
convinced
;
and
the
special
courtesy
with
which
he
handed
her
to
the
carriage
,
when
she
and
Lady
Glencora
went
out
for
their
drive
,
after
dinner
,
was
almost
as
good
as
a
petition
for
pardon
.
<EOS>
So
the
thing
went
on
,
and
by
degrees
Mr.
Palliser
and
Miss
Vavasor
were
again
friends
.
  
<EOS>
But
Alice
never
knew
in
what
way
the
matter
was
settled
between
Mr.
Palliser
and
his
wife
,
or
whether
there
was
any
such
settling
.
<EOS>
Probably
there
was
none
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
,
he
understands
that
it
did
n't
mean
anything
,
"
Lady
Glencora
had
said
.
<EOS>
"
He
knows
that
I
do
n't
want
to
gamble
.
"
<EOS>
But
let
that
be
as
it
might
,
their
sojourn
at
Baden
was
curtailed
,
and
none
of
the
party
went
up
again
to
the
Assembly
Rooms
before
their
departure
.
  
<EOS>
Before
establishing
themselves
at
Lucerne
they
made
a
little
tour
round
by
the
Falls
of
the
Rhine
and
Zurich
.
<EOS>
In
their
preparations
for
this
journey
,
Alice
made
a
struggle
,
but
a
struggle
in
vain
,
to
avoid
a
passage
through
Basle
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
too
clear
to
her
that
Mr.
Palliser
was
determined
to
go
by
Basle
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
bring
herself
to
say
that
she
had
recollections
connected
with
that
place
which
would
make
a
return
to
it
unpleasant
to
her
.
<EOS>
If
she
could
have
said
as
much
,
even
to
Glencora
,
Mr.
Palliser
would
no
doubt
have
gone
round
,
 
round
by
any
more
distant
route
that
might
have
been
necessary
to
avoid
that
eternal
gateway
into
Switzerland
.
<EOS>
But
she
could
not
say
it
.
<EOS>
She
was
very
averse
to
talking
about
herself
and
her
own
affairs
,
even
with
her
cousin
.
<EOS>
Of
course
Lady
Glencora
knew
the
whole
story
of
Mr.
John
Grey
and
his
rejection
,
 
and
knew
much
also
of
that
other
story
of
Mr.
George
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
And
,
of
course
,
like
all
Alice
's
friends
,
she
hated
George
Vavasor
,
and
was
prepared
to
receive
Mr.
John
Grey
with
open
arms
,
if
there
were
any
possibility
that
her
cousin
would
open
her
arms
to
him
also
.
<EOS>
But
Alice
was
so
stubborn
about
her
own
affairs
that
her
friend
found
it
almost
impossible
to
speak
of
them
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
that
you
trouble
me
,
"
Alice
once
said
,
"
but
that
you
trouble
yourself
about
that
which
is
of
no
use
.
<EOS>
It
is
all
done
and
over
;
and
though
I
know
that
I
have
behaved
badly
,
 
very
badly
,
 
yet
<EOS>
I
believe
that
everything
has
been
done
for
the
best
.
<EOS>
I
am
inclined
to
think
that
I
can
live
alone
,
or
perhaps
with
my
cousin
Kate
,
more
happily
than
I
could
with
any
husband
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
such
nonsense
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
so
;
but
,
at
any
rate
,
I
mean
to
try
.
<EOS>
We
Vavasors
do
n't
seem
to
be
good
at
marrying
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
want
some
one
to
break
your
heart
for
you
;
that
's
what
you
want
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
In
saying
this
she
knew
but
little
of
the
state
of
her
friend
's
heart
,
and
perhaps
was
hardly
capable
of
understanding
it
.
<EOS>
With
all
the
fuss
that
Lady
Glencora
made
to
herself
,
 
with
all
the
tears
that
she
had
shed
about
her
lost
lover
,
and
was
so
often
shedding
,
 
with
all
her
continual
thinking
of
the
matter
,
she
had
never
loved
Burgo
Fitzgerald
as
Alice
Vavasor
had
loved
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
But
her
nature
was
altogether
different
to
that
of
Alice
.
<EOS>
Love
with
her
had
in
it
a
gleam
of
poetry
,
a
spice
of
fun
,
a
touch
of
self
-
devotion
,
something
even
of
hero
-
worship
;
but
with
it
all
there
was
a
dash
of
devilry
,
and
an
aptitude
almost
for
wickedness
.
<EOS>
She
knew
Burgo
Fitzgerald
to
be
a
scapegrace
,
and
she
liked
him
the
better
on
that
account
.
<EOS>
She
despised
her
husband
because
he
had
no
vices
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
given
everything
she
had
to
Burgo
,
 
pouring
her
wealth
upon
him
with
a
total
disregard
of
herself
,
had
she
been
allowed
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
forgiven
him
sin
after
sin
,
and
might
perhaps
have
brought
him
round
,
at
last
,
to
some
life
not
absolutely
reckless
and
wretched
.
<EOS>
But
in
all
that
she
might
have
done
,
there
would
have
been
no
thoughtfulness
,
 
no
true
care
either
for
him
or
for
herself
.
<EOS>
And
now
that
she
was
married
there
was
no
thoughtfulness
,
or
care
either
for
herself
or
for
her
husband
.
<EOS>
She
was
ready
to
sacrifice
herself
for
him
,
if
any
sacrifice
might
be
required
of
her
.
<EOS>
She
believed
herself
to
be
unfit
for
him
,
and
would
have
submitted
to
be
divorced
,
 
or
smothered
out
of
the
way
,
for
the
matter
of
that
,
 
if
the
laws
of
the
land
would
have
permitted
it
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
never
for
a
moment
given
to
herself
the
task
of
thinking
what
conduct
on
her
part
might
be
the
best
for
his
welfare
.
  
<EOS>
But
Alice
's
love
had
been
altogether
of
another
kind
,
 
and
I
am
by
no
means
sure
that
it
was
better
suited
for
the
work
of
this
work
-
a
-
day
world
than
that
of
her
cousin
.
<EOS>
It
was
too
thoughtful
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
say
that
there
was
no
poetry
in
it
,
but
I
will
say
that
it
lacked
romance
.
<EOS>
Its
poetry
was
too
hard
for
romance
.
<EOS>
There
was
certainly
in
it
neither
fun
nor
wickedness
;
nor
was
there
,
I
fear
,
so
large
a
proportion
of
hero
-
worship
as
there
always
should
be
in
a
girl
's
heart
when
she
gives
it
away
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
in
it
an
amount
of
self
-
devotion
which
none
of
those
near
to
her
had
hitherto
understood
,
 
unless
it
were
that
one
to
whom
the
understanding
of
it
was
of
the
most
importance
.
<EOS>
In
all
the
troubles
of
her
love
,
of
her
engagements
,
and
her
broken
promises
,
she
had
thought
more
of
others
than
of
herself
,
 
and
,
indeed
,
those
troubles
had
chiefly
come
from
that
self
-
devotion
.
<EOS>
She
had
left
John
Grey
because
she
feared
that
she
would
do
him
no
good
as
his
wife
,
 
that
she
would
not
make
him
happy
;
and
she
had
afterwards
betrothed
herself
for
a
second
time
to
her
cousin
,
because
she
believed
that
she
could
serve
him
by
marrying
him
.
<EOS>
Of
course
she
had
been
wrong
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
very
wrong
to
give
up
the
man
she
did
love
,
and
more
wrong
again
in
suggesting
to
herself
the
possibility
of
marrying
the
man
she
did
not
love
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
she
had
been
wrong
in
both
,
and
was
undergoing
repentance
with
very
bitter
inward
sackcloth
.
<EOS>
But
she
said
little
of
all
this
even
to
her
cousin
.
  
<EOS>
They
went
to
Lucerne
by
Basle
,
and
put
up
at
the
big
hotel
with
the
balcony
over
the
Rhine
,
which
Alice
remembered
so
well
.
<EOS>
On
the
first
evening
of
her
arrival
she
found
herself
again
looking
down
upon
the
river
,
as
though
it
might
have
been
from
the
same
spot
which
she
had
occupied
together
with
George
and
Kate
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
truth
,
that
house
is
very
large
,
and
has
many
bedrooms
over
the
water
.
<EOS>
Who
has
ever
been
through
Basle
,
and
not
stood
in
one
of
them
,
looking
down
upon
the
father
of
waters
?
<EOS>
Here
,
on
this
very
spot
,
in
one
of
these
balconies
,
was
brought
to
her
a
letter
from
her
cousin
Kate
,
which
was
filled
with
tidings
respecting
her
cousin
George
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
brought
it
to
her
with
his
own
hands
,
and
she
had
no
other
alternative
but
to
read
it
in
his
presence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
George
has
lost
his
election
,
"
the
letter
began
.
<EOS>
For
one
moment
Alice
thought
of
her
money
,
and
the
vain
struggle
in
which
it
had
been
wasted
.
<EOS>
For
one
moment
,
something
like
regret
for
the
futility
of
the
effort
she
had
made
came
upon
her
.
<EOS>
But
it
passed
away
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
worth
our
while
to
try
it
,
"
she
said
to
herself
,
and
then
went
on
with
her
letter
.
<EOS>
"
I
and
Aunt
Greenow
are
up
in
London
,
"
the
letter
went
on
to
say
,
"
and
have
just
heard
the
news
.
<EOS>
Though
I
have
been
here
for
three
days
,
and
have
twice
sent
word
to
him
to
say
so
,
he
has
not
been
near
me
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
is
best
that
he
should
stay
away
,
as
I
do
not
know
how
any
words
could
pass
between
us
that
would
be
pleasant
.
<EOS>
The
poll
was
finished
this
afternoon
,
and
he
lost
his
election
by
a
large
majority
.
<EOS>
There
were
five
candidates
altogether
for
the
two
seats
 
three
Liberals
,
and
two
Conservatives
.
<EOS>
The
other
two
Liberals
were
seated
,
and
he
was
the
last
of
the
five
.
<EOS>
I
continue
to
hear
tidings
about
him
from
day
to
day
,
 
or
rather
,
my
aunt
hears
them
and
tells
them
to
me
,
which
fill
me
full
of
fears
as
to
his
future
career
.
<EOS>
I
believe
that
he
has
abandoned
his
business
,
and
that
he
has
now
no
source
of
income
.
<EOS>
I
would
willingly
share
what
I
have
with
him
;
or
I
would
do
more
than
that
.
<EOS>
After
keeping
back
enough
to
repay
you
gradually
what
he
owes
you
,
I
would
give
him
all
my
share
of
the
income
out
of
the
estate
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
do
this
while
we
are
presumed
to
be
enemies
.
<EOS>
I
am
up
here
to
see
a
lawyer
as
to
some
steps
which
he
is
taking
to
upset
grandpapa
's
will
.
<EOS>
The
lawyer
says
that
it
is
all
nonsense
,
and
that
George
's
lawyer
is
not
really
in
earnest
;
but
I
can
not
do
anything
till
the
matter
is
settled
.
<EOS>
Dear
Alice
,
though
so
much
of
your
money
is
for
a
time
gone
,
I
am
bound
to
congratulate
you
on
your
safety
,
 
on
what
I
may
more
truly
call
your
escape
.
<EOS>
You
will
understand
what
my
own
feelings
must
be
in
writing
this
,
after
all
that
I
did
to
bring
you
and
him
together
,
 
after
all
my
hopes
and
ambition
respecting
him
.
<EOS>
As
for
the
money
,
it
shall
be
repaid
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
I
shall
ever
dare
to
indulge
in
any
strong
desire
again
.
<EOS>
I
think
you
will
forgive
me
the
injury
I
have
done
you
;
 
and
I
know
that
you
will
pity
me
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
here
to
see
the
London
lawyer
,
 
but
not
only
for
that
.
<EOS>
Aunt
Greenow
is
buying
her
wedding
clothes
,
and
Captain
Bellfield
is
in
lodgings
near
to
us
,
also
buying
his
trousseau
;
or
,
as
I
should
more
properly
say
,
having
it
bought
for
him
.
<EOS>
I
am
hardly
in
a
mood
for
much
mirth
,
but
it
is
impossible
not
to
laugh
inwardly
when
she
discusses
before
me
the
state
of
his
wardrobe
,
and
proposes
economical
arrangements
 
greatly
to
his
disgust
.
<EOS>
At
present
,
she
holds
him
very
tightly
in
hand
,
and
makes
him
account
for
all
his
hours
as
well
as
all
his
money
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
,
he
'll
run
wild
<EOS>
directly
he
's
married
,
"
she
said
to
me
,
yesterday
;
"
and
,
of
course
,
there
'll
always
be
a
fight
about
it
;
but
the
more
I
do
to
tame
him
now
,
the
less
wild
he
'll
be
by
-
and
-
by
.
<EOS>
And
though
I
dare
say
,
I
shall
scold
him
sometimes
,
I
shall
never
quarrel
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
all
that
is
true
;
but
what
a
fool
she
is
to
trouble
herself
with
such
a
man
.
<EOS>
She
says
she
does
it
for
an
occupation
.
<EOS>
I
took
courage
to
tell
her
once
that
a
caged
tiger
would
give
her
as
much
to
do
,
and
be
less
dangerous
.
<EOS>
She
was
angry
at
this
,
and
answered
me
very
sharply
.
<EOS>
I
had
tried
my
hand
on
a
tiger
,
she
said
,
and
had
felt
his
claws
.
<EOS>
She
chose
to
sacrifice
herself
,
 
if
a
sacrifice
it
were
to
be
,
 
when
some
good
result
might
be
possible
.
<EOS>
I
had
nothing
further
to
say
;
and
from
that
time
to
this
we
have
been
on
the
pleasantest
terms
possible
as
to
the
Captain
.
<EOS>
They
have
settled
with
your
father
to
take
Vavasor
Hall
for
three
years
,
and
I
suppose
I
shall
stay
with
them
till
your
return
.
<EOS>
What
I
may
do
then
will
depend
entirely
upon
your
doings
.
<EOS>
I
feel
myself
to
be
a
desolate
,
solitary
being
,
without
any
tie
to
any
person
,
or
to
any
place
.
<EOS>
I
never
thought
that
I
should
feel
the
death
of
my
grandfather
to
be
such
a
loss
to
me
as
it
has
been
.
<EOS>
Except
you
,
I
have
nothing
left
to
me
;
and
,
as
regards
you
,
I
have
the
unpleasant
feeling
that
I
have
for
years
been
endeavouring
to
do
you
the
worst
possible
injury
,
and
that
you
must
regard
me
as
an
enemy
from
whom
you
have
escaped
indeed
,
but
not
without
terrible
wounds
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
was
always
angered
by
any
assumption
that
her
conduct
to
Mr.
Grey
had
been
affected
by
the
advice
or
influence
of
her
cousin
Kate
.
<EOS>
But
this
very
feeling
seemed
to
preserve
Kate
from
the
worse
anger
,
which
might
have
been
aroused
against
her
,
had
Alice
acknowledged
the
injury
which
her
cousin
had
in
truth
done
to
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
undoubtedly
true
that
had
Alice
neither
seen
nor
heard
from
Kate
during
the
progress
of
John
Grey
's
courtship
,
John
Grey
would
not
have
lost
his
wife
.
<EOS>
But
against
this
truth
Alice
was
always
protesting
within
her
own
breast
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
weak
,
foolish
,
irresolute
,
 
and
had
finally
acted
with
false
judgement
.
<EOS>
So
much
she
now
admitted
to
herself
.
<EOS>
But
she
would
not
admit
that
any
other
woman
had
persuaded
her
to
such
weakness
.
<EOS>
"
She
mistakes
me
,
"
Alice
thought
,
as
she
put
up
her
letter
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
not
the
enemy
who
has
wounded
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
who
had
brought
her
the
letter
,
was
seated
in
the
same
balcony
,
and
while
Alice
had
been
reading
,
had
almost
buried
himself
in
newspapers
which
conveyed
intelligence
as
to
the
general
elections
then
in
progress
.
<EOS>
He
was
now
seated
with
a
sheet
of
_
<EOS>
The
Times
_
in
his
hand
,
opened
to
its
full
extent
,
 
for
he
had
been
too
impatient
to
cut
the
paper
,
 
and
<EOS>
as
he
held
it
up
in
his
hands
before
his
eyes
,
was
completely
hidden
beneath
it
.
<EOS>
Five
or
six
other
open
papers
were
around
him
,
and
he
had
not
spoken
a
word
since
he
had
commenced
his
present
occupation
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
standing
on
the
other
side
of
him
,
and
she
also
had
received
letters
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Sophy
tells
me
that
you
are
returned
for
Silverbridge
,
"
she
said
at
last
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
?
<EOS>
I
!
<EOS>
yes
<EOS>
;
I
'm
returned
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
speaking
with
something
like
disdain
in
his
voice
as
to
the
possibility
of
anybody
having
stood
with
a
chance
of
success
against
him
in
his
own
family
borough
.
<EOS>
For
a
full
appreciation
of
the
advantages
of
a
private
seat
in
the
House
of
Commons
let
us
always
go
to
those
great
Whig
families
who
were
mainly
instrumental
in
carrying
the
Reform
Bill
.
<EOS>
The
house
of
Omnium
had
been
very
great
on
that
occasion
.
<EOS>
It
had
given
up
much
,
and
had
retained
for
family
use
simply
the
single
seat
at
Silverbridge
.
<EOS>
But
that
that
seat
should
be
seriously
disputed
hardly
suggested
itself
as
possible
to
the
mind
of
any
Palliser
.
<EOS>
The
Pallisers
and
the
other
great
Whig
families
have
been
right
in
this
.
<EOS>
They
have
kept
in
their
hands
,
as
rewards
for
their
own
services
to
the
country
,
no
more
than
the
country
is
manifestly
willing
to
give
them
.
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
I
have
been
returned
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sorry
to
see
,
Miss
Vavasor
,
that
your
cousin
has
not
been
so
fortunate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
find
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
a
great
misfortune
to
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
suppose
so
.
<EOS>
Those
Metropolitan
elections
cost
so
much
trouble
and
so
much
money
,
and
under
the
most
favourable
circumstances
,
are
so
doubtful
.
<EOS>
A
man
is
never
sure
there
till
he
has
fought
for
his
seat
three
or
four
times
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
has
been
the
third
time
with
him
,
"
said
Alice
,
"
and
he
is
a
poor
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
who
himself
knew
nothing
of
such
misfortunes
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
always
thought
that
those
seats
should
be
left
to
rich
commercial
men
who
can
afford
to
spend
money
upon
them
.
<EOS>
Instead
of
that
,
they
are
generally
contested
by
men
of
moderate
means
.
<EOS>
Another
of
my
friends
in
the
House
has
been
thrown
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
that
unfortunate
?
"
asked
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Bott
,
"
said
the
unthinking
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Bott
out
!
"
exclaimed
Lady
Glencora
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
thrown
out
!
<EOS>
I
am
so
glad
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
are
you
not
glad
?
<EOS>
The
red
-
haired
man
,
that
used
to
stand
about
,
you
know
,
at
Matching
;
 
he
has
lost
his
seat
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
he
'll
go
and
stand
about
somewhere
in
Lancashire
,
now
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
very
indiscreet
woman
was
poor
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
's
face
became
black
beneath
_
<EOS>
The
Times
_
newspaper
.
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
know
,
"
said
he
,
"
that
my
friend
Mr.
Bott
and
Miss
Vavasor
were
enemies
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Enemies
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
suppose
they
were
enemies
,
"
said
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
But
he
was
a
man
whom
no
one
could
help
observing
,
 
and
disliking
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
was
a
man
I
specially
disliked
,
"
said
Alice
,
with
great
courage
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
may
be
very
well
in
Parliament
;
but
I
never
met
a
man
who
could
make
himself
so
disagreeable
in
society
.
<EOS>
I
really
did
feel
myself
constrained
to
be
his
enemy
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Bravo
,
Alice
!
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
he
did
nothing
at
Matching
,
to
 
to
 
to
 
,
"
began
Mr.
Palliser
,
apologetically
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
especially
to
offend
me
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
 
except
that
he
had
a
way
that
I
especially
dislike
of
trying
to
make
little
secret
confidences
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
then
he
was
so
ugly
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
felt
certain
that
he
endeavoured
to
do
mischief
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
he
did
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
;
"
and
he
had
a
habit
of
rubbing
his
head
against
the
papers
in
the
rooms
,
and
leaving
a
mark
behind
him
that
was
quite
unpardonable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
effectually
talked
down
,
and
felt
himself
constrained
to
abandon
his
political
ally
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
did
this
the
easier
as
the
loss
which
Mr.
Bott
had
just
suffered
would
materially
interfere
with
his
political
utility
.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
he
will
remain
now
among
his
own
people
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
hope
he
will
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
 
"
and
that
his
own
people
will
appreciate
the
advantage
of
his
presence
.
<EOS>
"
Then
there
was
nothing
more
said
about
Mr.
Bott
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
evening
,
and
while
they
were
still
sitting
among
their
letters
and
newspapers
,
there
came
a
shout
along
the
water
,
and
the
noise
of
many
voices
from
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
there
shot
down
before
them
in
the
swift
running
stream
the
heads
of
many
swimmers
in
the
river
,
and
with
the
swimmers
came
boats
carrying
their
clothes
.
<EOS>
They
went
by
almost
like
a
glance
of
light
upon
the
waters
,
so
rapid
was
the
course
of
the
current
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
shout
of
voices
,
 
the
quick
passage
of
the
boats
,
 
the
uprising
,
some
half
a
dozen
times
,
of
the
men
's
hands
above
the
surface
;
and
then
they
were
gone
down
the
river
,
out
of
sight
,
 
like
morsels
of
wood
thrown
into
a
cataract
,
which
are
borne
away
instantly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
how
I
wish
I
could
do
that
!
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
be
very
dangerous
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
they
can
stop
themselves
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
they
want
to
stop
themselves
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
Think
how
cool
the
water
must
be
,
and
how
beautiful
to
be
carried
along
so
quickly
,
and
to
go
on
,
and
on
,
and
on
!
<EOS>
I
suppose
we
could
n't
try
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
As
no
encouragement
was
given
to
this
proposition
,
Lady
Glencora
did
not
repeat
it
;
but
stood
leaning
on
the
rail
of
the
balcony
,
and
looking
enviously
down
upon
the
water
.
<EOS>
Alice
was
,
of
course
,
thinking
of
that
other
evening
,
when
perhaps
the
same
swimmers
had
come
down
under
the
bridge
and
before
the
balcony
,
and
where
George
Vavasor
was
sitting
in
her
presence
.
<EOS>
It
was
,
I
think
,
on
that
evening
,
that
she
made
up
her
mind
to
separate
herself
from
Mr.
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
day
after
that
,
Mr.
Palliser
and
his
party
went
on
to
Lucerne
,
making
that
journey
,
as
I
have
said
,
by
slow
stages
;
taking
Schaffhausen
and
Zurich
in
their
way
.
<EOS>
At
Lucerne
,
they
established
themselves
for
some
time
,
occupying
nearly
a
dozen
rooms
in
the
great
hotel
which
overlooks
the
lake
.
<EOS>
Here
there
came
to
them
a
visitor
,
of
whose
arrival
I
will
speak
in
the
next
chapter
.
   
<EOS>
At
Lucerne
.
 
<EOS>
I
am
inclined
to
think
that
Mr.
Palliser
did
not
much
enjoy
this
part
of
his
tour
abroad
.
<EOS>
When
he
first
reached
Lucerne
there
was
no
one
there
with
whom
he
could
associate
pleasantly
,
nor
had
he
any
occupation
capable
of
making
his
time
run
easily
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
care
for
scenery
.
<EOS>
Close
at
his
elbow
was
the
finest
to
be
had
in
Europe
;
but
it
was
nothing
to
him
.
<EOS>
Had
he
been
simply
journeying
through
Lucerne
at
the
proper
time
of
the
year
for
such
a
journey
,
when
the
business
of
the
Session
was
over
,
and
a
little
change
of
air
needed
,
he
could
have
enjoyed
the
thing
in
a
moderate
way
,
looking
about
him
,
passing
on
,
and
knowing
that
it
was
good
for
him
to
be
there
at
that
moment
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
none
of
that
passion
for
mountains
and
lakes
,
none
of
that
positive
joy
in
the
heather
,
which
would
have
compensated
many
another
man
for
the
loss
of
all
that
Mr.
Palliser
was
losing
.
<EOS>
His
mind
was
ever
at
home
in
the
House
of
Commons
,
or
in
that
august
assembly
which
men
call
the
Cabinet
,
and
of
the
meetings
of
which
he
read
from
week
to
week
the
simple
records
.
<EOS>
Therein
were
mentioned
the
names
of
those
heroes
to
whom
Fortune
had
been
so
much
kinder
than
she
had
been
to
him
;
and
he
envied
them
.
<EOS>
He
took
short
,
solitary
walks
,
about
the
town
,
over
the
bridges
,
and
along
the
rivers
,
making
to
himself
the
speeches
which
he
would
have
made
to
full
houses
,
had
not
his
wife
brought
ruin
upon
all
his
hopes
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
pictured
to
himself
the
glorious
successes
which
probably
never
would
have
been
his
had
he
remained
in
London
,
so
did
he
prophesy
to
himself
an
absolute
and
irremediable
downfall
from
all
political
power
as
the
result
of
his
absence
,
 
having
,
in
truth
,
no
sufficient
cause
for
such
despair
.
<EOS>
As
yet
,
he
was
barely
thirty
,
and
had
he
been
able
to
judge
his
own
case
as
keenly
as
he
could
have
judged
the
case
of
another
,
he
would
have
known
that
a
short
absence
might
probably
raise
his
value
in
the
estimation
of
others
rather
than
lower
it
.
<EOS>
But
his
personal
annoyance
was
too
great
to
allow
of
his
making
such
calculations
aright
.
<EOS>
So
he
became
fretful
and
unhappy
;
and
though
he
spoke
no
word
of
rebuke
to
his
wife
,
though
he
never
hinted
that
she
had
robbed
him
of
his
glories
,
he
made
her
conscious
by
his
manner
that
she
had
brought
him
to
this
miserable
condition
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
herself
had
a
love
for
the
mountains
and
lakes
,
but
it
was
a
love
of
that
kind
which
requires
to
be
stimulated
by
society
,
and
which
is
keenest
among
cold
chickens
,
picnic
-
pies
,
and
the
flying
of
champagne
corks
.
<EOS>
When
they
first
entered
Switzerland
she
was
very
enthusiastic
,
and
declared
her
intention
of
climbing
up
all
the
mountains
,
and
going
through
all
the
passes
.
<EOS>
She
endeavoured
to
induce
her
husband
to
promise
that
she
should
be
taken
up
Mont
Blanc
.
<EOS>
And
I
think
she
would
have
carried
this
on
,
and
would
have
been
taken
up
Mont
Blanc
,
had
Mr.
Palliser
's
aspirations
been
congenial
.
<EOS>
But
they
were
not
congenial
,
and
Lady
Glencora
soon
lost
all
her
enthusiasm
.
<EOS>
By
the
time
that
they
were
settled
at
Lucerne
she
had
voted
the
mountains
to
be
bores
,
and
had
almost
learned
to
hate
the
lake
,
which
she
declared
always
made
her
wet
through
when
she
got
into
a
small
boat
,
and
sea
-
sick
when
she
put
her
foot
in
a
large
one
.
<EOS>
At
Lucerne
they
made
no
acquaintances
,
Mr.
Palliser
being
a
man
not
apt
to
new
friendships
.
<EOS>
They
did
not
even
dine
at
the
public
table
,
though
Lady
Glencora
had
expressed
a
wish
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
did
not
like
it
,
and
of
course
Lady
Glencora
gave
way
.
<EOS>
There
were
,
moreover
,
some
marital
passages
which
were
not
pleasant
to
a
third
person
.
<EOS>
They
did
not
scold
each
other
;
but
Lady
Glencora
would
make
little
speeches
of
which
her
husband
disapproved
.
<EOS>
She
would
purposely
irritate
him
by
continuing
her
tone
of
badinage
,
and
then
Mr.
Palliser
would
become
fretful
,
and
would
look
as
though
the
cares
of
the
world
were
too
many
for
him
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
,
therefore
,
say
that
Alice
had
much
to
make
the
first
period
of
her
sojourn
at
Lucerne
a
period
of
enjoyment
.
  
<EOS>
But
when
they
had
been
there
about
a
fortnight
,
a
stranger
arrived
,
whose
coming
at
any
rate
lent
the
grace
of
some
excitement
to
their
lives
.
<EOS>
Their
custom
was
to
breakfast
at
nine
,
 
or
as
near
nine
as
Lady
Glencora
could
be
induced
to
appear
,
 
and
then
Mr.
Palliser
would
read
till
three
.
<EOS>
At
that
hour
he
would
walk
forth
by
himself
,
after
having
handed
the
two
ladies
into
their
carriage
,
and
they
would
be
driven
about
for
two
hours
.
<EOS>
"
How
I
do
hate
this
carriage
,
"
Lady
Glencora
said
one
day
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
so
wish
it
would
come
to
grief
,
and
be
broken
to
pieces
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
the
Swiss
people
think
that
we
are
going
to
be
driven
about
here
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
There
were
moments
,
however
,
which
seemed
to
indicate
that
Lady
Glencora
had
something
to
tell
her
cousin
,
which
,
if
told
,
would
alter
the
monotony
of
their
lives
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
however
,
would
not
press
her
for
her
secret
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
anything
to
tell
,
why
do
n't
you
tell
it
?
"
<EOS>
Alice
once
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
so
hard
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
you
tell
me
very
often
,
"
Alice
replied
;
"
and
it
is
not
complimentary
.
<EOS>
But
hard
or
soft
,
I
wo
n't
make
a
petition
for
your
confidence
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Glencora
said
something
savage
,
and
the
subject
was
dropped
for
a
while
.
  
<EOS>
But
we
must
go
back
to
the
stranger
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
put
the
ladies
into
their
carriage
,
and
was
standing
between
the
front
door
of
the
hotel
and
the
lake
on
a
certain
day
,
doubting
whether
he
would
walk
up
the
hill
to
the
left
or
turn
into
the
town
on
the
right
,
when
he
was
accosted
by
an
English
gentleman
,
who
,
raising
his
hat
,
said
that
he
believed
that
he
spoke
to
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
Mr.
Palliser
,
"
said
our
friend
,
very
courteously
,
returning
the
salute
,
and
smiling
as
he
spoke
.
<EOS>
But
though
he
smiled
,
and
though
he
was
courteous
,
and
though
he
raised
his
hat
,
there
was
something
in
his
look
and
voice
which
would
not
have
encouraged
any
ordinary
stranger
to
persevere
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
not
a
man
with
whom
it
was
easy
to
open
an
acquaintance
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
John
Grey
,
"
said
the
stranger
.
  
<EOS>
Then
the
smile
was
dropped
,
the
look
of
extreme
courtesy
disappeared
,
the
tone
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
voice
was
altered
,
and
he
put
out
his
hand
.
<EOS>
He
knew
enough
of
Mr.
John
Grey
's
history
to
be
aware
that
Mr.
John
Grey
was
a
man
with
whom
he
might
permit
himself
to
become
acquainted
.
<EOS>
After
the
interchange
of
a
very
few
words
,
the
two
men
started
off
for
a
walk
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
do
n't
wish
to
meet
the
carriage
?
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
If
so
,
we
had
better
go
through
the
town
and
up
the
river
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
went
through
the
town
,
and
up
the
river
,
and
when
Mr.
Palliser
,
on
his
return
,
was
seen
by
Alice
and
Lady
Glencora
,
he
was
alone
.
<EOS>
They
dined
together
,
and
nothing
was
said
.
<EOS>
Together
they
sauntered
out
in
the
evening
,
and
together
came
in
and
drank
their
tea
;
but
still
nothing
was
said
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
Alice
and
her
cousin
took
their
candles
from
Mr.
Palliser
's
hands
and
left
the
sitting
-
room
for
the
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
as
soon
as
they
were
in
the
passage
together
,
"
I
have
been
dying
for
this
time
to
come
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
speak
before
,
or
I
should
have
made
blunders
,
and
so
would
you
.
<EOS>
Let
us
go
into
your
room
at
once
.
<EOS>
Who
do
you
think
is
here
,
at
Lucerne
,
in
this
house
,
at
this
very
moment
?
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
knew
at
once
who
it
was
.
<EOS>
She
knew
,
immediately
,
that
Mr.
Grey
had
followed
her
,
though
no
word
had
been
written
to
her
or
spoken
to
her
on
the
subject
since
that
day
on
which
he
himself
had
told
her
that
they
would
meet
abroad
.
<EOS>
But
though
she
was
quite
sure
,
she
did
not
mention
his
name
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
is
it
,
Glencora
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
,
very
calmly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whom
in
all
the
world
would
you
best
like
to
see
?
"
said
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
cousin
Kate
,
certainly
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
it
is
not
your
cousin
Kate
.
<EOS>
And
I
do
n't
believe
you
;
 
or
else
you
're
a
fool
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
was
accustomed
to
Lady
Glencora
's
mode
of
talking
,
and
therefore
did
not
think
much
of
this
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
am
a
fool
,
"
she
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Only
I
know
you
are
not
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
at
all
so
sure
as
to
your
being
no
hypocrite
.
<EOS>
The
person
I
mean
is
a
gentleman
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
Why
do
n't
you
show
a
little
excitement
,
at
any
rate
?
<EOS>
When
Plantagenet
told
me
,
just
before
dinner
,
I
almost
jumped
out
of
my
shoes
.
<EOS>
He
was
going
to
tell
you
himself
after
dinner
,
in
the
politest
way
in
the
world
,
no
doubt
,
and
just
as
the
servants
were
carrying
away
the
apples
.
<EOS>
I
thought
it
best
to
save
you
from
that
;
but
,
I
declare
,
I
believe
I
might
have
left
him
to
do
it
;
it
would
have
had
no
effect
upon
you
.
<EOS>
Who
is
it
that
has
come
,
do
you
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
know
now
,
"
said
Alice
,
very
calmly
,
"
that
Mr.
John
Grey
has
come
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mr.
John
Grey
has
come
.
<EOS>
He
is
here
in
this
house
at
this
minute
;
 
or
,
more
probably
,
waiting
outside
by
the
lake
till
he
shall
see
a
light
in
your
bedroom
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Glencora
paused
for
a
moment
,
waiting
that
Alice
might
say
something
.
<EOS>
But
Alice
said
nothing
.
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
rising
up
from
her
chair
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
nothing
to
say
?
<EOS>
Is
it
the
same
to
you
as
though
Mr.
Smith
had
come
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
not
exactly
the
same
.
<EOS>
I
am
quite
alive
to
the
importance
of
Mr.
Grey
's
arrival
,
and
shall
probably
lie
awake
all
night
thinking
about
it
,
 
if
it
will
do
you
any
good
to
know
that
;
but
I
do
n't
feel
that
I
have
much
to
say
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
had
let
Mr.
Palliser
tell
you
,
in
an
ordinary
way
,
before
all
the
servants
.
<EOS>
I
do
indeed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
not
have
made
much
difference
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
the
least
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
you
ever
did
care
for
anybody
in
your
life
,
 
for
him
,
or
for
that
other
one
,
or
for
anybody
.
<EOS>
For
nobody
,
I
believe
;
 
except
your
cousin
Kate
.
<EOS>
Still
waters
,
they
say
,
run
deep
;
and
sometimes
I
think
your
waters
run
too
deep
for
me
to
fathom
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
may
go
now
,
if
you
have
got
nothing
more
to
say
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
me
to
say
?
<EOS>
Of
course
I
know
why
he
has
come
here
.
<EOS>
He
told
me
he
should
come
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
never
said
a
word
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
told
me
he
should
come
,
and
I
thought
it
better
not
to
say
a
word
about
it
.
<EOS>
He
might
change
his
mind
,
or
anything
might
happen
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
not
to
come
;
and
it
would
have
been
much
better
that
he
should
have
remained
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
;
 
why
;
 
why
would
it
be
better
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
his
being
here
will
do
no
good
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
good
!
<EOS>
It
seems
to
me
impossible
but
that
it
should
do
all
the
good
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
Look
here
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
If
you
do
not
altogether
make
it
up
with
him
before
to
-
morrow
evening
,
I
shall
believe
you
to
be
utterly
heartless
.
<EOS>
Had
I
been
you
<EOS>
I
should
have
been
in
his
arms
before
this
.
<EOS>
I
'll
go
now
,
and
leave
you
to
lie
awake
,
as
you
say
you
will
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
she
left
the
room
,
but
returned
in
a
moment
to
ask
another
question
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
Plantagenet
to
say
to
him
about
seeing
you
to
-
morrow
?
<EOS>
Of
course
he
has
asked
permission
to
come
and
call
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
He
may
come
if
he
pleases
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
think
I
have
quarrelled
with
him
,
or
would
refuse
to
see
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
may
we
ask
him
to
dine
with
us
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
make
up
a
picnic
,
and
all
the
rest
of
it
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
he
is
to
be
regarded
as
only
an
ordinary
person
.
<EOS>
Well
;
 
good
night
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
understand
you
,
that
's
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
may
be
doubted
whether
Alice
understood
herself
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
her
friend
was
gone
,
she
put
out
her
candle
and
seated
herself
at
the
open
window
of
her
room
,
looking
out
upon
the
moonlight
as
it
played
upon
the
lake
.
<EOS>
Would
he
be
there
,
thinking
of
her
,
looking
up
,
perhaps
,
as
Glencora
had
hinted
,
to
see
if
he
could
distinguish
her
light
among
the
hundred
that
would
be
flickering
across
the
long
front
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
so
,
at
any
rate
he
should
not
see
her
,
so
she
drew
the
curtain
,
and
sat
there
watching
the
lake
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
pity
that
he
should
have
come
,
and
yet
she
loved
him
dearly
for
coming
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
pity
that
he
should
have
come
,
as
his
coming
could
lead
to
no
good
result
.
<EOS>
Of
this
she
assured
herself
over
and
over
again
,
and
yet
she
hardly
knew
why
she
was
so
sure
of
it
.
<EOS>
Glencora
had
called
her
hard
;
but
her
conviction
on
that
matter
had
not
come
from
hardness
.
<EOS>
Now
that
she
was
alone
,
her
heart
was
full
of
love
,
of
the
soft
romance
of
love
towards
this
man
;
and
yet
she
felt
that
she
ought
not
to
marry
him
,
even
though
he
might
still
be
willing
to
take
her
.
<EOS>
That
he
was
still
willing
to
take
her
,
that
he
desired
to
have
her
for
his
wife
in
spite
of
all
the
injury
she
had
done
him
,
there
could
be
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
Why
else
had
he
followed
her
to
Switzerland
?
<EOS>
And
she
remembered
,
now
at
this
moment
,
how
he
had
told
her
at
Cheltenham
that
he
would
never
consider
her
to
be
lost
to
him
,
unless
she
should
,
in
truth
,
become
the
wife
of
another
man
.
<EOS>
Why
,
then
,
should
it
not
be
as
he
wished
it
?
  
<EOS>
She
asked
herself
the
question
,
and
did
not
answer
it
;
but
still
she
felt
that
it
might
not
be
so
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
right
to
such
happiness
after
the
evil
that
she
had
done
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
driven
by
a
frenzy
to
do
that
which
she
herself
could
not
pardon
;
and
having
done
it
,
she
could
not
bring
herself
to
accept
the
position
which
should
have
been
the
reward
of
good
conduct
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
analyse
the
causes
which
made
her
feel
that
she
must
still
refuse
the
love
that
was
proffered
to
her
;
she
could
not
clearly
read
her
own
thoughts
;
but
the
causes
were
as
I
have
said
,
and
such
was
the
true
reading
of
her
thoughts
.
<EOS>
Had
she
simply
refused
his
hand
after
she
had
once
accepted
it
,
 
had
she
refused
it
,
and
then
again
changed
her
mind
,
she
could
have
brought
herself
to
ask
him
to
forgive
her
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
done
so
much
more
than
this
,
and
so
much
worse
!
<EOS>
She
had
affianced
herself
to
another
man
since
she
had
belonged
to
him
,
 
since
she
had
been
his
,
as
his
future
wife
.
<EOS>
What
must
he
not
think
of
her
,
and
what
not
suspect
?
<EOS>
Then
she
remembered
those
interviews
which
she
had
had
with
her
cousin
since
she
had
written
to
him
,
accepting
his
offer
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
been
with
her
in
Queen
Anne
Street
she
had
shrunk
from
all
outward
signs
of
a
love
which
she
did
not
feel
.
<EOS>
There
had
been
no
caress
between
them
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
allowed
him
to
touch
her
with
his
lips
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
impossible
that
the
nature
of
that
mad
engagement
between
her
and
her
cousin
George
should
ever
be
made
known
to
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
She
sat
there
wiping
the
tears
from
her
eyes
as
she
looked
for
his
figure
among
the
figures
by
the
lake
-
side
;
but
,
as
she
sat
there
,
she
promised
herself
no
happiness
from
his
coming
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
reader
,
can
you
forgive
her
in
that
she
had
sinned
against
the
softness
of
her
feminine
nature
?
<EOS>
I
think
that
she
may
be
forgiven
,
in
that
she
had
never
brought
herself
to
think
lightly
of
her
own
fault
.
  
<EOS>
If
he
were
there
,
by
the
lake
-
side
,
she
did
not
see
him
.
<EOS>
I
think
we
may
say
that
John
Grey
was
not
a
man
to
console
himself
in
his
love
by
looking
up
at
his
lady
's

.
<EOS>
He
was
one
who
was
capable
of
doing
as
much
as
most
men
in
the
pursuit
of
his
love
,
 
as
he
proved
to
be
the
case
when

Alice
to

,

,
and

;
but

a

,

,

of

might

,

.
<EOS>
He
had
come

with

,
which

,
if

,

;
but
I

already

,

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
At

the

morning
nothing

.
<EOS>
At
last
Mr.
Palliser

.
"
<EOS>
Glencora
has
told

,

,

?
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey

?
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
,

,

Grey
had
been
,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
knew

,
and
what

use

any

dissimulation
?
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
glad
to
see

,
 
if
you

allow

?
<EOS>
"
she
went
on
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Glencora

,
"

;
and

.
  
<EOS>
But

did
not

.
<EOS>
Early

his
card

,

Lady

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed

need

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
I
shall
go
,
"
said
her

.
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
's
proper
on
these

,
if
you
do
n't
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
she
went
,
whisking

along
the

with
a
little

;
and
Mr.
Grey
,
as

her

,
saw

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
took

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

"
<EOS>
but

"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
;

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No

;
<EOS>
no
.
<EOS>
I

,
and
,

none

.
<EOS>
I

;
and

Asia

Africa
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
You

a

John
Bull
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

my

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

<EOS>
"
But
I

,

.
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

;

.
<EOS>
What

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Other

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Indeed

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
These

,

;

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.

<EOS>
Soon

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

,
"

"
the

.
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
In

,

,

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So

Mr.
Palliser
's

that

.
<EOS>
But
he
bethought

of
the
blood

Pallisers
,
and

.
<EOS>
There
are
comforts
which
royalty
may
never
enjoy
,
and
luxuries
in
which
such
men
as
Plantagenet
Palliser
may
not

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
About
her
and
her
character
I
have

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
In
all

she

I

I

;
and
though
I

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
Had

,
I

,
 
though
I

all

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Living

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
Whereupon
,

.
<EOS>
"
I
think

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
said

,
though
what
ground
he
had
for
such

<EOS>
I
am
quite
unable

surmise
.
<EOS>
He
was
probably
desirous
of
saying
the
most

which

.
  
<EOS>
The
little

-

that

was
pleasant
enough
,
and
nothing
more

said

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
talked
nonsense
to
Mr.
Grey
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
contradicted
all
the

his
wife

.
<EOS>
But
this
was
all

in

that

passed
away

.
<EOS>
It
was

that
Mr.
Grey
was

come
among

,
and

to
him
aside
,
in

.
   
<EOS>
Showing
How
George
Vavasor
Received
a
Visit
.
 
<EOS>
We
must
go
back
for
a
few
pages
to
scenes
which
happened
in
London
during
this
summer
,
so
that
the
reader
may
understand
Mr.
Grey
's
position
when
he
reached
Lucerne
.
<EOS>
He
had
undergone
another
quarrel
with
George
Vavasor
,
and
something
of
the
circumstances
of
that
quarrel
must
be
told
.
  
<EOS>
It
has
been
already
said
that
George
Vavasor
lost
his
election
for
the
Chelsea
Districts
,
after
all
the
money
which
he
had
spent
,
 
money
which
he
had
been
so
ill
able
to
spend
,
and
on
which
he
had
laid
his
hands
in
a
manner
so
disreputable
!
<EOS>
He
had
received
two
thousand
pounds
from
the
bills
which
Alice
had
executed
on
his
behalf
,
 
or
rather
,
had
received
the
full
value
of
three
out
of
the
four
bills
,
and
a
part
of
the
value
of
the
fourth
,
on
which
he
had
been
driven
to
raise
what
immediate
money
he
had
wanted
by
means
of
a
Jew
bill
-
discounter
.
<EOS>
One
thousand
pounds
he
had
paid
over
at
once
into
the
hands
of
Mr.
Scruby
,
his
Parliamentary
election
agent
,
towards
the
expenses
of
his
election
;
and
when
the
day
of
polling
arrived
had
exactly
in
his
hands
the
sum
of
five
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
Where
he
was
to
get
more
when
this
was
gone
<EOS>
he
did
not
know
.
<EOS>
If
he
were
successful
,
 
if
the
enlightened
constituents
of
the
Chelsea
Districts
,
contented
with
his
efforts
on
behalf
of
the
River
Bank
,
should
again
send
him
to
Parliament
,
he
thought
that
he
might
still
carry
on
the
war
.
<EOS>
A
sum
of
ready
money
he
would
have
in
hand
;
and
,
as
to
his
debts
,
he
would
be
grandly
indifferent
to
any
consideration
of
them
.
<EOS>
Then
there
might
be
pickings
in
the
way
of
a
Member
of
Parliament
of
his
calibre
.
<EOS>
Companies
,
 
mercantile
companies
,
 
would
be
glad
to
have
him
as
a
director
,
paying
him
a
guinea
a
day
,
or
perhaps
more
,
for
his
hour
's
attendance
.
<EOS>
Railways
in
want
of
vice
-
chairmen
might
bid
for
his
services
;
and
in
the
City
he
might
turn
that
"
M.P.
"
which
belonged
to
him
to
good
account
in
various
ways
.
<EOS>
With
such
a
knowledge
of
the
City
world
as
he
possessed
,
he
thought
that
he
could
pick
up
a
living
in
London
,
if
only
he
could
retain
his
seat
in
Parliament
.
  
<EOS>
But
what
was
he
to
do
if
he
could
not
retain
it
?
<EOS>
No
sooner
had
Mr.
Scruby
got
the
thousand
pounds
into
his
clutches
than
he
pressed
for
still
more
money
.
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
,
with
some
show
of
justice
on
his
side
,
pointed
out
to
this
all
-
devouring
agent
that
the
sum
demanded
had
already
been
paid
.
<EOS>
This
Mr.
Scruby
admitted
,
declaring
that
he
was
quite
prepared
to
go
on
without
any
further
immediate
remittance
,
although
by
doing
so
might
subject
himself
to
considerable
risk
.
<EOS>
But
another
five
hundred
pounds
,
paid
at
once
,
would
add
greatly
to
the
safety
of
the
seat
;
whereas
eight
hundred
judiciously
thrown
in
at
the
present
moment
would
make
the
thing
quite
secure
.
<EOS>
But
Vavasor
swore
to
himself
that
he
would
not
part
with
another
shilling
.
<EOS>
Never
had
he
felt
such
love
for
money
as
he
did
for
that
five
hundred
pounds
which
he
now
held
in
his
pocket
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
use
,
"
he
said
to
Mr.
Scruby
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
what
you
asked
,
and
would
have
done
more
<EOS>
had
you
asked
for
more
at
that
time
.
<EOS>
As
it
is
,
I
can
not
make
another
payment
before
the
election
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
shrugged
his
shoulders
,
and
said
that
he
would
do
his
best
.
<EOS>
But
George
Vavasor
soon
knew
that
the
man
was
not
doing
his
best
,
 
that
the
man
had
,
in
truth
,
abandoned
his
cause
.
<EOS>
The
landlord
of
the
"
Handsome
Man
"
jeered

when
he
went
there
canvassing
.
<EOS>
"
Laws
,
Mr.
Vavasor
!
"
said
the
landlord
of
the
"
Handsome
Man
,
"
"
you
're
not
at
all
the
fellow
for
us
chaps
along
the
river
,
 
you
ai
n't
.
<EOS>
You
're
afraid
to
come
down
with
the
stumpy
,
 
<EOS>
that
's
what
you
are
.
"
<EOS>
George
put
his
hand
upon
his
purse
,
and
acknowledged
to
himself
that
he
had
been
afraid
to
come
down
with
the
stumpy
.
  
<EOS>
For
the
last
five
days
of
the
affair
George
Vavasor
knew
that
his
chance
was
gone
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
's
face
,
manner
,
and
words
,
told
the
result
of
the
election
as
plainly
as
any
subsequent
figures
could
do
.
<EOS>
He
would
be
absent
when
Vavasor
called
,
or
the
clerk
would
say
that
he
was
absent
.
<EOS>
He
would
answer
in
very
few
words
,
constantly
shrugging
his
shoulders
.
<EOS>
He
would
even
go
away
and
leave
the
anxious
candidate
while
he
was
in
the
middle
of
some
discussion
as
to
his
plans
.
<EOS>
It
was
easy
to
see
that
Mr.
Scruby
no
longer
regarded
him
as
a
successful
man
,
and
the
day
of
the
poll
showed
very
plainly
how
right
Mr.
Scruby
had
been
.
  
<EOS>
George
Vavasor
was
rejected
,
but
he
still
had
his
five
hundred
pounds
in
his
pocket
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
was
subject
to
that
mortification
which
a
man
feels
when
he
reflects
that
some
little
additional
outlay
would
have
secured
his
object
.
<EOS>
Whether
it
might
have
been
so
,
or
not
,
who
can
say
?
<EOS>
But
there
he
was
,
with
the
gateway
between
the
lamps
barred
against
him
,
ex
-
Member
of
Parliament
for
the
Chelsea
Districts
,
with
five
hundred
pounds
in
his
pocket
,
and
little
or
nothing
else
that
he
could
call
his
own
.
<EOS>
What
was
he
to
do
with
himself
?
  
<EOS>
After
trying
to
make
himself
heard
upon
the
hustings
when
he
was
rejected
,
and
pledging
himself
to
stand
again
at
the
next
election
,
he
went
home
to
his
lodgings
in
Cecil
Street
,
and
endeavoured
to
consider
calmly
his
position
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
He
had
lost
his
inheritance
.
<EOS>
He
had
abandoned
one
profession
after
another
,
and
was
now
beyond
the
pale
of
another
chance
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
His
ambition
had
betrayed
him
,
and
there
were
no
longer
possible
to
him
any
hopes
of
political
activity
.
<EOS>
He
had
estranged
from
himself
every
friend
that
he
had
ever
possessed
.
<EOS>
He
had
driven
from
him
with
violence
the
devotion
even
of
his
sister
.
<EOS>
He
had
robbed
the
girl
whom
he
intended
to
marry
of
her
money
,
and
had
so
insulted
her
that
no
feeling
of
amity
between
them
was
any
longer
possible
.
<EOS>
He
had
nothing
now
but
himself
and
that
five
hundred
pounds
,
which
he
still
held
in
his
pocket
.
<EOS>
What
should
he
do
with
himself
and
his
money
?
<EOS>
He
thought
over
it
all
with
outer
calmness
for
awhile
,
as
he
sat
there
in
his
arm
-
chair
.
  
<EOS>
From
the
moment
in
which
he
had
first
become
convinced
that
the
election
would
go
against
him
,
and
that
he
was
therefore
ruined
on
all
sides
,
he
had
resolved
that
he
would
be
calm
amidst
his
ruin
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
he
assumed
a
little
smile
,
as
though
he
were
laughing
at
his
own
position
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
's
day
of
rejection
had
come
before
his
own
,
and
he
had
written
to
Mr.
Bott
a
drolling
note
of
consolation
and
mock
sympathy
.
<EOS>
He
had
shaken
hands
with
Mr.
Scruby
,
and
had
poked
his
fun
at
the
agent
,
bidding
him
be
sure
to
send
in
his
little
bill
soon
.
<EOS>
To
all
who
accosted
him
,
he
replied
in
a
subrisive
tone
;
and
he
bantered
Calder
Jones
,
whose
seat
was
quite
sure
,
till
Calder
Jones
began
to
have
fears
that
were
quite
unnecessary
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
as
he
sat
himself
down
,
intending
to
come
to
some
final
decision
as
to
what
he
would
do
,
he
maintained
the
same
calmness
.
<EOS>
He
smiled
in
the
same
way
,
though
there
was
no
one
there
to
see
the
smile
.
<EOS>
He
laughed
even
audibly
once
or
twice
,
as
he
vainly
endeavoured
to
persuade
himself
that
he
was
able
to
regard
the
world
and
all
that
belonged
to
it
as
a
bubble
.
  
<EOS>
There
came
to
him
a
moment
in
which
he
laughed
out
very
audibly
.
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
"
<EOS>
he
shouted
,
rising
up
from
his
chair
,
and
he
walked
about
the
room
,
holding
a
large
paper
-
knife
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
<EOS>
"
Then
he
threw
the
knife
away
from
him
,
and
thrusting
his
hands
into
his
trousers
-
pockets
,
laughed
again
 
"
<EOS>
Ha
!
ha
!
"
<EOS>
He
stood
still
in
the
centre
of
the
room
,
and
the
laughter
was
very
plainly
visible
on
his
face
,
had
there
been
anybody
there
to
see
it
.
  
<EOS>
But
suddenly
there
was
a
change
upon
his
face
,
as
he
stood
there
all
alone
,
and
his
eyes
became
fierce
,
and
the
cicatrice
that
marred
his
countenance
grew
to
be
red
and
ghastly
,
and
he
grinned
with
his
teeth
,
and
he
clenched
his
fists
as
he
still
held
them
within
his
pockets
.
<EOS>
"
Curse
him
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
out
loud
.
"
<EOS>
Curse
him
,
now
and
for
ever
!
"
<EOS>
He
had
broken
down
in
his
calmness
,
when
he
thought
of
that
old
man
who
had
opposed
him
during
his
life
,
and
had
ruined
him
at
his
death
.
"
<EOS>
May
all
the
evils
which
the
dead
can
feel
cling
to
him
for
ever
and
ever
!
"
<EOS>
His
laughter
was
all
gone
,
and
his
assumed
tranquillity
had
deserted
him
.
<EOS>
Walking
across
the
room
,
he
struck
his
foot
against
a
chair
;
upon
this
,
he
took
the
chair
in
his
hands
,
and
threw
it
across
the
room
.
<EOS>
But
he
hardly
arrested
the
torrent
of
his
maledictions
as
he
did
so
.
<EOS>
What
good
was
it
that
he
should
lie
to
himself
by
that
mock
tranquillity
,
or
that
false
laughter
?
<EOS>
He
lied
to
himself
no
longer
,
but
uttered
a
song
of
despair
that
was
true
enough
.
<EOS>
What
should
he
do
?
<EOS>
Where
should
he
go
?
<EOS>
From
what
fountain
should
he
attempt
to
draw
such
small
draughts
of
the
water
of
comfort
as
might
support
him
at
the
present
moment
?
<EOS>
Unless
a
man
have
some
such
fountain
to
which
he
can
turn
,
the
burden
of
life
can
not
be
borne
.
<EOS>
For
the
moment
,
Vavasor
tried
to
find
such
fountain
in
a
bottle
of
brandy
which
stood
near
him
.
<EOS>
He
half
filled
a
tumbler
,
and
then
,
dashing
some
water
on
it
,
swallowed
it
greedily
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
 
---
!
"
he
said
,
"
I
believe
it
is
the
best
thing
a
man
can
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
where
was
he
to
go
?
<EOS>
to
whom
was
he
to
turn
himself
?
<EOS>
He
went
to
a
high
desk
which
stood
in
one
corner
of
the
room
,
and
unlocking
it
,
took
out
a
revolving
pistol
,
and
for
a
while
carried
it
about
with
him
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
He
turned
it
up
,
and
looked
at
it
,
and
tried
the
lock
,
and
snapped
it
without
caps
,
to
see
that
the
barrel
went
round
fairly
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
beggarly
thing
to
do
,
"
he
said
,
and
then
he
turned
the
pistol
down
again
;
"
and
if
I
do
do
it
,
I
'll
use
it
first
for
another
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
poured
out
for
himself
more
brandy
-
and
-
water
,
and
having
drunk
it
,
he
threw
himself
upon
the
sofa
,
and
seemed
to
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
sleep
,
and
by
-
and
-
by
there
came
a
slight
single
knock
at
the
door
,
which
he
instantly
answered
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
answer
it
in
the
usual
way
by
bidding
the
comer
to
come
in
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
's
there
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
.
<EOS>
Then
the
comer
attempted
to
enter
,
turning
the
handle
of
the
door
.
<EOS>
But
the
door
had
been
locked
,
and
the
key
was
on
Vavasor
's
side
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Who
's
there
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
again
,
speaking
out
loudly
,
but
in
an
angry
voice
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
I
,
"
said
a
woman
's
voice
.
<EOS>
"
D
 
---
ation
!
"
said
George
Vavasor
.
  
<EOS>
The
woman
heard
him
,
but
she
made
no
sign
of
having
heard
him
.
<EOS>
She
simply
remained
standing
where
she
was
till
something
further
should
be
done
within
.
<EOS>
She
knew
the
man
well
,
and
knew
that
she
must
bide
his
time
.
<EOS>
She
was
very
patient
,
 
and
for
the
time
was
meek
,
though
it
might
be
that
there
would
come
an
end
to
her
meekness
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
when
he
had
heard
her
voice
,
and
knew
who
was
there
,
had
again
thrown
himself
on
the
sofa
.
<EOS>
There
flashed
across
his
mind
another
thought
or
two
as
to
his
future
career
,
 
another
idea
about
the
pistol
,
which
still
lay
upon
the
table
.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
let
the
intruder
in
,
and
undergo
the
nuisance
of
a
disagreeable
interview
,
if
the
end
of
all
things
might
come
in
time
to
save
him
from
such
trouble
?
<EOS>
There
he
lay
for
ten
minutes
thinking
,
and
then
the
low
single
knock
was
heard
again
.
<EOS>
He
jumped
upon
his
feet
,
and
his
eyes
were
full
of
fire
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
it
was
useless
to
bid
her
go
and
leave
him
.
<EOS>
She
would
sit
there
,
if
it
were
through
the
whole
night
.
<EOS>
Should
he
open
the
door
and
strangle
her
,
and
pass
out
over
her
with
the
pistol
in
his
hand
,
so
that
he
might
make
that
other
reckoning
which
he
desired
to
accomplish
,
and
then
never
come
back
any
more
?
  
<EOS>
He
took
a
turn
through
the
room
,
and
then
walked
gently
up
to
the
door
,
and
undid
the
lock
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
open
the
door
,
nor
did
he
bid
his
visitor
enter
,
but
having
made
the
way
easy
for
her
if
she
chose
to
come
in
,
he
walked
back
to
the
sofa
and
threw
himself
on
it
again
.
<EOS>
As
he
did
so
,
he
passed
his
hand
across
the
table
so
as
to
bring
the
pistol
near
to
himself
at
the
place
where
he
would
be
lying
.
<EOS>
She
paused
a
moment
after
she
had
heard
the
sound
of
the
key
,
and
then
she
made
her
way
into
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
at
first
speak
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
closed
the
door
very
gently
,
and
then
,
looking
around
,
came
up
to
the
foot
of
the
sofa
.
<EOS>
She
paused
a
moment
,
waiting
for
him
to
address
her
;
but
as
he
said
nothing
,
but
lay
there
looking
at
her
<EOS>
,
she
was
the
first
to
speak
.
"
<EOS>
George
,
"
she
said
,
"
what
am
I
to
do
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
a
woman
of
about
thirty
years
of
age
,
dressed
poorly
,
in
old
garments
,
but
still
with
decency
,
and
with
some
attempt
at
feminine
prettiness
.
<EOS>
There
were
flowers
in
the
bonnet
on
her
head
,
though
the
bonnet
had
that
unmistakable
look
of
age
which
is
quite
as
distressing
to
bonnets
as
it
is
to
women
,
and
the
flowers
themselves
were
battered
and
faded
.
<EOS>
She
had
long
black
ringlets
on
each
cheek
,
hanging
down
much
below
her
face
,
and
brought
forward
so
as
to
hide
in
some
degree
the
hollowness
of
her
jaws
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
had
a
peculiar
brightness
,
but
now
they
left
on
those
who
looked
at
her
cursorily
no
special
impression
as
to
their
colour
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
blue
,
 
that
dark
violet
blue
,
which
is
so
rare
,
but
is
sometimes
so
lovely
.
<EOS>
Her
forehead
was
narrow
,
her
mouth
was
small
,
and
her
lips
were
thin
;
but
her
nose
was
perfect
in
its
shape
,
and
,
by
the
delicacy
of
its
modelling
,
had
given
a
peculiar
grace
to
her
face
in
the
days
when
things
had
gone
well
with
her
,
when
her
cheeks
had
been
full
with
youth
and
good
living
,
and
had
been
dimpled
by
the
softness
of
love
and
mirth
.
<EOS>
There
were
no
dimples
there
now
,
and
all
the
softness
which
still
remained
was
that
softness
which
sorrow
and
continual
melancholy
give
to
suffering
women
.
<EOS>
On
her
shoulders
she
wore
a
light
shawl
,
which
was
fastened
to
her
bosom
with
a
large
clasp
brooch
.
<EOS>
Her
faded
dress
was
supported
by
a
wide
crinoline
,
but
the
under
garment
had
lost
all
the
grace
of
its
ancient
shape
,
and
now
told
that
woman
's
tale
of
poverty
and
taste
for
dress
which
is
to
be
read
in
the
outward
garb
of
so
many
of
Eve
's
daughters
.
<EOS>
The
whole
story
was
told
so
that
those
who
ran
might
read
it
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
left
her
home
this
afternoon
,
she
had
struggled
hard
to
dress
herself
so
that
something
of
the
charm
of
apparel
might
be
left
to
her
;
but
she
had
known
of
her
own
failure
at
every
twist
that
she
had
given
to
her
gown
,
and
at
every
jerk
with
which
she
had
settled
her
shawl
.
<EOS>
She
had
despaired
at
every
push
she
had
given
to
her
old
flowers
,
vainly
striving
to
bring
them
back
to
their
old
forms
;
but
still
she
had
persevered
.
<EOS>
With
long
tedious
care
she
had
mended
the
old
gloves
which
would
hardly
hold
her
fingers
.
<EOS>
She
had
carefully
hidden
the
rags
of
her
sleeves
.
<EOS>
She
had
washed
her
little
shrivelled
collar
,
and
had
smoothed
it
out
painfully
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
a
separate
grief
to
her
that
she
could
find
no
cuffs
to
put
round
her
wrists
;
 
and
yet
she
knew
that
no
cuffs
could
have
availed
her
anything
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
avail
her
now
.
<EOS>
She
expected
nothing
from
her
visit
;
yet
she
had
come
forth
anxiously
,
and
would
have
waited
there
throughout
the
whole
night
had
access
to
his
room
been
debarred
to
her
.
"
<EOS>
George
,
"
she
said
,
standing
at
the
bottom
of
the
sofa
,
"
what
am
I
to
do
?
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
lay
there
with
his
face
turned
towards
her
,
the
windows
were
at
her
back
,
and
he
could
see
her
very
plainly
.
<EOS>
He
saw
and
appreciated
the
little
struggles
she
had
made
to
create
by
her
appearance
some
reminiscence
of
her
former
self
.
<EOS>
He
saw
the
shining
coarseness
of
the
long
ringlets
which
had
once
been
softer
than
silk
.
<EOS>
He
saw
the
sixpenny
brooch
on
her
bosom
where
he
had
once
placed
a
jewel
,
the
price
of
which
would
now
have
been
important
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
saw
it
all
,
and
lay
there
for
a
while
,
silently
reading
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
let
me
stand
here
,
"
she
said
,
"
without
speaking
a
word
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
you
to
stand
there
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
all
very
well
,
George
.
<EOS>
I
know
you
do
n't
want
me
to
stand
here
.
<EOS>
I
know
you
do
n't
want
to
see
me
ever
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
know
it
.
<EOS>
But
what
am
I
to
do
?
<EOS>
Where
am
I
to
go
for
money
?
<EOS>
Even
you
would
not
wish
that
I
should
starve
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
true
,
too
.
<EOS>
I
certainly
would
not
wish
it
.
<EOS>
I
should
be
delighted
to
hear
that
you
had
plenty
to
eat
and
plenty
to
drink
,
and
plenty
of
clothes
to
wear
.
<EOS>
I
believe
that
's
what
you
care
for
the
most
,
after
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
only
for
your
sake
,
 
because
you
liked
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
;
 
I
did
like
it
;
but
that
has
come
to
an
end
,
as
have
all
my
other
likings
.
<EOS>
You
know
very
well
that
I
can
do
nothing
more
for
you
.
<EOS>
What
good
do
you
do
yourself
by
coming
here
to
annoy
me
?
<EOS>
Have
I
not
told
you
over
and
over
again
that
you
were
never
to
look
for
me
here
?
<EOS>
Is
it
likely
that
I
should
give
you
money
now
,
simply
because
you
have
disobeyed
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
else
was
I
to
find
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
have
found
me
at
all
?
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
you
to
find
me
.
<EOS>
I
shall
give
you
nothing
;
 
not
a
penny
.
<EOS>
You
know
very
well
that
we
've
had
all
that
out
before
.
<EOS>
When
I
put
you
into
business
I
told
you
that
we
were
to
see
no
more
of
each
other
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Business
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
could
make
enough
out
of
the
shop
to
feed
a
bird
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
was
n't
my
fault
.
<EOS>
Putting
you
there
cost
me
over
a
hundred
pounds
,
and
you
consented
to
take
the
place
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
consent
.
<EOS>
I
was
obliged
to
go
there
because
you
took
my
other
home
away
from

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
it
as
you
like
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
That
was
all
I
could
do
for
you
;
 
and
more
than
most
men
would
have
done
,
when
all
things
are
considered
.
"
<EOS>
Then
he
got
up
from
the
sofa
,
and
stood
himself
on
the
hearthrug
,
with
his
back
to
the
fireplace
.
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
you
may
be
sure
of
this
,
Jane
;
 
that
I
shall
do
nothing
more
.
<EOS>
You
have
come
here
to
torment
me
,
but
you
shall
get
nothing
by
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
here
because
I
am
starving
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
for
you
.
<EOS>
Now
go
;
"
and
he
pointed
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
for
more
than
three
years
of
his
life
this
woman
had
been
his
closest
companion
,
his
nearest
friend
,
the
being
with
whom
he
was
most
familiar
.
<EOS>
He
had
loved
her
according
to
his
fashion
of
loving
,
and
certainly
she
had
loved
him
.
<EOS>
"
Go
,
"
he
said
repeating
the
word
very
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
Do
as
I
bid
you
,
or
it
will
be
the
worse
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
give
me
a
sovereign
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
I
will
give
you
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
have
desired
you
not
to
come
to
me
here
,
and
I
will
not
pay
for
you
coming
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
not
go
;
"
and
the
woman
sat
down
upon
a
chair
at
the
foot
of
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
go
till
you
have
given
me
something
to
buy
food
.
<EOS>
You
may
put
me
out
of
the
room
if
you
can
,
but
I
will
lie
at
the
door
of
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
get
me
out
of
the
house
,
I
will
sit
upon
the
door
-
step
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
play
that
game
,
my
poor
girl
,
the
police
will
take
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
them
.
<EOS>
It
has
come
to
that
with
me
,
that
I
care
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
Out
of
this
I
will
not
go
till
you
give
me
money
 
unless
I
am
put
out
.
"
  
<EOS>
And
for
this
she
had
dressed
herself
with
so
much
care
,
mending
her
gloves
,
and
darning
her
little
fragments
of
finery
!
<EOS>
He
stood
looking
at
her
,
with
his
hands
thrust
deep
into
his
pockets
,
 
looking
at
her
and
thinking
what
he
had
better
do
to
rid
himself
of
her
presence
.
<EOS>
If
he
even
quite
resolved
to
take
that
little
final
journey
of
which
we
have
spoken
,
with
the
pistol
in
his
hand
,
why
should
he
not
go
and
leave
her
there
?
<EOS>
Or
,
for
the
matter
of
that
,
why
should
he
not
make
her
his
heir
to
all
remainder
of
his
wealth
?
<EOS>
What
he
still
had
left
was
sufficient
to
place
her
in
a
seventh
heaven
of
the
earth
.
<EOS>
He
cared
but
little
for
her
,
and
was
at
this
moment
angry
with
her
;
but
there
was
no
one
for
whom
he
cared
more
,
and
no
friend
with
whom
he
was
less
angry
.
<EOS>
But
then
his
mind
was
not
quite
made
up
as
to
that
final
journey
.
<EOS>
Therefore
he
desired
to
rid
himself
and
his
room
of
the
nuisance
of
her
presence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jane
,
"
he
said
,
looking
at
her
again
with
that
assumed
tranquillity
of
which
I
have
spoken
,
"
you
talk
of
starving
and
of
being
ruined
,
 
"
  
"
I
am
starving
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
a
shilling
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
may
be
a
comfort
to
you
in
your
troubles
to
know
that
I
am
,
at
any
rate
,
as
badly
off
as
you
are
?
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
say
that
I
am
starving
,
because
I
could
get
food
to
eat
at
this
moment
if
I
wanted
it
;
but
I
am
utterly

.
<EOS>
My

,
 
what
should
have
been
mine
,
 
has
been
left
away
from

.
<EOS>
I
have
lost
the
trumpery
seat
in
Parliament
for
which
I
have
paid
so
much
.
<EOS>
All
my
relations
have
turned

upon
me
 
"
  
"
Are

not

to
be

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Married
!
<EOS>
No
;
 
<EOS>
but
I
am
going
to
blow

out
.
<EOS>
Look
at
that
pistol
,
my
girl
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
wo
n't
think
that
I
am
in
earnest
,
 
but
I
am
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
looked
up
into
his

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
George
,
"
she
said
,
"
you
wo
n't
do
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
shall
do
that
.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
else

do
.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
I

,

so

in

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
You
and
I
,
Jane
,
have
not

.
<EOS>
We
have
staked

that

,

've

.
<EOS>
It
's
no

whimpering
after
what
's

.
<EOS>
We
'd
better
go
somewhere
else
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go
where
?
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
 
<EOS>
that
's
just
what
I
ca
n't

you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
George
,
"
she

,
"
I
'll
go

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

'm
poorly

"
  
"

,

,

;
and

when

,
 
<EOS>
they

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

,

"
  
"
George
,
"

,
 
"
George
,

.
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
Say

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
I
do

.
<EOS>
I

;
 
<EOS>
indeed

.
<EOS>
But

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

;

,
 
at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I

.
<EOS>
But
all

is
nonsense
,
Jane
,
and

must

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must

,

,

not

kill
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
