I
shall
do
it
to
-
night
,
 
or
,
perhaps
,
not
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Very
probably
I
may
allow
myself
a
week
,
so
that
your
staying
here
can
do
no
good
.
<EOS>
I
merely
wanted
to
make
you
understand
that
you
are
not
the
only
person
who
has
come
to
grief
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
are
not
going
to
be
married
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
'm
not
going
to
be
married
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
I
must
go
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I
think
you
'd
better
go
now
.
<EOS>
"
Then
she
rose
and
went
,
and
he
let
her
leave
the
room
without
giving
her
a
shilling
!
<EOS>
His
bantering
tone
,
in
speaking
of
his
own
position
,
had
been
successful
.
<EOS>
It
had
caused
her
to
take
herself
off
quietly
.
<EOS>
She
knew
enough
of
his
usual
manner
to
be
aware
that
his
threats
of
self
destruction
were
probably
unreal
;
but
,
nevertheless
,
what
he
had
said
had
created
some
feeling
in
her
heart
which
had
induced
her
to
yield
to
him
,
and
go
away
in
peace
.
   
<EOS>
Showing
How
George
Vavasor
Paid
a
Visit
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
nearly
seven
o'clock
in
the
evening
,
 
a
hot
,
July
evening
,
 
when
the
woman
went
from
Vavasor
's
room
,
and
left
him
there
alone
.
<EOS>
It
was
necessary
that
he
should
immediately
do
something
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
he
must
dine
,
unless
he
meant
to
carry
out
his
threat
,
and
shoot
himself
at
once
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
no
such
intention
as
that
,
although
he
stood
for
some
minutes
with
the
pistol
in
his
hand
.
<EOS>
He
was
thinking
then
of
shooting
some
one
else
.
<EOS>
But
he
resolved
that
,
if
he
did
so
at
all
,
he
would
not
do
it
on
that
evening
,
and
he
locked
up
the
pistol
again
in
the
standing
desk
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
he
took
up
some
papers
,
referring
to
steam
packets
,
which
were
lying
on
his
table
.
<EOS>
They
contained
the
programmes
of
different
companies
,
and
showed
how
one
vessel
went
on
one
day
to
New
York
,
and
another
on
another
day
would
take
out
a
load
of
emigrants
for
New
Zealand
and
Australia
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
good
line
,
"
said
he
,
as
he
read
a
certain
prospectus
.
<EOS>
"
They
generally
go
to
the
bottom
,
and
save
a
man
from
any
further
trouble
on
his
own
account
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
dressed
himself
,
putting
on
his
boots
and
coat
,
and
went
out
to
his
club
for
his
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
London
was
still
fairly
full
,
 
that
is
to
say
,
the
West
End
was
not
deserted
,
although
Parliament
had
been
broken
up
two
months
earlier
than
usual
,
in
preparation
for
the
new
elections
.
<EOS>
Many
men
who
had
gone
down
into
the
country
were
now
back
again
in
town
,
and
the
dining
-
room
at
the
club
was
crowded
.
<EOS>
Men
came
up
to
him
condoling
with
him
,
telling
him
that
he
was
well
rid
of
a
great
nuisance
,
that
the
present
Members
for
the
Chelsea
Districts
would
not
sit
long
,
or
that
there
would
be
another
general
election
in
a
year
or
two
.
<EOS>
To
all
these
little
speeches
he
made
cheerful
replies
,
and
was
declared
by
his
acquaintance
to
bear
his
disappointment
well
.
<EOS>
Calder
Jones
came
to
him
and
talked
hunting
talk
,
and
Vavasor
expressed
his
intention
of
being
at
Roebury
in
November
.
<EOS>
"
You
had
better
join
our
club
,
"
said
Calder
Jones
.
<EOS>
In
answer
to
which
Vavasor
said
that
he
thought
he
would
join
the
club
.
<EOS>
He
remained
in
the
smoking
-
room
till
nearly
eleven
;
then
he
took
himself
home
,
and
remained
up
half
the
night
destroying
papers
.
<EOS>
Every
written
document
on
which
he
could
lay
his
hands
he
destroyed
.
<EOS>
All
the
pigeon
-
holes
of
his
desk
were
emptied
out
,
and
their
contents
thrown
into
the
flames
.
<EOS>
At
first
he
looked
at
the
papers
before
he
burned
them
;
but
the
trouble
of
doing
so
soon
tired
him
,
and
he
condemned
them
all
,
as
he
came
to
them
,
without
examination
.
<EOS>
Then
he
selected
a
considerable
amount
of
his
clothes
,
and
packed
up
two
portmanteaus
,
folding
his
coats
with
care
,
and
inspecting
his
boots
narrowly
,
so
that
he
might
see
which
,
out
of
the
large
number
before
him
,
it
might
be
best
worth
his
while
to
take
with
him
.
<EOS>
When
that
was
done
,
he
took
from
his
desk
a
bag
of
sovereigns
,
and
,
pouring
them
out
upon
the
table
,
he
counted
them
out
into
parcels
of
twenty
-
five
each
,
and
made
them
up
carefully
into
rouleaus
with
paper
.
<EOS>
These
,
when
complete
,
he
divided
among
the
two
portmanteaus
and
a
dressing
-
bag
which
he
also
packed
and
a
travelling
desk
,
which
he
filled
with
papers
,
pens
,
and
the
like
.
<EOS>
But
he
put
into
it
no
written
document
.
<EOS>
He
carefully
looked
through
his
linen
,
and
anything
that
had
been
marked
with
more
than
his
initials
he
rejected
.
<EOS>
Then
he
took
out
a
bundle
of
printed
cards
,
and
furnished
a
card
-
case
with
them
.
<EOS>
On
these
cards
was
inscribed
the
name
of
Gregory
Vance
.
<EOS>
When
all
was
finished
,
he
stood
for
awhile
with
his
back
to
the
fireplace
contemplating
his
work
.
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
"
he
said
to
himself
,
"
I
know
that
I
shall
never
start
;
and
,
if
I
do
,
nobody
can
hinder
me
,
and
my
own
name
would
be
as
good
as
any
other
.
<EOS>
As
for
a
man
with
such
a
face
as
mine
not
being
known
,
that
is
out
of
the
question
.
<EOS>
"
But
still
he
liked
the
arrangements
which
he
had
made
,
and
when
he
had
looked
at
them
for
awhile
he
went
to
bed
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
up
early
the
next
morning
,
and
had
some
coffee
brought
to
him
by
the
servant
of
the
house
,
and
as
he
drank
it
he
had
an
interview
with
his
landlady
.
<EOS>
"
He
was
going
,
"
he
said
;
 
"
going
that
very
day
.
<EOS>
"
It
might
be
possible
that
he
would
change
his
mind
;
but
as
he
would
desire
to
start
without
delay
,
if
he
did
go
,
he
would
pay
her
then
what
he
owed
her
,
and
what
would
be
due
for
her
lodgings
under
a
week
's
notice
.
<EOS>
The
woman
stared
,
and
curtseyed
,
and
took
her
money
.
<EOS>
Vavasor
,
though
he
had
lately
been
much
pressed
for
money
,
had
never
been
so
foolish
as
to
owe
debts
where
he
lived
.
<EOS>
"
There
will
be
some
things
left
about
,
Mrs.
Bunsby
,
"
he
said
,
"
and
I
will
get
you
to
keep
them
till
I
call
or
send
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bunsby
said
that
she
would
,
and
then
looked
her
last
at
him
.
<EOS>
After
that
interview
she
never
saw
him
again
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
was
left
alone
he
put
on
a
rough
morning
coat
,
and
taking
up
the
pistol
,
placed
it
carefully
in
his
pocket
,
and
sallied
forth
.
<EOS>
It
was
manifest
enough
that
he
had
some
decided
scheme
in
his
head
,
for
he
turned
quickly
towards
the
West
when
he
reached
the
Strand
,
went
across
Trafalgar
Square
to
Pall
Mall
East
,
and
then
turned
up
Suffolk
Street
.
<EOS>
Just
as
he
reached
the
club
-
house
at
the
corner
he
paused
and
looked
back
,
facing
first
one
way
<EOS>
and
then
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
chances
are
that
I
shall
never
see
anything
of
it
again
,
"
he
said
to
himself
.
<EOS>
Then
he
laughed
in
his
own
silent
way
,
shook
his
head
slightly
,
and
turning
again
quickly
on
his
heel
,
walked
up
the
street
till
he
reached
the
house
of
Mr.
Jones
,
the
pugilistic
tailor
.
<EOS>
The
reader
,
no
doubt
,
has
forgotten
all
he
ever
knew
of
Mr.
Jones
,
the
pugilistic
tailor
.
<EOS>
It
can
soon
be
told
again
.
<EOS>
At
Mr.
Jones
's
house
John
Grey
lodged
when
he
was
in
London
,
and
he
was
in
London
at
this
moment
.
  
<EOS>
Vavasor
rang
the
bell
,
and
as
soon
as
the
servant
came
he
went
quickly
into
the
house
,
and
passed
her
in
the
passage
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
is
at
home
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
go
up
to
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
girl
said
that
Mr.
Grey
was
at
home
,
but
suggested
that
she
had
better
announce
the
gentleman
.
<EOS>
But
Vavasor
was
already
halfway
up
the
stairs
,
and
before
the
girl
had
reached
the
first
landing
place
,
he
had
entered
Mr.
Grey
's
room
and
closed
the
door
behind
him
.
  
<EOS>
Grey
was
sitting
near
the
open
window
,
in
a
dressing
-
gown
,
and
was
reading
.
<EOS>
The
breakfast
things
were
on
the
table
,
but
he
had
not
as
yet
breakfasted
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
saw
George
Vavasor
,
he
rose
from
his
chair
quickly
,
and
put
down
his
book
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Vavasor
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
hardly
expected
to
see
you
in
my
lodgings
again
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
not
,
"
said
Vavasor
;
"
<EOS>
but
,
nevertheless
,
here
I
am
.
"
<EOS>
He
kept
his
right
hand
in
the
pocket
which
held
the
pistol
,
and
held
his
left
hand
under
his
waistcoat
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
why
you
have
come
?
"
said
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
intend
to
tell
you
,
at
any
rate
,
whether
you
ask
me
or
not
.
<EOS>
I
have
come
to
declare
in
your
own
hearing
,
 
as
I
am
in
the
habit
of
doing
occasionally
behind
your
back
,
 
that
you
are
a
blackguard
,
 
to
spit
in
your
face
,
and
defy
you
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
he
said
this
he
suited
his
action
to
his
words
,
but
without
any
serious
result
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
come
here
to
see
if
you
are
man
enough
to
resent
any
insult
that
I
can
offer
you
;
but
I
doubt
whether
you
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
that
you
can
say
to
me
,
Mr.
Vavasor
,
will
have
any
effect
upon
me
;
 
except
that
you
can
,
of
course
,
annoy
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
mean
to
annoy
you
,
too
,
before
I
have
done
with
you
.
<EOS>
Will
you
fight
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fight
a
duel
with
you
,
 
with
pistols
?
<EOS>
Certainly
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
are
a
coward
,
as
I
supposed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
a
fool
if
I
were
to
do
such
a
thing
as
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
You
managed
to
worm
yourself
into
an
intimacy
with
my
cousin
,
Miss
Vavasor
,
and
to
become
engaged
to
her
.
<EOS>
When
she
found
out
what
you
were
,
how
paltry
,
and
mean
,
and
vile
,
she
changed
her
mind
,
and
bade
you
leave
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
here
at
her
request
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
here
as
her
representative
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Self
-
appointed
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
sir
,
you
think
wrong
.
<EOS>
I
am
at
this
moment
her
affianced
husband
;
and
I
find
that
,
in
spite
of
all
that
she
has
said
to
you
,
 
which
was
enough
,
I
should
have
thought
,
to
keep
any
man
of
spirit
out
of
her
presence
,
 
you
still
persecute
her
by
going
to
her
house
,
and
forcing
yourself
upon
her
presence
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
give
you
two
alternatives
.
<EOS>
You
shall
either
give
me
your
written
promise
never
to
go
near
her
again
,
or
you
shall
fight
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
do
neither
one
nor
the
other
,
 
as
you
know
very
well
yourself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
till
I
have
done
,
sir
.
<EOS>
If
you
have
courage
enough
to
fight
me
,
I
will
meet
you
in
any
country
.
<EOS>
I
will
fight
you
here
in
London
,
or
,
if
you
are
afraid
of
that
,
I
will
go
over
to
France
,
or
to
America
,
if
that
will
suit
you
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
of
the
kind
will
suit
me
at
all
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
to
have
anything
to
do
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
are
a
coward
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
am
;
 
but
<EOS>
your
saying
so
will
not
make
me
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
coward
,
and
a
liar
,
and
a
blackguard
.
<EOS>
I
have
given
you
the
option
of
behaving
like
a
gentleman
,
and
you
have
refused
it
.
<EOS>
Now
,
look
here
.
<EOS>
I
have
come
here
with
arms
,
and
I
do
not
intend
to
leave
this
room
without
using
them
,
unless
you
will
promise
to
give
me
the
meeting
that
I
have
proposed
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
took
the
pistol
out
of
his
pocket
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
that
you
are
going
to
murder
me
?
"
<EOS>
Grey
asked
.
<EOS>
There
were
two
windows
in
the
room
,
and
he
had
been
sitting
near
to
that
which
was
furthest
removed
from
the
fireplace
,
and
consequently
furthest
removed
from
the
bell
,
and
his
visitor
was
now
standing
immediately
between
him
and
the
door
.
<EOS>
He
had
to
think
what
steps
he
might
best
take
,
and
to
act
upon
his
decision
instantly
.
<EOS>
He
was
by
no
means
a
timid
man
,
and
was
one
,
moreover
,
very
little
prone
to
believe
in
extravagant
action
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
think
,
even
now
,
that
this
disappointed
,
ruined
man
had
come
there
with
any
intention
of
killing
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
knew
that
a
pistol
in
the
hands
of
an
angry
man
is
dangerous
,
and
that
it
behoved
him
to
do
his
best
to
rid
himself
of
the
nuisance
which
now
encumbered
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
that
you
are
going
to
murder
me
?
<EOS>
"
he
had
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
that
you
shall
not
leave
this
room
alive
unless
you
promise
to
meet
me
,
and
fight
it
out
.
"
<EOS>
Upon
hearing
this
,
Grey
turned
himself
towards
the
bell
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
move
a
step
,
I
will
fire
at
you
,
"
said
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Grey
paused
a
moment
,
and
looked
him
full
in
the
face
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
"
said
Vavasor
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
would
be
murder
,
"
said
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
think
that
you
will
frighten
me
by
ugly
words
,
"
said
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
beyond
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
Grey
had
stopped
for
a
moment
to
fix
his
eyes
on
the
other
man
's
face
;
but
it
was
only
for
a
moment
,
and
then
he
went
on
to
the
bell
.
<EOS>
He
had
seen
that
the
pistol
was
pointed
at
himself
,
and
had
once
thought
of
rushing
across
the
room
at
his
adversary
,
calculating
that
a
shot
fired
at
him
as
he
did
so
might
miss
him
,
and
that
he
would
then
have
a
fair
chance
of
disarming
the
madman
.
<EOS>
But
his
chief
object
was
to
avoid
any
personal
conflict
,
to
escape
the
indignity
of
a
scramble
for
the
pistol
,
 
and
especially
to
escape
the
necessity
of
a
consequent
appearance
at
some
police
-
office
,
where
he
would
have
to
justify
himself
,
and
answer
the
questions
of
a
lawyer
hired
to
cross
-
question
him
.
<EOS>
He
made
,
therefore
,
towards
the
bell
,
trusting
that
Vavasor
would
not
fire
at
him
,
but
having
some
little
thought
also
as
to
the
danger
of
the
moment
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
that
everything
was
over
for
him
now
,
 
that
the
fatal
hour
had
come
,
and
that
eternity
was
close
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Something
of
the
spirit
of
a
prayer
flashed
across
his
mind
as
he
moved
.
<EOS>
Then
he
heard
the
click
of
the
pistol
's
hammer
as
it
fell
,
and
was
aware
that
his
eyes
were
dazzled
,
though
he
was
unconscious
of
seeing
any
flame
.
<EOS>
He
felt
something
in
the
air
,
and
knew
that
the
pistol
had
been
fired
;
 
but
he
did
not
know
whether
the
shot
had
struck
him
or
had
missed
him
.
<EOS>
His
hand
was
out
for
the
bell
-
handle
,
and
he
had
pulled
it
,
before
he
was
sure
that
he
was
unhurt
.
  
<EOS>
"
D
 
---
ation
!
"
exclaimed
the
murderer
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
pull
the
trigger
again
.
<EOS>
Though
the
weapon
had
of
late
been
so
often
in
his
hands
,
he
forgot
,
in
the
agitation
of
the
moment
,
that
his
missing
once
was
but
of
small
matter
if
he
chose
to
go
on
with
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
Were
there
not
five
other
barrels
for
him
,
each
making
itself
ready
by
the
discharge
of
the
other
?
<EOS>
But
he
had
paused
,
forgetting
,
in
his
excitement
,
the
use
of
his
weapon
,
and
before
he
had
bethought
himself
that
the
man
was
still
in
his
power
,
he
heard
the
sound
of
the
bell
.
<EOS>
"
D
 
---
ation
!
"
<EOS>
he
exclaimed
.
<EOS>
Then
he
turned
round
,
left
the
room
,
hurried
down
the
stairs
,
and
made
his
way
out
into
the
street
,
having
again
passed
the
girl
on
his
way
.
  
<EOS>
Grey
,
when
he
perceived
that
his
enemy
was
gone
,
turned
round
to
look
for
the
bullet
or
its
mark
.
<EOS>
He
soon
found
the
little
hole
in
the
window
-
shutter
,
and
probing
it
with
the
point
of
his
pencil
,
came
upon
the
morsel
of
lead
which
might
now
just
as
readily
have
been
within
his
own
brain
.
<EOS>
There
he
left
it
for
the
time
,
and
then
made
some
not
inaccurate
calculation
as
to
the
narrowness
of
his
own
escape
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
standing
directly
between
Vavasor
and
the
shutter
,
and
he
found
,
from
the
height
of
the
hole
,
that
the
shot
must
have
passed
close
beneath
his
ear
.
<EOS>
He
remembered
to
have
heard
the
click
of
the
hammer
,
but
he
could
not
remember
the
sound
of
the
report
,
and
when
the
girl
entered
the
room
,
he
perceived
at
once
from
her
manner
that
she
was
unaware
that
firearms
had
been
used
.
  
<EOS>
"
Has
that
gentleman
left
the
house
?
"
<EOS>
Grey
asked
.
<EOS>
The
girl
said
that
he
had
left
the
house
.
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
admit
him
again
,
"
said
he
;
 
"
that
is
,
if
you
can
avoid
it
.
<EOS>
I
believe
he
is
not
in
his
right
senses
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
asked
for
Mr.
Jones
,
his
landlord
,
and
in
a
few
minutes
the
pugilistic
tailor
was
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
During
those
few
minutes
he
had
been
called
upon
to
resolve
what
he
would
do
now
.
<EOS>
Would
he
put
the
police
at
once
upon
the
track
of
the
murderer
,
who
was
,
as
he
remembered
too
well
,
the
first
cousin
of
the
woman
whom
he
still
desired
to
make
his
wife
?
<EOS>
That
cross
-
examination
which
he
would
have
to
undergo
at
the
police
-
office
,
and
again
probably
in
an
assize
court
,
in
which
all
his
relations
with
the
Vavasor
family
would
be
made
public
,
was
very
vivid
to
his
imagination
.
<EOS>
That
he
was
called
upon
by
duty
to
do
something
he
felt
almost
assured
.
<EOS>
The
man
who
had
been
allowed
to
make
such
an
attempt
once
with
impunity
,
might
probably
make
it
again
.
<EOS>
But
he
resolved
that
he
need
not
now
say
anything
about
the
pistol
to
the
pugilistic
tailor
,
unless
the

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Jones
,
"
he
said
,
"
that
man
whom
I
had
to
put
out
of
the
room
once

,
has
been
here

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Has
there
been
another
tussle
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
nothing
of
that
kind
.
<EOS>
But
we
must
take
some
steps
to
prevent
his
getting
in
again
,
if
we
can
help
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Jones
promised
his
aid
,
and
offered
to
go
at
once
to
the
police
.
<EOS>
To
this
,
however
,
Mr.
Grey
demurred
,
saying
that
he
should
himself
seek
assistance
from
some
magistrate
.
<EOS>
Jones
promised
to
be
very
vigilant
as
to
watching
the
door
;
and
then
John
Grey
sat
down
to
his
breakfast
.
<EOS>
Of
course
he
thought
much
of
what
had
occurred
.
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
that
he
should
not
think
much
of
so
narrow
an
escape
.
<EOS>
He
had
probably
been
as
near
death
as
a
man
may
well
be
without
receiving
any
injury
;
and
the
more
he
thought
of
it
,
the
more
strongly
he
was
convinced
that
he
could
not
allow
the
thing
to
pass
by
without
some
notice
,
or
some

as
to
the
future
.
  
<EOS>
At
eleven
o'clock
he
went
to
Scotland
Yard
,
and
saw
some
officer
great
in
power
over
policemen
,
and
told
him
all
the
circumstances
,
 
confidentially
.
<EOS>
The
powerful
officer
recommended
an
equally
confidential
reference
to
a
magistrate
;
and
towards
evening
a
very
confidential
policeman
in
plain

paid
a
visit
to
Vavasor
's
lodgings
in
Cecil
Street
.
<EOS>
But
Vavasor
lodged
there
no
longer
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Bunsby
,
who
was
also
very
confidential
,
 
and
at
her
wits
'
end
because
she
could
not
learn
the
special
business
of
the
stranger
who
called
<EOS>
,
 
stated
that
Mr.
George
Vavasor
left
her
house
in
a
cab
at
ten
o'clock
that
morning
,
having
taken
with
him
such
luggage
as
he
had
packed
,
and
having
gone
,
"
she
was
afraid
,
for
good
,
"
as
Mrs.
Bunsby
expressed

.
  
<EOS>
He
had
gone
for
good
,
and
at
the
moment
in
which
the

was
making
the
inquiry
in
Cecil
Street
,
was
leaning
over
the
side
of
an
American
steamer
which
had
just
got
up
her
steam
and
weighed
her
anchor
in
the
Mersey
.
<EOS>
He
was
on
board
at
six
o'clock
,
and
it
was
not
till
the
next
day
that
the
cabman
was
traced
who
had
carried
him
to
Euston
Square
Station
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
it
was
soon
known
that
he
had
gone
to
America
,
but
it
was
not
thought
worth
while
to
take
any
further
steps
towards
arresting
him
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
himself
was
decidedly
opposed
to
any
such
attempt
,
declaring
his
opinion
that
his
own
evidence
would
be
insufficient
to
obtain
a
conviction
.
<EOS>
The
big
men
in
Scotland
Yard
were
loth
to
let
the
matter
drop
.
<EOS>
Their
mouths
watered
after
the
job
,
and
they
had
very
numerous
and
very
confidential
interviews
with
John
Grey
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
decided
that
nothing
should
be
done
.
"
<EOS>
Pity
!
"
said
one
enterprising
superintendent
,
in
answer
to
the
condolings
of
a
brother
superintendent
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pity
's
no
name
for
it
.
<EOS>
It
's
the
greatest
shame
as
ever
<EOS>
I
knew
since
I
joined
the
force
.
<EOS>
A
man
as
was
a
Member
of
Parliament
only
last
Session
,
 
as
belongs
to
no
end
of
swell
clubs
,
a
gent
as

as
any

about

!
<EOS>
And
I
'd
have

back
in
three

,
as

my

's
Walker
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
that
superintendent
felt
that
his

and
his
country
were
alike
disgraced
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
George
Vavasor
vanishes
from
our
pages
,
and
will
be

no

.
<EOS>
Roebury
knew
him
no

,
nor
Pall
Mall
,
nor

.
<EOS>
His

was
a
nine
days
"
wonder
,
but

nothing
of

of
that
attempt
in
Suffolk

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
himself
told
the

to

,

at

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Scruby
complained

of
the
way
in

Vavasor
had
robbed

;
but
I

Scruby
,

,

.
<EOS>
To
Kate
,
down

,
no

of

,
and
her

in
London
with

had

.
<EOS>
Even

through
Captain

,
and

what
few
facts
she

from
Mrs.
Bunsby
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
was

,
"

Greenow
,
"

now

has

.
<EOS>
I
hate

,
and
,
as

,
I

will

much
better
that
he

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
Kate
was
of

,
but
,

,
she

to

.
   
<EOS>
In
Which
Come
Tidings
of
Great
Moment
to
All
Pallisers
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
not
till

had
been
for
a
day
or
two

at
Lucerne
that
Mr.
Grey
told

the
story
of
George

's

to

in
Suffolk

.
<EOS>
Having

of
his
connection
with
Alice
,
he
found

to
go
with
it
to
the
end
,

as

had

,
 
that

,

,

not

,

.
"
<EOS>
And
he
tried
to
murder

!
"
said
Mr.

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
should
be
caught
and
,
 
and
 
"
Mr.
Palliser

,
not

to
say

that
the
first

of
the
lady

was

ought

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
better
as
it
is
,
"
said
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
actually
walked
into
your
rooms
in
the
day

,
and
fired
a

at
you
as

!
<EOS>
He
did
that
in
London
,
and
then
walked
off
and
went
abroad
,
as
though
he
had
nothing
to
fear
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
was
just
it
,
"
said
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
began
to
think
that
something
ought
to
be
done
to
make
life
more
secure
in
the
metropolis
of

.
<EOS>
Had

not
known
Mr.
Grey
,
or
been
accustomed
to
see
the
other
man
in
Parliament
,
he
would
not
have
thought
so
much
about
it
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
almost
too
much
for
him
when
he
reflected
that
one
man
whom
he
now
called
his
friend
,
had
been
nearly
murdered
in
daylight
,
in
the
heart
of
his
own
part
of
London
,
by
another
man
whom
he
had
reckoned
among
his
Parliamentary
supporters
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
has
got
your
money
too
!
"
<EOS>
said
Palliser
,
putting
all
the
circumstances
of
the
case
together
.
<EOS>
In
answer
to
this
Mr.
Grey
said
that
he
hoped
the
loss
might
eventually
be
his
own
;
but
that
he
was
bound
to
regard
the
money
which
had
been
taken
as
part
of
Miss
Vavasor
's
fortune
.
"
<EOS>
He
is
simply
the
greatest
miscreant
of
whom
I
ever
heard
in
my
life
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
wonder
is
that
Miss
Vavasor
should
ever
have
brought
herself
to
 
to
like
him
.
"
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Grey
apologized
for
Alice
,
explaining
that
her
love
for
her
cousin
had
come
from
her
early
years
;
that
the
man
himself
was
clever
and

of
assuming
pleasant
ways
,
and
that
he
had
not
been
wholly
bad
till
ruin
had
come
upon
him
.
"
<EOS>
He
attempted
public
life
and
made
himself
miserable
by
failing
,
as
most
men
do
who
make
that
attempt
,
"
said
Grey
.
<EOS>
This
was
a
statement
which
Mr.
Palliser
could
not
allow
to
pass
without
notice
.
<EOS>
Whereupon
the
two
men
got
away
from
George
Vavasor
and
their
own
individual
interests
,
and
went
on
seriously
discussing
the
merits
and
demerits
of
public
life
.
<EOS>
"
The
end
of
it
all
is
,
"
said
Grey
at

,
"
that
public
men
in
England
should
be
rich
like
you
,
and
not
poor
like
that
miserable
wretch
,
who
has
now
lost
everything
that
the
Fates
had
given
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
continued
to
live
at
Lucerne
in
this
way
for
a
fortnight
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
,
though
he
was
not

alone
with
Alice
,
did
not

suit
in

;
but
continued
to
live
with
her
on
terms
of
close

.
<EOS>
He
had
told
her
that
her
cousin
had
left
England
,
 
that

had
gone
to
America

after
his
disappointment
in

the
seat
in

,
and
that

probably
not

.
"
<EOS>
Poor
George
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
had
said
;
"
he
is
a
man
very
much
to
be
pitied
.
"
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
man
very
much
to
be
pitied
,
"
Grey
had
replied
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
nothing
more

said
between

about
George
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
From
Lady
Glencora
Alice
did
hear
something
;
but
Lady
Glencora
herself
had
not
heard
the
whole

.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
he
misbehaved

,

,
"
Lady

;
"
but

,

.
<EOS>
I

that

saw

Grey

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

not

-
and

by
.
<EOS>
You
'll
be
able

.
<EOS>
"
In

Alice

,
and
Lady
Glencora
,
as
was

,
told

that
she
was
a

.
  
<EOS>
I
am
inclined
to
think
that
Mr.
Grey
knew
what

was
about
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
once
scolded
him
very

for
not

to

.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be
going
on
to
Italy

,
"

;
"
<EOS>
and
I

n't
suppose

go

,
unless
it
is
settled
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
protested
that
he
had
no

going
to
Italy
in
either
case
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then

will

for
another

,
and

both

you
as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
ancient

are
never

,
"
said
Grey
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
were
you
I
would
go
to

and
tell

,
roundly
,
that
she

,

.
<EOS>
If

,
till

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Suppose

,
Lady

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
.
<EOS>
It
's
she

always

,
 
as
you
will
her
,
when
she
's
your

.
<EOS>
You

Palliser
are

.
<EOS>
You

so
very

that
no

picking

.
"
  
<EOS>
But
Lady
Glencora
was
wrong
.
<EOS>
Alice
would
,
no
doubt
,
have
submitted
herself
patiently
to
her
lover
's
rebukes
,
and
would
have
confessed
her
own
sins
towards
him
with
any
amount
of
self
-
accusation
that
he
might
have
required
;
but
she
would
not
,
on

,
have
been
more
willing
to
obey
him
in
that
one
point
,
as
to
which
he
now
required
present

.
<EOS>
He
understood
that
she
must
be
taught
to
forgive
herself
for
the
evil
she
had
done
,
 
to
forgive

,
at
any
rate
in
part
,
 
before
she
could
be
induced
to
return
to
her
old

to
him
.
<EOS>
Thus
they
went
on
together
at
Lucerne
,
passing
quiet
,
idle
days
,
 
with
some
pretence
of
reading
,
with
a
considerable
amount
of
letter
-
writing
,
with
boat

and
pony
excursions
,
 
till
the
pony
excursions
came
to
a
sudden
end
by
means
of
a
violent
edict
,
as
to
which
,
and
the
cause
of
it
,
a
word
or
two
must
be
said
just
now
.
<EOS>
During
these
days
of
the
boats
and
the
ponies
,
the
carriage
which
Lady
Glencora
hated
so
vehemently
was
shut
up
in
limbo
,
and
things
went
very
pleasantly
with
her
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
received
political
letters
from
England
,
which
made
his
mouth
water
sadly
,
and
was
often
very
fidgety
.
<EOS>
Parliament
was
not
now
sitting
,
and
the
Government
would
,
of
course
,
remain
intact
till
next
February
.
<EOS>
Might
it
not
be
possible
that
when
the
rent
came
in
the
Cabinet
,
he
might
yet
be
present
at
the
darning
?
<EOS>
He
was
a
constant
man
,
and
had
once
declared
his
intention
of
being
absent
for
a
year
.
<EOS>
He
continued
to
speak
to
Grey
of
his
coming
travels
,
as
though
it
was
impossible
that
they
should
be
over
until
after
the
next
Easter
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
sighing
for
Westminster
,
and
regretting
the
blue
books
which
were
accumulating
themselves
at
Matching
;
 
till
on
a
sudden
,
there
came
to
him
tidings
which
upset
all
his
plans
,
which
routed
the
ponies
,
which
made
everything
impossible
,
which
made
the
Alps
impassable
and
the
railways
dangerous
,
which
drove
Burgo
Fitzgerald
out
of
Mr.
Palliser
's
head
,
and
so
confused
him
that
he
could
no
longer
calculate
the
blunders
of
the
present
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
.
<EOS>
All
the
Palliser
world
was
about
to
be
moved
from
its
lowest
depths
,
to
the
summits
of
its
highest
mountains
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
had
whispered
into
her
husband
's
ear
that
she
thought
it
probable
 
;
she
was
n't
sure
;
 
she
did
n't
know
.
<EOS>
And
then
she
burst
out
into
tears
on
his
bosom
as
he
sat
by
her
on
her
bedside
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
beside
himself
when
he
left
her
,
which
he
did
with
the
primary
intention
of
telegraphing
to
London
for
half
a
dozen
leading
physicians
.
<EOS>
He
went
out
by
the
lake
side
,
and
walked
there
alone
for
ten
minutes
in
a
state
of
almost
unconscious
exaltation
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
quite
remember
where
he
was
,
or
what
he
was
doing
.
<EOS>
The
one
thing
in
the
world
which
he
had
lacked
;
the
one
joy
which
he
had
wanted
so
much
,
and
which
is
so
common
among
men
,
was
coming
to
him
also
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
it
was
to
him
as
though
each
hand
already
rested
on
the
fair
head
of
a
little
male
Palliser
,
of
whom
one
should
rule
in
the
halls
at
Gatherum
,
and
the
other
be
eloquent
among
the
Commons
of
England
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
,
 
for
the
last
eight
or
nine
months
,
since
his
first
hopes
had
begun
to
fade
,
 
he
had
been
a
man
degraded
in
his
own
sight
amidst
all
his
honours
.
<EOS>
What
good
was
all
the
world
to
him
if
he
had
nothing
of
his
own
to
come
after
him
?
<EOS>
We
must
give
him
his
due
,
too
,
when
we
speak
of
this
.
<EOS>
He
had
not
had
wit
enough
to
hide
his
grief
from
his
wife
;
his
knowledge
of
women
and
of
men
in
social
life
had
not
been
sufficient
to
teach
him
how
this
should
be
done
;
but
he
had
wished
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
willingly
rebuked
her
for
his
disappointment
,
either
by
a
glance
of
his
eye
,
or
a
tone
of
his
voice
;
and
now
he
had
already
forgiven
everything
.
<EOS>
Burgo
Fitzgerald
was
a
myth
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Marsham
should
never
again
come
near
her
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bott
was
,
of
course
,
a
thing
abolished
;
 
he
had
not
even
had
the
sense
to
keep
his
seat
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
Dandy
and
Flirt
should
feed
on
gilded
corn
,
and
there
should
be
an
artificial
moon
always
ready
in
the
ruins
.
<EOS>
If
only
those
d
 
---
<EOS>
able
saddle
-
ponies
of
Lucerne
had
not
come
across
his
wife
's
path
!
<EOS>
He
went
at
once
into
the
yard
and
ordered
that
the
ponies
should
be
abolished
;
 
sent
away
,
one
and
all
,
to
the
furthest
confines
of
the
canton
;
and
then
he
himself
inspected
the
cushions
of
the
carriage
.
<EOS>
Were
they
dry
?
<EOS>
As
it
was
August
in
those
days
,
and
August
in
Lucerne
is
a
warm
month
,
it
may
be
presumed
that
they
were
dry
.
  
<EOS>
He
then
remembered
that
he
had
promised
to
send
Alice
up
to
his
wife
,
and
he
hurried
back
into
the
house
.
<EOS>
She
was
alone
in
the
breakfast
-
room
,
waiting
for
him
and
for
his
wife
.
<EOS>
In
these
days
,
Mr.
Grey
would
usually
join
them
at
dinner
;
but
he
seldom
saw
them
before
eleven
or
twelve
o'clock
in
the
day
.
<EOS>
Then
he
would
saunter
in
and
join
Mr.
Palliser
,
and
they
would
all
be
together
till
the
evening
.
<EOS>
When
the
expectant
father
of
embryo
dukes
entered
the
room
,
Alice
perceived
at
once
that
some
matter
was
astir
.
<EOS>
His
manner
was
altogether
changed
,
and
he
showed
by
his
eye
that
he
was
eager
and
moved
beyond
his
wo
nt
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
said
,
"
would
you
mind
going
up
to
Glencora
's
room
?
<EOS>
She
wishes
to
speak
to
you
.
"
<EOS>
He
had
never
called
her
Alice
before
,
and
as
soon
as
the
word
was
spoken
,
he
remembered
himself
and
blushed
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
n't
ill
,
I
hope
?
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
she
is
n't
ill
.
<EOS>
At
least
I
think
she
had
better
not
get
up
quite
yet
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
her
excite
herself
,
if
you
can
help
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
to
her
at
once
,
"
said
Alice
rising
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
so
much
obliged
to
you
;
 
but
,
Miss
Vavasor
 
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
called
me
Alice
just
now
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
and
I
took
it
as
a
great
compliment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
blushed
again
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Did
I
?
<EOS>
Very
well
.
<EOS>
Then
I
'll
do
it
again
 
if
you
'll
let
me
.
<EOS>
But
,
if
you
please
,
do
be
as
calm
with
her
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
She
is
so
easily
excited
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
Of
course
,
if
there
's
anything
she
fancies
,
we
'll
take
care
to
get
it
for
her
;
but
she
must
be
kept
quiet
.
<EOS>
"
Upon
this
Alice
left
him
,
having
had
no
moment
of
time
to
guess
what
had
happened
,
or
was
about
to
happen
;
and
he
was
again
alone
,
contemplating
the
future
glories
of
his
house
.
<EOS>
Had
he
a
thought
for
his
poor
cousin
Jeffrey
,
whose
nose
was
now
so
terribly
out
of
joint
?
<EOS>
No
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
His
thoughts
were
all
of
himself
,
and
the
good
things
that
were
coming
to
him
,
 
of
the
new
world
of
interest
that
was
being
opened
for
him
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
better
to
him
,
this
,
than
being
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
.
<EOS>
He
would
rather
have
it
in
store
for
him
to
be
father
of
the
next
Duke
of
Omnium
,
than
make
half
a
dozen
consecutive
annual
speeches
in
Parliament
as
to
the
ways
and
means
,
and
expenditure
of
the
British
nation
!
<EOS>
Could
it
be
possible
that
this
foreign
tour
had
produced
for
him
this
good
fortune
?
<EOS>
If
so
,
how
luckily
had
things
turned
out
!
<EOS>
He
would
remember
even
that
ball
at
Lady
Monk
's
with
gratitude
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
a
residence
abroad
would
be
best
for
Lady
Glencora
at
this
particular
period
of
her
life
.
<EOS>
If
so
,
abroad
she
should
certainly
live
.
<EOS>
Before
resolving
,
however
,
on
anything
permanently
on
this
head
,
he
thought
that
he
might
judiciously
consult
those
six
first
-
rate
London
physicians
,
whom
,
in
the
first
moment
of
his
excitement
,
he
had
been
desirous
of
summoning
to
Lucerne
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
Alice
had
gone
up
to
the
bedroom
of
the
lady
who
was
now
to
be
the
subject
of
so
much
anxious
thought
.
<EOS>
When
she
entered
the
room
,
her
friend
was
up
and
in
her
dressing
-
gown
,
lying
on
a
sofa
which
stood
at
the
foot
of
the

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.

.
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
Showing

.

Barsetshire
.
<EOS>
Though
,
by
-
the
-
by
,
I
do
n't
suppose
we
shall
go
anywhere
this
year
,
"
Mr.
Palliser
added
,
interrupting
the
warmth
of
his
invitation
,
and
reflecting
that
,
under
the
present

,
perhaps
,
it
might
be
improper
to
have
any
guests
at
Matching
in

.
<EOS>
But
he
had
become
very
fond
of
Mr.
Grey
,
and
on
this

,
as
he

done
on
some

,

to

Parliament
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
n't
nearly

,
"
said

,
when
Grey

that

not

.
<EOS>
"
See
the
men
that

.
<EOS>
There

Mr.
Vavasor
.
<EOS>
Even
he
got

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
had
to
pay

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
might

find

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quiet
little
boroughs
have
usually
got
their
own
quiet
little
Members
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
They
're
fond
of
change
;
and
if
you
like
to
spend
a
thousand
pounds
,
the
thing
is
n't
difficult
.
<EOS>
I
'll
put
you
in
the
way
of
it
.
"
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Grey
still
declined
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
man
prone
to
be
talked
out
of
his
own
way
of
life
,
and
the
very
fact
that
George
Vavasor
had
been
in
Parliament
would
of
itself
have
gone
far
towards
preventing
any
attempt
on
his
part
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
Alice
had
also
wanted
him
to
go
into
public
life
,
but
he
had
put
aside
her
request
as
though
the
thing
were
quite
out
of
the
question
,
 
never
giving
a
moment
to
its
consideration
.
<EOS>
Had
she
asked
him
to
settle
himself
and
her
in
Central
Africa
,
his
manner
and
mode
of
refusal
would
have
been
the
same
.
<EOS>
It
was
this
immobility
on
his
part
,
 
this
absolute
want
of
any
of
the
weakness
of
indecision
,
which
had
frightened
her
,
and
driven
her
away
from
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
partly
aware
of
this
;
but
that
which
he
had
declined
to
do
at
her

,
he
certainly
would
not
do
at
the
advice
of
any
one
else
.
<EOS>
So
it
was
that
he
argued
the
matter
with
himself
.
<EOS>
Had
he
now
allowed
himself
to
be
so

,
with
what

acknowledgements
of
his
own

must
he
not
have

Alice
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
books
,
then
,
will
be
your
object
in
life
?
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
they
will
be
my
aids
,
"
Grey
answered
.
<EOS>
"
I
almost
doubt
whether
any
object
such
as
that
you
mean

necessary

,
or
even

.
<EOS>
It
seems

that
if
a
man

so

that
he
may
live
honestly
and
die
fearlessly
,
he
has
done
about

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
has
done
a

deal
,

,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
who
was
not

enough
to

the
argument
as
he
might
have
done
<EOS>
had
more

been

to

to

.
<EOS>
He
knew
very
well
that
he
himself
was
working
for
others
,
and
not
for
himself
;
and
he
was
aware
,
though
he
had
not

his
own

on
the

,
that
good
men
struggle
as
they
do
in
order
that
others
,
besides
themselves
,
may
live
honestly
,
and
,
if
possible
,
die
fearlessly
.
<EOS>
The
recluse
of
Nethercoats
had
thought
much
more
about
all
this
than
the
rising
star
of
the
House
of
Commons
;
but
the
philosophy
of
the
rising
star
was
the
better

of
the
two
,
though
he
was
by
far

less

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
see
why
a
man
should
not
live
honestly
and
be
a
Member
of
Parliament
as
well
,
"
continued
Mr.
Palliser
,
when

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
I
either
,
"
said
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
sure
that
there
are
such
men
,
and
that
the
country
is
under
great

to
them
.
<EOS>
But
they
are
subject
to
temptations
which
a
prudent
man
like
myself
may
perhaps
do
well
to
avoid
.
"
<EOS>
But
though
he
spoke
with
an
assured
tone
,
he
was
shaken
,
and
almost
regretted
that
he
did
not
accept
the
aid
which
was
offered
to
him
.
<EOS>
It
is
astonishing
how
strong
a
man
may
be
to
those
around
him
,
 
<EOS>
how
impregnable
may
be
his
exterior
,
while
within
he
feels
himself
to
be
as
weak
as
water
,
and
as
unstable
as
chaff
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
object
which
he
had
now
in
view
was
a
renewal
of
his

with
Alice
,
and
he
felt
that
he
must
obtain

her
before

Lucerne
.
<EOS>
If
she
still
persisted
in
refusing
to

,
it
would
not
be
consistent
with
his

as

man
to

of

any

.
<EOS>
In
such
case
he
must
leave
her
,
and
see
what
future
time
might
bring
forth
.
<EOS>
He
believed
himself
to
be
aware
that
he
would
never
offer
his
love
to
another
woman
;
and
if
Alice
were
to
remain
single
,
he
might
try
again
,
after
the

of
a
year
or
two
.
<EOS>
But
if
he
failed
now
,
 
then
,
for
that
year
or
two
,
he
would
see
her
no
more
.
<EOS>
Having
so
resolved
,
and
being
averse
to
anything
like
a
surprise
,
he
asked
her
,
as
he
left
her
one
evening
,
whether
she
would
walk
with
him
on
the
following
morning
.
<EOS>
That
morning
would
be
the
morning
of
her
last
day
at
Lucerne
;
and
as
she
assented
she
knew
well
what
was
to
come
.
<EOS>
She
said
nothing
to
Lady
Glencora
on
the
subject
,
but
allowed
the
coming
prospects
of
the
Palliser
family
to
form
the
sole
subject
of
their
conversation
that
night
,
as
it
had
done
on
every
night
since
the
great
news
had
become
known
.
<EOS>
They
were
always
together
for
an
hour
every
evening
before
Alice
was
allowed
to
go
to
bed
,
and
during
this
hour
the
anxieties
of
the
future
father
and
mother
were
always
discussed
till
Alice
Vavasor
was
almost
tired
of
them
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
patient
with
her
friend
,
and
on
this
special
night
she
was
patient
as
ever
.
<EOS>
But
when
she
was
released
and
was
alone
,
she
made
a
great
endeavour
to
come
to
some
fixed
resolution
as
to
what
she
would
do
on
the
morrow
,
 
some
resolution
which
should
be
absolutely
resolute
,
and
from
which
no
eloquence
on
the
part
of
any
one
should
move
her
.
<EOS>
But
such
resolutions
are
not
easily
reached
,
and
Alice
laboured
through
half
the
night
almost
in
vain
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
she
loved
the
man
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
he
was
as
true
to
her
as
the
sun
is
true
to
the
earth
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
she
would
be
,
in
all
respects
,
safe
in
his
hands
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
Lady
Glencora
would
be
delighted
,
and
her
father
gratified
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
the
countesses
would
open
their
arms
to
her
,
 
though
I
doubt
whether
this
knowledge
was
in
itself
very

.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
by
such
a
marriage
she
would
gain
all
that
women
generally
look
to
gain
when
they
give
themselves
away
.
<EOS>
But
,
nevertheless
,
as
far
as
she
could
decide
at
all
,
she
decided
against
her
lover
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
right
of
her
own
to
be
taken
back
after
the
evil
that
she
had
done
,
and
she
did
not

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
are
you
going
?
"
said

,
when

with

hat

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
walk
,
 
with
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
By

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
by
appointment
.
<EOS>
He
asked
me
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
it
's
all

,

have

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
that
is
settled
I
have
told
you
very
often
.
<EOS>
He

me
yesterday
to
walk
with
him
this
morning
,
and
I
could
not
well

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
you
have

to

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
said

I
did

.
<EOS>
But
I
hate
scenes
,
and
I
think
it
would
have
been

for
us
to
have
parted
without
any

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
you
are
such
a

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
you
tell
me
very
often
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
he
is
now
going
to
say
the
very
thing
that
he
has
come
all
this

.
<EOS>
He
has

about

;
but
then
slow

,
you
are
slower
.
<EOS>
If
you
do
n't
make
it
up
with
him
now
,
I
really
shall
think
you
are
very
wicked
.
<EOS>
I
am
becoming
like
Lady
Midlothian
;
 
I
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
I
know
you
want
to
be
his
wife
,
and
<EOS>
I
know
he
wants
to

your

,
and
the

that
keeps

apart
is
your
obstinacy
,
 
just

you
have
said

would
n't

.
<EOS>
My
belief
is
that
if
Lady
Midlothian
and

rest

were
to
pat

on

,
and
tell

,

'd

to
take

,

.
<EOS>
You
may
be
sure
of
this
,
Alice
;
if
you
refuse

now
,

'll

.
"
  
<EOS>
This
,
and
much
more
of
the
same
kind
<EOS>
,
she
bore
before
Mr.
Grey
came
to
take
her
,
and
she
answered
to
it
all
as
little
as
she
could
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
making
me
very
unhappy
,
Glencora
,
"
she
said
once
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
could
break
you
down
with
unhappiness
,
"
Lady
Glencora
answered
,
"
so
that
he
might
find
you
less
stiff
,
and

,
and
unmanageable
.
"
<EOS>
Directly
upon
that
he
came
in
,
looking
as
though
he
had
no
business
on
hand
more
exciting
than
his
ordinary

's

.
<EOS>
Alice
at
once
got
up
to
start

.
"
<EOS>
So
you
and
Alice
are
going
to
make

adieux
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
done
sooner
or
later
,
"
said
Mr.
Grey
;
and
then
they
went
off
.
  
<EOS>
Those
who
know
Lucerne
,
 
and
almost
everybody
now
does
know
Lucerne
,
 
will
remember
the
big
hotel
which
has
been
built
close
to
the
landing
-
pier
of
the
steamers
,
and
will
remember
also
the
church
that
stands
upon
a
little
hill
or
rising
ground
,
to
the
left
of
you
,
as
you
come
out
of
the
inn
upon
the
lake
.
<EOS>
The
church
is
immediately
over
the
lake
,
and
round
the
church
there
is
a
burying
-
ground
,
and
skirting
the
burying
-
ground
there
are
cloisters
,
through
the
arches
and
apertures
of
which
they
who
walk
and
sit
there
look
down
immediately
upon
the
blue
water
,
and
across
the
water
upon
the
frowning
menaces
of
Mount
Pilate
.
<EOS>
It
is
one
of
the
prettiest
spots
in
that
land
of
beauty
;
and
its
charm
is
to
my
feeling
enhanced
by
the
sepulchral
monuments
over
which
I
walk
,
and
by
which
I
am
surrounded
,
as
I
stand
there
.
<EOS>
Up
here
,
into
these
cloisters
,
Alice
and
John
Grey
went
together
.
<EOS>
I
doubt
whether
he
had
formed
any
purpose
of
doing
so
.
<EOS>
She
certainly
would
have
gone
without
question
in
any
direction
that
he
might
have
led
her
.
<EOS>
The
distance
from
the
inn
up
to
the
church
-
gate
did
not
take
them
ten
minutes
,
and
when
they
were
there
their
walk
was
over
.
<EOS>
But
the
place
was
solitary
,
and
they
were
alone
;
and
it
might
be
as
well
for
Mr.
Grey
to
speak
what
words
he
had
to
say
there
as
elsewhere
.
<EOS>
They
had
often
been
together
in
those
cloisters
before
,
but
on
such
occasions
either
Mr.
Palliser
or
Lady
Glencora
had
been
with
them
.
<EOS>
On
their
slow
passage
up
the
hill
very
little
was
spoken
,
and
that
little
was
of
no
moment
.
<EOS>
"
We
will
go
in
here
for
a
few
minutes
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
the
prettiest
spot
about
Lucerne
,
and
we
do
n't
know
when
we
may
see
it
again
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
they
went
in
,
and
sat
down
on
one
of
the
embrasures
that
open
from
the
cloisters
over
the
lake
.
  
<EOS>
"
Probably
never
again
,
"
said
Alice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
I
have
been
here
now
two
years
running
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
shuddered
as
she
remembered
that
in
that
former
year
George
Vavasor
had
been
with
her
.
<EOS>
As
she
thought
of
it
all
she
hated
herself
.
<EOS>
Over
and
over
again
she
had
told
herself
that
she
had
so
mismanaged
the
latter
years
of
her
life
that
it
was
impossible
for
her
not
to
hate
herself
.
<EOS>
No
woman
had
a
clearer
idea
of
feminine
constancy
than
she
had
,
and
no
woman
had
sinned
against
that
idea
more
deeply
.
<EOS>
He
gave
her
time
to
think
of
all
this
as
he
sat
there
looking
down
upon
the
water
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
I
would
sooner
live
in
Cambridgeshire
,
"
were
the
first
words
he
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Partly
because
all
beauty
is
best
enjoyed
when
it
is
sought
for
with
some
trouble
and
difficulty
,
and
partly
because
such
beauty
,
and
the
romance
which
is
attached
to
it
,
should
not
make
up
the
staple
of
one
's
life
.
<EOS>
Romance
,
if
it
is
to
come
at
all
,
should
always
come
by
fits
and
starts
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
live
in
a
pretty
country
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
would
like
to
live
a
romantic
life
,
 
no
doubt
;
but
all
those
things
lose
their
charm
if
they
are
made
common
.
<EOS>
When
a
man
has
to
go
to
Vienna
or
St.
Petersburg
two
or
three
times
a
month
,
you
do
n't
suppose
he
enjoys
travelling
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
the
same
,
I
should
like
to
live
in
a
pretty
country
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
want
you
to
come
and
live
in
a
very
ugly
country
.
<EOS>
"
Then
he
paused
for
a
minute
or
two
,
not
looking
at
her
,
but
gazing
still
on
the
mountain
opposite
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
speak
a
word
,
but
looked
as
he
was
looking
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
the
request
was
coming
,
and
had
been
thinking
about
it
all
night
;
but
now
that
it
had
come
she
did
not
know
how
to
bear
herself
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
,
"
he
went
on
to
say
,
"
that
you
would
let
that
consideration
stand
in
your
way
,
if
on
other
grounds
you
were
willing
to
become
my
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
consideration
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Because
Nethercoats
is
not
so
pretty
as
Lucerne
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
It
would
have
nothing
to
do
with
it
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
should
have
nothing
to
do
with
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
;
nothing
at
all
,
"
repeated
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
come
,
then
?
<EOS>
Will
you
come
and
be
my
wife
,
and
help
me
to
be
happy
amidst
all
that
ugliness
?
<EOS>
Will
you
come
and
be
my
one
beautiful
thing
,
my
treasure
,
my
joy
,
my
comfort
,
my
counsellor
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
want
no
counsellor
,
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
man
ever
wanted
one
more
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
this
has
been
a
bad
year
to
me
,
and
I
do
not
think
that
it
has
been
a
happy
one
for
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Indeed
,
no
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
forget
it
,
 
or
rather
,
let
us
treat
it
as
though
it
were
forgotten
.
<EOS>
Twelve
months
ago
you
were
mine
.
<EOS>
You
were
,
at
any
rate
,
so
much
mine
that
I
had
a
right
to
boast
of
my
possession
among
my
friends
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
poor
boast
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
did
not
seem
to
think
so
.
<EOS>
I
had
<EOS>
but
one
or
two
to
whom
I
could
speak
of
you
,
but
they
told
me
that
I
was
going
to
be
a
happy
man
.
<EOS>
As
to
myself
,
I
was
sure
that
I
was
to
be
so
.
<EOS>
No
man
was
ever
better
contented
with
his
bargain
than
I

.
<EOS>
Let
us
go
back
to
it
,
and
the
last
twelve
months
shall
be
as
though
they
had
never
been
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
can
not
be
,
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
If
it
could
,
I
should
be
worse
even
than
I
am
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
can
not
it
be
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
can
not
forgive
myself
what
I
have
done
,
and
because
you
ought
not
to
forgive
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
.
<EOS>
There
has
never
been
an
hour
with
me
in
which
there
has
been
an
offence
of
yours
rankling
in
my

unforgiven
.
<EOS>
I
think
you
have
been
foolish
,
misguided
,
 
<EOS>
led
away
by
a
vain
ambition
,
and
that
in
the
difficulty
to
which
these
things
brought
you
,
you
endeavoured
to
constrain
yourself
to
do
an
act
,
which
,
when

came
near
to

,
 
when
the
doing
of
it
had
to
be
more

,
you
found
to
be
contrary
to
your
nature
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
as
he
spoke
thus
,
she
turned
her

upon
him
,
and
looked
at
him
,
wondering
that
he
should
have
had
power
to
read
her
heart
so
accurately
.
<EOS>
"
I
never
believed
that
you
would
marry
your
cousin
.
<EOS>
When
I
was
told
of
it
,
I
knew
that
trouble
had
blinded
you
for
awhile
.
<EOS>
You
had
driven
yourself
to
revolt
against
me
,
and
upon
that
your
heart
misgave
you
,
and
<EOS>
you
said
to
yourself
that
it
did
not
matter
then
how
you
might
throw
away

your

.
<EOS>
You
see
that
I
speak
of
your
old
love
for
me
with
the

of
a
happy
lover
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
 
no
,
no
!
"
<EOS>
she
ejaculated
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
the
storm
passes
over
the
tree
and
does
not
tear
it
up
by
the
roots
or
spoil
it
of
all
its
symmetry
.
<EOS>
When
we
hear
the
winds
blowing
,
and
see
how
the
poor
thing
is
shaken
,
we
think
that
its
days
are
numbered
and
its
destruction
at
hand
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
when
the
winds
were
shaking
you
,
and
you
were

and

,
I
never
thought
so
.
<EOS>
There
may
be
some
who
will
forgive

slowly
.
<EOS>
Your
own
self
-

will

.
<EOS>
But
I
,
who
have
known
you
better
than
any

,
 
yes
,
better
than
any

,
 
I
have
forgiven

,
have

.
<EOS>
Come
to
me
,
Alice
,
and
comfort
me
.
<EOS>
Come
to
me
,
for
I
want
you
sorely
.
"
<EOS>
She
sat
quite
still
,
looking
at
the
lake
and
the
mountain
beyond
,
but
she
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
What
could
she
say
to
him
?
<EOS>
"
My
need
of
you
is
much
greater
now
,
"
he
went
on
to
say
,
"
than
when
I
first
asked
you
to
share
the
world
with
me
.
<EOS>
Then
I
could
have
borne
to
lose
you
,
as
I
had
never
boasted
to
myself
that
you
were
my
own
,
 
had
never
pictured
to
myself
the
life
that
might
be
mine
if
you

always
to

.
<EOS>
But
since
that

I
have
had
no
other

,
 
no
other
hope
but
this
for
which
I
plead
now
.
<EOS>
Am
I
to
plead
in
vain
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
know
me
,
"
she
said
;
"
how
vile
I
have
been
!
<EOS>
You
do
not

what
it
is
,
 
for
a
woman
to
have

one

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
was

you

.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
Alice
,
I
can
forgive
that
.
<EOS>
Do
I
not

you
that
I
did

it
the

?
<EOS>
Do
you
not

that
I
never

would

?
<EOS>
Alice
,
you
should

for
my

,
for
I
have
believed
all

that
you
loved

,

.
<EOS>
Come
to

,
dear
,
and

that

,
and

past
shall
be

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
dreaming
it
always
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
will
cease
to
be
bitter

if
your

be

my

.
<EOS>
You
will
cease
to
reproach
yourself
when
you
know
that
you
have
made
me
happy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
cease
to

.
<EOS>
I
have
done
that
which
no
woman
can
do
and

.
<EOS>
I
have
been
 
a
jilt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
noblest

that
ever
yet
halted
between
two

!
<EOS>
There
has
been
no

of

in

.
<EOS>
I
think
I
could
be
hard
enough
upon
a
woman
who
had

greater

,
for

,
 
who
had
left
me
even
that
she
might

gay

.
<EOS>
It
has
not
been

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
has
.
<EOS>
I
thought
you
were
too

in
your
own
will
,
and
 
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
you
think
so
still
.
<EOS>
Is
that
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
does
not
matter
what
I
think
now
.
<EOS>
I
am
a
fallen
creature
,
and
have
no
longer
a
right
to
such

.
<EOS>
It
will
be
better
for
us
both
that
you
should
leave
me
,
 
and

.
<EOS>
There
are
things
which
,
if
a
woman

,
should
never

;
 
which
she
should
never

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
am
I
to
be
punished
,
then
,
because
of
your

?
<EOS>
Is
that
your
sense
of
justice
?
"
<EOS>
He
got
up
,
and
standing
before
her
,
looked
down
upon

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Alice
,
if
you
will
tell
me
that
you
do
not
love
me
,
I
will
believe
you
,
and
will
trouble
you
no
more
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
you
will
say
nothing
to
me
that
is
false
.
<EOS>
Through
it
all
you
have
spoken
no
word
of
falsehood
.
<EOS>
If
you
love
me
,
after
what
has
passed
,
I
have
a
right
to
demand
your
hand
.
<EOS>
My
happiness
requires
it
,
and
I
have
a
right
to
expect
your
compliance
.
<EOS>
I
do
demand
it
.
<EOS>
If
you
love
me
,
Alice
,
I
tell
you
that
you
dare
not
refuse
me
.
<EOS>
If
you
do
so
,
you
will
fail
hereafter
to
reconcile
it
to
your
conscience
before
God
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
he
stopped
his
speech
,
and
waited
for
a
reply
;
but
Alice
sat
silent
beneath
his
gaze
,
with
her
eyes
turned
upon
the
tombstones
beneath
her
feet
.
<EOS>
Of
course
she
had
no
choice
but
to
yield
.
<EOS>
He
,
possessed
of
power
and
force
infinitely
greater
than
hers
,
had
left
her
no
alternative
but
to
be
happy
.
<EOS>
But
there
still
clung
to
her
what
I
fear
we
must
call
a
perverseness
of
obstinacy
,
a
desire
to
maintain
the
resolution
she
had
made
,
 
a
wish
that
she
might
be
allowed
to
undergo
the
punishment
she
had
deserved
.
<EOS>
She
was
as
a
prisoner
who
would
fain
cling
to
his
prison
after
pardon
has
reached
him
,
because
he
is
conscious
that
the
pardon
is
undeserved
.
<EOS>
And
it
may
be
that
there
was
still
left
within
her
bosom
some
remnant
of
that
feeling
of
rebellion
which
his
masterful
spirit
had
ever
produced
in
her
.
<EOS>
He
was
so
imperious
in
his
tranquillity
,
he
argued
his
question
of
love
with
such
a
manifest
preponderance
of
right
on
his
side
,
that
she
had
always
felt
that
to
yield
to
him
would
be
to
confess
the
omnipotence
of
his
power
.
<EOS>
She
knew
now
that
she
must
yield
to
him
,
 
that
his
power
over
her
was
omnipotent
.
<EOS>
She
was
pressed
by
him
as
in
some
countries
the
prisoner
is
pressed
by
the
judge
,
 
so
pressed
that
she
acknowledged
to
herself
silently
that
any
further
antagonism
to
him
was
impossible
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,
the
word
which
she
had
to
speak
still
remained
unspoken
,
and
he
stood
over
her
,
waiting
for
her
answer
.
<EOS>
Then
slowly
he
sat
down
beside
her
,
and
gradually
he
put
his
arm
round
her
waist
.
<EOS>
She
shrank
from
him
,
back
against
the
stonework
of
the
embrasure
,
but
she
could
not
shrink
away
from
his
grasp
.
<EOS>
She
put
up
her
hand
to
impede
his
,
but
his
hand
,
like
his
character
and
his
words
,
was
full
of
power
.
<EOS>
It
would
not
be
impeded
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
pressed
her
close
with
his
arm
,
"
the
battle
is
over
now
,
and
I
have
won
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
win
everything
,
 
always
,
"
she
said
,
whispering
to
him
,
as
she
still
shrank
from
his
embrace
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
winning
you
I
have
won
everything
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
he
put
his
face
over
her
and
pressed
his
lips
to
hers
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
whether
he
was
made
happier
when
he
knew
that
no
other
touch
had
profaned
those
lips
since
last
he
had
pressed
them
?
   
<EOS>
Rouge
et
Noir
.
 
<EOS>
Alice
insisted
on
being
left
up
in
the
churchyard
,
urging
that
she
wanted
to
"
think
about
it
all
,
"
but
,
in
truth
,
fearing
that
she
might
not
be
able
to
carry
herself
well
,
if
she
were
to
walk
down
with
her
lover
to
the
hotel
.
<EOS>
To
this
he
made
no
objection
,
and
,
on
reaching
the
inn
,
met
Mr.
Palliser
in
the
hall
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
already
inspecting
the
arrangement
of
certain
large
trunks
which
had
been
brought
down
-
stairs
,
and
was
preparing
for
their
departure
.
<EOS>
He
was
going
about
the
house
,
with
a
nervous
solicitude
to
do
something
,
and
was
flattering
himself
that
he
was
of
use
.
<EOS>
As
he
could
not
be
Chancellor
of
the
Exchequer
,
and
as
,
by
the
nature
of
his
disposition
,
some
employment
was
necessary
to
him
,
he
was
looking
to
the
cording
of
the
boxes
.
"
<EOS>
Good
morning
!
<EOS>
good
morning
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
said
to
Grey
,
hardly
looking
at
him
,
as
though
time
were
too
precious
with

to
allow
of
his
turning

upon
his
friend
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
up
to
the
station
to
see
after
a
carriage
for
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
'll
come
with
me
.
"
<EOS>
To
this

Mr.
Grey
assented
.
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
,
you
know
,
"
continued
Mr.
Palliser
,
"
the
springs
of
the
carriages
are
so
very
rough
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
,
in
a
very
few
words
,
Mr.
Grey
told
him
what
had
been
his
own
morning
's
work
.
<EOS>
He
hated
secrets
and
secrecy
,
and
as
the
Pallisers
knew
well
what
had
brought
him
upon
their
track
,
it
was
,
he
thought
,
well
that
they
should
know
that
he
had
been
successful
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
congratulated
him
very

,
and
then
,
running
up
-
stairs
for
his
gloves
or

stick
,
or
,
more

,
that

one
other

as
to
her

of

,
he

also
that
Alice
had
yielded
at
last
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of
course
she
has
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
did
n't
think
she
would
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
because
you
do
n't
understand
things
of
that
sort
,
"
said
his
wife
.
<EOS>
Then
the
caution
was
repeated
,
the
mother
of
the
future
duke
was

,
and
Mr.
Palliser
went
off
on
his
mission
about
the
carriage
,
its

,
and
its

.
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
their
walk
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
suggested
that
,
as
things
were
settled
so
pleasantly
,
Mr.
Grey
might
as
well
return
with

to
England
,
and
to
this

Mr.
Grey
assented
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
remained
alone
for
nearly
an
hour
,
looking
out
upon
the
rough
sides
and
gloomy
top
of
Mount
Pilate
.
<EOS>
No
one
disturbed
her
in
the
churchyard
,
 
<EOS>
no
steps
were
heard
along
the
tombstones
,
 
no
voice
sounded
through
the
cloisters
.
<EOS>
She
was
left
in
perfect
solitude
to
think
of
the
past
,
and
form
her
plans
of
the
future
.
<EOS>
Was
she
happy
<EOS>
,
now
that
the
manner
of
her
life
to
come
was
thus
settled
for
her
;
that
all
further
question
as
to
the
disposal
of
herself
was
taken
out
of
her
hands
,
and
that
her
marriage
with
a
man
she
loved
was
so
firmly
arranged
that
no
further
folly
of
her
own
could
disarrange
it
?
<EOS>
She
was
happy
,
though
she
was
slow
to
confess
her
happiness
to
herself
.
<EOS>
She
was
happy
,
and
she
was
resolute
in
this
,
 
that
she
would
now
do
all
she
could
to
make
him
happy
also
.
<EOS>
And
there
must
now
,
she
acknowledged
,
be
an
end
to
her
pride
,
 
to
that
pride
which
had
hitherto
taught
her
to
think
that
she
could
more
wisely
follow
her
own
guidance
than
that
of
any
other
who
might
claim
to
guide
her
.
<EOS>
She
knew
now
that
she
must
follow
his
guidance
.
<EOS>
She
had
found
her
master
,
as
we
sometimes
say
,
and
laughed
to
herself
with
a
little
inward
laughter
as
she
confessed
that
it
was
so
.
<EOS>
She
was
from
henceforth
altogether
in
his
hands
.
<EOS>
If
he
chose
to
tell
her
that
they
were
to
be
married
at
Michaelmas
,
or
at
Christmas
,
or
on
Lady
Day
,
they
would
,

,
be
married
accordingly
.
<EOS>
She
had
taken
her
fling
at
having
her
own
will
,
and
she
and
all
her
friends
had
seen
what
had
come
of
it
.
<EOS>
She
had
assumed
the
command
of
the
ship
,
and
had
thrown
it
upon
the
rocks
,
and
she
felt
that
she
never
ought
to
take
the

's

again
.
<EOS>
It
was
well
for
her
that
he
who
was
to
be
captain
was
one
whom
she
respected
as

as
she
loved

.
  
<EOS>
She
would
write
to
her
father
at
once
,
 
to
her
father
and
Lady
Macleod
,
 
and
would
confess
everything
.
<EOS>
She
felt
that
she
owed
it
to
them
that
they
should
be
told
by
herself
that
they
had
been
right
and
that
she

been

.
<EOS>
Hitherto
<EOS>
she
had
not
mentioned
to

the

that
Mr.
Grey
was
with

in

.
<EOS>
And
,
then
,
what
must

do

Lady
Midlothian
?
<EOS>
As

Lady
Midlothian
,
she
would
do
nothing
.
<EOS>
Lady
Midlothian
,
of
course
,
would
triumph
;
 
would
jump
upon

,
as
Lady
Glencora
had
once

,

,
 
would

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

have
nothing

do

Lady

,
unless
,

,

Grey
should

.
<EOS>
Then
she
laughed
at

again
with
that
inward

,
and
,
rising

her
seat
,
proceeded

the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Vanquished
at
last
!
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
vanquished
;
if
you

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
what
I

,
but
what
you
feel

,
"
said

other
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you

that
I
do

to

that
you
regard

now
as
an

,
 
as
a

in
war
,

,
without

?
<EOS>
I

that

that

happy
woman
of
at

.
<EOS>
I
understand
it
all
,
<EOS>
my

,
and
my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
;
I
knew

the

you
would

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
what
way
would
you
have
me
treat

?
<EOS>
If
I
were
to
hug
you
with

,
and

how

he

,

,
 
if

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Do

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

;

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

Lady
Midlothian
in

,

.
<EOS>
But

;

,

.
<EOS>
I

the

,

;

.
<EOS>
I
do

mean

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

to

.
<EOS>
What

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,

,
if

will

.
<EOS>
Some

do
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
And
how
happy
you
will

!
<EOS>
He
'll
never

the

-

,
and

no
Mr.
Bott

.
<EOS>
"
They
sat
together
the
whole

,
 
while
Mr.
Palliser
was
seeing
to
the
springs
and
cushions
,
 
and
by
degrees
Alice
began
to

.
<EOS>
As

did
so
her
friend
enjoyed
it

,
and
at

something
of

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
That
's

in

I
can
be

;
and
if
we
can
bespeak
some
sun
,
we
'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
they
all
started
together
,
a
first
-
class
compartment
having
been
taken
for
the
Palliser

,
and

-

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
as
he
slowly
handed
his
wife
in
,
was
a
triumphant
man
;
as
was
also
Mr.
Grey
,
as
he
handed
in
his
lady
-
love
,
though
,
in

manner
,
much
less

.
<EOS>
We
may
say
that
both
the
gentlemen
had
been
very
fortunate
while
at
Lucerne
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
come
abroad
with
a
feeling
that
all
the
world
had
been
cut
from
under
his
feet
.
<EOS>
A
great
change
was
needed
for
his
wife
,
and
he
had
acknowledged
at
once
that
everything
must
be
made
to
yield
to
that
necessity
.
<EOS>
He
certainly
had
his
reward
,
 
now
in
his
triumphant
return
.
<EOS>
Terrible
troubles
had
afflicted
him
as
he
went
,
which
seemed
now
to
have
dissipated
themselves
altogether
.
<EOS>
When
he
thought
of
Burgo
Fitzgerald
he
remembered
him
only
as
a
poor
,
unfortunate
fellow
,
for
whom
he
should
be
glad
to
do
something
,
if
the
doing
of
anything
were
only
in
his
power
;
and
he
had
in
his
pocket
a
letter
which
he
had
that
morning
received
from
the
Duke
of
St.
Bungay
,
marked
private
and
confidential
,
which
was
in
its
nature
very
private
and
confidential
,
and
in
which
he
was
told
that
Lord
Brock
and
Mr.
Finespun
were
totally
at
variance
about
French
wines
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Finespun
wanted
to
do
something
,
now
in
the
recess
,
 
to
send
some
political
agent
over
to
France
,
 
to
which
Lord
Brock
would
not
agree
;
and
no
one
knew
what
would
be
the
consequence
of
this
disagreement
.
<EOS>
Here
might
be
another
chance
,
 
if
only
Mr.
Palliser
could
give
up
his
winter
in
Italy
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
as
he
took
his
place
opposite
his
wife
,
was
very
triumphant
.
  
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Grey
was
triumphant
,
as
he
placed
himself
gently
in
his
seat
opposite
to
Alice
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
assume
no
right
,
as
he
took
that
position
apparently
because
it
was
the
one
which
came
naturally
to
his
lot
.
<EOS>
No
one
would
have
been
made
aware
that
Alice
was
his
own
simply
by
seeing
his
arrangements
for
her
comfort
.
<EOS>
He
made
no
loud
assertion
as
to
his
property
and
his
rights
,
as
some
men
do
.
<EOS>
He
was
quiet
and
subdued
in
his
joy
,
but
not
the
less
was
he
triumphant
.
<EOS>
From
the
day
on
which
Alice
had
accepted
his
first
offer
,
 
nay
,
from
an
earlier
day
than
that
;
from
the
day
on
which
he
had
first
resolved
to
make
it
,
down
to
the
present
hour
,
he
had
never
been
stirred
from
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
By
every
word
that
he
had
said
,
and
by
every
act
that
he
had
done
,
he
had
shown
himself
to
be
unmoved
by
that
episode
in
their
joint
lives
,
which
Alice
's
other
friends
had
regarded
as
so
fatal
.
<EOS>
When
she
first
rejected
him
,
he
would
not
take
his
rejection
.
<EOS>
When
she
told
him
that
she
intended
to
marry
her
cousin
,
he
silently
declined
to
believe
that
such
marriage
would
ever
take
place
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
given
her
up
for
a
day
,
and
now
the
event
proved
that
he
had
been
right
.
<EOS>
Alice
was
happy
,
very
happy
;
but
she
was
still
disposed
to
regard
her
lover
as
Fate
,
and
her
happiness
as
an
enforced
necessity
.
  
<EOS>
They
stopped
a
night
at
Basle
,
and
again
she
stood
upon
the
balcony
.
<EOS>
He
was
close
to
her
as
she
stood
there
,
 
so
close
that
,
putting
out
her
hand
for
his
,
she
was
able
to
take
it
and
press

closely
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
thinking
of
something
,
Alice
,
"
he
said
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
here
,
"
she
said
 
"
here
,
on
this
very

,
that
I
first
rebelled
against
you
,
and
now
you
have
brought

here
that
I
should

and
submit
on

.
<EOS>
I
do
confess
.
<EOS>
How
am
I
to
thank
you
for
forgiving
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
On
the
following
morning
they
went
on
to
Baden
-
Baden
,
and
there
they
stopped
for
a
couple
of
days
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
had
positively
refused
to
stop
a
day
at
Basle
,
making
so
many
objections
to
the
place
that
her
husband
had
at
last
yielded
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
go
from
Vienna
to
London
without
feeling
it
,
"
she
said
,
with
indignation
;
"
and
to
tell
me
that
I
ca
n't
do
two
easy
days
"
journey
running
!
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
been
afraid
to
be
imperious
,
and
therefore
,
immediately
on
his
arrival
at
one
of
the
stations
in
Basle
,
he
had
posted
across
the
town
,
in
the
heat
and
the
dust
,
to
look
after
the
cushions
and
the
springs
at
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
a
particular
favour
to
ask
of
you
,
"
Lady
Glencora
said
to
her
husband
,
as
soon
as
they
were
alone
together
in
their
rooms
at
Baden
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
declared
that
he
would
grant
her
any
particular
favour
,
 
only
premising
that
he
was
not
to
be
supposed
to
have
thereby
committed
himself
to
any
engagement
under
which
his
wife
should
have
authority
to
take
any
exertion
upon
herself
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
were
a
milkmaid
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
are
not
a
milkmaid
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
You
have
n't
been
brought
up
like
a
milkmaid
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
what
was
the
favour
?
<EOS>
If
she
would
only
ask
for
jewels
,
 
though
they
were
the
Grand
Duchess
's
diamond
eardrops
,
he
would
endeavour
to
get
them
for
her
.
<EOS>
If
she
would
have
quaffed
molten
pearls
,
like
Cleopatra
,
he
would
have
procured
the
beverage
,
 
having
first
fortified
himself
with
a
medical
opinion
as
to
the
fitness
of
the
drink
for
a
lady
in
her
condition
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
expenditure
that
he
would
not
willingly
incur
for
her
,
nothing
costly
that
he
would
grudge
.
<EOS>
But
when
she
asked
for
a
favour
,
he
was
always
afraid
of
an
imprudence
.
<EOS>
Very
possibly
she
might
want
to
drink
beer
in
an
open
garden
.
  
<EOS>
And
her
request
was
,
at
last
,
of
this
nature
:
"
<EOS>
I
want
you
to
take
me
up
to
the
gambling
-
rooms
!
"
<EOS>
said
she
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
gambling
-
rooms
!
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
in
dismay
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Plantagenet
;
the
gambling
-
rooms
.
<EOS>
If
you
had
been
with
me
before
,
I
should
not
have
made
a
fool
of
myself
by
putting
my
piece
of
money
on
the
table
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
see
the
place
;
but
then
I
saw
nothing
,
because
I
was
so
frightened
when
I
found
that
I
was
winning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
aware
that
all
the
world
of
Baden
,
 
or
rather
the
world
of
the
strangers
at
Baden
,
 
assembles
itself
in
those
salons
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
also
that
he
himself
was
curious
to
see
how
men
looked
when
they
lost
their
own
money
,
or
won
that
of
others
.
<EOS>
He
knew
how
a
Minister
looked
when
he
lost
or
gained
a
tax
.
<EOS>
He
was
familiar
with
millions
and
tens
of
millions
in
a
committee
of
the
whole
House
.
<EOS>
He
knew
the
excitement
of
a
near
division
upon
the
estimates
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
never
yet
seen
a
poor
man
stake
his
last
napoleon
,
and
rake
back
from
off
the
table
a
small
hatful
of
gold
.
<EOS>
A
little
exercise
after
an
early
dinner
was
,
he
had
been
told
,
good
for
his
wife
;
and
he
agreed
therefore
that
,
on
their
second
evening
at
Baden
,
they
would
all
walk
up
and
see
the
play
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
shall
get
back
my
napoleon
,
"
said
Glencora
to
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
perhaps
I
shall
be
forgiven
when
somebody
sees
how
difficult
it
is
to
manage
you
,
"
said
Alice
,
looking
at
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
n't
in
earnest
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
almost
fearing
the
result
of
the
experiment
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
They
started
together
,
Mr.
Palliser
with
his
wife
,
and
Mr.
Grey
with
Alice
on
his
arm
,
and
found
all
the
tables
at
work
.
<EOS>
They
at
first
walked
through
the
different
rooms
,
whispering
to
each
other
their
comments
on
the
people
that
they
saw
,
and
listening
to
the
quick
,
low
,

of
the
croupiers
as
they
arranged
and
presided
over
the
games
.
<EOS>
Each
table
was
closely
surrounded
by
its
own
crowd
,
made
up
of
players
,
embryo

,
and
simple
lookers
-
on
,
so
that
they
could
not
see
much
as
they
walked
.
<EOS>
But
this
was
not
enough
for
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
She
was
anxious
to
know
what
these
men
and
women
were
doing
,
 
to
see
whether
the
croupiers
wore
horns
on
their
heads
and
were
devils
indeed
,
 
to
behold
the
faces
of
those
who
were
wretched
and
of
those
who
were

,
 
to
know
how
the
thing
was
done
,
and
to
learn
something
of
that
lesson
in
life
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let
us
stand
here
a
moment
,
"
she
said
to
her
husband
,
arresting
him
at
one
corner
of
the
table
which
had
the
greatest
