.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
be
able
to
see
in
a
few
minutes
.
"
<EOS>
So
he
stood
with
her
there
,
giving
way
to
Alice
,
who
went
in
front
with
his
wife
;
and
in
a
minute
or
two
an
aperture
was
made
,
so
that
they
could
all
see
the
marked
cloth
,
and
the
money
lying
about
,
and
the
rakes
on
the
table
,
and
the
croupier
skilfully
dealing
his
cards
,
and
,
 
more
interesting
than
all
the
rest
,
the
faces
of
those
who
were
playing
.
<EOS>
Grey
looked
on
,
over
Alice
's
shoulder
,
very
attentively
,
 
as
did
Palliser
also
,
 
but
both
of
them
kept
their
eyes
upon
the
ministers
of
the
work
.
<EOS>
Alice
and
Glencora
did
the
same
at
first
,
but
as
they
gained
courage
they
glanced
round
upon
the
gamblers
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
long
table
,
having
,
of
course
,
four
corners
,
and
<EOS>
at
the
corner
appropriated
by
them
they
were
partly
opposite
to
the
man
who
dealt
the
cards
.
<EOS>
The
corner
answering
to
theirs
at
the
other
end
was
the
part
of
the
table
most
removed
from
their
sight
,
and
that
on
which
their
eyes
fell
last
.
<EOS>
As
Lady
Glencora
stood
she
could
hardly
see
,
 
indeed
,
at
first
she
could
not
see
,
 
one
or
two
who
were
congregated
at
this
spot
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
who
was
behind
her
,
could
not
see
them
at
all
.
<EOS>
But
to
Alice
,
 
and
to
Mr.
Grey
,
had
he
cared
about
it
,
 
every
face
at
the
table
was
visible
except
the
faces
of
those
who
were
immediately
close
to
them
.
<EOS>
Before
long
Alice
's
attention
was
riveted
on
the
action
and
countenance
of
one
young
man
who
sat
at
that
other
corner
.
<EOS>
He
was
leaning
,
at
first
listlessly
,
over
the
table
,
dressed
in
a
velveteen
jacket
,
and
with
his
round
-
topped
hat
brought
far
over
his
eyes
,
so
that
she
could
not
fully
see
his
face
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
hardly
begun
to
observe
him
before
he
threw
back
his
hat
,
and
taking
some
pieces
of
gold
from
under
his
left
hand
,
which
lay
upon
the
table
,
pushed
three
or
four
of
them
on
to
one
of
the
divisions
marked
on
the
cloth
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
show
no
care
,
as
others
did
,
as
to
the
special
spot
which
they
should
occupy
.
<EOS>
Many
were
very
particular
in
this
respect
,
placing
their
ventures
on
the
lines
,
so
as
to
share
the
fortunes
of
two
compartments
,
or
sometimes
of
four
;
or
they
divided
their
coins
,
taking
three
or
four
numbers
,
selecting
the
numbers
with
almost
grotesque
attention
to
some
imagined
rule
of
their
own
.
<EOS>
But
this
man
let
his
gold
go
all
together
,
and
left
it
where
his
half
-
stretched
rake
deposited
it
by
chance
.
<EOS>
Alice
could
not
but
look
at
his
face
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
she
could
see
were
bloodshot
,
and
his
hair
,
when
he
pushed
back
his
hat
,
was
rough
and
dishevelled
;
but
still
there
was
that
in
his
face
which
no
woman
could
see
and
not
regard
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
face
which
at
once
prepossessed
her
in
his
favour
,
 
as
it
had
always
prepossessed
all
others
.
<EOS>
On
this
occasion
he
had
won
his
money
,
and
Alice
saw
him
drag
it
in
as
lazily
as
he
had
pushed
it
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see
that
little
Frenchman
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
He
has
just
made
half
a
napoleon
,
and
has
walked
off
with
it
.
<EOS>
Is
n't
it
interesting
?
<EOS>
I
could
stay
here
all
the
night
.
<EOS>
"
Then
she
turned
round
to
whisper
something
to
her
husband
,
and
Alice
's
eyes
again
fell
on
the
face
of
the
man
at
the
other
end
of
the
table
.
<EOS>
After
he
had
won
his
money
,
he
had
allowed
the
game
to
go
on
for
a
turn
without
any
action
on
his
part
.
<EOS>
The
gold
again
went
under
his
hand
,
and
he
lounged
forward
with
his
hat
over
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
croupiers
had
said
a
word
,
as
though
calling
his
attention
to
the
game
,
but
he
had
merely
shaken
his
head
.
<EOS>
But
when
the
fate
of
the
next
turn
had
been
decided
,
he
again
roused
himself
,
and
on
this
occasion
,
as
far
as
Alice
could
see
,
pushed
his
whole
stock
forward
with
the
rake
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
mass
of
gold
,
and
,
from
his
manner
of
placing
it
,
all
might
see
that
he
left
its
position
to
chance
.
<EOS>
One
piece
had
got
beyond
its
boundary
,
and
the
croupier
pushed
it
back
with
some
half
-
expressed
inquiry
as
to
his
correctness
.
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
"
said
a
voice
in
English
.
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Glencora
started
and
clutched
Alice
's
arm
with
her
hand
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
was
explaining
to
Mr.
Grey
,
behind
them
,
something
about
German
finance
as
connected
with
gambling
-
tables
,
and
did
not
hear
the
voice
,
or
see
his
wife
's
motion
.
<EOS>
I
need
hardly
tell
the
reader
that
the
gambler
was
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
  
<EOS>
But
Lady
Glencora
said
not
a
word
,
 
not
as
yet
.
<EOS>
She
looked
forward
very
gently
,
but
still
with
eager
eyes
,
till
she
could
just
see
the
face
she
knew
so
well
.
<EOS>
His
hat
was
now
pushed
back
,
and
his
countenance
had
lost
its
listlessness
.
<EOS>
He
watched
narrowly
the
face
of
the
man
as
he
told
out
the
amount
of
the
cards
as
they
were
dealt
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
try
to
hide
his
anxiety
,
and
when
,
after
the
telling
of
some
six
or
seven
cards
,
he
heard
a
certain
number
named
,
and
a
certain
colour
called
,
he
made
some
exclamation
which
even
Glencora
could
not
hear
.
<EOS>
And
then
another
croupier
put
down
,
close
to
Burgo
's
money
,
certain
rolls
of
gold
done
up
in
paper
,
and
also
certain
loose
napoleons
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
does
n't
he
take
it
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
taking
it
,
"
said
Alice
,
not
at
all
knowing
the
cause
of
her
cousin
's
anxiety
.
  
<EOS>
Burgo
had
paused
a
moment
,
and
then
prepared
to
rake
the
money
to
him
;
but
as
he
did
so
,
he
changed
his
mind
,
and
pushed
it
all
back
again
,
 
now
,
on
this
occasion
,
being
very
careful
to
place
it
on
its
former
spot
.
<EOS>
Both
Alice
and
Glencora
could
see
that
a
man
at
his
elbow
was
dissuading
him
,
 
had
even
attempted
to
stop
the
arm
which
held
the
rake
.
<EOS>
But
Burgo
shook
him
off
,
speaking
to
him
some
word
roughly
,
and
then
again
he
steadied
the
rolls
upon
their
appointed
place
.
<EOS>
The
croupier
who
had
paused
for
a
moment
now
went
on
quickly
with
his
cards
,
and
in
two
minutes
the
fate
of
Burgo
's
wealth
was
decided
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
drawn
back
by
the
croupier
's
unimpassioned
rake
,
and
the
rolls
of
gold
were
restored
to
the
tray
from
whence
they
had
been
taken
.
  
<EOS>
Burgo
looked
up
and
smiled
at
them
all
round
the
table
.
<EOS>
By
this
time
most
of
those
who
stood
around
were
looking
at
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
who
gathered
eyes
upon
him
wherever
he
might
be
,
or
whatever
he
was
doing
;
and
it
had
been
clear
that
he
was
very
intent
upon
his
fortune
,
and
on
the
last
occasion
the
amount
staked
had
been
considerable
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
men
and
women
were
looking
at
him
,
and
therefore
he
smiled
faintly
as
he
turned
his
eyes
round
the
table
.
<EOS>
Then
he
got
up
,
and
,
putting
his
hands
in
his
trousers
pockets
,
whistled
as
he
walked
away
.
<EOS>
His
companion
followed
him
,
and
laid
a
hand
upon
his
shoulder
;
but
Burgo
shook
him
off
,
and
would
not
turn
round
.
<EOS>
He
shook
him
off
,
and
walked
on
whistling
,
the
length
of
the
whole
salon
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
"
it
is
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
gone
so
deep
into
that
question
of
German
finance
that
he
had
not
at
all
noticed
the
gambler
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
what
can
we
do
for
him
?
<EOS>
It
is
Burgo
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
Many
eyes
were
now
watching
him
.
<EOS>
Used
as
he
was
to
the
world
and
to
misfortune
,
he
was
not
successful
in
his
attempt
to
bear
his
loss
with
a
show
of
indifference
.
<EOS>
The
motion
of
his
head
,
the
position
of
his
hands
,
the
tone
of
his
whistling
,
all
told
the
tale
.
<EOS>
Even
the
unimpassioned
croupiers
furtively
cast
an
eye
after
him
,
and
a
very
big
Guard
,
in
a
cocked
hat
,
and
uniform
,
and
sword
,
who
hitherto
had
hardly
been
awake
,
seemed
evidently
to
be
interested
by
his
movements
.
<EOS>
If
there
is
to
be
a
tragedy
at
these
places
,
 
and
tragedies
will
sometimes
occur
,
 
it
is
always
as
well
that
the
tragic
scene
should
be
as
far
removed
as
possible
from
the
salons
,
in
order
that
the
public
eye
should
not
suffer
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
and
Alice
had
left
their
places
,
and
had
shrunk
back
,
almost
behind
a
pillar
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
it
he
,
in
truth
?
"
<EOS>
Alice
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
very
truth
,
"
said
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
do
?
<EOS>
Can
I
do
anything
?
<EOS>
Look
at
him
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
If
he
were
to
destroy
himself
,
what
should
I
do
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
Burgo
,
conscious
that
he
was
the
regarded
of
all
eyes
,
turned
round
upon
his
heel
and
again
walked
the
length
of
the
salon
.
<EOS>
He
knew
well
that
he
had
not
a
franc
left
in
his
possession
,
but
still
he
laughed
and
still
he
whistled
.
<EOS>
His
companion
,
whoever
he
might
be
,
had
slunk
away
from
him
,
not
caring
to
share
the
notoriety
which
now
attended
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
shall
I
do
,
Alice
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
,
with
her
eyes
still
fixed
on
him
who
had
been
her
lover
.
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
Mr.
Palliser
,
"
whispered
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
immediately
ran
up
to
her
husband
,
and
took
him
away
from
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
Rapidly
she
told
her
story
,
 
with
such
rapidity
that
Mr.
Palliser
could
hardly
get
in
a
word
.
"
<EOS>
Do
something
for
him
;
 
do
,
do
.
<EOS>
Unless
I
know
that
something
is
done
,
I
shall
die
.
<EOS>
You
need
n't
be
afraid
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
afraid
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
,
as
she
went
on
quickly
,
got
hold
of
her
husband
's
hand
,
and
caressed
it
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
so
good
,
"
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
let
him
out
of
your
sight
.
<EOS>
There
;
he
is
going
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
home
with
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
I
will
be
ever
so
good
;
I
will
,
indeed
.
<EOS>
You
know
what
he
'll
want
,
and
for
my
sake
you
'll
let
him
have
it
.
<EOS>
But
do
n't
let
him
gamble
.
<EOS>
If
you
could
only
get
him
home
to
England
,
and
then
do
something
.
<EOS>
You
owe
him
something
,
Plantagenet
;
do
you
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
money
can
do
anything
,
he
shall
have
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
God
bless
you
,
dearest
!
<EOS>
I
shall
never
see
him
again
;
but
if
you
could
save
him
!
<EOS>
There
;
 
he
is
going
now
.
<EOS>
Go
;
 
go
.
"
<EOS>
She
pushed
him
forward
,
and
then
retreating
,
put
her
arm
within
Mr.
Grey
's
,
still
keeping
her
eye
upon
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
Burgo
,
when
he
first
got
to
the
door
leading
out
of
the
salon
,
had
paused
a
moment
,
and
,
turning
round
,
had
encountered
the
big
gendarme
close
to
him
.
"
<EOS>
Well
,
old
Buffer
,
what
do
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
said
he
,
accosting
the
man
in
English
.
<EOS>
The
big
gendarme
simply
walked
on
through
the
door
,
and
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
Then
Burgo
also
passed
out
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
quickly
went
after
him
.
<EOS>
They
were
now
in
the
large
front
salon
,
from
whence
the
chief
door
of
the
building
opened
out
upon
the
steps
.
<EOS>
Through
this
door
Burgo
went
without
pausing
,
and
Mr.
Palliser
went
after
him
.
<EOS>
They
both
walked
to
the
end
of
the
row
of
buildings
,
and
then
Burgo
,
leaving
the
broad
way
,
turned
into
a
little
path
which
led
up
through
the
trees
to
the
hills
.
<EOS>
That
hillside
among
the
trees
is
a
popular
resort
at
Baden
,
during
the
day
;
but
now
,
at
nine
in
the
evening
,
it
was
deserted
.
<EOS>
Palliser
did
not
press
on
the
other
man
,
but
followed
him
,
and
did
not
accost
Burgo
till
he
had
thrown
himself
on
the
grass
beneath
a
tree
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
trouble
,
I
fear
,
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
as
soon
as
he
was
close
at
Burgo
's
feet
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
will
go
home
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
has
something
to
do
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
to
Mr.
Grey
,
as
soon
as
the
two
men
had
disappeared
from
her
sight
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
a
friend
of
Mr.
Palliser
?
"
said
Mr.
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
that
is
,
he
knows
him
,
and
is
interested
about
him
.
<EOS>
Alice
,
shall
we
go
home
?
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
,
you
must
not
ask
any
questions
.
<EOS>
He
,
 
Mr.
Palliser
,
will
tell
you
everything
when
he
sees
you
,
 
that
is
,
if
there
is
anything
to
be
told
.
"
Then
they
all
went
home
,
and
soon
separated
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
shall
sit
up
for
him
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
to
Alice
,
"
but
I
will
do
it
in
my
own
room
.
<EOS>
You
can
tell
Mr.
Grey
,
if
you
like
.
"
<EOS>
But
Alice
told
nothing
to
Mr.
Grey
,
nor
did
Mr.
Grey
ask
any
questions
.
   
<EOS>
The
Landlord
's
Bill
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
trouble
,
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
I
fear
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
standing
over
Burgo
as
he
lay
upon
the
ground
.
<EOS>
They
were
now
altogether
beyond
the
gas
-
lights
,
and
the
evening
was
dark
.
<EOS>
Burgo
,
too
,
was
lying
with
his
face
to
the
ground
,
expecting
that
the
footsteps
which
he
had
heard
would
pass
by
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
that
?
"
<EOS>
said
he
,
turning
round
suddenly
;
but
still
he
was
not
at
once
able
to
recognize
Mr.
Palliser
,
whose
voice
was
hardly
known
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
have
been
wrong
in
following
you
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
thought
you
were
in
distress
,
and
that
probably
I
might
help
you
.
<EOS>
My
name
is
Palliser
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Plantagenet
Palliser
?
"
said
Burgo
,
jumping
up
on
to
his
legs
and
looking
close
into
the
other
's
face
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
By
heavens
!
<EOS>
it
is
Plantagenet
Palliser
!
<EOS>
Well
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
what
do
you
want
of
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
be
of
some
use
to
you
,
if
I
can
.
<EOS>
I
and
my
wife
saw
you
leave
the
gaming
-
table
just
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
she
here
too
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
she
is
here
.
<EOS>
We
are
going
home
,
but
chance
brought
us
up
to
the
salon
.
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
think
that
you
are
in
distress
,
and
that
I
could
help
you
.
<EOS>
I
will
,
if
you
will
let
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
during
the
whole
interview
,
felt
that
he
could
afford
to
be
generous
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
had
no
further
cause
for
fear
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
lingering
dread
of
this
poor
creature
who
stood
before
him
.
<EOS>
All
that
feeling
was
over
,
though
it
was
as
yet
hardly
four
months
since
he
had
been
sent
back
by
Mrs.
Marsham
to
Lady
Monk
's
house
to
save
his
wife
,
if
saving
her
were
yet
possible
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
she
is
here
,
is
she
;
 
and
saw
me
there
when
I
staked
my
last
chance
?
<EOS>
I
should
have
had
over
twenty
thousand
francs
now
,
if
the
cards
had
stood
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
cards
never
do
stand
to
any
one
,
Mr.
Fitzgerald
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never
;
 
never
,
 
never
!
"
said
Burgo
.
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
they
never
did
to
me
.
<EOS>
Nothing
ever
does
stand
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
want
twenty
thousand
francs
,
 
that
's
eight
hundred
pounds
,
I
think
 
I
can
let
you
have
it
without
any
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
devil
you
can
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
.
<EOS>
As
I
am
travelling
with
my
family
 
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
whether
Mr.
Palliser
considered
himself
to
be
better
entitled
to
talk
of
his
family
than
he
had
been
some
three
or
four
weeks
back
 
<EOS>
"
As
I
am
travelling
with
my
family
,
I
have
been
obliged
to
carry
large
bills
with
me
,
and
I
can
accommodate
you
without
any
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
pleasant
in
this
,
which
made
Burgo
Fitzgerald
laugh
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
the
husband
of
Lady
Glencora
M'Cluskie
,
and
the
heir
of
the
Duke
of
Omnium
happening
to
have
money
with
him
!
<EOS>
As
if
Mr.
Palliser
could
not
bring
down
showers
of
money
in
any
quarter
of
the
globe
by
simply
holding
up
his
hand
.
<EOS>
And
then
to
talk
of
accommodating
him
,
 
Burgo
Fitzgerald
,
as
though
it
were
simply
a
little
matter
of
convenience
,
 
as
though
Mr.
Palliser
would
of
course
find
the
money
at
his
bankers
"
when
he
next
examined
his
book
!
<EOS>
Burgo
could
not
but
laugh
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
not
in
the
least
doubting
your
ability
to
raise
the
money
,
"
said
he
;
"
but
how
would
you
propose
to
get
it
back
again
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
would
be
at
your
convenience
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
who
hardly
knew
how
to
put
himself
on
a
proper
footing
with
his
companion
,
so
that
he
might
offer
to
do
something
effectual
for
the
man
's
aid
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
have
any
such
convenience
,
"
said
Burgo
.
<EOS>
"
Who
were
those
women
whose
tubs
always
had
holes
at
the
bottom
of
them
?
<EOS>
My
tub
always
has
such
a
hole
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
the
daughters
of
Danaus
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
whose
daughters
they
were
,
but
you
might
just
as
well
lend
them
all
eight
hundred
pounds
apiece
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
were
so
many
of
them
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
trying
a
little
joke
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
as
you
are
only
one
I
shall
be
most
happy
,
as
I
said
before
,
to
be
of
service
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
now
walking
slowly
together
up
towards
the
hills
,
and
near
to
them
they
heard
a
step
.
<EOS>
Upon
this
,
Burgo
turned
round
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
see
that
fellow
?
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
who
was
somewhat
short
-
sighted
,
said
that
he
did
not
see
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
though
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
his
name
,
but
they
have
sent
him
out
from
the
hotel
with
me
,
to
see
what
I
do
with
myself
.
<EOS>
I
owe
them
six
or
seven
hundred
francs
,
and
they
want
to
turn
me
out
of
the
house
and
not
let
me
take
my
things
with
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
would
be
very
uncomfortable
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
uncomfortable
,
but
I
shall
be
too
many
for
them
.
<EOS>
If
they
keep
my
traps
they
shall
keep
me
.
<EOS>
They
think
I
'm
going
to
blow
my
brains
out
.
<EOS>
That
's
what
they
think
.
<EOS>
The
man
lets
me
go
far
enough
off
to
do
that
,
 
so
long
as
it
's
nowhere
about
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
're
not
thinking
of
such
a
thing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
long
as
I
can
help
it
,
Mr.
Palliser
,
I
never
think
of
anything
.
"
<EOS>
The
stranger
was
now
standing
near
to
them
,
 
almost
so
near
that
he
might
hear
their
words
.
<EOS>
Burgo
,
perceiving
this
,
walked
up
to
him
,
and
,
speaking
in
bad
French
,
desired
him
to
leave
them
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
see
that
I
have
a
friend
with
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
a
friend
,
"
said
the
man
,
answering
in
bad
English
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
de
friend
can
advance
moneys
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
what
he
can
do
,
"
said
Burgo
.
<EOS>
"
You
do
as
you
are
bid
,
and
leave
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
the
gentleman
from
the
hotel
retreated
down
the
hill
,
but
Mr.
Palliser
,
during
the
rest
of
the
interview
,
frequently
fancied
that
he
heard
the
man
's
footfall
at
no
great
distance
.
  
<EOS>
They
continued
to
walk
on
up
the
hill
very
slowly
,
and
it
was
some
time
before
Mr.
Palliser
knew
how
to
repeat
his
offer
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
Lady
Glencora
is
here
?
"
<EOS>
Burgo
said
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
she
is
here
.
<EOS>
It

she
who

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

!

.

Lady

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
He

,
 
who

not

his

"

;
but

are

.
<EOS>
His

who

up

.
"
<EOS>
Has

?
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Breakfast
!
<EOS>
Oh

;
"
and

landlord

.
<EOS>
He
had
been
very

in

had

.
<EOS>
He
had

his

to
be

,
 
with

pepper
,
and

.
<EOS>
He

;
but

,
or

-

,
that

of

.
<EOS>
The

of
ordinary
wine
of
the
country
had
just
that

been
sent
up
-
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
Then

,

's

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
What

Palliser
to

?
<EOS>
He

,
in

world

,

,

ought

;

.
<EOS>
Then

.
<EOS>
He

wife
without

something
;
so
,

,

.
<EOS>
The

's

,

most

.
  
<EOS>
"
Should

?
"
 
<EOS>
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
to

be

?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
thought
that
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
there
is
some

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser

difficulty
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
must
do
something
more
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
simply
pay
the
bill
and
go
away
.
<EOS>
That
would
not
satisfy
his
wife
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
he
must
do
something
more
;
but
how
was
he
to
do
it
?
<EOS>
So
at
last
he
let
the
landlord
into
his
confidence
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
tell
the
whole
of
Burgo
's
past

.
<EOS>
He
did
not
tell
that
little

in
Burgo
's
life
which
referred
to
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
make

landlord

that
he
was

to
administer
money
to
Mr.
Fitzgerald
,
if

only

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
keep
him
out
of
the
gambling
salon
,
you
know
,
sir
;
that
is
,
not
if

in

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
to
that

very

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
at
last
arranged
,
that
the

was
to

that
his
bill
did
not

present
,
and
that
the

's

.
<EOS>
At
the

he
was
to
have
notice
to

.
<EOS>
No
money
was
to

advanced
to

;
 
but
the
landlord
,
even

,
had
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
get
home
,
I

there
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
<EOS>
Then
he
went
home
and
told

wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
'll
have
no
clothes
,
"
said
Lady

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
said
that
the
judicious
landlord
would
manage
that
also
;
and
in
that
way
Lady
Glencora
was
appeased
,
 
appeased
,
till
something
final
could
be
done
for
the
young
man
,
on
Mr.
Palliser
's
return
home
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Burgo
!
<EOS>
He
must
now
be
made
to
end
his
career
as
far
as
these
pages
are
concerned
.
<EOS>
He
soon
found
that
something
had
been
done
for
him
at
the
hotel
,
and
no
doubt
he
must
have
made
some
guess
near
the
truth
.
<EOS>
The
discreet
landlord
told
him
nothing
,
 
would
tell
him
nothing
;
but
that
his
bill
did
not
signify
as
yet
.
<EOS>
Burgo
,
thinking
about
it
,
resolved
to
write
about
it
in
an
indignant
strain
to
Mr.
Palliser
;
but
the

did
not

itself

.
<EOS>
When
in
England
,
Mr.
Palliser
saw
Sir

,
and
with

,

done
.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

,
in

.
<EOS>
"
I
regret

;
not
for
the
money
's

,
but
I
regret

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
amount
expended
,

to

Palliser
,

for

to

,
through
a

,
as

at
a

which
was

,
and

.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
expressed

for

;
but
I
must
doubt

poor
Burgo
lived
long
in
comfort
on
the

.
  
<EOS>
Here
we
must
say
farewell
to
Burgo
Fitzgerald
.
   
<EOS>
The
Travellers
Return
Home
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
did
not
remain
long
in
Baden
after
the
payment
of
Burgo
's
bill
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
I
shall
not
throw
any
undeserved
discredit
on
his
courage
if
I
say
that
he
was
afraid
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
What
would
he
have
said
,
 
what
would
he
have
been
able
to
say
,
if
that
young
man
had
come
to
him
demanding

?
<EOS>
So
he
hurried
away
to
Strasbourg
the
same
day
,
much
to
his
wife
's
satisfaction
.
  
<EOS>
The
journey
home
from
thence
was
not
marked
by
any
incidents
.
<EOS>
Gradually
Mr.
Palliser
became
a
little
more
lenient
to
his
wife
and
slightly
less

in
his

.
<EOS>
If
he
still
inquired
about
the
springs
of
the
carriages
,
he
did
so
in
silence
,
and
he
ceased
to
enjoin
the
necessity
of
a
day
's
rest
after
each
day
's

.
<EOS>
By
the
time
that
they
reached
Dover
he
had
become
so
used
to
his
wife
's
condition
that
he
made
but
<EOS>
little
fluttering
as
she
walked
out
of
the
boat
by
that
narrow

which
is
so
contrived
as
to
make
an
arrival
there
a
serious

to
a

,
and
a

even

man
.
<EOS>
He
was
somewhat
staggered
when
a
big
man
,
in
the
middle

the
night
,
insisted
on
opening
the
little

which
his
wife

,
and
was
uncomfortable
when

to

on

while
he

which
he
thought
had
been
already
surrendered
;
but
he
was
becoming
used
to
his
position
,
and
bore
himself
like
a
man
.
  
<EOS>
During
their
journey
home
Mr.
Palliser
had
by
no
means
kept
his
seat
opposite
to
Lady
Glencora
with

.
<EOS>
He
had
soon
found
that
it

Mr.
Grey

wife
,
and
,

,
the
two
ladies
had
been
much
together
,
as

two
gentlemen
.
<EOS>
What
the
ladies
discussed
may
be
imagined
.
<EOS>
One
was
about
to
become
a
wife
and
the
other
a
mother
,
and
that
was
to
be
their
fate
after

had

.
<EOS>
It
may
,
however
,

that
for
every
one

that
Alice

Lady
Glencora
spoke
ten
.
<EOS>
The
two
men
,
throughout
these
days
of
close
intimacy
,
were
intent
upon
politics
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
,
who
may
be
regarded
as
the
fox
who
had
lost
his
tail
,
 
the
tail
being
,
in
this

,
the
comfort
of
domestic

,
 
was
eager
in
recommending
his
new
friend
to
cut
off
his
tail
also
.
"
<EOS>
Your
argument
would
be
very
well
,
"
said
he
,
"
if
men
were
to
be
contented
to
live
for
themselves
only
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
argument
would
be
very
well
,
"
said
the
other
,
"
if
it
were
used
to
a
man
who
felt
that
he
could
do
good
to
others
by
going
into
public

.
<EOS>
But

is
wholly

if
it
recommends
public
life
simply
or
chiefly
because
a
man
may
gratify

own

by

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
there
is
personal
gratification
,
and
of
course
there
is
good
done
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
,
 
or
should
be
,
"
said
Mr.
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Exactly
;
and
the
two
things
must
go
together
.
<EOS>
The
chief
gratification
comes
from
the
feeling
that
you
are
of
use
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
if
you
feel
that
you
would
not
be
of
use
?
"
  
We
need
not
follow
the
argument
any
further
.
<EOS>
We
all
know
its
nature
,
and
what
between
two
such
men
would
be
said
on

.
<EOS>
We
all
know
that
neither
of
them
would
put
the

altogether
in

.
<EOS>
Men
never
can
do
so
in
words
,
let
the
light
within
themselves
be
ever
so
clear
.
<EOS>
I
do
not
think
that
any
man
yet
ever
had
such

words
as
to
make

a

of
all

within

.
<EOS>
But
the
effect
was
partly
that
which
the
weaker
man
of
the
two
desired
,
 
the
weaker
in
the
gifts
of
nature
,
though
art
had
in
some

made
him

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grey
was
shaken
in
his
quiescent
philosophy
,
and
startled
Alice
,
 
startled
her
as
much
as
he
delighted
her
,
 
by
a
word
or
two
<EOS>
he
said
as
he
walked
with

in
the

of

Louvre
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
hollow
here
,
"
he
said
,
speaking
of
French
politics
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
hollow
,
"
said
Alice
,
who
had
no
love
for
the
French
mode
of
carrying
on
public

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
all
modes
of
governing
this
seems
to
me
to
be
the
surest
of
coming
to
a
downfall
.
<EOS>
Men
are
told
that
they
are
wise
enough
to
talk
,
but
not
wise
enough
to
have
any
power
of
action
.
<EOS>
It
is
as
though
men
were
cautioned
that
they
were
walking
through
gunpowder
,
and
that
no
fire
could
be
allowed
them
,
but
were
at
the

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
believe
in
the
gunpowder
,
and
I
think
there
should
be
fire
,
and
plenty
of
it
;
but
if
I
did
n't
want
the
fire
I
would
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
so
odd
to

talk
politics
,
"
said
Alice
,

.
  
<EOS>
After

,
as

,
but

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
wants
me
to
go
into
Parliament
.
"
<EOS>
Upon
hearing

Alice
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
She
was
afraid
to
speak
.
<EOS>
After
all
that
had
passed
she
felt
that
it
would
not
become

to
show
much
outward
joy
on

such

,
so
spoken
by
him
,
and
yet
she
could
say
nothing
without
some

of

in

.
<EOS>
So
she
walked
on
without
speaking
,
and
was
conscious
that
her
fingers
trembled
on
his
arm
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
about
it
?
"
<EOS>
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
I
say
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
John
,
what
right
can
I
have
to
say
anything
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
one
else
can
have
so
much
right
,
 
putting
aside
of
course
myself
,
who
must
be
responsible
for
my
own

.
<EOS>
He
asked
me
whether
I
could
afford
it
,
and
he
seems
to
think
that
a
smaller
income
suffices
for
such

now

.
<EOS>
I

that
I
could

,

that
was
not

expensive
at
the

.
<EOS>
He
could
help
me
there
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
On
that
point
,
of
course
,
I
can
have
no
opinion
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
;
not
on
that
point
.
<EOS>
I
believe
we
may
take
that
for

.
<EOS>
Living
in
London
for
four
or
five
months
in
the
year
might
be
managed
.
<EOS>
But
as
to
the
mode
of
life
!
"
  
Then
Alice
was
unable
to
hold
her
tongue
longer
,
and
spoke
out
her
thoughts
with
more
vehemence
than
discretion
.
<EOS>
No
doubt
he
combated
them
with
some
amount

opposition
.
<EOS>
He
seldom
allowed
out
-
spoken

to
pass
by
him
without
some
amount

.
<EOS>
But
he
was
not
so
perverse
as
to

from
his
new

by
the

that
Alice
approved
them
,
and
<EOS>
she
,

,
was
able

think

was
in

of
being

.
  
<EOS>
When

London
they
all
separated
.
<EOS>
It
was
Mr.
Palliser
's
purpose
to
take
his
wife
down

Matching
with
as

as

.
<EOS>
London
was
at
this

nearly
empty
,
and
all
the
doings
of
the
season
were
over
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
the
first

of
August
,
and
as
Parliament
had
not
been
sitting
for
nearly
two
months
,
the
town
looked
as
it
usually
looks
in
September
.
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
was
to
stay
but
one
day
in
Park
Lane
,
and
it
had
been
understood
between
her
and
Alice
that
they
were
not
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
odd
it
is
parting
in
this
way
,
when
people
have
been
together
so
long
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
It
always
seems
as
though
there
had
been
a
separate
little
life
of
its
own
which
was
now
to
be

.
<EOS>
I

,
Mr.
Grey
,
you

I
,
when
we
next

,
will
be
far
too
distant
to
fight
with

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope

may
never
be
the

,
"
said
Mr.
Grey
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
nothing
would
prevent
his

;
would
it
Alice
?
<EOS>
But
,

,
there
must
be
no

when

,
and
that

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
With
all

heart
,
"
said
Mr.
Grey
.
<EOS>
But

said
nothing
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Palliser
made
his
little

.
<EOS>
"
Alice
,
"
he
said
,
as

Vavasor
,
"
give

,

Matching
for
the

,
and

I

to

.
<EOS>
You
may
tell
him

that
he
will
have
to
stay
to

you
off
,
but
that
he
will
not

allowed

.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Glencora
thought
that
this
was
very
pretty
as
coming

her

,
and
so

told

on

.
  
<EOS>
Alice
insisted
on
going
to
Queen
Anne
Street
in
a

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Palliser
had
offered
a
carriage
,
and
Mr.
Grey
,
of
course
,
offered
himself
as
a

;
but
she

have
neither
the
one
nor

.
<EOS>
If
he
had
gone

,

's

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

Castle

DEAR

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
They

<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
   
<EOS>
Diamonds

.

of

Grey

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

why
are
you
to
have
everything
just
as
you
like
it
?
<EOS>
You
are
so
unreasonable
.
<EOS>
Think
how
I
've
been
jumped
on
!
<EOS>
Think
what
I
have
borne
from
them
!
<EOS>
If
you
knew
the
things
she
used
to
say
to
me
,
you
would
not
be
such
a
coward
.
<EOS>
I
was
sent
down
to
her
for
a
week
,
and
had
no
power
of
helping
myself
.
<EOS>
And
the
Marchioness
used
to
be
sent
for
to
look
at
me
,
for
she
never
talks
.
<EOS>
She
used
to
look
at
me
,
and
groan
,
and
hold
up
her
hands
till
I
hated
her
the
worst
of
the
two
.
<EOS>
Think
what
they
did
to
me
,
and
yet
they
are
my
dear
friends
now
.
<EOS>
Why
should
you
escape
altogether
?
"
  
<EOS>
Alice
could
not
escape
altogether
,
and
therefore
was
closeted
with
Lady
Midlothian
for
the
best
part
of
an
hour
.
"
<EOS>
Did
Lady
Macleod
read
to
you
what
I
wrote
?
<EOS>
"
the
Countess
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
 
that
is
,
she
gave
me
the
letter
to
read
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
hope
you
understand
me
,
Alice
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
I
suppose
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
suppose
so
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
If
you
only
suppose
so
I
shall
not
be
contented
.
<EOS>
I
want
you
to
appreciate
my
feelings
towards
you
thoroughly
.
<EOS>
I
want
you
to
know
that
I
am
most
anxious
as
to
your
future
life
,
and
that
I
am
thoroughly
satisfied
with
the
step
you
are
now
taking
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Countess
paused
,
but
Alice
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
Her
tongue
was
itching
to
tell
the
old
woman
that
she
cared
nothing
for
this
expression
of
satisfaction
;
but
she
was
aware
that
she
had
done
much
that
was
deserving
of
punishment
,
and
resolved
to
take
this
as
part
of
her
penance
.
<EOS>
She
was
being
jumped
upon
,
and
it
was
unpleasant
;
but
,
after
all
that
had
happened
,
it
was
only
fitting
that
she
should
undergo
much
unpleasantness
.
"
<EOS>
Thoroughly
satisfied
,
"
continued
the
Countess
;
"
and
now
,
I
only
wish
to
refer
,
in
the
slightest
manner
possible
,
to
what
took
place
between
us
when
we
were
both
of
us
under
this
roof
last
winter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
refer
to
it
at
all
,
Lady
Midlothian
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
think
it
may
do
good
,
and
because
I
can
not
make
you
understand
that
I
have
thoroughly
forgiven
everything
,
unless
I
tell
you
that
I
have
forgiven
that
also
.
<EOS>
On
that
occasion
I
had
come
all
the
way
from
Scotland
on
purpose
to
say
a
few
words
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
sorry
that
you
should
have
had
the
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
regret
it
,
Alice
.
<EOS>
I
never
do
regret
doing
anything
which
I
believe
to
have
been
my
duty
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
knowing
how
far
what
I
said
then
may
have
operated
for
good
.
"
<EOS>
Alice
thought
that
she
knew
very
well
,
but
she
said
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
I
must
confess
that
what
I
then
understood
to
be
your
obstinacy
,
 
and
<EOS>
I
must
say
also
,
if
I
tell
the
truth
,
your
indifference
to
 
to
 
to
all
prudential
considerations
whatever
,
not
to
talk
of
appearances
and
decorum
,
and
I
might
say
,
anything
like
a
high
line
of
duty
or
moral
conduct
,
 
shocked
me
very
much
.
<EOS>
It
did
,
indeed
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
Taking
it
altogether
,
I
do
n't
know
that
I
was
ever
more
shocked
in
my
life
.
<EOS>
The
thing
was
so
inscrutable
!
"
<EOS>
Here
Lady
Midlothian
held
up
one
hand
in
a
manner
that
was
truly
imposing
;
"
so
inscrutable
!
<EOS>
But
that
is
all
over
now
.
<EOS>
What
was
personally
offensive
to
myself
I
could
easily
forgive
,
and
I
do
forgive
it
.
<EOS>
I
shall
never
think
of
it
any
more
.
"
<EOS>
Here
Lady
Midlothian
put
up
both
her
hands
gently
,
as
though
wafting
the
injury
away
into
the
air
.
<EOS>
"
But
what
I
wish
specially
to
say
to
you
is
this
;
your
own
conduct
is
forgiven
also
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Here
she
paused
again
,
and
Alice
winced
.
<EOS>
Who
was
this
dreadful
old
Countess
;
 
what
was
the
Countess
to
her
,
that
she
should
be
thus
tormented
with
the
old
woman
's
forgiveness
?
<EOS>
John
Grey
had
forgiven
her
,
and
of
external
forgiveness
that
was
enough
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
forgiven
herself
,
 
would
never
forgive
herself
altogether
;
and
the
pardon
of
no
old
woman
in
England
could
assist
her
in
doing
so
.
<EOS>
She
had
sinned
,
but
she
had
not
sinned
against
Lady
Midlothian
.
<EOS>
"
Let
her
jump
upon
you
,
and
have
done
with
it
,
"
Lady
Glencora
had
said
.
<EOS>
She
had
resolved
that
it
should
be
so
,
but
it
was
very
hard
to
keep
her
resolution
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
Marchioness
and
I
have
talked
it
over
,
"
continued
Lady
Midlothian
,
"
and
she
has
asked
me
to
speak
for
both
her
and
myself
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
comfort
at
any
rate
in
that
,
thought
Alice
,
who
had
never
yet
seen
the
Marchioness
.
<EOS>
"
We
have
resolved
that
all
those
little
mistakes
should
be
as
though
they
had
never
been
committed
.
<EOS>
We
shall
both
be
most
happy
to
receive
you
and
your
husband
,
who
is
,
I
must
say
,
one
of
the
most
gentlemanlike
looking
men
I
ever
saw
.
<EOS>
It
seems
that
he
and
Mr.
Palliser
are
on
most
friendly
,
 
I
may
say
,
most
confidential
terms
,
and
that
must
be
quite
a
pleasure
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
pleasure
to
him
,
which
is
more
to
the
purpose
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Exactly
so
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
my
dear
,
everything
is
forgiven
and
shall
be
forgotten
.
<EOS>
Come
and
give
me
a
kiss
,
and
let
me
wish
you
joy
.
<EOS>
"
Alice
did
as
she
was
bidden
,
and
accepted
the
kiss
and
the
congratulations
,
and
a
little
box
of
jewellery
which
Lady
Midlothian
produced
from
out
of
her
pocket
.
"
The
diamonds
are
from
the
Marchioness
,
my
dear
,
whose
means
,
as
you
doubtless
are
aware
,
greatly
exceed
my
own
.
<EOS>
The
garnets
are
from
me
.
<EOS>
I
hope
they
may
both
be
worn
long
and
happily
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
I
hardly
know
which
was
the
worst
,
the
lecture
,
the
kiss
,
or
the
present
.
<EOS>
The
latter
she
would
have
declined
,
had
it
been
possible
;
but
it
was
not
possible
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
agreed
to
be
married
at
Matching
she
had
not
calculated
the
amount
of
punishment
which
would
thereby
be
inflicted
on
her
.
<EOS>
But
I
think
that
,
though
she
bore
it
impatiently
,
she
was
aware
that
she
had
deserved
it
.
<EOS>
Although
she
fretted
herself
greatly
under
the
infliction
of
Lady
Midlothian
,
she
acknowledged
to
herself
,
even
at
the
time
,
that
she
deserved
all
the
lashes
she
received
.
<EOS>
She
had
made
a
fool
of
herself
in
her
vain
attempt
to
be
greater
and
grander
than
other
girls
,
and
it
was
only
fair
that
her
folly
should
be
in
some
sort
punished
before
it
was
fully
pardoned
.
<EOS>
John
Grey
punished
it
after
one
fashion
;
by
declining
to
allude
to
it
,
or
to
think
of
it
,
or
to
take
any
account
of
it
.
<EOS>
And
now
Lady
Midlothian
had
punished
it
after
another
fashion
,
and
Alice
went
out
of
the
Countess
's
presence
with
sundry
inward
exclamations
of
"
mea
culpa
,
"
and
with
many
unseen
beatings
of
the
breast
.
  
<EOS>
Two
days
before
the
ceremony
came
the
Marchioness
and
her
august
daughter
.
<EOS>
Her
Lady
Jane
was
much
more
august
than
the
other
Lady
Jane
;
 
very
much
more
august
indeed
.
<EOS>
She
had
very
long
flaxen
hair
,
and
very
light
blue
eyes
,
which
she
did
not
move
frequently
,
and
she
spoke
very
little
,
 
one
may
almost
say
not
at
all
,
and
she
never
seemed
to
do
anything
.
<EOS>
But
she
was
very
august
,
and
was
,
as
all
the
world
knew
,
engaged
to
marry
the
Duke
of
Dumfriesshire
,
who
,
though
twice
her
own
age
,
was
as
yet
childless
,
as
soon
as
he
should
have
completed
his
mourning
for
his
first
wife
.
<EOS>
Kate
told
her
cousin
that
she
did
not
at
all
know
how
she
should
ever
stand
up
as
one
in
a
group
with
so
august
a
person
as
this
Lady
Jane
,
and
Alice
herself
felt
that
such
an
attendant
would
quite
obliterate
her
.
<EOS>
But
Lady
Jane
and
her
mother
were
both
harmless
.
<EOS>
The
Marchioness
never
spoke
to
Kate
and
hardly
spoke
to
Alice
,
and
the
Marchioness
's
Lady
Jane
was
quite
as
silent
as
her
mother
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
morning
of
this
day
,
 
the
day
on
which
these
very
august
people
came
,
 
a
telegram
arrived
at
the
Priory
calling
for
Mr.
Palliser
's
immediate
presence
in
London
.
<EOS>
He
came
to
Alice
full
of
regret
,
and
behaved
himself
very
nicely
.
<EOS>
Alice
now
regarded
him
quite
as
a
friend
.
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
understand
,
"
she
said
,
"
and
I
know
that
the
business
which
takes
you
up
to
London
pleases
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
Well
;
yes
;
 
it
does
please
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
glad
,
 
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mind
saying
so
to
you
.
<EOS>
But
it
does
not
please
me
to
think
that
I
shall
be
away
at
your
marriage
.
<EOS>
Pray
make
your
father
understand
that
it
was
absolutely
unavoidable
.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
see
him
,
of
course
,
when
I
come
back
.
<EOS>
And
I
shall
see
you
too
before
very
long
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
why
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Because
Mr.
Grey
must
be
at
Silverbridge
for
his
election
.
 
<EOS>
But
perhaps
I
ought
not
tell
you
his
secrets
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
he
took
her
into
the
breakfast
-
parlour
and
showed
her
his
present
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
service
of
Sèvres
china
,
 
very
precious
and
beautiful
.
<EOS>
"
I
got
you
these
things
because
Grey
likes
china
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
do
I
like
china
,
"
said
she
,
with
her
face
brighter
than
he
had
ever
yet
seen
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
would
like
them
best
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
Alice
looking
up
at
him
with
her
eyes
full
of
tears
told
him
that
she
did
like
them
best
;
and
then
,
as
he
wished
her
all
happiness
,
and
as
he
was
stooping
over
her
to
kiss
her
,
Lady
Glencora
came
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
pardon
,
"
said
she
,
"
<EOS>
I
was
just
one
minute
too
soon
;
was
I
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
would
have
them
sent
here
and
unpacked
,
"
said
Mr.
Palliser
,
"
though
I
told
her
it
was
foolish
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
would
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
Everything
shall
be
unpacked
and
shown
.
<EOS>
It
's
easy
to
get
somebody
to
pack
them
again
.
"
  
<EOS>
Much
of
the
wedding
tribute
had
already
been
deposited
with
the
china
,
and
among
other
things
there
were
the
jewels
that
Lady
Midlothian
had
brought
.
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
her
ladyship
's
diamonds
are
not
to
be
sneezed
at
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
for
diamonds
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Lady
Glencora
took
up
the
Countess
's
trinkets
,
and
shook
her
head
and
turned
up
her
nose
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
wonderfully
comic
expression
on
her
face
as
she
did
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
me
they
are
just
as
good
as
the
others
,
"
said
Alice
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
me
they
are
not
,
then
,
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
<EOS>
"
Diamonds
are
diamonds
,
and
garnets
are
garnets
;
and
I
am
not
so
romantic
<EOS>
but
what
I
know
the
difference
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
On
the
evening
before
the
marriage
Alice
and
Lady
Glencora
walked
for
the
last
time
through
the
Priory
ruins
.
<EOS>
It
was
now
September
,
and
the
evenings
were
still
long
,
so
that
the
ladies
could
get
out
upon
the
lawn
after
dinner
.
<EOS>
Whether
Lady
Glencora
would
have
been
allowed
to
walk
through
the
ruins
so
late
as
half
-
past
eight
in
the
evening
if
her
husband
had
been
there
may
be
doubtful
,
but
her
husband
was
away
and
she
took
this
advantage
of
his
absence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember
that
night
we
were
here
?
"
said
Lady
Glencora
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
shall
I
forget
it
;
or
how
is
it
possible
that
such
a
night
should
ever
be
forgotten
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
shall
never
forget
it
.
<EOS>
Oh
dear
,
what
wonderful
things
have
happened
since
that
!
<EOS>
Do
you
ever
think
of
Jeffrey
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
 
of
course
I
think
of
him
.
<EOS>
I
did
like
him
so
much
.
<EOS>
I
hope
I
shall
see
him
some
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
before

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Come
,

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
One

<EOS>

they

because

are
not

my

up

.
"
  
<EOS>
On

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
